478
1
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Acanthophysellum lividocoeruleum  (P. Karst.) Parmasto^  Eesti NSV Tead. Akad. Toim., Biol. seer 16(4): 377. 1967;  Acanthophysium lividocoeruleum  (P. Karst.) Boidin;  == Corticium lividocoeruleum  P. Karst.;  Aleurodiscus lividocoeruleus  (P. Karst.) P.A. Lemke;  Gloeocystidiellum lividocoeruleum  (P. Karst.) Donk
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dry barkless conifer wood, 2) fruitbodies that are dark blue to grayish blue, 3) elliptic to subcylindric spores that are smooth and amyloid, 4) a catahymenium composed of a) basidial elements, b) embedded pseudocystidia that darken in sulphobenzaldehyde, and c) numerous to scattered acanthophyses with apical projections, and 5) context that is monomitic with clamp connections.^ | 'lividocaeruleum' is considered a more correct Latin spelling than 'lividocoeruleum'. RANGE ^It has been recorded from BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, YT, AK, AZ, CO, FL, GA, IA, IN, MD, MI, MN, MS, MT, NC, NH, NM, NY, UT, VT, and WI, (Ginns), and Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson). Collections were examined from BC, WA, ID, MB, ON, and Sweden, (Lemke).
FRUITING BODY  corticioid, effused, dense, firm, adnate [tightly attached], when older somewhat loosened; "dark blue to greyish blue, often somewhat more pale when dry or even yellowish with a bluish tinge or a few scattered bluish patches", often weakly pigmented when young; smooth; margin not differentiated^, (Eriksson), "corticioid, in linear to irregularly effused patches" up to 10cm long and 3cm wide, 0.01-0.023cm thick, "texture inconspicuous-pruinose to adnate-subceraceous or submembranous", hymenium "variously colored, often partially pallid to livid, finally partially to completely plumbeous to bluish-black"; surface continuous [without cracks]; margins adnate [tightly attached] and determinate [distinct], (Lemke)
HABITAT  on wood of conifers and hardwoods: primarily on dry decorticated wood, conifer test flooring, utility poles, associated with a white rot^, (Ginns), principally on dry decorticated coniferous wood, (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 7.5 x 3 um, subcylindric, smooth, amyloid^, BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 5 um; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA numerous, 40-70 x 8-12 um, often moniliform apically, contents granular; ACANTHOPHYSES numerous, 15-25 x 4-5 um with short apical protuberances; HYPHAE monomitic "with thinwalled hyphae, usually densely interwoven and fused to an almost pseudo-parenchymatic structure in which distinct hyphae may be difficult to demonstrate", (even basidia and acanthophyses in the hymenium may be fused), in between hyphae are irregular and amorphous grains of a dark blue pigment, calcium oxalate crystals present in varying degrees, (Eriksson), SPORES 5.5-7(8) x 2.5-3.5(4) um, elliptic to subcylindric, rounded on both ends, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled, apiculate; catahymenium composed of basidial elements, embedded pseudocystidia, and numerous to scattered acanthophyses, BASIDIA (2-)4-spored, (15)20-25(30) x (4)4.5-5(5.5) um, subclavate, sterigmata up to 5.5 um long and 1 um wide at base; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) (25)30-80 x (4.5)5.5-8(9) um, flexuous-cylindric, "often apically moniliform, walls thin to partially thickened", "contents faintly yellowish in KOH, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde"; ACANTHOPHYSES mostly subclavate, (7)10-18(20) x (2.5)3-5(6) um, apically pronged [bottlebrush-like at tip]; HYPHAE monomitic, of hyphae 2-2.5(3) um wide, branched, with thin to partially thickened walls, conspicuously clamped, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the bluish black color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Lemke(1) (as Aleurodiscus), Eriksson(2) (as Aleurodiscus), Ginns(5) (as Acanthophysium)
2
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Acanthophysium abietis  (H.S. Jacks. & P.A. Lemke) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre^  Mycologia Memoir 19: 15. 1993;  == Aleurodiscus abietis  H.S. Jacks. & P.A. Lemke  Can J. Bot. 42: 225. 1964
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on the underside of dead branches and twigs of living fir and hemlock, 2) cushion-shaped, resupinate fruitbodies forming circular light orange-buff patches 0.1-0.3cm across that are separate or confluent, the texture pruinose-pulverulent, the margin at first indeterminate and radiate, lighter in color, cobwebby, becoming more determinate and fairly tightly attached, 3) nearly round spores that are smooth and amyloid, 4) catahymenium containing abundant bottlebrush-like acanthophyses, embedded, ampulliform pseudocystidia, paraphysoids, and emergent basidial elements, and 5) context monomitic without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^ Acanthophysium abietis has been recorded from BC, OR, ID, NS, ON, PQ, NY, and VT, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  pulvinate [cushion-shaped], resupinate, in circular patches (0.1)0.15-0.3cm across, separate or confluent, texture pruinose-pulverulent, 0.025-0.04cm in cross-section; hymenial (outer) surface light orange-buff; margin at first indeterminate and radiate, color lighter than hymenium, "cobwebby, at length more determinate, adnate or only slightly free"^, (Lemke)
HABITAT  on the underside of dead branches and twigs on live trees^; Abies balsamea, Abies grandis, Tsuga mertensiana, (Ginns), on the "underside of dead branches and twigs" of living Abies (fir), found also on Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) in the Pacific Northwest, (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (16)18-20(21) x (14)16-18 um, nearly round, slightly flattened adaxially, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled, apiculate^; hyphae "ascending to form a catahymenium" composed of emergent basidial elements, paraphysoids, embedded, ampulliform pseudocystidia, and abundant acanthophyses; BASIDIA 4-spored, at maturity clavate, (75)85-100 x (15)20-24 um, sterigmata 14-16 um long, arcuate; hyphal PARAPHYSOIDS scattered, 3-4 um wide, filiform; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA mostly embedded, (35)75-85(100) x (8)13-20 um, subcylindric to ampulliform with an apical bulb, contents not darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde; ACANTHOPHYSES variable, mostly cylindric and uniformly thin-walled, rarely swollen in lower part with the basal part thin-walled and generally naked, the aculeate-pronged part covering the top third to half of the element and 4-7 um wide, acanthophyses colorless to slightly yellowish in KOH, faintly amyloid in Melzer's reagent; CONTEXT monomitic, composed of hyphae 4-5 um wide, irregular, branched, with partially thickened walls, simple-septate, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  mean 'of Abies (fir)', referring to habitat
SIMILAR  Acanthophysium farlowii also occurs on conifers and has cylindric, thick-walled acanthophyses and smooth, amyloid spores, but habit is different (disciform with determinate raised margins as opposed to pulvinate with indeterminate adnate margins), habitat is mostly Douglas-fir in the Pacific Northwest, as opposed to fir and hemlock, spores are smaller and oval as opposed to nearly round, basidia are smaller, acanthophyses are wider, and pseudocystidia are flexuous-cylindric (as opposed to subcylindric ampulliform) and never become apically moniliform, (Lemke).
SOURCES  Lemke(1) (as Aleurodiscus abietis), Ginns(5)
3
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Acanthophysium cerussatum  (Bres.) Boidin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 101: 340. 1986;  == Corticium cerussatum  Bres.;  Aleurodiscus cerussatus  (Bres.) Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) fruitbodies that are thin, whitish to yellowish to grayish, 3) smooth, amyloid, elliptic to cylindric spores (seen to advantage only scattered through the hymenial layer in Melzer's reagent), 4) a catahymenium comprised of a) basidial elements (basidia rarely seen emergent), b) paraphysoids, c) variously shaped pseudocystidia, and d) bottlebrush-like acanthophyses that are filiform to subclavate, and 5) context that is monomitic with clamp connections.^ | This is a collective species, with limits yet to be defined precisely, (Lemke). RANGE ^Acanthophysium cerussatum has been recorded from BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, ON, AZ, CO, FL, MN, NM, and SD, (Ginns). Collections were examined from BC, ID, MB, ON, FL, NM, Italy, France, and Austria, (Lemke).
FRUITING BODY  corticioid, 0.005-0.02cm thick, subcoriaceous [somewhat leathery] to crustose; "whitish when young, darkening when old from yellowish to greyish, more or less ochraceous when dry"; smooth; margin not distinct^, (Eriksson), "corticioid, in irregularly effused patches", 0.02-0.03cm thick, texture compact-subceraceous to rigid-crustose; ochraceous buff on drying; rimose to [cracked like dried mud]; margin thick and determinate [distinct], adnate [tightly attached] to loose, (Lemke)
HABITAT  on wood: dead branches, slash, associated with a white rot (Ginns), on conifer wood or hardwood, (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 10 x 6 um, elliptic to subcylindric, smooth, amyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 40-50 x 7-8 um; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA numerous, about the same size as basidia, variable in shape but usually with a more or less moniliform apex, contents colorless or slightly yellowish and finely granular; ACANTHOPHYSES numerous, with apical protuberances [giving a somewhat bottlebrush-like appearance]; HYPHAE monomitic with hyphae 2-4 um wide, thin-walled, clamped, (Eriksson), SPORES inconspicuous in KOH and "may be seen to advantage only in Melzer's, where they initially appear as embedded, often collapsed, amyloid fragments which tend to regain their shape after about 10 minutes", (7)8-10(11) x (4.5)5-6(7) um, oval to oval-elliptic, slightly flattened adaxially, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled; catahymenium consisting of basidial elements, paraphysoids, variously shaped pseudocystidia, and filiform to subclavate acanthophyses; BASIDIA 4-spored, rarely seen emergent, 30-35 x 6-8(9) um, sterigmata incurved, basidioles embedded, (25)35-50 x (5.5)6-8(9.5) um, clavate; PARAPHYSOIDS 2-2.5 um wide, filiform to singly branched in upper part; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) "variable, scattered to numerous, initially embedded as long flexuous-cylindric elements", 40-65(85) x (7)8-12(14) um, "becoming emergent to the level of the hymenium, and then subclavate to fusiform", measuring (30)40-50 x (5.5)6-10(11) um, apically moniliform, contents of pseudocystidia faintly yellowish in KOH; ACANTHOPHYSES thin-walled, subclavate to filiform, mostly subclavate, 30-40 x (4)5-7 um, "aculeate to acicular-pronged at the apex", pronged parts thick-walled to semisolid, 4-6 um wide, covering the upper quarter of the acanthophysis, also filiform acanthophyses, 2.5-3.5 um wide, pronged at apices; HYPHAE monomitic, of hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, "branched, subregular, thin-walled, clamped", BASAL HYPHAE reaching 3.5-4 um wide, clamped, with partially thickened walls, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'lead-colored'
SIMILAR  Acanthophysium diffissum has spores that are larger and at least twice as long as they are broad, and the acanthophyses bear acicular prongs that are longer than the prongs on the acanthophyses of A. cerussatum, (Lemke).
SOURCES  Lemke(1) (as Aleurodiscus), Eriksson(2) (as Aleurodiscus), Ginns(5)
4
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Acanthophysium diffissum  (Sacc.) Parmasto^  Izv. Akad. Nauk Estonsk. SSR, Ser. Biol. 16: 378. 1967;  == Peniophora diffissa  Sacc.;  Aleurodiscus diffissus  (Sacc.) Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth predominantly on dead twigs and branches of Ericaceae, 2) small patches up to 0.3cm that become readily confluent, colored alutaceous to fuscous-gray, with thick determinate margins often slightly reflexed, the underside darker and smooth, 3) cylindric to suballantoid spores that are smooth and amyloid, 4) catahymenium composed of a) basidial elements (basidioles often pronged), b) simple paraphysoids, c) embedded pseudocystidia that darken in sulphobenzaldehyde and are often moniliform, and d) abundant bottlebrush-like acanthophyses that are filiform to subclavate, and 5) context monomitic with scattered clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Acanthophysium diffissum has been recorded from OR, AZ, CA, CO, (Ginns). Collections were examined from CA, CO, Mexico, and Russia (Siberia), and the distribution also includes OR and China, (Lemke).
FRUITING BODY  at first tuberculiform, in round patches 0.1-0.3cm across, 0.045-0.07cm thick, "gregarious to readily confluent, then forming irregular, effused patches", texture compact-farinose to subcoriaceous; surface alutaceous to fuscous-gray; drying deeply rimose to [cracked like dried mud]; margins determinate [distinct], thick, often slightly reflexed; underside, when exposed, appearing darker, smooth^, (Lemke)
HABITAT  predominantly on dead twigs and branches of members of Ericaceae^, (Lemke), on dead twigs and branches, recorded from Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Arctostaphylos nevadensis (Pinemat Manzanita), A. patula (Greenleaf Manzanita), Ceanothus greggii (Desert Ceanothus), Juglans major, Juniperus sp. (juniper)., Lycium andersonii (Anderson Thornbush), Quercus sp. (oak), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (10)12-16(18) x (4)5-6(7) um, cylindric to suballantoid, flattened to slightly curved adaxially, (some collections from Mexico with spores wider than expected), smooth, amyloid, thin-walled, apiculate^; catahymenium composed of basidial elements, simple paraphysoids, embedded moniliform pseudocystidia, and abundant acanthophyses; BASIDIA scattered, 4-spored, 80-100 x 7-9(10) um, flexuous-cylindric to subclavate, sterigmata up to 10 um long, basidioles numerous, 60-80 x 7-8.5 um, subclavate, often acicular-pronged; simple PARAPHYSOIDS up to 4.5 um wide, filiform; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) scattered, 80-100 x (6)7-9(11) um, flexuous-cylindric to subclavate, yellowish (in KOH), darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde, "mostly embedded with partially thickened walls", often apically moniliform; ACANTHOPHYSES abundant, 45-80 x 3-8.5 um, "variable, filiform to subclavate", with thin to partially thickened walls, "acicular prongs either borne laterally and scattered or borne terminally as an acicular-pronged outgrowth without a lumen", these acicular-pronged parts 9-30 x 6-7.5 um with individual prongs (2)3-5 um long, yellowish in KOH; CONTEXT monomitic, hyphae 1.5-3.5 um wide, subregular, thin-walled, with scattered clamp connections, BASAL HYPHAE 4-4.5 um wide, with partially thickened walls, simple-septate, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'split'
SIMILAR  Acanthophysium macrocystidiatum differs by having 1) a lighter, cream-buff color, 2) adnate margins, 3) wider spores (but note that some collections of A. diffissum from Mexico have wider spores than the dimensions above), 4) distinctly different pseudocystidia (guttate and vary from clavate to ampulliform as opposed to cylindric to subclavate-moniliform with granular-guttulate contents), 5) prongs on the acanthophyses that are rather short aculeate (as opposed to more linear-acicular), (Lemke). Acanthophysium cerussatum has spores (7)8-10(11) x (4.5)5-6(7) um, and acanthophyses that bear prongs that are shorter than the prongs on the acanthophyses of A. diffissum, (Lemke).
SOURCES  Lemke(1) (as Aleurodiscus), Ginns(5)
5
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Acanthophysium farlowii  (Burt) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre^  Mycologia Memoir 19: 16. 1993;  == Aleurodiscus farlowii  Burt  Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 5: 182. 1918
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on recently dead twigs of living conifers, 2) small round patches that may become confluent, with a pale yellow-brown surface that dries pale tan, a distinct upraised margin, and a darker brown bald underside, 3) large oval spores that are smooth and amyloid, 4) a catahymenium composed of a) basidial elements, b) embedded pseudocystidia that are flexuous-cylindric, and c) numerous bottlebrush-like acanthophyses that are cylindric to subclavate, and 5) a context that is monomitic without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^It has been recorded from BC, ID, ON, PQ, ME, NH, NY, and PA, (Ginns), and WA (Castellano). Collections examined from BC, ON, PQ, ME, NH, and NY, (Lemke).
FRUITING BODY  discoid with convex surface, separate or confluent, when separate 0.05-0.15cm across, 0.04-0.06cm thick, texture farinose-pulverulent [powdery] to subcoriaceous [somewhat leathery]; surface drying light buff; margins determinate, reflexed; underside bald, dark-colored, (Lemke), pale yellow-brown, drying pale tan; underside dark brown, bald^, (Castellano)
HABITAT  on recently dead twigs on live conifers, recorded from Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock)^, (Ginns), on Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) in BC and Idaho, also on Tsuga canadensis, (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (15)16-18(19) x (11)12-14(15) um, oval, slightly flattened adaxially, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled^; catahymenium composed of basidial elements, embedded pseudocystidia, and numerous acanthophyses; BASIDIA 4-spored, "at maturity subclavate, 75-90 x 14-20 um, occasionally with a lateral, aculeate-pronged outgrowth", sterigmata arcuate, subulate; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA inconspicuous, 100-220 x 10-15 um, flexuous-cylindric, without moniliform constrictions, colorless in KOH, not darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde; ACANTHOPHYSES variable, cylindric to subclavate, mostly swollen in lower part, with aculeate pronged parts covering the upper one third to two thirds and those parts 4.5-8 um wide, thick-walled to semi-solid, acanthophyses often swollen in lower part, the basal part clavate, thin-walled and naked, acanthophyses colorless to faintly yellowish in KOH, often slightly amyloid; CONTEXT "monomitic, hyphae radiating from vertex", 4.5-5.5(7) um wide, generative, thick-walled, simple-septate, (Lemke), SPORES ovate to elliptic; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (gloeocystidia) "inconspicuous, flexuous, cylindric, not apically moniliform", (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Acanthophysium abietis also occurs on conifers and has cylindric, thick-walled acanthophyses and smooth, amyloid spores, but habit is different (pulvinate with indeterminate adnate margins as opposed to disciform with determinate raised margins), habitat is mostly fir and hemlock in the Pacific Northwest, as opposed to Douglas-fir, spores are larger and nearly round as opposed to oval, basidia are larger, acanthophyses are narrower, and pseudocystidia are subcylindric ampulliform (as opposed to flexuous-cylindric) and may have an apical bulb, (Lemke).
SOURCES  Lemke(1) (as Aleurodiscus), Castellano(1)*, Ginns(5)
6
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Acanthophysium fruticetorum  (W.B. Cooke) Boidin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 101: 339. 1986;  Aleurodiscus fruticetorum  W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) effused-reflexed growth on twigs and stems of Arctostaphylos, Artemisia, and Ceanothus, 2) fruitbodies that are orange drying orange-buff, the margins upraised and on drying inrolled, and the underside grayish and conspicuously tomentose, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and amyloid, 4) hymenium that is poorly defined, consisting of a) basidial elements, b) abundant simple paraphysoids, c) pseudocystidia that are cylindric to clavate and darken in sulphobenzaldehyde, and d) thin-walled acanthophyses with scattered acicular prongs, and 5) context that is dimitic with hyphae mostly generative without clamp connections, but basal skeletal hyphae agglutinating on the abhymenial surface to form a trichoderm.^ RANGE ^Acanthophysium fruticetorum has been found in CA and CO, (Ginns). It was also found in eastern WA (J. Ginns, pers. comm., a collection on Ceanothus).
FRUITING BODY  substereoid [somewhat Stereum-like], effuso-reflexed, up to 0.1cm thick, texture subceraceous [somewhat waxy], hymenial surface drying orange-buff; continuous [without cracks]; margins reflexed up to 1cm, inrolled on drying; underside (abhymenial surface) grayish, conspicuously tomentose^, (Lemke), surface orange when fresh (Ginns, pers. comm.)
HABITAT  on twigs and stems; Arctostaphylos patula (Greenleaf Manzanita), Artemisia tridentata (Big Sagebrush), Ceanothus velutinus (Snowbrush Ceanothus); associated with a white rot^, (Ginns), on twigs and stems of Arctostaphylos and Ceanothus at 1830m elevation in California, (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (9.5)10-12(13) x 5.5-7 um, elliptic, rounded at both ends, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled, apiculus subterminal^; hymenium poorly defined, composed of basidial elements, paraphysoids, pseudocystidia, and acanthophyses; BASIDIA scattered, 60-70 x 7-9(11) um, typically 4-spored with sterigmata up to 7.5 um long and 2-2.5 um wide at base, basidioles often acicular pronged, clavate, 40-55 x 6-8 um; simple PARAPHYSOIDS abundant, naked; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) 70-80(120) x 7-10 um, embedded-cylindric to emergent-clavate, "apices often submoniliform and projecting beyond the level of the hymenium", "contents faintly yellowish in KOH, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde"; ACANTHOPHYSES 35-55 x 4-6 um, clavate to subfusiform, "uniformly thin-walled, bearing scattered acicular prongs mostly at the apex"; CONTEXT dimitic, hyphae mostly generative, 2.5-3.5 um wide, regular, simple-septate, with partially thickened walls, BASAL HYPHAE mostly skeletal, about 4 um wide, thick-walled to semisolid, unbranched, aseptate, skeletal hyphae "agglutinate on the abhymenial surface, forming a trichoderm", (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of thickets', from the Latin word 'fruticetum' meaning 'thicket'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Aleurodiscus penicillatus.
SOURCES  Lemke(1), Cooke(6), Ginns(5)
7
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Acanthophysium macrocystidiatum  (P.A. Lemke) Boidin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 101: 339. 1986;  == Aleurodiscus macrocystidiatus  P.A. Lemke  Can. J. Bot. 42: 255. 1964
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood of species of Ericaceae, 2) corticioid fruitbodies forming linear patches, the surface drying cream to ochraceous-buff, the margins distinct and tightly attached, 3) elliptic-cylindric spores that are smooth and amyloid, 4) catahymenium composed of a) scattered basidial elements, b) conspicuous embedded pseudocystidia that are clavate to ampulliform and darken in sulphobenzaldehyde, and c) numerous acanthophyses variable in shape with aculeate pronged part thick-walled, and 5) context monomitic without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Acanthophysium macrocystidiatum has been recorded from BC and CA (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  "corticioid, forming linear patches 0.5-3cm long" and 0.1-0.3(0.5)cm wide, 0.015-0.025cm thick, texture densely pruinose to subfelty; hymenial surface drying cream to ochraceous-buff; continuous [without cracks]; margins determinate [distinct], adnate [tightly attached]^, (Lemke) 
HABITAT  found on lower surface of branches of Arbutus menziesii that have recently died, recorded also from Arctostaphylos sp.^, (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 14-16 x (6.5)7-8(9) um, elliptic-cylindric, rounded at both ends, smooth, amyloid, apiculate^; catahymenium composed of scattered basidial elements, conspicuous pseudocystidia, and numerous acanthophyses; single basidium observed, 55 x 9.5 um, with 4 sterigmata up to 9 um long, basidioles numerous, (40)50-60(7.5) x (8)13-17 um, subclavate to clavate; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) (40)45-60(70) x (9)15-18(23) um, clavate to ampulliform, contents guttate and yellowish in KOH, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde, generally embedded; ACANTHOPHYSES variable, basal part cylindric, 3.5 um wide, to swollen-rectangular, and then measuring up to 45-50 x 14-15 um, "walls thin to slightly thickened, naked", aculeate-pronged part borne laterally or at the apex, 20-30 x 7.5-8 um, cylindric, thick-walled to semisolid, occasionally branched, pronged part faintly yellowish (in KOH), individual prongs 1.5-2.5(3) x 0.8 um; CONTEXT monomitic, composed of hyphae (2.5)3-4 um wide, subregular, thin-walled, simple-septate, BASAL HYPHAE up to 4.5 um wide, with partially thickened walls, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with macrocystidia'
SIMILAR  Acanthophysium diffissum differs by having 1) a darker color, alutaceous to fuscous-gray, 2) margins often slightly reflexed, 3) narrower spores with different details (but note that some collections of A. diffissum from Mexico have wider spores than those in type), 4) distinctly different pseudocystidia (cylindric to subclavate-moniliform with granular-guttulate contents as opposed to guttate and varying from clavate to ampulliform), 5) prongs on the acanthophyses that are more linear-acicular (as opposed to short aculeate), (Lemke).
SOURCES  Lemke(1) (as Aleurodiscus), Ginns(5)
8
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Acanthophysium succineum  (Bres.) Boidin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 101: 340. 1986;  == Aleurodiscus succineus  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead barkless Pacific Madrone wood, 2) small round patches that are gregarious to confluent, then form small, irregular, neutral gray, linear patches (that dry cracked), the margins thick, and abrupt to slightly raised, the underside lighter in color and smooth, 3) elliptic to subcylindric spores that are smooth and amyloid, 4) a catahymenium composed of a) basidial elements (basidia rarely seen, basidioles bearing scattered projections), b) naked paraphysoids, c) mostly embedded pseudocystidia that are clavate to flexuous-cylindric and darken in sulphobenzaldehyde, and d) numerous bottlebrush-like acanthophyses that are cylindric with the aculeate-pronged parts thin-walled, and 5) context that is monomitic with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Acanthophysium succineum has been recorded from OR and CA (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  at first round, in patches 0.05-0.15cm across, 0.035-0.05cm thick, "gregarious to confluent, then forming small, irregular, linear patches"; neutral gray; drying deeply rimose [cracked] to areolate [cracked like dried mud]; texture compact-subceraceous to crustulose; "margins determinate, thick, abrupt to slightly raised"; underside when exposed lighter in color, smooth^, (Lemke)
HABITAT  recorded on dead decorticated wood of Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone)^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (10)12-14(15) x (5)5.5-6.5(7) um, elliptic to subcylindric, rounded at both ends, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled, with a subterminal apiculus^; catahymenium composed of basidial elements, naked paraphysoids, mostly embedded pseudocystidia, and numerous acanthophyses; BASIDIA rarely seen, 4-spored, (40)55-70 x 7-8.5(9) um, subclavate, sterigmata 6-7 um long, 2-2.3 um wide, basidioles numerous, (40)55-75(80) x (4.5)5.5-8(8.5) um, subclavate, "often bearing scattered, aculeate prongs"; simple PARAPHYSOIDS scattered, 2.5-3 um wide, filiform; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) (50)70-100(120) x (6.5)8-12(13.5) um, thin-walled, flexuous-cylindric to subclavate, contents granular-guttulate, yellowish in KOH, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde, pseudocystidia rarely with an apical bulb; ACANTHOPHYSES abundant, mostly cylindric to cylindric-subclavate, (30)34-45(55) x (3)4-5(6) um, uniformly thin-walled, bearing aculeate prongs only on a part, generally on the apical third to half, acanthophyses colorless in KOH, faintly amyloid in Melzer's reagent; CONTEXT monomitic, hyphae (2)2.5-3 um wide, subregular, thin-walled, clamped, BASAL HYPHAE 3.5-4.5(5.5) um wide, generative with partially thickened walls, clamped, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Lemke(1) (as Aleurodiscus), Ginns(5)
9
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Acanthophysium weirii  (Burt) Nakasone^  Mycologia Memoir 15: 21. 1990;  == Aleurodiscus weirii  Burt  Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 5: 203. 1918
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on bark of conifers, 2) corticioid, effused, readily confluent fruitbodies that are white, aging cream to pale yellowish, with a powdery texture, cracked with drying, the margins adnate, and finally abrupt, 3) spores that are nearly round, finely spiny, amyloid, and relatively small, 4) a hymenium consisting of obscured basidial elements, simple paraphysoids, deep-seated pseudocystidia that darken in sulphobenzaldehyde, and acanthophyses, and 5) context that is monomitic with tips of hyphal branches capped by prongs.^ RANGE ^Acanthophysium weirii has been recorded from BC, OR, ID, AK, AZ, MI, and MT, (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  "corticioid, readily confluent, indefinitely effused", 0.02-0.08cm thick; "white when fresh, aging cream to cartridge-buff colored"; "deeply rimose to areolate on drying"; texture farinose-pulverulent [powdery], "pruinose-pulverulent toward the thinner margins"; margins at first indeterminate and adnate, finally determinate and abrupt^, (Lemke)
HABITAT  recorded from bark of conifers^, (Lemke), Abies concolor (White fir), A. grandis (Grand Fir), Larix laricina (Tamarack), L. occidentalis (Western Larch), P. sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7 x 5-6 um, nearly round, slightly flattened adaxially, echinulate [finely spiny] in Melzer's reagent, amyloid, firm-walled, apiculate^; catahymenium consisting of obscured basidial elements, simple paraphysoids, deep-seated pseudocystidia, and acanthophyses; BASIDIA (2)4-spored, 30-45 x 5-7 um, flexuous-cylindric to subclavate, basidioles "subclavate to clavate, maturing by an external prolongation"; PARAPHYSOIDS scattered, 3-4 um wide, cylindric, simple to singly branched; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) 55-80 x 5-6(8) um, flexuous-cylindric, rarely with an apical gemma, contents of pseudocystidia yellowish in KOH, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde; ACANTHOPHYSES cylindric, mostly 3-4 um wide, basal part thin-walled and naked, aculeate-pronged part semi-solid, borne at apex, these terminal pronged parts seen to advantage in Melzer's reagent, "separable and then appearing as free-floating fragments" measuring 7-15 x 4.5-6 um; CONTEXT monomitic, composed of hyphae that are 1.5-3 um wide, irregular, branched, clamped, walls thin to partially thickened, "tips of hyphal branches capped by a semisolid, aculeate-pronged apex", (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  after J.R. Weir who collected specimen cited by Burt
SIMILAR  Aleurodiscus spiniger has similar acanthophyses but spores are larger, (Lemke). Other Acanthophysium species do not have spiny spores, (and A. weirii may not belong in this genus), (Ginns(23)). See also SIMILAR section of Aleurodiscus occidentalis.
SOURCES  Lemke(1) (as Aleurodiscus), Ginns(5), Ginns(23)
10
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurocystidiellum disciformis  (DC.) Boidin, Terra & Lanq.^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 84: 63. 1968;  == Thelephora disciformis  DC.;  Aleurodiscus disciformis  (DC.) Pat.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on oak bark, 2) fruitbodies as thin flat patches whitish to light gray in color, the distinct margin often loosened, 3) spores that are nearly round to elliptic, amyloid, and with rounded irregular warts, and 4) a catahymenium composed of basidial elements, numerous hypha-like paraphysoids, and moniliform pseudocystidia.^ | Note that Lemke's description of this species as an Aleurodiscus species includes pseudocystidia, which he excludes in his description of the genus Aleurocystidiellum (the hymenium of which is supposed to contain basidial elements, simple paraphysoids, and apically encrusted skeletal paraphysoids), and note also that the genus Aleurocystidiellum has dimitic context with predominantly skeletal hyphae. RANGE ^Aleurocystidiellum disciformis has been recorded from WA, OR, AZ, and CA, (Ginns), Denmark, Norway, Sweden, (Eriksson), Mexico, and Siberia in Russia.
FRUITING BODY  Stereum-like, resupinate, usually a few centimeters wide, (more rarely coalescing into larger fruitbodies 1-1.5cm thick), consistency dense and hard, surface whitish to light gray, sometimes with yellowish tinges; more or less finely tuberculate, often dry when cracked; margin slightly loosened^, (Eriksson), in patches 1-3cm wide and 0.005-0.01cm thick, pulvinate [cushion-shaped] to disciform, broadly attached, texture compact-subcoriaceous to coriaceous [leathery]; drying "cream to pale yellow-buff, often with cinereous tints"; continuous to slightly cracked when old; margins thick, determinate [distinct], often reflexed [bent outwards] to slightly incurved; abhymenial surface when exposed is considerably darker and smooth, (Lemke)
HABITAT  typically on bark, recorded from Quercus (oak)^, (Ginns), "on trunks of old Quercus, often 1-5 m above the ground, usually in southernly [sic] exposed, locally warm and sheltered localities", (Eriksson), mostly on the bark of deciduous wood, usually Quercus, (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 15-17 x 10-12 um, nearly round to elliptic, covered with rounded irregular warts (not spines as in Aleurodiscus amorphus), amyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 75 x 10 um; CYSTIDIA "about the same size as the basidia, paraphysoid with a moniliform apex, usually abundantly covered with crystals"; no acanthophyses or dendrohyphidia; HYPHAE monomitic, with hyphae 2.5-3.5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, clamped, hyphae in basal layer have thickened walls and may be superficially called skeletal, (Eriksson), SPORES (13)16-18(20) x (8.5)11-14(16) um, oval to oval-elliptic, inconspicuously echinulate in Melzer's with spines measuring less than 0.5 um long, amyloid, walls firm to thickened up to 1.5 um; catahymenium composed of basidial elements, numerous hypha-like paraphysoids, and moniliform pseudocystidia; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 60-90 x 10-12(14) um, cylindric to subclavate, sterigmata up to 18 um long and 3-5 um wide at base, basidioles 45-75 x 8-11 um, clavate, with homogeneous contents; simple hypha-like PARAPHYSOIDS are 3-5 um wide; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) 50-80 x (6.3)7-10(12) um, "thin-walled, often embedded and then collapsed, flexuous-cylindric", "often moniliform with two-eight apical swellings", contents faintly yellowish in KOH, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde; HYPHAE monomitic of hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, "ascending, obscured by abundant crystalline granulation, simple-septate, subregular, mostly thin-walled, branched", BASAL HYPHAE 3.5-4.5 um wide, subregular, mostly thin-walled, branched, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  means "disc-shaped"
SIMILAR  Aleurodiscus amorphus has spores with spines rather than warts, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Lemke(1) (as Aleurodiscus), Eriksson(2) (as Aleurodiscus), Ginns(5)
11
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurocystidiellum subcruentatum  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) P.A. Lemke^  Can. J. Bot. 42: 277. 1964;  == Stereum subcruentatum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Aleurodiscus subcruentatus  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a discoid fruitbody (or subpileate from a reduced base), growing on live conifer bark, 2) a spore-bearing surface that dries cream-buff with grayish tints, 3) a thick determinate margin, 4) spores that are oval to broadly elliptic, amyloid, and minutely verruculose in Melzer's reagent, the wall thickening up to 2 um, 5) a catahymenium composed of large basidial elements, scattered hypha-like paraphysoids, and skeletal encrusted paraphysoids (cystidiohyphidia), and 6) a dimitic context mostly of thick-walled skeletal hyphae, (differing microscopically from Aleurodiscus species).^ RANGE ^Aleurocystidiellum subcruentatum has been found in BC, WA, OR, NS, ON, PQ, AK, CA, NH, and NY, (Ginns), and China and Japan, (Lemke).
FRUITING BODY  0.2-0.5(1)cm across, 0.02-0.16cm thick, "discoid to subpileate from a reduced base", texture subcoriaceous [somewhat leathery] to rigid farinose-pulverulent [powdery] on drying; spore-bearing surface drying cream-buff with grayish tints; continuous [not cracked]; margin "thick, determinate, reflexed to incurved on drying"; abhymenial surface variable, grayish brown at the vertex becoming light buff toward margin, bald, concentrically zoned in well-developed specimens^, (Lemke)
HABITAT  on conifer bark "of live trees, sometimes on bark lesions on suppressed trees"^; Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Picea glauca (White Spruce), P. rubens (Red Spruce), P. sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns), primarily on bark of Picea (spruce) in North America, occurring in Europe on Pinus, reported from Japan on Tsuga diversifolia (Japanese Hemlock), Thuja sp., and Cryptomeria japonica (Japanese-cedar), and from China on Abies (fir), (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (12)15-18(20) x (10)11-15(16) um, ovoid to broadly elliptic, flattened adaxially, minutely verruculose in Melzer's reagent, amyloid, wall thickened up to 2 um, apiculate^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 55-90(110) x 8-12 um, flexuous-cylindric to subclavate when mature, sterigmata slender up to 14(16) um long and 2-3 um wide at base; simple PARAPHYSOIDS scattered, 3-4 um wide, thin-walled; skeletal paraphysoids 3.5-5(6) um wide, cylindric, aseptate, walls thickened, smooth to wrinkled, the cystidiohyphidia "generally apically incrusted, with the incrustation dissolving in KOH"; CONTEXT dimitic, mostly of skeletal hyphae (2)3.5-4.5(6) um wide, aseptate, colorless to yellowish in KOH, thick-walled, generative hyphae scant, 1.5-3.5(4) um wide, irregular, branched, with scattered clamp connections, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Aleurodiscus spp. share catahymenial organization, large basidia, and amyloid spores, but the diagnostic cystidiohyphidia present in Aleurocystidiellum subcruentatum are foreign to Aleurodiscus, and it lacks the sterile elements (acanthophyses, pseudocystidia) typically found in Aleurodiscus; furthermore, Aleurocystidiellum subcruentatum is decidedly dimitic, (Lemke).
SOURCES  Lemke(1), Ginns(5)
12
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurodiscus amorphus  (Pers.) J. Schroet.^  In F. Cohn, Kryptogamen-Flora Schlesien 3(1): 429. 1888;  Peziza amorpha  Pers.;  Thelephora amorpha  (Pers.) Fr.;  Nodularia balsamicola  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on the bark of recently dead branches on live conifers, primarily fir, 2) disc-shaped or cup-shaped fruitbodies at first 0.0-0.5cm across, sometimes becoming confluent, the surface salmon pink when fresh and producing spores, with a distinct margin ringed with tiny white hairs, the abhymenial surface white, gray, or pale brown and finely hairy or matted, 3) spores large and nearly round to broadly elliptic, with amyloid spines, 4) a hymenium of a) basidial elements, b) hyphidia, c) pseudocystidia (not darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde) typically with 1 to several, successively smaller apical swellings, and d) crystals up to 10 um wide (which also occur in the context), and 5) a context that is monomitic without clamp connections.^ | A. amorphus is rare to uncommon within the range of Aleurodiscus grantii, a similar common species. RANGE ^Aleurodiscus amorphus has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PE, PQ, SK, YT, AZ, CA, CO, CT, MA, ME, MI, MN, MO, MT, NH, NY, TN, VT, WI, WV, (Ginns(5), who notes that "From the Pacific Coast to the eastern foothills of the Rocky Mountains, the very similar, Aleurodiscus grantii [italicized] is more common"). A. amorphus also found in Mexico, Europe, Russia (Siberia), Japan, and China, (Ginns(16)). It occurs in Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Sweden (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  1-5cm wide, 0.05-0.1cm thick, flat and rounded, slightly convex and discomycete-like, consistency firm, subcoriaceous (somewhat leathery), upper (spore-bearing) surface ochraceous, pinkish gray to orange-red; margin narrow and distinct^, (Eriksson), 0.1-0.7cm wide, disc-shaped to cushion-shaped, also sometimes cup-shaped, usually in small groups or cespitose, "isolated or concrescent, breaking through the bark and broadly attached in the center", margin "fringed-filamentous and often arched upward", consistency waxy, soft; upper surface "pale to red-orange, fading to pink-gray when old"; upper surface smooth, farinose (mealy), dull; margin "somewhat lighter-toned to whitish"; lower surface whitish, tomentose, (Breitenbach), 0.1-0.5cm across, disc-shaped or pezizaeform [cup-shaped like Peziza], typically circular, scattered to gregarious, sometimes confluent, attached by short central base up to 0.05cm x 0.05cm, surface flat to slightly convex; when fresh and producing spores salmon pink, when old or after storage pallid, pinkish orange, or olive ochraceous; finely granulose; "margin determinate, ringed with white hairs, cottony to fimbriate, sometimes fasciculate and then appearing hirsute", up to 0.1cm long; abhymenial surface white, gray, blackish gray, or pale brown, "matted tomentose to finely hirsute", (Ginns(16)), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  apparently "an early invader of dead or nearly dead branches in the lower crown, primarily on Abies spp., basidiomes produced on bark of recently dead limbs and stems; parasitic, causing cankers on branches of suppressed trees, main stems and often killing suppressed saplings", associated with a white rot; Abies, Larix, Picea, Pinus, Pseudotsuga, Thuja, Tsuga^, (Ginns(5)), on dead wood still with bark, principally of Abies (fir), more rarely on Picea (spruce), "on trunks and branches, both fallen and standing or attached respectively", (Breitenbach for Europe), Abies, Picea abies, usually "grows on nearly or recently dead, but still attached lower branches", annual, developing during humid periods, (Eriksson), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 25 x 20 um, nearly round to broadly elliptic, "densely covered with fine, cylindrical to slightly conical and abruptly cut (not tapering) spines"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 100 x 25 or even larger, sterigmata 15-25 um long; PARAPHYSOID HYPHAE "present between the basidia, moniliform (like a string of pearls) and not projecting", HYPHAE "monomitic with simple septate hyphae, 2-4 um wide, in an open texture of distinct hyphae", (Eriksson), SPORES 25-30 x 22-25 um, nearly round to oval, with fine blunt spines, colorless, amyloid; BASIDIA 4-spored, 140-180 x 20-30 um, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 100-200 x 15 um, moniliform hyphal ends; HYPHAE monomitic 2-4 um wide, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES (22)24-28(32) x (18)20-23(26) um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, with amyloid spines up to 4 um long, wall either colorless and thin or pale yellow and thickened, acyanophilic, apiculus broad and blunt; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 200 x 22-28 um, tapering to a narrow (4-5 um) base, basal septum without clamp connection, sterigmata 30-40 um long and up to 7.5 um wide at base; HYPHIDIA scattered, (2)3-5 um, cylindric or some irregularly swollen, "straight to wavy, some with one or two branches"; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA usually numerous, "typically with 1 to several, successively smaller, acropetal, apical swellings" up to 10-11 um wide (moniliform), acyanophilic, inamyloid, not darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde; CRYSTALS: hymenium and context with few to numerous, small to large (up to 10 um in diameter) crystals scattered throughout; HYPHAE monomitic, generative hyphae in context 3-5 um wide, colorless, simple-septate, thin-walled to rather thin-walled, "the exterior surface of the walls swelling in 2% KOH, with few to numerous segments crystalline incrusted", branched, inamyloid, acyanophilic; 'external hyphae, including those forming the "hairs" around the hymenial surface and those of the abhymenial surface, hyaline, pale yellow or some on the abhymenial surface yellow-brown, thin- to rather thin-walled, septate, rarely branched', the branches arising as an apical dichotomy, encrusted with few to numerous (up to 5 um), roughed or angular crystals (3)4-6.5 um in diameter, (Ginns(16))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'amorphous', 'without shape'
SIMILAR  Aleurodiscus grantii also has a discoid or pezizoid fruitbodies with large, spiny, amyloid spores, but 1) has clamp connections at about 10% of the septa on the context hyphae, and at the base of nearly all mature basidia, whereas A. amorphus lacks clamp connections, 2) has slightly larger spores (typically has some spores over 30 um, whereas in A. amorphus it is unusual to find spores over 28 um long), 3) lacks pseudocystidia, whereas A. amorphus has broad, apically moniliform pseudocystidia (in A. grantii some hyphidia in some specimens have the apical part strangulated to form irregular to moniliform swellings, and these strangulated hyphidia resemble the pseudocystidia of A. amorphus, but they never produce swellings that are as uniformly globose [spherical] or as broad (up to 11 um) as those of A. amorphus), (Ginns(16)). See also SIMILAR section of Aleurocystidiellum disciformis.
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(16), Ginns(5), Courtecuisse(1)*, Buczacki(1)*
13
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurodiscus aurantius  (Pers.) J. Schroet.^  in F. Cohn, Kryptogamen-Flora Schlesien 3(1): 429. 1888;  == Corticium aurantium  Pers.;  Acanthophysium aurantium  (Pers.) G. Cunn.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on twigs and stems of species of Rosaceae, 2) fruitbodies as patches that are palish with orange tinges, thin and leathery, and often pruinose, 3) spores that are oval to oval-elliptic, amyloid, and finely spiny, 4) a catahymenium composed of a) a loose network of basidial elements, b) naked dendrohyphidia (may be covered with crystals), and c) abundant yellowish pseudocystidia (macrocystidia) of a deep origin, and 5) a monomitic context without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Aleurodiscus aurantius has been recorded from BC, ON, and CA, (Ginns). It occurs in Europe including Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson). Collections were examined from BC, CA, France, Germany, Norway, and Sweden, and the range includes South America, Japan, and New Zealand, (Lemke).
FRUITING BODY  0.01-0.03cm thick, effused (spread out on substrate), closely attached, consistency subcoriaceous (somewhat leathery); "palish with orange tinges"; usually smooth; without distinct margin^, (Eriksson), corticioid, in resupinate patches 0.5-1.5cm wide, 0.015-0.0375cm thick, sometimes coalescing to form wider areas, texture densely pruinose to compact-submembranous; color variable, drying isabelline to cinereous, or even fuscous; drying rimose [cracked] to continuous; margin at first indeterminate [indistinct], adnate [tightly attached], fimbriate [fringed], and lighter in color, becoming more distinct and colored like the rest of the surface, (Lemke), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead twigs and stems, in Europe primarily on Rosaceae, in BC a collection from Vaccinium, in California from Arctostaphylos columbiana (hairy manzanita), Rhododendron occidentalis (western azalea), Ribes sanguineum (redflower currant), Rubus ursinus (Pacific blackberry), Umbellularia californica (California laurel), Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak)^, (Lemke), also recorded from Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns), usually on Rosaceae, but recorded from Taxus (yew), (Eriksson for North Europe), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 20 x 13 um, elliptic to nearly round, finely echinulate (spiny), amyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 60 x 15 um, sterigmata about 15 um long; DENDROHYPHIDIA numerous, richly branched and covered with crystals; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA "variable in shape, narrowly paraphysoid with rounded apex, or wider and more rounded, tapering basally to a long shaft with a +/- moniliform apex, or even smooth to simply tapering", cell contents yellowish (darken in sulfovanillin), making pseudocystidia easy to separate from basidia; HYPHAE monomitic with hyphae 2.5-4 um wide, simple-septate, thin-walled, in an open texture, (Eriksson), SPORES (14)16-20(22) x (10)12-15(16) um, oval to oval-elliptic, "apiculate, flattened adaxially, firm-walled, finely echinulate in Melzer's, amyloid"; catahymenium composed of a loose network of basidial elements, naked dendrohyphidia, and abundant pseudocystidia (macrocystidia) of a deep origin; BASIDIA 4-spored, (30)50-70(80) x 10-14 um, cylindric to flexuous-subclavate, sterigmata divergent and up to 20 um long and 4 um wide at base; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA embedded, (30)40-60 x 12-20 um, variable, mostly ampulliform with one to several apical constrictions, contents yellow brown in KOH, PARAPHYSOIDS 2-2.5 um wide, hypha-like, "without clamps, simple to branched, forming a mass of naked dendrohyphidia at the level of the hymenium"; HYPHAE monomitic, of hyphae 2.5-4 um wide, simple-septate, thin-walled, branched, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  means "orange"
SIMILAR  Among amyloid-spored Aleurodiscus species, A. aurantius is distinct in having naked, profusely branched dendrohyphidia, (Lemke). Peniophora erikssonii is somewhat similar in appearance, but very different microscopically, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Lemke(1), Eriksson(2), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
14
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurodiscus grantii  Lloyd^  Mycol. Writ. 6 (Note 62): 927. 1920
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also included in Cups category. Features include 1) growth on the lower surface of small dead branches on live conifers, especially true fir, 2) disc-shaped or cup-shaped fruitbodies at first 0.0-0.4cm across, sometimes becoming confluent, the surface pale orange-pink to pink, with a distinct margin ringed with tiny white hairs, the abhymenial surface white, gray, or pale brown and finely hairy or matted, 3) spores that are large and nearly round to broadly elliptic, with amyloid spines, 4) a hymenium of a) basidial elements, b) hyphidia, and c) crystals up to 10 um wide (which also occur in the context), and 5) a context that is monomitic with some septa clamped.^ | From the Pacific Coast to the eastern foothills of the Rocky Mountains more common than the very similar Aleurodiscus amorphus. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, YT, CA, and MT, (Ginns(16)).
FRUITING BODY  disc-shaped or pezizaeform [shaped like Peziza cup fungus], 0.1-0.4cm across, "scattered to gregarious, sometimes confluent", 0.05-0.1cm thick, surface flat to slightly convex, fruitbody "attached by a short, central base"; typically pale orange pink to pink, sometimes faded when old or after storage; finely granulose; margin determinate [distinct], ringed with white, shiny fascicles of hyphal hairs up to 0.02cm long; abhymenial surface "white, grey or pale brown, finely hirsute or matted"^, (Ginns(16))
HABITAT  typically on lower surface of small (1-6cm diameter), dead branches in the lower crown of live conifers, sometimes on trunks of dead saplings or on fallen stems; most often collected on Abies (fir), especially A. grandis (Grand Fir) and A. lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), and less often on other conifers^, (Ginns(16)) 
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 22-32(39) x 18-24(28) um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, with amyloid spines up to 4 um long, wall colorless, acyanophilic, up to 1 um thick, apiculus broad (up to 3 um), blunt^; BASIDIA 4-spored, +/- 230 x 25-28 um, clavate, tapering to a 4 um wide base, with clamp connection, sterigmata up to 21 um long; HYPHIDIA colorless, thin-walled to rather thin-walled, infrequently thick-walled, straight to wavy, unbranched or with up to 4 short branches, cylindric or with the apex irregularly swollen or strangulated, swellings sometimes moniliform, 4-6 um wide; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA lacking; CRYSTALS: hymenium, subhymenium, and adjacent context "with few to numerous, square to angular crystals up to 10 um wide"; HYPHAE monomitic, generative hyphae in the context colorless, branched, "thin- to sometimes rather thin-walled, the wall often with a 1.5 um thick gelatinized exterior as viewed in 2% KOH", about 10% of the septa with clamp connections; abhymenial surface "sometimes with hyphae parallel, compact", rather thin-walled to thick-walled, brownish yellow, up to 7 um wide, hyphal "hairs" on the abhymenial surface and the margin 3-5(6) um wide, straight, rarely branched (branching dichotomously), thin-walled to rather thin-walled, simple-septate, (Ginns(16))
NAME ORIGIN  named after Grant, collector of the type
SIMILAR  Aleurodiscus amorphus also has discoid or pezizoid fruitbodies with large, spiny, amyloid spores, but 1) lacks clamp connections (in A. grantii found at about 10% of the septa on the context hyphae, and at the base of nearly all mature basidia), 2) has slightly smaller spores (unusual to find spores over 28 um, whereas A. grantii typically has some spores over 30 um long), 3) has broad, apically moniliform pseudocystidia (in A. grantii some hyphidia in some specimens have the apical part strangulated to form irregular to moniliform swellings, and these strangulated hyphidia resemble the pseudocystidia of A. amorphus, but they never produce swellings that are as uniformly globose [spherical] or as broad (up to 11 um) as those of A. amorphus), (Ginns(16)).
SOURCES  Ginns(16), Ginns(5)
15
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurodiscus mirabilis  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Hoehn.^  Sitzungsber. Kaiserl. Akad. Wiss., Math.-Naturwiss. Kl., Abt. 1, 118: 818. 1909;  == Psilopeziza mirabilis  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Aleurodiscus apiculatus  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on larch and other wood, 2) cream to ocher fruitbodies with pinkish tints, at first round to cup-shaped and up to 0.3cm across, readily confluent, with distinct, upraised margins, the abhymenial surface pallid and tomentose, 3) spores that are large, biapiculate, elliptic to semilunar, smooth in KOH, but asperulate and amyloid in Melzer's reagent, 4) a catahymenium composed of a) basidial elements, b) subclavate paraphysoids, c) inconspicuous pseudocystidia that are flexuous-cylindric and darken in sulphobenzaldehyde, and d) scattered to numerous acanthophyses that are thick-walled and cylindric and have projections throughout their length, and 5) a monomitic context with clamp connections.^ | It is a collective species, held together by the nature of the spores, primarily pantropical to subtropical in distribution, with a wide host range, (Lemke). RANGE ^Aleurodiscus mirabilis has been recorded from ID, GA, MT, and NC, (Ginns). Collections were examined from GA, HI, NC, Cuba, Jamaica, Brazil, China, and Japan, and the distribution also includes Africa and Australasia, (Lemke).
FRUITING BODY  at first orbicular to cup-shaped, 0.1-0.3cm across, "readily confluent, forming irregularly fused areas", 0.04-0.065cm thick, texture variable, pruinose-pulverulent [powdery] to more compact-membranous; cream to ocher, with pinkish tints; continuous to slightly rimose [cracked] on drying, "smooth to reticulate-ridged in more compact specimens"; margins determinate [distinct], reflexed [upraised]; abhymenial surface pallid, tomentose^, (Lemke)
HABITAT  on bark, dead branches, the ID and MT records on Larix occidentalis, the eastern records on Betula alleghaniensis, Rhododendron sp.^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (20)24-28 x 14-16(17) um, elliptic to semilunar, distinctly flattened adaxially, smooth to slightly roughened in KOH, asperulate in Melzer's reagent, amyloid, walls thickened at maturity up to 1.5 um, "biapiculate"^; catahymenium composed of basidial elements, subclavate paraphysoids, inconspicuous pseudocystidia, and scattered to numerous acanthophyses; BASIDIA (2)4-spored, 80-160 x 16-24 um, clavate, sterigmata up to 24 um long and 6 um wide at base, basidioles clavate, mostly 18-20 um wide; PARAPHYSOIDS 75-100 x 9.5-12 um, subclavate, thin-walled, "occasionally bearing scattered aculeate prongs"; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) "variable, embedded, scattered to abundant", 70-150 x (7)9-13(15) um, flexuous-cylindric, "contents faintly yellowish in KOH, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde"; ACANTHOPHYSES thick-walled, mostly cylindric, (4)6-8 um wide, colorless in KOH, bearing prongs throughout their entire length that are aculeate to acicular curved, up to 8 um long and 1 um wide; CONTEXT monomitic, composed of hyphae 3-3.5(5) um wide, subregular, branched, clamped, with walls thin to partially thickened, (Lemke) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'wonderful'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Lemke(1), Ginns(5)
16
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurodiscus occidentalis  Ginns^  Mycologia 82: 753. 1990
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on Western Red-cedar on bark on the lower side of dead branches and twigs on live trees, 2) crustose, effused fruitbodies about 1cm x 0.6cm, colored gray to cream with a thick, abrupt, white margin up to 0.05cm wide, the subiculum colored as the outer surface, 3) spores that are nearly round to broadly elliptic, amyloid, colorless, with amyloid spines, 4) hymenium of a) basidial elements, b) hyphidia that are scattered, inconspicuous, and filiform, c) gloeocystidia that are usually rather common, are clavate with a long stem-like base, and are characteristically moniliform, and d) rare acanthophyses, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections and loosely arranged in a matrix of crystals.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from southern BC, northeastern WA, and northern ID, (Ginns(2)).
FRUITING BODY  crustose, effused, about 1cm x 0.6cm, up to 0.02cm thick; gray to cream; "arid, chalky", smooth, with fissures; margin up to 0.05cm wide, thick, abrupt, white; subiculum very thin, colored as the hymenium^, (Ginns(2))
HABITAT  on Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), "Typically on bark on the lower side of dead branches" (1-2cm diameter) "and twigs in the lower crown of live trees, occasionally collected on dead branches on ground or stems of small dead trees"^, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 14-17 x 11-14 um, nearly round to broadly elliptic, adaxially flattened, with amyloid spines 1(1.5) um long, spores colorless to nearly colorless, amyloid, with wall thin to 1 um thick, apiculus broad and blunt^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 65-70(95) x 12(16) um, cylindric-clavate, with short, narrow (2-3 um wide), stem-like base, sterigmata up to 10-15 um long, immature basidia about 40 x 10 um, often fusoid; HYPHIDIA scattered, inconspicuous, 2(4) um wide, filiform, often weakly branched, the walls colorless, thin, smooth, inamyloid, and acyanophilic; GLOEOCYSTIDIA "rather common but few in some specimens, 40-55 x 10-12 um, clavate with a relatively long stem-like base" 2-3 um wide, with a clamp connection at the base, characteristically moniliform, with one or several spherical, catenulate, apical swellings, 6-12 um wide, the contents colorless, sulfo-negative, the wall colorless, thin, inamyloid, acyanophilic; acanthophyses rare, 5 um wide, cylindric, thin-walled, with few (up to 6) apical prongs; HYPHAE monomitic, the hyphae 2-3(4) um wide, "tortuous, much branched, rather loosely arranged in a matrix of crystals and what appeared to be remnants of old basidia", walls colorless, thin, inamyloid, and acyanophilic, with single clamp connection at each septum, (Ginns(2))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'western'
SIMILAR  Acanthophysium lividocoeruleum has been reported on Thuja: its spores are 5.5-7(8) x 2.5-3.5(4) um and smooth, (Ginns(2)). Acanthophysium weirii has been reported on Thuja: its spores are 5-7 x 5-6 um, (Ginns(2)).
SOURCES  Ginns(2), Ginns(5)
17
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurodiscus penicillatus  Burt^  Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 5: 20. 1918
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead branches and twigs of conifers especially Douglas-fir and Western Hemlock, 2) corticioid patches up to 0.3cm across which become confluent, the color light buff to cream-buff, the margin distinct and tightly attached, 3) round to suboval spores that are amyloid with a spiny surface in Melzer's reagent, with germ pores at opposite ends of the spore, 4) a catahymenium composed of a) basidial elements, b) simple paraphysoids, c) ampulliform pseudocystidia (often with a conspicuous globe-like mass inside, and bearing one or more asexual propagules at the tip), and d) numerous, thin-walled acanthophyses with delicate acicular projections toward the apex, and 5) context monomitic with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Aleurodiscus penicillatus has been recorded from BC, WA, OR, ID, ON, PQ, CA, NH, NY, NC, and VT, (Ginns). Collections were examined from BC, OR, ID, ON, PQ, CA, NY, and VT, (Lemke).
FRUITING BODY  corticioid, at first in separate patches, 0.2-0.3cm across, "readily confluent, forming irregularly effused areas", 0.02-0.04cm thick, in western North America up to 0.07cm thick, "texture granular-pruinose to compact-pulverulent"; light buff to cream-buff; continuous to rimose [cracked] on drying, "often areolate in thicker specimens"; margins at length determinate [distinct], adnate [tightly attached]^, (Lemke)
HABITAT  on dead branches and twigs of various conifers, in the Pacific Northwest occurring commonly on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)^, (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 15.5-20(25) x (13)14-19(21) um, round to suboval, flattened adaxially, walls appearing smooth to roughened in KOH, echinate [spiny] in Melzer's reagent, walls amyloid, "thickened at maturity up to 2 um thick, and then bearing opposite germ-pores at the poles of the spore"^; spores of fruitbodies from Picea sitchensis with a larger average spore range, 22-25 x 15-21 um; catahymenium composed of basidial elements, simple paraphysoids, ampulliform pseudocystidia, and numerous, thin-walled acanthophyses; BASIDIA (2)4-spored, 55-90(110) x 16-24 um, clavate, thin-walled, often with lateral acicular prongs, sterigmata 14-19 um long, 4-5 um wide at base, subulate, slightly incurved; PARAPHYSOIDS (1.5)2-2.5 um wide, simple to branched, hyphal-like; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA embedded at first, (35)50-60(75) x (9)10-12 um, flexuous-cylindric to emergent-ampulliform, bearing one to several apical gemmae [asexual propagules], contents of pseudocystidia often "with a conspicuous globoid, hyaline in KOH, not darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde"; ACANTHOPHYSES 20-100 x 5-20 um, cylindric to broadly clavate, uniformly thin-walled, bearing scattered, delicate, acicular prongs mostly toward apex, the individual prongs seen to advantage in Melzer's reagent, 3-7 um long and about 0.7 um wide; CONTEXT monomitic, composed of hyphae that are 2-2.5(3) um wide, subregular, branched, thin-walled, and clamped, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  means "ending with a tuft of hairs", perhaps referring to the acanthophyses with their terminal projections
SIMILAR  Acanthophysium fruticetorum also has acanthophyses that are uniformly thin-walled with delicate acicular prongs, but is substereoid, smooth-spored, and dimitic, (Lemke).
SOURCES  Lemke(1), Ginns(5)
18
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurodiscus spiniger  D.P. Rogers & P.A. Lemke^  Can. J. Bot. 42: 265. 1964
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on the bark and on the underside of branches of Douglas-fir and Western Hemlock, 2) corticioid whitish fruitbodies, at first in separate patches 0.5-1.5cm across, readily confluent, with tightly attached margins that become more distinct as they mature, 3) nearly round, amyloid spores that are densely echinulate in Melzer's reagent, 4) a catahymenium consisting of a) initially embedded basidial elements, b) scattered paraphysoids, c) deep-seated to emergent pseudocystidia (flexuous-cylindric to subclavate, often bearing an apical bulb, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde), and d) numerous acanthophyses (thin-walled, aculeate-pronged parts borne laterally or apically or both), and 5) a monomitic context with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Aleurodiscus spiniger has been recorded from BC, OR, ID, and AZ, (Ginns). Collections were examined from BC, OR, ID, and China, (Lemke).
FRUITING BODY  corticioid, at first in separate patches 0.5-1.5cm across, "readily confluent, and then effused indefinitely", 0.02-0.06cm thick, texture pruinose to farinose-pulverulent; white when fresh, drying cream to cartridge-buff; drying rimose to [cracked like dried mud]; margins "indeterminate, thinning toward the edges, adnate, at length more determinate"^, (Lemke)
HABITAT  on bark, and on underside of branches, recorded from Larix occidentalis (Western Larch), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)^, (Ginns), on the bark and on the underside of branches of various conifers, in the Pacific Northwest primarily on Pseudotsuga and Tsuga, (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (10)11.5-14(16) x (9)9.5-12(13) um, nearly round, slightly flattened adaxially, densely echinulate in Melzer's reagent, amyloid, firm-walled, apiculate^; catahymenium consisting of initially embedded basidial elements, scattered paraphysoids, deep-seated to emergent pseudocystidia, and numerous acanthophyses; BASIDIA 4-spored, obscured, 60-90 x 10-13 um, flexuous-cylindric to subclavate, sterigmata 7-9 um long and 1.5-2.5 um wide at base; PARAPHYSOIDS rare, 3-4.5 um wide, simple to slightly branched; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (macrocystidia) 50-85 x 4-7 um, flexuous-cylindric to subclavate, often bearing an apical bulb, pseudocystidial contents yellowish to golden brown in KOH, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde; acanthophyses 25-35 x 7-12 um, subclavate to clavate, thin-walled, "aculeate-pronged parts borne laterally or apically or both", semisolid, pronged parts "separable, and then in the mount appearing as free-floating fragments", 7-15(18) x 5-10 um, individual prongs 4-10 x 1-1.5 um, appearing to advantage in Melzer's reagent; CONTEXT monomitic, composed of hyphae that are 1.5-3 um wide, subregular, thin-walled, and clamped, BASAL HYPHAE 3.5-5(6) um wide, with partially thickened walls, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing spines'
SIMILAR  Acanthophysium weirii is close but has larger spores (Lemke).
SOURCES  Lemke(1), Ginns(5)
19
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Alutaceodontia alutacea  (Fr.) Hjortstam & Ryvarden^  Syn. Fung. (Oslo) 15: 8. 2002;  Hyphodontia alutacea  (Fr.) J. Erikss.  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 104. 1958;  Hydnum alutaceum  Fr.;  Odontia alutacea  (Fr.) Bres.;  Kneiffiella alutacea  (Fr.) Julich & Stalpers  Verh. K. ned. Akad. Wet., tweede sect. 74: 134. 1980
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a creamy white to dingy ochraceous fruitbody that is flocculose to furfuraceous then odontioid (from small, conic spines that become densely crowded and accumulate into small, branched, almost coralloid structures), the tip of the spine brush-like, the spore-bearing surface between spines porose-reticulate, the periphery pruinose, the margin indistinct, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) thin-walled cystidia that are projecting or enclosed, cylindric, blunt, often with constrictions, the contents cyanophilic, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae cyanophilic, with clamp connections, and 6) conidia present in some collections.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed October 5, 2020, listed Alutaceodontia alutacea as the current name, but MycoBank listed Kneiffiella alutacea as the current name. RANGE ^Alutaceodontia alutacea has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NS, ON, AR, AZ, CO, IA, MA, ME, MN, MT, NM, NY, and WI, (Ginns), PQ, NY, Austria, Germany, Spain, and Sweden, (Langer), and Czechoslovakia, Finland, and Poland, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], "at first creamish white, when mature and especially when dried sordidly ochraceous"; "at first flocculose or furfuraceous, then more or less odontioid" with small (usually less than 0.1cm long) conic aculei [spines], "with time densely crowded and accumulating into (under the lens) small branched, almost coralloid structures", tips of spines penicillate [brush-like]; spore-bearing surface between the spines "porose-reticulate, in the mature fruitbody insignificant"; "margin indistinctly thinning out, in the periphery pruinose"^, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed conifer wood^ (Pinus, Picea), (Eriksson), Abies (fir), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Quercus (oak), Thuja; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8 x 1.5(2) um, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA at first subclavate, then nearly cylindric, "often with median suburniform constriction", 10-16 x 4-5 um, normally 4-spored; CYSTIDIA "varying in number, from very few to numerous", usually 50-75 x 4-7 um, sometimes longer, projecting or enclosed, cylindric, obtuse, "often with a few or several constrictions" (in extreme cases torulose), thin-walled, contents dense, strongly stained in cotton-blue; HYPHAE monomitic, about 3 um wide, "distinct, richly branched", with clamp connections, stainable in cotton-blue, in the center of the spines with thickened walls and sparse branching, in the subhymenium thinner and denser, hyphal constrictions frequent; CONIDIA present in some collections, developed from subulate [awl-shaped] conidiophores with basal clamp connections in the hymenium (mostly in the basidial bunches but can also be among sterile hyphae in the apices of the aculei), the conidia varying in size and shape but mostly oval or subelliptic, tapering toward the base, mostly 8-10 x 3-4 um, often containing oil droplets, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'alutaceous in color', 'of soft leather'
SIMILAR  Hyphodontia species with allantoid spores generally have thick-walled tubular cystidia, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hyphodontia alutacea), Bourdot(1) (as Odontia), Ginns(5) (as Hyphodontia alutacea), Langer(1) (as Hyphodontia alutacea), Buczacki(1)* (as Hyphodontia alutacea)
20
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amaurodon mustialaensis  (P. Karst.) Koeljalg & K.H. Larss.^  Syn. Fung. (Oslo) 9: 33. 1996;  == Hypochnopsis mustialaensis  (P. Karst.) P. Karst.;  == Hypochnus mustialaensis  P. Karst. [as H. mustialensis];  Coniophora mustialaensis  (P. Karst.) Massee;  Coniophora cyanospora  D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) thin, resupinate growth on wood, 2) an olive to yellow green, smooth to grandinioid spore-bearing surface, with a whitish margin that is often indistinct, 3) amyloid spores that discolor blue or purple in 2-3% KOH, 4) basidia that are narrowly clavate, usually with a median constriction and narrowing at the base, some with pale blue amorphous granules in KOH, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Amaurodon mustialaensis has been found in BC, ID, MB, ON, PQ, AZ, IA, MS, NJ, NM, and OH, (Ginns(5)). It has also been found in Finland and Sweden, (Ginns(21)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, usually in patches about 2cm by 1cm or to 4cm by 4cm, about 0.05cm thick, fragile, loosely attached, separable, "typically a delicate membrane supported by a sparse cottony subiculum"; spore-bearing surface dingy olive-yellow, yellow-green, to bright olive-green, smooth to grandinioid, margin up to 0.2cm wide, whitish, thin, often indistinct^, (Ginns(21))
HABITAT  on coniferous wood, especially Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Thuja, occasionally on hardwood, especially Quercus (oak), (Ginns(21)), on well-rotted wood and bark of logs and fallen limbs, decayed leaves, apparently associated with a brown rot, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4)4.8-5.5(6.4) x (3.2)4-4.5(5.4) um, nearly round to broadly oval in face view, broadly oval and adaxially flattened in side view, appear smooth but some spores "finely sculptured or verrucose" under high magnification such as 2000x, amyloid (moderate blue), pale yellow to colorless in water, deep purple blue in KOH, wall thickened to 0.6 um^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 22-30 x 5-6 um, narrowly clavate, usually with a median constriction and narrowing at the base, some with pale blue amorphous granules in KOH; HYPHAE monomitic, context hyphae (1.4)2.5-4.5(5.5) um wide, "loosely woven, often branched, septa frequent, each with single clamp connection", (Ginns(21)), SPORES of Amaurodon species staining violet to dark blue in 2-3% KOH, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  after Mustiala, the type location in Finland
SIMILAR  Amaurodon viridis is similar in gross features and many microscopic characters including amyloid spores that are colored blue or purple in KOH, (Ginns(21) where Amaurodon viridis is referred to as Tomentella viridis Cunn.). A. viridis has warted spores and a typically hydnoid surface, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Ginns(21) (as Hypochnopsis mustialaensis), Ginns(5) (as Hypochnopsis mustialaensis), Ginns(23)
21
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amaurodon viridis  (Alb. & Schwein.) J. Schroet.^  Krypt.-Fl. Schlesien 3(1): 461. 1888.;  Sistotrema viride  Alb. & Schwein.;  Tomentella viridis  (Berk.) G. Cunn.;  Tomentella chlorina  (Massee) G. Cunn.;  Hypochnus chlorinus  Massee;  Caldesiella viridis  (Alb. & Schwein.) Pat.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a cobwebby to cottony fruitbody that is dull green to yellowish green, the surface smooth to warted or toothed, often faintly punctate, the margin irregular and almost white, and the subiculum also paler than spore-bearing area, 3) spores that are round to nearly round, verrucose to aculeolate, pale citrine to yellow in water, and usually purple in 2-3% KOH, 4) subicular hyphae that are colorless to slightly citrine (often purple in KOH), with clamp connections, 5) presence of cordons.^ RANGE ^Amaurodon viridis has been found in BC, ID, AZ, CA, MO, MN, NY, PA, and VT, (Ginns(5)), and Czechoslovakia, France, Netherlands, Russia, United Kingdom, Tunisia, Australia, and New Zealand, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.03cm thick, separable, arachnoid [cobwebby] to byssoid [cottony], "somewhat pelliculose in mature portions", spore-bearing areas mostly continuous; dull green to yellowish green; "smooth to warted or toothed, often faintly punctate"; sterile margin irregular, paler than the spore-bearing area, "almost white, arachnoid, becoming fibrillose"; subiculum thin, arachnoid, paler than the spore-bearing area^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Quercus (oak)^, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 um in diameter, round to nearly round, verrucose to aculeolate, pale citrine to yellow in water, usually purple in KOH^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-35 x 5-7 um, clavate, with clamp connection at base, sterigmata up to 5 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-3.5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-4 um wide, colorless to slightly citrine (often purple in KOH), thin-walled or with some thickening apparent, with clamp connections; CORDONS 5-30 um wide, citrine to pale brown, individual hyphae 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Larsen), spores of Amaurodon species staining violet to dark blue in 2-3% KOH, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Amaurodon mustialaensis has nearly smooth spores and a smooth to grandinioid surface, (Ginns(23)). Tomentella species recorded from the Pacific Northwest (except Tomentella crinalis) have larger spores, and their ornamentation tends to be more prominent, while T. crinalis has a dimitic hyphal system, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9) (as Tomentella chlorina), Ginns(5) (as Tomentella chlorina), Ginns(23)
22
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amphinema byssoides  (Pers.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 112. 1958;  == Thelephora byssoides  Pers.;  Peniophora byssoides  (Pers.) Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Amphinema byssoides is recognized by 1) the yellow color of the resupinate growth on wood, 2) the characteristic crater-like holes in the surface, and 3) under a hand-lens the numerous projecting cystidia; other features include 4) a finely velvety, cobwebby surface, 5) a marginal zone with rhizomorphs, 6) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, with thickened walls, 7) long cylindric cystidia with septa and clamp connections, and 8) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Amphinema byssoides is found in BC, WA, OR, AB, MB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, YT, AK, AZ, CA, CO, IA, IL, LA, MA, MN, NM, NY, OH, TX, UT, and VT, (Ginns), and Europe and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, loosely attached; light ochraceous yellow, when young lighter and more creamy in color; "very finely velvety due to projecting cystidia, here and there interrupted by crater-like depressions"; margin usually with hyphal strands and rhizomorphs^, (Eriksson), forming incoherent +/- perforated patches, up to the size of the palm of a hand; irregularly loosely filamentous and open, "fibrous to thin and membranous"; ocher-yellow to sulphur yellow; arachnoid, furfuraceous; margin irregularly fringed with +/- distinct rhizomorphs, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead coniferous wood and debris, (Eriksson), on rotting wood, litter and soil, damp soil and roots, associated with a variety of conifers, also with Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Populus (aspen and cottonwood), Quercus (oak), Selaginella apoda (creeping spikemoss), mycorrhizal at least with Picea glauca (white spruce), reported to be associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on the underside of dead wood, commonly in burned places, according to literature also on remains of other plants such as ferns and mosses, (Breitenbach), also on cones, leaf litter, and old polypore fruitbodies; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-4.5 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, with thickened walls^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 4-5 um, clavate, rarely somewhat constricted; HYPHAL CYSTIDIA numerous, projecting 50-70 um, in total 75-125 x 4-6 um, "with septa and clamps, finely encrusted with thin, flat, projecting crystals, and small angular grains"; HYPHAE monomitic with hyphae 3-4 um wide, intertangled, pale yellowish, with thin or somewhat thickened walls and clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5 x 2.5-3 um, oval, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with one droplet; BASIDIA 4-spored, (according to literature also with 2), up to 18-23 x 5-6 um, clavate; CYSTIDIA up to 130 x 6 um, "cylindric, blunt, thin- to thick-walled, with 1 to 4 septa, with clamps, lightly incrusted toward the tips"; HYPHAE monomitic with hyphae 2-3.5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
