NAME ORIGIN  from Greek 'byssos', meaning 'cotton', and 'oides', meaning 'like', hence 'like cotton, cottony'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
23
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amyloathelia amylacea  (Bourdot & Galzin) Hjortstam & Ryvarden^  Mycotaxon 10: 202. 1979;  == Corticium amylaceum  Bourdot & Galzin;  Aleurodiscus amylaceus  (Bourdot & Galzin) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.;  Corticium ermineum  Burt;  Corticium sociatum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on bark or rotten wood of logs, 2) loosely adnate fruitbodies that are white to cream and have an indistinct margin, 3) spores that strongly amyloid, smooth, thick-walled, and elliptic to nearly round, 4) in most cases paraphysoids between basidia, and 5) monomitic context with clamped hyphae.^ RANGE ^Amyloathelia amylacea has been found in BC, OR, ID, MB, ON, PQ, MI, MT, and VT, (Ginns). Collections were examined from BC, ID, ON, France, and Germany, (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, effuse, loosely adnate", at first more or less byssoid [cottony], later pellicular to soft membranaceous and often rimose [cracked]; generally white to creamish; margin indeterminable [indistinct]^, (Hjortstam)
HABITAT  on bark or barkless, very rotten wood of logs; Picea (spruce), Thuja plicata, (Western Red-cedar), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), (Ginns), in central Europe known as growing on Juniperus (Hjortstam)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES varying in size but generally 9-11 x 5-7 um, elliptic to nearly round, smooth, strongly amyloid, walls thick^; BASIDIA "polymorphous, sometimes distinctly clavate, in some cases suburniform, mostly terminal but some lateral basidia present, usually 20-35 x 6-7 um, with four sterigmata"; CYSTIDIA lacking "but in most specimens paraphysoid hyphae between the basidia"; HYPHAE monomitic; BASAL HYPHAE about 2-3 um wide, "thin-walled, somewhat encrusted straight and uniform", SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE more irregular, all hyphae with clamp connections, (Hjortstam)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'amylaceous', referring to the strongly amyloid spores
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(2), Ginns(5)
24
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amylobasidium tsugae  Ginns^  Mycologia 80: 63. 1988;  Dendrothele tsugae  (Ginns) Hjortstam
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  The distinctive character is the amyloid basidia. Other features include 1) growth on Mountain Hemlock between 2500 and 3000m, 2) cushion-shaped fruitbodies that are sometimes confluent, with a surface that is pallid to cream becoming tan, and an abrupt distinct margin, 3) spores that are large, broadly elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) dendrophyses in some areas forming a catahymenium, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from OR and CA, (Ginns). Redhead(5) mentioned a BC report, and there is a collection collected and identified by R.G. Thorn at the Center for Mycological Research.
FRUITING BODY  pulvinate [cushion-shaped], 0.1-0.5cm across, 0.06-0.08cm thick, sometimes confluent; pallid to cream, becoming tan when old, often with a new hymenial layer growing through and over the old fruitbody; smooth, pruinose or bald where weathered; margin abrupt, determinate [distinct]; subiculum firm, pallid^, (Ginns(14))
HABITAT  on decorticated wood or in bark crevices of logs and snags, on Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock)^, (Ginns(5)), on wood or in bark crevices of logs and snags of Tsuga mertensiana, July to September, from volcanic peaks (between 2500 and 3000m) in the cordillera of western North America, Dr. W.B. Cooke believed it to be a snowbank fungus, (Ginns(14))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 19-25 x (12.6)14-17 um, broadly elliptic with broadly rounded ends, some approaching oval, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, apiculus truncated and 1.5 um broad^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 110-160 x 13-20 um, "apparently utriform, elongated, wavy, cylindrical", "the walls thin over the apical one-third but irregularly thickened (up to 1.5 um thick) over the lower part, amyloid, especially where thickened"; DENDROPHYSES "in some areas forming a catahymenium up to 30 um thick over the apices of immature basidia, sparsely to intricately branched", the ultimate branches up to 1 um wide; HYPHAE monomitic; hyphae of subiculum 2.5-3.5(5) um wide, "closely packed and woven, with clamp connections", walls typically 0.5 um thick or thin, colorless, inamyloid, acyanophilic, (Ginns(14))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Tsuga [hemlock]', referring to habitat
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Ginns(14), Ginns(5), Redhead(5)
25
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amylocorticiellum molle  (Fr.) Spirin & Zmitr.^  Mikol. Fitopatol. 36(1): 23. 2002;  Hypochniciellum molle  (Fr.) Hjortstam  Mycotaxon 13: 125. 1981;  == Thelephora mollis  Fr.;  Peniophora mollis  (Fr.) Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a thin, athelioid, cottony-webby fruitbody that is whitish to cream, the surface uneven to slightly verrucose, sometimes merulioid when young, rhizomorphs absent or rare and inconspicuous, the margin cobwebby then distinct, 3) elliptic, smooth, thick-walled spores that turn gray in Melzer's reagent, 4) sporadic cystidia that are long-cylindric, thick-walled, and gray in Melzer's reagent, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Amylocorticiellum molle has been found in WA, OR, and ID, (Ginns). The distribution includes Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, very thin, forming patches several centimeters across, attached loosely to substrate, "cottony-arachnoid to membranous-athelioid", consistency cottony-soft; whitish to cream; "uneven to slightly verrucose, sometimes merulioid when young"; margin arachnoid [cobwebby] when young, later distinctly bounded, according to the literature "rarely also with inconspicuous rhizomorphs"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, thin, loosely attached, spore-bearing surface when mature is continuous (often cracking when dried); herbarium material mostly pale ochraceous, but in the living state when young may be whitish, later grayish or pale ochraceous, sometimes with a reddish tint; thins out to arachnoid margin; rhizomorphs none or inconspicuous, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood of conifers, especially on pieces of board, fence wood, etc., but also on fallen logs and branches^, (Eriksson), on Pinus (pine); rotten wood; underside pine guard rails beside highway, (Ginns for North America), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6(7) x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, smooth, gray in Melzer's reagent, slightly yellowish, in KOH yellowish, thick-walled, with granular contents, cyanophilic only when young, commonly collapsing^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 5-7 um, clavate, often with basal clamp connection, often collapsing; CYSTIDIA only sporadic, 70-140 x 10 um, cylindric, gray in Melzer's reagent, smooth, thick-walled, without septa; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-6 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 5.5-7 x 2.5-3.5 um, narrowly elliptic, "adaxial side almost straight, rarely somewhat concave", walls smooth, thickened, gray in Melzer's reagent (obvious especially when several spores together), yellowish when mature in KOH, cyanophilic when young or nearly mature, acyanophilic when fully mature, in old specimens many spores collapsed; CYSTIDIA "few, sometimes difficult to find, maybe even lacking", 75-150 x 6-9 um, cylindric, "obtuse, with thin or somewhat thickened walls"; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-6 um wide, distinct, oil droplets in protoplasm, with clamp connections, subicular ones thinner, richly branched, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'soft'
SIMILAR  Hypochniciellum ovoideus (Julich) Hjortstam & Ryvarden occurs in CO, ON, and WV, and Amylocorticiellum subillaqueatum (Litsch.) Spirin & Zmitr. occurs in AZ and NM, but both lack cystidia, and the former also lacks gray staining spores in Melzer's reagent, and grows on hardwoods, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Leucogyrophana mollis), Breitenbach(2)* (as Hypochniciellum molle), Ginns(5) (as Hypochniciellum molle), Ginns(23) (as Hypochniciellum molle), Buczacki(1)* (as Hypochniciellum molle)
26
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amylocorticium cebennense  (Bourdot) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykol. 13: 11. 1959;  == Corticium cebennense  Bourdot
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed conifer wood, 2) soft fruitbodies that are whitish when fresh, the margin finely fibrillose under a hand lens, 3) spores that are suballantoid, smooth, amyloid, and colorless, 4) the absence of differentiated sterile hymenial elements, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Amylocorticium cebennense has been found in BC, ID, NS, ON, AR, CA, and MA, (Ginns), and Europe (Eriksson). Collections were examined from BC, ID, AZ, CA, and MA, (Gilbertson).
FRUITING BODY  "annual, resupinate, developing in small patches or becoming confluent", "light buff" to "ivory yellow" to almost white; "smooth, cracking on drying to expose a loose, white subiculum"; "margin thinning out, whitish", loosely floccose to finely fimbriate [fringed]; subiculum with up to 4 strata, with light buff layers separated by darker zones, up to 0.05cm thick, "soft, loosely arranged, floccose"^, (Gilbertson), effused, more or less athelioid (like a loose pellicular membrane), soft; white when fresh, more light yellowish when dry; smooth; margin finely fibrillose under hand lens, with no rhizomorphs, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on Abies balsamea (Balsam fir), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Larix occidentalis (Western Larch), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), associated with a brown cubical rot of dead wood, (Ginns), on decayed conifer wood (fallen trees, slash, fencing), rarely on hardwood, (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-7.5 x 2-2.5 um, cylindric to suballantoid, smooth, amyloid, colorless, thin-walled, collapsed in dried specimens^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 4.5-5.5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA and other sterile elements absent; HYPHAE monomitic; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled to firm-walled, "with conspicuous clamps at all septa, with frequent branching, typically branching from clamps", (Gilbertson), SPORES 6-7.5 x 2-2.5 um, allantoid, smooth, amyloid, with one or two droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 4-6 um, narrowly clavate, with a basal clamp connection; subhymenium distinct as fruitbody thickens; HYPHAE monomitic, with hyphae 3-4 um wide, loosely interwoven, rather straight, with clamp connections at all septa, the branches occurring almost exclusively from the clamp connections, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means "of the Cevenne Mountains in southern France"^, (Gilbertson)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Gilbertson(10), Ginns(5)
27
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amylocorticium suaveolens  Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort., 197. 1968
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on Douglas-fir wood, 2) a fruitbody that is soft and easily separated from its substrate, the fruitbody color pinkish buff to cinnamon buff on drying, the margin abrupt and colored as the rest of the surface, and the subiculum soft and pale brown, with up to 8 layers, 3) a pleasant fragrance that persists in dried fruitbodies, 4) cylindric spores (with a slightly curved base) that are smooth, amyloid, and colorless, 5) 4-spored basidia, 6) cylindric cystidia projecting from the hymenium to 40 um, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system with clamp connections on all hyphae.^ RANGE ^A collection was examined from OR, and it was described from Estonia, (Gilbertson).
FRUITING BODY  "annual, resupinate, becoming widely effused", soft and easily separated from substrate; "pinkish buff" to "cinnamon buff" on drying; smooth, cracking on drying; margin abrupt, colored as the rest of the surface; subiculum up to 0.15cm thick, soft, pale brown, distinctly layered with up to 8 strata; fragrance pleasant, persisting in dried fruitbodies
HABITAT  Oregon collection on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir); associated with a brown cubical rot
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5(7) x 2-2.5 um, cylindric, slightly curved at base, smooth, amyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 4.5-5.5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA scattered, 50-70 x 5-6 um, cylindric, with clamp connection, thin-walled, not encrusted, "arising in the subhymenial layer and projecting to 40 um"; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with conspicuous clamp connections at all septa, typically branching from clamp connections or adjacent to septa opposite clamp connections, "in Melzer's reagent appearing as if coated with a brownish amorphous material, particularly in lower context"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'sweet-smelling'
SIMILAR  Amylocorticium subincarnatum has a hymenial surface with reddish tints, lacks the persistent pleasant odor, and has spores that are slightly different in shape (oblong to cylindric-ellipsoid instead of cylindric), (Gilbertson).
SOURCES  Gilbertson(10)
28
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amylocorticium subincarnatum  (Peck) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykol. 13: 11. 1959;  == Corticium subincarnatum  Peck;  Peniophora subincarnata  (Peck) Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) yellow color when young, later tinged reddish, (with reddish tints in dried specimens), 3) a smooth to slightly tuberculate surface, 4) a fibrillose margin under a hand lens, 5) a subiculum with 4-6 alternating pale pinkish buff and darker layers up to 1 mm thick, and microscopic characters including 6) short cylindric-elliptic amyloid spores, 7) cylindric cystidia, 8) monomitic hyphae with clamp connections, and 9) sections in Melzer's reagent with brown globules and alternating layers of dark and light zones.^ | Amylocorticium subincarnatum is apparently the most common species in the genus in North America; it is also known from Europe where it is reported to be very rare, (Gilbertson). RANGE ^Amylocorticium subincarnatum has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, ON, PQ, AR, AZ, MN, MT, and NY, (Ginns), and Sweden and Finland, (Eriksson). Collections were examined from AB, ON, AZ, MN, MT, and NY, (Gilbertson).
FRUITING BODY  effused, adnate [tightly attached] and quite soft at first, when old firmer, subcoriaceous [somewhat leathery]; yellow at first, then more distinctly reddish; smooth when young, slight tuberculate when old; margin fibrillose under hand lens and "light yellowish, often not distinctly developed"^, (Eriksson), yellow to cinnamon yellow; margin minutely fibrillose, (Martin), "annual, resupinate, becoming widely effused", soft becoming firm on drying; pale yellowish, ("buff yellow" or "mustard yellow") to pinkish yellow when fresh, becoming "pinkish buff" to "pinkish cinnamon" or "cinnamon" on drying; smooth to slightly tuberculate; "margin abrupt and concolorous or thinning out, whitish and finely fimbriate to arachnoid"; subiculum distinctly stratose, with 4-6 alternating pale pinkish buff and darker layers, to 0.1cm thick, (Gilbertson)
HABITAT  on coniferous wood, mostly fallen trees^, (Eriksson), hosts: Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Larix occidentalis (Western Larch), Picea spp. (spruce), Pinus spp. (pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir); associated with a brown cubical rot, (Ginns), white rot (Martin)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5 x 2-2.5 um, narrowly elliptic, amyloid, with slightly thickened walls^; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 20 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAL CYSTIDIA projecting up to 30 um, in total 50-70 x 4-5 um, smooth, in a few cases clamped; subhymenium develops as fruitbody increases in thickness; HYPHAE monomitic, of hyphae 3-4 um wide, loosely interwoven, with clamp connections at all septa, branching mostly from the clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5.5 x 2-2.5 um, narrowly elliptic, flattened on one side; CYSTIDIA abundant, cylindric, (Martin), SPORES 4.5-6 x 2-2.5 um, oblong to cylindric-elliptic, smooth, amyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 22-30 x 5-5.5 um, clavate, with a basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA "frequent, cylindric, some with constrictions, thin-walled, not incrusted, often with 2-3 clamps, 65-110 x 4-6 um, with a basal clamp, arising in subiculum and partially imbedded, projecting to 40 um"; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3.5-6 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with conspicuous clamp connections at all septa, with frequent branching, often branching from clamp connections, "tissue in Melzer's reagent with abundant globules of brownish oily material, often adhering to the ends of broken hyphae", "sections in Melzer's reagent appearing like slices of bacon with alternating dark and light zones", (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  means "somewhat reddish"^ (Gilbertson)
SIMILAR  Amylocorticium subincarnatum is closely related to Amylocorticium subsulphureum which remains yellow when old, tends to be smaller, and has different spores (although the spores of A. subsulphureum vary considerably even in the same fruiting body, leading to some uncertainty about the distinctness of the two species), (Eriksson). Amylocorticium subsulphureum looks like A. subincarnatum, but has longer spores and cystidia with less frequent clamp connections, (Gilbertson). Amylocorticium subsulphureum has narrowly cylindric, slightly curved spores, measuring 5-6.5 x 1.5-2 um, whereas A. subincarnatum has narrowly elliptic spores flattened on one side, measuring 4-5.5 x 2-2.5 um, (Martin). Amylocorticium suaveolens lacks reddish tints on its hymenial surface, has a persistent pleasant odor, and has spores that are slightly different in shape (cylindric instead of oblong to cylindric-elliptic), (Gilbertson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Gilbertson(10), Martin, K.J.(1), Ginns(5)
29
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amylocorticium subsulphureum  (P. Karst.) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykol. 13: 11. 1959 [as Amylocorticium subsulphurea];  == Corticium subsulphureum  P. Karst.;  Peniophora subsulphurea  (P. Karst.) Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) yellowish color when young, remaining yellowish when old, 3) a smooth to slightly tuberculate surface, 4) a margin that is fibrillose under hand lens, concolorous or whitish, 5) narrowly cylindric, amyloid spores, 6) cylindric cystidia, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system with clamp connections, 8) sections showing alternating layers, and 9) sections in Melzer's reagent showing brown globules.^ RANGE ^Amylocorticium subsulphureum is found in BC, ID, AB, MB, NS, PQ, AR, AZ, MD, MN, MT, NM, and NY, (Ginns). It is also found in Sweden (Eriksson). Collections examined from AZ, MD, and MT, (Gilbertson).
FRUITING BODY  effused, adnate [tightly attached], quite soft; yellow; smooth; finely fibrillose^, (Eriksson), yellowish to cream-colored, (Martin), "annual, resupinate, becoming widely effused, soft"; yellowish ("naphthalene yellow" to "mustard yellow") when fresh, becoming "pinkish buff" to "pinkish cinnamon" when dried; "smooth to slightly tuberculate, often cracking into small angular blocks on drying"; margin abrupt to thinning out and finely fimbriate [fringed], colored as the rest of the surface to whitish; subiculum appearing stratose [layered] under 30x lens with 2-3 darker zones separated by paler pinkish buff tissue, soft, to 0.05cm thick, (Gilbertson)
HABITAT  on coniferous wood, usually free from bark^, (Eriksson), on decaying barkless wood; on log; on Abies sp., Larix occidentalis, Picea, Pinus spp.; associated with brown cubical rot, (Ginns), white rot (Martin)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7 x 2-2.5 um, subcylindric, smooth, amyloid, with slightly thickened walls^; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 25 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 60-90 x 4-6 um, "slightly differentiated and hyphae-like, smooth, sometimes with a clamped septum"; subhymenium develops as fruitbody thickens; HYPHAE monomitic, with rather straight hyphae, clamp connections at all septa, branching mostly from the clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 5-6.5 x 1.5-2 um, narrowly cylindric, slightly curved; CYSTIDIA abundant, cylindric, (Martin), SPORES 6-8.5 x 2-2.5 um, "cylindric, straight to slightly curved", smooth, amyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 21-27 x 5-6 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA "scattered, cylindric to narrowly clavate, thin-walled, not incrusted, rarely with clamps, 40-90 x 4.5-5.5 um, arising from the subiculum and partially imbedded, projecting to 30 um, with a basal clamp"; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-4.5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with conspicuous clamp connections on all septa, with frequent branching, typically branching from clamp connections or adjacent to the septum opposite a clamp connection, "sections in Melzer's reagent with copious brownish, oily globular material", (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  means "somewhat sulphur yellow"^ (Gilbertson)
SIMILAR  Amylocorticium subincarnatum is closely related: it becomes tinged reddish when old, tends to be larger, and has different spores (although the spores of A. subsulphureum vary considerably even in the same fruiting body, leading to some uncertainty about the distinctness of the two species), (Eriksson). A. subincarnatum looks like A. subsulphureum but has shorter, more elliptic spores and cystidia with more frequent clamp connections, (Gilbertson). A. subincarnatum has narrowly elliptic spores flattened on one side, 4-5.5 x 2-2.5 um, while A. subsulphureum has narrowly cylindric, slightly curved spores, 5-6.5 x 1.5-2 um, (Martin).
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Gilbertson(10), Martin, K.J.(1), Ginns(5)
30
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amylosporomyces subasperisporus  (Litsch.) Hjortstam & Ryvarden^  Acta Mycol. Sin. 7: 78. 1988;  == Corticium subasperisporum  Litsch.;  == Gloeocystidiellum subasperisporum  (Litsch.) J. Erikss. & Ryvarden;  == Boidinia subasperispora  (Litsch.) Julich;  = Corticium electum  H.S. Jacks.;  = Gloeocystidiellum electum  (H.S. Jacks.) Parmasto
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  The distinctly reniform [kidney-shaped] spore is the principal distinguishing character of this rare fungus. Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifers, 2) thin, delicate, waxy fruitbodies that are grayish white to pale ochraceous, and smooth to granulose, the margin not especially differentiated, 3) spores that are kidney-shaped, warted, and amyloid, 4) basidia that are suburniform, 5) gloeocystidia that are numerous, obclavate, clavate, and cylindric, the apex rounded, sometimes with 1-2 small papillate apical appendages, the contents pale yellow and granular in KOH and sulfo-positive or sulfo-negative, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae richly branched, with clamp connections.^ | The placement of this species is uncertain: Julich suggested Boidinia in 1982, but Eriksson(3) calls it Gloeocystidiellum subasperisporum (mentioning the anomalous suburniform basidia) and Stalpers(3) appears to favor the latter tentatively, based in part on similarity to Gloeocystidiellum porosum. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, ON, PQ, and Sweden, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], effused [spread out], generally of small dimensions, thin (mostly 0.005-0.01cm), ceraceous [waxy] when wet and alive, subcrustose when dried; grayish white to pale ochraceous; mostly almost smooth; margin not especially differentiated^, (Eriksson), effused, 0.004-0.0225cm thick, ceraceous [waxy], "light buff", "cartridge buff", "cream buff" when dry; "smooth, furfuraceous, neither cracked nor areolate"; margin pruinose, colored as the rest of the surface, (Ginns, herbarium specimens), effused, ceraceous, not cracked; grayish white to pale ochraceous or pinkish buff; even, (Stalpers)
HABITAT  on barkless, well-rotted coniferous wood, apparently associated with a white rot, in BC on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), in Ontario on Pinus resinosa (Red Pine), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine) and Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), and in Quebec on Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir)^, (Ginns), on decayed conifer wood, in Scandinavia Picea abies (Norway Spruce) and Pinus sylvestris (Scotch Pine), on wooden fencing, (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.0-5.0 x 2.5-3.5 um, reniform, ornamented with rather distinct warts, amyloid, thin-walled, "with a small, rounded, distinct apiculus"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (16)20-24(30) x 3-5 um, cylindric, suburniform, some with a ventricose base, sterigmata up to 4.5 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 18-38 x 3.5-5.5 um, "obclavate, clavate, cylindric, apex rounded, sometimes with a small papillate tip, thin-walled, the contents pale yellow in KOH under bright field, granular", sulfo-negative (in herbarium collections stored for more than 20 years, but at least one had been reported sulfo-positive when less old, and European collections have been reported to have sulfo-positive gloeocystidia); HYPHAE monomitic; subiculum compact, indistinct, lacking a layer of parallel hyphae next to the substrate; hyphae 1.5-2.5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with a clamp connection at each septum, (Ginns), SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 2-2.5 um, reniform, finely verrucose, amyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA subcylindric, in the middle constricted, suburniform, sometimes with adventitious septa, normally 4-spored and with basal clamp connection; GLOEOCYSTIDIA (= pseudocystidia) small, 20-30 x 3-5 um, very often with 1 or 2 apical appendices, contents in KOH granular, oily, yellowish, with positive reaction to sulfovanillin; HYPHAE monomitic, 1.5-2.5 um wide, densely intertwined, richly branched, thin-walled, with clamp connections; "subhymenial trama very little developed in the specimens studied", (Eriksson), SPORES 3.5-5 x 2-3.5 um, reniform, warted; BASIDIA 20-30 x 3-5 um, urniform to subcylindric; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 18-38 x 3-5.5 um, often with 1 or 2 apical constrictions, sulfo-positive; HYPHAE 1.5-2.5 um wide, thin-walled, (Stalpers)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with somewhat rough spores'
SIMILAR  A. subasperisporus differs from the Gloeocystidiellum porosum group by 1) the thin, granulose fruitbodies, 2) kidney-shaped spores, 3) suburniform basidia, and 4) generally smaller gloeocystidia, (Ginns).
SOURCES  Ginns(24) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Eriksson(3) (as Gloeocystidiellum subasperisporum), Stalpers(3) (as Gloeocystidiellum subasperisporum)
31
FAMILY  Echinodontiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amylostereum chailletii  (Pers.) Boidin^  Rev. Mycol. (Paris) 23: 345. 1958;  == Thelephora chailletii  (Pers.) Fr.;  Peniophora atkinsonii  Ellis & Everh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on conifer wood, either resupinate or more rarely bent out to form a dark brown cap projecting up to 1cm, 2) a spore-bearing surface that is cinnamon to dark brown and smooth, with a more or less distinct dark brown edge, 3) spores that cylindric to slightly allantoid, smooth, amyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia that are thick-walled with the upper part strongly encrusted, and 5) a hyphal system that is dimitic (thin-walled colorless generative hyphae with clamp connections, and thick-walled brown skeletal hyphae).^ |Amylostereum chailletii has been reported as transmitted and inoculated into dead trees by woodwasps (Sirex spp.): Amylostereum areolatum is a similar species confused with this species in the past, and since A. areolatum is known to be a symbiont with woodwasps, perhaps some of the North American reports of A. chailletii are in fact A. areolatum, (Ginns(5)). |Liu, Shi-Liang(1) provided evidence that this species should be in the family Echinodontiaceae rather than Amylostereaceae. RANGE ^A. chailletii has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, AK, AZ, CA, CO, CT, IA, ME, MI, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, PA, TN, VA, VT, and WI, (Ginns), Sweden (Eriksson), and Europe including Switzerland, Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate [growing flat], or more rarely effuso-reflexed [bent outward from flat growth on wood to form a cap], forming patches several centimeters to decimeters wide and 0.05-0.1cm thick, more or less loosely attached, consistency "waxlike and soft when fresh, brittle and hard when dry"; "cinnamon to dark brown, gray-brown when old, sometimes with a hint of lilac, when dry lighter"; smooth, dull, even to slightly tuberculate, when dry rimose-areolate [cracked]; margin +/- distinctly set off by a dark brown edge; caps if present projecting up to 1cm, with upper surface having fine dark brown tomentum toward edge^, (Breitenbach), small or widely effused, 0.1-0.3cm thick, resupinate or reflexed [flat or bent outward forming a narrow irregular cap]; the cap when present narrow, dark brown, irregular and finely tomentose; the spore-bearing surface "ochraceous to brown often somewhat patchy, when dry usually cracked in small squares", margin of spore-bearing surface somewhat thickened and finely tomentose under a hand lens, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on numerous conifer species; associated with a white rot^, (Ginns), on Picea [spruce] or on cultivated species of Abies [fir], mostly on not too much decayed trunks of 10-25cm diameter, but also on thinner branches, (Eriksson), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-7 x 2.5-3 um, cylindric to slightly allantoid, smooth, amyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 33-45 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 40-50 x 3-6 um, conic, thick-walled, brownish, upper part strongly encrusted, a few thin-walled cystidia without encrustation, 120 x 5 um; HYPHAE dimitic: generative hyphae 2-5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, some branched, septa with clamp connections, and skeletal hyphae 3-4 um wide, thick-walled, brownish, (Breitenbach), SPORES 6-7.5 x 2.5-3 um, cylindric or narrowly elliptic, smooth, amyloid; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 20-25 x 4-5 um, narrow and clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA "yellowish brown, thickwalled and apically encrusted", the encrusted part about 15-20 x 5 um, young cystidia "subulate, thinwalled and smooth", "A few larger, thinwalled, rounded to subulate cystidia often containing oily drops or resinous grains are seemingly of gloeocystidial character, and apparently remain thinwalled"; HYPHAE dimitic with thin-walled generative hyphae that have numerous clamp connections and thick-walled, straight, skeletal hyphae that are light brownish with few clamp connections: there are two distinct layers with different hyphal structures - a subicular or context layer with hyphae more or less parallel to the substrate (richly branched, colorless, clamped, generative hyphae and sparsely branched, straight, brown, skeletal hyphae), and a subhymenial layer with vertical hyphae (with mostly thin-walled to thick-walled generative hyphae 3-4 um wide that enclose encrusted cystidia from previous hymenial levels), (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Veluticeps abietina is similar, but caps are directed downward at an angle, rather than projecting horizontally, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*, Liu, Shi-Liang(1)
32
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Amyloxenasma rallum  (H.S. Jacks.) Hjortstam & Ryvarden^  Syn. Fung. (Oslo) 20: 35. 2005;  == Phlebiella ralla  (H.S. Jacks.) K.H. Larss. & Hjortstam;  == Corticium rallum  H.S. Jacks.;  == Xenasma rallum  (H.S. Jacks.) Liberta
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed wood and bark, 2) a somewhat waxy fruitbody that is gray or bluish gray to light buff, under a lens appearing waxy-pruinose, 3) spores that are elliptic to suballantoid, smooth, weakly amyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia with the base often bifurcate, and 5) hyphae that are nodulose with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Amyloxenasma rallum has been found in BC, OR, ON, IA, MA, NY, and RI, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  thin (in section 0.002-0.006cm thick), effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached], subceraceous [somewhat waxy]; gray or bluish gray to light buff; under a lens appearing waxy-pruinose^, (Liberta), thin, widely effused, adnate, subceraceous; grayish or bluish gray; waxy pruinose, (Jackson)
HABITAT  decayed wood and bark; Acer sp. (maple), Castanea grandidentata (chestnut), Fraxinus sp. (ash), Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Quercus macrocarpa (Bur Oak), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Vitis vulpinus (southern fox grape)^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5 x 2-3.5 um, elliptic and laterally depressed to suballantoid or allantoid, smooth, weakly amyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 7.5-16(24) x 4-5(6) um, cylindric to subclavate, the base bifurcate, often obscure, sterigmata 4-7.5 um long, subulate [awl-shaped], erect; SUBICULUM "either inconspicuous and giving rise to short, upright, nodulose hyphae, or rather thick and composed of hyphae parallel to the substratum, nodose-septate, 1-2.5 um in diam, conglutinate or the walls becoming gelatinized", (Liberta), SPORES 5.5-6.5 x 2.5-3.5 um, elliptic, "straight or more commonly depressed on one side, suballantoid, rounded above and below", smooth, weakly amyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-16 x 4-5 um, clavate or subcylindric, "often bifurcate or inflated at one side", sterigmata 4-5.5 um long, slender, erect; SUBHYMENIUM composed of hyphae 1.5-2.5 um wide, intertwined, nodulose, thin-walled, with clamp connections; SUBICULUM "obscure below", (Jackson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'thin'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Liberta(2) (as Xenasma), Jackson(2) (as Corticium rallum), Ginns(5) (as Phlebiella)
33
FAMILY  Hypoxylaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Annulohypoxylon thouarsianum  (Lev.) Y.M. Ju, J.D. Rogers & H.M. Hsieh^  Mycologia 97(4): 861. 2005;  == Hypoxylon thouarsianum  (Lev.) Lloyd;  == Sphaeria thouarsiana  Lev.;  == Daldinia thouarsiana  (Lev.) Sacc.;  = Hypoxylon malleolus  Berk. & Ravenel;  = Daldinia malleola  (Berk. & Ravenel) Kauffman;  = Hypoxylon occidentale  Ellis & Everh.;  = Hypoxylon gilletianum  Sacc.;  = Hypoxylon thouarsianum  (Lev.) Lloyd  var. gilletianum  (Sacc.) J.H. Mill.;  = Hypoxylon amaniense  Henn.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) hemispheric to spherical growth on wood, especially oak, 2) blackish brown color, interior fibrous-woody and dark brown, 3) blackish granules immediately beneath the surface, with KOH-extractable pigments dull green, and 4) elliptic-inequilateral spores that are brown, with germ slit spore-length on the flattened side.^ RANGE ^It has been found in OR, AL, CA, FL, GA, LA, MS, NC, TX, Costa Rica, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Puerto Rico, French Guiana, Galapagos Is., Peru, South Africa, Uganda, and Tahiti, (Miller, J.H.). Collections were examined from CA, SC, Mexico, Ecuador (Galapagos Is.), South Africa, and Tanzania, (Ju). 
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] 0.8-5cm across and 0.4-3cm thick, hemispheric to spherical; surface blackish brown; with inconspicuous perithecial mounds; "blackish granules immediately beneath surface, with KOH-extractable pigments dull green"; "the tissue below the perithecial layer massive, woody, dark brown"; perithecia obovoid, ostioles papillate, encircled with a sunken but convex H. truncatum-type disc [outermost layer of stroma around ostioles is flaked off gradually from the ostiole outwards], 0.02-0.05cm in diameter^, (Ju), stromata 1-4cm at base and 1-2cm high; spherical to hemispheric; dark brown to black; "surface carbonous, smooth or roughened with projecting perithecia, ostiola papillate, each in center of a slightly sunken, plane, annulate disc, usually with a raised margin", 0.03-0.07cm in diameter; entostroma [interior] "fibrous-woody, with faint lines radiating from a central basal point"; perithecia peripheral, spherical to compressed-spherical, (Miller, J.H.)
HABITAT  on wood, usually limbs with bark, Celtis (hackberry), Persea, and chiefly Quercus (oak)^, (Miller, J.H.)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 14-24 x 4-5.5 um, elliptic-inequilateral, "shriveled, with narrowly rounded ends", "light brown to brown, unicellular", "with straight germ slit spore-length on the flattened side"; "perispore indehiscent in 10% KOH, smooth", epispore smooth^; ASCUS not observed; PERITHECIUM 300-700 um in diameter, 500-1300 um high, obovoid, (Ju), SPORES 17-22 x 5-8.7 um, "elliptic-fusoid and elongate, light to dark brown", uniseriate overlapping; ASCUS very evanescent, 130-140 x 6-10 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, with stem 30-40 um long; PARAPHYSES soon deliquescing; PERITHECIUM 700-1000 um in diameter, spherical to compressed-spherical, (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  the type was collected by "Capitaine du Petit Thouars (Voyage de la Venus), Isles Galapagos"^, (Miller)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Ju(2) (as Hypoxylon thouarsianum), Hsieh(1), Miller, J.H.(1) (as Hypoxylon thouarsianum), Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*
34
FAMILY  Pterulaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aphanobasidium pseudotsugae  (Burt) Boidin & Gilles^  Cryptog. bot. 1(1): 75 1989;  == Phlebiella pseudotsugae  (Burt) K.H. Larss. & Hjortstam  Mycotaxon 29: 317. 1987;  == Corticium pseudotsugae  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on barkless conifer wood, 2) a grayish white to pale ochraceous fruitbody, the surface smooth to rarely tuberculate, 3) spores that are elliptic to fusiform or somewhat almond-shaped, thin-walled to thick-walled, and smooth, 4) basidia that are typically pleural, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Aphanobasidium pseudotsugae has been found in BC, ID, and NY, but the distribution likely more extensive, especially since some authors including Liberta(2) regarded this species as a synonym of Phlebiella filicina (Bourdot) Larsson & Hjortstam, now Aphanobasidium filicinum, (which lacks clamp connections and seems to be obligate on ferns) and numerous reports of Phlebiella filicina on wood may have been based on specimens of P. pseudotsugae, (Ginns). Aphanobasidium pseudotsugae is distributed in the whole of Northern Europe but seems more frequent in the central and northern parts, (Hjortstam(6)).
FRUITING BODY  thin to moderately thick (but inconspicuous in the first stage), resupinate, often widely effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached], when dried rather hard; grayish white to pale ochraceous; "smooth to uneven or uneven or rarely tuberculate", appearing pruinose under a strong lens^, (Hjortstam), very thin (in section 0.0045-0.0055cm), effused, closely adnate, not at all separable; light buff in the herbarium; "even, not shining, not cracked"; margin similar, thinning out, pulverulent [powdery], (Burt), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  particularly on all kinds of barkless conifer wood, "often on rotten wood waste, under foot-bridges, etc."^, (Hjortstam), on barkless, decaying wood or Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock); August to November, (Burt), all year; rarely also on hardwoods, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES somewhat variable in size and shape but as a rule elliptic to fusiform or subamygdaliform [somewhat almond-shaped], thin-walled to moderately thick-walled, smooth, normally 6-8 x 3.5-4.5 um^; BASIDIA cylindric, "slightly constricted, typically pleural", when fully developed usually 20-25 x 6-8 um, 4-spored, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, all with clamp connections, 2.5-4 um wide, thin-walled, "in the subiculum rather sparse, straight and fairly uniform", arranged in more or less parallel fashion, "other hyphae somewhat narrower, intermingled and agglutinated", (Hjortstam), SPORES 3-5 x 2-3 um, even, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored; GLOEOCYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE about 1.5-2 um wide, densely interwoven, conglutinate, not encrusted, section not appreciably colored, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Pseudotsuga' referring to Douglas-fir host
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6) (as Phlebiella), Burt(1) (as Phlebiella), Ginns(5) (as Phlebiella), Liberta(2) (discussing Xenasma filicinum), Buczacki(1)* (as Phlebiella)
35
FAMILY  Pterulaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aphanobasidium subnitens  (Bourdot & Galzin) Julich^  Persoonia 10(3): 326. 1979;  == Phlebiella subnitens  (Bourdot & Galzin) K.H. Larss. & Hjortstam;  == Corticium subnitens  Bourdot & Galzin;  == Xenasma subnitens  (Bourdot & Galzin) Liberta
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed wood, 2) a gelatinous fruitbody that is colorless to whitish gray, 3) spores that are obovate to broadly oblong-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia that are short-cylindric, with a bifurcate base, and 5) hyphae that are parallel to substrate, nodose-septate, and gelatinized.^ RANGE ^Aphanobasidium subnitens has been found in OR and IA, (Ginns), and France, (Liberta).
FRUITING BODY  thin (in section 0.0015-0.003cm thick), effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached], when dry a nearly invisible bloom to a grayish-white vernicose [varnish-like] film, under a lens appearing ceraceous-pruinose [waxy-pruinose], occasionally finely cracked, (Liberta), gelatinous; colorless to whitish gray, (Julich)
HABITAT  on decayed wood of Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Quercus (oak)^, (Liberta)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7(7.5) x 3.5-4.5(5) um, obovate to broadly oblong-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (8)9.5-14 x (4.5)5-7 um, short-cylindric, "borne directly on the horizontal hyphae, the base bifurcate, very often obscure"; HYPHAE (1)2.5-4(5) um wide, parallel to the substrate, nodose-septate, "somewhat irregular, conglutinate or the walls becoming gelatinized", (Liberta), hyphae with gelatinized walls (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Liberta(2) (as Xenasma), Julich(5) (as Phlebiella), Ginns(5) (as Phlebiella)
36
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Asterodon ferruginosus  Pat.^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 10: 130. 1894;  Asterodon setigera  (Peck) Peck;  Hydnochaete setigera  Peck;  Asterostroma ochrostroma  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  A distinctive character of the genus is the presence in the tissues of asterosetae, with 3-5(7) unbranched setae radiating from a central point. Other features of the species include 1) resupinate growth on rotten logs, under roots of old stumps, or in forest litter of mainly coniferous trees, 2) easily detachable, cottony, round fruitbodies, 3-20cm across and up to 0.5cm thick but much more extensive when confluent, the surface brownish orange to cinnamon brown, warted, soon composed of densely arranged teeth, and the margin thin, and radially fibrillose or cobwebby, 3) spores that are broadly elliptic, and colorless, with their walls thin or slightly thickened, 4) hymenial setae, and 5) hyphal system that is trimitic with generative hyphae, skeletal hyphae, and asterosetae.^ | Fruitbodies of this species sometimes grow over the remains of the ones from the previous year, and seem to be layered: one such specimen had 7 layers and was more than 1.5cm thick, (Parmasto). RANGE ^Asterodon ferruginosus has been found in BC, WA, ID, NB, ON, PQ, YT, AK, CT, ME, MI, MT, NH, and NY, (Ginns(5)), and also AR, DE, MA, VT, WI, and Russia, (Parmasto).
FRUITING BODY  "annual, effused, easily detachable from substrate, cottony soft", up to 0.5cm thick, round, 3-20cm across (when confluent up to 500cm long); bright fulvous or ochreous-fulvous to sienna (brownish orange, caramel brown or cinnamon brown); "warted, soon composed of densely arranged teeth", teeth (0.02)0.05-0.2(0.4)cm long, 0.012-0.03(0.04)cm wide, cylindric-conic; margin 0.05-0.2cm wide, "thin, radially fibrillose or almost arachnoid", whitish then colored as rest of surface, later disappearing, "margin and rotten substrate with numerous, sometimes branched, soft, whitish, later brownish mycelial threads" up to 0.07cm wide^, (Parmasto), resupinate, soft and cottony; hymenial surface cinnamon brown to reddish brown; surface hydnaceous; margin with brown rhizomorphs, (Martin), "membranous, hymenial surface whitish grey and covering densely packed spines, subiculum yellow brown, cottony and darkening in KOH", (Ginns(23), regarding the genus)
HABITAT  on bark and barkless wood^; Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Betula alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), P. glauca (White Spruce), P. rubens (Red Spruce), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), P. strobus (Eastern White Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock); associated with a white rot, (Ginns(5)), also Acer rubrum, Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Fagus grandifolia, Populus grandidentata, Tsuga canadensis; on "rotten logs, under roots of old rotten stumps or in forest litter of mainly coniferous trees", (Parmasto)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5(7) x 3.5-4.5 um, broadly elliptic, with one side slightly flattened, walls thin or slightly thickened, [smooth from Parmasto notes on family]^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 17-25(30) x 5-7(8) um, "clavate, some slightly flexuose", sterigmata 4-5 um long, basidioles present, without encrustation; HYPHIDIA rare, 1-2.5(3) um wide, colorless; CYSTIDIA (cystidioles) not numerous, 20-50 x 4-6 um, "mainly situated on top of a tooth, fusoid, with usually cylindric upper part, thin-walled"; HYMENIAL SETAE "numerous, 40-80 x 5-10 um, single or as side branches of setal hyphae, simple or with 2-4 sidebranches at base, 25-80 x 5-10 um, projecting to 40 um, subulate to fusiform, with acute tip, straight, naked, without incrustation"; crystalline matter absent from hymenium; HYPHAE trimitic with 1) generative hyphae numerous, 1.5-3 um wide, with thin, colorless or yellowish walls, septate, branched, 2) skeletal hyphae 1.5-3 um, thick-walled, brownish, 3) asterosetae common, with 3-5(7) unbranched rays, each 30-120(150) x 5-8 um, "in subhymenium smaller than at substrate"; hyphae in teeth more or less parallel, setal hyphae present in teeth, 60-170 x 5-7 um, (Parmasto), SPORES 5-7.5 x 3-4 um, oval to broadly elliptic, colorless; stellately branched setal hyphae abundant in subiculum and hymenium, (Martin), "hymenial setae with rays to 100 um long and occasionally branched, generative hyphae narrow, simple-septate, and skeletal hyphae", (Ginns(23), regarding genus)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ferruginous'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Parmasto(1) (colors from Munsell(1)) (colors in parentheses from Kornerup(1) but using 1967 edition), Martin, K.J.(3), Ginns(5), Ginns(23) (regarding genus)
37
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Asterostroma andinum  Pat.^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 9: 133. 1893;  Asterostroma bicolor  Ellis & Everh.;  Asterostroma spiniferum  Burt;  Asterostroma gracile  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  A notable character is 1) the conspicuous microscopic asterosetae which have 3-6(8) rays up to 150 um long that are not or only rarely dichotomously branched. Other features include 2) resupinate growth on rotten wood, 3) at cottony to cobwebby consistency, 4) light brown fruitbodies, and 5) spores that are round, smooth, and amyloid.^ | In the absence of a comprehensive description of this species, the notes of Martin, K.J.(3) and Ginns(5) on the species are supplemented below with descriptions of three species synonymized with it. RANGE ^Asterostroma andinum has been found in BC, NS, AL, DE, FL, IL, KY, LA, MD, MI, MN, NM, NY, and SC, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  fruitbodies soft, byssoid [cottony] to arachnoid [cobwebby]^, (Martin for A. andinum), effused, 1-6cm x 1-4cm, thin, 0.02-0.03cm thick in section; avellaneous when fresh, becoming whitish in the herbarium; the margin thin, cobwebby, (Burt for A. bicolor), effused, 4cm x 2cm, 0.03-0.035cm thick; pale pinkish buff; subiculum avellaneous, (Burt for A. spiniferum), effused, 0.5-1cm across, very thin, 0.015cm thick, cobwebby, delicate; pale olive-buff; not continuous but with the basidia in clusters; subiculum light drab, (Burt for A. gracile)
HABITAT  on rotten wood^; Acer saccharum (Sugar Maple), Picea sp. (spruce), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on rotten wood of both hardwood and coniferous species but more abundant on the latter, August to November, (Burt for A. bicolor, NY to Louisiana and westward to British Columbia), on rotten wood, July, (Burt for A. spiniferum, Puerto Rico), on very rotten hardwood, October in Alabama, (Burt for A. gracile)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 um in diameter, round to nearly round, smooth, amyloid^; ASTEROSETAE present in subiculum and hymenium, rays of asterohyphidia rarely branched; hyphae simple-septate, (Martin), SPORES 5-7 um in diameter, round, smooth, amyloid; stellate SETAE with 3-6(8) rays up to 150 um long that are not or only rarely dichotomously branched, (Breitenbach), SPORES 5-7 um in diameter, round, smooth, apiculate at the base, white in a spore collection; BASIDIA 4-spored; no CYSTIDIA; STELLATE ELEMENTS rather scattered, colored, with unbranched rays 45-120 um long and 3.5-4.5 um wide; hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, loosely arranged, colorless, (Burt for A. bicolor), SPORES 5-6 um in diameter, nearly round, smooth, colorless; CYSTIDIA sparingly present, 25 x 5 um, not encrusted; STELLATE ELEMENTS colored, not densely crowded together, with unbranched rays 50-90 x 6-7 um usually, "but next to the hymenium having rays perpendicular to the latter, larger than the other rays", up to 130 x 9 um, "and protruding beyond the basidia up to 110 um, like setae"; colorless hyphae arranged longitudinally along the substrate "and passing into a loosely arranged layer and becoming intermixed" with the stellate elements, (Burt for A. spiniferum), SPORES 6 um in diameter, round, smooth, colorless; BASIDIA 15 x 6 um; CYSTIDIA numerous, 30 x 8 um, fusoid, not encrusted; STELLATE ELEMENTS with central body 6 um in diameter and very slender, unbranched rays up to 100-150 x 3-3.5 um, "often protruding beyond the hymenium up to 45 um"; hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, loosely arranged, colorless, (Burt for A. gracilis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to the Andes Mountains'
SIMILAR  Asterostroma cervicolor has tuberculate spores, and the rays of the asterohyphidia are commonly branched, (Martin). Asterostroma laxum also has round, smooth, amyloid spores 5-7 um in diameter, but it has stellate setae up to about 60 um in diameter, with 2-4 rays in part dichotomously branched, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Martin, K.J.(3), Burt(6) (A. bicolor, Asterostroma spiniferum, A. gracile), Breitenbach(2) (discussing Asterostroma laxum), Ginns(5)
38
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Asterostroma cervicolor  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Massee^  J. Linn. Soc., Bot. 25. 155. 1889;  == Corticium cervicolor  Berk. & M.A. Curtis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  A notable character is 1) the conspicuous microscopic asterosetae which are brown and thick-walled with 3-7 unbranched rays 15-60 um long. Other features include 2) resupinate growth on decaying wood and other substrates, 3) effused, thin, spongy fruitbodies that are tawny when fresh but become pallid as basidia develop, the surface pulverulent, the margin paler and fibrillose-flocculose, 4) spores that are round and spiny, and 5) fusoid cystidia, often sharp pointed, not encrusted, projecting beyond the basidia.^ RANGE ^Asterostroma cervicolor has been found in WA, ID, AL, AZ, CA, DC, FL, GA, IA, LA, MA, MD, NC, NH, NY, OH, PA, SC, and VA, (Ginns), and Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico, and Japan, (Burt).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin, irregular, in patches several centimeters across, "loosely attached to substrate, surface smooth or slightly warty" [illustrated as pale yellow-brown]; margin indistinct, finely fibrous, and forming small rhizomorphs; flesh soft and membranous, whitish, brittle when dry; spore deposit white, (Buczacki), effused, thin, (in section 0.015-0.03cm thick), spongy, dry; tawny when fresh, [color also noted to be avellaneous to cinnamon-drab but it is not clear whether this refers to surface or interior], becoming pallid where basidia are well developed; even, pulverulent [powdery]; margin paler and fibrillose-floccose, (Burt)
HABITAT  on structural timber and plaster or concrete associated with timber in buildings, "often causing serious decay", rarely on wood elsewhere; probably all year^, (Buczacki), on decaying wood; earth; outside of a flower pot; Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), A. concolor (White Fir), Liquidambar styraciflua (Sweetgum), Picea glauca (White Spruce), Pinus palustris (Longleaf Pine), P. resinosa (Red Pine), Planera sp., Quercus arizonica (Arizona White Oak), Q. falcata (Southern Red Oak), Q. nigra (Water Oak); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), July to March (Burt)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6 x 5.5-6 um excluding ornamentation, nearly round, coarsely warty, inamyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 um long, elongated clavate; CYSTIDIA abundant, tubular-cylindric to worm-like; SETAE star-shaped; HYPHAE monomitic, (Buczacki); SPORES 4-5 um in diameter, white in spore collections, round, becoming echinulate; BASIDIA 4-spored; CYSTIDIA (?gloeocystidia) 30-45 x 8-12 um, protruding up to 25 um above basidia, fusoid, often sharp-pointed, not encrusted; stellate elements distributed throughout the fruitbody, "conspicuous, colored, thick-walled, rigid", with 3-7, usually about 5, unbranched rays 15-60 um long and 3-3.5 um wide; hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, loosely arranged, colorless, thin-walled, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Asterostroma andinum has smooth spores, and asterosetae are not or only rarely branched. Asterostroma laxum has smooth spores.
SOURCES  Burt(6), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
39
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Asterostroma laxum  Bres.^  in Bourdot & Galzin, Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 36: 46. 1920
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  A notable character is the asterosetae which are up to about 60 um in diameter, stellate, thick-walled, light brown, with 2-4 in part dichotomously branched rays. Other features include 1) resupinate growth on wood and old polypores, 2) fruitbodies that are loosely attached, forming rounded spots at first that become confluent, the consistency thick-membranous and soft, the surface yellow-brown to orange-brown and somewhat tuberculate, and the margin lighter to whitish and finely fringed, 3) spores that are round, smooth, and amyloid, 4) leptocystidia that are without contents and sulfo-negative, and 5) hyphal system that are monomitic, the hyphae thin-walled to thick-walled, without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Asterostroma laxum has been found in ID, MD, and NC, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe (including Switzerland) and in Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached loosely to substrate, forming rounded spots at first, becoming confluent in patches several centimeters across and up to 0.08cm thick, consistency thick-membranous, soft; yellow-brown to orange-brown; somewhat tuberculate; "margin lighter to whitish and finely fringed"^, (Breitenbach), surface smooth or slightly warty; flesh soft, membranous, whitish; margin indistinct; spore deposit white, (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on rotten conifer wood, (according to literature also on old polypores), summer-fall, (Breitenbach), Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Fagus (beech), Quercus (oak); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on rotting conifer wood, especially the underside of fallen logs; summer to fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8 um in diameter, round, smooth, amyloid, colorless, some with droplets (illustrated as one large droplet)^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50 x 5-8 um, cylindric to somewhat ventricose, without basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA (?gloeocystidia) 40-60 x 7-9 um, without contents and sulfo-negative; ASTEROSETAE up to about 60 um in diameter, "stellate, thick-walled, light brown", "with 2-4 in part dichotomously branched rays"; HYPHAE monomitic 2.5-6 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 7-8 x 6-7 um, nearly round, smooth, inamyloid; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50 um long, +/- cylindric; CYSTIDIA broadly spindle-shaped; SETAE star-shaped; HYPHAE monomitic, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'loose'
SIMILAR  Asterostroma andinum also has round, smooth, amyloid spores 5-7 um in diameter, but it has stellate setae with 3-6(8) rays up to 150 um long that are not or only rarely dichotomously branched, (Breitenbach). Asterophora cervicolor has spores that become echinulate (Burt). See also SIMILAR section of Asterostroma cervicolor.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Burt(6) (discussing Asterostroma cervicolor), Buczacki(1)*
40
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelia arachnoidea  (Berk.) Julich^  Beih. Willdenowia 7: 53. 1972;  == Corticium arachnoideum  Berk.;  Corticium bisporum  (J. Schroet.) Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, or occasionally leaves or lichens, 2) thin cottony easily detached patches that are whitish to cream, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) 2-spored basidia, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, with only basal hyphae having scattered clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Athelia arachnoidea has been found in WA, OR, ID, MB, NF, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, GA, IL, LA, MA, MD, MS, MT, NC, NJ, NY, PA, SC, and VT, (Ginns), and Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, USSR, and Tunisia, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  forming thin membranous patches several centimeters wide, easily detached, soft, cottony; whitish to cream; "smooth to slightly undulating, somewhat fissured when dry"; margin "sharply bounded to fringed"^, (Breitenbach), "thin and white, when fresh bluish white and pellicular", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on "branches of hardwoods, with and without bark, more rarely on conifers", (according to literature also on leaves and lichens), throughout the year^, (Breitenbach), on hardwood, conifer wood, and herbs; wood and bark of logs, fallen branches, decaying wood, dead leaves and twigs, humus; Dasylirion wheeleri (desert spoon), Heteromeles sp., Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus sp., Prosopis juliflora (mesquite), Rosa nutkana (Nootka rose), Salix sp. (willow), (Ginns), on hardwood, also as a parasite on lichens, (Eriksson), on rotting wood, also on dead and living leaves, rotting straw, wood-inhabiting algae and lichens; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-10 x 4-5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 2-spored, 15-20 x 4.5-5.5 um, clavate to ventricose; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic: BASAL HYPHAE colorless with a few clamp connections, the other hyphae without clamp connections, hyphae 2.5-5 um wide, "often branched at right angles and incrusted with large crystals", (Breitenbach), SPORES about 8-10 x 4-5 um, narrowly elliptic to narrowly oval; BASIDIA normally 2-spored, 20-30 x 5-7 um, clamp connection absent; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-5 um wide without clamp connections, BASAL HYPHAE "somewhat wider, with slightly thickened walls and with scattered clamps", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to arachnoid (cobwebby) consistency
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Julich(3) (in German), Buczacki(1)*
41
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelia cystidiolophora  Parmasto^  Izv. Akad. Nauk Estonsk. SSR, Ser. Biol. 16: 380. 1967
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a fruitbody that is whitish to pale cream-colored, rather thick in the middle and conspicuously grandinioid, the subiculum scarcely developed, 3) spores that are broadly elliptic and inamyloid, 4) 4-spored basidia, 5) cylindric cystidioles projecting about 15 um beyond the hymenium but at times poorly developed and not always easy to find, and 6) hyphae that are colorless, thin-walled, branching at right angles, with a visible central pore in the septa, but lacking clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Athelia cystidiolophora have been found in BC, Czechoslovakia, and Estonia, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  extending for several centimeters over the substrate, easily separable; whitish to pale cream-colored; in the middle rather thick, frequently and conspicuously grandinioid; subiculum scarcely developed^, (Julich)
HABITAT  Picea abies, Pseudotsuga menziesii^, (Julich)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 x 3-4 um, broadly elliptic, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA mostly 4-spored, 13-16 x 5-6 um, without basal clamp connection, sterigmata about 3-5 x 0.5-0.8 um; cystidioles about 20-30 x 4-5 um, projecting about 15 um beyond the hymenium, more or less cylindric, thin-walled, at times only poorly developed, not always easy to find; hyphae 3-5-5.5 um wide, branching at right angles, colorless, thin-walled (about 0.3 um), central pore distinctly visible going through the cross-walls (septa), clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing cystidioles'
SIMILAR  Athelia decipiens closely resembles A. cystidiolophora, and they may perhaps be varieties of the same species, (Julich).
SOURCES  Julich(3) (in German), Ginns(5)
42
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelia decipiens  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 86. 1958;  == Corticium decipiens  Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Corticium consimile  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood and organic debris, 2) a form consisting of soft thin whitish to ocher patches, with a sharply bounded to fringed margin, 3) spores that are broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia that are 4-spored or 2-spored, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with a central pore visible in the hyphal septa, but lacking clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Athelia decipiens has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NS, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, IL, ME, NH, NJ, NM, NY, PA, and UT, (Ginns), and Austria, Belarus, Czechoslovakia, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Latvia, Norway, Sweden, United Kingdom, Turkey, and the USSR, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, forming thin, membranous patches several centimeters across, soft in consistency, tightly appressed to substrate; whitish to cream to ocher; "smooth to slightly tuberculate, somewhat fissured when dry"; "margin sharply bounded to fringed"^, (Breitenbach), "thin, white, and pellicular", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood and other organic debris^, (Eriksson), on log, on stump; on Abies spp. (fir), Alnus oblongifolia (Arizona Alder), Artemisia tridentata (sagebrush), Carnegiea gigantea (saguaro cactus), Fouquieria splendens (ocotillo), Larix occidentalis (Western Larch), Picea spp. (spruce), Pinus spp. (pine), Thuja occidentalis (Western Hemlock), associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on dead wood (Breitenbach), on rotting wood, also fallen leaves, soil and decaying grass stems; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 3-3.5 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA mostly 2-spored, 22-25 x 5-6 um, clavate to ventricose; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, with hyphae 2.5-5 um wide, colorless, "not or only slightly incrusted, septa without clamps but with distinctly visible central pore", (Breitenbach), SPORES 4.5-5.5(6) x 3-3.5 um, elliptic to ovate, often glued together in groups of 2 or 4; BASIDIA about 12-15 x 5 um, "the sub-basidial cells often somewhat widened or swollen because of sidebranches developing from them"; HYPHAE monomitic 3-5 um wide, without clamp connections, often with a grainy encrustation, (Eriksson), SPORES 5.5-6 x 3-3.8 um; BASIDIA usually 4-spored, more rarely 2-spored, 10-14 x 5-6 um; hyphae with central pore of septa mostly distinctly visible, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'deceiving'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Athelia cystidiolophora and Athelia salicum.
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Julich(3) (in German), Buczacki(1)*
43
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelia epiphylla  Pers.^  Mycol. Eur. 1: 84. 1822
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood and other plant remains, 2) a white to cream fruitbody forming thin, membranous patches several centimeters across, 3) spores that are 6-10 x 2.5-5 um for the wide concept of the species, (6-7.5 x 2.8-3.2 um for the narrower concept), more or less elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) (2)4-spored basidia, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with occasional clamp connections in the basal hyphae but none in subhymenium or on basidia.^ | The description of Eriksson is for a wider concept of the species than that of Julich(1972), and includes Athelia salicum Pers. as well as several other species not recorded from the Pacific Northwest, but according to Breitenbach(2), Julich & Stalpers(1980) include several species in A. epiphylla, including A. salicum Pers. (Ginns(5) however maintains A. salicum Pers. as separate.) RANGE ^Athelia epiphylla has been found in BC, ID, AB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, IL, MA, MT, NY, OH, and UT, and for A. salicum also WA, CT, ME, NC, NH, NJ, and WI, (Ginns). Distribution includes Venezuela, Austria, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Latvia, Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, Turkey, USSR, and for A. salicum also Poland, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  "fully resupinate, easily loosened from the substrate, forming thin, membranous patches" several centimeters across, consistency cottony, soft; surface white to cream; smooth; margin distinctly bounded to thinning out^, (Breitenbach), "thin, white to light yellowish", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on plant remains such as branches, leaves, needles, etc., throughout the year, (Breitenbach), hosts include hardwoods and conifers, colonizing recently felled needles and twigs under snowbanks, symbiotic with filamentous Cyanophyceae (algae), (Ginns), hardwood and coniferous wood, dead lichens, leaves, etc., (Eriksson), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-10 x 3-5 um, subcylindric, narrowly elliptic or oval^; BASIDIA usually 4-spored, 15-20 x 5-6 um; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-5 um wide and without clamp connections, BASAL HYPHAE somewhat wider and with clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES (5)6-8 x 2.5-3.5 um, elliptic with obtuse base, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored or more rarely 2-spored, 18-22 x 4.5-6.5 um, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, BASAL HYPHAE 3.5-6 um wide, with occasional clamp connections, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-4.5 um wide, some coarsely encrusted, without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES (5.5)6-7.5(8) x 2.8-3.2 um, BASIDIA (2-)4-spored, 13-18 x 5-8 um, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'on leaves'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Athelia salicum.
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Julich(3) (1972 in German), Buczacki(1)*
44
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelia laxa  (Burt) Julich^  Beih. Willdenowia 7: 90. 1972;  == Peniophora laxa  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a broadly effused, thin, waxy-membranaceous fruitbody, loosely attached to the substrate, with a whitish, margin thinning out and fibrillose with some mycelial threads, 3) spores that are round, smooth, and inamyloid with a distinct apiculus, 4) (2)4-spored basidia, 5) projecting cystidia sometimes found that are capitate but not encrusted, and 6) hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Athelia laxa has been found in BC, CT, PA, and VA, (Julich(3)).
FRUITING BODY  "broadly effused, thin, waxy-membranaceous", in section 0.02-0.03cm thick, loosely attached to substrate by a cottony subiculum; surface probably white when growing, in the herbarium pale ivory-yellow; even, not much cracked; "margin thinning out, fibrillose, with some mycelial threads"^, (Burt), thin, pellicular to slightly membranous; whitish to cream; sometimes with a few narrow hyphal strands, (Julich)
HABITAT  BC specimen in woods "on bark with the wood underneath wholly decayed", December, (Burt), hosts Tsuga sp., Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6 um in diameter, round, smooth^; BASIDIA 4-spored, up to 6 um wide; CYSTIDIA 4.5-6 um wide, protruding about 30-50 um beyond the basidia, often capitate and 6-9 um wide at top, cystidia "not incrusted or with only a few incrusting granules"; no gloeocystidia; the compact hymenium supported by a very broad layer of hyphae 1.5-2 um wide (rarely 3 um wide), "loosely interwoven, thin-walled, granule-incrusted", "with the hyphae more densely arranged in the middle zone of this layer", (Burt), SPORES (5.5)6-6.5(7) um, round, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled (up to 0.3 um thick), with distinct apiculus; BASIDIA 18-33 x 6.5-8.5 um, +/- clavate; LEPTOCYSTIDIA 40-50 x 6-7 um, projecting up to 30 um, the upper capitate part 7-8 um wide, thin-walled, smooth, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE 2-2.5(3) um wide, colorless to slightly yellowish, thin-walled (up to 0.3 um thick), (Julich(5)), SPORES (5.5)6-6.5(7) um, colorless, inamyloid, with distinct apiculus, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled (0.2-0.3 um); BASIDIA mostly 4-spored, rarely 2-spored, 18-33 x 6.5-8.5 um, clamped at base; CYSTIDIA relatively rare, not found immediately in all specimens, about 40-50 x 6-7 um, projecting about 30-50 um beyond the hymenium, capitate on the end (7-8 um wide), thin-walled, colorless, with a large clamp connection at the base, not encrusted; hyphae about 2-2.5(3) um wide, colorless to pale yellowish, walls thin to somewhat thick (about 0.3 um), rarely anastomosing, clamp connections on all septa, crystals between the hyphae relatively frequent, (Julich(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'loose'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Burt(7) (as Peniophora laxa), Julich(5), Julich(3) (in German), Ginns(5)
45
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelia munda  (H.S. Jacks. & Dearden) M.P. Christ.^  Dansk Bot. Ark. 19: 155. 1960;  == Peniophora munda  H.S. Jacks. & Dearden  Mycologia 43: 58. 1951;  Leptosporomyces mundus  (H.S. Jacks. & Dearden) Julich
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a soft, white, membranous-pelliculose fruitbody, the margin not especially differentiated, 3) spores that are elongated, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) 4-spored basidia, 5) cystidia that are cylindric or narrowly obclavate, and 6) a subiculum of thin hyphae with clamp connections, the walls usually heavily encrusted with crystals.^ RANGE ^Athelia munda has been found in BC, AZ, CA, CO, NJ, and WY, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  extensive, irregularly effused over the substrate, soft membranous-pelliculose; white; "margin gradually thinning out, not especially differentiated"; subiculum loose^, (Jackson)
HABITAT  on bark; rotting stump; Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Abies magnifica (California Red Fir), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock)^; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), decaying wood inside rotting stump; inside crevices of fallen coniferous log, (Jackson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3-4 x 1.5-2 um, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 6-8 x 3-4 um, cylindric to subclavate, developed from SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE in cymose clusters through progressive proliferation from clamp connections, sterigmata upright, slender, slightly arcuate; CYSTIDIA 25-45 x 2.5-3.5 um, extending two thirds of their length beyond the hymenium, cylindric or narrowly obclavate, somewhat flexuous [wavy], thin-walled, unencrusted; SUBICULUM made up of hyphae 1-2 um wide, fine, horizontal or irregularly interwoven, thin-walled, with clamp connections, walls usually heavily encrusted with crystals, (Jackson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'clean, neat, elegant'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Jackson(4) (as Peniophora munda), Ginns(5), Julich(3) (as Leptosporomyces mundus, in German)
46
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelia rolfsii  (Curzi) C.C. Tu & Kimbr.^  Bot. Gaz. (Crawfordsville) 139: 460. 1978;  == Corticium rolfsii  Curzi
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on many genera of plants, 2) a whitish to creamy-white pellicular fruitbody, loosely adherent to the substrate, the surface merulioid, but becoming smooth on drying, usually associated with a sclerotial state, the sclerotia 0.05-0.2cm across, light to dark brown, and smooth or pitted, 3) spores that are smooth, inamyloid, and nearly round to elliptic, 4) 4-spored basidia, and 5) subicular hyphae with rare clamp connections.^ | This is a "soil-borne pathogen, commonly found as the Sclerotium rolfsii [italicized] state, which causes southern blight, also called southern Sclerotium blight and Sclerotium root rot, of turfgrasses and herbaceous plants, many of which are important crop plants, e.g., sugar beets and field beans, also southern root rot of seedlings", (Ginns). RANGE ^Athelia rolfsii has been found in WA, OR, AL, AR, AZ, CA, CT, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, MD, MO, MS, NC, NJ, NY, OH, OK, PA, SC, TN, TX, and VA, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused, in patches usually 1-2cm across, sometimes up to 6cm, pellicular, usually 0.005-0.01cm thick, (sometimes up to 0.3-0.5cm thick depending on the substrate), loosely adherent to the substrate and separable; spore-bearing surface "coriaceous-membranous, merulioid, but becoming smooth on drying, whitish to creamy-white"; rhizomorphs absent; usually associated with a sclerotial state, sclerotia 0.05-0.2cm across, light to dark brown, smooth or pitted^, (Punja)
HABITAT  cosmopolitan, affecting 225 known genera of host plants^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-7 x 3-5 um, nearly round to elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, "with distinct apiculus giving a tear-drop appearance", binucleate^; BASIDIA in clusters, mostly 4-spored, (11.5)15.5-19(26) x (4)5-6(6.5) um, clavate, without a basal clamp connection, "3-4 basidial generations are produced, but usually not resulting in a significant increase" in thickness of the fruitbody; CYSTIDIA lacking; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, loosely arranged, colorless, simple-septate with rare clamp connections, binucleate; hyphae of sclerotium "with clamps at some septa, branching at acute angles, with 2-9 nuclei per cell", (Punja)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Punja(1), Ginns(5)
47
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelia salicum  Pers.^  Mycol. Eur. 1: 84. 1822
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) whitish to light gray or light cream fruitbodies forming patches several centimeters wide, 3) spores that are (5.5)6-7.5(8) x 3.5-4.5 um and inamyloid, 4) basidia (2)4-spored, and 5) monomitic hyphal system with occasional clamp connections on basal hyphae, but no clamp connections on other hyphae.^ | This species is a member of the Athelia epiphylla complex and is included by Eriksson(1973) in a wider concept of that species, but Julich(3) (1972), Julich(5) (1980), and Ginns(5) (1993) maintain it as separate. RANGE ^Athelia salicum has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, NS, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CT, IL, ME, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NY, OH, and WI, (Ginns), and Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and the USSR, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  forming patches several centimeters wide, closely attached, the subiculum little developed; whitish to light gray or light cream^, (Julich(3)), thin, pellicular; whitish to cream, (Julich(5)), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  Acer circinatum, Betula occidentalis, Quercus sp.^, (Ginns), Abies, Picea, Pinus, Thuja, Tsuga, Acer, Alnus, Betula, Calluna, Carpinus, Castanea, Fagus, Malus, Populus, Quercus, Sambucus, Ulmus, lichens, other fungi (Asterodon, Hymenochaete, Tyromyces), (Julich(3)); all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5.5)6-7.5(8) x 3.5-4.5 um, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, with distinct apiculus^; BASIDIA mostly 4-spored, rarely 2-spored, 10-16 x 5.5-8 um, cylindric to clavate; hyphae about 3-8(10) um wide, the basal hyphae wider than the subhymenial hyphae, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled (0.2-0.5 um), occasional clamp connections on basal hyphae, otherwise absent, (Julich(3)), most collections have encrusted hyphae (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Athelia decipiens is similar to some material identified as this species but has no clamp connections, (Eriksson). Athelia epiphylla sensu stricto has narrower spores (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Julich(3) (in German), Julich(5), Ginns(5), Eriksson(2) (under Athelia epiphylla) Breitenbach(2) (under Athelia epiphylla), Buczacki(1)*
48
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelia scutellaris  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Gilb.^  Fungi that Decay Ponderosa Pine, 42. 1974;  == Corticium scutellare  Berk. & M.A. Curtis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood limbs, 2) a thin, whitish fruitbody, the surface cracked when mature exposing cobwebby subiculum, 3) spores that are small, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) 4-spored basidia, 5) hyphae with clamp connections, the hyphae encrusted in the subhymenial area.^ RANGE ^Athelia scutellaris has been found in BC, MB, ON, AZ, AL, DC, FL, GA, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MO, MS, NC, NJ, NM, NY, PA, SC, and VA, (Ginns).
