FRUITING BODY  resupinate, long and widely effused [spread out], 2-8cm x 1-4cm, thin, 0.012-0.025cm thick in section, adnate [tightly attached], "from white becoming cream-buff to warm buff in the herbarium"; waxy, often granular, finally cracked, the cracking pattern may be into minute areolae less than 0.1cm (and often flaking away), or into more rectangular masses up to 2cm wide; margin thinning out^, (Burt), pellicular, thin, becoming widely effused; white; "cracking and exposing the white, loosely interwoven, arachnoid subiculum in the fissures", (Gilbertson)
HABITAT  on fallen decaying limbs of hardwoods^ (Burt), Acer saccharum (Sugar Maple), Aesculus octandra (Yellow Buckeye), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Arundinaria gigantea subsp. tecta (switch cane), Cytisus scoparius (Scottish broom), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Morus rubra (Red Mulberry), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus sp., Quercus sp. (oak), Rhododendron canescens (Piedmont azalea), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-6 x 2-3 um, smooth, colorless^; CYSTIDIA absent; hyphae 2.5-3.5 um wide, "suberect, interwoven, thin-walled", "incrusted in the subhymenial region so as to form a conspicuous subhymenial zone of mineral matter", (Burt), SPORES 4-5 x 2-3 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 3.5-4 um wide, clavate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-4 um wide, "thin-walled to moderately thick-walled, nodose-septate, conspicuously incrusted in the subhymenial zone", (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Burt(1) (as Corticium scutellare), Gilbertson(9), Ginns(5)
49
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelopsis lembospora  (Bourdot) Oberw.^  Persoonia 7: 3. 1972;  == Corticium lembosporum  Bourdot
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, ferns, and horsetails, 2) a fruitbody that is pellicular, loosely adnate, and whitish, with a smooth surface and a margin that is not especially differentiated, 3) inamyloid spores that are short-allantoid and broadened toward the base, 4) 4-spored basidia with a stem, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae thin-walled with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Athelopsis lembospora has been found in OR and CA, (Ginns), and also in Europe.
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused, pellicular, loosely adnate; whitish; smooth; margin not especially differentiated^ (Hjortstam), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  collected on Athyrium filix-femina (lady fern), Dryopteris (wood fern), Equisetum pratense (meadow horsetail), and on hardwood, not known from conifer wood^, (Hjortstam), on wood and twigs; hosts not known in North America (Ginns), on rotting fern and rush debris, rarely on rotting hardwood or other woody debris; fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-8 x 3 um (generally), short-allantoid, broadened toward base, inamyloid, thin-walled, often glued together in pairs^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-25 x 5-7 um, clavate, tapering toward the more or less stemmed base; CYSTIDIA absent, "but in some collections with paraphysoid hyphae between the basidia"; HYPHAE monomitic; BASAL HYPHAE 2-2.5 um, straight and uniform, thin-walled, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE more branched and slightly broader, all hyphae with clamp connections, (Hjortstam)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with boat-shaped spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(2), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
50
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Athelopsis subinconspicua  (Litsch.) Julich^  Persoonia 8: 292. 1975;  == Corticium subinconspicua  Litsch. in Pilat and V. Lindtner;  Athelopsis hypochnoidea  Julich
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) pellicular to hypochnoid fruitbodies that are light yellowish with a faint greenish tint, the surface even and the margin thinning out, 3) spores that are broadly cylindric to broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, and 4) a monomitic hyphal system with clamp connections.^ | The Eriksson description is for Athelopsis hypochnoidea Julich, given by Ginns (fide Julich) as a synonym. RANGE ^Athelopsis subinconspicua has been found in BC, ON, and PQ, (Ginns), and Europe including Norway and Sweden (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, effused, hypochnoid to soft-pellicular"; "light yellowish with a rather faint greenish tint", surface even; margin thinning out^, (Julich), "thin, pellicular"; "light yellowish and sometimes with a light greenish tint", (Eriksson)
HABITAT  saprophytic on rotten wood^, (Julich), on fallen log (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-7.5 x 4-4.5 um, broadly cylindric to broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, acyanophilic, contents granulose or slightly guttulate, with distinct apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 13-18 x 4-5 um, stemmed-cylindric, colorless, thin-walled, with a basal clamp connection, the sterigmata about 3.5 x 1 um, "the contents homogeneous or slightly granulose"; CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHAE monomitic; hyphae 2-3 um wide, cylindric, colorless, rather thin-walled (about 0.3 um thick), "with clamps at all septa, the surface smooth or slightly covered with small granules or crystals", (Julich), SPORES 6.5-8 x 4-4.5 um, elliptic, smooth, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 15-20 x 5 um, clavate, with basal stem; CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHAE monomitic, of hyphae 2.5-3.5 um wide, very loosely arranged, thin-walled, colorless, clamped, BASAL HYPHAE are straight and sparsely branched at right angles, while SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE are more abundantly branched, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'somewhat inconspicuous', which is rather misleading since it is yellowish-greenish and in most cases easily seen, but the type happened to grow on rotten wood of almost the same color, (Julich)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2) (as Athelopsis hypochnoidea), Ginns(5), Julich(4)
51
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Basidiodendron caesiocinereum  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Luck-Allen^  Can. J. Bot. 41: 1036. 1963 [as B. caesiocinerium];  Corticium caesiocinereum  Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Bourdotia caesiocinerea  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Bourdot & Galzin;  Sebacina caesiocineria  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) D.P. Rogers;  Sebacina cinerella  (Bourdot & Galzin) Killerm.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on very rotten wood, 2) fruitbodies that are thin, waxy, and whitish to pale gray, 3) spores that are nearly round with a prominent apiculus, inamyloid, and smooth to finely punctate, germinating by repetition or by germ tubes produced at the non-apiculate end, 4) basidia longitudinally septate and borne in clusters of 2-3 at the ends of fertile hyphae that are sheathed on the sides by collapsed basidia, each new basidium splitting longitudinally into 2 to 4 cells, and 5) ascus-shaped gloeocystidia that sometimes have brown content and may have capitate ends.^ | The neuter ending is correct for Greek nouns ending in -dendron (ICN Melbourne Code 62.2). RANGE ^Basidiodendron caesiocinereum has been found in BC, OR, ON, PQ, AZ, FL, IA, MA, ME, MO, NM, NY, and RI, (Ginns), North America, Europe including Switzerland, Asia, and Africa, (Breitenbach), and Hawaii and Austria, (Martin).
FRUITING BODY  "fully resupinate, attached tightly to substrate, forming thin waxlike patches several centimeters to decimeters in extent", consistency wax-like, soft; "whitish-gray, sometimes with a slight pink tint, darker when dry"; "smooth, dull, finely pubescent under a lens"; margin tenuous^, (Breitenbach), forming a thin, waxy layer (in section 0.003-0.007(0.009)cm thick); whitish to pale gray, drying to pale gray; "appearing minutely porose-reticulate, almost continuous under a lens", (McGuire), very thin, 0.00026-0.0075(0.009)cm, waxy; whitish to "pearl gray"; "pruinose, on drying pruinose-reticulate to continuous and occasionally becoming crust-like, thinning toward the margin and porous-reticulate, often granulose, indeterminate", (Luck-Allen), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on very rotten hardwood and conifer wood, usually barkless^; Arbutus (madrone), Fraxinus (ash), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Quercus (oak), (Ginns), on bark and decayed wood, especially of Abies (fir), Pinus, Fagus (beech), and Betula (birch), (Luck-Allen), on very rotten hardwood lying on the ground, also on conifer wood, in very damp areas, summer-fall, (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8 x (5)6-7.5 um, nearly round, inamyloid, smooth to very finely punctate, colorless, with drops, with distinct apiculus^; HYPOBASIDIA 10-15 x 7-9(10) um, oval, longitudinally septate, with 2-4 epibasidia; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 30-50 x 6-9 um, ascus-shaped, sinuous, sometimes with brown contents; hyphae 1-3 um wide, gelatinized, "with gnarled branches, indistinctly visible", no septa observed, (Breitenbach), SPORES 5-7.5 in diameter, round, "with peglike apiculi 1-2 um long"; fertile hyphae "erect, tortuous, subdistinct", 1-1.5 um wide, "each bearing 2-3 basidia at the apex and a sheath of collapsed basidial walls down the sides", probasidia "at first obovate, finally ovate", colorless, 10-13.5 x 7.5-8.5 um, "becoming tardily and indistinctly two to four-celled by longitudinal division", epibasidia 5-8 um long including sterigmata, 3 um thick at base; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 25-40(60) x 4-8(15) um, "cylindric-clavate, sinuous, often expanding apically into globose heads up to 15 um in diameter", with contents at first colorless, soon brownish, (McGuire), SPORES 5-9 um in diameter, round, "very minutely roughened, at times roughening indistinct", "prominent apiculus measuring up to 2 um, germinating by repetition or by germ tubes produced at the non-apiculate end"; BASIDIA at first 2-celled, "eventually 4-celled with septum at times indistinct", 11-17(19) x 8-10, urniform, elongate, "produced in groups of 2-3(4) terminally on fertile axis", sterigmata 5-12 um long, "subulate, divergent, or incurved", PROBASIDIA 9-13 x 5-8 um, obovate, with clamp connections at bases; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 15-50 x (3)4.5-8(18) um, "cylindric, sometimes tapering toward the apex, cylindric-clavulate or irregular with contents hyaline, then yellowish, finally resinous, fragmented, infrequently septate, flexible, non-projecting"; hyphae in a thin horizontal layer, at times agglutinated, running parallel with substrate and connecting up with erect, ascending, fertile and sterile hyphae, fertile hyphae 2-3(4.5) um wide and up to 45 um long, "nodulose, tortuous, ascending", "with a sheath of collapsed basidia extending down the sides of the fertile columns almost to the base", (Luck-Allen)
NAME ORIGIN  from 'caesius' meaning 'bluish gray', and 'cinereus', meaning 'ash-gray'
SIMILAR  Basidiodendron eyrei has smooth spores with an obscure apiculus, (Luck-Allen). Basidiodendron fulvum (at least as B. grandinioides) has an interrupted granulate, tuberculate hymenium and spores measuring 3 x 2.5-3 um that have the shortest axis often through the minute apiculus (from Luck-Allen). Basidiodendron cinerea has and interrupted hymenium, and spores 8-11 x 6-8 um (from Luck-Allen). Basidiodendron pini has basidia generally more than 20 um long, and fertile sheaths are not sheathed by involucres of collapsed basidia, (from Luck-Allen).
SOURCES  Luck-Allen(1) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Breitenbach(2)*, McGuire(1) (as Sebacina), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Sebacina), Ginns(5)
52
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Basidiodendron cinereum  (Bres.) Luck-Allen^  Can. J. Bot. 41: 1043. 1963 [as B. cinerea];  Sebacina cinerea  Bres.;  Bourdotia cinerea  (Bres.) Bourdot & Galzin;  Sebacina murina  Burt;  Sebacina gloeocystidiata  Kuehner
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) fruitbodies that are thin and waxy, drying to ash-gray or ochraceous gray, the margin not well defined, 3) spores that are oblong to broadly ovate, and guttulate, and germinate by repetition, 4) basidia produced in clusters at the end of an ascending fertile hypha, leaving the previous basidia collapsed like an involucre lower on the fertile hypha, each new basidium splitting longitudinally into 2 to 4 cells, 5) dendrophyses or simple paraphysoids coming from clamp connections on the fertile hyphae, and 6) gloeocystidia that are cylindric or clavate-cylindric, with colorless then yellowish contents that become resinous.^ | The neuter ending is correct for Greek nouns ending in -dendron (ICN Melbourne Code 62.2). RANGE ^Basidiodendron cinereum has been found in BC, OR, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, IA, IN, LA, MI, NM, OH, and UT, (Ginns). It has also been found in Panama and Europe (Martin).
FRUITING BODY  effused (forming a patch on the wood), edge not well defined, thin, waxy; drying to a plainly visible cinereous (ash-gray) or ochraceous gray layer; very minutely porous-reticulate^, (Martin), thin, waxy-gelatinous or arid-waxy, drying smooth or pruinose-reticulate, occasionally vernicose [varnish-like]; varying from grayish white to "pale drab gray" or "pale ochraceous buff", becoming clay color when older, (Luck-Allen), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on rotten barkless conifer wood and hardwood^, (Martin), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Acer saccharum (Sugar Maple), Fagus grandifolia (American Beech), Pinus longaeva (Bristlecone Pine), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Platanus wrightii (Arizona Sycamore), Quercus sp. (oak), Salix sp. (willow), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Tilia americana (American Basswood), (Ginns), on bark and decayed wood of Thuja occidentalis, Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Abies balsamea, Populus spp., Salix spp. (willow), Fraxinus spp. (ash), Fagus grandifolia, (Luck-Allen), on rotting wood, tree fern debris, on Fuchsia; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (7)9-12(14) x 5-8(9) um, oblong to broadly ovate, usually adaxially flattened, guttulate, germinating by repetition^; PROBASIDIA 10-12-16.5 x 9-12-14 um, obovate to ovate, granular-opaque, becoming 2-4-celled by longitudinal division, epibasidia 8-14-25 x 3 um, subulate to subcylindric; hymenium consisting of erect fertile hyphae and gloeocystidia arising directly from substratum or subiculum, GLOEOCYSTIDIA 15-25-60 x 4-7(9) um, "clavate to cylindric, often expanded at apex, flexuous, thin-walled, sometimes incrusted", colorless, then brownish, BASIDIA - fertile branches "erect, tortuous, 1-2 um, the immature basidia clustered at the tips, borne terminally and on very short lateral proliferations from indistinct clamp-connections at the bases of older basidia, the clamps and proliferations and the collapsed walls of the older basidia forming a sheath about each fertile branch"; in section, 30-70(100) um thick, the thicker parts with a granular subiculum of agglutinated hyphae, (Martin), SPORES 8-11(13) x 6-8 um, "ovate to oblong, flattened on one side and slightly curved, guttulate, apiculate", "germinating by repetition or by germ-tube formation"; BASIDIA at the surface obovate, often elongating, becoming 2-celled to 4-celled by longitudinal septum, "with clamp connections at base and short lateral proliferations which grow out from indistinct clamps", sterigmata 8-15(25) x 2-3 um, "cylindric with blunt apex, or subulate", probasidia 10.5-15 x 8-13 um, pyriform to obovate; DENDROPHYSES or simple PARAPHYSOIDS present, 1-2 um wide, "straight or tortuous, emanating from clamps on system of fertile hyphae, generally nonemergent"; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 16-35(60) x 4-7.5 um, "flexuous, cylindric to clavate-cylindric, rarely incrusted", with colorless then yellowish contents that finally become resinous, fragmented, gloeocystidia "originating from a basal layer of indistinct hyphae or from clamps on fertile branches"; hyphae in a basal layer next to substrate composed of hyphae 1.5-2 um wide that are indistinct, agglutinated, and horizontal, fertile branches ascending 1.5-2.5 um wide, with "prominent nodes occurring along the sides of stalks subtending old and collapsed basidia forming an involucre and bearing at the apices, in clusters, younger basidia", (Luck-Allen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ash-gray'
SIMILAR  Basidiodendron eyrei and B. caesiocinerea have nearly round spores. Basidiodendron fulvum (at least as B. grandinioides) has much smaller spores measuring 3 x 2.5-3 um with the shortest axis often through the minute apiculus, (from Luck-Allen). Basidiodendron pini has basidia generally more than 20 um long, and fertile sheaths are not sheathed by involucres of collapsed basidia, (from Luck-Allen).
SOURCES  Luck-Allen(1) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Sebacina cinerea), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
53
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Basidiodendron eyrei  (Wakef.) Luck-Allen^  Can. J. Bot. 41: 1034. 1963;  Bourdotia eyrei  (Wakef.) Bourdot & Galzin;  Sebacina eyrei  Wakef.;  Basidiodendron deminutum  (Bourdot) Luck-Allen;  Sebacina deminuta  Bourdot;  Corticium involucrum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on rotten wood, 2) a thin, waxy, tightly attached fruitbody that is whitish to gray becoming buff, with a pruinose surface, 3) spores that are nearly round, minutely apiculate, and colorless or guttulate, and germinate by repetition, 4) erect fertile hyphae with 2-3 basidia clustered at top and many collapsed basidia sheathing the sides, each new basidium splitting longitudinally into 2 to 4 cells, and 5) gloeocystidia that are subcylindric, colorless to yellow brown, and not emerging.^ RANGE ^Basidiodendron eyrei has been found in BC, WA, OR, AB, ON, PQ, AK, AZ, CA, CO, IA, IN, LA, MA, MN, MS, NH, NJ, NY, OH, UT, and VT, (Ginns), Austria, (Luck-Allen), and the United Kingdom (McGuire).
FRUITING BODY  very thin, in section 0.005- 0.015cm, waxy, closely adnate [tightly attached]; whitish to gull gray becoming pale cinnamon buff, drying cinereous or light pinkish cinnamon to ochraceous-tawny; pruinose, drying to porous-reticulate or continuous; the margins thinning out or farinaceous [mealy]^, (McGuire), thin, waxy, grayish, (L.S. Olive), somewhat similar to Basidiodendron caesiocinerea but different microscopically (see MICROSCOPIC and SIMILAR), (Luck-Allen), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on rotten deciduous and conifer wood^, (Luck-Allen), Abies sp. (fir), Acer sp. (maple), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific madrone), Betula alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), Fagus sp. (beech), Fraxinus sp. (ash), Juglans major (Arizona Walnut), Picea sp. (spruce), Picea pungens (Blue Spruce), Pinus sp. (pine), Pinus aristata (Bristlecone Pine), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Populus sp., Populus fremontii (Fremont Cottonwood), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Prunus americana (American plum), Quercus sp. (oak), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Ulmus sp. (elm), Phellinus sp. (polypore); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-6.5 um, nearly round, minutely apiculate, colorless or guttulate, germinating by repetition^; fertile hyphae 1.5-2.5 um wide, erect, tortuous, arising almost directly from the wood to the surface, with 2-3 basidia clustered at the apex and a sheath of collapsed basidia down the sides, PROBASIDIA 8-11-13 x 6-8 um, "at first obovate, finally elongate-urniform", "becoming indistinctly longitudinally septate, 2-4 celled", epibasidia 5-9 um long, subulate, at first divergent then incurved; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 15-50 x 3.5-7 um, sinuous, subcylindric, with contents at first colorless, later yellowish brown, often fragmented, reaching the surface only in young fruitbodies and never emerging, (McGuire), SPORES round 5-7 um in diameter, or nearly round 5-7 x 4-5 um, smooth, with obscure mucronate apiculus, germinating by repetition or by germ tube, apparently through the apiculate end; PROBASIDIA 7.5-10.5 x 6-7.5 um, pyriform to obovate, mature basidia 8-14(15) x 6-8 um, "urniform, elongate, indistinctly longitudinally septate", at first 2-celled to 3-celled, finally 4-celled; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 10-45 x 3-6 um, (Luck-Allen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Basidiodendron caesiocinerea has round spores that are minutely roughened and provided with definite blunt peg-like apiculi (the apiculus of B. eyrei shows up as a slight hump on the spore), and B. caesiocinerea also has larger more elongate-urniform basidia, and wider gloeocystidia, (from Luck-Allen). B. eyrei is distinguished from B. caesiocinerea by its usually more elongate basidia and its smaller, minutely apiculate spores, (McGuire). Basidiodendron fulvum (at least as Basidiodendron grandinioides) has spores measuring 3 x 2.5-3 um, that are elliptic, with the shortest axis often through the minute apiculus, (from Luck-Allen). Basidiodendron cinerea has spores 8-11 x 6-8 um, (from Luck-Allen). Basidiodendron pini has basidia generally more than 20 um long, and fertile sheaths are not sheathed by involucres of collapsed basidia, (from Luck-Allen). See also SIMILAR section of Basidiodendron caesiocinereum and Basidiodendron cinereum.
SOURCES  Luck-Allen(1), McGuire(1) (as Sebacina), Ginns(5), Olive(2), Buczacki(1)*
54
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Basidiodendron fulvum  (Massee) Ginns^  Opera Bot. 61: 54. 1982;  Coniophora fulva  Massee;  Bourdotia grandinioides  Bourdot & Galzin;  Basidiodendron grandinioides  (Bourdot & Galzin) Luck-Allen;  Sebacina grandinioides  (Bourdot & Galzin)  D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead hardwood, 2) a fleshy pale yellow-brown fruitbody, under a hand lens appearing porose-reticulate, powdery, granular, and tuberculate, often pulling away in areas leaving knots of tissue connected by radiating strands, 3) spores that are short-elliptic, with the shortest axis often through the minute apiculus, germinating by repetition, 4) fertile hyphae with 2-3 basidia clustered at the end and many collapsed basidia sheathing the sides, each new basidia splitting longitudinally into 2 to 4 cells, and 5) gloeocystidia that are subfusiform, filled with yellow, often fragmented contents.^ | The description given here is derived from that of Martin for Sebacina grandinioides (Bourdot & Galzin) D.P. Rogers, and that of Luck-Allen for Basidiodendron grandinioides (Bourdot & Galzin) Luck-Allen, both given by Ginns(5) as synonyms of this species. RANGE ^Basidiodendron fulvum has been found in BC, OR, ON, AZ, FL, and NJ, (Ginns). It has also been found in Belize and France, (Martin).
FRUITING BODY  pulverulent (powdery), under a hand lens appearing porose-reticulate, "the strands radiating from and connecting blunt granular columns 40-100 um in diameter"; drying warm buff to cinnamon-buff^, (Martin), "broadly effused, thin, adnate, fleshy", 0.0035cm in section; isabella color (Ridgway) when fresh; "drying continuous or interrupted, reticulate, tuberculate, granular, often pulling away in areas leaving knots of tissue connected by radiating strands", "becoming occasionally finely reticulate", (Luck-Allen)
HABITAT  on dead hardwood^ (Martin), on decaying wood; Magnolia sp., Populus sp., P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-4 x 3 um, elliptic, "with the shortest axis often through the minute apiculus"^; PROBASIDIA 6-8 x 4.5-5(6) um, nearly spherical to suburniform, "becoming longitudinally, often indistinctly septate", epibasidia "at first divergent, finally incurved, subulate, about 3 um long"; strands of porose reticulate surface "radiating from and connecting blunt granular columns 40-100 um in diameter", "columns composed of erect axes of parallel hyphae from which gloeocystidia and fertile hyphae arise radially", GLOEOCYSTIDIA 30-50 x 4.5-6(8) um, "slender, subfusiform, ventricose, somewhat flexuous, blunt, filled with yellow, often fragmented contents", the fertile hyphae 1.5-2 um wide, "forming tortuous columns surrounded by sheaths of evacuated, collapsed basidia and bearing clusters of 2-3 young basidia at the apices", (Martin), SPORES 3 x 2.5-3 um, nearly round to oval, apiculate, germinating by repetition; PROBASIDIA 5-9 x 4.5-7.5 um, nearly spherical or pyriform, in clusters of two or three (rarely four), borne at apices of fertile branches, basidia 2-4-celled, typically 4-celled, 6-9(10) x 5-7(8) um, urniform, "sterigmata at first divergent becoming arcuate, subulate", 3-7 um long; fertile axis 18-40 x 1.5-2 um, tortuous, "with dense involucres of collapsed basidia"; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 25-50 x 3-7.5 um, at first homogeneous, colorless, "later becoming brownish, with globular or fragmented contents", cylindric or more commonly enlarged at base, narrowing and tortuous toward apex, "originating from a basal layer but often arising from fertile branches and projecting into the hymenium"; "central axis composed of fungal tissue growing up through hydnoid projections and radiating outward; new hymenium growing outwardly brought about by extensive proliferation with increasing thickness", (Luck-Allen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fulvous in color'
SIMILAR  Basidiodendron eyrei has nearly round spores measuring 4-6.5 um, (from Luck-Allen). Basidiodendron caesiocinerea has nearly round spores measuring 8 x (5)6-7.5 um, (from Luck-Allen). Basidiodendron cinerea has spores measuring 8-11 x 6-8 um, (from Luck-Allen). Basidiodendron pini has basidia generally more than 20 um long, and fertile sheaths are not sheathed by involucres of collapsed basidia, (from Luck-Allen). See also SIMILAR section of Basidiodendron caesiocinereum and Basidiodendron cinereum.
SOURCES  Luck-Allen(1) (as Basidiodendron grandinioides), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Sebacina grandinioides), Ginns(5)
55
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Basidiodendron pini  (H.S. Jacks. & G.W. Martin) Luck-Allen^  Can. J. Bot. 41: 1049. 1963;  Sebacina pini  H.S. Jacks. & G.W. Martin;  Bourdotia pini  (H.S. Jacks. & G.W. Martin) K. Wells
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a waxy, thin, smoke-gray fruitbody, the margin granular or mealy and not distinct, 3) spores that are large, ovate to cylindric, and guttulate, germinating by repetition, 4) basidia that are generally more than 20 um long, splitting longitudinally into 2 to 4 parts, 5) dendrophyses that are thin and tortuous but not generally emergent, 6) gloeocystidia that are numerous, cylindric, colorless becoming yellowish brown, and 7) the presence of clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Basidiodendron pini has been found in OR and ON (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  effused [forming a patch on the wood], arid-waxy, thin, 0.005cm-0.012cm thick, "drying to a thin pruinose crust"; smoke-gray, drying whitish to olive-buff; margin indeterminate [not distinct], farinaceous^, (Martin), "thin, effused, arid-waxy, smoke gray, on drying adnate, grayish-white to olive buff (R) or rarely inconspicuous, porous-reticulate verging toward rimose, finely pruinose" (R indicating Ridgway color); in section 0.005-0.012cm thick; margin very thin, indeterminate [not distinct], granular or farinaceous, (Luck-Allen)
HABITAT  on dead wood, Pinus sp. (pine), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Tsuga sp. (hemlock), T. canadensis (Eastern Hemlock)^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 16.5-22.5 x 8-11 um, ovate to cylindric, flattened on one side, conspicuously guttulate, germinating by repetition, commonly through the apiculus^; PROBASIDIA 22-25 x 18-22 um, "at first clavate, then obovate, finally suburniform, conspicuously guttulate", becoming cruciate-septate, epibasidia up to 20 um long, 3-5 um wide at base, short, divergent, subulate, sterigmata very short; PARAPHYSES numerous, 1-2 um wide, slender, tortuous, short-branched, arising from the subiculum and from clamp connections along the fertile hyphae; GLOEOCYSTIDIA very numerous, 15-45 x 5-6 um, cylindric to subclavate, arising from the subiculum, with contents at first colorless, finally yellow, (Martin), SPORES (12)15-22 x 8-10 um, "cylindrical laterally flattened, slightly curved or ovate, guttulate", "germinating by repetition or by broad germ tube"; PROBASIDIA 16-20(25) x 12-16 um, "pyriform to obovate then subglobose, proliferating from clamps at the base and with long lateral proliferations", basidia (13)19-24 x (10)18-22 um, "large, cruciate-septate splitting longitudinally from apex downward, 2- to 4-celled, suburniform", "borne terminally and on rather long lateral proliferations from distinct clamp connections at the base of each basidium", protosterigmata 10-25 x 2-3 um, straight, often divergent, subulate; DENDROPHYSES 1.5-2 um wide, (narrowing to less than 1 um at tip), very tortuous, "emanating from either clamps on fertile branches or from hyphae in the basal region, apparently forming a zone in which the basidia are situated, generally nonemergent"; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 15-50 x 5-7.5 um, "arising from basal layer or from fertile hyphae, occasionally projecting as much as 14-17 um beyond basidia - when originating from the fertile system, cylindric, flexible at first staining red in KOH-phloxine, then becoming yellowish brown when older (often with peculiar pits inside cells)"; basal layer thin, often agglutinated, hyphae 1-2 um wide, parallel with substrate, with prominent clamp connections, (Luck-Allen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of pine'
SIMILAR  Other species of Basidiodendron in the Pacific Northwest have basidia generally less than 20 um in length and fertile axes conspicuously sheathed with involucres of collapsed basidia, (from Luck-Allen). See also SIMILAR section of Basidiodendron caesiocinereum, Basidiodendron cinereum, Basidiodendron eyrei, and Basidiodendron fulvum.
SOURCES  Luck-Allen(1), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Sebacina pini), Ginns(5)
56
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Basidioradulum radula  (Fr.) Nobles^  Mycologia 59: 192. 1967;  Hydnum radula  Fr.;  Hyphoderma radula  (Fr.) Donk;  Radulum bennettii  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Corticium colliculosum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Corticium hydnans  (Schwein.) Burt;  Radulum orbiculare  Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  toothed crust
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on bark or less commonly barkless wood, 2) fruitbodies that start circular but become confluent, white when young becoming cream to bright yellow or ocher-yellow, waxy-membranaceous in consistency, smooth at first but developing teeth that are cylindric to conic to plate-like, 3) spores that are smooth, inamyloid, colorless, and cylindric to slightly curved, 4) basidia that are 4-spored and often constricted, 5) leptocystidia (?cystidioles) that are present but rarely projecting, sometimes moniliform, and 6) a hyphal system that is monomitic with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Basidioradulum radula is found in BC, WA, ID, NB, NF, NS, ON, PE, PQ, CA, DC, FL, GA, IA, IL, KY, LA, MA, MD, MI, MO, MN, MS, NC, NE, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, RI, TX, VT, WI, and WV, (Ginns). It is common in most parts of Scandinavia and Finland, (Eriksson). It occurs in Europe including Switzerland, and in Asia, (Breitenbach). It is found in Finland, Germany, Netherlands, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, circular at first, remaining separate or becoming confluent, arising from pads of mycelium under bark or within barkless wood, firm and waxy when dry, "soaking up to a flesh consistency"; white to 'light yellowish brown' to 'strong yellowish brown' (colors from Munsell(1)); smooth and remaining so, "becoming cracked and exposing white subiculum in some collections", "or developing occasional to crowded elevations or teeth", "isolated or fascicled, subulate, the tips usually remaining white and floccose, under magnification the surface appearing continuous, waxy"; margins distinct, white, fringed^, (Nobles), at first almost corticioid, soon raduloid with blunt teeth, 0.1-0.5cm long and 0.1-0.2cm wide, fruitbody waxy in living state; when young white, then cream to bright yellow or ocher-yellow; margin generally white, finely fringed, at least under hand lens, (Eriksson), forming patches several centimeters to decimeters across, out of rounded spots; irregularly tuberculate-verrucose when young, then odontoid with unevenly long, blunt teeth, (Breitenbach), thick-membranaceous; cream-colored, the margin lighter; even at first, but soon covered with teeth of variable shape, from cylindric to conic to plate-like, "scattered over the whole surface or slightly fasciculate"; margin adnate or reflexed, rhizomorphs lacking, (Julich), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on bark or rarely barkless wood of hardwoods and conifers; associated with a white rot^, (Nobles), twigs, decaying limbs on ground; hardwoods and conifers; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), mostly on hardwood bark, but may be found on debarked wood and in rare cases on conifers; "commonly seen on erect or sloping dead young trunks and branches, less often on stumps or fallen logs", (Eriksson), most frequent on wild cherry, but on many other species also; all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8.0-13.2 x 2.6-4.0 um, cylindric, flattened on one side, sometimes slightly curved, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 26-33 x 4.6-6.6 um, at first ovoid, elongating to clavate, usually with a central constriction; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 35-60(85) x 5.2-7.2 um, rarely projecting, thin-walled, with homogeneous content staining in phloxine, negative with sulfobenzaldehyde, "indistinguishable from immature basidia in hymenium developing at the margin of fruit bodies", "but soon recognizable as they elongate between the spent basidia", clavate or cylindric, often with constrictions, flexuous [wavy]; in section thin at first, consisting of a few hyphae radiating over substrate and curving down to form hymenium, "becoming 200-800 um or more thick with teeth up to 1500 um or more long, with a thin basal layer of horizontal hyphae, a broad intermediate layer making up most of the thickness of the section, composed of loosely arranged, obliquely or vertically descending hyphae", and often containing masses of crystalline material, hyphae 2.0-4.0 um wide, uniform throughout, loosely arranged, "thin-walled, nodose-septate, often lightly incrusted with crystals", with frequent H-anastomoses; moniliform terminal cells only on vegetative mycelium at base of fruitbody "or in growing margin or on hyphae in decayed wood", (15)30-66 um long, 3.3-4.6 um wide at base, slender, tapering, flexuous [wavy], (Nobles), SPORES 9-11 x 3-3.5 um, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, with homogeneous contents; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 4-6 um, subclavate to subcylindric (often constricted), with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA generally few, especially when mature, 50-70 x 5-8 um, thin-walled, with homogeneous contents, cylindric with few constrictions to definitely moniliform; HYPHAE monomitic mostly 3-4 um wide, "thin-walled or in the centre of the teeth with somewhat thickened walls", densely branched and closely interwoven in the subhymenial part, "otherwise rather straight with sparse branches", all septa with clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 8.5-10 x 3-3.5 um; LEPTOCYSTIDIA 45-60 x 5-7 um, sinuous to moniliform, (Breitenbach), SPORES 7-11 x 2.3-3 um, with small apiculus; CYSTIDIA and gloeocystidia lacking but moniliform CYSTIDIOLES sometimes present, 35-60 x 5-7 um; BASAL HYPHAE distinct and straight, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE often tortuous-torulose and indistinct, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Nobles(1), Eriksson(3) (as Hyphoderma radula), Julich(1), Breitenbach(2)* (as Hyphoderma radula), Ginns(5), Munsell(1), Buczacki(1)*
57
FAMILY  Bertiaceae, Order Coronophorales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Bertia moriformis  (Tode) De Not.^  G. bot. ital. 1(1): 335. 1844
ENGLISH NAME(S)  wood mulberry
NOTES  Features include tiny black blackberry-like fruitbodies on wood, often seen in small to large clusters^ |. Bertia moriformis var. latispora is characterized by its broader (6-8.5 um) and geniculate mature spores compared to the narrower (4.5-6.5 um) and straight to gently curved mature spores of var. moriformis. Approximately half of the Canadian collections examined and about one third of the US collections examined were variety latispora, but only two of the 13 collections from the Pacific Northwest (BC) and only 3 of over 40 European collections. RANGE ^Collections of var. moriformis were examined from BC, WA, ID, AB, NB, ON, QC, CA, CO, CT, IN, MA, MD, ME, NH, NY, OH, PA, VT, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Italy, Romania, Sweden, Switzerland, and United Kingdom; collections of var. latispora were examined from BC, NB, ON, QC, CO, MI, NC, NH, NY, VA, and Switzerland, (Corlett). F. Rhoades photographed var. moriformis in OR and Kauffman(5) also reported Bertia moriformis from OR.
FRUITING BODY  0.05-0.07cm across, 0.07-0.1(0.12)cm high (including base), upper fertile part spherical to almost spherical, with coarse tubercles over surface, resting on a well-developed, short-cylindric, non-tuberculate base^, (Corlett), 0.04-0.06cm across, spherical to ovoid, "usually somewhat taller than wide", "similar to a tiny blackberry or mulberry"; black, resting on wood without subiculum, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious, superficial on barkless sound or, occasionally, on partially rotted wood and dead branches of living trees and shrubs, "infrequently erumpent through attached bark of dead wood", mostly on hardwood, occasionally on coniferous wood or old basidiocarps (Coriolus, Hirschioporus); var. latispora on barkless sound wood, occasionally partially rotted wood and dead branches of living trees, mostly on conifer wood, occasionally on hardwood or on old basidiocarps (Hymenochaete)^, (Corlett), cespitose or growing in irregularly dense groups on small barkless hardwood branches lying on the ground, rarely on conifers; all year, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  mature spores 34.5-52.5 x 4.5-6.5 um (compared with 30-49 x 6-8.5(10.5) um in var. latispora), "straight to curved, ends rounded to acute", 1(3)-septate, smooth, with droplets, irregularly arranged in upper part of ascus, (mature spores best measured after release from ascus into central cavity of fruitbody)^; asci 8-spored, 92-140 x 10-21 um including stalk, clavate, long-stalked, thin-walled, deliquescing early and releasing spores into the central cavity of the fruiting body; wall of fruitbody at top and sides irregular in thickness due to the tubercles, ostiole as such not recognized externally but in longitudinal section seen as an apical thinning of the fruitbody wall, (Corlett), spores 40 x 5.5-6 um, "fusiform-allantoid or sinuous, smooth", colorless, "with 1 septum in the center, with a few droplets"; asci 8-spored, 150-160 x 10-17 um, iodine negative, 2-seriate; paraphyses "filiform, septate", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like Morus (mulberry)'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Corlett(3), Breitenbach(1)*, Kauffman(5)
58
FAMILY  Graphostromataceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Biscogniauxia bartholomaei  (Peck) Lar. N. Vassilyeva^  Mikologiya i Fitopatologiya 22: 392. 1988;  == Hypoxylon bartholomaei  Peck;  == Nummularia bartholomaei  (Peck) Lar. N. Vassilyeva
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on hardwood, most often alder, 2) a flat dark gray to dark brown fruitbody, the outer dehiscing layer dark brown and thin, 3) ostioles where perithecia open to the surface lower than the surface to slightly raised, and giving a punctate appearance, 4) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and dark brown, with a germ split the full length of the spore, 5) asci that are 8-spored with and apical ring turning blue in Melzer's reagent, and 6) paraphyses.^ RANGE ^Biscogniauxia bartholomae has been found in WA, OR, and ID, (Miller, J.H.). Collections were examined from WA and BC (Rogers).
FRUITING BODY  stromata growing flat, 0.8-3cm long x 0.4-1.1cm broad x 0.06-0.08cm thick, outer dehiscing layer dark brown and thin, "mature surface dark gray to blackish brown"; "carbonaceous immediately beneath surface"; "tissue between perithecia fibrous to woody, gray, becoming dark brown"; tissue under perithecia inconspicuous; perithecia 0.03-0.04cm diameter and 0.05-0.06cm high, obovoid, ostioles "lower than stromatal surface, with openings punctate"^, (Rogers), stromata erumpent, elliptic, applanate [flat] with discrete margin, 2-3cm x 1-1.5cm x 0.05-0.1cm; woody rather than carbonous; dull black; ostioles "slightly raised, widely punctate or very inconspicuous"; perithecia 0.04-0.07cm wide, semiglobose [hemispheric], (Miller, J.H.)
HABITAT  on Alnus rubra (Red Alder) and Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), (Miller, J.H.), on Alnus rubra and Alnus tenuifolia (Thinleaf Alder), (Rogers)^
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 17.5-22(25) x (8)9-11(12) um, elliptic, "equilateral to slightly inequilateral, with narrowly rounded ends", smooth, dark brown, with straight germ slit spore-length, unicellular^; ASCUS 180-200 x 11-13 um, the spore-bearing part 145-160 um long, stem 25-35 um long, with apical ring turning blue in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 2.5-3.5 um high and 5.5-7 um broad, (Rogers), SPORES 18-26 x 8-11 um, very variable in size, elliptic-obtuse, dark brown when mature, uniseriate; ASCUS 8-spored, spore-producing part 120-130 x 10-14 um, with short pedicel 15-20 um long, cylindric; PARAPHYSES present, (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  type collected by E. Bartholomew
SIMILAR  The Hypoxylon nummularium group is similar, but B. bartholomaei has a limited number of hosts and a restricted range, (Miller, J.H.).
SOURCES  Rogers, J.D.(3), Miller, J.H.(1) (as Hypoxylon bartholomaei)
59
FAMILY  Graphostromataceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Biscogniauxia cinereolilacina  (J.H. Mill.) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykol. 33: 216. 1979;  == Hypoxylon cinereo-lilacinum  J.H. Mill.  Mycologia 25: 324-325. 1933
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) flattened fruitbodies on Tilia (basswood), 2) outer color that is dull purplish brown to grayish or grayish lilac, with black papillae, the interior dark brown and woody, except for carbonaceous tissue encasing the ostiole of each perithecium, 3) elliptic spores that are brown and smooth, with a germ slit spore-length on both sides of the spore, 4) asci with the apical ring lightly blueing or not blueing in Melzer's reagent, and 5) paraphyses.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, ON, IA, and Hungary; the range also included IL, KS, NE, NY, TN, and WI, (Miller, J.H.). The distribution also includes France and Norway (Rogers).
FRUITING BODY  1.5-10.5cm x 0.4-3cm and 0.06-0.07cm thick, applanate; "outer dehiscing layer dark brown, thin; surface dull purplish brown when young, mouse gray when mature; dark brown, woody immediately beneath surface and between perithecia, with carbonaceous tissue encasing each individual ostiole; tissue beneath perithecia inconspicuous"^, (Rogers), 3-4cm x 1-2cm and 0.05-0.1cm thick, broadly effused and indeterminate, at first light gray, later grayish lilac with a white margin, "with black, briefly papillate ostiola"; perithecia spherical to oblong, monostichous [in a series or line], often crowded, (Miller, J.H.)
HABITAT  on dead wood of Tilia (basswood)^, (Miller, J.H.)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 12-16 (17.5) x (4.5) 5.5-7 um, elliptic, "nearly equilateral, with broadly rounded ends, smooth", unicellular, light brown to brown, "with straight germ slit spore-length on both sides"^; ASCUS 100-130 um x 7.5-10 um, the spore-bearing part 70-110 um long, the stem 10-30 um long, with apical ring lightly blueing or not blueing in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 1 um high and 3-4 um broad; PERITHECIA 400-500 um high, 200-400 um across, obovoid, ostioles "higher than stromatal surface, with openings papillate", (Rogers), SPORES 11-16 x 5-6.5 um, plano-convex or oblong, brown; ASCUS 75-102 x 7-9 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, stem 40-50 um long; PARAPHYSES present; PERITHECIA spherical to oblong, (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'cinereous (ash-gray) - lilac-colored'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Rogers, J.D.(3), Miller, J.H.(1)
60
FAMILY  Graphostromataceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Biscogniauxia mediterranea  (De Not.) Kuntze^  Rev. Gen. Plant. 2: 398. 1891;  == Hypoxylon mediterraneum  (De Not.) J.H. Mill.;  == Sphaeria mediterranea  De Not.;  == Nummularia mediterranea  (De Not.) Sacc.;  = Hypoxylon clypeus  (Schwein.) M.A. Curtis;  = Hypoxylon regium  De Not.;  = Hypoxylon sertatum  (Durieu & Mont.) Mont.;  Hypoxylon repandioides  Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) fruiting on hardwood, especially oak, usually following fire or drought injury, 2) irregularly rounded, cushion-like fruitbodies that break through the bark and may fuse with others to form a surface several centimeters square, the surface dotted with the papilla-shaped openings of the perithecia, 3) spores that are narrowly elliptic, smooth, and dark brown, with the germ split the full length of the spore, 4) asci that are 8-spored with the apical ring turning blue in Melzer's reagent, and 5) inconspicuous paraphyses.^ RANGE ^Biscogniauxia mediterranea is found in "All of United States", Canada, France, Germany, Portugal, Italy, China, Africa, and Australia; collections of var. microspora were examined from BC, WA, CA, Africa, China, Philippines, New Zealand, and Samoa, and a collection of var. macrospora was examined from Venezuela, (Miller, J.H.). Collections were examined from OR, AL, CA, IN, NC, ND, NJ, NY, OH, PA, VA, WI, Mexico, Brazil, Austria, France, Germany, Italy, Portugal, Ukraine, Georgia, Russia, Mauritania, and Nigeria, (Rogers).
FRUITING BODY  "irregularly rounded, cushion-like stroma breaks through the bark and can remain isolated or fuse with others" to form surfaces of several centimeters square; the surface is "dotted with warts", the papilla-shaped openings (ostioles) of the perithecia; perithecia 0.04-0.05cm wide, black, evenly embedded in a single layer in the black, coal-like stroma^, (Breitenbach), stromata applanate [flat], 1.8-7cm x 0.5-4cm x 0.06-0.1cm, outer dehiscing layer dark brown, 0.04-0.08cm thick, "mature surface blackish to shiny black", "carbonaceous immediately beneath surface and between perithecia", tissue under perithecia inconspicuous; perithecia 0.01-0.02cm across, 0.05-0.08cm high, "obovoid to tubular, laterally flattened", usually "several packed inside the same stromatal locule", 0.03-0.05cm in diameter, "and sharing a common ostiolar canal"; ostioles higher than stromatal surface, with openings coarsely papillate, (Rogers), stromata erumpent from bark, 2-5cm long and 0.1-0.15cm thick, nearly round to elliptic, flattened to convex, "very carbonous, black and shining"; surface studded with coarsely papillate ostioles, 2-3 per mm; perithecia "oblong, compressed when crowded, monostichous", 0.04-0.05cm wide and 0.05-0.1cm high, (Miller, J.H.)
HABITAT  on hardwood, chiefly oak, usually following fire or drought injury, (Miller, J.H.), wood of Acer (maple), Celtis (hackberry), Eucalyptus, Fagus (beech), Juglans (walnut), Pisonia, Quercus (oak), (Rogers)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 17-24 x 7-10 um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, dark brown, with 1 droplet and indistinct germ slit, uniseriate in ascus^; ASCUS 8-spored, 150-180 x 7-10 um; PARAPHYSES cylindric, indistinctly visible, (Breitenbach), SPORES 15.5-21 x (6.5)7-10 um, elliptic, "nearly equilateral, with narrowly to broadly rounded ends", smooth, brown to dark brown, unicellular, with straight germ slit spore-length; ASCUS 160-185 x 9-12.5 um, the spore-bearing part 120-150 um long, stem 20-35 um long, with apical ring turning blue in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 2-3 um high and 4-5 um wide, (Rogers), SPORES 16-23 x 6-10 um, (var. microspora 12-15.2 x 5-8 um, var. macrospora 22-34 x 13-17 um), "oblong-elliptic, usually with obtuse ends, dark brown"; ASCUS 120-185 x 8-11 um (80-100 x 7-9 for var. microspora), cylindric, short-stemmed; PARAPHYSES, straight bands, numerous, (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Rogers, J.D.(3), Miller, J.H.(1), Breitenbach(1)* 
61
FAMILY  Graphostromataceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Biscogniauxia uniapiculata  (Penz. & Sacc.) Whalley & Laessoe^  apud Whalley, Laessoe, & Kile, Mycol. Res. 94: 239. 1990;  == Nummularia uniapiculata  Penz. & Sacc.;  == Hypoxylon uniapiculatum  (Penz. & Sacc.) J.H. Mill.;  == Numulariola uniapiculata  (Penz. & Sacc.) P.M.D. Martin;  = Nummularia papyracea  Rehm;  = Hypoxylon papyraceum  (Rehm) J.H. Mill.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on dead trunks, 2) flat to flat-convex fruitbodies (either nearly circular or spread out) that are black (the outer dehiscing layer dark brown) and carbonaceous, with minute slightly raised openings to the perithecia, 3) oblong-elliptic brown spores with one end rounded and the other with a prominent apiculus, with a germ slit that is straight, spore-length or slightly less, on either the more convex or the less convex side, 4) asci with an apical ring turning blue in Melzer's reagent, and 5) numerous paraphyses.^ RANGE ^Biscogniauxia uniapiculata has been found in OR, HI, Puerto Rico, China, Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines, (Miller, J.H.). The distribution also includes Taiwan; the OR collection was not among the collections of this species studied, (Rogers).
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] 0.5-6cm long, 0.5-4cm broad, 0.04-0.07cm thick, applanate [flattened]; "outer dehiscing layer dark brown, thin", mature surface black; "carbonaceous immediately beneath surface and between perithecia; tissue beneath perithecia inconspicuous"; ostioles "at the same level as or lower than stromatal surface, with openings punctate, usually surrounded by slightly raised rim, sometimes overlain with white substance"^, (Rogers), stromata 0.2-7cm long, 0.05-0.1cm thick, superficial, erumpent, applanate [flattened] to plano-convex [flat-convex], suborbicular [nearly circular] to indefinitely effused [spread out]; carbonous; black; ostiola "minute, slightly raised and punctate", (Miller, J.H.)
HABITAT  on dead trunks^, (Miller, J.H.)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (9)10-14 x 5-7 um (not including appendage), elliptic, inequilateral to nearly equilateral, with one end narrowly to broadly rounded and the other bearing a colorless or pale brown cellular appendage 2-2.5 um long and 2-3 um broad, spores smooth, brown, "with straight, spore-length or, less frequently, slightly less than spore-length germ slit on either more convex or less convex side"^; ASCUS 75-130 x 5.5-7 um, spore-bearing part 65-105 um long, stem 10-30 um long, with apical ring turning blue in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 2.5-3 um high and 3.5 um broad; PERITHECIUM 200-300 um in diameter and 300-600 um high, obovoid, (Rogers, J.D.(1)), SPORES 10-13.6 x 5-6.8 um, oblong-elliptic, with one end rounded and the other with a subtriangular to spherical, colorless apiculus 2.5-3 um in diameter, spores brown, uniseriate; ASCUS 8-spored, 100-110 x 7-8 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, stem 15-20 um long; PARAPHYSES numerous, filiform; PERITHECIUM 200-300 um in diameter, oblong to spherical, monostichous [in one line or series], (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with one apiculus'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Miller, J.H.(1), Rogers, J.D.(1)
62
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Boidinia furfuracea  (Bres.) Stalpers & Hjortstam^  Mycotaxon 14: 77. 1982;  == Hypochnus furfuraceus  Bres.;  Gloeocystidiellum furfuraceum  (Bres.) Donk;  Gloeocystidium furfuraceum  (Bres.) Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a fruitbody surface that white to grayish white, and porous-furfuraceous, 3) spores that are round, bluntly spiny, and amyloid, 4) gloeocystidia that are cylindric, with yellowish granular contents, and 5) a hyphal system that is monomitic with clamp connections.^ | Note the different accounts of whether gloeocystidia are sulfo-positive. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, OR, MB, ON, PQ, FL, MN, MS, WI, and Italy, (Ginns(24)), Sweden and Norway, (Eriksson), the Netherlands (Hjortstam), and Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, "effused, of small to moderate dimensions", thin (0.005-0.01cm thick), adnate [tightly attached]; white to grayish white, (in herbarium generally creamish to pale ochraceous); farinose-porose or furfuraceous; margin indistinct^, (Eriksson), effused [spread out], about 2-7cm x 2-4cm, up to 0.0065cm thick; white to pallid, "cream buff", "cartridge-buff", to almost "olive-buff" when dry; smooth, furfuraceous; margin indeterminate, colored as rest of surface, finely granulose, sometimes indistinct, up to 0.3cm wide; subiculum very thin, (Ginns(24)), "resupinate, effused, arachnoid-pellicular to soft membranaceous", up to 0.01cm thick, separable; whitish to cream when fresh, becoming pale ochraceous when old; "surface even, somewhat farinaceous"; margin indistinct, (Hjortstam), resupinate, loosely attached, forming thin, soft, floccose patches up to about 0.02cm thick and several centimeters across; white to grayish; "surface porous, furfuraceous, easily wiped off"; margin distinctly bounded to diffuse, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on bark or well-rotted conifer wood^, except for single reports on Alnus rubra (Red Alder) and Betula sp. (birch): Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), P. elliottii (Slash Pine), P. resinosa (Red Pine), P. taeda (Loblolly Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), (Ginns(24)), on decayed wood of conifers (Eriksson), on conifers, mainly Pinus and Picea (Hjortstam in Europe), probably all year; also rarely on fern bracken, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.4-6.0 in diameter, round, echinulate, amyloid, thin-walled, with a peg-like distinct apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 24.0-36.0 x 4.5-6.0 um, "suburniform, when mature cylindric and sometimes with a ventricose base, some pleurobasidiate", sterigmata up to 4.0 um long, GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 25-65 x 4-8 um, "cylindric to slightly fusiform", "originating next to the substrate, terminating among the basidia", thin-walled, the contents colorless to yellowish, granular in KOH, sulfo-negative [note sulfo-positive in European specimens, see below]; HYPHAE monomitic, subiculum "sparse, a few strands of repent horizontally oriented hyphae"; hyphae "loosely arranged, distinct next to substrate, with a clamp connection at each septum", 1.5-3 um wide, the walls colorless, thin; "subhymenial hyphae remaining diffuse, distinct", (Ginns(24)), SPORES 6-7 um in diameter including ornamentation, nearly round to round, echinulate [spiny], amyloid; BASIDIA 27-35 x 4.5-5.5 um, "tubular to subclavate, more or less sinuose, old basidia with one or more adventitious septa", normally 4-spored; GLOEOCYSTIDIA (= pseudocystidia) "tubular, more or less sinuose, often laterally borne on the bearing hyphae, 50-90 x 7-10 um, in young specimens shorter, thinwalled, filled with oily yellowish granular contents, with positive reaction to sulfovanilline" [but note above North American specimens sulfo-negative]; hyphal structure monomitic, hyphae 2-3 um wide, loosely interwoven, richly branched, clamp connections at all septa, (Eriksson), SPORES 5-6.5 um in diameter excluding ornamentation, round to nearly round, echinulate, colorless, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled, spines up to 0.5 um long, strongly amyloid, with prominent apiculus, ornamentation instantly disappearing in 6% KOH; BASIDIA 22-35 x 4-5.5(6) um, "terminal, rarely lateral", subcylindric "and often flexuous to clavate or urniform with a basal swelling", typically 4-spored; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 30-90 x (4)6-10 um, terminal or more rarely lateral, cylindric, "often flexuous or somewhat swollen at the base, thin-walled, typically with yellowish contents", sulfo-positive but sometimes reaction very weak; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2-3(3.5) um wide, loosely interwoven, colorless, thin-walled to rarely thick-walled, regular or sometimes with swellings, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 1.5-3 um wide, denser than subicular hyphae, thin-walled; all primary septa with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 4.5-6 um in diameter excluding ornamentation, round, bluntly verrucose-spinose, colorless, warts up to 0.7 um long; BASIDIA 4-spored, 23-32 x 4-5.5 um, with basal clamp connection, some with secondary septa; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 50-75 x 3.5-5 um, sinuous, with yellowish contents, sulfo-positive; HYPHAE monomitic 1.5-3 um wide, most septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 4.5-6 um in diameter, GLOEOCYSTIDIA sulfo-negative, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'furfuraceous'
SIMILAR  Boidinia propinqua has spores measuring 3.5-4 x 3-3.5 um, sulfo-positive gloeocystidia, and hyphae of the subiculum without clamp connections. See also SIMILAR section of Phlebiella inopinata.
SOURCES  Ginns(24), Eriksson(3) (as Gloeocystidiellum furfuraceum), Breitenbach(2)*, Hjortstam(1), Ginns(23), Buczacki(1)*
63
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Boidinia propinqua  (H.S. Jacks. & Dearden) Hjortstam & Ryvarden^  Acta Mycol. Sinica 7: 79. 1988;  == Corticium propinquum  H.S. Jacks. & Dearden;  Gloeocystidiellum propinquum  (H.S. Jacks. & Dearden) Parmasto
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) membranaceous to waxy fruitbodies that are cream-colored and smooth, the margin narrow and indistinct, 3) spores that are small, amyloid, broadly elliptic to nearly round, and verrucous to warted, 4) numerous gloeocystidia that are cylindric to sinuous, with granular, sulfo-positive contents, not noticeably projecting, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Boidinia propinqua was originally described from BC, and it is known from 3 collections there and one in TN.
FRUITING BODY  2-3cm across and 0.015-0.03cm thick, effused [spread out], fragile, membranaceous to ceraceous [waxy], "often erupting as small discontinuous patches"; whitish cream "light buff" to cream color "light ochraceous-buff" when dry; "smooth, not cracking to cracking sparingly"; "margin narrow, indistinct, pruinose to weakly fibrillose", colored as the rest of the spore-bearing surface^, (Ginns(24)), "broadly effused, or in small irregular areas", 0.0125-0.02cm thick, adnate; creamy white; surface soft-membranous, becoming rimose [cracked], exposing substrate; margin abrupt, (Jackson)
HABITAT  on barkless, well-rotted or rather firm wood of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)^, (Ginns(24))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.8-4.0(4.4) x 3.0-3.6 um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, verrucose to warted, amyloid, thin-walled, with a large apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-38 x 3.4-4.4 um, cylindric to narrowly clavate, "sometimes with a median constriction and a ventricose base", sterigmata up to 4 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 40-200 x 5-11 um, "cylindric to sinuous, often with a ventricose base and acuminate tip, thin-walled, adventitious septa common and sometimes numerous", the contents colorless to yellowish green in KOH under bright field, "granular, sulfo-positive"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.0-3.6(4.8) um wide, distinct, colorless, thin-walled, smooth, without clamp connections, "the hyphae forming a loosely arranged, distinct layer" about 50 um thick next to and parallel with the substrate, "hyphae between the basal layer and the subhymenium compact but distinct", (Ginns(24)), SPORES 3.5-4 x 3-3.5 um, nearly round, verrucose, strongly amyloid, thin-walled, with prominent peg-like apiculus; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 4.5-5.5 um, cylindric, ventricose or subventricose in lower part, sterigmata 4 um long, nearly straight or slightly arcuate; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 50-90 x 6-8.5 um, cylindric or subclavate, flexuous [wavy], often ventricose in lower part, "arising from the base of the subiculum or at various levels and extending to the surface of the hymenium, not noticeably projecting"; subiculum "with a few horizontal hyphae but for the most part with upright, thin-walled, mostly collapsed hyphae without clamps", (Jackson), GLOEOCYSTIDIA sulfo-positive, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'near'
SIMILAR  Boidinia furfuracea has spores 4.5-6 um in diameter, sulfo-negative gloeocystidia, and clamp connections, (Ginns(23), but note that Eriksson(3) and Breitenbach(2) give gloeocystidia as sulfo-positive); Gloeocystidiellum porosum has clamp connections, (Jackson); Conferticium ravum has different gross characters of the fruitbody, different substrate, and larger, almost smooth spores, (Jackson)
SOURCES  Ginns(24) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Jackson(1) (as Corticium propinquum), Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Breitenbach(2) (discussing Boidinia furfuracea), Eriksson(3) (discussing Gloeocystidiellum furfuraceum)
64
FAMILY  Gloeophyllaceae, Order Gloeophyllales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Boreostereum radiatum  (Peck) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort. 187. 1968;  == Stereum radiatum  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Boreostereum radiatum is "readily recognized by its bright, ferruginous hymenium with shallow broad ridges radiating from the center to the margin, and by the black upper side of the pileus when reflexed", (Burt). Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, with the margin free all round and sometimes bent outward on the upper side to form a shelf-like cap, 2) a leathery fruitbody, with the spore-bearing surface rusty brown, uneven, with radiating thick ridges, 3) a cap when present that becomes black, velvety, crisped, and somewhat lobed, 4) spores that are slightly curved, smooth, and inamyloid, 5) cystidia that are thin-walled and lightly encrusted, 6) a dimitic hyphal system, the septa without clamp connections, and 7) sections staining yellow-green in KOH.^ RANGE ^Boreostereum radiatum has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, ON, PQ, AZ, IA, MA, ME, MI, MN, MT, NH, NY, PA, TN, VA, VT, and WI, (Ginns(5)). Collections were examined from ON, MA, MI, MT, NY, PA, VT, and Russia, (Burt).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, with the margin free all around, sometimes reflexed on the upper side", coriaceous [leathery], 0.1cm thick, 2cm in diameter up to 10cm x 3cm, the reflexed part 0.2-0.8cm broad, becoming black above, velvety, crisped, and somewhat lobed; hymenial surface Sudan-brown (Ridgway color), rarely black when turned upward and exposed to direct sunlight and weather; hymenium "uneven, not polished, marked with thick ridges radiating from the center", (Burt), resupinate to effused-reflexed; rusty brown, often turning blackish; with radially arranged ridges, (Martin)^, effuse to reflexed, leathery, spore bearing surface brown to ferruginous, smooth to wrinkled, cap or reverse of spore-bearing surface black, (Ginns(23))
HABITAT  charred wood and logs; logs; boards; associated with a white rot; Larix laricina (Tamarack), Malus sylvestris, Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce), Picea glauca (White Spruce), Picea mariana (Black Spruce), Picea rubens (Red spruce), Pinus sp. (pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock)^, (Ginns(5)), underside of hemlock, spruce, and pine boards and logs and charred wood, (Burt)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7.5-10 x 3-3.5 um, inamyloid^; CYSTIDIA 2-4 um wide, thin-walled, lightly encrusted; HYPHAE dimitic, generative hyphae simple-septate, (Martin), SPORES from spore collections 9-10 x 3.5-4 um, slightly curved, smooth, white; hyphae 3.5-4 um wide, densely and longitudinally arranged, colored, but color dissolved by dilute KOH; no CYSTIDIA, (Burt), microscopic sections staining yellow-green in KOH, HYPHAE dimitic: generative hyphae simple-septate, and skeletal hyphae yellow, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'radiating' referring to the folds on the spore-bearing surface
SIMILAR  The general aspect, color, and color changes with KOH are suggestive of some species of Hymenochaete, but no setae are present, (Burt).
SOURCES  Burt(2) (as Stereum radiatum), Martin, K.J.(3), Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Garcia-Sandoval(3)*
65
FAMILY  Botryobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Botryobasidium ansosum  (H.S. Jacks. & D.P. Rogers) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort. 51. 1968;  == Pellicularia ansosa  H.S. Jacks. & D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) cream to buff or bright yellow fruitbodies with hairs, 3) spores measuring 7.5-9.5 x 3.5-5 um that are elliptic to broadly fusiform or navicular, 4) 4-6-spored basidia that are subcylindric to suburniform, 5) abundant cystidia that are cylindric to subfusiform, smooth, and thin-walled, and 6) wide subicular hyphae with right angle branching, the walls up to 2.5 um thick, with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Botryobasidium ansosum has been found in BC, WA, AZ, CA, and NM, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  becoming widely effused; cream to bright yellow; pilose [with hairs]^, (Gilbertson), cream to bright yellow, (Martin), hypochnoid, continuous; buff, (Julich)
HABITAT  on bark; Abies magnifica (California Red Fir), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine)^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7.5-9.5 x 3.5-4.5 um, elliptic to broadly fusiform, inamyloid, colorless, illustrated as smooth with obvious apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-6-spored, 8-10 um wide, usually with slight median constriction; CYSTIDIA abundant, 50-110 x 6-10 um, cylindric, thin-walled, non-septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 5-8 um wide, with conspicuous right angle branching, thin-walled, nodose-septate, (Gilbertson), SPORES 7.5-9 x 3.5-4 um, elliptic to broadly fusiform; CYSTIDIA abundant, cylindric, thin-walled; hyphae with clamp connections, (Martin), SPORES 8-9 x 4-5 um, navicular to broadly fusiform; BASIDIA (4)6-spored, 17-29 x 8-10 um, subcylindric to suburniform; CYSTIDIA 55-120 x 8-12.5 um, cylindric to subfusiform, colorless, smooth, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled; HYPHAE 7-15 um wide, the basal ones with thickened walls (up to 2.5 um), according to key lead with clamp connections, "at least sub-basidial and at the basal hyphae", (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gilbertson(9), Martin, K.J.(1), Julich(5), Ginns(5)
66
FAMILY  Botryobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Botryobasidium croceum  Lentz^  Mycopathol. Mycol. Appl. 32: 6. 1967
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a cobwebby to hypochnoid fruitbody with whitish to buff color, 3) great variation in spore size and shape in single specimens, the spores smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) spherical young basidia, 5) wide subicular hyphae that branch at wide angles, and 6) the absence of clamp connections.^ | The description is derived from Lentz(1). RANGE ^Botryobasidium croceum has been found in SK and MS, (Ginns(5)). J. Ginns (pers. comm.) collected this species from Vancouver Island in BC.
FRUITING BODY  thin, spread out on wood, loosely and delicately arachnoid [cobwebby], ranging to moderately thin and densely hypochnoid [with dry rather loosely intertwined hyphae arranged flat on substrate]; thinner areas sordid whitish, thicker areas intermediate between "light buff" and "pinkish buff"
HABITAT  type found on dead tree stump
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (6)7.5-12.5(15) x 3.5-4.5(6) um, "showing extreme variability of shape, from naviculate or subfusiform to obliquely and narrowly ovoid or oblong-ellipsoid, apically rounded or tapered, broadly rounded basally or tapering obliquely, smooth, thin walled, colorless, nonamyloid"^; BASIDIA 2-6-spored, 12.5-17.5 x 8.5-12.5 um, initially more or less spherical, but flattened at base, becoming ovoid or obpyriform, thin-walled; hyphae bearing the basidia up to 12.5 um wide, "forming numerous short branches, more or less closely septate, with some sub-basidial cells appearing inflated between the septa, lacking clamp-connections, thin walled, colorless"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE about 7.5-11 um wide, "branching at wide angles, with numerous H-branches, septate, not constricted at the septa, lacking clamp-connections, moderately thin walled, colorless or yellowish, or more deeply colored near the substratum"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'saffron-like'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Lentz(1), Ginns(5)
67
FAMILY  Botryobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Botryobasidium danicum  J. Erikss. & Hjortstam^  Friesia 9: 11. 1969
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood in humid areas, 2) a fruitbody that is grayish white to yellowish, and loosely interwoven, 3) distinctive spores that are narrowly navicular to almost allantoid, and apically obtuse, 4) basidia that are 4-spored to 6-spored, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the basal hyphae wide, thick-walled, branching at right angles, and without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Botryobasidium danicum has been found in BC and PA, (Ginns). It has been found in Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, and is frequent in BC, especially in humid oceanic biotypes, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  thin, with loosely interwoven texture, reticulate [net-like] to hypochnoid [with dry rather loosely intertwined hyphae arranged flat on substrate]; grayish white or when old yellowish^, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on many types of substrate but seems to prefer conifer wood, and humid localities^, (Eriksson), bark; branches lying on ground; stems; logs; Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Acer circinatum (Vine Maple), Alnus rubra (Red Alder), Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Cornus pubescens (Western Dogwood), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Rubus spectabilis (salmonberry), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), (Ginns), probably all year; also on bracken debris, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (10)12-14(17) x 3-5 um, narrowly navicular [boat-shaped] to almost allantoid, apically obtuse^; BASIDIA 4-spored to 6-spored, 15-20 x 9-12 um, at first rounded to ellipsoid, then obovate, obconic to subcylindric; HYPHAE monomitic, BASAL HYPHAE 10-12 um wide, "thickwalled, the coarser hyphae with double walls", without clamp connections, hymenial hyphae 6-8 um, colorless, without clamp connections, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'Danish'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
68
FAMILY  Botryobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Botryobasidium intertextum  (Schwein.) Julich & Stalpers^  Verh. Kon. Ned. Akad. Wetensch. Afd. Natuurk., Tweed Sect. 74: 56. 1980;  == Sporotrichum intertextum  Schwein.;  Pellicularia angustispora  Boidin;  Botryobasidium angustisporum  (Boidin) J. Erikss.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed wood, mostly of conifers, 2) a fruitbody that is loosely interwoven and whitish, 3) distinctive spores that are narrowly navicular to subcylindric, 4) basidia that are 6-spored to 8-spored, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the basal hyphae wide, with thickened walls, with clamp connections at many septa.^ | The description is for Botryobasidium angustisporum (Boidin) J. Erikss., given by Ginns as a synonym of this species. RANGE ^Botryobasidium intertextum has been found in OR and PA, (Ginns), and Scandinavia (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  thin, with a loose consistency, first hypochnoid [with dry rather loosely intertwined hyphae arranged flat on substrate] then subpellicular [forming a skin-like layer]; whitish to cream, "in old parts yellowish to pale ochraceous"^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on Pseudotsuga menziesii [Douglas-fir], (Ginns), on decayed wood, mostly of conifers (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-10 x 1.5-2.5 um, narrowly navicular [boat-shaped] to subcylindric, inamyloid, often agglutinated in groups of 2 or more^; BASIDIA 6-spored to 8-spored, 15-20(25) x 6-8(10) um, subcylindric, "more or less constricted and somewhat urniform"; HYPHAE monomitic: BASAL HYPHAE 7-10 um wide, yellowish, with thickened walls, with clamp connections at many septa, "intermediate hyphae (basal parts of hymenial branches) thinner, hyaline, without clamps, basidial branches 4-6 um wide, thinwalled, hyaline, with clamps", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'interwoven'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2) (as Botryobasidium angustisporum), Ginns(5)
69
FAMILY  Botryobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Botryobasidium obtusisporum  J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 57. 1958
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) fruitbodies that are thin, loosely attached, cobwebby-cottony, and grayish white, 3) spores that are elliptic with the apex blunt-rounded, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) 6-spored basidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the basal hyphae wide and thick-walled, the other hyphae more thin-walled, and 6) the absence of clamp connections.^ RANGE ^James Ginns collected this species from Vancouver Island in BC (J. Ginns, pers. comm.). It has also been recorded from NC and TN (Ginns(5)) and Scandinavia (Eriksson). The distribution includes Europe and Asia (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  thin, at first hypochnoid [with dry rather loosely intertwined hyphae arranged flat on substrate], then more confluent; "greyish white or with age yellowish to pale ochraceous and of a loosely interwoven texture"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, forming thin patches several centimeters to decimeters in extent, loosely attached, membranous arachnoid-cottony, consistency soft and cottony; gray-white when moist, white to cream when dry; surface open and porous, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on conifer wood, rarely on hardwood^, (Eriksson), on dead wood of conifers, according to literature more rarely on wood of hardwoods; spring-fall, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7.5-12 x 3.5-5 um, obliquely oval, apex obtuse, smooth^; BASIDIA (4-)6-spored, 17-25 x 8-10 um, "at first rounded, then obovate to subcylindrical, somewhat constricted"; HYPHAE monomitic, BASAL HYPHAE 7.5-10 um wide, yellowish, more or less thick-walled, with sparse branching, without clamp connections, hymenial branches 5-6 um wide, colorless, more thin-walled, without clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 8-11 x 3.5-4.5 um, elliptic, obtuse apically, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 6-(7-)spored, 12-15 x 8-9 um, cylindric to clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic: BASAL HYPHAE 6-9 um wide, yellowish, thick-walled, somewhat branched, without clamp connections, other hyphae about the same width, thin-walled, without clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to obtuse apex of spores
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Botryobasidium pruinatum.
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5)
70
FAMILY  Botryobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Botryobasidium pruinatum  (Bres.) J. Erikss.^  Svensk Bot. Tidskr. 52: 9. 1958;  == Corticium pruinatum  Bres.;  Pellicularia pruinata  (Bres.) D.P. Rogers;  Corticium botryoideum  Overh.;  Pellicularia coronata  (J. Schroet.) Donk sensu D.P. Rogers;  Botryobasidium coronatum  (J. Schroet.) sensu D.P. Rogers;  Botryobasidium laeve  (J. Erikss.) Parmasto
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a loosely interwoven fruitbody with a netted to web-like surface, whitish in color, 3) spores that are obliquely oval, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, the walls somewhat thickened, with a distinct apiculus, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the basal hyphae wide, rather thick-walled, light brownish, and without clamp connections, 5) hyphae roughened by fine projections.^ | Note however that Botryobasidium laeve (Eriksson) Parmasto, which has smooth hyphae, is synonymized by Ginns (fide Maekawa) with this species, and Breitenbach(2) say the smooth hyphae are the only difference. RANGE ^Botryobasidium pruinatum has been found in BC, WA, OR, MB, NS, ON, PQ, AK, AL, AZ, CA, CO, IA, MA, MD, MN, MO, NC, NM, NY, OH, PA, RI, and VA, (Ginns). It occurs in Europe including Scandinavia (Eriksson) and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  loosely interwoven, resupinate, at first reticulate [netted] hypochnoid [with dry rather loosely intertwined hyphae arranged flat on substrate], then more confluent; grayish white or when old yellowish or pale ochraceous^, (Eriksson), resupinate, loosely attached, consistency cottony and soft, "forming thin, open-tomentose patches several centimeters to decimeters in extent"; white to cream; smooth; margin thin, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white, (Buczacki)
HABITAT  mostly on hardwood, rarely on conifers^, in humid fertile biotypes, (Eriksson), on dead wood of hardwoods, according to literature also rarely of conifers, (Breitenbach), on twig; bark; barkless branches and logs; ground; on a variety of hardwood and conifer species; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), fall, winter, spring; also on old polypore fruitbodies and bracken debris, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-8 x 2.5-3.5 um, obliquely oval, smooth, walls somewhat thickened, with very distinct apiculus^; BASIDIA 17-25 x 7-10 um, at first rounded, then obovate to subcylindric, more or less constricted; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae without clamp connections, most more or less asperulate [roughened by fine projections], BASAL HYPHAE 15-20 um wide or more, yellowish to brownish yellow, thick-walled, with sparse branching, hymenial hyphae narrower, basidial branches 4.5-6 um wide, thin-walled, colorless, (Eriksson), SPORES 5.5-8 x 2.5-3.5 um, oval elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, cyanophilic, rather thick-walled, with distinct apiculus, with droplets; BASIDIA 6-spored, 18-22 x 6-8 um, cylindric, somewhat constricted, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic: all hyphae finely verrucose, hyphae 6-8 um wide, thin-walled, BASAL HYPHAE up to 17 um wide, rather thick-walled, light brownish, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Botryobasidium obtusisporum has larger spores and basal hyphae that are at most 10 um wide (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
71
FAMILY  Botryobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Botryobasidium subcoronatum  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Donk^  Meded. Ned. Mycol. Ver. 18-21: 177. 1931;  == Corticium subcoronatum  Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Pellicularia subcoronata  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)
