NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is thin, flat, cottony, and whitish, 3) spores that are elliptic to slightly navicular, 4) 6-spored basidia, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, all septa with clamp connections, the basal hyphae wide and thick-walled.^ RANGE ^Botryobasidium subcoronatum has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, CT, LA, MA, MD, MI, MN, MO, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, PA, RI, TN, VT, and WI, (Ginns), Europe including Switzerland, Asia, (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, appressed tightly, cottony and soft in consistency, "open-tomentose when young, later almost membranous patches several centimeters in extent"; "whitish when young, cream-colored to yellow-ocherish when older"; smooth, dull, tomentose; margin thin^, (Breitenbach), thin, at first reticulate [netted] to hypochnoid [with dry rather loosely intertwined hyphae arranged flat on substrate], when old a more or less continuous subpellicular layer; at first whitish, then yellowish or ochraceous, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood of conifers and hardwoods^, (Eriksson), on wood or bark of a varieties of conifers and hardwoods; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), summer-fall (Breitenbach), on rotting hardwood and conifer wood in old woodland, also on old fruitbodies of Schizopora paradoxa and Phlebia tremellosa; fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-9 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic to slightly navicular [boat-shaped], smooth, inamyloid, colorless, cyanophilic^; BASIDIA 6-spored, 15-25 x 6-10 um, cylindric, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic 5-10(12) um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, all septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 6-7.5 x 2.5-3 um, navicular with distinct apiculus, smooth; BASIDIA mostly 6-spored, 20-25(30) x 7-9 um, "at first rounded or ellipsoid, then longer and more subcylindrical, more or less constricted"; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae loosely interwoven, clamped, BASAL HYPHAE 7-10 um wide, thick-walled, colorless, richly branched, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Most other Botryobasidium species do not have clamp connections.
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
72
FAMILY  Botryobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Botryobasidium vagum  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) D.P. Rogers^  Stud. Nat. Hist. Iowa Univ. 17: 17. 1935;  == Corticium vagum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Pellicularia vaga  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is arachnoid to hypochnoid, colored cream to pale buff, 3) spores measuring 7-10 x 2.5-5 um that are navicular to elliptic with a prominent apiculus, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) 4-8-spored basidia, and 5) wide subicular hyphae with right angle branching and without clamp connections.^ | Note that Corticium vagum (Berk. & Curt.) sensu Burt is a synonym of Rhizoctonia solani. RANGE ^Botryobasidium vagum has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, FL, GA, IA, IL, KS, LA, MA, MD, MI, MN, MO, NC, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, RI, SC, SD, TN, TX, and WI, (Ginns). Distribution includes AZ (Gilbertson).
FRUITING BODY  arachnoid to hypochnoid; cream to pale buff^, (Gilbertson), cream to pale buff (Martin), 0.02cm thick, "reticulate, hypochnoid, then continuous and subpellicular, often extensively confluent, loosely interwoven"; grayish white, greenish gray, yellowish gray, dull yellow, grayish yellow, grayish beige, or even brownish gray, (Jung, H.S.(1)), resupinate, arachnoid to hypochnoid, cream to light buff, margin thinning out, (Lindsey), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on bark of dead limb; "branch; trunk; stump; exposed root; decaying logs; dead fungus"^; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Larix (larch), Kalmia latifolia (Mountain Laurel), Libocedrus (Incense-cedar), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Rhododendron, Quercus (oak), Sabal palmetto (Cabbage Palm), Salix (willow), Sambucus (elder), Taxodium (baldcypress), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), and fungus species: Bjerkandera adusta, Hexagonia hydnoides, Phellinus laevigatus; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), fall, winter, spring; also occasionally on herbaceous debris, (Buczacki) 
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-10 x 3.5-5 um, navicular [boat-shaped] to elliptic, tapered at apex, curved or flattened on one side, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with prominent apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-8-spored, 7-9 um wide, cylindric, often inflated at base or apex; CYSTIDIA absent; SUBICULAR HYPHAE up to 10 um wide, branching at right angles, thin-walled, without clamp connections, (Gilbertson), SPORES 8-9 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, CYSTIDIA absent; hyphae without clamp connections, (Martin), SPORES 7.2-12(13.6) x 3-5 um, narrowly navicular, obliquely subfusiform, or navicularly subcylindric; BASIDIA 6-spored, (13.6)16-24.8 x (7.2)8.8-12.8 um, short clavate, then subcylindric, somewhat constricted in the middle; HYPHAE septate, without clamp connections, subhymenial hyphae 5.6-8 um wide, colorless, thin-walled or slightly thick-walled (wall up to 1 um thick), densely branched into candelabra, basal hyphae 8-12.4 um wide, yellowish, thick-walled (wall up to 2.4 um thick), commonly branched, (Jung, H.S.), SPORES 7-10 x 3.5-5 um, navicular to elliptic, "tapered at the apex, curved or flattened on one side, with a prominent apiculus", colorless, inamyloid; BASIDIA 4-8-spored, 18-30 x 7-8 um, simple septate at base; CYSTIDIA and other sterile elements lacking; HYPHAE monomitic, subicular hyphae up to 10 um wide, thin-walled, simple-septate, branching at right angles, (Lindsey)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'wandering'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gilbertson(9), Ginns(5), Martin, K.J.(1), Jung, H.S.(1), Lindsey(3), Buczacki(1)*
73
FAMILY  Botryobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Botryohypochnus isabellinus  (Fr.) J. Erikss.^  Svensk Bot. Tidskr. 52. 2. 1958;  == Hypochnus isabellina  Fr.;  Botryobasidium isabellinum  (Fr.) D.P. Rogers;  Pellicularia isabellina  (Fr.) D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed wood, 2) a fruitbody that is thin, cottony, whitish to yellowish, and several centimeters across, 3) spores that are round, spiny, inamyloid, and yellowish, 4) basidia that are short subcylindric, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae short-celled and relatively wide.^ RANGE ^Botryohypochnus isabellinus has been found in BC, WA, OR, MB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AZ, CO, CT, FL, IA, LA, MA, MI, NM, NY, PA, TN, VA, and WI, (Ginns), Europe including Switzerland, and Asia, (Breitenbach), and Denmark and Norway, (Eriksson). Desjardin(6) illustrate it for CA.
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, "forming thin tomentose-membranous patches" several centimeters across, attached loosely, consistency soft, cottony; light to ocher-yellow; surface cottony, tomentose^, (Breitenbach), loose, hypochnoid [with dry rather loosely intertwined hyphae arranged flat on substrate]; "at first whitish then yellowish to ochraceous", (Eriksson), spore deposit yellowish (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood of conifers and hardwoods^, (Eriksson), on "the underside of rotten trunks and branches of Picea (spruce)", according to literature "also of other conifers, as well as on hardwoods", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), bark; soil; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Liriodendron tulipifera (tuliptree), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus (aspen and cottonwood), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), Pteridium latiusculum (fern); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), summer, fall; also on old polypore fruitbodies, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9.5 um in diameter including ornamentation, round, with spines, inamyloid, yellowish, rather thick-walled, some with droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-22 x 9-10.5 um, short-subcylindric, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic: BASAL HYPHAE up to 12 um wide, yellowish, thick-walled, with right angled branches, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 6-8 um, short-celled, colorless, thin-walled; "All septa with clamps" [but note contrast with Eriksson below, and hyphae are illustrated without clamp connections], (Breitenbach), SPORES 7-10 um in diameter, round, with numerous spines 1-3 um long, inamyloid, yellowish, cyanophilic, with distinct apiculus; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-22 x 8-10 um, at first rounded, then obovate to subcylindric, oil droplets present; HYPHAE monomitic loosely interwoven, septa simple-septate [without clamp connections], BASAL HYPHAE about 10 um wide, yellow, sparsely branched at right angles, hymenial hyphae 6-8 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of isabelline color'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*
74
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Bulbillomyces farinosus  (Bres.) Julich^  Persoonia 8(1): 69. 1974
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  The most obvious feature is the crowded white granules less than 0.1cm across which represent the sclerotial stage, usually on wood. They range from spherical to nearly spherical or pear-shaped. These are more often seen than the sexual stage which consists of thin, soft, waxy, greyish patches tightly attached to wood in wet places.^ | The white sclerotia float away on the water and are dispersed widely when the water level falls again. "It can often be seen in localities that are submerged for a period of a month or more in the autumn or in the early spring, but are dry most of the summer.", (Eriksson(4)). Breitenbach(2) say the granules in the photograph [which is of fresh material] are about 0.01-0.02cm. Eriksson(4) say "reaching 0,4 in diam., when dried smaller". This could mean mm, but their photograph of living material with a 1 centimeter scale shows white granules that reach 0.2cm. RANGE ^The photographs were taken in BC. Collections are deposited from BC at the University of British Columbia. There is a New York Botanical Garden record from WA in 1929. Bulbillomyces farinosus is also known from ON, MA, MO, NH, NY, UT, and VA, (Ginns(5)), as well as Europe (including Switzerland) and Asia, (Breitenbach(2)). It is also found in Scandinavia (Eriksson(4)) and the British Isles (Buczacki(1)). MycoPortal adds records from DE, FL, IA, LA, MD, MI, NC, NJ, Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, Sweden, Portugal, and New Zealand.
FRUITING BODY  sexual stage spread out on the surface of wood, tightly attached, "forming thin, crustose patches several centimeters in extent, surface smooth to slightly verrucose, gray-ocherish", margin +/- thinning out; consistency "waxlike and soft when fresh"; sclerotia stage, also known as Aegerita candida Pers., consists of crowded, pear-shaped, white granules about 0.01-0.02cm across, and is more frequently seen than the sexual stage^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, adnate, usually 0.01-0.03cm, rarely thicker, "margin indeterminately thinning out in young specimens, in mature fruitbodies varying after circumstances but often more determinate"; grayish watery white and waxy when wet and alive; "smooth but under the lens more or less finely papillose and besides pilose by the projecting cystidia"; sclerotia round to nearly round, "like small eggs, in the living state reaching 0,4 in diam., when dried smaller, at first scattered on the wood then close together, loosely attached, pure white when alive", (Eriksson)
HABITAT  found on wood or bark (Acer, Alnus, Fagus, Populus, Ulmus, Pinus), or on ground, mostly in very wet places, (Ginns(5)), on "the undersides of stumps and on wood of broadleaved trees lying on the ground, in damp, periodically flooded places in lake- and streamside woods", spring and fall, (Breitenbach)^, on "decayed, soaked wood on shores of lakes and brooks or in depressions which are water-filled during wet periods", (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-9 x 4.5-6 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, cyanophilic, thick-walled, with or without droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 26-32 x 6-7 um, clavate, somewhat constricted, with basal clamp connection; LAMPROCYSTIDIA 55-100 x 8-15 um, "exserted beyond the hymenium", thick-walled, "smooth when young, later finely incrusted"; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-5.5 um wide, "tightly interwoven and indistinct", septa with clamp connections; SCLEROTIA surface "composed of pyriform to subglobose cells arranged in clusters", 9-18 x 8-14 um, septa with clamp connections, "contents granular-guttulate, cyanophilic and dextrinoid", (Breitenbach), SPORES 6-9(11) x 5-6(7) um, inamyloid, cyanophilic, at least in fresh material; BASIDIA "at first subglobose to pyriform, then obpyriform to subcylindrical, when mature more or less urniform or sometimes sinuous", normally 4-spored, containing numerous oil droplets and with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA "varying in number but normally numerous", reaching 60-100 um in length, basally 8-12 um wide, projecting part 4-7 um wide, "at first thin-walled, later much thickwalled, and heavily encrusted with crystals of varying sizes, wider at the base, projecting part subcylindrical, tapering towards the apex"; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-5 um wide, mostly thin-walled, clamped, richly branched and anastomosed, all hyphae more or less cyanophilic at least when fresh; sclerotia composed of radially growing short-celled, thin-walled, clamped hyphae with numerous branches and anastomoses, sclerotial surface formed by subglobose or pyriform, often somewhat stalked, terminal cells, "the protoplasm of which, when stained in cotton-blue consists of a central grainy part where the grains are more stained, and a peripheral, homogenous protoplasm, evenly stained", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'farinose' (flour-like or mealy)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Eriksson(4)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
75
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Butlerelfia eustacei  Weresub & Illman^  Can. J. Bot. 58: 145. 1980
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  This fungus was found associated with fisheye rot of apples and was studied as isolated from the apples and grown on wood. Features are 1) a fruitbody spread over the woody substrate, with a surface that is white to cream (then aging to tan) and a waxy consistency, 2) sometimes a sweetly fruity odor, 3) spores that are elliptic to oblong, and when mature cyanophilic, 4) basidia that are 4-spored, long and evenly clavate, 5) context that is prosenchymatous with branching of hyphae more usually interseptal than from clamp connections, 6) thickened walls of subicular tissues and other elements, and 7) globoid crystalline masses found within the context.^ RANGE ^Butlerelfia eustacei has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, IL, NY, and VA, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  on woody substrate eventually broadly effused; white to cream, then aging to tan; context as much as 0.02cm deep, somewhat ceraceous [waxy], additionally browned; odor sometimes sweetly fruity^, (Weresub)
HABITAT  isolated from fisheye rot of apples in cold storage^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4)4.5-6(7.5) x 2.5-3(3.5-4) um, elliptic to oval to somewhat oblong, "basally slightly askew"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (16-20)30-45 x 3.5-5(5.5) um, long and evenly clavate; hymenium homogeneous; CONTEXT prosenchymatous, branching of hyphae, at least initially, more usually interseptal than from the clamp cell, subhymenium and subiculum eventually (with increasing numbers of sprouting clamp connections) building up into a texture intricata to epidermoidea, eventually cyanophilic in wall of the firm to slightly thickened wall of spores "and thickened wall of subicular hyphae, sometimes as well in the thin wall of other hyphae and hymenial elements", "globoid crystalline masses within the prosenchymatous context" (on woody substrate), (Weresub)
NAME ORIGIN  after Eustace, who like Butler reported fisheye rot of stored apples from North America
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Weresub(1), Ginns(5)
76
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Byssocorticium atrovirens  (Fr.) Singer^  as Bondartsev & Singer ex Singer, Mycologia 36: 69. 1944;  == Thelephora atrovirens  Fr.;  Corticium atrovirens  (Fr.) Fr.;  Sporotrichum aeruginosum  Schwein.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood or ground litter, 2) a cottony fruitbody that is blue or bluish green, 3) small round spores that are thick-walled, with one large oil droplet, 4) basidia with numerous oil droplets, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae narrow and light blue green, with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Byssocorticium atrovirens has been found in OR, NB, NS, ON, PQ, CA, CT, IA, IL, IN, MA, MI, NC, NH, NJ, NY, PA, SC, VA, and VT, (Ginns(5)), and Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Poland, Portugal, Sweden, United Kingdom, Yugoslavia, USSR, and Morocco, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  soft, hypochnoid [with dry rather loosely intertwined hyphae arranged flat on substrate], byssoid [cottony], loosely attached; blue or bluish green^, (Eriksson), irregularly spread out flat, 1-4cm long, 1-2cm wide, thin, 0.015-0.025cm thick, floccose-fibrillose or arachnoid [cobwebby]; greenish glaucous blue to deep bluish gray-green; even, not cracked; margin thinning out, (Burt), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood of conifers and hardwoods, as well as on leaves and other ground litter, usually in humid localities^, (Eriksson), on decaying bark, rotting wood, fallen branches, soil, Acer sp., Betula sp., Quercus sp., mycorrhizal with some amentiferous trees, (Ginns(5)), on underside of decaying bark and fallen branches (Burt); fall, winter, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3-4 x 3-4 um, round, with distinct apiculus, thick-walled, one large oil droplet^; BASIDIA 4-spored, clavate, mostly 15-20 x 4-5 um, with numerous oil droplets; HYPHAE monomitic narrow, light blue green, mostly 2.5-3 um wide, with clamp connections, "basal hyphae with somewhat thickened walls, straight and often joined to rhizomorph-like bundles of parallel hyphae", sparsely branched at right angles, with numerous anastomoses and scattered clamp connections, hymenial hyphae "usually branched from clamps, otherwise from the vicinity of septa", (Eriksson), SPORES 2.5-4(4.5) um in diameter, nearly round to round, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means "black-green"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Burt(1) (as Corticium atrovirens), Ginns(5), Julich(3) (in German), Ginns(23), Buczacki(1)*
77
FAMILY  Irpicaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Byssomerulius albostramineus  (Torrend) Hjortstam^  Windahlia 17: 56. 1987;  Meruliopsis albostraminea  (Torrend) Julich & Stalpers [as Meruliopsis albostramineus];  == Merulius albostramineus  Torrend;  Ceraceomerulius albostramineus  (Torrend) Ginns;  Merulius armeniacus  Bres.;  Byssomerulius armeniacus  (Bres.) Gilb.;  Merulius atropurpureus  W.B. Cooke;  Merulius bellus  Berk. & M.A. Curtis sensu W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a resupinate fruitbody growing spread out on wood, 2) a surface that is white to cream or flesh color when fresh, 3) folds on the spore-bearing surface that are randomly oriented, interrupted or if continuous anastomosing to form circular, oval, or irregularly shaped pits, 4) a margin that is granulose to mycelioid, 5) spores that are cylindric to narrowly oblong, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 6) narrowly clavate cystidia that project, and fusoid cystidioles that do not, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the context hyphae often branched at right angles, sometimes granule encrusted, and simple-septate or with very rare clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, MA, MT, NC, NV, NY, PA, WV, WY, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Finland, Italy, Portugal, Sweden, Switzerland, Malaysia, Russia, Australia, and the Solomon Islands, and it has been recorded from NJ, Germany, and Poland, (Ginns(12)). It has also been recorded from NM (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  up to 15cm x 5cm and averaging 0.05cm thick, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached]; spore-bearing surface when fresh white to cream or flesh color, when dry pale ochraceous, ochraceous, tan, flesh color, rufous, chestnut, or deep reddish purple, shiny, folds up to 0.05cm deep, randomly oriented, interrupted or "if continuous anastomosing to form circular, oval, or irregularly shaped pits", 2 to 4 per millimeter; margin generally 0.1-0.3cm but up to 0.8cm wide, "white to pallid, adnate, granulose to mycelioid"; context about 0.03cm thick, homogeneous, white to cream; spore print white^, (Ginns(12))
HABITAT  saprophytic on Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja, occasionally on Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Eucalyptus, and Populus; associated with a brown rot; usually collected from late June through September^, (Ginns(12)), also Tsuga (hemlock), Cercocarpus (mountain mahogany), (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-5.5 x 1.5-2(2.5) um, cylindric to narrowly oblong, in side view "allantoid or cylindrical and either bent at the basal end or adaxially slightly concave", "smooth, IKI -, pale blue in lactic-blue", colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 12-24 x 4.5-5.5 um, narrowly clavate; HYPHOID CYSTIDIA sometimes rare or absent, 22-50 x 3-7 um, projecting up to 20 um, narrowly clavate, "utriform to obclavate or lageniform, thin-walled, occasionally capitate incrusted"; FUSOID CYSTIDIOLES scattered, not projecting; HYPHAE monomitic, context hyphae 2-5(6) um wide, loosely woven, often branched at right angles, colorless, simple-septate or with very rare clamp connections, thin-walled, "sometimes granule encrusted, particularly near the subhymenium", "subhymenium and adjacent context impregnated with a yellow granular or resin-like substance" (Ginns(12)) 
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Gloeoporus taxicola has smaller, allantoid spores measuring 3-5 x 1-1.5 um, (Ginns(12)). Ceraceomyces serpens is morphologically similar to pale ochraceous specimens of Byssomerulius albostramineus but "has clamp connections, and spores that are predominantly ovoid, 2-2.5 um wide with a comparatively broad, truncate apiculus", (Ginns(12)). See also SIMILAR section of Gloeoporus ambiguus and Byssomerulius corium.
SOURCES  Ginns(12) (as Ceraceomerulius albostramineus), Ginns(5) (as Meruliopsis albostramineus)
78
FAMILY  Irpicaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Byssomerulius corium  (Pers.) Parmasto^  Eesti NSV Tead. Akad. Toim., Biol. seer 16(4): 383. 1967;  Meruliopsis corium  (Pers.) Ginns  Can. J. Bot. 54: 126. 1976;  == Thelephora corium  Pers.;  Merulius corium  (Pers.) Fr.;  Merulius confluens  Schwein.;  Byssomerulius confluens  (Schwein.) Lindsey & Gilb.;  Merulius pallens  Schwein.;  Merulius haedinus  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Merulius ulmi  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  netted crust
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on hardwood, often on the underside of small branches, 2) a leathery fruitbody spread out over the surface, often with band-like or shingled cap edges projecting, the cap surface white to pallid, zonate, and tomentose to hairy, 3) a spore-bearing surface that is whitish or pale yellow to red-orange, either with oval pits 2-4 per millimeter, or with a merulioid pattern, or with warty projections, 4) the extreme margin fringed, 5) spores that are oblong to oval, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae simple-septate or with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Byssomerulius corium is found in BC, WA, OR, MB, NS, ON, SK, AK, AL, AZ, CA, DC, FL, GA, LA, MD, MN, MT, NM, NY, OH, PA, SC, TN, VA, and WI, (Ginns(5)). Collections were examined from BC, MB, ON, SK, AL, NY, PA, Mexico, Cuba, Brazil, Chile, Ecuador, Venezuela, United Kingdom, Tanzania, and Australia. It is widespread throughout the hardwood forests of North America and Europe. It has also been recorded from Morocco, Mozambique, South Africa, China, India, Japan, Russia (including Siberia, Kamchatka), and New Zealand (Ginns(12)). Its presence has also been recorded in Switzerland (Breitenbach) and Scandinavia (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  effused [spread out over surface] to effused-reflexed [bent outwards from surface to form cap], rarely dimidiate, often confluent or imbricate [shingled]; when effused adnate [firmly attached], generally 4cm x 2cm but up to 10cm x 5cm; margin tomentose to cottony, "white to pallid, rarely pinkish tan", the extreme edge fimbriate [fringed], overall up to 0.2cm wide; where reflexed the cap up to 5cm wide and 0.6cm thick, firm, white to pallid, zonate, "tomentose or matted-tomentose to hirsute"; spore-bearing surface waxy, the folds about 0.03cm wide and up to 0.1cm deep, "pale yellow, pale orange, fawn, ochraceous to distinctly orange or red-orange", "interrupted to form warty projections or more commonly continuous and anastomosing to form concentrically or randomly arranged, oval pits, two to four per millimetre"; context white to pallid, generally about 0.07cm thick but in reflexed specimens occasionally up to 0.5cm thick^, (Ginns(12)) |resupinate to semipileate, forming membranous patches 0.05-0.1cm thick and several centimeters to decimeters across; band-like cap edges projecting 0.3-1(2)cm from substrate, on vertical substrates often imbricate, cap surface whitish to ocherish, weakly zoned, fibrillose-tomentose; spore-bearing surface "almost smooth when young, then distinctly reticulate-poroid to merulioid and strongly verrucose, whitish to ocherish, brownish when old, margin finely fringed where growing (byssoid)"; consistency "leathery, membranous, rather tough"; odor and taste none, (Breitenbach), about 0.05-0.1cm thick, first resupinate then with reflexed margin or even capped, the cap usually remaining white, sometimes gray or even green (from algae), finely tomentose; spore-bearing surface at first white then yellowish and finally more or less brownish; flesh white and very soft, (Eriksson) |spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on bark and wood of hardwoods, rarely on conifers, associated with a white rot, frequently found on branches up to 3cm in diameter; in Canada and northern US principally in late summer and fall, but fruitbodies persist into the winter^, (Ginns(12)), "on bark and wood; dead twigs; dead branches on live trees", (Ginns(5)), on the underside of dead branches of hardwoods, commonly on the underside of branches and twigs in brush piles; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), often colored violaceous pink by Hypomyces rosellus but perithecia rare (Courtecuisse for Europe)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-7(8.5) x 2-3.5 um, oblong to oval, in side view adaxially often flattened or slightly concave, smooth, IKI-, colorless, very pale blue in lactic-blue, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 17-40 x 4-6 um, cylindric to narrowly clavate, CYSTIDIA lacking; HYPHAE monomitic, context hyphae in two, sometimes indistinct layers, the layer farther from the hymenium with hyphae 2-6.5(8.5) um wide, randomly woven, colorless, rather thin-walled to thick-walled, "rigid, simple-septate or with rare clamp connections", the layer closer to the hymenium extending to the subhymenium "impregnated with fine granules or a resin-like substance", the hyphae similar but 2-5.5(6.5) um wide, "thin-walled, often slightly gelatinized and then rather thin-walled", subhymenial hyphae "contorted, often branched", clamp connections rather common, (Ginns(12)) |SPORES 5-6 x 2.5-3.5 um, cylindric-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 4-6 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, in part coarsely encrusted, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach) |SPORES 5-6 x 2.5-3 um, subcylindric, inamyloid, smooth, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-35 x 5-6 um, narrowly clavate; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, all hyphae without clamp connections, subhymenial hyphae 2.5-3.5 um wide, densely intertwined, thin-walled, more or less covered with fine crystals, basal hyphae 3-5 um wide, with thickened walls, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Gloeoporus ambiguus grows primarily on conifers, and has a shiny, violaceous-brown to dark purple-black spore-bearing surface (but intergradations in color can cause difficulty in assigning the species name), (Ginns(12)). Byssomerulius albostramineus and Gloeoporus taxicola may be violaceous or dark purple, and have small, allantoid or basally bent spores, (Ginns(12)). See also SIMILAR section of Phlebia tremellosa.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)* (as Meruliopsis), Ginns(12) (as Meruliopsis), Eriksson(2), Trudell(4)* (as Meruliopsis), Ginns(5) (as Meruliopsis), Courtecuisse(1)* (as Meruliopsis), Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, MacKinnon(1)*
79
FAMILY  Carcinomycetaceae, Order Tremellales, Class Tremellomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Carcinomyces effibulatus  (Ginns & Sunhede) Oberw. & Bandon^  Nordic Jl Bot. 2(5): 509 (1982);  Syzygospora effibulata  (Ginns & Sunhede) Ginns  Mycologia 78(4): 626. 1986;  Christiansenia effibulata  Ginns & Sunhede
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Carcinomyces effibulatus grows as a thin film on the surface of tumor-like growths of the caps and stems of Gymnopus dryophilus.^ |The description is derived from Ginns(6) except where noted. |Liu, X.-Z.(1) resurrected the genus Carcinomyces for a clade containing this species as well as Tremella polyporina and Bullera arundiariae. The genus Syzygospora sensu Ginna(6) has been shown to be polyphyletic (Liu, X.-Z.(1)). MycoBank, accessed January 2, 2022, listed Carcinomyces effibulatus as the current name, but the online Species Fungorum, accessed the same day, listed Syzygospora effibulata as the current name. RANGE ^It is found at least in BC and Sweden.
FRUITING BODY  a thin film on the surface of galls (tumor-like outgrowths) on the surface of Gymnopus dryophilus caps and stems, (Ginns), the macroscopically indistinguishable Syzygospora mycetophila [also known as Carcinomyces mycetophilus] is described as a 0.01-0.05cm thick, glassy, gelatinous, cream-yellow film covering round, wart-like, or brain-shaped to somewhat compressed gelatinous growths (0.5-5cm wide or larger), as many as 35, sometimes fused, on cap, gills, and stem of Gymnopus dryophilus, (Lincoff, but Ginns indicates that the gills are not involved in this species or S. mycetophila)
HABITAT  on Gymnopus dryophilus caps and stems
MICROSCOPIC  spores (5.5)6-8(10) x 1.8-2.5 um, cylindric to narrowly obovate, in side view cylindric, rarely suballantoid (somewhat curved sausage-shaped), broadly attached to basidia; blastoconidia of two types, some nearly round to broadly elliptic, 2-3.5 x 1.5-2 um, "formed by budding from basidiospores or, more commonly, from the apices of conidiophores, others rather few, cylindrical to narrowly ellipsoid, up to 13 x 2 um formed on conidiophores"^; basidia 2(3)-spored, cylindric, (25)35-55 x 5-7 um, sterigmata up to 5(7) um long with the tips containing a refractive oily deposit; hyphae colorless, thin-walled, simple-septate, 2-4 um wide, clamp connections not observed, (Ginns), basidiospores inamyloid, smooth, (Oberwinkler)
NAME ORIGIN  "fibula" means "clasp", "effibulata" refers to the absence of clamp connections
SIMILAR  Syzygospora mycetophila, also known as Carcinomyces mycetophilus, (NB, ON, PQ, NY, NH, VT, Mexico) which also grows on the surface of galls on Gymnopus dryophilus, is indistinguishable macroscopically but has 4-spored basidia, clamp connections, and more ellipsoid spores, (Ginns). |Syzygospora tumefaciens (NB, Denmark, Sweden) which also grows on galls of Gymnopus dryophilus as well as galls of Rhodocollybia butyracea, is indistinguishable macroscopically but has broadly elliptic spores 6-8(9) x 3-4 um, obliquely attached to 4-spored basidia, and has clamp connections, (Ginns). |Syzygospora norvegica (found in Norway) grows on hypertrophied gills of Rhodocollybia butyracea, (Ginns). |Heterocephalacria bachmannii (as Syzygospora) grows on Cladonia lichen and is distinguished from the other heterobasidiomycetes growing on lichen by its aseptate basidia: it has been reported from BC, AK, Europe, Africa (Madeira), Asia (New Guinea), and South America (Guyana), (Hafellner).
SOURCES  Ginns(6) (as Syzygospora effibulata), Lincoff(2) has illustration of the similar S. mycetophila as Christiansenia mycetophila, Oberwinkler(1), Hafellner(1) (re Heterocephalacria bachmannii), Liu, X.-Z.(1)
80
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ceraceomyces borealis  (Romell) J. Erikss. & Ryvarden^  Cort. N. Europe 2: 205. 1973;  == Merulius borealis  Romell;  Athelia borealis  (Romell) Parmasto;  Merulius gyrosus  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on wood, 2) fruitbodies that are pellicular, cream color at first, developing interrupted randomly arranged folds and wrinkles, the surface somewhat waxy when old, the margin mycelioid to membranous, the subiculum soft, loose, and white, and rhizomorphs often present, 3) spores that are cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, with a prominent apiculus, and 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Ceraceomyces borealis has been reported from BC, WA, ID, AB, ON, PQ, AL, CO, ME, MI, MN, NC, NY, and TN, (Ginns(5)), and Czechoslovakia, Finland, Sweden, USSR (European part), Russia (Siberia), and Morocco, (Ginns(12)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, up to 13cm x 6cm, and averaging 0.08cm thick; separable; cream when fresh, "drying ochraceous to brownish or rarely darker"; "frequently mottled, shiny or somewhat pruinose, translucent near the margin, often fissured, crust-like, rugose to gyrose-plicate", the folds when present about 0.05cm wide and 0.07cm deep, "interrupted, randomly arranged, not forming pits"; margin 0.2(0.4)cm wide, "mycelioid to membranous, thin, loosely attached", white when fresh, white or pallid when dry; hyphal strands present in some specimens up to 0.05cm wide; flesh about 0.07cm thick, homogeneous, white to pallid^, (Ginns), large, often several decimeters in extent, loosely attached to wood, pellicular, at first thin and soft, when old developing a thickened somewhat ceraceous [waxy] spore-bearing surface; white becoming yellowish or even pale ochraceous; "at first smooth but soon much folded and wrinkled"; subiculum soft, loose, and white, rhizomorphs often present, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  saprophytic on hardwoods and conifers, especially Betula [birch], Populus, Quercus [oak], Abies [fir], Picea [spruce], and Pinus [pine]; associated with a brown rot, mainly in August and September, but recorded as early as July and as late as December^, (Ginns(12)), associated with a brown rot or a white rot, (Ginns(5)), summer, fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-7(8.5) x 1.5-2(2.5) um, subfusiform to cylindric, in side view "adaxially concave or basally bent", "with prominent, broad, blunt apiculus", spore iodine negative, colorless in KOH, often adhering in groups of 2-4^; BASIDIA 20-33 x 4-5.5 um, narrowly clavate; CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHAE monomitic: context hyphae 2-7.5(9) um wide, loosely woven, colorless, "exterior sparsely crystalline-incrusted, with prominent clamps", thin-walled or occasionally rather thick-walled, often collapsed when dried; "subhymenial detail often obscure because of dense, granular deposits, generally showing thickening, hyphae closely packed", (Ginns(12)), SPORES 6-8 x 1.8-2 um, cylindric, with oblique apiculus, smooth, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 16-22 x 4-5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic: SUBICULAR HYPHAE 4-7 um wide, thin-walled, or somewhat thick-walled, loosely interwoven, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, richly branched and densely interwoven, clamp connections on all septa, hyphal branches originating at clamp cells or between septa, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'northern'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Ginns(12), Eriksson(2), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
81
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ceraceomyces serpens  (Tode) Ginns^  Can. J. Bot. 54: 147. 1976;  == Merulius serpens  Tode;  Byssomerulius serpens  (Tode) Parmasto;  Ceraceomerulius serpens  (Tode) J. Erikss. & Ryvarden
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) fruitbodies with a soft-membranous texture, the color tan or yellow to pink-ochraceous, the surface with convoluted fine folds, and the white margin sometimes with rhizomorphs, 3) spores that small, oval, smooth, inamyloid, and thin-walled, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, and the subhymenial hyphae with crystalline to granular or resin-like material.^ | Justo(6) indicates that this species belongs in Irpicaceae, and since the holotype of Ceraceomyces (C. tessulatus) is in Amylocorticiaceae, C. serpens would need a different name. RANGE ^Ceraceomyces serpens has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AK, AZ, CA, CO, FL, MI, MN, MT, NC, NJ, NM, NY, SC, and WI, (Ginns(5)), Brazil, widespread in Europe from France to Hungary to Finland, Siberia in Russia, and China, (Ginns(12)), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  up to 10cm x 4cm, occasionally longer, up to 0.07cm thick, effused, adnate [firmly attached]; "usually tan or lemon-yellow to pink-ochraceous, rarely darker to cinnamon-brown"; when fresh soft and membranous, when dry, shiny, pruinose, frequently becoming fissured; folds up to 0.05cm deep, "frequently branched, sometimes interrupted, occasionally gyrose-plicate, anastomosing to form oval or more often, by convergence, irregularly shaped pits, three to five per millimetre"; margin up to 0.5cm wide, "white, variable in a particular specimen from narrow and granulose to wide, radiating and cottony"; flesh homogeneous, white; "hyphal strands sometimes present, white to pallid", up to 0.05cm wide^, (Ginns(12)), resupinate, about 0.05cm thick; at first white, "then more or less yellowish, orange, pale red or even greenish"; at first smooth then merulioid; margin white and becoming fibrillose; "small rhizomorphs often present in the decayed wood and in the periphery of the fruitbody"; subiculum white, (Eriksson), forming soft membranous-waxy patches up to 0.05cm thick and several centimeters to decimeters across, attached +/- loosely; whitish with lilac-red to pink-red spots, "with lilac-red tinge toward margin"; "with cerebriform convoluted folds and somewhat tuberculate"; margin filamentous, sometimes with thin rhizomorphs, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  saprophytic on conifer wood and hardwood^, especially Populus, Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), (Ginns(12)), associated with a white rot, (Ginns(5)), on decayed wood, mostly conifers but also hardwoods, (Eriksson), on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, with and without bark, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-5 x 2-2.5 um, oval to broadly oval, in side view "adaxially flattened or slightly concave, with a distinct, truncated, somewhat elongated apiculus", smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 16-33 x 3.5-5.5 um, narrowly clavate; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic: CONTEXT HYPHAE 2-4.5(6.5) um wide, sometimes swollen at a septum, thin-walled, colorless, with clamp connections, sometimes crystalline-encrusted, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-4 um, the subhymenial area "often heavily impregnated with fine granules or a resin-like substance", (Ginns(12)), SPORES 4-5.5 x 2-2.5 um, narrowly elliptic; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-28 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-3.5 um wide, "densely intertwined, more or less covered with crystalline material", with clamp connections, BASAL HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, more loosely intertwined and more sparsely branched, often joined in parallel fashion to hyphal strings, with clamp connections; abundant crystalline material in interhyphal spaces, (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5.5 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, some with droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 4.5-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 2-4 um, septa with clamp connections, no crystals observed (according to literature with crystal deposits), young fruitbody, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'snake' or 'creeping'
SIMILAR  Pale ochraceous specimens of Byssomerulius albostramineus are morphologically similar, but spores are different and clamp connections are rare, (Ginns(12)).
SOURCES  Ginns(12), Eriksson(2) (as Ceraceomerulius serpens), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Justo(6)
82
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ceraceomyces subapiculatus  (Bres.) Ginns^  Mycotaxon 44(1): 210. 1992;  == Corticium subapiculatum  Bres.;  Peniophora subapiculata  (Bres.) Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) athelioid growth on barkless wood, 2) the type collection pastel yellow to cream, smooth, and crustose, with a very thin, whitish subiculum, 3) spores that are cylindric-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, with a rather broad, blunt apiculus, 4) cystidia that are cylindric, septate, and 3.6 um wide, projecting from the hymenium, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ | Most collections identified as this species (as Peniophora subapiculata) by Burt belong to other species, (Ginns(3)). RANGE ^Ceraceomyces subapiculatus has been found in ID and MT (Ginns(3)).
FRUITING BODY  effused, in pieces, the largest 10cm x 3cm and 0.03cm thick, athelioid; pastel yellow to cream; hymenial surface "smooth, delicate, crustose"; margin "not extant"; subiculum very thin, white to pallid; spore print "pallid to white when dry and on black paper"^, (Ginns(3))
HABITAT  underside of charred, debarked but not obviously decayed log; barkless wood; Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine)^, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (6.0)6.2-8.0(10.0) x 3.0-3.6 um, cylindric-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, acyanophilic, thin-walled, with rather broad, blunt apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 28-30 x 5-7 um, cylindric-clavate, sterigmata projecting 10-15 um when mature, all cells in hymenium have basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA scattered in marginal area, 3.6 um wide, projecting up to 16 um, cylindric with broadly rounded apex, "septate with a clamp connection at each septum"; HYPHAE monomitic: SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3.2-7.5 um wide, loosely woven, colorless, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled to 0.8 um thick, with clamp connections, (Ginns(3))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Ginns(3), Ginns(5)
83
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ceraceomyces sublaevis  (Bres.) Julich^  Beih. Willdenowia 7: 147. 1972;  == Corticium sublaeve  Bres.;  Peniophora sublaevis  (Bres.) Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) fruitbodies that are thin at first but become thicker and waxy, the color whitish to cream, the surface smooth or merulioid, and the margin white, 3) spores that are small, nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) hyphal cystidia present or not, when present projecting, usually septate and with clamp connections, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, the subhymenial hyphae usually with crystalline deposits.^ RANGE ^Ceraceomyces sublaevis has been found in BC, WA, ON, PE, PQ, CO, CT, NC, NH, NY, OH, PA, RI, and TN, (Ginns), and Austria, Czechoslovakia, Estonia Finland, France, Germany, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Sweden, and United Kingdom, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  effused, at first thin and pellicular, becoming thicker and ceraceous [waxy] in consistency; white to cream; "smooth or in the fresh state sometimes merulioid, when dry cracked, mostly transverse to the wood grain, separable in small pieces"; margin white, finely fibrillose under hand lens^, (Eriksson), thin membranous patches, several centimeters in extent, attached loosely, consistency membranous, wax-like, and soft; whitish to cream; "smooth to slightly merulioid, somewhat fissured when dry, dull"; margin finely arachnoid [cobwebby], without rhizomorphs, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood, mostly of conifers^, (Eriksson), Abies balsamea, Picea engelmannii, Picea rubens, Rhododendron sp., on branch, on log, associated with a white rot, (Ginns), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3-3.5 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic to nearly round; smooth, with one oil droplet^; BASIDIA narrowly clavate, mostly 20-25 x 4-5 um, 4-spored; CYSTIDIA usually few, (sometimes absent), hyphal, 40-60(100) x 4-5 um, projecting 10-30 um, more or less encrusted, with septa and clamp connections; HYPHAE monomitic: subiculum hyphae 3-4 um wide, rather straight and with sparse branching and anastomoses, with clamp connections; subhymenium hyphae 2-3 um wide, densely interwoven, with clamp connections, "as a rule with crystalline deposits", (Eriksson), SPORES 3-3.5 x 2.2-2.5 um, drop-shaped, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with one droplet; BASIDIA 4-spored, 22-28 x 3.5-4.5 um, narrowly clavate, basal clamp connection not seen; SEPTOCYSTIDIA often only a few, which moreover are hard to find, 50-65 x 4.5-6 um, "cylindric, blunt, usually septate and with large clamps"; HYPHAE monomitic 2.5-4.5 um wide, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 2.8-3.5 x 2-2.5 um, inamyloid, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Julich(3) (in German), Buczacki(1)*
84
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ceraceomyces tessulatus  (Cooke) Julich^  Beih. Willdenowia 7: 154. 1972;  == Corticium tessulatum  Cooke;  Athelia tessulata  (Cooke) Donk;  Corticium apiculatum  Bres.;  Corticium illaqueatum  Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is thin, white to yellowish, becoming thicker and waxy, with conspicuous rhizomorphs, 3) on drying a tendency to for the fruitbody to separate off in small rectangular blocks, 4) spores that are obliquely elliptic to pip-shaped, smooth, and colorless, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the subicular hyphae wide with large clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Ceraceomyces tessulatus has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, NS, ON, PQ, AL, AZ, LA, MD, ME, MO, NH, NM, NY, RI, SC, and VT, (Ginns), and Austria, Czechoslovakia, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Norway, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom, and the USSR, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  moderate in size to rather large, detachable, thin at first and pellicular, then becoming thicker and ceraceous [waxy], brittle when dry; white to yellowish, in old parts darker; smooth; subiculum loose and white, rhizomorphs frequent at periphery, emerging from subiculum^, (Eriksson), growing thin and flat on wood, 2-4cm across, in section 0.015-0.02cm thick, "adnate" but with "loose attachment" to substrate with a tendency to scale away from it in rectangular masses, somewhat membranous; "in the herbarium becoming naphthalene-yellow, with central parts light ochraceous-buff"; cracking with drying into masses 0.1-0.4cm wide and separated by fissures 0.1-0.2cm wide, "with some of the white silky subiculum clinging to the substratum"; margin fibrillose and whitish, (Burt), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed hardwood or conifer wood, boards, etc.^, (Eriksson), decaying branches; bark of decaying logs; bark on ground; Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Alnus tenuifolia (Thinleaf Alder), Castanea sp. (chestnut), Picea glauca (White Spruce), Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns), Juniperus (juniper), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Salix (willow), Rubus idaeus (red raspberry), (Julich), summer, fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8 x 3.5-4.5 um, obliquely elliptic to pip-shaped, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-35 x 5-6 um, narrowly clavate; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic: subiculum hyphae 4-8 um wide, loosely interwoven, somewhat thick-walled, sparsely branched and anastomosed, with clamp connections, subhymenium hyphae 3-4 um wide, densely branched and interwoven, with clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 4-4.5 x 3 um, smooth, colorless, few found; no GLOEOCYSTIDIA, hyphae 4 um wide, loosely interwoven, very thin-walled, abundantly nodose-septate, not encrusted, (Burt), SPORES 6-8(10) x 3-4(5) um, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'inlaid with small square stones'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Burt(1) (as Corticium tessulatum), Julich(3) (in German), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
85
FAMILY  Ceratobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ceratobasidium anceps  (Bres. & Syd.) H.S. Jacks.^  Canadian Jour. Res. C. 27: 243. 1949;  Tulasnella anceps  Bres. & Syd.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Ceratobasidium anceps is pathogenic "on live petioles and leaves, causing brown necrotic patches"; the fruiting bodies are produced on the underside of leaves in advance of the necrotic tissue, brown sclerotia developing on surface of dead areas of host, (Ginns). Microscopic characters include 1) asymmetrically elliptic spores that are smooth and inamyloid, 2) basidia usually 4-spored, with sterigmata 10-16 um long, basidia often formed directly from hyphal cells (pleurobasidial), and 3) hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Ceratobasidium anceps has been found in WA, OR, ON, PQ, ME, NH, NY, and WI, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  forms "a delicate film over the apparently uninjured lower surface of leaves of the host, usually at or near the margin of necrotic lesions, sometimes forming a separable pellicle", imperfect stage "represented by brown sclerotia which develop on the surface of dead areas of host and which are deciduous when fully matured"^, (Martin), "pruinose to pellicular, very thin"; spore bearing surface discontinuous or continuous, whitish or grayish; sclerotia "at first whitish, brown when mature", deciduous [falling off], (Julich), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on at least 66 genera of trees, herbs, and ferns^, (Ginns), on living bracken fronds; spring to fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 9-13 x 4.5-7 um, asymmetrically elliptic, widest below middle, flattened and appearing straight on one side, with prominent apiculus, spore smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 10-18 x 8-12 um, "short-cylindric, broadly clavate, obovate, or irregular", "often formed directly from hyphal cells, in which case the base may have a lateral extension on one or both sides", sterigmata usually 4, occasionally 3, developing as spherical projections that become ventricose-cylindric, 10-16 um long; hyphae 3.5-5.5 um wide, intertwining, branching (often at right angles), thin-walled, without clamp connections, (Martin), SPORES 9-13 x 4.5-7.5 um, elliptic to subcylindric; basidia 10-18 x 8-12 um, subspherical to short-cylindric, sometimes pleurobasidial, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'two-headed, double'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Martin, G.W.(1), Julich(5), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)
86
FAMILY  Ceratobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ceratobasidium cornigerum  (Bourdot) D.P. Rogers^  Stud. Nat. Hist. Iowa Univ. 17: 5. 1935;  Corticium cornigerum  Bourdot
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood and other substrates, 2) a fruitbody that is a thin gray layer, waxy-pruinose when fresh, 3) spores that are smooth, inamyloid, and oval to elliptic, germinating by repetition, 4) 4-spored, roundish basidia with large sterigmata, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Ceratobasidium cornigerum has been found in OR, AB, ON, CO, IA, IL, NY, and OH, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe and the Marshall Islands, (Martin). There are collections from BC deposited at University of British Columbia by R. Bandoni.
FRUITING BODY  effused, tenuous, margin indefinite; "gull-gray"(R) to "pale gull-gray"(R), when dry silvery gray; when fresh waxy-pruinose, when dry forming a closely adherent encrustation or bloom, under hand lens minutely poroid to minutely floccose^, (Martin), very thin, when fresh smooth ceraceous [waxy], when dry appears like a grayish bloom, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on bark and wood, decayed wood, mycorrhizal with exotic and native orchids, hosts include Coeloglossum (an orchid genus), Platanthera obtusata (blunt-leaf orchid), Rhus glabra (smooth sumac), Quercus gambelii. (Gambel Oak), Salix sp. (willow), Ulmus sp. (elm), (Ginns), on different kinds of substrate, but preferably newly fallen branches of conifers and hardwoods with still fresh bark, seeming to be most common on twigs of Pinus (pine) and Picea (spruce) fallen to the ground, (Eriksson), on a wide range of organic substrates including leaf litter, rotting hardwood, old fern fronds, living leaves, and soil; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-11.5 x 3.5-6 um, narrowly oval to elliptic, smooth, inamyloid^, spore repetition occurs laterally; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-16 x 7-10 um, sterigmata 10-15 um long; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, BASAL HYPHAE about 5 um wide, with somewhat thickened walls, straight, sparsely branched at right angles, no clamp connections, hymenial branches more narrow, thin-walled and richly branched especially in old hymenia, no clamp connections, "finally forming a pseudoparenchymatous structure", (Eriksson), SPORES (6.5)7.5-9.5 x 4-6 um, "broadly fusiform in one aspect, asymmetrical, oblong-ellipsoid, obliquely attenuate in the other", germinating by repetition; BASIDIA 12-14 x 7.5-9(11) um, "terminal or lateral on the supporting hyphae, ovate or pyriform", "bearing on the end or on the outer side four stout epibasidia, straight or somewhat curved or divergent, sometimes inflated just above the base", 9-12(14) x 2-3 um; hyphae (3)5-6(7.5) um wide, "colorless, without clamps, mostly repent, branching at right angles", (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing horns', perhaps referring to basidia
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Martin, G.W.(1), Ginns(5), Ridgway(1) colors indicated by (R), Buczacki(1)*
87
FAMILY  Ceratobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ceratobasidium ochroleucum  (F. Noack) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre^  Mycologia Memoir 19: 37. 1993 (as Ceratobasidium ochroleuca);  == Hypochnopsis ochroleuca  F. Noack;  == Hypochnus ochroleuca  (F. Noack) F. Noack;  == Corticium stevensii  Burt;  = Pellicularia koleroga  Cooke sensu D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a thin, pinkish buff, felty layer forming on the undersurface of leaves and often separable from them, 2) chestnut brown sclerotia 0.3-0.4cm in diameter, 3) spores that are elongate and colorless, 4) basidia scattered along hyphae on short lateral branches, with short sterigmata, and 5) hyphae 4.5-7.5 um wide.^ | Burt proposed the name Corticium stevensii on transfer of Hypochnus ochroleucus to Corticium, because there already was a Corticium ochroleucum Bres. RANGE ^Ceratobasidium ochroleucum has been recorded from WA, AL, FL, GA, IN, LA, MS, NC, OK, SC, and TX, (Ginns). It also occurs in Trinidad and Brazil (Burt).
FRUITING BODY  11cm long, 3-4cm broad, very thin, 0.0045-0.006cm, unbroken over whole undersurface of leaves, sclerotia 0.3-0.4cm in diameter, mycelial strands 0.05-0.1cm wide, many centimeters long, "Vegetative mycelium forms on the twigs roundish or oblong, chestnut-brown sclerotia 3-4 mm. in diameter, and also slender mycelial strands white when young, becoming chestnut-brown, running along the twigs and petioles to the leaves and fructifying there; fructifications at first downy and barely visible, soon thickening into a dirty pinkish buff, felty membrane covering the whole under side of the leaf and frequently separable from it as a whole by mere handling"^, (Burt)
HABITAT  thread blight of twigs and leaves, causing leaves to dry and fall, 48 genera of host plants, including a wide variety of orchard and ornamental crops^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-11 x 3-4 um, flattened or slightly concave on one side, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 11 x 7-8 um, with short sterigmata, "scattered along the hyphae on short lateral branches"; hyphae 4.5-7.5 um wide, colorless or slightly colored, giving their color to the fruitbody, "even, thin-walled, not incrusted, not nodose-septate", (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ocher-white'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Burt(1) (as Corticium stevensii), Ginns(5)
88
FAMILY  Dacrymycetaceae, Order Dacrymycetales, Class Dacrymycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cerinomyces crustulinus  (Bourdot & Galzin) G.W. Martin^  Mycologia 41: 85. 1949;  == Ceracea crustulina  Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is a thin, flat, ochraceous to whitish, soft-waxy crust, 3) differentiation from others in genus by apically branched dikaryophyses and narrow, cylindric to allantoid spores that are aseptate or tardily 1-septate, and 4) basidia with two large sterigmata.^ RANGE ^Cerinomyces crustulinus has been found in BC, LA, and MI, (Ginns), France and Sweden, (McNabb), and Finland (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin, originating "as small, corticioid plates on a coarse subiculum, becoming effused, finally coalescing to form areas up to 2cm in extent, at no stage attached to the substratum by a root-like base", consistency soft-waxy; drying "fawn color" (R) in the center, fading to "vinaceous buff" (R) toward the margin^, (McNabb), spread out, adherent, thin, continuous, smooth, waxy, isabelline then pale tawny, margin pruinose-reticulate and lighter, (Bourdot), "thin, resupinate, smooth (corticioid), greyish white to pale ochraceous, ceraceous, margin indistinct", (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on hardwood and conifer wood^, (Ginns), on rotten beech wood, (Bourdot), on coniferous wood (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 9-11(12) x 3-4 um, cylindric to curved-cylindric, thin-walled, apiculate^; PROBASIDIA 19-31 x 3-4 um, at first cylindric, becoming subclavate or narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connections, producing 2 sterigmata to 17.5 um long; hymenium smooth, consisting of densely packed basidia and dikaryophyses, the latter simple or more often irregularly branched apically, "projecting beyond the basidia, with basal clamp connections"; internal hyphae "thin-walled, smooth, conspicuous clamp connections present", (McNabb), SPORES 9-12 x 3-4 um, cylindric, attenuated obliquely at the base depressed or a little curved, colorless, not septate; BASIDIA 30-45 x 3-4 um, narrowly claviform, sterigmata divergent, 12-15 x 2.5-3 um; hyphae 3 um wide, thin-walled, clamp connections sparse, (Bourdot), SPORES 7-12 x 2.5-4 um, allantoid, inamyloid; BASIDIA narrowly clavate when young, 20-25 x 5-6 um, then producing two large, first obtuse, then acute sterigmata, 10-15 um long and about 2 um wide at base; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, BASAL HYPHAE 3-4 um wide, wall somewhat thickened, with clamp connections, hymenial branches 2.5-3.5 um, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Others in the genus either have (1)3-septate spores or do not have apically branched dikaryophyses (McNabb).
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), McNabb(1) ((R) refers to Ridgway(1)), Bourdot(1) (as Ceracea), Ginns(5)
89
FAMILY  Gloeophyllaceae, Order Gloeophyllales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Chaetodermella luna  (D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.) Rauschert^  Haussknechtia 4: 52. 1988;  == Peniophora luna  Romell ex D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.;  == Chaetoderma luna  (Romell) Parmasto;  Peniophora odorata  sensu Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) 1-2cm, tough, pulvinate patches on wood, 2) color that is whitish, pale grayish to pale ochraceous, 3) spores that are large, fusiform to crescent-shaped, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) long, slender basidia, 5) cystidia that are abundant, long, cylindric to narrowly clavate, encrusted, and thick-walled, with the wall thinning out at the apex, and 6) dense vertical hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Chaetodermella luna has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, YT, AK, AZ, CO, MT, NM, UT, and WY, (Ginns), and Norway and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, pulvinate [cushion-shaped], 0.05-0.2cm thick, mostly small, 1-2cm, "usually extended in the direction of the wood grain and sometimes confluent to longish fruitbodies", tough, almost suberose; whitish, pale grayish to pale ochraceous; when dry more or less rimose [cracked]; margin abrupt, finely fibrillose under hand lens^, (Eriksson), "developing in small, often confluent patches"; white to cream; pilose under 10x lens, (Gilbertson)
HABITAT  on a variety of conifers, Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), associated with a brown cubical rot^, (Ginns), on dry and naked wood of conifers, mostly Pinus silvestris (Scotch Pine), (Eriksson for Scandinavia)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 12-16 x 4-6 um, fusiform [spindle-shaped], more or less arcuate [crescent-shaped], smooth, inamyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 100 um long and 5-7 um wide, (very long and slender), usually with a fine grainy encrustation, sterigmata about 6-8 um long; CYSTIDIA "very long, up to 300 um, projecting 15-50 um, thickwalled and finely encrusted or apically with some larger crystals"; HYPHAE "monomitic, consisting of vertical, densely interwoven hyphae, mostly 2-3 um wide and with clamps at all septa, thinwalled or slightly thickwalled, old hyphae often with a fine grainy encrustation", (Eriksson), SPORES 12-18 um long, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA "long and slender, up to 100 um long, 5-6 um wide", narrowly clavate; CYSTIDIA "very abundant, cylindric to narrowly clavate, thick-walled, wall thinning out at apex"; hyphae with clamp connections, (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'moon', perhaps relating to spore shape
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2) (as Chaetoderma luna), Burt(7) (as Peniophora odorata), Gilbertson(3), Ginns(5)
90
FAMILY  Cyphellaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Chondrostereum purpureum  (Pers.) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykol. 13: 18. 1959;  == Thelephora purpurea  Pers.;  Stereum purpureum  (Pers.) Fr.;  Stereum micheneri  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Corticium nyssae  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Stereum rugosiusculum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  silver leaf fungus, silver-leaf fungus
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate, leathery growth on hardwood, or with projecting overlapping buff caps, the spore-bearing surface colored shades of violet, and smooth to slightly wrinkled, 2) a visible black line in flesh when cap cut in cross-section, 3) spores that are elliptic to cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia that are sparse, narrow-fusiform, projecting, and incrusted or not, 5) bladder-like hyphal ends in the subhymenium, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Chondrostereum purpureum has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PE, PQ, SK, YT, AK, AL, CA, CT, DE, FL, GA, IA, IN, KS, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MT, ND, NH, NJ, NY, OH, OK, PA, VA, VT, WI, WV, and WY, (Ginns), and Europe and Asia (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate on wood, or with projecting overlapping caps, 0.5-2cm wide, sometimes in masses 10-50cm long, caps sometimes crimped or lobed; "light ocher-buff to cinnamon-buff; hairy to hairless and wrinkled"; spore-bearing surface light purple-drab to dark wine-buff, waxy and smooth to minutely powdery; consistency leathery^, (Lincoff(2)), resupinate or having a cap that extends several millimeters to 4cm from the wood, forming patches several centimeters to several decimeters in extent, upper cap surface gray-whitish, indistinctly zoned, hirsute-tomentose [hairy-cottony], margin lighter, spore-bearing surface [under cap or exposed on surface] "pink-violet to dark violet, when old brown-violet", "smooth, undulating tuberculate to slightly wrinkled", margin distinctly bounded to slightly fringed; flesh 0.1-0.25cm thick, tough, in cross section a visible black line separates tomentum from flesh and spore-bearing surface; odor not characteristic, taste mild, (Breitenbach), resupinate or with a projecting cap, tough when fresh, brittle when dry, the cap white and tomentose, the spore-bearing surface "smooth and dark violaceous, purplish or brown-violaceous when fresh and wet", paler when dry; in vertical section the white tomentum of the cap is separated from the lower layers by a dark line visible to the naked eye, (Eriksson), cap surface "grayish to yellowish buff or pale cinnamon to darker brown, often with a distinct pale edge", hairy to tomentose; spore-bearing surface violet to brown-violet, smooth, and waxy-looking, (Trudell), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  saprophytic or parasitic on stumps, branches or trunks of hardwoods, rarely conifers; infected trees such as fruit trees develop a characteristic leaf change called "silver leaf" disease^, (Eriksson), on a variety of conifers and hardwoods, the fungus produces toxins that produce silver leaf disease and ultimately kill branches or the entire tree, fruit bodies produced on old sticks, dead stems, dead stumps, logs, pulpwood, associated with a white rot, (Ginns), June to April, may persist for several years, on apple, plum, and other hardwoods, causes silver leaf disease of apple and plum trees, (Lincoff(2)), year round, with new growth between spring and fall, (Bacon)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-8 x 2.5-3.5 um, elliptic to cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 45-60 x 6-7 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA: leptocystidia 60-70 x 4.5-7.5 um, fusiform, "some resembling stinging hairs, some incrusted", in subhymenium many conspicuous hyphae with bladder-like ends 7-15 um across; HYPHAE monomitic 2.5-4 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 5-8 x 2.5-3 um, allantoid to subcylindric, smooth, inamyloid; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 50 x 5 um, placed together in a very dense hymenium; CYSTIDIA sparse, 60-80 x 6-8 um, projecting 25-50 um, fusoid or obtuse, thin-walled, smooth or with crystalline deposits; HYPHAE "monomitic with clamped hyphae, thinwalled in the subhymenium, more or less thickwalled in the other parts of the fruitbody", hyphal width from 3 um, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'purple'
SIMILAR  Under some circumstances, old fruitbodies can be confused with Amylostereum (amyloid spores), Veluticeps (long, encrusted cystidia), Stereum, Peniophora (with strongly encrusted subulate cystidia), or Trichaptum abietinum (pores under hand lens), (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Lincoff(2)*, Lincoff(1)*, Ginns(5), Courtecuisse(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Bacon(1)*, Buczacki(1)*
91
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Clavulicium macounii  (Burt) J. Erikss. & Boidin^  in Parmasto, Consp. Syst. Cort. 165. 1968;  == Corticium macounii  Burt;  Corticium vinososcabens  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed conifer wood, 2) fruitbodies that are gray to ochraceous, 3) spores that are broadly elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) 2-spored basidia, 5) sinuous slender gloeocystidia, and 6) amorphous yellowish bodies in the subhymenium.^ | According to Breitenbach(2), Parmasto places this in Clavulinaceae because the basidia and spores are similar to Clavulina, but Eriksson places it in Corticiaceae. RANGE ^It has been found in BC, PQ, NH, NY, VT, and WI, (Ginns), in Europe including Switzerland, and in Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, forming thin patches 0.02-0.04cm thick and several centimeters in extent, attached more or less tightly, consistency soft, membranous, wax-like, when dry soft and brittle; "ocher to gray-ocher, sometimes with flesh-colored tints"; "smooth, dull (somewhat fissured when dry)"; margin "distinctly bounded to finely fringed and then somewhat paler to whitish, with a tendency to lift when dry"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, smooth, adnate [firmly attached], but later especially when dry, rolling back and loosening; gray to ochraceous; smooth; margin white and somewhat fibrillose, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on strongly decayed wood of conifers^, (Eriksson), on decaying wood, Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Picea glauca (White Spruce), Pinus sp. (pine), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Alnus "rubra", (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8.5-11 x 6-7.5 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, "hyaline, with drops or granular contents (contents yellow-green)"^; BASIDIA 2-spored, 45-55 x 6-7 um, cylindric-clavate, with a stem, with basal clamp connection; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 50-110 x 4-5 um, fusiform to subulate, sinuous, walls cyanophilic; HYPHAE monomitic 1.5-3 um wide, thin-walled, branched, septa with clamp connections; irregular amorphous yellowish bodies among the hyphae in the subhymenium, (Breitenbach), SPORES 9-12(13) x 6.5-8 um, elliptic to oboval, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, with few or numerous oil droplets, many spores completely filled with oil; BASIDIA normally 2-spored, more rarely 4-spored, 35-50 x 6.5-8 um, clavate to subcylindric, somewhat sinuate or constricted, with few or numerous oil droplets; GLOEOCYSTIDIA passing through the subhymenium and into the hymenium but not projecting, narrow, sinuous, thin-walled, walls stained in cotton blue; in the subhymenium "there are irregular, but usually rounded bodies of yellowish material, probably excreted from widened hyphal ends", HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, richly branched, with clamp connections, next to the substrate there is a distinct layer of horizontal, parallel hyphae "from which vertical hyphae branch off forming a subhymenium", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5)
92
FAMILY  Heterogastridiaceae, Order Heterogastridiales, Class Microbotryomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Colacogloea peniophorae  (Bourdot & Galzin)  Oberw., R. Bauer, & Bandoni^  Can. J. Bot. 68: 2534. 1990;  Platygloea peniophorae  Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on certain resupinate fungi and on Dacrymyces, 2) a fruitbody that is waxy to somewhat gelatinous (or sometimes spreading through a gelatinous host without definite fruiting), 3) ovate basidiospores and obovate or oval conidia borne on the same hyphal system, 4) details of basidial development, 5) thin-walled hyphae with clamp connections, growing internally in the host fungi.^ | "Attention was drawn to the occurrence of two distinct types of hymenial conidia...Perhaps two taxa exist or maybe there are two forms of a single species. Conidia in collections from North America are commonly of the paired, blastic type...those in European collections are of the solitary chlamydospore type...Basidiocarps of European collections appear to be distinctly gelatinous, whereas those from North American are predominantly mucoid, the visible mass being composed mainly of slime and conidia"; Bandoni(9) commented earlier, "In my opinion, the specimens designated as this species in North America do not constitute a single taxon. The basidiospores and basidia are similar in these collections, but the hymenial conidiophores and basidiocarps are of two distinct types.": he goes on to say that specimens from BC include both the sort matching the Bourdot collections and another sort. RANGE ^Colacogloea peniophorae has been found in BC and Germany, (Oberwinkler). It has been recorded from BC, WA, OR, ON, PQ, AZ, GA, IA, IL, MN, NC, and TN, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  at first discoid, 0.1-0.3cm wide, "with a dry, floccose, white margin", soon anastomosing and becoming broadly effused [thinly spread out], up to 10cm in extent, waxy to subgelatinous, or when growing on gelatinous hosts, without a definite fruiting, "the mycelium and basidia immersed in and spreading through the gelatinous surface of the host"; "pallid or yellowish when moist, drying as an invisible film in scanty developments to ochraceous-buff or ochraceous tawny in well-developed fructifications", (Martin), predominantly mucoid, the visible mass being composed mainly of slime and conidia, (Oberwinkler)
HABITAT  parasitic "on effused thelephoraceous fungi, Peniophora, Corticium etc., and on Dacrymyces spp."^, (Martin, with genus names italicized), Corticium sp., Dacrymyces sp., D. minor, Hyphoderma argillaceum [here Kurtia argillacea], Peniophora sp., (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7(10) x 3.5-4.5(6) um, ovate, CONIDIUM 5-10(12.4) x 3.3-4.6 um, obovate or oval^; CONIDIOPHORES borne on same hyphal system as basidia; PROBASIDIA 25-60 x 4-6 um, clavate, becoming transversely 3-septate; hyphae slender, branched, with numerous clamp connections, (Martin), SPORES smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, germinating by repetition or by budding; BASIDIA transversely 3-septate at maturity, each basidium "developing one long, tubular, hypha-like sterigma and an asymmetrically attached spore"; without conspicuous probasidia; hyphae colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Oberwinkler), in the Bourdot type, the conidia are borne singly and terminally, proliferation then occurs though the loop of the clamp, and the fruiting bodies are distinctly gelatinous; in the other sort found in BC, the conidiophores are short, apparently determinate, and each bears two terminal conidia, both the loop of the clamp and the cell that it subtends produce conidia, the conidia when shed bear a minute basal conidiophore remnant, and fruiting bodies are watery or mucenoid and consist largely of conidia and conidiophores, (Bandoni), "characterized by hyphae with conspicuous clamp connections, narrow haustorial branches which are frequently found applied to the hyphae of the host, and conidiophores that produce obovate or oval conidia which measure 3.3-4.6 x 5-9.8(12.4) um", clamp connections often occurring at the bases of the conidiophores, (Olive)
NAME ORIGIN  referring to one of its hosts, Peniophora
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Oberwinkler(4), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Platygloea peniophorae), Bandoni(9) (as Platygloea peniophorae), Olive(3) (as Platygloea peniophorae), Ginns(5) (as Platygloea peniophorae var. peniophorae Bourdot & Galzin)
93
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Conferticium ochraceum  (Fr.) Hallenb.^  Mycotaxon 11: 448. 1980;  == Gloeocystidiellum ochraceum  (Fr.) Donk;  == Thelephora ochraceus  Fr.;  == Corticium ochraceum  (Fr.) Fr.;  == Gloeocystidium friesii  S. Lundell
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) fruitbodies that are waxy becoming hard, creamish pale to honey-colored becoming ochraceous, and smooth becoming tuberculate and cracked, the margin abrupt to slightly pruinose, and the fruitbodies typically layered, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and amyloid, 4) gloeocystidia that are numerous to rare, cylindric to clavate, colorless to yellowish, and sulfo-negative, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae densely arranged, and lacking clamp connections.^ | Ginns(23) and Ginns(24) accept this species in Conferticium as Conferticium ochraceum (Fr.) Hallenb., but Stalpers(3) uses the name Gloeocystidiellum ochraceum. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, NS, PQ, CA, 14 collections found from North America, reported also from NT, AK, MA, NC, PA, (Ginns(24)). It also occurs in Europe including Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, at first thin but thickening to about 0.1cm, often reaching large dimensions, adnate [tightly attached] but when old detachable in small pieces, ceraceous [waxy] at first, with time firmer and hard when dried; creamish pale or melleous [honey-colored] at first, when old darker, ochraceous to ocher-brown; smooth at first then somewhat tuberculate and when old very rimose [cracked]; margin "as a rule not especially differentiated"^, (Eriksson), effused [spread out], 4cm x 3cm but often confluent, up to 0.067cm thick, typically stratose [layered]; pale yellow with a pink tint, "ivory yellow", "cream-buff", "light ochraceous-buff", "ochraceous-buff"; smooth, ceraceous [waxy], not cracked in young specimens, becoming strongly areolate [cracked like dried mud] in old fruitbodies, cracks extending to substrate; margin abrupt to slightly pruinose, colored as the rest of the surface, (Ginns(24))
HABITAT  fruiting on the bark of dead saplings, and the underside of fallen, rotted limbs of conifers and hardwoods in a variety of genera^, Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Alnus sp. (alder), Betula alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), P. glauca (White Spruce), P. sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pinus resinosa (Red Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus chrysolepis (Canyon Live Oak), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Ginns(24)), on barkless wood, moss-covered cut wood; butt, (Ginns(5)), on conifer wood, producing an intense fibrous and lamellate decay, (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-5.5 x 2.0-3.0 um, elliptic, adaxially slightly concave, smooth, amyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, "with a small, rounded, indistinct apiculus"^, (the two Washington collections with larger and somewhat differently shaped spores, compared with the others); BASIDIA 4-spored, 17.5-28.0 x 4.0-5.0 um, clavate to cylindric, sterigmata 4-5 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous to rare, 35-120 x 4-8 um, cylindric to clavate, contents colorless to yellowish in KOH, granular, sulfo-negative; HYPHAE monomitic; subiculum weakly amyloid in some collections; hyphae 2.0-4.0 um wide, "compact, indistinct, pseudoparenchymatous", lacking clamp connections, typically stratose, encrusted with scattered crystals near the substrate, the walls thin to 1.2 um thick, acyanophilic; hymenium and subhymenium weakly dextrinoid in some collections, (Ginns(24)), SPORES 4.5-6 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic to somewhat oval, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 4-5 um, subclavate, without clamp connections; GLOEOCYSTIDIA (= pseudocystidia) 40-60 x 4-5 um, thin-walled, "filled with oily, granular, yellowish contents (in KOH)", best seen in young fruitbodies, in which they may be numerous; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 2-3.5 um wide, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled, cyanophilic, without clamp connections, "in a very dense parenchymatous context", with a thin layer of horizontal hyphae next to substrate, otherwise "of vertical, parallel, densely united hyphae", in perennial strata, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ochraceous'
