MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-12 x 4.3-6 um, pyriform [pear-shaped], inamyloid, colorless, in some slightly cyanophilic, with a large apiculus, spores often agglutinated^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-80 x 6-8 um, cylindric to very narrowly clavate, not distinctly stemmed, always with basal clamp connection, sterigmata about 4-6 x 1-1.5 um; cystidioles present, sometimes rare, about 60-80 x 6-7.5 um, fusiform, clamped; HYPHAE monomitic 3-5 um wide, almost colorless "but the basal and older ones often slightly yellowish-brownish", thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled (up to 0.4-1.0 um), with clamp connections, guttulate, (Julich), SPORES 8-10(12) x 4-5(7) um, obliquely ellipsoid to lacrymoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, not or only slightly cyanophilic, thin-walled, often agglutinated in groups of 2-4 spores; BASIDIA 4-spored, long and narrowly clavate, mostly 40-50 x 5-6 um (when young sometimes longer), with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA often few and inconspicuous, 50-80 x 5-8 um, apically borne on basidia-producing hyphae, fusiform, thin-walled, not encrusted; HYPHAE monomitic about 3 um wide, containing numerous oil-droplets, thin-walled or somewhat thick-walled, colorless or in the basal part yellowish, with clamp connections, SUBICULAR HYPHAE rather straight and parallel to substrate with sparse clamp connections and ramifications [branching], and loosely intertwined, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE vertically arranged, densely united, and thinner, (Eriksson), SPORES 8-12 x 5-6(7.5) um, oval to drop-shaped, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, some agglutinated in small groups, some with granular contents or droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 45-65 x 5-7 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA 45-70 x 5-7 um, fusiform, smooth; HYPHAE monomitic 3-5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, some filled with droplets, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 7-12 x 4.5-6 um, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Cylindrobasidium corrugum has spores measuring (8.5)9.9-12.0(13) x (5.0)6.3-7.7(8.8) um, (Ginns(23)). Cylindrobasidium torrendii has spores measuring 4-6 x 2.5-3.0 um (Ginns(23)). Phanerochaete affinis can be macroscopically similar, but is easy to separate microscopically (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Julich(1) (as Cylindrobasidium evolvens), Eriksson(4) (as Cylindrobasidium evolvens), Breitenbach(2)* (as Cylindrobasidium evolvens), Ginns(5), Chamuris(1), Ginns(23), Buczacki(1)*
113
FAMILY  Physalacriaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cylindrobasidium torrendii  (Bres.) Hjortstam^  Mycotaxon 17: 571. 1983;  == Peniophora torrendii  Bres.;  Peniophora albula  G.F. Atk. & Burt;  Corticium albulum  (G.F. Atk. & Burt) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.;  Cylindrobasidium albulum  (G.F. Atk. & Burt) J. Erikss. & Hjortstam;  Peniophora burkei  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) a whitish fruitbody with the surface somewhat granular to tubercular, and becoming cracked into polygons, the margin thinning out, 3) smooth, colorless spores measuring 4-6 x 2.5-3 um, 4) protruding cystidia, tapering toward the tip, and 5) hyphae that are suberect, branching, and occasionally with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^It has been found in WA, ON, AL, DC, FL, IA, MA, MD, ME, NH, NJ, NY, PA, and VA, (Burt for Peniophora albula), and GA, IL, IN, MI, MS, TN, WI, and WV, (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  2-20cm long, 1-2cm wide, in section 0.007-0.02cm thick, adnate [tightly attached], thin, tender, small pieces separable; "white, becoming light buff when old and in the herbarium"; somewhat granular, becoming cracked into polygonal masses 0.1-0.2cm in diameter; the margin thinning out^, (Burt for Peniophora albula), probably large: 4cm x 2-2.5cm with pieces broken off, in section 0.012-0.018cm thick, "broadly effused, thin, adnate, membranaceous, tender, small pieces separable when moistened", cream buff in herbarium; somewhat tubercular, conforming to uneven bark, somewhat cracked in drying; margin thinning out, (Burt for Peniophora burkei)
HABITAT  on bark of fallen decaying branches; rough hardwood bark; wood products (stored willow pulpwood, beechwood chips, yellow poplar and sassafras mine timbers); associated with a white rot; hosts include Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Fagus sp. (beech), Fraxinus oregona (Oregon Ash), Juglans nigra (Black Walnut), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Prunus sp., Quercus durandii (Durand White Oak), Rhus typhina (Staghorn Sumac), Salix nigra (Black willow), Sassafras albidum (Sassafras)^, (Ginns(5)), on bark of fallen decaying branches on the ground; Alnus, Acer, Tilia, Populus, and other hardwoods; July to February, (Burt for Peniophora albula), on rough hardwood bark in October (Burt for Peniophora burkei in Alabama)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-6 x 2.5-3 um, smooth, colorless^; CYSTIDIA protruding 10-20 um, sometimes very few and inconspicuous, 3 um wide, tapering toward the tip, not encrusted; no gloeocystidia; hyphae about 3 um wide, suberect, branching, thin-walled, occasionally nodose-septate [septa with clamp connections], not encrusted, sometimes slightly brownish near substrate, (Burt for Peniophora albula), SPORES 6-7 x 4-5 um, smooth, colorless; CYSTIDIA 50 x 4.5-5 um, protruding up to 20 um, not encrusted, subulate; no gloeocystidia; hyphae 3 um wide, loosely interwoven, suberect, thin-walled, nodose-septate, not encrusted, (Burt for Peniophora burkei), SPORES 4-6 x 2.5-3 um, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Cylindrobasidium corrugum and Cylindrobasidium laeve have spores of a different size, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Burt(7) (as Peniophora albula and P. burkei), Ginns(5), Ginns(23)
114
FAMILY  Cystobasidiaceae, Order Cystobasidiales, Class Cystobasidiomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cystobasidium fimetarium  (Schumach.) P. Roberts^  in Roberts & Watling  Mycologist 13(4): 171. 1999;  Platygloea fimetaria  (Schumach.) Hoehn.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) thin, flat growth on dung in association with Saccobolus violascens, 2) narrow-obovate spores, 3) details of basidial development, 4) hyphae that mostly 1.5-2.5 um in diameter, all septa with clamp connections in the hymenial region, some hyphae moniliform or tortuous, paraphysis-like and extending into the hymenium.^ RANGE ^It has been found in in BC and MB, (Ginns), and in Germany, (Martin).
FRUITING BODY  0.2-0.4(1)cm in diameter, effused, somewhat circular, waxy-membranous, flat to slightly concave; pallid flesh-color to pale violaceous^, (Martin), "gelatinous, discoid, the hymenium plane, margin abrupt, expanding and sometimes anastomosing, pale violaceous to pinkish or sordid white", (Bandoni)
HABITAT  associated with Saccobolus violascens Boudier on herbivore dung^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 10-11 x 4-6 um, ovoid^; PROBASIDIA cylindric-clavate, giving rise at the tips to cylindric epibasidia 36-42 x 5-6 um that become transversely 3-septate, (Martin), SPORES (6.5) 9-10 x 4-5 um, narrow-obovate, flattened adaxially, with a very small apiculus, germinating by repetition; BASIDIA when mature mostly 4-septate, the sporogenous part 39-54 x (3.5)4-5 um, the total length reaching 120 um although most less than 100 um; epibasidia lacking or up to 25 x 2.5-3 um; probasidia "at first cylindric to narrow clavate or pyriform, thin walled, developing a cylindric sporogenous portion apically, often in compact clusters formed through proliferation at the basal clamp, 6-9 um in diameter and mostly 15-25 um in length, a few exceeding 50 um"; hyphae mostly 1.5-2.5 um in diameter, all septa with clamp connections in the hymenial region, "some hyphae moniliform or tortuous, paraphysis-like and extending into hymenium", (Bandoni)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to dung'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Bandoni(9) (as Platygloea fimetaria), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Platygloea fimetaria), Ginns(5) (as Platygloea fimetaria)
115
FAMILY  Cystostereaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cystostereum murrayi  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykol. 13: 18. 1959;  == Thelephora murrayi  Berk. & M.A. Curtis [as 'murraii'];  == Stereum murrayi  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Burt;  Stereum tuberculosum  Fr.;  Stereum pulverulentum  Peck;  Corticium effusum  Overh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood (or bent out to form a narrow black cap), 2) a light ochraceous to light grayish spore-bearing surface, 3) a tough hard consistency, 4) a coconut odor, 5) spores that are narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, cyanophilic, and colorless, 6) inflated to clavate gloeocystidia, not or only slightly projecting, smooth, sometimes filled with yellowish material, and 7) a dimitic hyphal system, the generative hyphae with clamp connections.^ | Eriksson notes that there are some differences between American and European material: 1) in Europe it only grows on Picea abies whereas in North America it prefers hardwoods, 2) the European fruitbodies are thinner, 0.1cm compared to 0.2-0.3cm or more in North America, 3) the spore-bearing surface in Europe is grayish white (ash-colored), in North America as a rule brighter (e.g. light yellowish ochraceous), 4) spores are generally somewhat larger in North American specimens, (Eriksson). RANGE ^Cystostereum murrayi has been reported from BC, OR, ID, NB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, CT, FL, IA, IL, LA, MA, ME, MI, MN, NH, NY, PA, RI, TN, VA, VT, WI, and WV, (Ginns). It occurs in Norway and Sweden, (Eriksson), and Switzerland, Germany, and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, or bent outward to form cap, may extend to 100cm or more long, about 0.1cm thick; suberose [corky] to ligneous [woody], brittle when dry, perennial; cap when present black and hard, uneven, often with concentric ridges; spore-bearing surface tuberculate, light colored, mostly grayish white when young, darker when old; odor characteristic, pleasant and aromatic, both when fresh and when dry^, (Eriksson), resupinate, (or bent outward on vertical wood to form cap a few millimeters wide), forming patches several centimeters to decimeters across, attached firmly, hard, crustose, tough; whitish to gray-white or ocher-white, "when fresh spotting slightly brownish when bruised", "uneven, tuberculate-verrucose, often with concentric ribs, fissured when dry"; margin distinct, tomentose; odor when fresh pleasant, like shredded coconut, but odorless when dry, (Breitenbach), not edible (Phillips)
HABITAT  on a variety of hardwoods, Picea [spruce], Pinus [pine], on rotting logs and limbs, stumps, associated with a white rot, (Ginns), in Europe on fallen trunks, stumps etc. of Picea abies (Norway Spruce), in North America more often on hardwood, (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 2.5-3 um, narrowly elliptic to subcylindric, smooth, inamyloid, cyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA narrowly clavate, usually 25-30 x 5 um, 4-spored with basal clamp connection; GLOEOCYSTIDIA (pseudocystidia) "very numerous, especially in the subhymenial trama but also in the subiculum": when very young, "they originate from the subiculum and extend into the hymenium, later new gloeocystidia develop in the hymenium as long as the thickness increases", "usually ovate to ellipsoid, 7-15 um wide, rarely more, and 30-40 um long in the hymenium and the subhymenial trama, longer and narrower in the subiculum", in thin sections "they appear empty but are normally filled with oildroplets", they remain as rounded vesicles rather than lengthening as in Gloeocystidiellum, in many specimens some of them are filled with a homogeneous yellow substance; HYPHAE dimitic: sparse thick-walled skeletal hyphae 1.5-3 um wide, especially in the subiculum, and thin-walled richly branched generative hyphae, 2-3.5 um wide, with clamp connections, the hyphae in general are agglutinated, and hyphal direction is horizontal in subiculum and vertical in subhymenium, (Eriksson), SPORES 4.5-5 x 2-3 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-40 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; GLOEOCYSTIDIA not or only slightly projecting, 20 x 15 um or 40-60 x 8-10 um, clavate to fusiform or nearly spherical, smooth, sometimes filled with yellowish material; HYPHAE dimitic: generative hyphae 2-3.5 um, thin-walled, septa with clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 1.5-3.5 um wide, thick-walled, strongly branched, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as C. murraii), Breitenbach(2)* (as C. murraii), Phillips(1)* (as C. murraii), Ginns(5) (as C. murraii)
116
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cytidia lanata  W.B. Cooke^  Mycologia 43: 205. 1951
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Cups category. Features include 1) growth on birch bark, 2) cup-shaped fruitbodies 1-3cm across, attached at and near a central point, free over the rest of the upper surface and covered with tan to brownish woolly tomentum, the spore-bearing surface dull purple and smooth to somewhat wrinkled, 3) spores that are ovate to oblong-elliptic, smooth, and colorless, 4) multiple hymenial layers, 5) lack of sterile elements, and 6) gelatinous hyphae without clamp connections at the infrequent septa.^ RANGE ^The type was found in ID (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  receptacles 1-3cm across, attached at and near a central point, free over remainder of upper surface, free surface covered with tan to brownish woolly tomentum, more or less zonate; hymenium dull purple, smooth to somewhat wrinkled^, (Cooke)
HABITAT  type scattered on bark of branch of Betula (birch)^, (Cooke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-7 x 2-3 um, ovate to oblong-elliptic, flattened on one side, smooth, colorless, with apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 23-28 x 4-6 um, with small clamp connections at bases; no sterile elements seen in context or hymenium; HYMENIUM 50-60 um in section, brownish, in 2 to 3 layers, "the lower layers of which appear as brown palisades of collapsed cells through which hyphae penetrate to form a context from which an additional hymenial layer arises"; RECEPTACLE 600-800 um thick in section, free surface made up of colorless hyphae that are united into bundles that are more compactly arranged toward the outside, the bundles merging and anastomosing and connected by individual hyphae, hyphae 5-8 um wide, bundles 25-50 um wide, hyphae of tomentum originate from context through a zone of darkened tissue, hyphae of context densely interwoven, more or less parallel, without clamp connections at the infrequent septa, "with gelatinous walls, becoming perpendicular to the receptacle in the subhymenial region of each annual increment", (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'woolly'
SIMILAR  Cytidia salicina has receptacles with a surface that is pruinose rather than woolly (Cooke).
SOURCES  Cooke(3), Ginns(5)
117
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cytidia patelliformis  (Burt) A.L. Welden^  Mycologia 50: 304. 1958;  == Stereum patelliforme  Burt;  Auriculariopsis patelliformis  (Burt) Ryvarden  Syn. Fung. (Oslo) 28: 53. 2010 (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Cups category. Features include 1) resupinate to open cup-shaped fruitbodies with a spore-bearing surface that is pink to dark reddish brown, and an abhymenial surface with coarse hairs and yellow-buff to dark reddish brown in color, 2) growth on fallen hardwood branches, 3) spores that are slightly curved, smooth, and colorless, 4) thin branched elements among the basidia, 5) projecting cystidia that are cylindric or tapering slightly, and 6) hyphae that are strongly gelatinized and having prominent clamp connections.^ |Auriculariopsis patelliformis was the current name listed on the online Species Fungorum, accessed September 12, but Cytidia patelliformis was the current name listed on MycoBank. RANGE ^Cytidia patelliformis is found in WA, CA, and NM, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate to open cup-shaped, 0.5-2cm long, 0.3-0.9cm wide, some fruitbodies with confluent margins; "superior surface from yellow-buff to dark reddish-brown, strigose with matted white hairs in well-developed receptacles, hymenial surface pink to dark reddish-brown, pulverulent to setulose under the lens"^, (Welden), 0.3cm x 0.2cm, up to 2.5cm x 0.3cm, the margin free all around and rolled up 0.1-0.2cm, "coriaceous-fleshy, resupinate, the margin becoming free or narrowly reflexed, hoary with a few short hairs, drying cinnamon to bone-brown, the margin entire", hymenium waxy, even, cracking in drying, drying cinnamon to bone-brown, (Burt)
HABITAT  on fallen branches; hosts include Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Corylus cornuta (Beaked Hazel), C. californica (California Hazel), Crataegus douglasii (Black Hawthorn), Fraxinus latifolia (Oregon Ash), Purshia tridentata (Antelope Bitterbrush), Quercus sp. (oak), Rhus diversiloba (poison-oak), Rosa nutkana (Nootka rose)^, (Ginns), on fallen branches of Acer, Quercus, and other hardwoods, August to April, (Burt)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 10-15 x 4-5 um, slightly curved, with apiculus, smooth, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 56-80(108) x 6-8 um, often projecting 10-11 um above hymenial surface, sterigmata fleshy, arcuate, 6-8 um long; DENDROPHYSES intermingled with basidia, 2-3 um wide; CYSTIDIA projecting up to 60 um beyond hymenial surface, 7-8 um wide, cylindric or tapering slightly, a few with swollen apices, non-septate, thin-walled, unencrusted; RECEPTACLE 525-700 um thick in free-hand section, cuticle absent to poorly developed, context and hymenium forming the two zones generally present, "context interwoven with the hyphae turning outward to form the superior surface of the receptacle and the hymenium, in resupinate forms only the hyphae next to the substrate densely interwoven, then radiating outward forming the hymenium at their tips", hyphae with walls somewhat thickened and strongly gelatinized, with numerous and prominent clamp-connections, branching, 4-6 um wide, subhymenial hyphae similar but with thinner walls, 3-4 um wide, (Welden)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'in the form of a small pan, dish'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Welden(1), Burt(2) (as Stereum patelliforme), Ginns(5)
118
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cytidia salicina  (Fr.) Burt^  Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 11: 10. 1924;  == Thelephora salicina  Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  scarlet-splash
NOTES  Also listed in Cups and Jelly categories. Features include growth on attached dead or damaged willow branches, at first growing flat, but loosening along the margin to resemble shallow orange to wine-red cups, which then become confluent. Microscopic characters include cylindric spores that are smooth, iodine negative, and colorless; large basidia that protrude from a dense layer of dendrohyphidia; and a monomitic hyphal system with hyphae that turn blue in sulfovanilline, have clamp connections, and are strongly agglutinated by gelatinous interhyphal substance.^ RANGE ^Cytidia salicina is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, YT, AK, AL, CO, CT, IN, LA, MA, ME, MI, MN, MT, NC, ND, NH, NM, NY, OH, PA, VA, VT, WI, WV, and WY, (Ginns), Europe including Switzerland, and Asia, (Breitenbach), France, Sweden, central and eastern Europe, and north Asia, (Eriksson), and Algeria, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Finland, Germany, Italy, Latvia, Norway, and Sweden, (Cooke).
FRUITING BODY  when young disc-shaped to slightly plate-shaped to cup-shaped, irregularly rounded to oblong, 0.5-1cm in size, "with a pointlike attachment on underside, later coalescing in rows to form bands often several decimeters long", up to 0.05-0.08cm thick, elastic, gelatinous, tough, when dry shriveled and crustose, corneous [horny] and hard; bright orange to wine-red, drying dull wine-red; "when moist smooth, pruinose and dull, slightly verrucose-tuberculate", drying dull, with inrolled margin^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, loosening along the margin and becoming cup-shaped, almost umbilicate, and looking like a discomycete, about 1cm wide, but sometimes confluent to larger irregular structures, when wet coriaceous [leathery] to somewhat gelatinous, soft, pliable, when dry corneous [horny], hard and brittle; "orange red when young, then dark red to violaceous red", "smooth, even or when wet somewhat tuberculate", at first bald, when fertile pruinose from spores and projecting basidia; upper side "covered by crystals and therefore whitish, farinose or finely floccose"; margin "more or less revolute, esp. in the dry state", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on "attached dead or damaged branches with bark, as well as standing trunks", of various Salix (willow) species, throughout the year but mature only in late fall, (Breitenbach), on various Salix species, Alnus spp., Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Populus spp., Prunus serotina (Black Cherry); on limbs, (Ginns)^, on dry, still attached twigs and branches of Salix, mostly seen in shadowed thickets on branches 1-2 meters above the ground, (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 12.5-17.5 x 4-5 um, cylindric, slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with many small droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 80-100 x 7-9 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; DENDROHYPHIDIA in hymenium 2.5-3 um wide, "very densely interwoven and imbedded in a gelatinous substance, gnarled, strongly branched, brownish", +/- thick-walled, stain bluish in sulfovanillin; HYPHAE monomitic 2-4 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, stain bluish in sulfovanillin, (Breitenbach), SPORES 12-18 x 4-5 um, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic; BASIDIA 4-spored, very large, 75-100 x 8-11 um (according to Bourdot 60-225 x 7-9 um), young basidia "develop within the dendrohyphidial layer and protrude at maturity"; cystidia none; DENDROHYPHIDIA numerous, richly branched, forming a dense layer, light yellowish brown, best seen on young fruiting bodies as they seem to disintegrate to some degree as basidia develop, (best studied in KOH heated close to boiling over a flame, when the other hyphae will swell and the dendrohyphidia will not), stain strongly in sulfovanillin; HYPHAE monomitic about 2-3 um wide, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, mostly straight, sparsely septate and with clamp connections at all septa, strongly agglutinated by gelatinous interhyphal substances, all hyphae blue or violaceous blue in sulfovanillin, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to Salix [willow]'
SIMILAR  Cytidia lanata has receptacles with a woolly surface (Cooke).
SOURCES  Eriksson(3), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Courtecuisse(1)*, Buczacki(1)*
119
FAMILY  Dacryobolaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dacryobolus karstenii  (Bres.) Parmasto^  as Oberw. ex Parmasto, Consp. Syst. Cort. 98. 1968;  == Stereum karstenii  Bres.;  Peniophora crassa  Burt;  Peniophora verticillata  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) color cream to yellow-buff, coral, cinnamon or darker, 3) membranaceous to leathery consistency, 4) slender spores that are curved, smooth, and inamyloid, 5) narrow basidia, 6) very long cystidia, 7) a dimitic hyphal system, and 8) clamp connections.^ | The name Peniophora crassa was proposed with the transfer to that genus because there already was a Stereum karstenii. RANGE ^It has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NS, ON, PQ, AK, AL, AZ, CA, CO, MA, ME, MT, NC, ND, NH, NJ, NM, NY, PA, SC, TN, and VT, (Ginns). It occurs also in Europe including Scandinavia (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, at first rounded or elongate then confluent, about 0.05-0.1cm thick, adnate [tightly attached], membranaceous to coriaceous [leathery]; whitish to cream to pale yellowish ochraceous, when old darker; tuberculate, when dried almost smooth, cracked; margin abrupt and when young finely radially fibrillose under 50x lens; when fresh with a pleasant odor recorded by K. Hjortstam^, (Eriksson), starting as pinpoint fleshy patches, becoming confluent and widespread, (often hardened), up to 0.1cm thick or more, more or less separable; cream to yellow-buff, coral, cinnamon, or darker; "frequently deeply fissured, exposing the cream to white subiculum, margin determinate, white, fibrous, sometimes reflexed, surface pruinose, velvety or, on occasion, almost tomentose under the lens", (Weresub(3)), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on conifer wood^ of Abies (fir), Pinus (pine), Picea (spruce), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja, and Tsuga (hemlock), (Weresub(3)), on Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Chamaecyparis nootkatensis (Alaska Yellow-cedar), Corylus cornuta (Beaked Hazel), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), P. glauca (White Spruce), P. sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), P. leiophylla var. chihuahuana (Chihuahua Pine), P. monticola (Western White Pine), P. ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus sp., Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus gambelii (Gambel Oak), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), on decaying logs, associated with a brown cubical rot, (Ginns), on wood, less often bark, of conifers, in most cases on lying barkless logs, (Eriksson), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6 x 1.2-1.5 um, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, long and narrow, 35-45 x 2-3.5 um, apically 2-2.5 um wide, conspicuously constricted just behind sterigmata and then widened to 3-3.5 um wide, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of two types 1) very long (to 250 um), 5-8 um wide, projecting 50-75 um, penetrating pseudocystidia, inamyloid, apically thin-walled, thickening toward base, the projecting part often with crystal grains, 2) hymenial cystidia 60-80 x 3-4 um, projecting 20-30 um, thin-walled or somewhat thick-walled, with scattered crystal grains; HYPHAE dimitic: context of two layers: 1) subiculum next to wood, with some hyphae thick-walled and sparsely septate, other thin-walled with conspicuous clamp connections and numerous branches, 2) trama consisting of a network of vertical, thin-walled, collapsed hyphae, penetrated by thin-walled generative hyphae and very long thick-walled cystidia, (Eriksson), |SPORES (4)4.5-6(8.5) x (1)1.25-2(2.5) um, allantoid, often narrowed toward the apicular end, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA very slender, broadening below the apex to a width of 2.5-3.5 um, rising above hymenial surface when mature; CYSTIDIA "not always clear, sometimes completely embedded, otherwise projecting 15-30-70(-over 100) um, very long, with basal septa hard to find . . . usually more or less obovate, with thick stem walls, nonamyloid, dissolving in KOH . . . lumina expanding more or less gradually toward obtuse apices, these usually 4-10 um broad, sometimes heavily encrusted, thin-walled or sometimes with rather thickened walls best differentiated in Melzer's; cystidial stems frequently very slender, 2.5 um broad 30 um from apex, at other times as much as 7 um broad a distance of 100 um from apex, with variations between and beyond"; hymenium often zonate, consisting of vertically arranged hyphae 1.5-3 um wide, thin-walled but usually firm walled, often prominently clamped, along with broader hyphae 5 um wide, thick-walled, perhaps cystidiophores or cystidial stems, (Weresub(3))
NAME ORIGIN  likely after Petter Adolf Karsten, Finnish mycologist, 1834-1917
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3), Weresub(3) (as Peniophora crassa), Weresub(4) (as Peniophora crassa), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
120
FAMILY  Dacryobolaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dacryobolus sudans  (Alb. & Schwein.) Fr.^  Summa veg. Scand. 2: 404. 1849;  == Hydnum sudans  Alb. & Schwein.;  Odontia sudans  (Alb. & Schwein.) Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  weeping toothcrust
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead conifer wood, 2) a smooth, cream to dingy white spore-bearing surface with teeth that exude a drop of colorless viscid liquid, 3) waxy soft consistency, 4) spores that are allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) basidia that are long and narrow with thin sterigmata, 6) long septate cystidia in the central part of the teeth, shorter cystidia in the hymenium, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^It has been found in BC, ID, ON, AZ, CO, FL, IA, MD, MI, MN, MS, MT, NC, NM, NY, TN, WI, WY, and UT, (Ginns). It is found in Europe including Scandinavia, (Eriksson), and Switzerland, (Breitenbach who include Asia as well in the distribution).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, usually small (some square centimeters) but sometimes confluent and spread more widely, closely adnate [tightly attached]; whitish then pale ochraceous, finally darker; smooth surface with small conic separated teeth (generally less than 0.05cm long), teeth "with an apical tuft of hairlike hyphae, which excrete a drop of viscid liquid", that in fresh, wet fungi looks like a glittering pearl; margin abrupt^, (Eriksson), resupinate in thin, waxy-crustose patches several centimeters to decimeters across, tightly attached, consistency wax-like and soft; cream to dingy white; "punctate with warts when young, with small papillae, covered with irregularly long teeth or spines when old", up to 0.1cm long, bluntly conic, usually with a colorless excretion droplet at tips "which after drying up sometimes colors the tips brownish", teeth getting smaller toward margin; margin distinct, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  growing on wood, rarely bark, of conifers, also on boards lying on ground^, (Eriksson), on dead conifer wood, with and without bark, on branches of Pinus (pine) and Picea (spruce) lying on the ground, also on spruce timber used in construction near the ground, (Breitenbach), on dead branches, conifers and hardwoods, Cornus florida, Juniperus monosperma, J. virginiana, Larix occidentalis, Malus sylvestris, Picea glauca, Pinus aristata, P. edulis, P. ponderosa, Platanus wrightii, Populus sp., Quercus hypoleucoides, Q. reticulata, Rhododendron sp., Tsuga heterophylla, associated with a brown rot, (Ginns), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 5-6 x 1.5 um, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 2.5-3.5 um, long and narrow, with thin sterigmata, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of two types 1) very long, 150-250 um or more, 5-8 um wide pseudocystidia, "penetrating the central part of the teeth and projecting like tufts in their apices", "thin-walled, filled with dense protoplasm, at least in the apical part, and containing numerous droplets", many with adventitious septa, "but at least basally with primary septa with clamps", (these seem to be the excreting organ for the viscid drops), 2) hymenial cystidia, 50-70 x 3-5 um, projecting 20-30 um, "scattered in the hymenium or together in groups", "generally embedded in a viscoid matter which can be seen as small drops between the large ones on the teeth"; HYPHAE monomitic with two layers 1) basal subiculum of mostly distinct hyphae about 3 um wide, richly branched, with clamp connections, to some degree swelling in KOH, 2) trama generally of closely united hyphae but sometimes with layers of a more net-like context, (Eriksson), SPORES 6-8 x 1.5 um, cylindric, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, containing droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 3-4 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; SEPTOCYSTIDIA in the spines clustered, smooth, septate, with droplets, basal septa with clamp connection, HYMENIAL CYSTIDIA shorter, 50-60 x 5 um, sometimes coated with amorphous material, these cystidia dissolving in KOH; HYPHAE monomitic, of hyphae 2-5 um wide, +/- thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, swelling in KOH, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'sweating'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
121
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dendrophora albobadia  (Schwein.) Chamuris^  Mycotaxon 28: 544. 1987;  == Thelephora albobadia  Schwein.;  Stereum albobadium  (Schwein.) Fr.;  Peniophora albobadia  (Schwein.) Boidin;  Thelephora albomarginata  Schwein. in Berk.;  Peniophora albomarginata  (Schwein.) Massee;  Stereum bizonatum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Stereum heterosporum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) leathery, circular to confluent fruitbodies that grow resupinate on wood of a variety of hardwood trees and shrubs, or are sometimes bent outward to form narrow cap, 2) a cap when present that is brown and villose with a whitish margin, 3) a spore-bearing surface that is brown and somewhat velvety, 4) smooth spores measuring 7-11 x (2.5)3.0-4.0 um, 5) dendrohyphidia confined to the hymenium, thick-walled, lacking encrustation, and becoming colored, and 6) cystidia that are also confined to the single-layered hymenium.^ | Dendrophora was segregated from Peniophora, the principal reason being that Dendrophora "has pigmented, thick-walled dendrohyphidia lacking encrustation", and spore prints from Dendrophora are presumably white whereas spore prints from Peniophora species are pink, (Ginns(23)). RANGE ^It has been found in in ID, AL, AZ, CA, DC, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, KS, LA, MD, MO, MS, NC, NJ, NM, NY, OH, OK, PA, SC, TN, TX, VA, and WV, (Ginns(5)), as well as the West Indies and Brazil, (Burt).
FRUITING BODY  coriaceous [leathery], thin, at first resupinate, circular, 0.5-1cm across, becoming confluent over areas 1-2cm wide and 3 to many centimeters long; sometimes becoming narrowly reflexed 0.2-0.5cm [bent outward to form narrow cap], with the upper surface villose, varying from buffy brown to Natal-brown, becoming somewhat zonate when reflexed about 0.5cm, the margin entire and usually whitish; spore-bearing surface even, somewhat velvety, bister or snuff-brown, becoming light drab and somewhat pruinose when old^, (Burt)
HABITAT  on dead hardwood and fallen limbs, throughout the year^, (Burt), on a variety of hardwood trees and shrubs; dead twigs; fallen branches; crevices of the bark of dead limbs and logs; barkless log; associated with a white rot, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-11 x 3-4.5 um, flattened on one side, smooth, white in spore collection^; fruitbody in structure about 500 um thick, hymenium 30-45 um thick, not zonate, BASIDIA 4-spored, PARAPHYSES [dendrohyphidia] present in hymenium, 2 um wide, filiform, branched, becoming colored; CYSTIDIA 30-45 x 8-15 um, protruding up to 25 um, all confined to the single-layered hymenium, the intermediate layer of the fruitbody with a darker zone on its abhymenial side composed of loosely, longitudinally arranged, slightly colored hyphae 3-3.5 um wide, (Burt), SPORES 7-11 x (2.5)3.0-4.0 um; DENDROHYPHIDIA confined to hymenium; CYSTIDIA 9-15 um wide, confined to hymenium, encrusted, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white - chestnut-colored'
SIMILAR  Dendrophora erumpens and D. versiformis (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Chamuris have spores measuring 5-8(9) x 1.5-2.0(2.5) um, dendrohyphidia both in the hymenium and embedded in the context, and encrusted cystidia 10-25 um wide typically embedded in subiculum, (Ginns(23))
SOURCES  Burt(2) (as Stereum albobadium), Ginns(5), Ginns(23)
122
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dendrophora erumpens  (Burt) Chamuris^  Mycotaxon 28: 544. 1987;  == Stereum erumpens  Burt;  Peniophora erumpens  (Burt) Boidin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on hardwood, 2) small discs or cups with elevated black margins and grayish spore-bearing surface that may become crowded as if confluent, and the margin on the upper side may form a narrow grooved blackish brown cap, the spore-bearing surface even or somewhat tuberculate, 3) spores measuring 6.5-7.2 x 2-2.5 um, that are cylindric, slightly curved, smooth, and colorless, 4) dendrohyphidia both in the hymenium and embedded in the context, and 5) encrusted cystidia 10-25 um wide, sometimes protruding, arising from different levels in the fruitbody.^ RANGE ^Dendrophora erumpens has been found in in WA, OR, AL, AR, DC, GA, IA, IL, IN, MD, MT, ND, NJ, NY, PA, RI, SD, and VA, (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  0.1-0.25cm across, may be reflexed 0.1-0.2cm [bent outward to form cap], corky, rarely resupinate, usually bursting out from inner bark as small, circular discs or cups with elevated black margins and cinereous or pallid neutral gray spore-bearing surface; the fruitbodies "may become crowded as if confluent, and then broken up into frustules and remain attached by the under side to the substratum, or the margin on the upper side may grow outward" so as to form umbonate, sessile caps attached by the umbo and lower side, with the upper surface narrowly concentrically sulcate [grooved], mummy brown [blackish brown] to fuscous; spore-bearing surface even or somewhat tuberculate, pallid neutral gray^, (Burt), 0.02-0.04cm thick, at first discoid with elevated black margin, later confluent; spore-bearing surface grayish to brownish, even, (Julich), discrete, erumpent fruitbodies, spore-bearing surface gray, and cap surface dark brown to black, (Ginns(23))
HABITAT  on a variety of hardwoods; on dead limbs^, (Ginns(5)), on dead limbs of hardwoods, March to January, (Burt)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7 x 1.5-2.5 um, smooth, colorless^; CYSTIDIA 30-60 x 8-20 um, sometimes protruding up to 20 um beyond the hymenium, cylindric, encrusted, arising from all parts of the fruitbody; fruitbody 200-300 um thick in structure, "composed of ascending, densely interwoven hyphae both colored and hyaline, the former 3 1/2 um in diameter, with the tips arranged side by side in colored subhymenial zones, mark the 1-3 strata finally present", (Burt who also comments that an important microscopic detail "is the narrow olivaceous zone of colored hyphal tips at the very base of the basidia of the hymenium"), SPORES 6.5-7.2 x 2-2.5 um, cylindric, slightly curved; BASIDIA 4.5-5 um wide; LAMPROCYSTIDIA 30-80 x 5-25 um, conic, encrusted; HYPHAE 3.5-5 um wide, pale brown, often thick-walled, with clamp connections, a basal horizontal layer developed, (Julich), SPORES 5-8(9) x 1.5-2.0(2.5) um; DENDROHYPHIDIA both in the hymenium and embedded in the context, encrusted CYSTIDIA 10-25 um wide and typically embedded in the subiculum, (Ginns(23) for both Dendrophora erumpens and D. versiformis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'erumpent' (bursting out of the inner bark)
SIMILAR  Dendrophora albobadia has encrusted cystidia (9-15 um wide) and dendrohyphidia both confined to the hymenium, and spores measuring 7-11 x (2.5)3.0-4.0 um, (Ginns(23)). Dendrophora versiformis (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Chamuris, [according to Ginns(5) widespread in eastern North America, west to Missouri, Arkansas, and Arizona], has adnate, spreading fruitbodies when young, the spore-bearing surface a rich brown color, and the cap surface brown, (whereas C. erumpens has discrete, erumpent fruitbodies, the spore-bearing surface gray, and the cap surface dark brown to black), (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Burt(2) (as Stereum erumpens), Julich(5) (as Peniophora erumpens), Ginns(5), Ginns(23)
123
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dendrothele candida  (Schwein.) P.A. Lemke^  Persoonia 3: 366. 1965;  == Thelephora candida  Schwein.;  Aleurodiscus candidus  (Schwein.) Burt;  Aleurocorticium candidum  (Schwein.) P.A. Lemke;  Aleurodiscus crassus  Lloyd
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on the bark of living oaks and other hardwoods, 2) cushion-shaped to discoid or confluent fruitbodies that are whitish, with a pruinose surface that is continuous to rarely cracked, 3) clearly marked margins that are free to slightly raised, 4) an undersurface that is dark-colored and smooth, 5) spores that are round to somewhat oval, smooth to slightly roughened, and inamyloid, 6) a hymenium composed of abundant, encrusted dendrophyses and interspersed basidia, but absent pseudocystidia, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae obscured by abundant crystallization.^ RANGE ^Dendrothele candida is found in BC, OR, ON, CA, CT, FL, GA, IL, IN, LA, MA, MD, MO, NC, NH, OH, PA, SC, TN, TX, VA, and WV, (Ginns), and also Mexico and Jamaica, (Burt).
FRUITING BODY  pulvinate [cushion-shaped] to discoid, at first separate and 0.1-0.3cm across, readily confluent into patches up 2-3cm across; chalk-white to ivory-white; continuous to rarely rimose [cracked] on drying; texture pruinose-pulverulent [appearing powdery] to compact-crustulose; annual and 0.02-0.05cm thick in cross-section, or perennial attaining a thickness of 0.08-0.3cm in cross-section; margins determinate [clearly marked], thick, free to slightly raised; abhymenial surface dark-colored, smooth; context pallid^, (Lemke), resupinate, adnate, at first convex and circular, soon expanded and flattened, following the inequality of the bark, usually 0.3-0.6cm across, sometimes 1-2cm across; in structure 0.08cm thick; white; pruinose; margin thick, entire, blackening underneath, (Burt)
HABITAT  bark of live trees, especially oaks^; on Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Acer rubrum (Red Maple), Acer saccharum (Sugar Maple), Carya illinoensis (Pecan), Castanea sp. (chestnut), Fraxinus americana (White Ash), Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak), Quercus alba (White Oak), Q. chrysolepis (Canyon Live Oak), Q. falcata (Southern Red Oak), Q. garryana (Oregon White Oak), Q. nigra (Water Oak), Q. prinus (Chestnut Oak), Q. rubra (Red Oak), Q. stellata (Post Oak), Q. velutina (Black Oak), Ulmus alata (Winged Elm), (Ginns), in North America primarily on the bark of living Quercus, also on other hardwoods, in Ontario only on Acer, (Lemke), on trunks of living Quercus, rarely on Fraxinus and Acer; August to January, (Burt)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (13)15-20(22) x (11)13-16(20) um, round to suboval, apiculate, appearing smooth to roughened in Melzer's reagent, inamyloid, walls partially thickened^; catahymenium "composed of abundant, incrusted dendrophyses and basidial elements"; BASIDIA 4-spored, (45)50-70 x (11)13.5-15.5(16) um, flexuous-clavate, sterigmata up to 14 um long; DENDROPHYSES 2-3 um wide at base, encrusted, delicate but readily discerned, with irregular and tapering branches at the apex; pseudocystidia not present; CONTEXT, on sectioning appearing somewhat stratified in well-developed specimens, monomitic, obscured by abundant crystallization, hyphae 2-3 um wide, "branched, thin-walled, simple-septate, irregular", BASAL HYPHAE up to 4 um wide with partially thickened walls, generative, (Lemke), SPORES 15-17 x 11-14 um, subglobose [nearly round], smooth, colorless; hymenium composed of clavate BASIDIA 45-60 x 10-15 um and hyphal PARAPHYSES that are flexuous [wavy], colorless, thin-walled, encrusted, with tips bushy, branched in somewhat corymbose fashion, branches 2-3 um wide under their encrustation, "not moniliform and noteworthy, as are the hyphae, by the large amount of crystalline matter attached to them", often by only a corner or small end of the crystal; beneath hymenium somewhat stratose, composed of hyphae that are 2-3 um wide (under the heavy encrustation), "densely arranged, suberect, interwoven", much of the encrusting matter is large, angular, crystalline grains, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'shining white'
SIMILAR  Dendrothele nivosa has pseudocystidia and the host affinity is different (Lemke). D. nivosa has thinner and more elongated fruitbodies that are not at all stratose within, encrusting matter not in the form of large, angular, crystalline grains, a margin with no tendency to be free nor blackening on underside, and common occurrence on bark of living juniper, (Burt). Dendrothele macrodens is generally thinner, with the margins tightly attached, (Lemke).
SOURCES  Lemke(2) (as Aleurocorticium candidum), Burt(5) (as Aleurodiscus candidus), Ginns(5)
124
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dendrothele macrodens  (Coker) P.A. Lemke^  Persoonia 3: 366. 1965;  == Aleurodiscus macrodens  Coker;  Aleurocorticium macrodens  (Coker) P.A. Lemke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on bark of living ash, tupelo, or oak, 2) scattered to confluent patches that are whitish and pruinose, with a clearly marked and tightly attached margin, 3) large rectangular spores that are smooth and inamyloid, 4) a hymenium of encrusted dendrophyses and interspersed basidia, pseudocystidia absent, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae obscured by abundant crystallization, with inconspicuous clamp connections^, RANGE ^It has been found in in OR, CT, GA, LA, MA, MI, NC, NH, NY, OH, PA, and WV, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  "corticioid, in scattered to irregularly confluent patches" up to 2.5cm long and 1cm wide; 0.01-0.015(0.02)cm thick in cross-section; chalk-white to dingy white or ivory colored; rimose on drying [cracked]; texture pruinose to pruinose-pulverulent [appearing powdery]; margin determinate [clearly marked], adnate^, (Lemke)
HABITAT  on bark of living Fraxinus (ash) in eastern North America, but also found on Nyssa in Louisiana; a single collection from Oregon was on Quercus kelloggii (California Black Oak)^, (Lemke), on bark of live trees, Fraxinus americana (White Ash), Fraxinus nigra (Black Ash), Nyssa sylvatica (Black Tupelo), Quercus kelloggii, Salix sp. (willow), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (17)19-23(29) x 11-16(18) um, rectangular spores bearing scattered appendages up to 4 um long, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; catahymenium composed of encrusted dendrophyses and basidial elements; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-80 x (12)15-18(20) um, flexuous-subclavate to clavate, basidial initials imbedded, 30-45 x (12)15-20 um, obovate; DENDROPHYSES measuring 1.5-2.5 um wide at base, delicately branched; pseudocystidia not present; CONTEXT monomitic, obscured by abundant crystallization, hyphae 2-2.5(3) um wide, branched, irregular, thin-walled, inconspicuously clamped, (Lemke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with large tooth'
SIMILAR  Dendrothele candida is generally thicker with margins raised to expose a darkened abhymenial surface, (Lemke). Dendrothele nivosa has pseudocystidia.
SOURCES  Lemke(2) (as Aleurocorticium macrodens), Ginns(5)
125
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dendrothele nivosa  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) P.A. Lemke^  Persoonia 3: 367. 1965;  == Aleurodiscus nivosus  Berk. & M.A. Curtis ex Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Aleurocorticium nivosum  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) P.A. Lemke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on bark of living juniper, 2) cushion-shaped fruitbodies that become elliptic to linear patches, with a pruinose, whitish surface, the margin clearly marked and tightly attached, 3) spores that are round to oval, smooth to finely spiny, 4) a hymenium consisting of abundant encrusted dendrophyses, embedded pseudocystidia, and basidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system in the context, the hyphae obscured by abundant crystallization, with scattered, inconspicuous clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Dendrothele nivosa has been found in in OR, ON, AL, AR, CT, FL, GA, IN, KS, LA, MA, MO, MS, NC, NJ, NY, OH, OK, PA, SC, TN, and TX, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  pulvinate [cushion-shaped], forming elliptic to linear patches 0.1-2(2.5)cm long and 0.1-0.5cm wide, 0.008-0.025(0.033)cm thick in cross-section; "chalk-white to pallid on drying"; deeply rimose [cracked]; texture pruinose-pulverulent [appearing powdery]; margin determinate [clearly marked], thick, adnate [tightly attached]^, (Lemke), 0.3-3cm long, about 0.2-0.6cm wide, in structure 0.02-0.025cm thick; "small, resupinate, adnate, circular or oblong", convex at first becoming flat; white; margin thick, determinate, adnate, (Burt)
HABITAT  bark on trunks and branches of living trees, especially Juniperus spp. (juniper)^: J. virginiana (Eastern Juniper), J. scopulorum (Rocky Mountain Juniper), J. silicicola (Southern Red-cedar), J. phoenica (Phoenician Juniper), also Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Chamaecyparis thyoides (Atlantic White-cedar), (Ginns), primarily on bark of Juniperus virginiana in North America, reported also on J. scopulorum and Chamaecyparis, in Asia recorded on Tsuga (hemlock) and in New Zealand on Libocedrus and Podocarpus (podocarp), (Lemke)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (14)16-20 x 12-15 um, nearly round to oval, smooth to finely echinulate in Melzer's reagent, inamyloid, thin-walled, apiculate^; catahymenium "composed of a mass of incrusted dendrophyses, embedded pseudocystidia (macrocystidia), and basidial elements"; BASIDIA 4-spored, (60)70-95(150) x 12-18 um, flexuous-subclavate, sterigmata up to 14 um long, arcuate; DENDROPHYSES 2-3 um at base, "delicately and corymbosely branched at the apex, with individual branches tapering, 1-1.5 um in diameter"; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA (20)30-40(50) x (8)10-16 um, "embedded to ascendant, obovate to clavate or rarely subcylindric", "contents granular to granular-guttulate, faintly yellowish in KOH, darkening in sulphobenzaldehyde", rarely with an apical bulb; CONTEXT "monomitic, obscured by abundant crystallization", hyphae (1.5)2-3 um wide, thin-walled, irregular with scattered inconspicuous clamp connections, (Lemke), SPORES 15-20 x 12-16 um, smooth, colorless; hymenium consisting of basidia, paraphyses, gloeocystidia, and many encrusted hyphae; BASIDIA only rarely found, 4-spored, 40-60 x 12-16 um, clavate; PARAPHYSES about 2-3 um wide under the encrustation, "cylindric, flexuous, more or less irregular in form, somewhat corymbosely branched at surface of hymenium and with branches loaded with crystalline matter"; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 18-30 x 9 um, clavate, colorless, even; beneath hymenium not stratose, composed of hyphae about 2 um wide, erect, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, bearing a large amount of encrusting granular matter, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'snowy'
SIMILAR  Dendrothele candida lacks pseudocystidia and has a different host affinity, (Lemke). D. candida is thicker, less elongated, and stratose within, has encrusting matter in the form of large, angular, crystalline grains, has a margin with a tendency to become free and blackening on underside, and occurs mostly on the bark of living oaks, (Burt). Dendrothele macrodens lacks pseudocystidia.
SOURCES  Lemke(2) (as Aleurocorticium nivosum), Burt(5), Ginns(5)
126
FAMILY  Hericiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dentipellis fragilis  (Pers.) Donk^  Persoonia 2: 233. 1962;  == Hydnum fragile  Pers.;  Dryodon fragilis  (Pers. per Fr.) Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) soft, fragile fruitbodies that are attached tightly (but detaching starting at the margin when dried), colored whitish to ocherish, composed of a thin, membranous subiculum with crowded thin spines up to 1cm long, the margin floccose or similar to the rest of the fruitbody, 3) spores that are nearly round, smooth, amyloid, and colorless, 4) gloeocystidia that are irregularly fusiform or cylindric, 5) a monomitic hyphal system with some gloeoplerous hyphae, and 6) clamp connections.^ RANGE ^It has been recorded from WA and AK, (Ginns), Austria, France, and Sweden, (Bourdot), Asia, and Europe including Switzerland, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached tightly but detaching from margin inward when dry, forming patches several centimeters across; consistency soft, fragile; surface composed of "a thin, membranous subiculum with vertical, densely crowded, fine, fragile spines", up to 1cm long, white to ocherish; margin finely floccose^, (Breitenbach), membranous thin, flat on substrate, separating from substrate on drying; whitish; margin floccose-subbyssoid or similar to the rest of the surface, teeth 1-1.5cm long, fragile, elongated, slender, flexuous [wavy], serrate, (Bourdot)
HABITAT  on Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), (Ginns), on hardwoods, beech, September to November, (Bourdot)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 4-4.5 um, nearly round, smooth, amyloid, colorless, with droplets^; BASIDIA not seen, according to literature 20-35 x 4.5-7.5 um; GLOEOCYSTIDIA up to about 130 x 10-13 um, "fusiform, sinuous, smooth, exserted beyond the hymenium"; HYPHAE monomitic, 1) hyphae 1.5-4.5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections, 2) 4-5 um wide, gloeoplerous, sinuous, with yellowish contents, (Breitenbach), SPORES 4.5-6 um in diameter, oval round, amyloid; BASIDIA 21-36 x 4.5-6 um, with droplets that are sometimes blue with iodine; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 40-75 x 4-9 um, irregularly fusiform or cylindric, more or less "toruleuses"; hyphae 2-4 um wide, thin-walled, septa distant, (Bourdot)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fragile'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Donk(2), Bourdot(1) (as Dryodon fragilis, in French), Ginns(5)
127
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dichostereum boreale  (Pouzar) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre^  Mycologia Memoir 19: 59. 1993;  == Vararia borealis  Pouzar;  Vararia granulosa  (Pers.) Laurila sensu Aucts.;  Dichostereum granulosum  (Pers.) Boidin & Lanq. sensu Aucts.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a fruitbody surface that is ochraceous-buff and granular, 3) spores measuring 4-6 x 3-4 um, that are amyloid and subtly ornamented with small warts and ridges, 4) granular gloeocystidia, and 5) strongly dextrinoid dichophyses.^ RANGE ^It has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, ON, AZ, CO, MI, MN, MT, NH, NM, and SD, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate; surface ochraceous-buff and granular; creamy ocher in the herbarium; "with a slightly tuberculate or irregularly warty hymenial surface"^, (Castellano)
HABITAT  on conifer logs, associated with a white rot, (Ginns), saprophytic on dead conifer wood; fruits May, July, October, (Castellano)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-6 x 3-4 um, elliptic, "subtly ornamented with small warts and ridges", amyloid^; GLOEOCYSTIDIA present, filled with granular material; dichophyses abundant, up to 5 um wide, strongly dextrinoid, (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'northern'
SIMILAR  Dichostereum pallescens "has more highly ornamented, larger spores (6-7.5 x 5.5-6.5 um), narrow dichophyses (up to 2 um in diam), and lacks gloeocystidia", (Castellano). Dichostereum effuscatum has larger spores (6-8 x 5.5-7 um), and smaller dichophyses, (Castellano).
SOURCES  Castellano(1), Ginns(5)
128
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dichostereum effuscatum  (Cooke & Ellis) Boidin & Lanq.^  Mycotaxon 6: 284. 1977;  == Corticium effuscatum  Cooke & Ellis;  Vararia effuscata  (Cooke & Ellis) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwoods, 2) fruitbodies that are honey-yellow to russet, the surface appearing powdery and the margin thinning out, 3) spores measuring 6-8 x 5.5-7 um, smooth, and colorless, 4) microscopic composition that is very densely arranged, with nearly erect, interwoven hyphae about 2 um in diameter, 5) gloeocystidia that are flexuous [wavy] and start from the substrate, and 6) numerous chlamydospores 5-6 um in diameter.^ RANGE ^Dichostereum effuscatum has been found in BC, WA, ID, NB, NF, NS, ON, PE, PQ, CT, DC, GA, IA, IL, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, TX, VA, and WI, (Ginns), although Castellano(1) says that it appears restricted to eastern North America: Burt lists BC, WA, and ID specimens and perhaps these identifications are disputed.
FRUITING BODY  3-10cm long, 2-4cm wide, in section 0.02-0.05cm thick, broadly spread out, "rather thick, membranaceous, small pieces separable when moistened"; "honey-yellow to russet when fresh, fading to cream-buff in the herbarium"; even, pulverulent [powdery]; the margin thinning out^, (Burt)
HABITAT  on the underside of decaying wood and bark of hardwoods, September to November^, (Burt), on Acer saccharinum (Silver Maple), Acer saccharum (Sugar Maple), Acer rubrum (Red Maple), Alnus incana (Speckled Alder), Betula alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), Betula nigra (River Birch), Carpinus sp. (hornbeam), Carya ovata (Shagbark Hickory), Fraxinus nigra (Black Ash), Juglans cinerea (Butternut), Populus sp., Quercus alba (White Oak), Salix sp. (willow), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Ulmus sp. (elm); branch on ground; decaying wood and bark of logs; rotten log, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8 x 5.5-7 um^, (Castellano(1)), SPORES 6 um in diameter, smooth, colorless; fruitbody "composed of very densely arranged, suberect, interwoven hyphae about 2 um in diameter, gloeocystidia, and chlamydospores"; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 40-150 x 5-9 um, starting from the substrate, flexuous; imbedded chlamydospores very numerous, 5-6 um in diameter, round, sometimes comprising nearly the whole fruitbody, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Dichostereum boreale has spores 4-6 x 3-4 um, and larger dichophyses, (Castellano(1)). Dichostereum pallescens lacks gloeocystidia, (Castellano(1)).
SOURCES  Burt(1) (as Corticium effuscatum), Ginns(5), Castellano(1) (discussing Dichostereum boreale)
129
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dichostereum pallescens  (Schwein.) Boidin & Lanq.^  Mycotaxon 6: 284. 1977;  == Thelephora pallescens  Schwein.;  Vararia pallescens  (Schwein.) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.;  Thelephora insinuans  Schwein.;  Corticium thelephoroides  Ellis & Everh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on wood of conifers and hardwoods, 2) relatively thick fruitbodies with a smooth to somewhat warted surface that is minutely powdery, the margin abrupt, 3) spores that are 6-7.5 x 5.5-6.5 um with a prominent oblique apiculus, pale yellow, amyloid, with warts often joined by fine lines, 4) dichophyses that are golden yellow to yellowish brown, bearing 1-2 clusters of short dichotomous branches with acute apices, and 5) hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Dichostereum pallescens has been found in BC, WA, OR, ON, AL, AZ, CA, DC, FL, GA, IL, LA, MA, MD, ME, MO, NC, NH, NY, PA, RI, TN, TX, VA, VT, and WI, (Ginns), and also Grenada (Welden).
FRUITING BODY  compact, thick (context up to 0.1cm in section); colored 'honeysuckle' (12 D 6); surface smooth to somewhat warted, minutely powdery; margin abrupt, colored as surface^, (Welden)
HABITAT  on fallen wood^, (Welden), Acer saccharum (Sugar Maple), Alnus oblongifolia (Arizona Alder), Betula alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Castanea dentata (American Chestnut), Pinus echinata (Shortleaf Pine), Pinus palustris (Longleaf Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus rubra (Northern Red Oak), Rubus spectabilis (salmonberry), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Ulmus americana (American Elm); logs; old logs, stumps; dead roots; fallen wood; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7 x 5-6 um, round or nearly round, with prominent, oblique apiculus, pale yellow, episporium about 0.5 um thick, "surrounded by a continuous or interrupted amyloid exosporium which may be smooth or organized into warts", warts up to 1 um high, "often joined by fine lines into a semi-reticulate pattern"^; fruitbody with several strata, filled with dichophyses and crystalline material; BASIDIA 4-spored, up to 62 um long, sterigmata straight or slightly curved, about 5 um long; dichophyses "golden yellow to yellowish brown, bearing 1-2 clusters of short dichotomous branches with acute apices", terminal branches may be dendrophysoid; hyphae about 2-4 um wide, colorless to slightly tinted, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Welden), SPORES 6-7.5 x 5.5-6.5 um, (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming pale'
SIMILAR  Dichostereum boreale has spores measuring 4-6 x 3-4 um and less highly ornamented (Castellano(1)). Dichostereum effuscatum has gloeocystidia, (Castellano(1)).
SOURCES  Welden(2), Ginns(5), Castellano(1) (discussing Dichostereum boreale)
130
FAMILY  Sebacinaceae, Order Sebacinales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Efibulobasidium albescens  (Sacc. & Malbr.) K. Wells^  Mycologia 67: 149. 1975;  Epidochium albescens  Sacc & Malbr.;  Exidiopsis albescens  (Sacc. & Malbr.) D.A. Reid;  Tremella albescens  (Sacc. & Malbr.)  Sacc.;  Tremella fusispora  Bourdot & Galzin;  Sebacina fusispora  (Bourdot & Galzin) Raitv.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Features include 1) pustular, soft to firm gelatinous, colorless to pale yellow fruitbodies with a granulose surface, in older specimens becoming confluent to form a continuous layer, 2) growth on decaying herbaceous stems and 3) microscopic characters including fusiform-curved to cylindric-curved spores and absent clamp connections.^ | The description from Wells(6). RANGE ^It is known from Azerbaijan and France, (Wells). There is a collection from BC by Robert Bandoni at the University of British Columbia.
FRUITING BODY  arising as small pustules, 0.01-0.3cm in diameter, "becoming confluent in older specimens to form a continuous layer with abrupt margins", fruitbodies 0.018-0.2cm thick, consistency soft to firm gelatinous, loosely attached; colorless or translucent to pale yellow; "surface granulose, becoming undulate in continuous specimens"; drying evanescent [disappearing] or forming colorless or amber, vernicose [varnish-like] patches
HABITAT  on decaying herbaceous stems
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 15-21(25) x 5.5-7.5 um, fusiform-curved to cylindric-curved, capable of germinating by repetition^; HYPOBASIDIA 15-22(25) x (10)12-16 um, epibasidia "tubular, gradually enlarging apically, bulbous adjacent to sterigma", up to 130 um long, 2-3.5 um wide and up to 5 um wide adjacent to sterigma, probasidia at first pyriform to clavate, becoming ovoid, to narrowly ampulliform, or rarely fusiform, finally subspherical, ovoid, obovate, to clavate, pyriform or rarely fusiform, forming 2-4 hypobasidial segments, "adjoining walls of hypobasidial segments longitudinally to obliquely oriented"; HYMENIUM distinct, consisting of a zone of developing basidia covered by a layer of dikaryophyses 50-90 um in section, DIKARYOPHYSES "at first distinct, simple to little branched, some segments curved", 1-3 um in diameter; subhymenial HYPHAE at first distinct, thin-walled, branching, without clamp connections, 1.5-4 um wide; pustular fruitbodies "consisting of branching hyphae radiating from the substrate and terminating in a convex hymenium of fertile hyphae and dikaryophyses", in continuous fruitbodies "margins of original pustules outlined by layers of collapsed, yellowish basidia"; collapsed basidia are present in most areas of the ascending hyphae
NAME ORIGIN  means "becoming white"
SIMILAR  Efibulobasidium rolleyi has smaller spores measuring 9-14 x 4.5-6 um that are cylindric-curved and flattened adaxially, and smaller hypobasidia measuring 8-13 x 8-12 um, (Wells).
SOURCES  Wells(6)
131
FAMILY  Sebacinaceae, Order Sebacinales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Efibulobasidium rolleyi  (Olive) K. Wells^  Mycologia 67: 152. 1975;  Exidia rolleyi  Olive
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Features include 1) small, pustular, waxy gelatinous, colorless to pale amber fruitbodies with a finely granulose surface, in older specimens becoming confluent to form a continuous layer, 2) growth on decaying wood with bark in place or on leaves, and 3) microscopic characters including cylindric-curved spores and absent clamp connections.^ | The description from Wells(6) except where noted. RANGE ^It has been found in IA and Tahiti, (Wells). There are collections from BC and CA by Robert Bandoni at the University of British Columbia.
FRUITING BODY  arising as small pustules 0.01-0.3cm in diameter, becoming confluent when older to form continuous layer with abrupt margins, fruitbodies 0.008cm to 0.2cm thick, waxy-gelatinous in consistency, loosely attached; colorless to pale amber; surface undulate, finely granulose; evanescent [disappearing] on drying or forming a light to dark amber, vernicose [varnish-like] layer
HABITAT  on decaying, corticate wood [wood with bark] or leaves, (Wells), on dead Salix (willow), one collection on Alnus rubra (Red Alder), (Bandoni's notes with collections at University of British Columbia) 
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (8)9-14 x (3.5)4.5-6(7) um, cylindric-curved and flattened adaxially, "capable of germinating by repetition"^; HYPOBASIDIA (7.5)8-13(14) x (7.5)8-12 um, epibasidia up to 100(255) um long, "tubular, usually enlarging towards apices", probasidia at first cylindric, then clavate, broadly fusiform or ampulliform, finally subspherical, ovoid, obovate, or clavate, "forming 2 or 4 hypobasidial segments, adjoining wall of hypobasidial segments longitudinally to obliquely oriented"; HYMENIUM distinct, with developing basidia in a zone 20-55 um in section, covered by a layer of dikaryophyses 20-65 um in depth, DIKARYOPHYSES "usually abundant and distinct, branching, somewhat nodulose near apices, some segments curved", 1-1.5-3 um thick, fertile HYPHAE "proliferating laterally from the apical region of subbasidial segment", 1.5-2-3 um in diameter, without clamp connections; subhymenial hyphae "without clamp connections, usually distinct, thin-walled", 1.5-3 um wide; "in pustules hyphae arising from a restricted region of the substrate, then expanding and forming a loosely interwoven and ascending layer of hyphae" terminating in hymenium, "in continuous specimens ascending, interwoven layer continuous with a poorly defined basal layer that is very loosely attached to substrate, collapsed basidia scattered throughout ascending, interwoven layer"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Efibulobasidium albescens has larger fusiform-curved to cylindric-curved spores measuring 15-21 x 5.5-7.5 um, and larger hypobasidia measuring 15.5-22 x 12-16 um, (Wells).
SOURCES  Wells(6)
132
FAMILY  Auriculariaceae, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Eichleriella deglubens  (Berk. & Broome) D. Reid^  Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc. 55: 436. 1970;  == Radulum deglubens  Berk. & Broome;  Eichleriella spinulosa  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Burt sensu N. Amer. Aucts.;  Radulum spinulosum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis sensu Burt 1915 sensu N. Amer. Aucts.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwoods, especially Populus species, 2) soft wax-like fruitbodies, the mealy surface with sparse warts or spines up to 0.1cm long, the color light pink to flesh-colored, turning wine-red when injured, the margin whitish, somewhat fringed, distinctly bounded and at times somewhat lifted, 3) spores that are cylindric, slightly curved, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets, 4) hypobasidia that are longitudinally septate with 2-4 epibasidia, and 5) hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Eichleriella deglubens has been found in BC, OR, ID, AB, MB, NT, ON, and AK, (Ginns). It also occurs in Europe including Switzerland, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate (flat on substrate), attached tightly, forming patches up to 0.05cm thick and a few centimeters across, consistency of fruiting body wax-like and soft when fresh, crustose and hard when dry; light pink, flesh-colored, turning wine-red when injured; smooth, farinose [mealy] with isolated, sparsely distributed warts, spines, or thorns up to 0.1cm long; margin whitish, "distinctly bounded and at times somewhat lifted from substrate", in part somewhat fringed^, (Breitenbach), spore deposit (white)
HABITAT  on hardwoods especially Populus species, associated with a white rot^, (Ginns), on dead parts of living Fraxinus (ash) and Fagus (beech), as well as on dead branches and trunks on ground, fall-spring, (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 12-18 x 6-7 um, cylindric, slightly allantoid [curved], smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets, some spores forming secondary spores^; HYPOBASIDIA 30-40 x 10-12 um, clavate to cylindric, longitudinally septate, with 2-4 epibasidia up to 5 um wide; CYSTIDIA not seen; hyphae in hymenium 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, sparsely septate, with clamp connections; BASAL HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, thick-walled, sinuous, gnarled, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'peeling off'
SIMILAR  Corticium roseum, Peniophora incarnata, and some resupinate Stereum spp. are similar macroscopically in certain respects but lack the scattered small spines on the hymenium (easily visible with hand lens) and they are different microscopically, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Gilbertson(8) (note on Radulum spinulosum), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
133
FAMILY  Xylariaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Entoleuca mammata  (Wahlenb.) J.D. Rogers & Y.-M. Ju^  Mycotaxon 59: 446. 1996;  == Sphaeria mammata  Wahlenb.;  Hypoxylon mammatum  (Wahlenb.) P. Karst.;  Sphaeria mammaeformis  Wahlenb.;  Sphaeria pruinata  Klotzsch;  Hypoxylon pruinatum  (Klotzsch) Cooke;  Hypoxylon pauperatum  P. Karst.;  Hypoxylon morsei  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Anthostoma morsei  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Cooke;  Fuckelia morsei  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Cooke;  Hypoxylon blakei  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Hypoxylon holwayi  Ellis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  Hypoxylon canker
NOTES  Features include 1) erumpent growth on aspen and sometimes other hardwoods, 2) cankers that are crusty, cracked, and white-pruinose then black, the cankers having gray perithecia and gray dusty conidial pegs between bark and cambium, 3) not exuding pigments when a small piece is placed in 10% KOH on a microscope slide, 4) a germ slit on the concave side of the spore, and immature spores bearing a cellular appendage, and 5) the ascus tip containing an amyloid plug clearly visible at 400x.^ | In eastern North America, "Hypoxylon canker is a very important and damaging disease of aspen, especially in stands predisposed by weather or insect damage", but in BC it is infrequently collected and has not been associated with heavy damage within stands, (Callan). RANGE ^Entoleuca mammata has been found in BC, WA, ON, NF, AK, CO, IA, MA, ME, MI, MN, MO, ND, NH, NJ, NY, PA, VA, WI, WY, Finland, Germany, and Sweden, (Miller, J.H.).
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] "immersed or erumpent from bark", on plants with thick hard bark discrete, orbicular [circular], 0.2-0.5cm across and 0.1-0.2cm thick, while on plants with soft bark often indefinite in shape and usually coalescing to form an effused fruitbody up to 2.5cm in length; "at first white pruinose, later becoming black"; "smooth except for the coarsely papillate ostiola, or often tuberculate from the prominent perithecial projections, carbonous", perithecia single to many, up to 30 in a stroma^, (Miller, J.H.), cankers "begin as yellow to orange, slightly sunken areas of bark on lower trunks or branches", then "expand more rapidly longitudinally than horizontally, the surface becoming roughened or cracked", after a few years, "cankered bark starts to separate from the underlying wood", as gray, dusty pillars of fungal tissue (hyphal pegs) 0.2-0.5cm in diameter, and 0.1-0.2cm tall, covered with conidia, force the bark outward; perithecia develop in whitish to grayish crusts "on dark central areas of the canker, where bark has split or sloughed off", clusters of 10-30 perithecia may be fused into a single crust, with the top of each perithecium nipple-like, opening with darker central ostiole; interior black and shiny when a fresh, dry crust is sectioned, (Callan)
HABITAT  "Hypoxylon cankers occur most commonly on Populus tremuloides, but are also rarely encountered on Salix spp. and Alnus sinuata (Regel) Rydb. (Sitka alder) in BC"; perennial and thus detected any time of year, new cankers appearing after stress or wounding, (Callan, Latin names italicized)^, on wood: Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carpinus (hornbeam), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Populus, Pyrus (pear), Salix (willow), Sorbus (mountain-ash), Ulmus (elm), (Miller, J.H.), a serious pathogen of Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen) and a number of other species of Populus, Alnus, Salix, Betula, and other genera, (Rogers)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 20-33 x 9-12 um, oblong-elliptic with obtuse ends, dark brown, uniseriate or obliquely uniseriate^; ASCUS 140-200 x 12-16 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, with stem 30-40 um long; PARAPHYSES present; PERITHECIUM 700-1000 um in diameter, spherical to ovate, (Miller, J.H.), SPORES 20-33 x 9-12 um, elliptic, with one side flattened, blackish brown, with straight germ slit appearing under high magnification as a pale line on the concave side of the spore; ASCUS 8-spored, cylindric, long-stemmed, with prominent rectangular plug that turns blue in Melzer's reagent; CONIDIUM 5.5-8.0 x 1.5-4.0 um, single-celled, colorless, (Callan)
NAME ORIGIN  from 'mamma', Latin for 'breast', meaning 'breast-like'
SIMILAR  Entoleuca callimorpha Syd. is described in Rogers, J.D.(5) and collections were examined from Montana and Colorado; as far as they knew it had not been collected in recent times: 1) the ascospores averaged much smaller, (14.5)17.5-20.5(22.0) x (6.5)7.0-9.5 um, than for Entoleuca mammata, 2) spore shape is elliptic to elliptic-inequilateral, with narrowly rounded or broadly rounded ends (as opposed to somewhat rectangular for Entoleuca mammata), (Rogers, J.D.(5)). |E. mammata differs from Hypoxylon spp. in several ways including 1) the stroma does not exude pigments when a small piece is placed in 10% KOH on a microscope slide or watch glass, 2) the ascospore germ slit occurs on the concave side of the pore whereas in Hypoxylon the slit is on the concave side if the spore is inequilateral, 3) immature ascospores bear a cellular appendage, 4) the "ascus tip contains a plug which turns blue in Melzer's reagent, is taller than broad", and is clearly visible at 400x under a microscope, whereas Hypoxylon species "have much reduced disc-like ascus apical structures that are much broader than tall, and are often hard to see even at high magnification", and 5) the anamorph produces bark-rupturing hyphal pegs covered in conidia, unlike anamorphs of Hypoxylon species, (Callan, after Ju and Rogers(1996)).
SOURCES  Miller, J.H.(1), Callan(1), Rogers, J.D.(5)
134
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Entomocorticium dendroctoni  H.S. Whitney^  Can. J. Bot. 65: 96. 1987
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth in pupal chambers and on the walls of larval galleries of the mountain pine beetle, 2) a fruitbody at first consisting of a thin, white, cottony layer and delicate radiating strands, 3) spores that are mostly elliptic (occasionally broadly elliptic to nearly round), smooth, and inamyloid, 4) basidia that are usually 4-spored, occasionally 1-spored, 2-spored, or 6-spored, 5) cystidia that are thick-walled in the lanceolate to ventricose distal part which becomes encrusted, but thin-walled and sometimes collapsing in the more basal part, 6) hyphae with clamp connections, branches originating between clamp connections.^ |Mountain pine beetles, which are associated with major damage to lodgepole pine, carry a variety of micro-organisms into host trees at the time of penetration: this basidiomycete grows in the pupal chambers and on the walls of larval galleries (young beetles eat the fungus lining of their pupal chambers), and it is most likely that E. dendroctoni is carried from tree to tree by adult mountain pine beetles, (Whitney), the spores lack an active release mechanism (Ginns). RANGE ^Entomocorticium dendroctoni has been found in BC and MT (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  fruitbody primordia at first consisting of a very thin, adherent, white byssoid [cottony] layer, and delicate radiating strands, the spore-bearing surface thickening and becoming continuous, separating readily from the substrate; surface white to pale cream or buff; smooth^, (Whitney) 
HABITAT  on Pinus contorta var. latifolia (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), growing in pupal chambers and on the walls of larval galleries of the beetle Dendroctonus ponderosae, disseminated "by the beetle as the spores are borne symmetrically and lack an active release mechanism", (Ginns), sometimes "growing beyond galleries and chambers if separation of bark and wood occurs", (Whitney)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES elliptic and (7)8-10(12) x 4-6 um (mostly), "frequently narrowed slightly near the middle, rounded distally, tapered slightly proximally to a broad, truncated attachment", occasionally broadly elliptic to nearly round and 8-10.5 x 7.5-10 um, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, wall thick and appearing multilayered^, spores "accumulating to form a fragile crust on the hymenium"; BASIDIA 24-27(31) x 5.5-6.6 um, "clavate or suburniform, often irregular, frequently secondarily septate, collapsing after spore production (often while the spores are still attached), mostly 4-spored, a few with 1, 2, or 6 spores, these born symmetrically on short, broad sterigmata"; CYSTIDIA 22-60 x 5-10 um, "smooth, thick-walled above, mostly becoming incrusted, thin-walled and sometimes collapsing below the incrustation, incrusted portion lanceolate to ventricose or irregular, often sharply bent basally, especially in those formed initially"; HYPHAE 3-5(6) um wide, walls thin to slightly thickened, remaining distinct, with a clamp connection at each septum, branches originating between clamp connections; HYMENIUM begins with scattered clusters of basidia and cystidia, "arising either directly on the subicular hyphae or elevated on erect hyphae arising from the subiculum, the hymenium spreading, becoming continuous", the initial hymenial layer about 45-50 um thick, "with abundant cystidia, the extremely thin underlying parallel layer of hyphae inconspicuous except at margins and in the initial stages of basidiocarp development, the hymenium thickening, the basidiocarp eventually layered and successive hymenia with few or no cystidia", the total thickness eventually up to about 500 um; the RADIATING STRANDS "mostly composed of less than 10 closely adherent, clamped hyphae that branch infrequently, the branches recurving and adherent, single large crystalline deposits at frequent intervals on the strands"
NAME ORIGIN  named after the beetle Dendroctonus ponderosae (mountain pine bark beetle)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Whitney(1), Ginns(5)
135
FAMILY  Clavicipitaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Epichloe typhina  (Pers.) Tul. & C. Tul.^  Select. fung. carpol. (Paris) 3: 24. 1865;  Typhodium typhinum  (Pers.) Seaver, Mycologia 2(2): 87. 1910;  Neotyphodium typhinum  (Morgan-Jones & W. Gams) Glenn, C.W. Bacon & Hanlin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  choke of grasses
NOTES  Epichloe typhina forms white to pale yellow to orange sheaths 2-5cm long around the stems of grasses, with a granular surface due to the perithecia. The affected grasses usually do not bloom. The name has a dieresis over the terminal e of Epichloe.^ RANGE ^The distribution is from NY to WA and Mexico, including DE, FL, IA, MO, OH, SD, and WI, (Seaver(6)). It also occurs in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach(1)).
