FRUITING BODY  at first forms a whitish smooth sheath up to 5cm long around stem, then the light yellow perithecia develop, "giving the surface a granular and rough appearance"^, (Breitenbach), forming sheaths 2-5cm in length around the stems of various grasses, stroma spread out, somewhat fleshy, at first pale, becoming bright orange; perithecia "thickly scattered, partially to completely immersed, soft, membranaceous", similar in color to the stroma, with a rather prominent ostiolum
HABITAT  fruiting on various living grasses in summer^ (Breitenbach), on living grasses including Agropyron divergens, Agropyron occidentalis, Calamagrostis canadensis, Dactylis glomerata, Elymus virginicus, Hystrix hystrix, Koeleria cristata, Panicularia nervata, and Stipa sp., also reported on Carex, (Seaver)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 80-90 x 1.5-2 um, filiform [threadlike], parallel in ascus, smooth, colorless, "multiply septate, with granular contents"^; asci 8-spored, 80-100 x 6-7 um, iodine-negative, (Breitenbach), spores nearly as long as the ascus, in a close fascicle, about 2 um in diameter, many septate; asci 8-spored, cylindric, very long, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to Typha', perhaps due to the resemblance of the fruitbody to the head of a cattail
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(6) (as Typhodium typhinum)
136
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Erythricium laetum  (P. Karst.) J. Erikss. & Hjortstam^  Svensk bot. Tidskr. 64(2): 166. 1970;  Hyphoderma laeta  P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a bright rose red, loosely attached, resupinate fruitbody with a smooth to wrinkled surface and a white margin, 2) growth on decaying hardwood and surrounding area, often near melting snowbanks, and 3) microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Eriksson(3) except where noted. RANGE ^The distribution in North America includes MI, MT, ND, and NY, (Ginns(5)). It is found also in WA (J. Ginns, pers. comm.). It has been found in Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson). There is a BC collection by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia.
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, loosely attached; bright rose red (fading in the herbarium), margin white; "smooth at least when dry, in the fresh state often irregularly wrinkled, soft and almost athelioid when young, with age membranaceous, when dried brittle"^, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood and branches of hardwoods, but often growing out on dead leaves, wet soil, and so on, "belongs to the rich, moist biotypes with deciduous trees and herbs on mouldy soil", mostly in late fall, winter, and spring, "apparently active fruitbodies can be found under snow-cover"^, (Eriksson, for Europe), on Alnus sp., A. tenuifolia, Betula sp., B. populifolia, Populus sp., mosses, (Ginns(5)), often but not invariably found near receding snowbanks, (J. Ginns, pers. comm.), including large dead herbaceous stems; fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 11-13(15) x 6-7.5 um, mainly elliptic, but varying in shape (oval to oblong), with thickened walls and conspicuous apiculus, spore wall cyanophilic, "The color of the living spore is probably red."^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-50 x 8-12 um, sterigmata curved and a few apically swollen, basidia "varying in shape, clavate, sinuose or somewhat constricted, often basally widened to a suburniform shape"; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, "but hyphae varying in nature in different parts of the fruitbody", in subhymenium, hyphae 2.5-3 um wide, densely interwoven into a ceraceous [waxy] context, thin-walled, the rest of the hyphae forming the main part of the fruitbody wide (up to 10 um or even 15 um wide), "short-celled and branched into a loose context", the hyphal walls somewhat thickened, still more thick-walled are "the straight hyphae that penetrate the context and are mainly found in the margin and next to the substrate", these about 4-9 um wide, with sparse septa and branchings; anastomoses frequent in all parts of the context; clamp connections absent throughout
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bright', 'pleasant'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
137
FAMILY  Auriculariaceae, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Exidiopsis 'calcea'  (Pers.) K. Wells sensu North American authors^  Mycologia 53: 348. 1961 (issued 1962);  Sebacina calcea  (Pers.) Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on wood, 2) an arid-waxy fruitbody, arising in small patches that become continuous; grayish white to ochraceous tawny; pruinose; and with margins somewhat lighter, abrupt at maturity, 3) suballantoid spores, 4) 2-4-spored basidia that are large and guttulate, 5) two types of dikaryophyses, and 6) a subiculum often containing calcareous concretions.^ | This species as described in Wells(4) and Martin, G.W(1) is thought to be an unnamed species and not the same species as Exidiopsis calcea (Pers.) Wells (which is found in Eurasia and is very similar to or possibly identical to E. macrospora (Ell. & Everh.) Martin), (Wells(5)). RANGE ^Exidiopsis 'calcea' has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NS, NT, ON, PE, SK, YT, AK, AZ, CA, FL, GA, IA, IL, LA, ME, MI, MN, MT, NC, NH, NY, and VT, (Ginns). It has been found in MB, SK, north central United States including IA, and IL, (Wells(4)), It occurs from ON, IL, IA, MB, ME to WA, south to FL, (Martin).
FRUITING BODY  arid-waxy, adnate [firmly attached to substrate], "arising in small patches which become confluent to form an irregular crust with somewhat abrupt margins", 0.005-0.02cm thick; grayish white to ochraceous tawny; pruinose; margins somewhat lighter, abrupt at maturity; drying to a dingy pulverulent [powdery] layer; entire hymenium has a yellowish tint when stained with Phloxine and Congo Red^, (Wells(4)), resupinate, arid-waxy, closely adnate, thin (in section 0.005-0.016cm), "arising as minute pruinose patches which by confluence form an irregular subcontinuous crust", up to 5-6 x 1cm, "drying to a very thin pulverulent dingy crust"; grayish white to ochraceous tawny; margin white, (Martin)
HABITAT  on living limbs or on dead barked or barkless wood^, (Wells(4))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 15-22 x (6)7.5-9.5 um, cylindric-curved to suballantoid, granular to guttulate, germinating directly or by repetition^; PROBASIDIA "at first elongate, becoming obovate to ovate", 2-4-spored at maturity, guttulate, 19-27(35) x (12)13-17.5 um, "epibasidia tubular, up to 85 um in length and 3-4 um in width"; FERTILE HYPHAE tortuous, 2-4(5.5) in diameter, bearing basidia in clusters by proliferations through or near clamp connections at the base of the probasidia; DIKARYOPHYSES of 2 types: 1) cylindric to clavate, "arising from the fertile hyphae, frequently septate" with clamp connections, up to 50 um in length and 2-7 um wide, and 2) "simple to little branched, arising from the basal hyphal layer, tortuous, becoming indistinct", 0.5-2.5 um wide, forming a layer 35-75 um above the mature basidia; HYPHAE forming a thin basal layer and "an ascending layer terminating in the fertile hyphae and dikaryophyses"; basal hyphae 1.5-3 um wide, parallel to the substrate in a thin layer, colorless, with clamp connections throughout, becoming indistinct; MINERAL ACCRETIONS often present in the subhymenium, numerous brownish mineral granules in the vicinity of the dikaryophyses and frequently attached to them, (Wells(4)), SPORES 15-22 x 7.5-9.5 um, cylindric, unilaterally flattened or suballantoid; PROBASIDIA "at first oblong, finally ovate or obovate", mostly 19-24 x 13-16.5 um, becoming cruciate-septate, epibasidia cylindric, 3-4 um wide, up to 50 um long; PARAPHYSES [dikaryophyses] of 2 types: 1) 2-3 um wide, "clavate, clamp-bearing, often sparsely branched, arising as proliferations from the bases of the basidia", 2) 1-2 um thick, tortuous, arising from the subiculum; hymenium consisting of sparsely scattered basidia borne terminally on short, erect, fertile hyphae 2-3 um wide, the basidia proliferating from clamp connections at their bases, "and of paraphyses forming a layer 15-40 um above the basidia"; subiculum varying from very thin to 100 um thick, composed of agglutinated hyphae parallel with substrate, often containing 1 or 2 layers of calcareous concretions, (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Exidiopsis macrospora also has an arid-waxy texture, 2 types of dikaryophyses, and a similar form of fertile hyphae, basidia, and basidiospores, but basidiospores of E. macrospora are smaller, and margins of E. macrospora are abrupt and frequently reflexed especially after the specimen has dried (margins of E. calcea are abrupt at maturity), (Wells(4)).
SOURCES  Wells(4), Martin, G.W.(1), Ginns(5) (as Exidiopsis species A), Wells(5) 
138
FAMILY  Auriculariaceae, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Exidiopsis diversa  K. Wells^  Mycologia 79(2): 280. 1987
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on decaying wood of Populus, 2) a waxy to firm gelatinous fruitbody that is colorless to pale grayish or light amber, the surface granulose to pruinose, and the margin tightly attached but not well marked, 3) scattered, subhymenial, white mineral deposits present in some parts, 4) spores that are elliptic to short cylindric curved, 5) basidia that are longitudinally septate, developing on fertile hyphae that proliferate through the subbasidial clamp connection, and 6) sparse dikaryophyses that rarely project beyond the hypobasidial layer.^ RANGE ^The holotype is from BC.
FRUITING BODY  effused (spread out on substrate), waxy to firm gelatinous, in section 0.0045-0.0155cm thick; scattered, subhymenial, white mineral deposits present in some parts; fruiting body drying to a thin varnish-like layer; colorless, grayish colorless to light amber (when soaked), drying to colorless, light gray, to light to dark amber; "granulose with pruinose patches, some parts glistening; surface granulose to pruinose, smooth"; margins adnate [tightly attached], indeterminate [not well marked]^, (Wells)
HABITAT  on decaying wood of Populus sp.^ (Wells)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 10-12.5 x (4.5)5.5-6.5 um, elliptic and laterally depressed to short cylindric curved, guttulate, germination by repetition not observed^; PROBASIDIA (13.5)15-22(24) x (9)10-12(13.5) um distal from clamp connection, enucleate part when present up to 12.5 um and 3-4 um wide, "initially narrow obovate to narrow clavate or pyriform, with basal clamp connection, with (2-)4 segments, often with an enucleate stalk, attached at the morphological base or obliquely to almost laterally attached", epibasidia up to 22 um long, 2-3.5 um wide, "tubular, somewhat flexuous, usually slightly swollen beneath the sterigma"; fertile hyphae (1.5)2.5-4(7) um wide, "flexuous, proliferating through or near the subbasidial clamp"; DIKARYOPHYSES "relatively sparse, rarely projecting beyond the hypobasidial layer", 1-2.5 um wide in apical part, 1.5-5 um wide in basal part, "simple, nodulose to short-branched distally"; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, mainly distinct, with clamp connections; in section "consisting of a compact to loose ascending layer of interwoven hyphae terminating in the hymenium of fertile hyphae and scattered dikaryophyses, basidia in a zone 25-35 um wide", "portions of the substrate and other debris often incorporated within the ascending layer"
NAME ORIGIN  "from 'diversus', referring to the variable morphology of the basidia"^, (Wells)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Wells(2), Ginns(5)
139
FAMILY  Auriculariaceae, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Exidiopsis fuliginea  Rick^  Broteria ser. Bot. 5: 8. 1906;  Sebacina adusta  Burt;  Sebacina variseptata  L.S. Olive
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead wood, often with bark, 2) a waxy to cartilaginous-gelatinous fruitbody that is at first colorless to light yellow, becoming light brown, reddish brown or olive-gray, the surface often grayish-pruinose or whitish-pruinose, the margin tightly attached but not easily apparent, 3) spores that are cylindric to allantoid, 4) the hymenium consisting of a) simple or little branched dikaryophyses that become filled with brown granules eventually left scattered, b) clavate to subcylindric dikaryophyses that are colorless, seldom emergent, and sometimes absent, and c) fertile hyphae that bear longitudinally or obliquely septate basidia, the basidia developing in dense clusters by lateral proliferations through or near conspicuous clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Exidiopsis fuliginea has been found in WA, ID, LA, and FL, (Ginns), and also Belize, Cuba, Brazil, Colombia, (Wells).
FRUITING BODY  widely effused [spread out flat], thin (0.0035-0.0375cm), waxy to cartilaginous-gelatinous; at first colorless to light yellow, "becoming light brown, reddish brown or olive-gray", drying to a yellow, reddish-brown or gray layer; surface often grayish-pruinose or whitish-pruinose, smooth or undulate [wavy], "usually with protruding strands of agglutinate, whitish hyphae", drying vernicose (varnished appearance); margins adnate [tightly attached], indeterminate [not easily apparent], often lighter in color than the rest of the surface^, (Wells)
HABITAT  on dead wood, often with bark^, (Wells), Betula microphylla, Populus deltoides (Eastern Cottonwood), P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Trachycarpus fortunei (Windmill Palm), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock); rotten wood; limb; barkless trunk; dead bases of leaves and fruiting stems of windmill palm, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (8)9-13.5 x (3.5)4-6(7) um, cylindric and laterally depressed to allantoid, often guttulate, capable of germinating by repetition^; PROBASIDIA (9)10-16.5(18) x 8.5-12 um, arising as elongate structures, subtended by clamp connections, becoming clavate, obovate, or ovate, rarely nearly spherical, often guttulate, becoming 2-4-celled by longitudinal to oblique septa, epibasidia up to 30 um in length, 2-3.5 um in diameter, tubular, often flexuous [wavy]; hymenium of 1) simple to little branched dikaryophyses, 2) subcylindric dikaryophyses, and 3) fertile hyphae: the simple to little branched DIKARYOPHYSES 1.5-3 um wide, "somewhat nodulose, becoming filled with brown granules, disintegrating and leaving the granules scattered throughout the hymenium, granulation less often extending into the subhymenial region", the clavate to subcylindric dikaryophyses 25-45 x 8-10 um, often arising from fertile hyphae, colorless, rarely terminating in finely branched tips, seldom emergent, sometimes absent, the fertile hyphae 2.5-4.5 um wide, "bearing basidia in dense clusters by lateral proliferations through or near conspicuous clamp connections"; fruitbody 35-375 um thick in section, "consisting of a basal hyphal layer, ascending hyphal layer which is rarely lacking, and the hymenium", mineral granules often scattered throughout the hymenium and subhymenium, the basal hyphal layer usually dense, parallel with the substrate, becoming indistinct, the ascending hyphal layer "at first distinct, loosely interwoven, becoming indistinct, lacking in thinner specimens", (Wells)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'sooty'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Wells(4), Ginns(5)
140
FAMILY  Auriculariaceae, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Exidiopsis macrospora  (Ellis & Everh.) K. Wells^  Mycologia 53: 351. 1961;  Eichleriella macrospora  (Ellis & Everh.) G.W. Martin;  Sebacina macrospora  (Ellis & Everh.) Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is thin, chalk-white to ochraceous, the older specimens usually with abrupt margins and a tuberculate surface, 3) cylindric-curved spores, 4) obovate basidia that are longitudinally septate, 5) two types of dikaryophyses, 6) clamp connections, and 7) mineral crystals especially in the vicinity of the hymenium.^ RANGE ^Exidiopsis macrospora has been found in BC, NS, ON, CO, FL, IA, OH, MO, NH, NY, TN, TX, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Europe (Wells).
FRUITING BODY  leathery, dry, "at first very thin, whitish to pale drab or dingy ochraceous, orbicular, appressed, with a cottony, concolorous or white margin, becoming broadly expanded by growth and confluence, up to 10cm or more in extent and much thicker, with determinate, reflexed, often subapplanate margins, hymenium at first smooth, then developing scattered, forked or branching spines and tubercles on the surface, ochraceous or brownish, finally shining white when dry, usually with ochraceous or pinkish brown patches"^, (Martin), thin at first, (0.0025)0.006-0.03(0.055)cm thick in section, in scattered patches, coriaceous [leathery], dry, with adnate [firmly attached], fimbriate [fringed] margins, becoming confluent, thicker, and with abrupt margins that may become reflexed [curl back] with drying; "at first pale drab or ochraceous, becoming white with ochraceous patches to chalk-white", dries to ochraceous to shining white layer; at first smooth, often finely pruinose at low magnification, becoming scattered-tuberculate, (Wells)
HABITAT  dead wood or bark attached to tree^, bark of log, limbs, Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Acer negundo (Boxelder), Alnus rugosa var. americana (Speckled Alder), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), P. glauca (White Spruce), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns), dead hardwood, often on limbs still on trees, (Martin), "on dead wood or bark attached to tree", (Wells)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 10-15(17) x 5-7(8) um, suballantoid to ovate^; PROBASIDIA 18-22 x 10-12 um, ovate, often becoming nearly spherical, eventually cruciate-septate or sometimes 2-celled, epibasidia up to 20 um or more long, 2-3.5 um wide, coarse; "slender, tortuous, sparsely branched paraphyses, together with clavate and often septate paraphyses arising from the same hyphae as the basidia and with a clamp-connection at the septum, the tips of the slender paraphyses forming an agglutinated layer 20-40 um thick above the basidia"; in section, very thin to 300(450) um thick, consisting of a horizontal layer of interwoven hyphae parallel with the substrate, (at first colorless, then brown), an intermediate layer of gelatinized hyphae, (often calcareous), and a rather wide hymenial zone of closely aggregated basidia and paraphyses, (Martin), SPORES 10-15(17) x 5-7.5(8) um, usually cylindric-curved, guttulate, "germinating by formation of germination tube or by repetition"; hymenium consists of fertile hyphae and two types of dikaryophyses: fertile hyphae 2-5 um wide, toruloid, forming basidia in clusters by lateral proliferation through or near subbasidial clamp connections, probasidia arising as elongate structures becoming ovate, obovate or almost subspherical with 2 or 4 longitudinal septa, guttulate, 15-22 x 8-14 um, epibasidia 2-4(5) um wide, up to 75 um long; DIKARYOPHYSES of two types: a) slender ones 1.5-4(5) um wide, "simple to little branched, usually nodulose, becoming indistinct", forming a well-defined layer 20-75 um thick above the mature basidia, b) subcylindric septate dikaryophyses 35-70 x 3.5-10 um, cylindric (or sometimes clavate or subfusiform), flexuous [wavy], colorless, apparently arising from the fertile hyphae; basal layer of hyphae 2.5-4 um wide, becoming yellowish and somewhat thick-walled, with clamp connections, either parallel with substrate or interwoven and ascending, superficial to that an ascending interwoven layer of indistinct toruloid hyphae 2.5-4(6) um wide, with clamp connections, terminating in the hymenium; mineral granules usually abundant throughout, often very abundant in vicinity of hymenium, (Wells)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with large spores'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Exidiopsis 'calcea'.
SOURCES  Martin, G.W.(1), Wells(4), Ginns(5)
141
FAMILY  Auriculariaceae, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Exidiopsis paniculata  K. Wells & Bandoni^  Mycologia 79(2): 283. 1987
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on decaying wood (of black locust), 2) a waxy gelatinous fruitbody that is light grayish white, bruising dark buff, the surface pruinose to granulose, and the margin tightly attached but not easily apparent, 3) allantoid spores, 4) basidia that are longitudinally septate, developing on fertile hyphae that proliferate through the subbasidial clamp connection, and 5) a hymenium that consists of a zone of basidia below a rather distinct layer of dikaryophyses.^ RANGE ^The holotype is from BC.
FRUITING BODY  effused [spread out flat over the wood], in section 0.008-0.035cm thick, waxy gelatinous; light grayish-white (when soaked), bruising dark buff, fruiting body drying to a light gray to very light buff to almost pure white at margins; surface pruinose to granulose, relatively smooth, drying varnish-like, margins adnate [tightly attached] and indeterminate [not easily apparent], usually lighter than the rest of the surface, and sometimes colorless; surface and margins sometimes glistening, sometimes cracking^, (Wells)
HABITAT  on fallen, dead, barked branch of Robinia pseudoacacia (black locust)^, (Wells)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (13.5)14.5-20(22) x (5.5)6-8(9) um, cylindric curved to allantoid, guttulate, capable of germinating by repetition^; "hymenium consisting of a zone of basidia below a rather distinct layer of dikaryophyses"; PROBASIDIA formed in a zone 30-55 um wide, (15)16-25(26.5) x 12.5-17(22) um, "ovate, obovate to clavate, less often ovate or pyriform, at times irregular, with basal clamp, with (2-)4 segments, guttulate", epibasidia up to 50 um long, 3-5.5(7) um wide, tubular to flexuous [wavy] or almost nodulose; fertile hyphae 2-5 um wide, "nodulose to flexuous, forming clusters of basidia by proliferating through or near subbasidial clamp connections", dikaryophyses rather abundant, forming a well-defined layer 18-45 um tall above the hypobasidia, 1-2 um wide near apices, 1.5-4 um wide in basal part, distinct, "usually distinctly short-branched distally, less often with short, nodulose lateral branches, often irregular in diam to nodulose", "apparently originating from the fertile hyphae, with a basal clamp"; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE relatively distinct, 2-5 um wide, colorless, with clamp connections, "becoming slightly thick-walled and devoid of contents adjacent to the substrate"; fruitbody in section "consisting of a basal layer of closely interwoven hyphae becoming ascending in the subhymenial zone, in places erupting through the substrate then ascending to the hymenium, or with basal hyphae parallel to the substrate and ascending to the hymenium, portions of the substrate and other debris, including hyphae and spores of other fungi, often included in the subhymenial zones", (Wells)
NAME ORIGIN  "from paniculatus, referring to the branching dikaryophyses that form a distinct layer above the hypobasidia"^, (Wells)
SIMILAR  An unnamed species of Exidiopsis which has been known incorrectly as Exidiopsis calcea (Pers.) Wells or Sebacina calcea (Pers.) Bres. has been recorded from BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NS, NT, ON, PE, SK, YT, AK, AZ, CA, FL, GA, IA, IL, LA, ME, MI, MN, MT, NC, NH, NY, and VT, (Ginns).
SOURCES  Wells(2), Ginns(5)
142
FAMILY  Auriculariaceae, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Exidiopsis plumbescens  (Burt) K. Wells^  Lloydia 20: 53. 1957;  Sebacina plumbescens  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on decaying hardwood, 2) a waxy-gelatinous fruitbody that is colorless to light gray or buff or nearly white, usually with a faint pinkish tinge, the surface granulose to pruinose, and the margin tightly attached but not easily apparent, 3) allantoid spores, 4) basidia that are longitudinally septate, developing on fertile hyphae that proliferate through the subbasidial clamp connection, 5) a hymenium that consists of a zone of basidia below a layer of dikaryophyses that are simple to sparingly long-branched, nodulose to short-branched apically.^ RANGE ^Collections of Exidiopsis plumbescens were examined from BC, WA, OR, and CA, (Wells). It has been found in NB, NS, ON, GA, IA, and LA, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  "spreading to form a thin, effused layer or arising as erumpent, hemispherical pustules that become confluent to form a continuous resupinate layer" up to several centimeters long, consistency soft to firm waxy-gelatinous, in section 0.0035-0.078cm thick; colorless to light gray or buff, or nearly white, usually with faint pinkish tinge, drying to nearly colorless, light to dark amber, or bluish-gray in strongly pruinose forms, sometimes light buff in thicker specimens; smooth to undulate (wavy), under the lens granulose to strongly pruinose, drying to a vernicose [varnish-like] layer, sometimes with scattered white mineral nodules; margin adnate [tightly attached], indeterminate [not distinct], thin to abrupt^, (Wells)
HABITAT  on decaying hardwood^, (Wells), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Arctostaphylos manzanita (Manzanita), Betula (birch), Fraxinus (ash), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Umbellularia californica (California laurel), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (10.5)12.5-19(21) x (4.5)5-6.5(7.5) um, cylindric-curved to allantoid, guttulate, capable of germinating by repetition^; PROBASIDIA at first cylindric or broadly clavate, "proliferating through or near subbasidial clamps", hypobasidia with distinct basal clamp, forming (2)4 hypobasidial segments, "becoming oval, ovate, obovate to clavate, less often subglobose, very rarely pyriform with enucleate stalk", (11.5)12.5-20(24) x (9.5)10.5-16 um, epibasidia 10-87.5 x (2)2.5-4.5 um (when mature), "tubular to flexuous, usually enlarging apically, sometimes becoming delimited from hypobasidial segments"; cystidioles sparse to absent, 24-85.5 x 2.5-8(9.5) um, subcylindric, subfusiform, subclavate, or flexuous [wavy], sometimes branching apically, thin-walled with staining contents, intergrading with simple dikaryophyses; probasidia and hypobasidia forming a well-defined zone 25-50 um thick and covered by a zone of dikaryophyses (9)12-30 um thick; DIKARYOPHYSES 1-2.5(5) um in diameter, "simple to sparingly long-branched, nodulose to short-branched apically, usually distinct"; fertile hyphae 2-5 um in diameter, "sometimes branching, giving rise to both basidia and dikaryophyses"; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE (1.5)2-4(5.5) um wide, "usually distinct, with clamps; thin-walled, infrequently becoming slightly thick-walled adjacent to the substrate"; in section fruitbody "consisting of a loose, ascending hyphal layer arising directly from the substrate" and terminating in the hymenium; "mineral accumulations present or absent in the trama, portions of the substrate sometimes incorporated in the ascending layer", (Wells)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming like lead'
SIMILAR  Exidiopsis effusa is not necessarily similar but appears in Germany to be the fungus associated with the hair-ice phenomenon (Hofmann(1)). Hair ice occurs in the Pacific Northwest at least in Washington, but the associated fungus has not been proven.
SOURCES  Wells(3), Ginns(5), Hofmann(1) (re Exidiopsis effusa)
143
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Fibricium lapponicum  J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 114. 1958
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Fibricium lapponicum is recognized by "fibrous skeletal hyphae together with encrusted cystidia". Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) cream to pale ochraceous smooth spore-bearing surface, and a fibrillose margin with small rhizomorphs, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid with oil droplets or inclusions, 4) cystidia that are numerous in some mature specimens, thick-walled, tapering to a blunt apex, encrusted when fully developed, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the skeletal hyphae fibrous and the generative hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^It has been found in BC (Wells Gray National Park), Sweden, and Finland, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, membranaceous; cream to pale ochraceous; mostly smooth; margin more or less fibrillose, with small rhizomorphs, which can also be found in the wood; in cross-section under a hand lens the hymenium-subhymenium and the subiculum are visible as two separate layers^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on much decayed wood of conifers: Pinus sylvestris (Scotch Pine) and Picea abies (Norway Spruce)^, (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-6.5 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, with oil droplets or irregular oily inclusions^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 5-6 um, when young some may be longer (to 40-45 um); CYSTIDIA few or rare when young, numerous in some mature specimens, 40-70 x 7-11 um, "tapering to the obtuse apex, with thickened walls, encrusted when fully developed"; HYPHAE dimitic: generative hyphae 2.5-4 um wide, thin-walled, richly branched, with anastomoses and with clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 1.5-2.5 um wide, thick-walled, without branches and clamp connections, subhymenium "composed of densely joined generative hyphae, subiculum mainly of abundant skeletal hyphae"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Lappland'
SIMILAR  Fibricium rude has smaller spores and cystidia that are not encrusted (the cystidia may have a cap of non-crystalline substance that is dissolved in KOH), (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(3)
144
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Fibricium rude  (P. Karst.) Julich^  Persoonia 8: 81. 1974;  == Corticium rude  P. Karst.;  Fibricium greschikii  (Bres.) J. Erikss.;  Peniophora greschikii  (Bres.) Bourdot & Galzin;  Peniophora alba  Burt;  Peniophora subcremea  Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a white or creamy white spore-bearing surface, the margin with small rhizomorphs, 3) spores that are narrowly elliptic to cylindric, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) cystidia that are tapering, obtuse, thin-walled, with or without a globular cap that dissolves in mounting media, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the generative hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Fibricium rude has been found in BC, WA, ID, MB, NS, ON, AK, AZ, CO, MI, MT, NM, NY, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Europe including Scandinavia, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, membranaceous, firmly attached; white or creamy white; generally smooth, cracked when dry and old; margin "thinning out, often with small rhizomorphs" which also occur in the wood^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on coniferous wood and hardwood^, (bark and wood; twigs; needles; slash), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), A. concolor, Alnus oblongifolia (Arizona alder), A. rubra (Red Alder), Amelanchier alnifolia (Saskatoon serviceberry), Juglans major (Arizona Walnut), Juniperus sp. (juniper), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), P. sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), P. ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus sp., Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Symphoricarpos occidentalis (western snowberry), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on "a wide variety of substrates but no doubt most common on coniferous wood", (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 1.2-2 um, narrowly elliptic to subcylindric, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-17 x 3-5 um, clavate; CYSTIDIA 45-60 x 5-7 um, "obtuse, thinwalled, generally tapering, rarely cylindrical", apical part looks different from the basal part (especially in phase contrast, where apical part refractive), and may also have a globular cap of non-crystalline substance that is easily dissolved in KOH and other mounting media; HYPHAE dimitic: generative hyphae 2.5-3.5 um wide, thin-walled, richly branched, with anastomoses and clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 1.5-2 um wide, thick-walled, without branches or clamp connections, subhymenium "of densely joined generative hyphae, subiculum of generative hyphae mixed with skeletal hyphae", (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5.5 x 2-2.5 um, short-cylindric; CYSTIDIA 55-85 x 5-7 um, projecting to 50 um, fusoid, (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'rough, raw, wild'
SIMILAR  Fibricium lapponicum is rare, and has larger spores and encrusted cystidia (cystidia of Fibricium rude may have a cap of non-crystalline substance that is dissolved in KOH), (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(3), Martin, K.J.(3), Ginns(5)
145
FAMILY  Sirobasidiaceae, Order Tremellales, Class Tremellomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Fibulobasidium sirobasidioides  Bandoni^  Can. J. Bot. 76: 1540. (1999) [1998]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include cushion-shaped, colorless to whitish fruitbodies that coalesce into flattened layers under the bark of Acer macrophyllum (Big-leaf Maple). It is microscopically characterized by the production of basidia in chains, each basidium in the chain arising through enlargement and transformation of a clamp connection.^ RANGE ^The holotype is from BC.
FRUITING BODY  pulvinate, aggregated, eventually coalescing, eventually appearing effused, maximum size seen about 6cm long, 1.5cm wide, and 0.05cm thick, gelatinous, outer surface flattened by pressure of adjacent bark; colorless to whitish, "deliquescing in age, then brownish", "drying to an inconspicuous, hyaline or brownish, vernicose film"
HABITAT  "Specimens were collected by stripping slightly loosened bark of fallen branches and trunks" of Acer macrophyllum (Big-leaf Maple), "(generally recently fallen, windblown branches or trunks with insect damage, the bark mostly sound and still attached to the wood in areas other than those immediately surrounding the basidiomata)."; fruitbodies subcortical [under bark], "on recently dead branches or trunks, typically associated with unidentified dark stromata and adjacent to bark beetle tunnels"
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-18 x (4)5-7 um, "fusiform to slightly rhomboid, bluntly pointed distally, truncate at the base", sessile, "sometimes abruptly enlarged near the base and contracted near the apex", germinating by budding^; mature basidia (2-)4-celled, 13-17 x 11-14 um, spherical to nearly spherical, ellipsoid or ovoid, basidium production starts at about 20 um above the substrate in some short fertile hyphae, but others extend to 100 um or more with few or no branches, before growth is terminated by a basidium (basidia are thus produced at all levels within the fruitbody), "after the first basidium develops, subsequent basidia in a chain develop by direct swelling of successively produced basal clamps", each chain having 3-12 basidia, "those in a chain closely appressed and strongly adherent, sometimes more or less retaining the clamp form until near maturity", the spores produced terminally on the terminal basidium in the chain, but laterally on the others; hyphae 2-4 um wide, slightly swollen basally, not compactly arranged, with infrequent branches, arising from prostrate hyphae on the substrate or directly from the substrate, parallel to each other and directed away from the substrate; clamp connections infrequent apart from those associated with basidium development
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like Sirobasidium'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Bandoni(11)
146
FAMILY  Pterulaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Flavophlebia sulfureoisabellina  (Litsch.) K.H. Larss. & Hjortstam^  Mycotaxon 5: 475. 1977;  == Corticium sulfureoisabellinum  Litsch. in Pilat;  Phlebia sulfureoisabellina  (Litsch.) Parmasto;  Cerocorticium sulfureoisabellinum  (Litsch.) Julich & Stalpers, Verh. K. ned. Akad. Wet., tweede sect. 74: 71 (1980) (proposed combination)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on fir, 2) a waxy fruitbody colored yellowish but becoming ochraceous or pale brown, the surface smooth but cracking when old, 3) smooth, inamyloid, and colorless spores that are oblong to nearly round with a sublateral apiculus and oily substance dispersed in the protoplasm, 4) clavate 4-spored basidia, 5) filiform hyphidia, 6) cystidia that are usually enclosed, and 7) a monomitic hyphae system, the individual hyphae with clamp connections and indistinct.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed October 6, 2018 and September 12, 2022, listed the current name as Cerocorticium sulfureoisabellinum, but MycoBank, accessed on the same dates, listed the current name as Flavophlebia sulfureoisabellina. RANGE ^It has been found in BC, NS, ON, PQ, MN, and NH, (Ginns), Austria, France, Poland, and not uncommon in Carpathian Mountains, (Hjortstam), and Czechoslovakia (Jackson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], at first thin but thickening when old, ceraceous [waxy], smooth at first but cracking when old; yellowish becoming ochraceous or pale brown; margin indistinct^, (Hjortstam), broadly and irregularly effused, 0.005-0.009cm thick, adnate [tightly attached], at first soft ceraceous, subgelatinous, becoming indurated, thinly crustaceous, or submembranous; at first sulphurous or somewhat dingy yellowish, becoming cream, creamy-alutaceous or isabelline to cinnamon buff; smooth, bald, continuous, when old often cracked; margin gradually thinning out, (Jackson)
HABITAT  on Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir)^, (Ginns), in Europe on Abies (Hjortstam)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-8 x 5-6 um, oblong, nearly round or rarely round, with distinct sublateral apiculus, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, with oily substance dispersed in the protoplasm^; BASIDIA 4-spored, terminal, 20-30 x 6-8 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 50-80 x 6 um, enclosed or slightly projecting, cylindric or subfusiform, thin-walled; HYPHAE monomitic, individual hyphae mostly indistinct, 2-2.5 um wide, thin-walled, those of the subhymenium sparsely branched, all hyphae with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 5-8 x 5-6 um, HYPHIDIA found in genus are filiform, some weakly branched, (Ginns(23)), SPORES 5.5-7 x 5-6 um, round or nearly round, slightly compressed laterally with distinct apiculus, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, multiguttulate or uniguttulate; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-40 x 7-8.5 um, "broadly clavate, tapering from slender hyphal base", sterigmata 8-10 um long, subulate, somewhat arcuate or nearly straight; PARAPHYSES in hymenium "hyphal-like, flexuous, branching, tortuous to subclavate"; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 35-75 x 5.5-8 um, cylindric to subclavate, flexuous [wavy]; "subiculum somewhat indistinct, basal hyphae horizontal, conglutinate, vertical hyphae densely entangled, with clamps at septa, wall thin becoming collapsed and indistinct", (Jackson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'sulphureous - isabelline' referring to its color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(3), Jackson(3), Ginns(5), Ginns(23)
147
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Galzinia incrustans  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Parmasto^  Izv. Akad. Nauk Estonsk. SSR, Ser. Biol. 14: 225. 1965;  == Corticium incrustans  Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Corticium roseopallens  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on barkless, rotten hardwood, 2) a watery grayish color often with tint of pink or lilac, 3) waxy consistency, 4) spores that are allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) basidia that are more or less constricted, sometimes the basidia developing inside old basidia (internal basidial repetition), 6) absent cystidia, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Galzinia incrustans has been found in BC, ID, ON, PQ, IA, LA, MA, MD, ME, MN, MO, NY, WI, and VT, (Ginns), and Sweden and Norway, (Eriksson). The distribution includes Europe including Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin, mainly about 0.005cm thick; "watery grayish, often with a tint of rose or violaceous"; smooth, ceraceous [waxy] when fresh and wet, pruinose when dry; margin indeterminate [indistinct]^, (Eriksson), resupinate, "forming inconspicuous isolated spots or continuous thin patches several centimeters across", tightly attached, waxy, soft; gray-ocherish with lilac to pink tint; uneven, slightly undulating-tuberculate, ocher-farinose; margin indistinctly farinose [mealy], (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on barkless decayed wood, mainly hardwood, generally in wet localities^, (Eriksson), on barkless rotten hardwood lying on the ground, (Breitenbach), Acer sp. (maple), Alnus sp. (alder), Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Fagus sp. (beech), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Quercus sp. (oak), Salix sp. (willow), Ulmus americana (American Elm), Phellinus sp., (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6 x 1.5-2.5 um, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 4-5 um, subcylindric, more or less constricted, internal basidial repetition observed in a few basidia; CYSTIDIA "normally none, but thinwalled, projecting cystidia-like organs are found in one specimen"; HYPHAE monomitic 2.5-3.5 um wide, walls thin or somewhat thickened, richly branched, clamp connections at all septa, (Eriksson), SPORES 5.5-7 x 2-3 um, cylindric, curved, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 17-27 x 3-4.5 um, cylindric-clavate, young basidia develop in some of the old, mostly somewhat collapsed basidia (internal repetition), best observed under phase contrast; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 2-3 um wide, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'encrusting'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
148
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Galzinia pedicellata  Bourdot^  Assoc. Franc. Avancem. Sci. (Rouen) 45: 578. 1922
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a thin fruitbody with a gelatinous consistency (like one of the flat jelly fungi), a hygrophanous grayish or bluish color, and an indistinct margin, 3) allantoid, inamyloid spores, 4) distinctive basidia, 5) absent cystidia, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae thin-walled, with numerous oil droplets in the protoplasm, richly branched from or close to clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Galzinia pedicellata has been found in OR, PA, (Ginns(5)), in Sweden rarely, (Eriksson), and in France (Bourdot).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin, gelatinous; hygrophanous, watery grayish or bluish; when dry pruinose or almost invisible; margin indeterminate [indistinct]^, (Eriksson), spread out, thin, interrupted, "muqueux"; hyaline gray, then glazed fuscescent on drying, or invisible, (Bourdot)
HABITAT  on very decayed wood, found only once in Scandinavia, on felled birch trunk, (Eriksson), under partly detached bark of rotten branches of Pinus sylvestris (Scotch Pine), April to June, (Bourdot), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus pungens (Table Mountain Pine); barkless, partly decayed logs, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-11 x 2-3 um, allantoid, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA normally 4-spored, varying from 15-80 um long, 5-6 um wide at apex, 2.5-4 um at narrowest part, "first rounded, vesicular, then extended, tube-like, sinuose, apically widened", pleurobasidia frequent [relatively broad at base and with bifurcated spreading roots, as if growing from side of hypha constituting the roots]; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, with numerous oil droplets in protoplasm, with clamp connections, richly branched from or close to clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 8-10 x 3-4 um, curved subcylindric, with oil droplets; PROBASIDIA ovoid or flattened ovoid, 7-12 x 4.5-6 um, giving off from the top (or sometimes laterally) a filament which bears the basidium, slender, 15-60 x 1.5-2 um; hyphae 2-4 um wide, thin-walled, with scattered clamp connections, (Bourdot), SPORES 8-11 x 2-4 um, basidial repetition occurring [new basidia sometimes developing inside old ones], (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with a small foot or stem'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3), Bourdot(1), Ginns(5), Ginns(23)
149
FAMILY  Pterulaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Globulicium hiemale  (Laurila) Hjortstam^  Svensk Bot. Tidskr. 67: 109. 1973;  == Corticium hiemale  Laurila;  Aleurodiscus hiemalis  (Laurila) J. Erikss.;  Radulomyces hiemalis  (Laurila) Parmasto;  Corticium probatum  H.S. Jacks.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) thin fruitbodies, usually in roundish patches, with a waxy consistency, a whitish to cream color, and a smooth surface, 3) spores that are round to nearly round, smooth, and inamyloid, the wall somewhat cyanophilic, 4) large basidia with oil droplets, 5) numerous paraphysoid hyphae in the hymenium, 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, and 7) in older specimens crystalline matter.^ RANGE ^Globulicium hiemale has been found in OR, MB, ON, and AK, (Ginns(5)), as well as in Europe including Sweden and "the whole conifer region of Scandinavia", (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, circular, sometimes confluent but usually of small dimensions (some square centimeters), thin (mostly about 0.01cm), ceraceous [waxy]; whitish to cream; smooth; margin variable: distinct to indistinct, but mostly indistinct, pruinose to finely fibrillose under 50x lens^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  normally on barkless conifer wood, only rarely seen on hardwood^ (e.g. Salix [willow]), (Eriksson), on Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES round to nearly round, 9-14 in diameter, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, with oil droplets in protoplasm, wall stains somewhat in cotton blue^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (40)50-60(80) x 10-15 um, clavate at first, later often prolonged, subcylindric, often constricted or sinuose, sterigmata stout, basidia with many small oil droplets, later confluent to fewer larger droplets; CYSTIDIA none, PARAPHYSOID HYPHAE (= hyphal cystidia) numerous in hymenium, 50-70 x 1.5-3 um, little projecting above basidia, often with a rounded, head-like apex [like a long balloon], rarely with few branches, in old specimens they are +/- encrusted with needle-like crystals, "lying parallel to the hyphae or forming sheaf- or star-like apical crystal groups", crystal stars also found in hyphal context, at least when young paraphysoids have dense protoplasm that is very refractive under phase contrast microscope; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae about 1.5-2.5 um, thin-walled, richly branched, with occasional anastomoses, clamp connections at all septa, subicular layer mostly thin (10-30 um), old specimens with abundant crystalline matter in context, (Eriksson), hyphae 1.5-3.0 um wide, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of winter'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3), Ginns(5), Ginns(23)
150
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloeocystidiellum clavuligerum  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Nakasone^  Mycotaxon 14: 320. 1982;  == Gloeocystidium clavuligerum  Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Corticium vesiculosum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) a waxy to membranous fruitbody that is well attached, often layered, pale to distinctly yellow, becoming tan when old, and smooth or with small scattered warts, the margin indistinct, pruinose to mealy, and white to pallid, 3) spores that are elliptic to nearly round, warted (but sometimes appearing smooth), amyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia often in multiple layers, 5) gloeocystidia that are numerous, embedded, flask-shaped with elongated neck, or tubular to fusoid, sulfo-positive or not, often with secondary septa, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, OR, ON, PQ, AK, AZ, CO, CT, IL, LA, ME, MI, MN, MS, NM, NY, and WI, and it has also been reported from MA and WY, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], rather large (the pieces seen up to 10cm x 3cm and 0.009-0.026cm thick), crustose, often stratose [layered]; "pale yellow or pastel yellow, or some with a tan tint"; "smooth, cracked extensively in some specimens"; margin sparse, indistinct, 0.1(0.2)cm wide, white to pallid; "subiculum thin, white"^, (Ginns), annual, effused [spread out flat], sometimes occurring as small patches, up to 15cm x 4cm, 0.03-0.04cm thick, ceraceous [waxy] to membranous, adherent; "light buff" to "pinkish buff", older areas "light ochraceous-salmon" or "tawny-olive"; smooth with small scattered warts, often cracking; margin abrupt or gradually thinning out, colored as the spore-bearing surface, pruinose to farinaceous, (Nakasone), pale to distinctly yellow, becoming tan when old; often stratified with several basidial layers, subiculum very thin, (Stalpers)
HABITAT  on barkless branches on the ground and logs, associated with a white rot of hardwoods^, but reported once on Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce) and once on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir): on Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Acer saccharum (Sugar Maple), Alnus crispa (Green Alder), Alnus rubra (Red Alder), Corylus rostrata (Beaked Hazel), Fagus grandifolia (American Beech), Fraxinus nigra (Black Ash), Ostrya virginiana (Eastern Hophornbeam), Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Quercus alba (White Oak), Tilia americana (American Basswood), Ulmus americana (American Elm), (Ginns), associated with a white rot of barkless hardwood slash and logs, rarely on coniferous wood, (Nakasone)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.8-4.8(5.0) x (2.6)2.8-3.2(3.4) um, verrucose (sometimes appearing smooth), amyloid, colorless, thin-walled, with a small, blunt apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 17-24 x 4 um (but 30-35 um long in one specimen), cylindric; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 40-75 x 6-12 um (but 140-230 x 13-22 in the specimen with long basidia), typically flask-shaped with an elongated neck, "others tubular to fusoid, sulfo-positive in about one-third of the collections"; HYPHAE monomitic; subiculum "typically a very thin, indistinct layer next to the substrate", however as the fruitbodies thicken "a horizontally arranged hyphal layer develops over the surface of the current hymenium and it gives rise to the new basidial layer"; hyphae 2-3 um wide, with clamp connection at each septum, colorless, inamyloid, and thin-walled, (Ginns(24)), SPORES 4.5-5.5(6) x 3.5-4(4.5) um, elliptic to nearly round, asperulate, amyloid, colorless, acyanophilic, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 5-6.5 um, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connection at base; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA numerous, arising in hymenium, embedded, (40)55-85(100) x 6-12(16) um, lageniform to obclavate, colorless, thin-walled or walls slightly thickened at basal end, clamped at base, "blue-black in sulfobenzaldehyde, apex usually moniliform or constricted to form a bulb, often developing secondary septa"; "subhymenial trama thickening, consisting primarily of pseudocystidia, indistinct, compact hyphae, and numerous basidiospores"; HYPHAE monomitic, subiculum very thin, not well differentiated, SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2-4 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, nodose-septate [septa with clamp connections], frequently branched, (Nakasone), SPORES 3.8-4.8(5) x (2.6) 2.8-3.5 um, nearly round to ellipsoid, distinctly warty; BASIDIA 17-35 x 4-5 um; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 40-75 x 6-12 um, cylindric to fusiform, sometimes swollen at the base, sulfobenzaldehyde reaction +/-, no hyphidia; no gloeoplerous hyphae, GENERATIVE HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, somewhat agglutinated, (Stalpers)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing small club', likely referring to pseudocystidia
SIMILAR  Gloeocystidiellum porosum is inseparable macroscopically, but has elliptic to cylindric spores, and grows on bark of dead twigs and branches in the ground, (Ginns(24)). G. porosum has spores that are less broad in relation to length, (Stalpers). Gloeocystidiellum luridum, G. leucoxanthum, Gloiothele lactescens, and Conferticium ochraceum have smooth spores, and the last two lack clamp connections, (Eriksson(3)). Conferticium ravum lacks clamp connections, (Eriksson(3)).
SOURCES  Ginns(24), Nakasone(6) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Stalpers(3), Eriksson(3) (discussing some similar species)
151
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloeocystidiellum leucoxanthum  (Bres.) Boidin^  Compt. Rend. Hebd. Seances Acad. Sci. 233: 825. 1951;  == Corticium leucoxanthum  Bres.;  Megalocystidium leucoxanthum  (Bres.) Julich
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood of a firmly attached fruitbody that is whitish to ocher-brown color with a smooth to tuberculate surface, 2) oblong to suballantoid, smooth, amyloid spores, 3) basidia narrowing in the basal direction, 4) paraphysoid hyphae often between the basidia, 5) tubular gloeocystidia with granular, oily, yellowish contents, 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, and 7) crystals in the trama of old fruitbodies.^ | The name Megalocystidium leucoxanthum (Bres.) Julich is accepted by Ginns(24), but Stalpers(2) still called it Gloeocystidiellum leucoxanthum, as did the online Species Fungorum, accessed May 31, 2016. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, ON, YT, AK, AZ, CA, CO, MN, MT, NH, and WI, (Ginns(24)). It has been found in Europe including Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and central Europe, (Eriksson), and including France (Bourdot).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [tightly attached] or when old detachable in pieces, at first thin but thickening (up to 0.1cm), orbicular [circular] at first but soon becoming confluent; whitish to creamish pale, then melleo-ochraceous [honey-ochraceous] to isabel-colored [pale tan] or light ocher-brown; at first smooth but becoming uneven to conspicuously tuberculate and deeply rimose [cracked]; margin byssoid [cottony] when young, not especially differentiated when mature or old^, (Eriksson), effused, up to 30cm x 5cm and up to 0.05cm thick, ceraceous [waxy], "pinkish buff", "cinnamon buff", to "clay color" when dry, "smooth to strongly tuberculate, not cracked or cracked extensively exposing the nearly white subiculum"; margin abrupt to slightly pruinose, whitish or colored as the rest of the surface, up to 0.1cm wide, (Ginns(24)), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  typically on bark and wood of twigs, branches, and small stems, up to 3cm wide, lying on the ground, predominantly on amentiferous hosts, especially Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Quercus (oak), Populus, and Salix(willow), one report on conifer wood^; associated with a white rot, (Ginns(24)), on hardwoods, recorded on Acer saccharum (Sugar Maple), Alnus rugosa var. americana (Speckled Alder), A. sinuata (Sitka Alder), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), (needs confirmation), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Quercus chrysolepis (Canyon Live Oak), Q. hypoleucoides (Silverleaf Oak), Q. garryana (Oregon White Oak), associated with a white rot, (Ginns(5)), in subalpine habits, especially on Alnus viridis (Green Alder) (central Europe), or dead branches of Salix (willow) (Scandinavia), the former tending to have longer spores (15-20 um), and the latter tending to have shorter spores (12-15 um), other substrates include Alnus glutinosa (European Alder), Populus tremula (European Aspen), Corylus (hazel); when growing on barked branches "appearing through the lenticells and other holes in the bark", (Eriksson), probably all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 12-20 x 4.5-7 um, oblong to suballantoid, adaxial side somewhat concave, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA normally 4-spored, 40-60 x 6-8 um, clavate, narrowing toward base, with basal clamp connection; paraphysoid hyphae frequently occurring between the basidia; GLOEOCYSTIDIA (= pseudocystidia) numerous, 100-150 x 8-15 um, shorter when young, occasionally broader ones can be found, tubular, sinuose, contents granular, oily, yellowish in water and KOH, often with moniliform apical appendices; HYPHAE monomitic 2-3.5 um wide, "with thin or somewhat thickened walls", with clamp connections, BASAL HYPHAE forming layer about 100 um thick "of irregularly intertwined hyphal branches in a rather loose tissue, subhymenial trama denser; old fruitbodies with plenty of crystals in the trama context", (Eriksson), SPORES (12.8)15.2-17.6(21.0) x 4.5-7.0 um, elliptic to suballantoid, smooth, amyloid, easily collapsed, with distinct, blunt apiculus; BASIDIA 4-spored, 45-65 x 5.0-7.5 um, clavate, sterigmata up to 5.0 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 60-160 x 10-16 um, "cylindric to subfusoid, some with constrictions and some with a bulb at the apex, the walls thin to 0.5 um thick, the contents yellow in KOH, granular, sulfo-negative, but many appear to be empty"; HYPHIDIA scattered, 2-2.6 um wide, filiform, simple, projecting up to 16 um; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-5.0(5.5) um wide, "with clamp connections, the walls thin, distinct, forming a loosely interwoven to compact, distinct, parallel layer about 50-100 um thick next to substrate"; marginal hyphae weakly amyloid en masse; gloeoplerous hyphae in margin, (Ginns(24))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white-yellow'
SIMILAR  Megalocystidium montanum has finely verrucose spores measuring (8.4)9.6-12.0(14.0) x (4.0)4.4-5.6(6.0) um that are elliptic, with warts 0.2 um tall and 0.2-0.3 um wide, (Ginns(24)). The European species Gloeocystidiellum luridum (also known as Megalocystidium luridum) has elliptic spores measuring 8-10 um long, (Eriksson). Spores of G. luridum are 7-10(12) um long, (Ginns(24)). Gloeocystidiellum porosum and G. clavuligerum have verrucose spores, (Eriksson). Gloiothele lactescens, Conferticium ochraceum, and Conferticium ravum lack clamp connections and the last has verrucose spores (although the ornamentation is not easy to see), (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Ginns(24) (as Megalocystidium leucoxanthum, colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Eriksson(3), Bourdot(1) (as Gloeocystidium), Ginns(5), Stalpers(2), Buczacki(1)* (as Megalocystidium leucoxanthum)
152
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloeocystidiellum porosum  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Donk^  Medd. Nedl. Mycol. Ver. 18-20: 156. 1931;  == Corticium porosum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis in Berk. & Broome;  Corticium pruni  Overh.;  Corticium stramineum  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth in thin flat waxy to membranous patches on wood, 2) whitish to light ocher color, 3) a smooth to sparsely tuberculate surface, 4) elliptic, verrucose, amyloid spores, 5) sulfovanillin positive gloeocystidia with granular contents, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Collections of Gloeocystidiellum porosum were examined from BC, ON, PQ, AZ, CT, IL, MI, MN, NH, NM, NY, NC, OH, and the United Kingdom, and it was also reported from WA, OR, AB, MB, NB, AK, CA, CO, GA, IA, MA, MD, ME, MT, NJ, PA, TN, VT, and WI, (Ginns). It occurs in Europe including "all parts of Scandinavia" (Eriksson). It also occurs in Switzerland, and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], forming thin, soft, waxy, membranous patches several centimeters across, tightly attached; whitish to cream or light ocher; dull, smooth to sparsely tuberculate, when dry with fissures; "margin distinctly bounded to diffuse"^, (Breitenbach), effused, rather large, the largest piece seen 8cm x 4cm, 0.007-0.035cm thick, orbicular [circular] soon coalescing; ceraceous [waxy], "cream-buff" to "pale ochraceous-buff", "light ochraceous-buff" or "ochraceous-buff" when dry; "smooth, some cracked extensively"; margin up to 0.1cm wide, "abrupt to pruinose, white to pallid", (Ginns(24)), resupinate, of small or moderate dimensions, 0.005-0.02cm thick, adnate [attached tightly], ceraceous to membranaceous; white to cream, when old sometimes ochraceous; "margin generally not especially differentiated, sometimes finely byssoid, white", (Eriksson), annual, effused, at first small orbicular patches on bark, becoming confluent, 0.01-0.03cm thick, membranous to ceraceous, adherent; "ivory yellow", "light buff", or "maize yellow", older areas "pinkish cinnamon"; "smooth, occasionally with small, scattered warts", often cracking on drying, becoming deeply cracked when old; margin colored as spore-bearing surface, "narrow, thinning out, fibrillose"; subiculum white, (Nakasone), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on a variety of hardwoods and conifers, fruiting on the bark of dead twigs and branches on the ground, associated with a white rot^, on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Ceanothus, Corylus (hazel), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Liquidambar, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Rhus, Salix (willow), Tilia (basswood), Ulmus (elm), (Ginns), on the underside of branches of hardwoods lying on the ground, spring to fall, (Breitenbach), on many kinds of substrate but prefers hardwood, (Eriksson), usually "on bark of conifer and hardwood twigs and branches", sometimes on barkless wood and associated with a white rot, (Nakasone), probably all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4.4)4.8-5.2(6.0) x (2.6)2.8-3.2(3.4) um, elliptic to nearly cylindric, verrucose to minutely verrucose (some appearing smooth), amyloid, colorless, thin-walled, with a small, blunt apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 17.0-28.0 x (3.6)4.0(4.4) um, narrowly clavate to almost cylindric, sterigmata up to 4.0 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 50-90(170) x 8-12(14) um, "arising either in the hymenium or from the basal hyphal layer", tubular, fusoid, or flask-shaped, "some with an elongated neck, some with a long narrow base, thin-walled, the contents yellowish green in KOH, granular", sulfo-positive but the occasional collection sulfo-negative; HYPHAE monomitic, subiculum a basal layer up to 100 um thick "of woven but essentially parallel and horizontally arranged hyphae"; hyphae 2.0-3.5 um wide, colorless, inamyloid, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Ginns(24)), SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, sometimes somewhat flattened on one side, finely verrucose, amyloid, colorless, with droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 3.5-4 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 60-80 x 9-20 um (according to literature up to 150 um long), cylindrical to fusiform, "sometimes sinuous, narrowing abruptly into a thin hypha at the base", sulfovanillin-positive; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 4.5-6(8) x 2.5-3.5 um, elliptic, subovate [somewhat oval] to subcylindric [somewhat cylindric], finely verrucose (best seen on empty spore coats in Melzer's), amyloid; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-22 x 3-4 um, narrowly clavate; GLOEOCYSTIDIA (= pseudocystidia) numerous, 60-150 x 8-15 um, tubular, more or less sinuous, often coming laterally from the bearing hypha, "contents in KOH granular, oily, yellowish, in cotton blue with a number of oildrops of varying sizes, with positive reaction to sulfovanilline"; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, thin basal layer (25-50 um) next to substrate of hyphae that are mainly parallel, "subhymenial trama of densely interwoven, vertical hyphae", (Eriksson), SPORES (4.5)5-6.5 x 3-3.5 um, cylindric to elliptic, asperulate, amyloid, colorless, acyanophilic, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 22-26 x 5-6 um, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, with basal clamp connection, sterigmata 3-4 um long; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA "numerous, arising throughout subiculum and subhymenium", embedded, 80-160 x (9)12-15 um, obclavate to tubular, sinuose, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, with basal clamp connection, turning blue-black in sulfobenzaldehyde; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-4.5 um wide, "loosely interwoven but forming a compact layer of parallel hyphae next to the substrate", colorless, thin-walled, "nodose septate, moderately branched", smooth or moderately encrusted with colorless crystals, (Nakasone)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'full of pores'
SIMILAR  Gloeocystidiellum clavigerum is inseparable macroscopically but has broadly elliptic to nearly round spores and occurs on barkless wood, (Ginns(24)). G. clavuligerum has spores that are broader in relation to their length, (Stalpers(3)). Gloeocystidiellum luridum, G. leucoxanthum, Gloiothele lactescens, and Conferticium ochraceum have smooth spores, and the last two lack clamp connections, (Eriksson). Conferticium ravum lacks clamp connections, (Eriksson). Boidinia propinqua lacks clamp connections, (Jackson(1)). Amylosporomyces subasperisporus differs from the Gloeocystidiellum porosum group by having 1) thin, granulose fruitbodies, 2) kidney-shaped spores, 3) suburniform basidia, and 4) generally smaller gloeocystidia, (Ginns(24)).
SOURCES  Ginns(24) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Eriksson(3), Breitenbach(2)*, Nakasone(6) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Stalpers(3), Jackson(1) (discussing Corticium propinquum), Buczacki(1)*
153
FAMILY  Gloeodontiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloeodontia columbiensis  Burds. & Lombard^  as Burt ex Burds. & Lombard, Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 28: 17. 1976
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a buff surface with short teeth, 3) amyloid spiny spores, 4) gloeocystidia and encrusted cystidia, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the generative hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^It has been recorded from BC, OR, ID, AB, MN, and MT, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, becoming effused [spread out], annual; "light buff" to "pinkish buff" or "cartridge buff"; surface grandinioid, teeth short, crowded, branched at tips, surface often cracking into rectangular blocks^, (Lindsey)
HABITAT  causing white rot of hardwood and conifer logs and slash^, (Lindsey), on dead wood, associated with white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 3-4 um, oval to elliptic, colorless, amyloid and distinctly echinulate in Melzer's reagent^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA clustered at tips of teeth, 60-80 x 4-8 um, cylindric, tapering slightly at the tip, thick-walled, heavily encrusted on upper part, gloeocystidia numerous, 25-40 x 4-6 um, projecting slightly, fusoid to cylindric, often mammillate, "with highly refractive contents, positive in sulfuric benzaldehyde", with a basal clamp connection; HYPHAE dimitic, generative hyphae 2-3.5 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 1.5-3 um wide, thick-walled, aseptate, rarely branched, (Lindsey)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Lindsey(3), Ginns(5)
154
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloeohypochnicium analogum  (Bourdot & Galzin) Hjortstam^  Mycotaxon 28(1): 30. 1987;  Hypochnicium analogum  (Bourdot & Galzin)  J. Erikss.;  Corticium analogum  (Bourdot & Galzin) Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwoods, 2) a tightly attached, waxy fruitbody colored creamish to pale ochraceous, the surface smooth to tuberculate, the margin white, finely fibrillose in young specimens, 3) a fruity odor when fresh, 4) spores that are nearly round or broadly elliptic, inamyloid, and thick-walled, with low rounded warts, 5) basidia that are suburniform with a stem, 6) sulfo-positive gloeocystidia that are very numerous (young ones projecting), cylindric or fusiform, and obtuse or acute, with oil droplets of various sizes, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Gloeohypochnicium analogum has been found in BC, ID, ON, AZ, MD, ME, NC, and WV, (Ginns), as well as France, Norway, Poland, Sweden, and the USSR, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, 0.02-0.05cm thick, adnate [tightly attached], ceraceous [waxy] when wet and alive; creamish to pale ochraceous; smooth or when vigorously growing more or less tuberculate, when dried often rimose [cracked]; "margin white, finely fibrillose in young specimens"; "when newly dried with a strong, pleasant, fruitish scent"^, (Eriksson), fruitbodies in fragments up to 8cm long and 3cm wide, (Burt), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on bark or wood of hardwoods^ (e.g. Acer (maple), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Populus, Quercus (oak), and Ulmus (elm)), (Eriksson), Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), A. saccharum (Sugar Maple), Carya sp. (hickory), Fraxinus velutina (Velvet Ash), Populus sp., Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Quercus sp. (oak), Q. emoryi (Emory Oak), Salix gooddingii (Goodding's Black Willow), Salix nigra (Black Willow); mine timber; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), July to December (Bourdot), fall, winter, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (6)7.5-10 x (5)7-8 um, nearly round or broadly elliptic, with low rounded warts, inamyloid, cyanophilic, thick-walled, with prominent apiculus, usually with one droplet^; BASIDIA 4-spored (normally), 50-75 x 6-9 um, at first narrowly clavate, then cylindric, "somewhat constricted in a suburniform way and often sinuous, basally tapering to a stalk-like hyphal part", with basal clamp connection, protoplasm grainy and with some oil droplets of different sizes; CYSTIDIA (gloeocystidia, sulfocystidia) very numerous, cylindric or fusiform, obtuse or acute, vertical like a palisade, thin-walled, protoplasm filled with oil droplets of different sizes, positive reaction to sulfovanillin, turning the oil violet, oil droplets also visible in cotton blue but dissolved in Melzer's reagent, some adventitious septa without clamp connections seen, "apices of gloeocystidia often projecting as far as mature basidia, in young specimens even longer"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4 um wide, richly branched, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "densely united especially in the thickened subhymenium where they are vertically arranged between the gloeocystidia, in the subiculum easier to distinguish but still in a close texture", "subicular layer reaching 100 um in thickness with more or less horizontal hyphae, growing hyphal ends often seen among the basidia", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hypochnicium analogum), Bourdot(1), Burt(1) (as Corticium analogum), Ginns(5) (as Hypochnicium analogum), Buczacki(1)*
155
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloeohypochnicium versatum  (Burt) Tellera, M. Duenas, Melo & M.P. Martn^  Mycologia 102(6): 1431. 2010;  Hypochnicium versatum  (Burt) Ginns  Mycotaxon 44(1): 214. 1992;  Peniophora versata  Burt;  Corticium versatum  (Burt) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer lumber, 2) a pale yellow fruitbody with a smooth dull surface, the subiculum thin, white, and fibrous when wetted, 3) broadly elliptic spores that are finely warted, inamyloid, colorless, acyanophilic, and slightly thick-walled, 4) numerous sulfo-positive gloeocystidia, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae narrow, thick-walled, and gelatinized.^ RANGE ^Gloeohypochnicium versatum has been found in WA (Ginns(5))
FRUITING BODY  effuse [spread out], up to 5-1.5cm and up to 0.025cm thick; pale yellow; smooth, dull; margin about 0.05cm wide, "indistinct, determinate"; "subiculum thin, white, fibrous when wetted"^, (Ginns(3))
HABITAT  on conifer lumber that shows little sign of decay^, (Ginns(3)), slightly decayed planks and cross-ties, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (6.5)6.8-8.2(8.4) x 4.0-4.8 um, broadly elliptic, with blunt apiculus, inamyloid, acyanophilic, walls colorless, "most thickened to 0.4 um, most finely roughened with warts up to 0.2 um diam"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 40 x 6.0-6.5 um, narrowly clavate, sterigmata 4 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 35-100 x 8-15 um, "imbedded or some projecting to 10 um, clavate to broadly clavate", "the contents granular, pale yellow in KOH, sulfo-positive", the walls colorless, "smooth, thin or, in a few, thickened to 1.5 um"; lamprocystidia lacking; HYPHAE monomitic, subicular hyphae 2.5-3.0(5.0) um wide, closely packed, woven, colorless, inamyloid, acyanophilic, the walls thickened, gelatinized, subhymenium occupying most of the thickness of the fruitbody, "with hyphae vertically oriented and similar to subicular hyphae", (Ginns(3))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Ginns(3) (as Hypochnicium versatum), Ginns(5) (as Hypochnicium versatum)
156
FAMILY  Irpicaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloeoporus ambiguus  (Berk.) Zmitr. & Spirin^  in Zmitrovich, Malysheva & Spirin, Mycena 6: 35. 2006;  == Byssomerulius ambiguus  (Berk.) Gilb. & Budington  J. Ariz. Acad. Sci. 6(2): 92. 1970;  == Meruliopsis ambigua  (Berk.) Ginns  Can. J. Bot. 54: 117. 1976 [as Meruliopsis ambiguus];  == Merulius ambiguus  Berk.;  Merulius succineus  Lloyd
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth spread out on conifer wood (especially pine), generally bent outward to form caps that are often shingled, 2) caps that are cream to gray when old, tomentose, and zonate, the spore-bearing surface dark purple to violet brown, with radiating folds that may be interrupted and may anastomose to form small pits, 3) spores that are oblong to oval, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Specimens were examined from BC, AB, MB, ON, PQ, YT, AK, AZ, GA, MN, SC, TX, and Ecuador; it has been recorded from ID, AL, AR, CA, CO, CT, FL, MD, MT, NC, NE, NJ, NM, NY, WI, France, and Russia, (Ginns(12)). It has also been recorded from SK (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  occasionally effused [spread out over surface], generally effused-reflexed [bent outwards from surface to form cap], often imbricate [shingled], when reflexed up to 4cm x 3cm, when effused up to 10cm long, in either case up to 1.5cm thick; margin up to 0.2cm wide, white, gray, cream, sometimes with a pinkish tinge, tomentose, "the extreme edge generally serrate and on the reflexed portion distinctly inflexed"; cap surface cream to gray in old specimens, tomentose, zonate; spore-bearing surface "generally dark purple (nearly black), also violet-brown, shiny, waxy, the folds generally radiating, often interrupted, sometimes anastomosing to form circular pits, one to three per millimetre"; flesh up to 0.1cm thick, homogeneous, cottony, white to pallid^, (Ginns(12))
HABITAT  on bark and wood of conifers, primarily Pinus (pine), and rarely on hardwood; associated with a white rot; in the Alaska to Idaho area collections May through September^, (Ginns(12)), primarily on Pinus, also Alnus, Picea, Salix, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4.4)5.6-7.2(8.8) x (2)2.2-2.8(3) um, oblong to oval, in side view "adaxially flattened or slightly concave, or sometimes basally bent", smooth, IKI-, colorless, colorless or quickly pale blue in lactic-blue, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 17-30 x 4-5.5 um, narrowly clavate to cylindric; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, context hyphae generally horizontally woven, colorless, "predominantly thick-walled, occasionally branched at a right angle, simple-septate", 3.5-6.5 um wide, adjacent to subhymenium "the hyphae are often thin-walled, closely packed, with yellow granules interspersed"; subhymenium "of thin-walled hyphae, closely packed, frequently branched", up to 3 um wide, "oriented parallel to the long axis of the basidia", (Ginns(12))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'uncertain, changeable, doubtful, of double meaning'
SIMILAR  Byssomerulius corium grows primarily on hardwoods, and has a pale orange-yellow to orange-brown spore-bearing surface (but intergradations in color can cause difficulty in assigning the species name), (Ginns(12)). Gloeoporus taxicola may be similar in color but has deeper folds, a thicker broader margin, and narrow spores 1-1.5 um wide, (Ginns(12)). Byssomerulius albostramineus may also be violaceous or dark purple but has small, allantoid or basally bent spores, (Ginns(12) under Meruliopsis corium). See also SIMILAR section of Phlebia tremellosa.
SOURCES  Ginns(12) (as Meruliopsis ambiguus), Ginns(5) (as Meruliopsis ambiguus)
157
FAMILY  Irpicaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloeoporus taxicola  (Pers.) Gilb. & Ryvarden^  Mycotaxon 22(2): 364. 1985;  == Meruliopsis taxicola  (Pers.) Bondartsev  in Parmasto, Izv. Akad. Nauk Estonsk SSR, Ser. Biol. 8: 274. 1959;  == Xylomyzon taxicola  Pers.;  == Merulius taxicola  (Pers.) Duby
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifers, 2) a fruitbody with pores that are tan to orange ocher to reddish brown to deep purplish or almost black with a contrasting white margin, 3) spores that are cylindric-allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) awl-shaped or spindle-shaped cystidioles arising at the same level as the basidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Gloeoporus taxicola has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, ON, AL, AZ, CO, CT, ME, MI, MT, NH, NJ, NM, NY, UT, and WY: it is circumglobal in the coniferous zone, including Australia and New Zealand, (Gilbertson). It has also been found in MB, PQ, SK, CA, GA, and MS, (Ginns(5)), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  up to 25cm x 15cm and 0.3cm thick, resupinate with pore surface exposed, rarely bent back to form a cap; margin up to 1cm wide, white to pallid, "when narrow granulose and indistinct", "when wide thick and mycelioid", flesh up to 0.2cm thick, cottony, soft, homogeneous; white to pallid; pores tan to purplish black waxy surface with narrow folds up to 0.1cm deep, usually randomly arranged, anastomosing to form oval or angular pits, 2-5 per mm^, (Ginns(12)), up to 0.4cm thick, resupinate with pore surface exposed, often widely spread out, "tough and waxy when fresh, brittle and hard when dry", separable to slightly adherent, annual, margin wide and white, conspicuous in contrast to colored pore surface; flesh up to 0.2cm thick, fibrous; white; pores 2-4 per mm, angular, reddish to deep purplish or almost black; tubes up to 0.1cm long, with continuous hymenium over the dissepiments, (Gilbertson), spore bearing surface orange-ocherish when young, later orange-red-brown to dark red-brown, color always bright, often forming concentric zones, tubes up to 0.1cm deep, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  saprophytic on conifer wood, causing a white rot, collected in Canada from July through October, but one collection in early May^, (Ginns(12)), on coniferous wood, most common on Pinus (pine) and Picea (spruce), rarely on Populus, causes a white rot, (Gilbertson), on dead conifer wood with and without bark, commonly on branches, fallen or attached, (Breitenbach)
