MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3-5 x 1-1.5 um, cylindric, in side view allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 13-20 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate; CYSTIDIOLES arising at a level with the basidia, 10-25 x 4-5 um, fusoid, thin-walled; HYPHAE monomitic 2-6.5(8) um wide, "loosely woven next to substrate, becoming vertically arranged and closely packed in the folds, simple-septate, thin- to rather thin-walled or occasionally thick-walled"; "subhymenium and adjacent context heavily incrusted with golden, resin-like or granular material", (Ginns(12)), SPORES 4.5-6 x 1-1.5(2) um, allantoid to cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-25 x 4-5 um, clavate, simple-septate at base; CYSTIDIA "present as subulate smooth cystidioles of the same size as the basidia, 15-30 x 3-4 um, simple septate at the base, quite common in the hymenium which is dense and palisade-like"; HYPHAE monomitic, generative hyphae in trama and subiculum up to 6 um wide, slightly thick-walled, often encrusted, with simple septa, branching often at right angles, loosely interwoven in the subiculum, more parallel and compact in the trama, those in hymenium and subhymenium up to 4 um wide, also simple-septate and branching often at right angles, but more delicately thin-walled, smooth, (Gilbertson), SPORES with 2 droplets; CYSTIDIA 12-20 x 2.5-3 um, subulate, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means "inhabiting Taxus (yew)"
SIMILAR  Gelatoporia dichroa (Polypore category) has clamped generative hyphae, lacks cystidioles, and occurs primarily on hardwoods, (Gilbertson). Byssomerulius albostramineus has larger spores, (Ginns(12)). See also SIMILAR section of Byssomerulius ambigua and Byssomerulius corium.
SOURCES  Ginns(12) (as Meruliopsis taxicola), Gilbertson(1), Breitenbach(2)* (as Meruliopsis taxicola), Ginns(5) (as Meruliopsis taxicola), Buczacki(1)*
158
FAMILY  Bondarzewiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloiodon occidentalis  Ginns^ [as occidentale] Mycologia 80: 66. 1988 
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat semicircular bracket with something of a lateral stem, 2) a cap surface that is brownish purple to brown, fleshy when fresh, becoming densely hairy, wavy, and lumpy, near the margin yellow-brown and bald, as viewed from above with fan-shaped sectors and a black fringe, 3) flesh that is pallid to brown, with zones or patches of hard, woody flesh and soft, woolly flesh, with fine dark brown line in cross-section delimiting hard zones, 4) teeth gradually narrowing to an acute tip, white drying gray, and stained red-brown where bruised, 5) spores that are broadly elliptic, verrucose, and amyloid, 6) sulfo-positive gloeocystidia originating in spine trama parallel with the other hyphae but bending almost at a right angle to project into and slightly through the hymenium, and 7) a dimitic hyphal system with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Gloiodon occidentale is known from the type specimen found in BC, (Ginns(5)), and a specimen found in WA (illustrated here, Buck McAdoo pers. comm.)
FRUITING BODY  dimidiate [somewhat semicircular], laterally substipitate [with something of a lateral stem], 4.5-8cm x 4-7cm, 1-1.5cm thick; cap surface "when fresh, brownish purple to brown and quite fleshy, drying pale brown", "densely strigose, undulating and lumpy", near the margin yellow-brown, bald "and, as viewed from above, tending to divide into fan-shaped sectors" with the extreme margin of black, fimbriate [fringed], horny, split tongues 0.1-0.2cm broad; context [flesh] in vertical section pallid but brown near the base, up to 1cm thick, "when fresh soft and woody, when dry hard and woody, homogeneous near the margin, elsewhere of alternating zones or patches of hard, woody tissue which is delimited by a thin dark brown line and soft, woolly tissue", [the illustrated vertical cross-section shows from to top to bottom a) coarsely hairy zone, b) thin black line, c) pallid context, and d) spines]; spines acicular, 0.5-1.2cm long and 0.03cm wide, "gradually narrowing to an acute tip, when fresh white, drying lead gray" or dark gray "and stained red-brown where bruised, when fresh fleshy, drying hard and brittle"^, (Ginns(14))
HABITAT  on Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), "on the cut end of the butt log and associated stump, and in hollow of decayed log; associated rot unknown"^, (Ginns(14))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5.5)6-7(7.5) x (4)5(5.5) um, broadly elliptic, minutely warted (verrucose), amyloid, colorless, acyanophilic, walls thin to 0.5 um thick, with a minute apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 24-28 x 5-6.5 um, cylindric-clavate, when mature projecting 10-15 um, sterigmata about 3 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA originating in the spine trama and 3-4 um wide, "extending parallel to the other hyphae for up to several hundred um then abruptly bending, almost at a right angle, to project into and slightly through the hymenium, the apical portion extending into the hymenium about 45 um long, ellipsoid to fusoid with a bluntly conic apex", 8-12 um wide, wall colorless, thin, smooth, contents black in sulfobenzaldehyde; HYPHAE dimitic inamyloid, acyanophilic; strigose cap composed of fascicles of generative hyphae, 3-4 um wide, "parallel, straight, infrequently branched", with clamp connections and a few simple septa, walls slightly thickened, nearly colorless, and rather common sulfocystidia 3-4 um wide "with the apical 10-20 um typically inflated to 5 um"; CONTEXT HYPHAE in the woolly zones forming numerous woven strands, 6-40 um wide, "composed of a mixture of parallel, essentially straight generative and skeletal hyphae": 1) generative hyphae 3-4 um wide with clamp connections, infrequently branched, colorless, walls thin to moderately thickened, 2) skeletal hyphae 3-4 um wide, "aseptate, rarely branched, the walls pale yellow, slightly refractive, thickened so that some have only a capillary lumen", hyphae between the strands loosely woven; context hyphae in hard zones delimited by a dark line are like those in the strands, but 3-5 um wide, closely packed, and not arranged into strands; hyphae in the teeth "parallel, longitudinally arranged, compact, essentially straight": 1) skeletal hyphae predominating, infrequently branched, some weakly knobby, 2.5-4 um wide, the walls thickened, pale yellow, slightly refractive, 2) generative hyphae 2-3.5(4) um wide, colorless, with clamp connections, walls thin to slightly thickened, (Ginns(14))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'western'
SIMILAR  Gloiodon strigosus is another species that may be in the Pacific Northwest. According to D. Miller (pers. comm.), one of two different sequences of collections in the Pacific Northwest corresponds to European sequences identified as G. strigosus. Ginns(14) wrote, "Gloiodon strigosus was redescribed by Jahn and Sturm (1983) from European specimens. Their excellent, illustrated account and Canadian specimens in DAOM led me to conclude that G. strigosus differs in (a) occurring on angiosperm wood, (b) having smaller basidiomes, (c) dark brown pileus, (d) spines only 2-6 mm long, (e) distinctly yellow brown skeletals, (f) smaller spores 4.5-6 x 4-4.5 Am, (g) verrucose spores with elongated warts (FIG. 4), (h) lacking gloeocystidia in the hirsute pileus tissue and (i) well-developed context in the pileus." (Latin names italicized, date of year bold font).
SOURCES  Ginns(14), Ginns(5), McAdoo(1)*
159
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloiothele citrina  (Pers.) Ginns & G.W. Freeman^  Biblthca Mycol. 157: 55. 1994;  Gloeocystidiellum citrinum  (Pers.) Donk  Fungus 26: 9. 1956;  == Vesiculomyces citrinus  (Pers.) E. Hagstr.;  == Thelephora citrina  Pers.;  = Corticium radiosum  (Fr.) Fr.;  = Gloeocystidiellum radiosum  (Fr.) Boidin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood and conifer wood, 2) pale to bright yellow fruitbodies that fade to more ochraceous when old or dried, the surface waxy, and smooth to tuberculate, the margin white and fibrillose, 3) spores that are round to nearly round, smooth, weakly amyloid, and colorless, 4) numerous thin-walled gloeocystidia that are bladder-like and apically tapering, the basal ones usually very wide, but those in hymenium narrow (ventricose-rostrate, lageniform, fusiform), the gloeocystidia generally considered sulfo-negative, but found to be sulfo-positive in fresh culture, 5) scattered hyphidia, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, OR, ID, AB, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, CT, MA, MI, MT, NC, NJ, NM, NY, PA, TN, UT, VT, WI, WY, and France: the species is also reported from WA, NB, NS, AK, AL, AR, FL, LA, MO, MS, and WV, (Ginns). It is a fairly common species in most parts of Scandinavia, (Eriksson). It is also occurs in Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], orbicular [circular] to confluent and widely effused [spread out], of moderate thickness (mostly 0.01-0.05cm thick), ceraceous [waxy] when alive and wet, membranaceous when dry; when fresh, "yellow, pale (or even whitish) in young fruitbodies, brighter in mature ones, colour fading in herbarium, old specimens often ochraceous"; bald, "smooth or more or less tuberculate when alive, smoothed out when dry", thicker fruitbodies more or less rimose [cracked] when dried; "margin when well developed white, fibrillose"^, (Eriksson), effused, 0.01-0.05cm thick, membranous, "ivory yellow", "cartridge buff", "cream buff", "light buff", or "pale yellow-orange" when dry; "smooth to slightly tuberculate, not cracked to extensively cracked" with fissures 0.1-0.2cm long "revealing a white subiculum"; "margin usually distinct, white", fibrillose to fimbriate [fringed], sometimes farinaceous [mealy] or abrupt, (Ginns), resupinate, tightly attached, "rather small patches or coherent expanses" several decimeters across, wax-like when fresh, membranous when dry; lemon yellow when young, then ocher-yellow, "places damaged by feeding animals whitish"; "smooth to bluntly verrucose"; margin whitish and fringed-filamentous, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on "logs, rotten wood, tree base, stump, moss-covered wood and bark", of a variety of hardwoods and conifers^, Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juglans (walnut), Juniperus (juniper), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja, Tilia (basswood), Ulmus (elm), on soil; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), generally on conifer wood, but can also be found on hardwood, "as well as on soil, rich in humus", (Eriksson), on stumps of conifers, especially Picea (spruce), according to the literature also on hardwoods; throughout the year, especially in the winter half, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-6.5 um wide, round to nearly round, smooth, weakly amyloid (weakly mottled on the interior surface in Melzer's reagent), wall thin up to 0.4 um thick, spore with a distinct apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-60 x 4.0-7.5 um, clavate or cylindric, sterigmata up to 5.0 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 40-105 x 7-20 um, "ventricose, ventricose-rostrate, and lageniform, thin-walled, the contents not refringent, sulfo-negative in herbarium specimens" (but said by Boidin & Lanquetin 1983 to be sulfo-positive in living cultures); HYPHIDIA "scattered, uncommon", 2-3 um wide, "filiform, some weakly branched at the apex"; HYPHAE monomitic; subiculum "a loosely arranged layer about 25-50 um thick of distinct, parallel hyphae"; hyphae 2.0-4.0(5.6) um wide, without clamp connections; subhymenial hyphae 2.5-5.6 um, compact, distinct, colorless, thin-walled; gloeoplerous hyphae "adjoining the substrate, unbranched with scattered septa", 5 um wide, the contents oily, (Ginns), SPORES round to nearly round, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled, containing one or more oil droplets, with prominent apiculus, mostly 4-5 um in diameter; BASIDIA narrowly clavate, containing a number of oil droplets of varying sizes, mostly 30-50 x 5-7 um, without basal clamp connection, normally 4-spored; GLOEOCYSTIDIA vesicular [bladder-like], apically tapering, mostly 50-70 x 10-20 um, thin-walled with watery contents, without reaction to sulfo-vanillin; basal gloeocystidia usually very wide, vesicular, while in the hymenium very narrow gloeocystidia can be found; in thicker fruitbodies "prolonged gloeocystidia can be seen, reaching a length of 150 um"; the hymenial gloeocystidia contain a number of oil droplets, while such droplets are usually absent in the basal gloeocystidia; HYPHAE monomitic, 1.5-2.5 um wide, acyanophilic, very thin-walled, without clamp connections; "next to the substrate a layer of varying thickness of more or less parallel hyphae"; texture when young loose, denser when mature, especially in the subhymenial trama, (Eriksson), SPORES 4.5-6 um in diameter, nearly round, smooth, amyloid, colorless, with 1 droplet; BASIDIA 1-4-spored, 35-45 x 5-7 um, narrowly clavate; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 40-60 x 15-20 um, ventricose-rostrate to narrowly fusiform, without visible contents, sulfo-negative; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, acyanophilic, without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES (4) 5-6.5(7) um; BASIDIA, 30-60 x 4-7.5 um, clavate; GLOEOCYSTIDIA vesicular to fusiform or flexuous-cylindric, 40-100(150) x 7-20 um, usually sulfo-negative; GENERATIVE HYPHAE 1.5-4(5.5) um wide, (Stalpers)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of citron', referring presumably to the pale yellow color of the fruitbody
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Ginns(24) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Eriksson(2) (as Gloeocystidiellum citrinum), Breitenbach(2)* (as Vesiculomyces citrinus), Ginns(5) (as Vesiculomyces citrinum), Stalpers(3) (as Gloeocystidiellum citrinum), Buczacki(1)* (as Vesiculomyces citrinus)
160
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloiothele lactescens  (Berk.) Hjortstam^  Windahlia 17: 58. 1987;  == Gloeocystidiellum lactescens  (Berk.) Boidin;  == Thelephora lactescens  Berk. in J.E. Smith;  Corticium lactescens  (Berk.) Berk.;  Megalocystidium lactescens  (Berk.) Julich;  = Corticium epigaeum  Ellis & Everh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood (mostly hardwood) in waxy to thickly membranous patches, 2) a surface that is whitish, then yellowish to pink-tinted, usually some shade of brown, 3) a characteristic cracking pattern when mature and dry, 4) spores that are broadly elliptic, smooth, and weakly amyloid, 5) basidia over 40 um long, 6) projecting hyphidia between the basidia, 7) gloeocystidia that are long (>100 um) tubular, sinuous, and sulfo-positive, and 8) a monomitic hyphal system with clampless septa.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, MB, ON, AZ, CA, CT, FL, MI, NY, TN, WI: the species is also reported from BC, OR, NF, PQ, LA, MA, ME, NC, TN, and VT, (Ginns(24)). It occurs in Europe including Scandinavia and the United Kingdom, (Eriksson). It also occurs in Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [tightly attached], of moderate size, thickening when old to about 0.1cm, ceraceous [waxy]; hygrophanous, whitish or watery gray, then yellowish to reddish; when mature and dry cracked in a characteristic way, at first with scattered, short, 0.1-0.2cm, mouth-like cracks, when old "with numerous deep furrows, in all directions subdividing the hymenium in small pieces in a net-like manner"; margin byssoid when young, not especially differentiated when old; said by Berkeley to bleed when broken with a milky juice, which in taste and odor is said to resemble that of Lactarius quietus^, (Eriksson), effused [spread out], fragmented, the largest pieces 6cm x 2cm, and 0.02 to 0.05cm thick; pale yellow with a slight pink tint, "cream buff", "pinkish buff" sometimes with "avellaneous" tints, "cinnamon-buff", or "clay color" when dry; color also stated to be "usually some shade of brown"; "smooth, crustose, younger specimens cracked sparingly", older specimens drying with characteristic mouth-like fissures 0.1-0.2cm long "or shrinking to form a characteristic reticulate pattern and revealing a white to resinous subiculum; margin often nearly white and fibrillose, sometimes abrupt or pruinose", (Ginns(24)), resupinate, tightly attached, forming soft, waxy to thickly membranous patches 0.05-0.1cm thick and several centimeters across; somewhat hygrophanous, white to cream, according to literature also with a reddish gleam, later yellowish; smooth to slightly uneven, furrowed-fissured when dry; margin filamentous to distinctly bounded, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on barkless, sometimes rotted wood, associated with a white rot of a variety of hardwoods or rarely conifers^, Acer (maple), Agave, Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja, Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), Ulmus (elm), (Ginns(24)), on hardwood in Scandinavia but type from England on bark of Pinus sylvestris (Scotch Pine), (Eriksson), late summer to fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.8-8.4(9.4) x 5.0-5.6(6.0) um, nearly round to broadly elliptic, smooth, weakly amyloid, mottled on the inner surface in Melzer's reagent, thin-walled, "with a rather broad, distinct apiculus which is smoothly molded into the spore wall"^; BASIDIA 40-75(100) x 6.0-8.0 um, clavate, most 4-spored, sterigmata up to 5.0 um long, a few 2-spored; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 120-300 x 6-11 um, "sinuous, tubular, typically broader at the base, apex broadly rounded, thin-walled", the contents colorless to yellowish green in KOH, usually homogeneous, sulfo-positive; HYPHIDIA numerous, 2-3 um wide, "filiform, some weakly branched at the apex", HYPHAE monomitic; subiculum a layer about 50 um thick next to substrate, "with hyphae woven, distinct, parallel"; hyphae 2.0-3.6(4.4) um wide, colorless, inamyloid, thin-walled, lacking clamp connections; subhymenium up to 300 um thick, compact, indistinct, (Ginns(24)), SPORES 6-7 x 4-4.5 um, broadly elliptic or nearly round, smooth, amyloid, thin-walled, with granular oily contents or with numerous oil droplets or irregular oil bodies; BASIDIA normally 4-spored, 40-60 x 6-7 um, basally tapering to a narrow stem-like part, no basal clamp connection, numerous oil droplets or irregular oil bodies in the protoplasm; numerous projecting paraphysoid hyphae between the basidia; GLOEOCYSTIDIA (= pseudocystidia) numerous, 150-200 um or more long, mostly 8-10 um wide, tubular, sinuose, "with granular, oily, yellowish contents, which react positively with sulfovanilline", adventitious septations frequent; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 1.5-2.5 um wide, thin-walled, without clamp connections, BASAL HYPHAE arranged in horizontal layer about 50 um deep, parallel to substrate, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE more densely intertwined and oriented more vertically, (Eriksson), SPORES 6-8 x 4-5 um, elliptic, smooth, amyloid, colorless; BASIDIA (2-)4-spored, 50-60 x 6-7 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; cylindric HYPHIDIA present between the basidia, 60-70 x 2-3 um; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 100-150 x 6-8 um, (according to Julich 150-250 x 8-12 um), cylindric, sinuous, with granular contents, sulfo-positive; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 2-4 um wide, thin-walled, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to milky exudate when broken
SIMILAR  Gloeocystidiellum porosum, G. leucoxanthum, G. luridum, and G. clavuligerum have clamp connections, (Eriksson). Conferticium ochraceum, Conferticium ravum, and G. clavuligerum have shorter gloeocystidia, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Ginns(24) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Eriksson(3) (as Gloeocystidiellum lactescens), Breitenbach(2)* (as Megalocystidium), Ginns(3) (as Gloeocystidiellum), Stalpers(2) (as Gloeocystidiellum), Buczacki(1)*
161
FAMILY  Cyphellaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Granulobasidium vellereum  (Ellis & Cragin) Julich^  Persoonia 10(3): 328. 1979;  Hypochnicium vellereum  (Ellis & Cragin) Parmasto;  Corticium vellereum  Ellis & Cragin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) soft wax-like membranous patches attached tightly to wood, colored whitish with a rose tint, the surface smooth to powdery or mealy, and the margin fibrillose when young but often not differentiated when mature, 3) spores that are round, irregularly uneven, inamyloid, cyanophilic, and thick-walled, with many chlamydospores usually also present, 4) long tubular basidia with a tapering base and comparatively short sterigmata, 5) cystidia lacking, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Granulobasidium vellereum has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, ON, PQ, AL, CA, GA, IL, KS, MA, MI, MO, MN, MT, NH, NY, OH, PA, SD, TX, VT, and WI, (Ginns). The distribution also includes Europe including Denmark and Sweden, (Eriksson), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, forming thin, membranous patches 0.01-0.02cm thick and several centimeters to decimeters across, attached tightly to substrate, consistency soft, wax-like; "white to ocherish when young, later with slight pink tint", smooth, finely farinose [mealy], dull; "margin diffuse to somewhat fringed"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, about 0.01-0.02cm thick, membranaceous, adnate [tightly attached to substrate], spore-bearing area continuous; "whitish with a rose tint to rose red, in the herbarium fading to yellowish or pale ochraceous"; smooth or somewhat pulverulent [powdery]; sterile margin fibrillose when young, but mature specimens often fertile throughout, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead wood of hardwoods, especially Ulmus (elm); winter half of the year^, (Breitenbach), on hardwood (e.g. Ulmus), usually near ground, but when weather is mild and humid may be found on trunks several meters above the ground, (Eriksson), Acer rubrum (Red Maple), Acer saccharum (Sugar Maple), Betula alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), Celtis occidentalis (Hackberry), Fagus grandifolia (American Beech), Malus sp. (apple / crabapple), Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Ulmus pumila (Siberian Elm), (Ginns), on rotting bark and sometimes wood of hardwood trees; usually winter, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8.5 x 5.5-7.5 um, nearly round, "with fine roughening on surface", inamyloid, colorless, cyanophilic, thick-walled, containing droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 45-65 x 4.5-5.5 um, "cylindric-clavate, somewhat sinuous", with basal clamp connection; CONIDIA (chlamydospores) 9-10 x 5.5-6 um, elliptic, smooth, cyanophilic, thick-walled, with droplets, some germinating; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-5 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES round, irregularly uneven (may look echinulate), inamyloid, cyanophilic, thick-walled, usually containing one droplet, mostly 7-8 um in diameter; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-60 x 5-6 um, "tubular, somewhat sinuous, tapering towards the base", with basal clamp connection, sterigmata small; CONIDIA (chlamydospores) "usually present, often in large quantities", 8-10 x 6-8 um, "formed apically or intercalary" on thin-walled hyphae, about 2 um wide, apical conidia rounded or pear-shaped, "intercalary ones more or less fusiform", conidial wall much thickened, strongly cyanophilic and also dextrinoid, protoplasm mostly with one oil droplet; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-5 um wide, "with thin or somewhat thickened walls", with clamp connections; "subiculum of densely interwoven hyphae with predominantly vertical hyphal direction", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'made of fleece'
SIMILAR  Other Hypochnicium species do not have the combination of reddish fruitbody, round, not quite smooth spores, usually many chlamydospores, long tubular basidia with a tapering base, and a lack of cystidia, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hypochnicium vellereum), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5) (as Hypochnicium vellereum), Buczacki(1)*
162
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hastodontia hastata  (Litsch.) Hjortstam & Ryvarden^  Syn. Fung. (Oslo) 26: 49. 2009;  Hyphodontia hastata  (Litsch.) J. Erikss.  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 104. 1958;  Kneiffiella hastata  (Litsch.) Julich & Stalpers;  Grandinia hastata  (Litsch.) Julich;  Peniophora hastata  Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, less often on hardwood, 2) a whitish fruitbody that is at first smooth but becomes tuberculate, and is bristly under a 50x lens, the margin with a pruinose zone or fertile throughout, 3) spores that are subcylindric and smooth, with 1 or several oil droplets, 4) cystidia of 2 types: a) numerous awl-shaped cystidia, somewhat projecting, with thickened walls, with an excreted globe of resinous matter that dissolves in mounting media, and b) a few enclosed moniliform cystidia, thin-walled, with dense protoplasm, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae slightly thick-walled, cyanophilic, with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Hastodontia hastata has been found in BC, WA, ID, ON, AZ, CO, NM, NY, and WI, (Ginns). The known distribution is BC, ID, PQ, AZ, MT, Austria, Norway, Sweden, China, Japan, and Russia (Siberia), (Langer).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], "but when old often detachable in pieces", "when young porose, then continuous and submembranaceous"; white to creamish white, when postmature often pale ochraceous; "at first smooth but more or less tuberculate when mature" (becoming smoother on drying), under 50x lens finely pilose from projecting cystidia; "margin variable, often fertile throughout but in young fruitbodies often with a sterile, pruinose, indeterminate marginal zone"^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  mostly on decayed, barkless or barked coniferous wood, but also on hardwood "as well as on small debris on the ground in coniferous forests"^, (Eriksson), Pinus sp. (pine), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), P. radiata (Monterey Pine), Quercus gambelii (Gambel's Oak); on rotten wood; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 x 2-2.5 um, subcylindric, smooth, thin-walled, with 1 or several oil droplets^; BASIDIA at first subclavate, then subcylindric, "usually with a median suburniform constriction", sometimes basally tapering into a short stem-like part, 14-22 x 4-5 um, normally 4-spored, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) numerous subulate [awl-shaped] cystidia, "somewhat projecting, with thickened walls, apically or subapically with an excreted globe of resinous matter, visible under the lens but more or less dissolving in most mounting media", 2) enclosed cystidia, few, 40-50 x 3-5 um, "more or less torulose (moniliform), thinwalled, with dense, strongly stainable protoplasm"; HYPHAE monomitic, "distinct, slightly thickwalled, cyanophilous, 2-3 um wide, richly branched and irregularly interwoven into a loose texture in the subiculum, hyphae of the subhymenium thinner, densely united with the predominantly vertical hyphal direction", [hyphae illustrated with clamp connections], (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  probably from 'hasta', Latin for 'spear', referring to the cystidia
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hyphodontia hastata), Ginns(5) (as Hyphodontia hastata), Langer(1) (as Hyphodontia hastata), Riebesehl(1)
163
FAMILY  Helicobasidiaceae, Order Helicobasidiales, Class Pucciniomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helicobasidium brebissonii  (Desm.) Donk^  Taxon 7:164. 1958;  Protonema brebissonii  Desm.;  Helicobasidium purpureum  Pat.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead hardwood, on the ground, or encrusting live plants, 2) loosely attached soft patches with a distinct margin, the color violet to pink-violet, and the surface smooth to undulating-tubercular and whitish pruinose, 3) spores that have a polar cap and sometimes a sterigmal remnant, 4), helical or hook-like basidia that are transverse septate, 5) lack of cystidia, and 6) lack of clamp connections.^ | Helicobasidium brebissonii is included in some classifications of jelly fungi, and Breitenbach(2) list it in Auriculariaceae, but it is usually now considered to be a member of Platygloeaceae, a family in the Pucciniomycetes. RANGE ^Helicobasidium brebissonii has been found in BC, WA, OR, PE, AK, AZ, IA, KS, MA, MI, MO, MT, NC, ND, NE, NY, OH, OK, TX, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  fully resupinate (lying flat), "attached loosely to substrate, forming thin patches several centimeters in extent", consistency soft, membranous, when dry becomes brittle; violet to pink-violet, drying gray-ocher with slight lilac tint; smooth to undulating-tuberculate [wavy with bumps], dull, whitish-pruinose; margin distinctly bounded^, (Breitenbach) 
HABITAT  on dead hardwood, on the ground, or encrusting live plants; causes violet root rot of a variety of deciduous woody plants; often on seedlings^; Acer, Ambrosia, Ampelopsis, Asparagus, Carya, Catalpa, Celtis, Daucus, Fraxinus, Helianthus, Iresine, Malvaviscus, Medicago, Melia, Morus, Parthenocissus, Phytolacca, Ratibida, Rhus, Rivina, Salix, Sambucus, Solanum, Trifolium, Ulmus, Verbesina, Viguiera, Viola, (Ginns), parasitic and saprophytic on trees and shrubs, fall-spring, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 11-13.5 x 6-7 um, irregularly elliptic to cylindric, some also somewhat curved, smooth, inamyloid, colorless to slightly lilac-brownish, some spores with polar cap and sometimes with attached remnant of sterigma^; BASIDIA 4.5-7 um wide, hypha-like, transversely septate, bent over and hook-like to helical, slightly lilac-brownish, sterigmata subulate [awl-shaped] to cylindric; CYSTIDIA not seen; hyphae 4-6 um wide, somewhat thick-walled, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Helicobasidium corticioides is the label for a collection by O. Ceska from Vancouver Island, British Columbia at the University of British Columbia (UBC F24797, Mushroom Observer 70008, spores 14-20 x 5-6 with microscopic drawings). It has been recorded also from Alberta, Colorado (holotype), Utah, and Wyoming, (Ginns(5)). It is distinguished from other species of Helicobasidium "by the corticioid aspect of the fructification, the basidia, which are usually coiled or loosely spiralled rather than crozier-shaped, and by the size of the basidia and spores". Spores are 14-22.5 x 6.5-12.5 um, ovoid to cylindric, and adaxially flattened, and basidia arched, loosely spiralled, or forming one or two coils, mostly 2-septate to 3-septate, basal cells 80-160 x 6-11 um. (Bandoni(14)).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Bandoni(14) (about Helicobasidium corticioides)
164
FAMILY  Phleogenaceae, Order Atractiellales, Class Atractiellomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helicogloea lagerheimii  Pat.^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. Fr. 8: 121. 1892;  Saccoblastia sebacea  Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Helicogloea lagerheimii produces a thin, waxy, colorless to slate gray coating on sodden dead hardwood, identified by microscopic characters. Features include 1) waxy to gelatinous coating on hardwood, colorless to gray with the surface smooth to tuberculate or corrugated, 2) ovate-elliptic spores, 3) probasidia that are lateral, saccate, and oblong-ovoid to elongate, sometimes with 1-3 constrictions, 4) epibasidia arising from near the basal end of hypobasidium, narrow, then abruptly enlarged, the thickened distal part becoming 3-septate, each of the four cells so formed producing a short lateral branch bearing a sterigma and spore.^ RANGE ^Helicogloea lagerheimii has been found in BC, OR, MB, ON, AZ, CA, IA, LA, MO, New England, and OH, (Ginns), WA (Klett), and Ecuador, Brazil, Hawaii, and Europe, (Martin).
FRUITING BODY  sometimes 30cm or more in extent, and in thickness from a mere coating to 0.1cm or more, waxy to soft gelatinous, drying to a varnish-like film; colorless to slate gray, drying to colorless or dusky; surface smooth to tuberculate or corrugated^, (Martin)
HABITAT  on dead, usually sodden, hardwood^, (Martin), Acer sp. (maple), Betula sp. (Birch), Fraxinus velutina (Velvet Ash), Picea mariana (Black Spruce), Quercus hypoleucoides (Silverleaf Oak), Salix sp. (willow), Trachycarpus fortunei (Chinese Windmill Palm); on dead limb; old leaf bases, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 10-15 x 5-8 um, sometimes said to be larger, ovate-elliptic, flattened on one side, colorless, germinating by repetition^; PROBASIDIA 15-40 x 5-13 um, "lateral, saccate, oblong-ovoid to elongate, sometimes with 1-3 constrictions", epibasidia "arising from near basal end of hypobasidium, narrow, then abruptly enlarged, finally 45-105 x 4-9 um, the thickened distal portion becoming 3-septate, each of the four cells so formed producing a usually short lateral branch bearing a sterigma and basidiospore", (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Martin, G.W.(1), Ginns(5), Klett(1)
165
FAMILY  Phleogenaceae, Order Atractiellales, Class Atractiellomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helicogloea longispora  G.E. Baker^  Mycologia 38: 634. 1946;  Helicogloea parasitica  Olive
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth as a dull gray mucous-gelatinous coating on fungi such as Exidia glandulosa, Gloeotulasnella spp., or Sebacina spp., 2) elongated fusiform spores with a stout cylindric apiculus, 3) basidial details including the absence of a hypobasidial sac at times, 4) hyphae that are 2-10 um wide, short-celled, contorted, sometimes constricted at septa, with walls of varying thickness, and without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Helicogloea longispora has been found in OR, LA, and NC, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  mucous-gelatinous, inconspicuous when dry; dull gray^, (Baker)
HABITAT  mycoparasitic, on Exidia glandulosa, Gloeotulasnella sp., Sebacina sp., also reported on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 13-15 x 4.5-7.5 um, "subcylindric to fusiform, somewhat tapered at both ends and strongly curved toward the apiculus at the base, with very stout, cylindric apiculus", "germinating by repetition with one or two germ tubes"^; "basidial primordia intercalary or apical", "hypobasidial sac smooth, or more often once or twice constricted", "sometimes missing and then replaced by the swelling of the intercalary primordium", "usually germinating from the primordial portion", epibasidium 65-70 x 5-8 um or more, "producing spores at ends of long filaments, 2.5-3 um diam"; hyphae 2-10 um wide, irregular, contorted, short-celled and sometimes constricted at septa, with walls of varying thickness, (Baker)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with long spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Baker(1), Ginns(5)
166
FAMILY  Phleogenaceae, Order Atractiellales, Class Atractiellomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helicogloea vestita  (Bourdot & Galzin) P. Roberts^  Windahlia 22: 19 (1997) [1995-96];  Platygloea vestita  Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead branches and litter, 2) a fruitbody that is relatively thick, mucoid-gelatinous, grayish or colorless, and covered with a thin, white, felty layer, 3) colorless spores that are oblong-elliptic or subcylindric, 4) basidia that are 1-3-septate, with epibasidia (sterigmata) up to 20 um long, and 5) hyphae that are 8-10 um wide, without clamp connections, producing erect branches, flexuous [wavy] and distinguished by irregular thickenings.^ RANGE ^Helicogloea vestita has been found at least in BC and IA, (Ginns), as well as France, England, and Denmark, (Raitviir). Bandoni(10) notes that the Iowa specimen has smaller basidia, 30-50 x 5-6.5 um, and spores mostly 18-21 x 5-7 um, germinating by repetition. Bandoni(9) comments that 2 collections from BC fit the Bourdot and Galzin description but do not appear conspecific with an Iowa collection by Martin.
FRUITING BODY  "mucoid-gelatinous, effused, thick"; grayish or colorless, almost invisible when dry, clothed with a thin white felty layer^, (Bandoni(10)), "effused in small patches; fairly thick, mucogelatinous or sometimes waxy-gelatinous, greyish hyaline, leaving no trace when dry", (Pearson), widely procumbent, up to 5cm wide, thick, mucous-gelatinous; grayish or colorless, covered with a thin white tomentose layer, (Raitviir) 
HABITAT  on dead branches; on litter^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 15-21-30 x 5-7.5-9 um, oblong-elliptic or subcylindric, obliquely attenuate [narrowing] at the base and laterally depressed^; PROBASIDIA "at first ovoid, then cylindrical, becoming 1-3-septate", basidia 40-50 x 9-10 um, curved, epibasidia at first conic, becoming slender, up to 20 um long; hyphae 8-10 um wide, "without clamp-connections, producing erect branches, flexuous and distinguished by irregular thickenings", 60-100 x 6-10 um, projecting above the surface 40-50 um, (Bandoni(10)), SPORES 15-30 x 5-9 um, mostly about 22 x 6 um, "sublanceolate, depressed on one side, rounded at top"; BASIDIA 40-50 x 6-10 um, at first obovate, then cylindric-clavate, basidia 1-3-septate, with conic epibasidia up to 20 um long, (Pearson), SPORES 16-21 x 5-7 um, oblong-elliptic or almost cylindric, flattened on one side, colorless; BASIDIA 2-4-cellular, 40-50 x 9-10 um, cylindric, bent; HYPHAE 8-10 um wide, without clamp connections, sinuously branched, projecting 40-50 um beyond the fruitbody surface, (Raitviir)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'clothed'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Bandoni(10) (as Platygloea vestita), Pearson(1) (as Platygloea vestita), Raitviir(1) (as Platygloea vestita), Ginns(5) (as Platygloea vestita), Bandoni(9) (as Platygloea vestita)
167
FAMILY  Helminthosphaeriaceae, Order Uncertain, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helminthosphaeria clavariarum  (Desm.) Fuckel^  Jb. nassau. Ver. Naturk. 23-24: 166 (1870) [1869-70]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Helminthosphaeria clavariarum forms a gray to black coating on Clavulina coralloides (caused by formation of their minute fruitbodies), seeming to reduce branching of the tips of the Clavulina, (Trudell). It is found on fruitbodies of Clavulina coralloides (as C. cristata) and C. cinerea, (Dennis). Black dots may be observed in the coating under a hand lens and are visible in larger digital images.^ | The conidial state, which may be found without perithecia, has been called Spadicoides clavariarum. RANGE ^Helminthosphaeria clavariarum on fruitbodies of Clavulina coralloides has been vouchered from WA (for instance WTU-F-000133 as Clavulina cristata from WA at the University of Washington, by S. Trudell). It is casually reported more widely on sight in the Pacific Northwest including BC, and a parasitized collection of Clavulina coralloides (as Clavulina cristata) from BC is at the Pacific Forestry Centre. 
FRUITING BODY  perithecia about 0.03cm across, "scattered over a web of dark brown hyphae, superficial or somewhat embedded in the mat", subglobose [nearly spherical], without a distinct papilla; black, covered with spreading hairs^, (Dennis)
HABITAT  on fruitbodies of Clavulina coralloides (as C. cristata) and C. cinerea, (Dennis)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14 x 6-7 um, broadly fusiform or one-sided, dark brown, non-septate, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, up to 90 x 8 um, cylindric, stalked; paraphyses numerous; some hairs tapering to a point, others cylindric and bearing elliptic, 1-septate, brown conidia, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Clavarias'
SIMILAR  It may be difficult to distinguish Clavulina cinerea macroscopically from parasitized collections of Clavulina coralloides. There is an excellent discussion of this problem in Kuo(7). Helminthosphaeria clavariarum parasitizes both species from the base upwards, rendering them gray to black. 'Under a hand lens, the tiny black dots that form the perithecia of the pyrenomycete can be seen' and under the microscope the differences are obvious. The black dots may be seen on larger digital images. Most Clavulina cinerea fruitbodies, as presented in field guides and on the Internet, 'display grayish to purplish gray (not dark gray or black) colors on the branches and paler surfaces near the base of the mushroom, suggesting that the gray surfaces above do not represent the influence of the parasite, which attacks from the base upward.'. 'However, even if Clavulina cinerea does not (usually) represent parasitization of Clavulina cristata, it may still merely represent a gray and frequently less cristate form or "ecotype" of the latter', (Kuo(7) with Latin names italicized). 
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Trudell(4)* (discussing Clavulina cinerea), Kuo(7)*
168
FAMILY  Filobasidiaceae, Order Filobasidiales, Class Tremellomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Heterocephalacria bachmannii  (Diederich & M.S. Christ.) Millanes & Wedin^  in Liu, Wang, Goker, Groenewald, Kachalkin, Lumbsch, Millanes, Wedin, Yurkov, Boekhout & Bai, Stud. Mycol. 81: 120. 2015;  Syzygospora bachmannii  Diederich & M.S. Christensen  Bibliotheca Lichenologica Band 61: 30. 1996
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Heterocephalacria bachmannii forms minute fruiting bodies on Cladonia and Cladina lichens. The fruitbodies are elongate, roundish, or irregular, colored reddish brown to pale or dark brown, waxy gelatinous in consistency, and identified by microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Diederich(1). RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, and it occurs in Europe, Madeira, and Papua New Guinea, (Diederich(1)), as well as Panama (Diederich(2)).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.5cm long, roundish or more often elongate, often irregular, sometimes tuberculate; waxy to gelatinous; "reddish brown, sometimes pale or dark brown"
HABITAT  on Cladonia lichens, on the podetia, rarely on the primary thallus
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 4.5-6 um, elliptic or oval to almost limoniform [lemon-shaped], "obliquely attached to sterigmata, refractive at the point of attachment"^; BASIDIA, when mature, (2)4-spored, 50-90 x 4-6.5 um, cylindric, aseptate, epibasidia 5-12 um long, 1-2 um wide, subulate [awl-shaped], sterigmata refractive; HYMENIUM colorless, containing numerous probasidia, probasidial initials ellipsoid, proliferations occurring through the basal clamp connection; HYPHIDIA and CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHAE of context, 2-3.5 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "haustorial branches frequent, tremelloid, with clamp connections, mother cell subspherical to ellipsoid", 2.5-4 um in diam, haustorial filament 1-7 um long, 0.5 um wide; anamorph of two kinds: 1) "lunate germination conidia are present in many specimens", 2) catenate conidia with individual conidia subspherical to elongate, 2.5-5 um in diam
NAME ORIGIN  named after Ewald Theodor Bachmann "in recognition of his important contribution to the study of lichen 'galls', including those produced by the new fungus"
SIMILAR  Heterocephalacria physciacearum has basidia 24-55 um (Diederich(1)) and grows on Heterodermia, Physcia, and Physconia lichens, (Diederich(2)). Tremella cladoniae is pinkish brown to reddish brown, is generally confined to the squamules of the primary thallus (but can occasionally also grow on higher parts of the podetia), and differs microscopically, (Diederich(1)). See also SIMILAR section of Carcinomyces effibulatus.
SOURCES  Diederich(1) (as Syzygospora), Diederich(2) (as Syzygospora)
169
FAMILY  Carcinomycetaceae, Order Tremellales, Class Tremellomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Heterocephalacria physciacearum  (Diederich) Millanes & Wedin^  in Liu, Wang, Goker, Groenewald, Kachalkin, Lumbsch, Millanes, Wedin, Yurkov, Boekhout & Bai, Stud. Mycol. 81: 120. 2015;  Syzygospora physciacearum  Diederich  Bibliotheca Lichenologica Band 61: 38. 1996
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Heterocephalacria physciacearum produces minute fruiting bodies on Heterodermia, Physcia, and Physconia lichens. The fruiting bodies are convex often with a constricted base, sometimes with gall formation, colored pinkish, pale brown reddish brown, grayish brown to almost black, the consistency waxy to gelatinous, identified by microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Diederich(1). RANGE ^The distribution includes WA, CA, ON, Ecuador, Austria, Ireland, Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom, Ethiopia, Rwanda, and Papua New Guinea, (Diederich(1)). It also occurs in OR, AK, and ME, (Diederich(2)).
FRUITING BODY  0.01-0.12cm, convex, often with a constricted base, old fruitbodies often tuberculate, sometimes inducing gall formation; waxy to gelatinous; pinkish, pale brown, reddish brown, grayish brown to almost black; fruitbodies sometimes reduced, growing in the hymenium of the host
HABITAT  on Heterodermia, Physcia, and Physconia lichens
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7.5-11 x 3.5-6.5 um, elliptic or oval to almost limoniform [lemon-shaped], obliquely attached to sterigmata, refractive at point of attachment^; BASIDIA when mature (2)3-4-spored, cylindric, 24-55 x 5-7(9) um, rarely subspherical, 9-11 um in diam, epibasidia 5-9 um long, 1.5-2.5 um wide, subulate; HYMENIUM mostly hyaline, sometimes with dark brown, thick-walled hyphae in the outer part with cells 8-15 x 4-9 um, containing numerous probasidia, probasidial initials ellipsoid, proliferation occurring through the basal clamp connection; HYPHIDIA and CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHAE of context 2-3.5 um wide, thin-walled, "clamp connections not observed in most specimens, but frequent in some specimens"; haustorial branches frequent, tremelloid, mother cell subspherical to ellipsoid, 2.5-5 um in diam, haustoria filament 1-8 um long, 0.5 um wide; anamorph: "lunate conidia have been observed in one specimens, asteroconidia in two specimens and catenate conidia are frequent in some specimens"
NAME ORIGIN  "growing on Physciaceae"
SIMILAR  Heterocephalacria bachmannii has basidia 50-90 um long and grows on Cladonia lichens (Diederich(1)). Tremella phaeophysciae Diederich & M.S. Christ. grows on Phaeophyscia orbicularis and has been recorded in Europe, AB, CA, and CO, but not in the Pacific Northwest, (Diederich(2)).
SOURCES  Diederich(1) (as Syzygospora), Diederich(2) (as Syzygospora)
170
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hydnochaete olivacea  (Schwein.) Banker^  Mycologia 6(5): 234. 1914;  Sistotrema olivaceum  Schwein.;  Hydnum olivaceum  (Schwein.) Fr.;  Sistotrema fuscescens  Schwein.;  Hydnoporia fuscescens  (Schwein.) Murrill;  Irpex cinnamomeus  Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  brown-toothed crust
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead branches, often still attached to the trees, 2) fruitbodies that are sometimes bent outward to form a narrow cap up to 0.2cm wide, 3) fruitbodies that are leathery, tightly attached, cinnamon to reddish brown or rusty brown, with surface warted or hydnoid with irregular round to flattened teeth, 4) when old a black line visible next to the substrate, 5) cylindric to allantoid spores, 6) numerous hymenial setae, but no hyphidia or cystidia, and 7) a dimitic hyphal system with skeletal hyphae dominating over generative hyphae, and also some setal hyphae [very thick-walled with greater width and darker walls than skeletal or generative hyphae].^ RANGE ^Hydnochaete olivacea has been found in WA, ID, NB, NS, ON, PQ, AL, AR, CT, FL, GA, IL, IN, KY, LA, MD, ME, MI, MO, MS, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, RI, SC, TN, TX, VA, VT, WI, WV, Mexico, Jamaica, and Ecuador, (Parmasto).
FRUITING BODY  effused or effuso-reflexed [spread out flat but bent outward from substrate to form a cap], cap when present projecting only up to 0.2cm but broad, fruitbody circular, 5-25cm across, closely adnate [tightly attached], coriaceous [leathery], woody when dry; in fertile specimens cinnamon or reddish brown when fresh and fertile, rusty brown in sterile and old specimens, without olive or lilac tint; "warted or hydnoid with irregular, round to flattened teeth", 0.05-0.025cm long, obtuse to incised at top, often antler-like with a fused base, spore-bearing surface not cracked; resupinate margin fibrillose or abrupt, lighter in color, then colored as the rest of the surface, pale cinnamon to rusty brown or ferruginous; tomentum and cortex absent, or cortex present when old as a black zone next to the substrate^, (Parmasto), nearly pore-like at margin but strongly tooth-like elsewhere, teeth up to 0.6cm long, flattened to cylindric, blunt and ragged near tip, bristles numerous over entire surface of the teeth, (Phillips), flesh dark brown or black with KOH (Lincoff)
HABITAT  on "dead branches, often still attached to the trees"^, Acer rubrum (red maple), A. spicatum (Mountain Maple), Alnus incana (Gray Alder), A. rubra (Red Alder), A. viridis ssp. crispa (Mountain Alder), Betula alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), B. lenta (Sweet Birch), B. lutea (Yellow Birch), B. pumila (Bog Birch), Carpinus caroliniana (American Hornbeam), Fagus grandifolia (American Beech), Ligustrum sp. (privet), Ostrya virginiana (Eastern Hophornbeam), Populus sp., Prunus serotina (Black Cherry), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus alba (White Oak), Q. coccinea (Scarlet Oak), Q. marilandica (Blackjack Oak), Q. nigra (Water Oak), Q. rubra (Northern Red Oak), Q. velutina (Black Oak), Salix nigra (Black Willow), (Parmasto), twig; moss-covered or lichen-covered bark, (Ginns), on the underside of dead branches of hardwoods, especially oak, July to October, may persist for years, (Phillips)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 x 1.2-2 um, cylindric to allantoid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 6-12 x 4-5 um, clavate or subclavate; basidioles, hyphidia, and cystidia absent; SETAE "numerous, 60-200 x 8-15 um, projecting to 50 um, fusiform-subulate, with acute tip, straight, naked, without incrustation"; "hyphal system dimitic; setal hyphae present"; generative hyphae 1.5-3 um wide, "yellowish, with thickened walls, moderately branched, with scattered septa", skeletal hyphae dominating, 3-5 um wide, yellow to pale rusty brown, thick-walled or very thick-walled to solid, also a few hyphae of transitional type with very rare septa, "in context and hymenium crystalline matter absent", (Parmasto), SPORES smooth, deposit white, (Phillips)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'olivaceous'
SIMILAR  Hymenochaete species have bristles (setae) which grow from the hymenium, whereas those in Hydnochaete are only found on the teeth, (Lincoff). Irpex lacteus is lighter in color and lacks setae on the flattened teeth, (Lincoff). Most crust-like tooth fungi are fleshy rather than leathery, and lack setae, (Lincoff).
SOURCES  Parmasto(1), Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Ginns(5)
171
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hydnomerulius pinastri  (Fr.) Jarosch & Besl^  Pl. Biol. 3(3): 448. 2001;  Leucogyrophana pinastri  (Fr.) Ginns & Weresub  Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 28: 96. 1976;  == Hydnum pinastri  Fr.;  Odontia pinastri  (Fr.) Quel.;  Merulius pinastri  (Fr.) Burt;  Serpula pinastri  (Fr.) W.B. Cooke;  Merulius irpicinus  Peck;  Merulius atrovirens  Burt;  Serpula atrovirens  (Burt) W.B. Cooke;  Merulius byssoideus  Burt;  Serpula byssoidea  (Burt) W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) effused growth on wood and other substrates, 2) a yellow brown surface that develops low ridges forming a reticulum, then conic spines that are olive-yellow, yellow, or brownish, when fresh bruising red-brown, 3) a margin that is whitish to honey-yellow to brownish yellow, typically matted-cottony, 4) hyphal strands that are common to rare, microscopically composed of few to several wide core hyphae surrounded by narrow, branched hyphae, 5) spores that are broadly elliptic, smooth, (usually) weakly dextrinoid, yellow, cyanophilic, and with a wall about 0.8 um thick, 6) cystidioles that are thin-walled and mostly clavate, and 7) numerous to rare black sclerotia.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, ID, ON, PQ, CA, NC, NY, OH, PA, SC, WI, Puerto Rico, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Sweden, United Kingdom, Uganda, and New Zealand, (Ginns(15)), Hydnomerulius pinastri has also been recorded from OR, AK, AR, AZ, CO, DC, FL, IA, IL, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MO, MT, NE, NH, NM, TN, VA, VT, and WV, (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  4(6)cm x 5(10)cm and up to 0.1(0.2)cm thick, effused, separable from substrate; spore-bearing surface "smooth and yellow-brown when young, then with low ridges which form a reticulum", finally with conic, fluted spines 0.1-0.2cm long "and olive-yellow, yellow or occasionally brownish, when fresh bruising a red-brown color, often drying dark brownish black, finely pruinose to somewhat granular owing to the accumulation of spores, brittle, waxy shiny", older fruitbodies are sometimes a more deeply olive-brown, "apparently because of the presence of a heavy spore deposit"; margin 0.2-0.5(1)cm wide, "whitish or honey-yellow to brownish yellow, typically matted-cottony, sometimes crustose, waxy and translucent"; context "cottony to cobwebby, whitish", soft in distinct contrast with hard, brittle spore-bearing surface and trama; hyphal strands "common to rare, pallid to brown or blackish", in the margin and adjacent to substrate beneath fruitbody; sclerotia numerous to rare, 0.1-0.15cm long, ovoid to broadly oblong-ellipsoid, black^, (Ginns(15)), spore deposit yellowish (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on Abies (fir), Alnus (alder), Corylus (hazel), Larix (larch), Liriodendron (tuliptree), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Umbellularia californica (California-laurel); "Wood and bark; underside of half-decayed log; pulpwood, discarded boards; compost; litter; soil; in greenhouses; cellars; crawl spaces; mushroom bed; associated with a brown rot"^, (Ginns(5)), fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4.8)5-6(7) x 3.6-4.4(4.8) um, broadly elliptic, some broadly oval to nearly round, "the adaxial surface slightly to distinctly flattened", smooth, usually weakly dextrinoid ("but sometimes only the walls of a few spores becoming red-brown"), pale yellow to yellow, cyanophilic, wall about 0.8 um thick^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-38 x 6-7.6 um, clavate to narrowly clavate, sterigmata nearly 5 um long; CYSTIDIOLES numerous, colorless, thin-walled, occasionally projecting 5(10) um, usually clavate or narrowly clavate, 4-7 um wide, "some narrower ones with apices irregularly inflated, forked, or crooked, or with finger-like extensions"; SUBHYMENIUM about 50-70 um thick, the hyphae 2-4 um wide, rather loosely woven, much branched, short-celled, staining with difficulty and may be embedded in a gelatinous matrix, with clamp connections; TRAMAL HYPHAE 5-8(12) um wide, "closely packed, parallel, forming a distinct core in the larger ridges and teeth", colorless, thin-walled, clamp connections scattered and inconspicuous, branches of 2 types: 1) "to hyphae of comparable diameter, these uncommon, arising at an acute angle from the parent hypha and near a septum", and 2) to very narrow hyphae (2-4 um wide), "arising from hyphae on the exterior of tramal core and giving rise to the subhymenium"; CONTEXT HYPHAE 3-8 um wide, woven, colorless "or some next to the substrate with pale yellow to brownish walls", thin-walled, with frequent clamp connections; HYPHAL STRANDS up to 150 um wide, composed of few to several wide (6-12 um wide) core hyphae that are surrounded by numerous, narrow (3-5 um wide), branched hyphae, (Ginns(15))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  No Leucogyrophana species are olive-yellow and distinctly toothed, although confusion may occur with young fruitbodies that are often merulioid without distinct teeth, (Ginns(15)). Leucogyrophana pulverulenta may be similar to poorly developed fruitbodies of H. pinastri, but the spores of L. pulverulenta are slightly longer, the spore-bearing surface is more granulose and brown, the context is thicker, and the tramal hyphae are more interwoven than in H. pinastri, (Ginns(15)).
SOURCES  Ginns(15) (as Leucogyrophana pinastri), Ginns(5) (as Leucogyrophana pinastri), Buczacki(1)*
172
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hydnoporia corrugata  (Fr.) K.H. Larss. & Spirin^  in Miettinen, Larsson & Spirin, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 4: 88. 2019;  Hymenochaete corrugata  (Fr.) Lev.  Ann. Sci. Nat. Bot., Ser. III, 5: 152. 1846;  == Thelephora corrugata  Fr.;  Hymenochaete agglutinans  Ellis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  glue crust
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood species of trees and bushes, 2) fruitbodies that are hard; brownish to grayish often with a reddish or lilac tint; smooth, granulose, or bumpy; and cracked, 3) fine bristles visible on the surface under hand lens, 4) spores that are cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) the fruitbody consisting of 2-3 layers: a) a hymenium (outer layer) of basidia and setae (hyphidia and cystidia absent), b) a context consisting of a setal layer of overlapping rows of setae 35-80(100) x (6)7-15(17) um, projecting to 50(60) um above hymenium, the upper part of each encrusted or rugose, c) a thin dense cortex-like hyphal layer that may be present (but tomentum and true cortex absent).^ RANGE ^Hydnoporia corrugata has been found in WA, ID, MB, NB, NS, ON, PE, PQ, AL, AR, AZ, CT, DC, DE, FL, GA, HI, IL, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MS, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, RI, SC, TN, TX, VA, VT, WI, WV, Costa Rica, Jamaica, Puerto Rico, Argentina, Brazil, Ecuador, Uruguay, Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Switzerland, Ukraine, United Kingdom, Tunisia, Southern Africa, China, Japan, Russia (Siberia), Taiwan, New Zealand, (Parmasto), and Norway (Miettinen - neotype). There are 3 collections from BC at the University of British Columbia.
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached tightly, forming crustose patches 0.01-0.02cm thick and several centimeters to decimeters across, consistency hard, brittle; gray-lilac to brownish lilac; "surface irregularly tuberculate, dull, areolate, with fine bristles under a hand lens (setae)"; "margin filamentous when young, later distinctly bounded"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, "closely adnate, hard when dry", 0.02-0.06cm thick, 0.5-3cm across, then confluent and up to 30cm or more long; brownish or reddish gray, sometimes with rosy tint, or dark brown or blackish, without an olive tint; "smooth or minutely granulose, azonate, minutely irregularly cracked (rarely not cracked)"; margin 0.02-0.07cm wide, thin, indeterminate [not distinct], fibrillose or tomentose, whitish, then colored as the rest of the surface, later as a narrow brown border, (Parmasto), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  found on more than 70 species of trees and bushes, only 2% of specimens on conifers; causes white rot of wood^, (Parmasto), on dead wood of Corylus (hazel), on fallen and standing trunks, fallen and attached branches, according to literature also on Quercus, Fagus, Calluna, Crataegus, Populus, and Betula; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), summer to fall; especially on hazel, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6 x 1.8-2.3 um, "cylindric-elliptic, somewhat curved at the apiculus, smooth", inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-15 x 2.5-4 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; SETAE 40-70 x 6-10 um, thick-walled, subulate [awl-shaped] "with obtuse, usually pale and finely incrusted tips, dark brown, both exserted beyond the hymenium and enclosed in the trama"; HYPHAE monomitic up to 3.5 um wide, "densely interwoven and difficult to see", thin-walled to thick-walled, colorless to brownish, without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 4.5-6.8(7) x 1.5-2.3 um, cylindric, slightly curved; fruitbody consists of 2-3 layers: 1) hymenium of basidia and setae (hyphidia and cystidia absent), 2) context consisting of setal layer, 3) thin dense cortex-like hyphal layer may be present (tomentum and true cortex absent, no dark line representing cortex); BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-22 x 3.5-4 5 um, clavate or subclavate, sterigmata 4-5 um long; SETAL LAYER 200-550 um thick, of overlapping rows of setae, setae numerous, 35-80(100) x (6)7-15(17) um, projecting to 50(60) um above hymenium, conic to almost fusiform, "at base surrounded with a node of agglutinated hyphae, with blunt or almost acute easily broken tip, straight, naked, in upper part always encrusted with scattered amorphous granules or rugose"; CONTEXT HYPHAE compactly agglutinated, erect, or interwoven; BASAL HYPHAL LAYER 10-40 um thick; HYPHAE monomitic, setal hyphae absent, generative hyphae 2.2-4.2 um wide, "brownish to brown, thick-walled, septate, branched"; "in context and hymenium crystalline matter absent", (Parmasto)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'wrinkled' or 'ridged'
SIMILAR  Hymenochaete cinnamomea subspecies spreta differs by the presence of hyphal layer(s) and with long, sharp, never encrusted setae (60)70-120(150) x 5-9(10) um, (Parmasto). |Hymenochaete fuliginosa has hyphidia and has setae that have acute tips that are not encrusted, whereas H. corrugata lacks hyphidia and has setae that have almost blunt tips and in upper part are encrusted with amorphous granules or rugose, (Parmasto). |Hymenochaete curtisii has few setae but the sterile hymenium has numerous hyphidia with hook-like or coiled tips, (Parmasto). |Hymenochaete rubiginosa, Hydnoporia tabacina, and H. curtisii differ in having caps or at least elevated margins, (Parmasto).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)* (as Hymenochaete corrugata), Parmasto(1) (as Hymenochaete corrugata), Ginns(5) (as Hymenochaete corrugata), Buczacki(1)* (as Hymenochaete corrugata), Miettinen(4)
173
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hydnoporia tabacina  (Sowerby) Spirin, Miettinen & K.H. Larss.^  in Miettinen, Larsson & Spirin, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 4: 93 (2019);  Hymenochaetopsis tabacina  (Sowerby) S.H. He & Jiao Yang  in Yang, Dai & He, Mycol. Progr. 15(2/13): 7. 2016;  Pseudochaete tabacina  (Sowerby) T. Wagner & M. Fisch.;  Hymenochaete tabacina  (Sowerby) Lev.;  Auricularia tabacina  Sowerby
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a fruitbody that grows flat on wood or with shingled caps that project up to 1.5cm, 2) caps when present that are zoned, soft-leathery to brittle, zoned, rust brown, grayish brown or dark brown, radiately fibrillose, and silky (bald when old), 3) bristle-like setae visible with a 10x lens on the spore-bearing surface, 4) tissue that blackens in KOH, 5) spores that are cylindric, smooth, and inamyloid, if present, and 6) a fruitbody in 4-5 layers: a) hymenium with setae, basidia, and basidioles but no hyphidia or cystidia, b) setal layer (not always present), c) hyphal layer, d) cortex, and e) tomentum. Most fruitbodies studied lack basidia and spores, but are recognizable due to the presence of tomentum, cortex, and setal hyphae in the context, although the setal hyphae are sometimes quite rare. ^ |Hydnoporia tabacina has been known as Hymenochaetopsis tabacina, Pseudochaete tabacina, and Hymenochaete tabacina. It is not to be confused with Hydnochaete tabacina (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Ryvarden found in southeastern North America. RANGE ^Hydnoporia tabacina has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, NB, NF, NT, NS, ON, PE, PQ, YT, AK, AL, AR, CA, CO, CT, DE, FL, GA, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MT, NC, ND, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OK, PA, RI, SC, TN, UT, VA, VT, WI, WV, WY, Greenland, Mexico, Costa Rica, Panama, Trinidad, Argentina, Guyana, Brazil, Venezuela, Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Ukraine, United Kingdom, Rwanda, Tunisia, Zaire, China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Nepal, Pakistan, Australia, and New Zealand, (Parmasto). A lectotype was chosen from Sweden (Miettinen)
FRUITING BODY  resupinate to semipileate [with projecting caps], forming membranous-leathery patches (capable of being torn), several centimeters to decimeters across, initially as circular discs that become confluent; when caps present (on vertical substrates), they are imbricate [shingled] projecting up to 1cm, the upper surface "tomentose, orange-brown, then gray-brown"; spore-bearing surface (flat on wood or under caps) tobacco brown to rust brown, coffee brown when dry, surface dull, finely tomentose (under 10x lens bristle-like setae are visible), "often with concentric undulations, irregularly tuberculate-verrucose, with fine radial fissures when dry"; margin of spore-bearing area undulating, distinctly lifted, crenate [scalloped], "gold-yellow when young, later ocherish-whitish, brown when old"^, (Breitenbach) |effuso-reflexed or effused [spread out with or without a cap], closely adnate, soft coriaceous [leathery] but brittle when dry, 0.01-0.06(0.07)cm thick; caps when present confluent, imbricate [shingled], dimidiate [roughly semicircular] or broad along substrate with short projection (0.3-1.5cm), cap surface "rust brown, grayish or dark brown", "radiately fibrillose, silky", bald when old, with concentric zones, cap margin "thin, entire, sometimes torn, plicate or crispate, lighter coloured (golden yellow)", colored as cap surface when old; spore-bearing surface (under cap and flat on wood) is "yellowish or golden brown, brownish with grey or slightly rosy tint", then umber, without any lilac tint, "smooth but uneven, usually concentrically zonate and sulcate, sometimes only with some broad zones, rarely tuberculose, radially or plumosely cracked", margin of resupinate part fibrillose or abrupt, lighter colored, then colored the same as the rest of the resupinate part, (Parmasto) |tissue blackens in KOH (Arora) |spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on nearly 155 species of trees and shrubs in North America, hardwoods (Acer, Alnus, Betula, etc., Quercus rare) more commonly than conifers (Thuja, Abies, Larix, etc.)^, (Parmasto), on bark; twig; dead limbs, branch, barkless branches; trunk; on Abies, Acer, Alnus, Amelanchier, Arbutus, Arctostaphylos, Aristolochia, Betula, Castanea, Castanopsis, Ceanothus, Corylus, Fagus, Fraxinus, Holodiscus, Larix, Notholithocarpus, Lyonothamnus, Ostrya, Paxistima, Physocarpus, Picea, Pinus, Populus, Prunus, Pseudotsuga, Quercus, Rosa, Rubus, Salix, Sambucus, Sequoia, Sorbus, Symphoricarpos, Taxus, Thuja, Tsuga, Ulmus, Vaccinium, (Ginns), on dead wood of shrubs and hardwoods, on fallen or attached branches and fallen or standing trunks, of Corylus, Salix, etc., commonly in hedges, on stream banks, and forest edges; throughout the year, normally annual but sometimes old fruitbodies are overgrown by young ones, (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5 x 1.5-2 um, cylindric, slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 17-22 x 3-4.5 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; SETAE 60-90 x 7-12 um, subulate, dark brown, "thick-walled, some finely incrusted toward the tip", exserted beyond the hymenium; HYPHAE monomitic 3-8 um wide, colorless to brownish, branched, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES (4.3)4.5-7 x 1.2-2.2(2.5) um, cylindric, slightly curved; fruitbody in 4-5 layers: 1) hymenium with basidia, basidioles, and setae, but no hyphidia or cystidia, 2) setal layer (not always present), 3) hyphal layer, 4) cortex, and 5) tomentum; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-25 x 3.5-5 um, clavate or subclavate, sterigmata up to 4(5) um long, basidioles 10-14 x 3.5-5 um, without encrustation; setal layer (when present) up to 150(300) um thick, "setae in 2-5 overlapping rows, numerous", (50)60-120(150) x 7-15(16) um, projecting up to 50(70) um, "very rarely bifurcate at base, fusiform, with acute tip, straight or rarely some few slightly curved, naked or enmeshed in hyphal sheaths", finely encrusted with colorless or yellowish amorphous granules or crystals in upper part; "hyphal layer 50-300 um thick, lighter colored than other layers, orange-yellow, hyphae longitudinally loosely to (towards the hymenium) compactly arranged"; cortex (15)20-50 um thick, "hyphae tightly interwoven, thick-walled"; tomentum (20)30-50(100) um thick, "sometimes with a few setal hyphae"; HYPHAE dimitic, "setal hyphae present in hyphal layer but not numerous", 120-250 x 7-13 um, "dark brown, with very thick walls", sometimes absent in young fruitbodies, generative hyphae (2.5)3-5 um wide, "yellowish, thin-walled or with thickened walls, septate, branches usually diverging at a right angle", "skeletoids brown, thick-walled, with scarce septa"; "in context and hymenium crystalline matter absent", (Parmasto)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to tobacco', probably referring to color
SIMILAR  Hymenochaete rubiginosa has 1) consistency that is woody-hard (whereas Hydnoporia tabacina is soft-leathery and when dry brittle), 2) a cap that is velvety but soon bald, (whereas H. tabacina has a cap surface that is radially fibrillose, hairy, bald when very old), 3) a hymenium that is either not cracked or deeply scantily creviced when old, (whereas H. tabacina has a hymenium that is radially or plumosely densely cracked), 4) setae but no setal hyphae, (whereas H. tabacina, as well as having setae, has setal hyphae usually present but scattered, 120-250 um long), (Parmasto). |Hymenochaete cinnamomea is fully resupinate and cinnamon-brown and has a firmly appressed margin, (Breitenbach). |Hydnoporia corrugata has a finely areolate, light gray to brownish spore-bearing surface and smaller spores, (Breitenbach). |H. corrugata and Hymenochaete fuliginosa are fully resupinate, and never bent outwards to form cap, (Parmasto). |Hymenochaete curtisii has few setae but the sterile hymenium has numerous hyphidia with hook-like or coiled tips, (Parmasto). |See also SIMILAR section of Stereum hirsutum.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)* (as Hymenochaete tabacina), Parmasto(1) (as Hymenochaete), Arora(1) (as Hymenochaete), Ginns(5) (as Hymenochaete), Buczacki(1)* (as Hymenochaete), Yang, J.(1) (as Hymenochaetopsis tabacina), Miettinen(4)*
174
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hymenochaete cinnamomea  (Pers.) Bres.^  Atti Imp. Regia Accad. Rovereto, Ser. III, 3: 66.  1897;  == Thelephora cinnamomea  Pers.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth flat on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is cinnamon to dark brown or reddish brown, smooth becoming cracked, 3) bristle-like setae visible with hand lens on surface, 4) spores that are short cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) the fruitbody with three layers: a) a hymenium (outer layer) with basidia, basidioles, and setae, (no hyphidia or cystidia), b) a setal layer with 1-10 rows of setae, and c) a hyphal layer, (next to substrate: cortex and tomentum are not present).^ | In contrast to most species of Hymenochaete, only about a half of the specimens of H. cinnamomea studied have numerous spores (less than that in most Hymenochaete species), (Parmasto(1)). The Parmasto(1) description here is for subspecies spreta. RANGE ^ Hymenochaete cinnamomea subsp. spreta has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, YT, AK, AL, AZ, CA, CO, CT, DC, FL, GA, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, MD, MI, MN, MO, MS, MT, NC, ND, NE, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, SC, TN, UT, VA, VT, WI, WV, Greenland, and Mexico, (Parmasto(1)). Subspecies cinnamomea is found in Cuba, Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Europe (common in all countries), Macaronesia, Northern Africa, West-Central and East Tropical Africa, Southern Africa, Israel, Caucasus, Middle Asia, Siberia, Russian Far East, Turkmenistan, China, Japan, and New Zealand, (Parmasto(1)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, (0.005)0.02-0.1(0.2)cm thick, confluent and then up to 25cm long, loosely adnate and separable, soft but not waxy, coriaceous [leathery] or brittle when dry; cinnamon, then dark sienna to cinnamon umber or reddish brown, ('cinnamon' to 'light brown' or 'brick red'), without an olive or lilac tint; "smooth, azonate, not cracked when very young, then densely, later deeply irregularly cracked"; margin thin, indeterminate [not distinct], later distinct, colored as the spore-bearing surface, (Parmasto, subspecies spreta), resupinate, attached tightly, forming patches 0.01-0.1cm thick and several centimeters to decimeters across, consistency soft, tough, and membranous; "cinnamon-brown, rust-red, also cinnamon-ocher"; smooth, velvety and dull, crustose-membranous, with fine bristles (setae) under a 20x hand lens; margin thin, in part finely filamentous^, (Breitenbach, presumably subspecies cinnamomea), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on wood of numerous species of hardwoods and more rarely conifers; causes a white rot^, (Parmasto), on dead wood on Corylus (hazel), on fallen or standing trunks, and fallen or attached branches, according to the literature more rarely also on other hardwoods and very rarely on conifers; throughout the year; perennial, (Breitenbach, presumably subspecies cinnamomea), all year; often on hazel, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6.5(7) x 1.8-2.8(3.2) um, short cylindric, some slightly curved, or almost elliptic with one side flattened^; FRUITBODY consists of 3 layers: 1) hymenium with basidia, basidioles, and setae, (no hyphidia or cystidia), 2) setal layer, 3) hyphal layer, (cortex and tomentum are not present, and there is no dark line representing cortex); BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-30 x 3.8-6 um, subclavate or subutriform, sometimes with thickened basal walls, sterigmata 4-5 um long, basidioles 15-30 x 3.5-5 um, septate, "usually yellowish, later walls often thickened at base, yellow or brownish and granulose", basidioles may simulate thick-walled hyphidia; SETAE numerous, (60)70-120(150) x 5-9(10) um, projecting to 90 um, subulate [awl-shaped], "usually some slightly curved, naked or enmeshed in hyphal sheaths, without incrustation, tips acute or very sharp", "hyphae between setae vertically arranged, short-celled"; setal layer has 1-10 more or less distinct rows of setae, sometimes between the rows there is a thin intermediate hyphal layer up to 30(60) um thick composed of densely, sometimes partly loosely interwoven hyphae; basal hyphal layer 20-150(250) um thick, lighter in color than setal layers or the same color, hyphae loosely arranged and interwoven; HYPHAE monomitic, setal hyphae absent, generative hyphae 2-4.5 um wide, distinct, "yellow to brownish, with thickened walls, branches diverging at a right angle, with numerous septa"; in hyphal layer, setal layer, and hymenium, crystalline matter absent, (Parmasto, subspecies spreta), SPORES 5-7.5 x 2-3 um, cylindric-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-20 x 3-5 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection (although illustrated without clamp connection); CYSTIDIA none; SETAE 55-95 x 5-7 um, "pointed, thick-walled, brown, both exserted beyond the hymenium and enclosed in the trama"; HYPHAE monomitic 2.5-5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, brown, richly branched, without clamp connections, (Breitenbach, presumably subspecies cinnamomea)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'cinnamon-colored'; 'spreta' means 'despised' or 'scorned'
SIMILAR  Subspecies cinnamomea "differs in having distinctly alternating hyphal and setal layers with hyphal layer 50-200 um thick and composed of loosely interwoven hyphae; hymenial surface is of lighter colour, not cracked or with few cracks" - young specimens of subspecies spreta "lack a thickened setal layer (hymenium) and are of light color": "such specimens are indistinguishable from ssp. cinnamomea", (Parmasto, Latin words italicized). |Hydnoporia corrugata and Hymenochaete fuliginosa lack a hyphal layer, (Parmasto). |Hymenochaete curtisii has few setae but the sterile hymenium has numerous hyphidia with hook-like or coiled tips, (Parmasto). |Hymenochaete rubiginosa, Hydnoporia tabacina, and H. curtisii differ in having caps or at least elevated margins, (Parmasto).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Parmasto(1) (colors in single quotation marks from Kornerup(1) 1967 edition), Ginns(5) (as Hymenochaete spreta and Hymenochaete cinnamomea), Buczacki(1)*
175
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hymenochaete curtisii  (Berk.) Morgan^  J. Cincinnati Soc. Nat. Hist. 10: 197. 1888;  == Stereum curtisii  Berk.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  The distinctive feature is 1) crowded, vertical hyphal tips with hooked, bent, curved, or coiled tips which are unique in Hymenochaete and allow identification in sterile state, but are rare when fruitbody is fertile. Other features include 2) a growth pattern that is flat or bent outward to form a cap that projects up to 0.8cm, the cap brown, and concentrically grooved, 3) a spore-bearing surface that is golden brown, grayish brown, sepia, or umber, smooth to velvety and not cracked, 4) growth on hardwood (usually oak), 5) spores that are cylindric, inamyloid, and colorless, 6) rare setae, and 7) a monomitic hyphal layer.^ RANGE ^Hymenochaete curtisii has been found in WA, OR, MB, AL, AR, AZ, CT, DC, DE, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, MN, MO, MS, NC, ND, NH, NJ, NV, NY, OH, OK, PA, SC, TN, TX, VA, WI, WY, Mexico, Panama, and Puerto Rico, (Parmasto).
FRUITING BODY  "effused to effuso-reflexed or with slightly elevated margins, attached with umbos, adnate but separable, soft or soft coriaceous and flexible but not waxy when dry", 0.01-0.05cm thick, orbicular [circular], confluent and then up to 20cm x 2.5cm; caps when present short and broad, projecting up to 0.8cm, brown ('brownish orange' to 'light brown', later 'grayish'), cap surface concentrically (sometimes indistinctly) sulcate [grooved], sometimes radially fibrillose, silky, bald when old, with zones, margin lighter in color than cap surface ('yellowish brown'); spore-bearing surface (where effused or under caps) golden brown or grayish brown ('yellowish brown' or 'light brown'), (when sterile sepia or vivid umber), without an olive or lilac tint, smooth or velvety, azonate, not cracked; margin of spore-bearing surface cinnamon brown when young, then colored as the rest of the surface; context darker than spore-bearing surface^, (Parmasto)
HABITAT  usually on Quercus (oak) but also on other hardwood species^ (Acer, Betula, Carpinus, Castanea, Fagus, Fraxinus, Gordonia, Juglans, Ligustrum, Populus, Robinia, Sambucus, Ulmus), (Parmasto), bark; twigs; branch; dead branches; rotting limbs, (Ginns)
