NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) a whitish to ochraceous fruitbody that is odontioid, with spines that are conic to nearly cylindric, the tips fringed under a 30x lens, the margin indeterminate and pruinose when young, more clearly demarcated when mature, sometimes with a narrow fibrillose zone, 3) spores that are cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, with droplet(s), 4) sterile hyphal ends in the hymenium that are mostly capitate with apical encrustation but sometimes awl-shaped or torulose, in the tips of the spines obtuse or tapering, in some specimens a few cystidioles seen, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, when young cyanophilic, thickened in the subiculum, spherical swellings on the hyphae of the spine trama often present.^ RANGE ^Hyphodontia quercina has been found in BC, NS, YT, AK, AZ, and IA, (Ginns). It has been found in BC, Italy (Sardinia), Poland, Romania, Spain, Sweden, and Iran, (Langer), and Denmark and Norway, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, usually orbicular [circular] at first, then confluent and effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], ceraceous [waxy] when alive and moist, fibrous and rather tough when dried; whitish then cream and finally ochraceous; odontioid or almost raduloid, the aculei [spines] variable, conic to subcylindric, about 0.2-0.3cm long in mature specimens but often smaller, the tips more or less fimbriate [fringed] under a 50x lens; "subiculum in dried specimens often more or less cracked"; "margin variable, indeterminate and pruinose in young specimens, more determinate in mature ones, sometimes with a narrow, fibrillose sterile zone"^, (Eriksson), effused up to 8cm, adnate; white to cream; with crowded, short teeth that appear fimbriate [fringed] at tips under 30x lens, surface cracking to expose white byssoid [cottony] subiculum which is very thin, soft; margin thinning out, (Gilbertson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed hardwood, with or without bark, mostly on fallen branches or dead but still attached branches^; on all sorts of hardwoods, such as Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Corylus (hazel), Fagus (beech), Malus, Populus, Quercus (oak), Ulmus (elm), (Eriksson), on Acer (maple), Alnus sp., Alnus rubra (Red Alder), Malus pumila (Apple), Prosopis juliflora (Mesquite), Salix sp. (willow), (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-7.5 x 2.5-3 um, cylindric (adaxial side somewhat concave), smooth, thin-walled, with 1 droplet or more than one^; BASIDIA subclavate at first, then subcylindric with suburniform constriction, basally tapering, mostly 25-35 x 4.5-5.5 um, in young hymenia sometimes longer, thin-walled or basally with slightly thickened walls, normally 4-spored, containing several oil droplets, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none but sterile hyphal ends occur, in the hymenium varying in number and mostly capitate with apical encrustation, but also torulose [moniliform] or subulate [awl-shaped], in the tips of the spines obtuse or tapering to almost subulate; in some specimens a few subulate cystidioles are also seen; HYPHAE monomitic, about 2-3 um wide, distinct, with clamp connections, thickened in the subiculum, arranged in parallel fashion in the center of the spines, "irregularly intertwined in the subiculum, in the subhymenium densely and the predominant hyphal direction perpendicular to the hymenial surface"; spherical swellings on the hyphae of the spine trama often present; younger hyphae are cyanophilic, (Eriksson), SPORES 6-7.5 x 2.5-3 um, cylindric-oblong, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 17-20 x 4.5-5.5 um, clavate with median constriction; CYSTIDIA abundant in hymenial layer, 3-5 um wide, "irregularly cylindric or slightly swollen at apex", projecting up to 10 um, smooth or lightly encrusted with coarse crystals; HYPHAE monomitic, subicular hyphae 2.5-4 um wide, loosely interwoven, with frequent branching, moderately thick-walled, with abundant clamp connections, [illustrated lightly encrusted with crystals], (Gilbertson), SPORES 6-8 x 2.5-3.5 um, basidia 25-40 x 4.5-5.5 um, (Langer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to Quercus' (oak), referring to one of its hosts
SIMILAR  Lyomyces crustosus may be similar to young specimens of Hyphodontia quercina (with spines still less than 0.1cm), but L. crustosus has smaller basidia and spores, and has numerous subulate cystidioles, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Gilbertson(2), Ginns(5), Langer(1), Buczacki(1)*
196
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hyphodontia spathulata  (Schrad.) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort. 123. 1968;  == Hydnum spathulata  Schrader;  Radulum  spathulatum  (Schrad.) Bres.;  Odontia spathulata  (Schrad.) Litsch.;  Grandinia spathulata  (Schrad.) Julich;  Hydnum pithyophilum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Hydnum caryophylleum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Hydnum velatum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Hydnum xanthum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Irpex ambiguus  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a cream to ochraceous fruitbody that is odontioid with apically fringed spines that are mostly flattened, but may be conic or subcylindric, incised or denticulate, 3) a variable margin that is often well demarcated with a whitish, narrow sterile zone, fringed under a lens, 4) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) cystidial organs of 2 types: a) capitate hyphal ends with apical resinous encrustation, and b) sparse gloeocystidia, acute, with one or more constrictions, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, the projecting hyphae in the tips of the spines generally tapering, with attached aggregated crystals.^ RANGE ^Hyphodontia spathulata has been found in BC, MB, NB, NS, ON, PE, AZ, CO, FL, IA, IN, MD, MI, MN, NC, NM, NY, SC, and WI, (Ginns). Distribution includes AZ, MN, NY, Austria, Italy, Poland, Spain, Sweden, and Taiwan, (Langer), and Czechoslovakia (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], creamish to ochraceous; odontioid with dense aculei [spines] of variable shape, mostly flattened, but may be conic or subcylindric, incised or denticulate [finely toothed], apically fimbriate when intact, about 0.1-0.2cm long, on vertical substrate sometimes longer; margin variable, often determinate [well demarcated] with a whitish, narrow sterile zone, fimbriate [fringed] under lens^, (Eriksson), annual, resupinate, effused up to 15cm; cream; becoming hydnaceous, the spines "tending to become flattened, often branched at the tip, crowded", up to 0.1cm long; "subiculum thin, cream-colored", (Gilbertson), teeth up to 0.2cm long (Langer)
HABITAT  on decayed wood especially of conifers but also of hardwoods^, (Eriksson), on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Juniperus (juniper), Malus pumila (Apple), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); on bark; dead barkless branches; piece of wood; "associated with a white rot and a soft spongy white rot", (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 3.5-4 um, elliptic, smooth, thin-walled, with 1 to 3 droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, at first subclavate, then subcylindric with suburniform constriction, 12-20 x 4-5 um, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIAL ORGANS of 2 types: 1) sterile, capitate hyphal ends frequently occurring in the hymenium, 25-50 um long to the most distal septum, with apical resinous encrustation, and 2) gloeocystidia, sparse in the hymenium, 20-35 um long, acute, thin-walled, "with one or more constrictions and dense, strongly stainable protoplasm"; HYPHAE monomitic, distinct, somewhat thick-walled, 2.5-3.5 um wide, richly branched, irregularly interwoven in the subiculum, arranged in parallel fashion in the spine trama, cyanophilic; projecting hyphae in the tips of the spines general tapering, with attached aggregated crystals, (Eriksson), SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 4-5 um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-17 x 4-5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIOLES up to 34 um long and 4.5 um wide, capitate, also some rare moniliform elements in hymenium, up to 30 um long and 5 um wide, staining brightly in phloxine; HYPHAE monomitic, subicular hyphae "thin to firm-walled", with clamp connections at all septa, often branched, 2.5-4 um wide, (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'spatulate', from Greek 'spathe', meaning a broad flat tool, perhaps referring to the flattened spines
SIMILAR  Flattened spines are a useful character, but if not present, confusion may occur with other Hyphodontia species, for example Hyphodontia granulosa which generally has shorter spines and different projecting hyphae, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Gilbertson(5), Ginns(5), Langer(1)
197
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hyphodontia subalutacea  (P. Karst.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 104. 1958;  == Corticium subalutacea  P. Karst.;  Peniophora subalutacea  (P. Karst.) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Grandinia subalutacea  (P. Karst.) Julich;  Kneiffia subalutacea (P. Karst.) Bres.  Annls mycol. 1(2): 104. 1903 (proposed current name);  Kneiffiella subalutacea (P. Karst.) Julich & Stalpers  Verh. K. ned. Akad. Wet., tweede sect. 74: 131. 1980 (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed wood, 2) a thin, whitish to lurid yellow fruitbody, soft and fibrous in consistency, porose-reticulate or somewhat furfuraceous under 50x lens, bristly from projecting cystidia, the margin thinning out, and the periphery often pruinose, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia that are numerous, long-cylindric, constricted in places and sometimes with secondary septa without clamp connections, thick-walled except in the distal part, the projecting part with resinous encrustation that dissolves in mounting media, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed September 12, 2020, listed the current name as Kneiffia subalutacea, but MycoBank, accessed on the same date, listed the current name as Kneiffiella subalutacea. RANGE ^Hyphodontia subalutacea has been found in BC, WA, ID, NS, ON, PQ, AL, AZ, CO, GA, IL, LA, MD, MI, MN, NC, NM, NJ, NY, UT, and WI, (Ginns). The distribution includes BC, Argentina, Finland, France, Italy, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Turkey, United Kingdom, Kenya, Taiwan, (Langer), and Denmark, (Eriksson), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], thin (about 0.01cm), creamish white or lurid yellow when young and alive, "darkening to ochraceous or tan when old and dried"; "porose-reticulate or somewhat furfuraceous under the lens, pilose by the projecting cystidia"; "margin mostly indeterminately thinning out, in the periphery often pruinose"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, attached tightly, forming thin, membranous-crustose patches several centimeters across, consistency soft, fibrous; white when young, later and also when dry cream to ocherish; "reticulate-porous, dull and farinose to slightly tuberculate"; margin diffuse, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood, especially of conifers, several times on hardwood, especially of trees that normally grow mixed in conifer forest, such as Betula (birch) and Salix (willow)^, (Eriksson), on the undersides of rotten trunks and branches of conifers, according to the literature also on hardwoods; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak); decaying wood; twig; log; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8 x 1.5-2 um, allantoid, smooth, thin-walled^; spores and basidia may be smaller in old fruitbodies than in young ones; BASIDIA at first subclavate, then subcylindric with suburniform constriction, thin-walled except for the basal part that is somewhat thickened, 12-20 x 3-4 um, normally 4-spored, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA numerous, usually 80-150 um but may reach 200 um or more, width 5-7 um, long-cylindric or somewhat widening in the apical direction, more or less constricted in places and sometimes with secondary septa without clamp connections, thick-walled except in the distal part, "projecting part normally with a resinous encrustation, which, however, normally dissolves in the mounting media"; HYPHAE monomitic; subicular hyphae 2-3 um wide, distinct, richly branched and irregularly interwoven, cyanophilic, with thin or slightly thickened walls, with clamp connections; "subhymenial hyphae thinner and more densely united with predominantly vertical hyphal direction", (Eriksson), SPORES 6.5-8 x 1.5-2 um, narrowly cylindric, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 14-18 x 3-4 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA up to 130 x 6-7 um, (according to the literature up to 200 um long), projecting a long way, long-cylindric, thick-walled, thin-walled toward apex, some with secondary septa; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, strongly branched, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Kneiffiella cineracea has thinner, grayish white fruitbodies and broader, shorter spores, (Eriksson). Kneiffiella floccosa is distinguished by the odontioid spore-bearing surface with cystidia developing in the tips of the spines, whereas H. subalutacea is normally smooth or almost so with scattered cystidia, but there are forms of H. subalutacea "which under the lens appear to have a slightly furfuraceous or floccose hymenium", (Eriksson). 
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Langer(1), Buczacki(1)*
198
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypochnicium bombycinum  (Sommerf.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 101. 1958;  == Thelephora bombycina  Sommerf.;  Corticium bombycinum  (Sommerf.) P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, less commonly on conifer wood, 2) a tightly attached fruitbody, colored whitish, the surface smooth to tuberculate, and the margin fimbriate, 3) spores that are oval, smooth, inamyloid, cyanophilic, and thick-walled, and have internal droplets or granular content, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the septa with clamp connections.^ | Hypochnicium bombycinum is the type of the genus but does not appear closely related to Hypochnicium punctulatum and Hypochnicium sphaerosporum (Justo(6)). RANGE ^Hypochnicium bombycinum has been found in WA, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AK, AZ, CO, FL, MA, MI, MN, NM, NY, TN, TX, and VT, (Ginns). Distribution includes Switzerland (Breitenbach), Norway, Sweden, and Germany, (Julich), and Denmark (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, forming crustose patches several centimeters to decimeters across, 0.02-0.05cm thick (according to the literature up to 0.25cm thick), attached loosely to substrate, consistency soft, wax-like, when dry somewhat fissured; whitish, cream, to yellowish; slightly uneven to tuberculate (according to the literature also with pointed spines up to 0.15cm long = var. irpicoides); margin filamentous^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, varying in thickness, mostly 0.01-0.05cm (but vigorously growing specimens may be several millimeters thick), often becoming large (several square decimeters), adnate [tightly attached] and separable only in pieces, spore-bearing surface continuous (when mature and dried, more or less cracked); "white, often hygrophanous when young and wet, when old turning yellowish and at last pale ochraceous"; "smooth or tuberculate, sometimes projecting hyphae giving a hispid or more or less hydnoid appearance"; sterile margin usually fibrillose but varying in growth circumstances, sometimes fruitbody spore-bearing throughout, (Eriksson), membranaceous, adnate; about cream-colored; even or sometimes warted; margin fimbriate; rhizomorphs lacking, (Julich), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead hardwood, on fallen and standing trunks and fallen and attached branches, all with or without bark, according to the literature more rarely on conifers, fall^, (Breitenbach), on all sorts of hardwood, mostly on fallen logs but also on stumps, standing trunks, dead hanging branches and so on, less common on coniferous wood, (Eriksson), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prosopis, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Sambucus (elder); bark of live and dead species; dead barkless branches; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8.5-11.5 x 6-8 um, oval, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, cyanophilic, thick-walled, with droplets or granular content^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-60 x 7-10 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-5 um wide, cyanophilic, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 9-11 x 6-8 um, elliptic or ovoid ("Most of the spores are evenly ellipsoid but there is always a number of ovoid spores, i.e. the tangents to the central parts of the spores are not parallel but meet at a sharp angle"), smooth, inamyloid, cyanophilic, thick-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored (normally), 45-65 x 6-8 um, "at first narrowly clavate, when mature more or less constricted and sinuous", containing numerous oil droplets, sterigmata conic and somewhat curved; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-5 um wide, distinct, thin-walled to rather thick-walled, with clamp connections, richly branched from or close to clamp connections, cyanophilic, SUBICULAR HYPHAE "forming an open texture of more sparsely branched hyphae, next to the substrate more or less parallel, otherwise mainly descending", SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE "thinner, forming a denser texture with predominantly vertical hyphae", (Eriksson), SPORES 8-11 x 6-8 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, often weakly cyanophilic, distinctly thick-walled (0.4-0.8 um), mostly with 1 or 2 droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-45 x 7-9 um, clavate, somewhat flexuous [wavy], thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, colorless, containing oil droplets, with clamp connection at the base, sterigmata about 4-5 x 0.8-1 um; CYSTIDIA lacking but in compact fruitbodies HYPHIDIA may be present; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-6 um wide, colorless, thin-walled to thick-walled (up to 0.8-1.2 um), with clamp connections at septa, or rarely some secondary septa lacking clamp connections, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'silken', 'bombyx' is Latin for silkworm
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Julich(1), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*, Justo(6)
199
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypochnicium geogenium  (Bres.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 101. 1958;  == Corticium geogenium  Bres.;  Peniophora albostraminea  Bres.;  Corticium albostramineum  (Bres.) Overh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a waxy, soft fruitbody that is white to cream, the surface smooth or with scattered warts and farinose-tomentose, the margin distinct to diffuse, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, thick-walled, and cyanophilic, 4) cylindric, projecting cystidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Hypochnicium geogenium has been found in ID, MB, NS, NT, PQ, AZ, CA, NC, and NM, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, tightly attached, forming thin, more or less continuous expanses several centimeters across, consistency wax-like, soft; white to cream; surface smooth or with scattered warts, farinose-tomentose, when dry somewhat fissured; margin distinctly bounded to diffuse^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, adnate [tightly attached], about 0.01-0.03cm thick, ceraceous [waxy] when fresh and alive, membranaceous when dried; white, later becoming yellowish white; more or less tuberculate, on drying smoothing out; margin "not especially differentiated", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on the underside of rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers; the winter half of the year^, (Breitenbach); on decayed wood of conifers and hardwoods, rarely on soil, (Eriksson); Abies (fir), Alnus (alder), Juglans (walnut), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar); wood and bark; moss-covered wood, (Ginns), on damp soil and mud and rotting hardwood especially gorse; fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-7.5 x 4.5-5.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, cyanophilic, thick-walled, some with 1-2 droplets in protoplasm^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 5-6 um, narrowly clavate, somewhat sinuous, with basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA 100-140 x 7-8 um, cylindric, smooth, clearly projecting beyond the hymenium; HYPHAE monomitic, 3.5-4.5 um wide, most septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 6-7.5(9) x 4-4.5(5.5) um, elliptic with mostly parallel sides, smooth, inamyloid, cyanophilic, thick-walled, one or sometimes two oil droplets in protoplasm, small apiculus; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 5-6 um, "clavate, somewhat sinuous when mature", with oil droplets in protoplasm, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA numerous, 80-125(150) x 6-8 um, projecting 20-40 um, subcylindric, thin-walled, "filled with homogeneous, yellowish protoplasm"; HYPHAE monomitic, thin-walled or basal hyphae somewhat thick-walled, with clamp connections, 3-4(5) um wide, "subicular texture open, consisting of richly and irregularly branched hyphae", "subhymenial hyphae densely united", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'born (formed) on earth'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
200
FAMILY  Podoscyphaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypochnicium punctulatum  (Cooke) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 101. 1958;  == Corticium punctulatum  Cooke;  Peniophora peckii  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, also on soil, 2) wax-like, soft fruitbodies colored whitish, the surface porous to smooth, slightly verrucose or tuberculate, the margin bounded to diffuse, 3) spores that are broadly elliptic, bluntly verrucose, inamyloid, cyanophilic, and thick-walled, 4) long thin-walled cystidia that project somewhat, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Hypochnicium punctulatum has been found in WA, ID, AZ, FL, MA, MI, NJ, NM, NY, SC, and WI, (Ginns). Distribution includes, Sweden, Denmark, and central Europe eastwards, (Eriksson), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, forming thin, +/- connected patches several centimeters across, consistency wax-like, soft; white to cream; dull, "porous to smooth, also slightly verrucose"; margin +/- bounded to diffuse^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, 0.01-0.03cm thick, adnate [tightly attached], "at first porose, then continuous"; white (or in the herbarium creamish); "more or less tuberculate, after drying smooth"; "margin not especially differentiated", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, fall^, (Breitenbach), on decayed wood, mostly of conifers, also on soil, (Eriksson), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Ceanothus, Juniperus (juniper), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Sageretia wrightii (Wright's Mock Buckthorn), Simmondsia chinensis (Jojoba), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), "angiosperm, rarely gymnosperm"; bark and wood; rotten logs; bare ground in woods; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), fall, winter, spring; also rotting polypore fruitbodies, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-8.5 x 6-6.5 um, broadly elliptic, bluntly verrucose, inamyloid, colorless, cyanophilic, thick-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 27-40 x 5.5-7 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA 80-140 x 5-10 um, projecting somewhat, smooth; HYPHAE monomitic, 4-5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES (5)5.5-6.6(7.5) x 4.5-5 um, broadly elliptic or nearly round, finely verrucose or echinulate, cyanophilic, thick-walled, containing one droplet; BASIDIA 30-40 x 6-7 um, "narrowly clavate, more or less sinuous and often somewhat constricted", "normally with 4 sterigmata and a basal clamp"; CYSTIDIA numerous, 70-150 x 7-10 um, "projecting in young fruitbodies, enclosed to slightly projecting in mature ones", yellowish (in fresh material), mostly thin-walled, "sometimes with 1-2 simple secondary septa, protoplasm homogeneous"; HYPHAE monomitic, 4-5 um wide, colorless, usually thin-walled but basal ones may be rather thick-walled, "texture of subiculum varying with age and growth conditions, from loose and open with distinct hyphae to dense with rather indistinct hyphae", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'finely punctate'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
201
FAMILY  Podoscyphaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypochnicium sphaerosporum  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 101. 1958;  == Peniophora sphaerospora  Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead wood, 2) a somewhat waxy fruitbody colored whitish, the surface porose at first, more or less tuberculate, the margin not especially differentiated, 3) spores that are round to nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, cyanophilous, and thick-walled, 4) numerous cylindric to subfusiform cystidia that are smooth, thin-walled, with homogeneous, colorless or somewhat yellowish contents, projecting when young, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Hypochnicium sphaerosporum has been found in OR, AZ, MN, NM, and TN, (Ginns), and also in Europe including Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, 0.01-0.03cm thick, subceraceous [somewhat waxy], at first porose then continuous; "white or in the herbarium yellowish, argillaceous or pale ochraceous"; "more or less tuberculate, when dried almost smooth and membranaceous"; "margin not especially differentiated, in young specimens indeterminately thinning out"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, "forming waxy-membranous patches" several centimeters across, "attached closely to the substrate", consistency wax-like, soft; whitish to cream; surface porous-arachnoid [porous-cobwebby] when young, +/- tuberculate-verrucose when older; "margin distinctly bounded, slightly filamentous when young", (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on decayed hardwood or conifer wood^, Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Corylus (hazel), Quercus (oak), Pinus (pine), (Eriksson), on dead wood of conifers and hardwoods, fall-winter, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus, Pinus, Tsuga (hemlock), Ulmus (elm); associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-7.5 um in diameter, round to nearly round, smooth, cyanophilous, thick-walled, contents vary from grainy with small oil droplets to one rounded oil droplet or irregular oil body^; BASIDIA 25-35 x 6-8 um, "subclavate, more or less sinuous or constricted", "with normally 4 sterigmata and a basal clamp"; CYSTIDIA numerous, 50-200 um long, "varying with the thickness of the fruitbody, but mostly 80-100 um", 6-12 um wide, "projecting in young fruitbodies but in the mature ones enclosed, cylindric to subfusiform", smooth, thin-walled, with homogeneous, colorless or somewhat yellowish contents; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-4 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "texture variable, from very dense with indistinct hyphae to a rather open context at least in the basal part with rather distinct hyphae", (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5 x 3-3.5 um [note measurements larger above in Eriksson(4)], nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, cyanophilic, thick-walled, with droplets; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 25-30 x 5-6 um, narrowly clavate, "in part somewhat constricted", with basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA 80-100 x 5-7 um, cylindric to slightly fusiform, smooth, thin-walled to thick-walled, sometimes with one septum; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-4 um wide, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with spherical spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5)
202
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypocrea pulvinata  Fuckel  ^Jb. nassau. Ver. Naturk. 23-24: 185 (1870) [1869-70];  == Hypocrea karsteniana  Niessl in Rehm;  == Hypocrea fungicola  (P.  Karst.) Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include flat to cushion-shaped, orangish yellow to grayish or brownish fruitbodies growing on polypores, up to several centimeters across, with visible small openings and hairs on the surface.^ | The description is derived from Overton(1). RANGE ^Hypocrea pulvinata sensu stricto collections were examined from WA, NH, NY, UT, Austria, Finland, Germany, Luxembourg, Poland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, and the distribution includes Japan, (Overton(1)). There are collections from BC and OR at the University of British Columbia and a collection from WA at Oregon State University.
FRUITING BODY  cushion-shaped or lying flat, single to confluent, covering areas 0.2-6cm across; "orangish yellow to greyish orange, sometimes brownish yellow to golden-yellow, or brown-yellow"; KOH+ but variable, sometimes weak, generally becoming orange or red; openings of ostioles visible on surface, hairs present on surface
HABITAT  on a variety of polypores including Laetiporus sulphureus, Fomitopsis pinicola, Piptoporus betulinus, and Ganoderma spp.
MICROSCOPIC  part-ascospores colorless, smooth to minutely spinulose, thin-walled, generally monomorphic and longer than broad, distal part elliptic, sometimes nearly round, (2.8)3.7-4.7(6.0) x (2.3)2.9-3.7(4.6) um, proximal part elliptic, sometimes nearly round, (2.8)3.8-5(6.7) x (2.3)2.8-3.8(4.7) um^; asci cylindric, (44)66-90(115) x (2.8)3.6-5.2(7.9) um, cylindric, tip slightly thickened, containing 8 two-celled uniseriate ascospores (appearing like a line of 16); warted hairs at surface of stromata, "tissue immediately below the stroma surface formed of compact to loose pseudoparenchymatous cells", textura globulosa to t. angularis; perithecia "numerous and completely immersed in the stromata, generally widely spaced but compact near the centre", ellipsoidal, (189)206-246(275) um long (including length of ostiolar canal), width of perithecia near the base 3/4 total length of perithecium; length of ostiolar canal (36)48-72(82) um; width of ostiolar canal (29)43-63(72) um; perithecial wall KOH+, reaction variable, usually brownish orange
NAME ORIGIN  means 'cushion-shaped'
SIMILAR  Hypocrea americana and Hypocrea protopulvinata are closely related and the habitat is on polypores in both cases. H. americana has part-ascospores that are subglobose to rhomboidal, measuring (1.7)2.63.8(6.2) x (2.4)3.24.2(5.4) um. Collections were examined by Overton(1) from AZ, NH, NM, and NY. Hypocrea protopulvinata has dimorphic smooth spores with the distal part nearly round, (3)3.3-3.9(4.3) x (2.6)3-5(4.2) um, and the proximal part elliptic, sometimes nearly round, (3.2)3.6-4.2 (4.8) x (2.4)2.7-3.3(3.8) um. Collections were examined by Overton(1) from MD, NY, OH, and Japan. Hypocrea citrina (Pers) Fr. sensu Overton et al. is also closely related but is white to yellow and grows flat on leaf litter, soil, bark, or moss. The part-ascospores have spinulose ornamentation, with the distal part nearly round, sometimes subelliptic, (3.2)4.1-5.2(6.3) x (2.9)3.7-4.8(5.7) um, and the proximal part elliptic, sometimes nearly round to ovate, (3.3)4.4-6(7.1) x (2.5)3.3-4.9(6.3) um. H. citrina has been reported from the Pacific Northwest but the sense is unknown: the name has often been used with the synonym Hypocrea pulvinata to cover both fruitbodies that grow on polypores and those that grow elsewhere. Collections were examined by Overton(1) from GA, KY, NC, NY, OH, and Europe, and the range includes Japan. Hypocrea rufa has been reported by Oluna Ceska from British Columbia (collections at the University of British Columbia) and a collection from Washington is at the New York Botanical Garden. Fruitbodies are red-brown (with the margin white when young), hemispherical to plate-like, and grow on damp wood or wet bark, or occasionally on old fungi or other plant remains. Hypocrea gelatinosa has cushions up to 0.2cm with dark green spots (because of spores) on a pale yellowish background and grows on wood. Hypocrea aureoviridis has disc-shaped bright yellow to brownish fruitbodies up to 0.5cm across, and also has dark green spots. Both of these have been reported from British Columbia by Oluna Ceska (collections at the University of British Columbia). O. Ceska has also deposited at the University of British Columbia a collection from British Columbia of Hypocrea moravica on a rotting branch of Alnus rubra (on bark and branchlet portions). Hypocrea patella has yellow plate-like fruitbodies on wood (with a definite border) - collections from British Columbia at the University of British Columbia are identified as this species.
SOURCES  Overton(1)*, Breitenbach(1)*, Barron(1)*, Seaver(6) (as H. citrina), Hansen, L.(1)
203
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces aurantius  (Pers.) Tul.^  Ann. Sci. Nat. Ser. IV. Bot. 13: 12. 1860;  Hypomyces subaurantius  Heinr.-Norm.;  Hypomyces cesatii  (Mont.) Tul. & C. Tul.;  Nectria cesatii  Mont.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) an orange layer growing over polypores and other fungi, turning violet to purplish red in KOH, 2) orange red perithecia (flasks) forming small pimples on surface, turning purple red in KOH, and 3) ascospores that are two-celled, verrucose, apiculate, and usually less than 25 um in length.^ | The associated anamorph is Cladobotrum varium Nees. RANGE ^Hypomyces aurantius is common in north and south temperate regions of the world (Poldmaa). There are collections at the University of British Columbia from BC, OR, IA, and New Zealand. There are collections at the University of Washington from WA, CA, and ON. It was examined from Switzerland, Ukraine, and New Zealand, (Rogerson). It has been recorded from North America (including CA), Cuba, Europe (including Estonia, Switzerland, Ukraine, and the United Kingdom), China, Japan, Kazakhstan, the Russian Far East, Uzbekistan, Eastern Asia, and Australasia (including New Zealand), (Poldmaa).
FRUITING BODY  effuse [spread out], floccose, often covering entire host, occasionally spreading over adjacent substrate; "typically yellowish-orange, orange, red to rusty-red, varying from almost white to buff, through many shades of orange and red", turning violet to purplish red in KOH; perithecia "pale yellow to golden yellow, orange or red, turning purplish in 3% KOH"^, (Rogerson), subiculum profuse, texture hyphal, color white or orange, turning purple in KOH; perithecia orange, turning purple in KOH, "formed all over or only in some parts of the subiculum, gregarious or in some specimens caespitose, semi-immersed in the subiculum"; anamorph in nature "easily recognized through the profuse pure white cottony mat", powdery appearance is due to the conidia, (Poldmaa)
HABITAT  on "many members of the Aphyllophorales, particularly species of Polyporaceae" (polypores), "also on a few members of the Agaricales", "occasionally found on adjacent nonfungous substrates after initially starting on a fungus"^, (Rogerson), growing on fruitbodies of fungi, wood or bark, or occasionally on litter, mosses or ground, next to decayed agarics; covering host's spore-bearing surface or also host's cap, host fruitbody becoming decayed or with no apparent change; hosts belonging to Agaricales (mostly wood-decaying species), Aphyllophorales or rarely Heterobasidiomycetes: Armillaria, Auricularia, Bjerkandera, Cerrena, Clitocybe, Collybia, Coltricia, Cystoderma, Flammulina, Fomes, Fomitopsis, Inonotus, Irpex, Laetiporus, Lenzites, Panus, Phaeolus, Phellinus, Piptoporus, Pleurotus, Polyporus, Ramaria, Schizophyllum, Schizopora, Stereum, Trametes, Trichaptum, (Poldmaa)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (13)20-25(27) x (3)4-6(7.5) um, fusiform to lanceolate, verrucose (verrucae <=0.5 um high), apiculate (apiculi 2-4.5 um long, acute), 2-celled^; ASCUS 100-140 x 6-7 um, cylindric to clavate, "apex thickened and with a pore"; PERITHECIUM 250-575 x 200-375 um (mostly 350 x 300 um), spherical to ovate or obpyriform, gregarious, "pale yellow to golden yellow, orange or red, turning purplish in 3% KOH", "papillate, papilla typically not well differentiated, when distinctive then 150-200 um wide, 75-100 um high"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 4-6 um wide, "much branched and often at right angles, septate, smooth", thin-walled, cells often becoming much enlarged and thick-walled, "up to 10-12 um wide with wall 1-1.5 um thick", loosely interwoven; CONIDIA (8.5)10-16(21) x 5-7.5(10) um, at first round or nearly round, becoming elliptic or oboval, (0)1-septate, "with a basal hilum and often with refractive material at the apex", "produced singly and held end to end in dry chains", Blastotrichum-like chlamydospores 18-48 x 12-18 um, oblong-oval, "1-4 celled, constricted at septa", pale brown to reddish brown, thick-walled, wall 1-3 um thick; conidiogenous cells "30-65 um long, 1.5-3 um at base tapering slightly to the tip", conidiogenous apex apical, "proliferating retrogressively and percurrently, periclinal thickening not observed"; CONIDIOPHORES "arising in the aerial mycelium, indefinite in length", main axis about 4 um wide, "verticillately branched with three or more branches arising at one point and occasionally repeatedly verticillate", "branches sparingly septate or aseptate, each terminating in a single conidiogenous cell", (Rogerson), SPORES 20-25 x 4-6 um, fusiform, verrucose (verrucae arranged uniformly, 0.5 um high), ends apiculate (apiculi 2-4.5 um long, with acute tips), 1-septate (septum median); ASCUS 100-160 x 6-7 um, "with apex thickened, penetrated by a pore"; PERITHECIUM (250)350-570 x 200-375 um, orange, "KOH reaction with the whole perithecium turning purple", perithecial papillae 75-100 um high, 150-200 um wide at base (tip obtuse), "of pseudoparenchymatous texture, with cells in divergent files, becoming narrower toward the ostiolar canal and more rounded towards the outer surface"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 4-6 um wide (becoming swollen), loosely interwoven; CONIDIA (10)12-17(25) x (5)6-8(10) um, elliptic to cylindric or oboval, "equilateral, with a central basal hilum", colorless, 1-septate, very rarely also 2-3-septate; conidiogenous locus "proliferating retrogressively, percurrently, forming up to 50 conidia that are held in end-to-end chains"; conidiogenous cells by 2-5(7) in a verticil, 30-65(80) um long, 3-5 um wide at base, attenuating to 2-3 um at tip, "proliferating retrogressively, forming 1 conidiogenous locus"; CONIDIOPHORES "arising from aerial hyphae, hardly or not differentiated from these", 4-7 5m wide, branching irregular to verticillate; aerial mycelium scanty; thick-walled cells "formed in terminal position on lateral branches or intercalarly on aerial or submerged hyphae", yellow or pale brown, with cells 12-20 um in diameter, subspherical to spherical, held by 3-4, "wall 1-3 um thick, smooth", (Poldmaa)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'orange'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Hypomyces rosellus.
SOURCES  Poldmaa(2), Rogerson(2), Breitenbach(1)*, Redhead(5), Trudell(4)*
204
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces cervinigenus  Rogerson & Simms^  Mycologia 63: 416. 1971;  Hypomyces cervinus  Tul. & C. Tul.  Select. fung. carpol. (Paris) 3: 51. 1865 (proposed old name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a white covering formed on Helvella species, the covering becoming pinkish brown to cocoa brown, 2) an anamorph that is common, and forms two kinds of asexual spores, and a teleomorph that is rare (with asci and ascospores), 3) ascospores that are less than 25 um long (with acute not apiculate ends), smooth, and 2-celled, and 4) perithecia that are waxy, and white to pale buff.^ | The current name in the online Species Fungorum, accessed September 6, 2017 and September 12, 2022, was Hypomyces cervinus Tul. & C. Tul. but the current name on MycoBank, accessed the same day, was Hypomyces cervinigenus Rogerson & Simms. RANGE ^The type is from WA. Distribution and records include BC, WA, Europe (including Estonia, Germany, Netherlands, Norway), Japan, Kazakhstan, (Poldmaa), and CA (MykoWeb). There is a collection from AK at the University of Washington.
FRUITING BODY  a soft, tomentose to finely pubescent mould-like covering, "white, becoming pinkish to cream-buff", powdery when old, parasitizing stem and cap tissue of the host^, (MykoWeb), subiculum white, not changing color in KOH, texture hyphal; the anamorph in nature "starts as a white mycelium that during the production of chlamydospores turns into powdery cocoa-brown layer that usually expands over the whole fruitbody of the host", (Poldmaa), subiculum "white, at first loose and cottony, becoming compacted into a mat" (as perithecia appear), perithecia separate to densely compacted in patches up to 1 square centimeter, "usually with base immersed in host tissue", when fresh white and translucent with a waxy appearance, when dry and when old light yellow, buff, or amber, (Rogerson)
HABITAT  parasitic on Helvella species, especially Helvella lacunosa; fruiting from mid to late winter^, (MykoWeb), growing on fungi; hosts belonging to Pezizales: Helvella spp., including H. elastica, H. ephippium, and H. lacunosa; covering cap of host or both cap and stem; host's fruitbody becomes decayed, (Poldmaa)
MICROSCOPIC  two types of asexual SPORES: 1) aleuriospores 13.5-17.5 um in diameter including ornamentation, round, spiny, thick-walled, "joined to a secondary, thin-walled, more or less hemispheric cell", in deposit the aleuriospores are pinkish buff, 2) conidia: 14.0-25.5 x 4.0-5.0 um, cylindric-elliptic, smooth, thin-walled, contents granular or with one to several oil droplets, some centrally septate; ascospores and perithecia rare^, according to Rogerson & Simms spores (15)18-22(26) x 2-4(5) um, subfusiform, smooth, at maturity typically 1-septate, the ends pointed, not apiculate, (MykoWeb), CONIDIUM (6)12-22 x 3-5(6) um, "fusiform, equilateral, with basal hilum absent", 0-1(3)-septate, conidiogenous locus "with no proliferation observed, forming 1-3 conidia that are held in heads", CONIDIOGENOUS CELLS "usually borne directly from aerial or submerged hyphae", by 1(2) in a verticil, 55-140 um long, 2-2.5 um wide at base, proliferation not observed, CONIDIOPHORES hardly or not differentiated from aerial hyphae; ASCOSPORES 14-22(26) x 3-4(5) um, fusiform or naviculate [boat-shaped], smooth, "ends nonapiculate, the upper end usually acute and the base obtuse", "1-septate (with the septum often obscured) or aseptate, septum median or submedian"; ASCUS (100)115-125(140) x 2-3(4.5) um; with apex thickened (about 2 um), penetrated by a pore; PERITHECIA "gregarious to scattered, semi-immersed in the subiculum", (165)250-350(385) x (130)165-200(265) um, "buff or light yellow, KOH reaction absent", perithecial wall 10-12 um wide, perithecial papillae 45-100 um high, 45-60(75) um wide at base, "tip obtuse, of hyphal texture, with cells not forming differentiated regions", surface cells 1-2 um in diameter; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, loosely interwoven (at first) or densely compacted (when perithecia are formed), (Poldmaa), ASCOSPORES 22(26) x (1.5)2-4(5) um, "fusiform to spindle-shaped, sometimes curved", (usually acute at the apices but often with lower end obtuse), smooth, colorless, cytoplasm usually vacuolate, 1 or 2 celled, septum often obscured, lower cell often narrower and smaller than upper cell, septum median or submedian, spores obliquely uniseriate; ASCUS 8-spored, filling the centrum, "frequently protruding from the ostiole", (100)115-125(142) x 2-3(4.5) um, long and linear, thin-walled except at obtuse apex, apex forming a thickened cap, 1-2 um thick, with a distinct pore (staining with cotton blue in lacto-phenol, not staining in Melzer's reagent) visible in young asci, contracted at base, then swollen and foot-like, pore obscured as spores mature, the acute apex of upper spore protruding into the pore; PERIPHYSES 15-20 x 2 um, filamentous, "obtuse at apex, curved upward, lining the ostiolar canal", "apical paraphyses present in early stages, disappearing as asci form"; PERITHECIUM (165)250-350(385) x (132)165-200(265) um, spherical-ovate to spherical-papillate, frequently collapsing laterally, papilla obtuse to truncate, 45-90(100) x 45-62(75) um, wall 10-12 um thick, irregularly pseudoparenchymatous in face view, cells thin-walled, irregularly elongate and prosenchymatous up to 15 x 6 um, with 4-5 layers in longitudinal section, "becoming filamentous and parallel at the papilla", "papilla with an outside layer of irregular cells covered by a zone of amorphous, small, contracted, hyphal cells creating a waxy appearance"; SUBICULUM hyphae less than 3 um wide, branched, colorless, septate, "disappearing as perithecia become compacted", (Rogerson)
NAME ORIGIN  "cervina" is the specific epithet for the imperfect state Mycogone cervina (for the fawn color of its aleuriospores), + "genus" - offspring or issue (originating from)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Rogerson(4), Poldmaa(2), MykoWeb(1), Desjardin(6)*
205
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces chrysospermus  Tul.  group^  Ann. Sci. Nat. Bot. IV. 13: 16. 1860;  == Apiocrea chrysosperma  (Tul.) Syd. & P. Syd.;  = Hypomyces boletinus  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  bolete-eater, golden bolete-eater
NOTES  This taxon is designated as a group so that it includes Hypomyces microspermus (see separate description) which is difficult to distinguish and was at one time considered a small-spored form of Hypomyces chrysospermus. |The descriptions below are specific to Hypomyces chrysospermus itself except probably for Arora's. |Features include 1) a three stage mould-like growth on fungi of Boletaceae, the first white, the second yellow, and the third (seldom seen) red-brown and pimpled, and 2) spores in the white stage that are elliptic, colorless and smooth (conidia), in the yellow stage round, yellow, thick-walled, and warted ("aleuriospores"), and in the final (sexual) stage spindle-shaped, colorless, and usually 1-septate (ascospores).^ |Hypomyces chrysospermus is not edible (Arora). |The anamorph of H. chrysospermus is common, but the teleomorph is uncommon, (Poldmaa). The commoner anamorph stage of Hypomyces chrysospermus is known as Sepedonium chrysospermum and the anamorph stage of Hypomyces microspermus is a similar Sepedonium. |The subicular hyphae in H. chrysospermus are 2-2.5 um wide but when old many cells become irregularly inflated; in H. microspermus, the subicular cells are 3-5 um wide. |Six other Hypomyces species growing on boletes in the United States are described in Rogerson(1). Like H. chrysospermus and H. microsporus, they start with a white subiculum on the surface of the bolete, but they have a different range of features, including a) the width of the subicular hyphae, b) the color of the subiculum that develops, c) the features of the usually round or nearly round "aleuriospores" of the second anamorph stage, d) the features of the sexual stage, and e) sometimes in the species of bolete involved. |The sexual stage is uncommonly observed because by the time it develops, the original bolete and the subiculum is often not evident. RANGE ^Collections of Hypomyces chrysospermus were examined from NF, ME, NC, NH, NY, Belgium, France, United Kingdom, Japan, Nepal, Australia, and New Zealand, (Rogerson). H. chrysospermus has also been found in NC, Cuba, northern Africa, China, Kazakhstan, and Russia, (Poldmaa), and CA (Siegel). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia and from AK at the University of Washington, but there is no indication in the online records that ascospores were measured to distinguish H. chrysospermus from H. microspermus. A collection at the University of Washington from Washington was previously identified as Hypomyces lactifluorum which seems an unlikely confusion. There are two more collections from WA at the University of Washington deposited under the yellow anamorph name Sepedonium chrysospermum, which presumably could represent either Hypomyces chrysospermus or Hypomyces microspermus. Hypomyces chrysospermus may occur more widely in the Pacific Northwest and in other areas of the United States (see Mushroom Observer for instance), but needs to be better documented especially considering the similarity to the common Hypomyces microspermus.
FRUITING BODY  beginning as a white mouldy-looking covering "that attacks and quickly engulfs boletes, then turns bright yellow and powdery", and then finally becomes reddish brown and pimpled (but this final stage rarely seen, only occurring after host is decayed beyond recognition and unpleasant to handle); flesh of bolete "often soft or mushy"^, (Arora), subiculum "at first white, usually becoming golden yellow, remaining white or becoming pink, vinaceous to ferruginous"; perithecia "orange-yellow, brick red, red-brown, or rufous brown, not reacting in KOH, or becoming yellow-brown to red-brown and often with distinctly red coloration at base of papilla, immersed in subiculum except for papilla", (Rogerson), subiculum profuse, texture hyphal, at first white, turning yellow when old (as chlamydospores formed), not changing color in KOH, perithecia "formed all over the subiculum, caespitose, immersed in the subiculum except the papilla", "yellow, brown or red", KOH reaction present or absent (see MICROSCOPIC), (Poldmaa)
HABITAT  on members of the Boletaceae, covering the cap, stem and tube surfaces of the host and filling the tubes; the yellow stage has been reported as Sepedonium "from, in addition to boletes, other fungi including, Rhizopogon, Scleroderma, various agarics, and it has been isolated from the air, soil, dung, etc." but the sexual stage has only been found on boletes^, (Rogerson, genus names italicized), on fungi of Boletales: Boletus, Gomphidius, Gyroporus, Leccinum, Paxillus, Phylloporus, Pisolithus, Porphyrellus, Strobilomyces, Suillus, Tylopilus, Xerocomus, covering host's spore-bearing surface or also host's cap and part of stem, the host fruitbody becomes decayed, (Poldmaa), June to September (Phillips), commonly seen on Boletus zelleri, B. chrysenteron, B. mirabilis, and other boletes, (Trudell)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES in white stage 10-30 x 5-12 um, elliptic, smooth, in yellow stage 10-25 um, round, thick-walled, and warted, in final (sexual) stage 25-30 x 5-6 um, spindle-shaped, colorless, usually 1-septate^; perithecia only present in final stage, (Arora), CONIDIUM (4)7-13.3(20) x (2.5)3.3-5.5(7) um, oblong, broadly elliptic to elliptic, produced from macronematous, irregularly to verticillately branched, colorless conidiophores; ALEURIOSPORES 10-25 um, round, prominently verrucose ("verrucae 1.5-2 um high and appearing acute at first but becoming obtuse or wedge-shaped"), yellow, golden yellow to yellow-brown, wall 2-3 um thick; ASCOSPORES (15)20-25(30) x 4-5(6) um, fusiform to lanceolate, prominently verrucose, "verrucae usually dense and randomly arranged but sometimes appearing to be arranged in longitudinal rows", apiculate, with apiculi acute, dimorphic and longer at upper end (1-2(3) um) than at lower end ((0.5)1-2 um), unequally bicellular, "septum usually well below center but sometimes almost median", upper cell (8)12-15(18) x 4-5(6) um, lower cell 4-6(7) x 3-4(5) um and often appearing as an appendage, spores "uniseriate in the ascus, sometimes overlapping"; ASCUS 100-120(140) x 5-8(10) um, cylindric, spore-bearing part 65-75 um, ascal wall thickened, "with apical pore, attenuated at base", 25 um or more long x 7-8 um wide; PERITHECIA (375)435-445(460) x (280)310-320(330) um, spherical to flask-shaped, typically aggregated in a compact layer on parts of host fruitbodies but most commonly found on tube layer, perithecial wall 25-30 um wide, cells 8-15 x 4-8 um, walls 0.5-1 um thick, papilla 94 um high and 125 um wide at base, terminal wall cells 4-10 um in diameter, +/- inflated and clavate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2-2.5 um wide, when old many becoming irregularly inflated, (Rogerson), CONIDIUM 7-20(25) x 3-10 um, cylindric to elliptic, equilateral, with no basal hilum, colorless, aseptate; conidiogenous locus "with no proliferation observed, forming up to 50 conidia that are held in drops of liquid"; conidiogenous cells "by 2-4 in a verticil, 30-120 um long, 3-5 um wide at the base", (proliferation not observed), forming 1 conidiogenous locus; CONIDIOPHORES "arising from aerial hyphae, hardly or not differentiated from these", branching verticillate or irregular; thick-walled cells "formed in terminal position on lateral branches on conidiophores", (10)12-21(25) um in diameter, held singly, subglobose to globose, yellow, "wall 2-3 5m thick, warted, with verrucae 1.5-2 um high"; SPORES (13)15-20(25) x 4-6 um, naviculate, "1-septate, septum submedian, wall verrucose, verrucae arranged uniformly or occasionally in rows with the wall appearing ridged", spore ends apiculate, apiculi 1-2(3) um long at the upper end, 0.5-1.5(2) um long at the lower end, with tips obtuse; ASCUS 110-150 x 6.5-9 um; "with apex thickened, penetrated by a pore"; PERITHECIA 300-450 x 200-320 um, "yellow, brown or red, KOH reaction absent or present in some collections with reddish perithecia", with only the basal part of perithecial papilla turning purple or the whole perithecium turning yellow, perithecial wall 25-30 um wide, perithecial papilla 65-95 um high, 105-125 um wide at the base, 50-66 um wide at the top, (tip obtuse), "of pseudoparenchymatous texture, with cells in divergent files, becoming narrower toward the ostiolar canal and more rounded towards the outer surface", cells at the surface 4-10 um in diameter; subicular hyphae "loosely interwoven, cells not swollen, 2-2.5 5m in diam or becoming swollen", (Poldmaa)
NAME ORIGIN  from Greek, meaning "with golden seed", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), likely referring to the golden yellow to yellowish color of the aleuriospores
SIMILAR  Hypomyces microspermus Rogerson & Samuels is "the most frequently collected of the boleticolous species in North America" (whereas H. chrysospermus is "the most frequently reported boleticolous species"). H. microspermus is found at least in CA (Del Norte Co.), eastern North America, Indonesia, and New Zealand. It has ascospores rarely above 15 um in length, not prominently verrucose, varying from equally bicellular to unequally bicellular, whereas those of H. chrysospermus rarely range below 20 um in length, are prominently verrucose, and unequally bicellular. Conidia and aleuriospores of H. microspermus averaged somewhat smaller than those of H. chrysospermus but the measurements overlapped. The size of the conidia is given as 11-14 x 4-5 um and (in culture) as (5)6.4-11.7(14) x (2.5)2.7-4.5(5) um. The size of the aleuriospores given as 12-15 um in diameter. (Rogerson). The following species are found in the United States but not documented from the Pacific Northwest: 1) Hypomyces completus, usually on Suillus pictus, subiculum becomes yellow-brown, brown, greenish brown, greenish black, to black, subicular hyphae 3-5 um wide, 2) Hypomyces melanocarpus known from Tylopilus, subiculum white to buff-colored, subicular cells 1-3 um wide, 3) Hypomyces transformans on Suillus and possibly other species, subiculum ochraceous to brick red, subicular hyphae 2-3 um wide, 4) Hypomyces boletiphagus subiculum white becoming pale brown, subicular hyphae 2-3 um wide, 5) Hypomyces chlorinigenus subiculum white, pale yellow to light brown, subicular hyphae 2-4 um wide, aleuriospores cylindric, 6) Hypomyces melanochlorus, subiculum pale brown to dark olivaceous brown when dry, black in 3% KOH, subicular hyphae 2-3 um wide, known only from type specimen. (Rogerson(1)). |Dicranophora fulva J. Schroet. is a rarely reported yellow mold in Mucoraceae that was reported in Zeller(19) from Benton, Linn, and Jackson Counties as common in October. It favors fruitbodies of Boletales.
SOURCES  Poldmaa(2), Rogerson(1), Phillips(1)*, Arora(1), Lincoff(2)*, Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2), Zeller(19) (re Dicranophora fulva)
206
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces hyalinus  (Schwein.) Tul.^  Ann. Sci. Nat. Bot. Ser. IV. 13: 11. 1860;  == Peckiella hyalina  (Schwein.) Sacc.;  == Apiocrea hyalina  (Schwein.) Syd.;  = Hypomyces vanbruntianus  W.R. Gerard;  = Hypomyces inaequalis  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  Amanita mold, Amanita eater
NOTES  Features include 1) a mould-like covering with a pimpled surface, formed on Amanita species, covering gills, cap, and stem, and turning the fruitbody firm, 2) the color white, pallid when old or tinged with pink, yellow, or brown, not changing in KOH, 3) ascospores measuring 15-20 x 4.5-6.5 um, 2-celled, apiculate, and prominently verrucose, and 4) no anamorph that is definitely associated.^ RANGE ^Distribution and records include WA, ID, NS, PQ, CT, GA, IA, LA, MA, MD, ME, MO, NC, NY, PA, TN, VA, WI, Northeastern U.S.A., China, and Japan, (Poldmaa) It is common, at least in North America, (Poldmaa). It also occurs in DC, DE, IN, MI, NH, NJ, OH, VT, and WV, (Rogerson). It is found in northeastern North America west to CO, and south to NC, (Phillips).
FRUITING BODY  subiculum effused [spread out], white, pallid when old or tinged with pink, yellow, or brown, KOH-; perithecia "pallid to light orange or brownish, colorless in KOH", "immersed in the subiculum except for the papilla, KOH-"^, (Rogerson), subiculum profuse, white or buff, not changing color in KOH, perithecia "formed all over the subiculum, caespitose, gregarious or scattered", buff or pale brown, KOH reaction absent, immersed in the subiculum except the papilla, (Poldmaa), parasitizes Amanita species and turns them into white clubs (Miller)
HABITAT  usually covering entire host, the host typically unexpanded with cap completely deformed and fused to stem, the gills obliterated; on Amanita species, including A. muscaria, A. rubescens, and A. frostiana^, (Rogerson), on Amanita spp., covering host gills, cap, and stem, host fruitbody turns firm, (Poldmaa), June to October (Lincoff)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 15-20 x 4.5-6.5 um, "fusiform, subcymbiform to oblanceolate", apiculate and prominently verrucose ("apiculi acute to obtuse, 1-2.5 um long, verrucae 1.0-1.5 um high"), 2-celled, septum near the base^; ASCUS 110-130 x 4-6 um, cylindric to narrowly clavate, "apex thickened and with a pore"; PERITHECIA 250-325 x 180-210 um, ovate to obpyriform, "pallid to light orange or brownish, colorless in KOH", "immersed in the subiculum except for the papilla, KOH-", papilla 125 um high, 60-100 um wide at apex, broadly truncate, perithecial wall "15-20 um wide, cells fusiform in section, 10-15 um long, 3-5 um wide, walls 1.0-1.5 um thick, nonpigmented", cells of papilla "tending to be arranged in somewhat divergent files, 7-10 um long, 3-5 um wide, walls 1 um thick", the terminal cell of each file clavate to subglobose, 7-10 x 4-6 um, wall 0.5 um thick, cells of the papilla progressively merging with the periphyses; subicular hyphae 2-3 um wide, "loosely interwoven between perithecia with few free ends visible, septate, branched", (Rogerson), SPORES 15-20 x 4.5-6.5 um, fusiform or naviculate [boat-shaped], verrucose (verrucae 1-1.5 um high), ends apiculate, (apiculi 1-2.5 um long, with tips acute or obtuse), 1-septate, septum submedian; ASCUS 110-130 x 4-6 um, "with apex thickened, penetrated by a pore"; PERITHECIUM 250-325 x 180-210 um, buff or pale brown, KOH reaction absent, perithecial wall 15-20 um wide, perithecial papillae 100-125 um high, 60-100 um wide at the top, tip obtuse, "of pseudoparenchymatous texture, with cells in divergent files, becoming narrower toward the ostiolar canal and more rounded towards the outer surface", cells at the surface 4-6 um in diameter; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, loosely interwoven; anamorph in nature "observed in some collections but there is no proven connection between H. hyalinus and any anamorph"; 1-2-celled thick-walled cells, reminiscent of those of species of Mycogone, "are embedded in the white mycelium that covers the mummified host, usually on the parts where perithecia have not yet formed", thick-walled cells "absent or present in some collections, formed in terminal position on lateral branches", colorless, subspherical to spherical, held by 1-2, wall smooth or warted, (Poldmaa) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'hyaline', i.e. colorless
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Poldmaa(2), Rogerson(3), Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Miller(14)
207
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces lactifluorum  (Schwein.) Tul.^  Ann. Sci. Nat. Bot. Ser. IV. 13: 11. 1860;  = Hypomyces insignis  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  = Hypomyces purpureus  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  lobster mushroom, orange mushroom pimple, lobster crust
NOTES  Also listed in Veined category. Features include 1) bright orange to reddish color and smoothly pimpled surface, 2) growth on distorted Russula brevipes (and other Russula and Lactarius spp.) whose gills are often reduced to blunt ridges, 3) the anamorph not being found in nature, and 4) spores measuring 30-50 x 4.5-8 um, 2-celled, warted, and apiculate.^ |The anamorph is not found in nature, (Poldmaa). |The edibility [of firm specimens] is often rated highly, although there is no absolute assurance that the host species is edible, (Arora). Although it is reportedly edible, some experience intestinal upset: it is probably best avoided since the host fungus cannot be identified accurately, (McKnight). |Researchers found that H. lactifluorum DNA "is not restricted to the margin but is distributed relatively evenly across the sporocarp of the lobster mushroom", and significant chemical changes occur as a result of the parasitization process, (Laperriere(1)). RANGE ^Hypomyces lactifluorum is found throughout North America (Phillips). Distribution includes NS, MB, and the majority of states in all 6 regions of US, including specifically IA, MI, NC, and PA, as well as Mexico and Guatemala, (Poldmaa). It is known only from North America: WA, OR, ID, MB, NB, NS, ON, PE, PQ, AL, AZ, CO, CT, DE, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, KS, KY, MA, MD, ME, MI, MO, MS, NC, ND, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, RI, SC, TN, TX, VA, VT, WI, WV, Guatemala, and Mexico, (Rogerson). It is reported from BC (Redhead(5) and there are BC collections at the University of British Columbia). There are AK collections at the University of Washington. Desjardin(6) shows it for CA.
FRUITING BODY  "a layer of roughened or pimpled, bright orange to orange-red to purple-red or occasionally yellow-orange tissue which is firm to the touch"; overall shape of mushroom and parasite "often like an inverted pyramid"; flesh (of host) crisp, white^, (Arora). |subiculum "pale yellowish orange to bright orange, in age becoming deep red, reddish purple to very dark purple, occasionally fading to pink"; perithecia "deep orange to reddish purple, usually darker than the surrounding subiculum, immersed except for papilla, KOH+", (Rogerson). |subiculum "profuse, light to deep orange or reddish orange, red to purple when old", turning purple in KOH, texture hyphal; perithecia orange to lobster-colored or brownish cherry red, "caespitose, immersed in the subiculum except the papilla", turning purple with KOH, (Poldmaa). |white at first, becoming orange as it matures, (McKnight)
HABITAT  usually on the fruiting bodies of Lactarius and Russula (especially Russula brevipes), whose gills are often reduced to blunt ridges^, (Arora), usually covering the aborted cap, stem, and deformed gills of host, (Rogerson), formed all over the host's gills and stem, sometimes also in small patches on cap; hosts belonging to Russulales: Lactarius spp., Russula spp., (Poldmaa), fruits July to October (Lincoff), found on Lactarius torminosus, and also next to Lactarius volemus, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), other known hosts include Lactarius piperatus, L. deceptivus, and L. vellereus, (McKnight)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 30-50 x 4.5-8 um, "spindle-shaped or shaped like caraway seeds", colorless, warted, 1-septate^, (Arora). |SPORES 35-40 x 4.5-7 um, fusiform, prominently verrucose and apiculate (verrucae 1-1.5 um high, apiculi 4.5-7.5 um long, acute, straight or curved), 2-celled, septum median; ASCUS 200-260 x 5-10 um, long cylindric, "apex thickened and with a pore"; PERITHECIUM 400-600 x 200-450 um, immersed except for papilla, KOH+, "papilla averaging 120 um high, 120 um wide", perithecial wall 25-30 um wide laterally, cells 7-15 um long, about 5 um wide, fusoid, walls 1.5 um thick, nonpigmented, perithecial apex composed "of circular to elliptic cells tending to be arranged in files and with long axis parallel to long axis of perithecium", 5-15 x 3-7 um, walls 1.5 um thick, cells around the ostiolar opening 3-5 um wide, clavate, ostiolar canal periphysate; subicular hyphae "3-5 um wide, septate, much branched, branching very irregular, often at right angles, densely compacted but remaining filamentous, smooth", occasionally some cells swollen to 10 um wide, KOH+ purple, (Rogerson). |SPORES 35-45 x 5-8 um, "fusiform, with one side sometimes flattened", verrucose ("verrucae low and confluent with each other, 1-1.5 um high"), ends apiculate (apiculi 4.5-7.5 5m long, with acute tips), 1-septate (septum median); ASCUS 200-260 x 6-10 um, "with apex thickened, penetrated by a pore"; PERITHECIA "caespitose, immersed in the subiculum except the papilla", 400-600 x 250-450 um, "KOH reaction with the whole perithecium turning purple, reaction in the perithecial wall usually much weaker (or sometimes lacking) than in the papilla", perithecial wall 25-30 um wide, perithecial papillae 120-220 um high, 120-200 um wide at base, 80-120 5m wide at top, tip obtuse, "of pseudoparenchymatous texture, with cells in divergent files, becoming narrower toward the ostiolar canal and more rounded towards the outer surface", cells at the surface 6-13 um in diameter; subicular hyphae 3.5-8 um wide, loosely interwoven to densely compacted, cells not swollen or occasionally swollen; anamorph in nature not observed; thick-walled cells absent, (Poldmaa)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the flow of milk^ (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  Hypomyces macrosporus Seaver (found in WA, AL, CT, MD, NY, OH, SC, WV, Mexico) is distinguishable only by color (subiculum white to buff, perithecia buff to yellowish amber) and negative reaction to KOH and may be merely an albino form of this species: orange specimens of H. lactifluorum have been found mixed with specimens that were variously white, white with orange streaks and orange-red with white streaks, but only the reddish streaks of the whitish form became purple in KOH, (Rogerson). See also SIMILAR section of Hypomyces luteovirens.
SOURCES  Poldmaa(2), Rogerson(3), Lincoff(2)*, Arora(1)*, Phillips(1)*, Miller(14)*, Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, McKnight(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Sept(1)*, Redhead(5), AroraPocket(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*, Marrone(1)*, Laperriere(1), McBride(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
208
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces lateritius  (Fr.) Tul.^  Ann. Sci. Nat. Ser. IV. 13: 11. 1860;  == Peckiella lateritia  (Fr.) Maire;  == Byssonectria lateritia  (Fr.) Petch;  = Hypomyces volemi  Peck;  = Peckiella hymenioides  Peck;  = Hypomyces camphorati  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on gills of Lactarius species, 2) color that is white to lemon yellow when fresh, buff, yellowish orange, tawny, at full maturity becoming ochraceous, brick red and brown or reddish black, the surface pimpled from perithecia, 3) a whitish cottony anamorph Acremonium tulasnei G.R.W. Arnold that may be found on host's mummified fruitbody before perithecia or in early stages, 4) ascospores that are 1-celled (appearing 2-celled), mostly 15-21 x 3.6-4.8 um, fusiform, lanceolate, or boat-shaped, with warts less than 0.5 um high, and with a conspicuous acute apiculus.^ | Rogerson(3) say that it is a variable species that may ultimately prove to be a complex of species: for instance, collections on Lactarius camphoratus complex "tend to have a yellowish subiculum and slightly larger ascospores". RANGE ^The distribution includes BC, WA, OR, ID, NS, ON, PQ, AK, AL, CA, CO, CT, IA, MA, ME, MD, MI, MN, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, RI, SC, TN, VT, VA, WI, WY, Mexico, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Russia, Sweden, United Kingdom, and New Zealand: it occurs apparently worldwide wherever species of Lactarius occur, (Rogerson). It also occurs in Estonia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, and Kyrgyzstan, (Poldmaa).
FRUITING BODY  subiculum "white to lemon yellow when fresh, buff, yellowish orange, tawny, at full maturity becoming ochraceus [sic], brick red and brown or reddish black", "of loose texture, covering and apparently restricted to the deformed gill surfaces"; perithecia "dark amber to reddish brown, becoming lighter and yellowish in KOH, immersed in the subiculum or half free, KOH-"^, (Rogerson), subiculum "profuse, buff or ochraceous", not changing color in KOH, texture hyphal; perithecia formed all over the subiculum on host's spore-bearing surface, "caespitose, immersed in the subiculum except the papilla", buff to brown, KOH reaction yellow; anamorph in nature "found on host's mummified fruitbodies on which perithecia usually have not yet formed or are immature", anamorph "can be seen as a white cottony mycelium" that fills the space between gills and cavities inside the mummified host's fruitbody, (Poldmaa)
HABITAT  on Lactarius species^ including Lactarius aurantiacus, L. camphoratus, L. chelidonium, L. controversus, L. deliciosus, L. rufus, L. sanguifluus, L. thejogalus, L. trivialis, L. uvidus, and L. volemus; deforming the gill surfaces, (Rogerson), most frequently on Lactarius deliciosus, L. deterrimus, and L. sanguifluus but also L. camphoratus, L. chelidonium, L. controversus, L. porninsis, L. rufus, L. thejogalus, L. torminosus, and L. trivialis; covering host's gills, host fruitbody turns firm, (Poldmaa)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (11.2)15-21(30) x (2.6)3.6-4.8(6.0) um, fusiform, lanceolate or naviculate, verrucose, verrucae < 0.5 um high, apiculi (0.5)1.7-2.9(4.2) um long and acute, spores one-celled "but with inclusions giving the appearance of a median septum"^; ASCUS 90-150 x 4-8 um, long cylindric, "apex thickened and with a pore"; PERITHECIUM 300-470 x 170-360 um, ovate to obpyriform, "dark amber to reddish brown, becoming lighter and yellowish in KOH, immersed in the subiculum or half free, KOH-", papilla "120-150 um high, 100-175 um wide at apex", perithecial wall "15-30 um wide, cells fusiform to sinuous, 7-15 um long, 3-6 um wide, walls 1.0-1.5 um thick, nonpigmented", cells of papilla "with long axis parallel to long axis of perithecium and tending to be arranged in files, 7-15 um long, 3-5 um wide, walls 0.5-1.0 um thick", "cells around the ostiolar opening tending to be narrowly clavate, 3 um wide, merging the periphyses, cells of the papilla continuous with subicular hyphae at the surface, ostiolar canal periphysate"; subicular hyphae 2-5 um wide, septate, much branched, "densely compacted but remaining filamentous and with many free ends at subicular surface" and sometimes forming enlarged terminal or intercalary, spherical to ellipsoid cells 18-25 x 7-9 um, KOH-, (Rogerson), SPORES (15)21-27(30) x (3)4-5.5(6) um, fusiform, aseptate, wall finely verrucose, verrucae 0.5 um high, spore ends apiculate, apiculi 1.5-3(4) um long with acute tips; ASCUS 90-150 x 4-8 um, "with apex thickened, penetrated by a pore"; PERITHECIA formed all over the subiculum on host gills, "caespitose, immersed in the subiculum except the papilla", 300-470 x 170-360 um, "buff to brown, KOH reaction with the whole perithecium turning yellow", perithecial wall 15-30 um wide, perithecial papillae "120-150 um high, 100-175 um wide at the top, tip obtuse, of pseudoparenchymatous texture, with cells in divergent files, becoming narrower toward the ostiolar canal and more rounded towards the outer surface", cells at the surface 3 um in diameter; SUBICULUM "profuse, buff or ochraceous", not changing color in KOH, texture hyphal, hyphae densely compacted, cells 2-5 um wide, becoming swollen; CONIDIA (4.5)5-6.5(7.5) x 4.5-6(7) um, round or nearly round, equilateral, "with no hilum or a minute central basal hilum", aseptate; conidiogenous locus with no proliferation observed, forming up to 6 conidia that are held in heads; conidiogenous cells (15)27-37(45) um long, 2.5-3.2 um wide at base, by 1-4(6) in a verticil, "often placed at right angle with respect to the conidiophore", proliferation not observed, forming 1 conidiogenous locus; CONIDIOPHORES "hardly or not differentiated from aerial hyphae, unbranched or branching verticillate or irregular", (Poldmaa)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'brick-colored'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Hypomyces luteovirens.
SOURCES  Poldmaa(2), Rogerson(3), AroraPocket(1)*
209
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces luteovirens  (Fr.) Tul.^  Ann. Sci. Nat. Ser. Bot. IV. 13: 13. 1860 emend. Plowr. Grevillea 11: 46. 1882;  == Peckiella luteovirens  (Fr.) Maire;  = Hypomyces atra  (Fr.) Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  yellow-green Hypomyces, green mushroom pimple
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on Russula species and occasionally Lactarius, covering deformed gills and often the stem, sometimes the cap, turning the fruitbody firm, 2) color that is yellow or green, 3) large unicellular spores, 4) a peculiar anatomy of the perithecial apex ("distinctive for the moniliform chains of cells that extend from the surface of the papilla"), and 5) no anamorph known in nature.^ | It should not be eaten (Lincoff). It is common in wet weather wherever the host species are found, throughout many parts of North America, (Phillips). RANGE ^It is widespread in north temperate regions, occurring in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, PQ, AK, AZ, CO, CT, FL, GA, OH, MA, MD, ME, MI, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, RI, SC, TN, TX, UT, VA, VT, WI, WV, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Estonia, France, Finland, Germany, Norway, Russia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and Japan, (Rogerson). It also occurs CA (Castellano) and in Ukraine and Kazakhstan, (Poldmaa).
FRUITING BODY  subiculum "at first yellowish to bright yellow, then yellowish green to dark green, finally blackish green"; perithecia "yellow when fresh, olivaceous to blackish when dry, usually darker than the surrounding subiculum, immersed except for papilla"^, (Rogerson), subiculum "profuse, first yellow or green when old", not changing color in KOH, texture hyphal; perithecia "formed all over the subiculum, caespitose, immersed in the subiculum except the papilla", at first yellow, becoming green when mature, KOH reaction absent, (Poldmaa), "first yellow, then yellow-green to green, finally black-green", (Castellano), white at first, but eventually becomes light olive-green as spores mature, (McKnight)
HABITAT  on Russula species, covering the deformed gills and often the stem, sometimes spreading to the top of the cap of the host^, (Rogerson), growing on fruitbodies of Russulales: Russula spp., also reported on Lactarius; covering host spore-bearing surface and upper stem; host fruitbodies turn firm, (Poldmaa), fruiting July through November (Castellano)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 32-35 x 4.5-5.5 um, fusiform to naviculate, nearly smooth to prominently verrucose and apiculate (verrucae up to 1 um high, "apiculi 2.4-7.3 um long, acute, straight or curved and sometimes hooked"), one-celled^; ASCUS 160-200 x 5-8 um, filiform to long cylindric, "apex thickened and with a pore"; PERITHECIUM 380-485 x 180-290 um, broadly ovate to obpyriform, immersed except for papilla, papilla 96-120 um high, 180-230 um wide at apex, truncate or obtuse, KOH-, perithecial wall about 25 um wide laterally, of hyphae 3-4 um wide, sinuous, with nonpigmented walls, perithecial apex composed "of hyphae constricted at septa and appearing moniliform with cells 5-7 um long, 4-5 um wide" and walls < 0.5 um thick, "hyphae tending to separate from each other"; subicular hyphae 3-5.5 um wide, "much branched, septate, much entangled, remaining filamentous", "hyphae at the surface with many 3 um wide free ends and short cells with constrictions at the septa" and mimicking the hyphae of the perithecial apex, KOH-, (Rogerson), SPORES (27)30-36 x 4.5-5.5(6.5) um, fusiform, aseptate, "finely verrucose, verrucae arranged uniformly, 1 um high, ends apiculate", apiculi 2.5-7 um long, with acute tips; ASCUS 160-200 x 5-8 um, "with apex thickened, penetrated by a pore"; PERITHECIUM 380-480 x 180-290 um, "immersed in the subiculum except the papilla", perithecial wall 25 um wide, perithecial papillae 95-120 um high, tip obtuse, "of hyphal texture, with cells not forming differentiated regions"; subiculum cells 3-5.5 um wide, not swollen; anamorph in nature not observed, (Poldmaa)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin, meaning "yellow, becoming green"
SIMILAR  The Hypomyces species that parasitize members of the Russulaceae can be distinguished by color when mature, but several species are somewhat yellow when immature: these taxa and their color when mature include Hypomyces lactifluorum (orange), H. lateritius (ochraceous to brick red to red-black), H. macrosporus (white to pale tan), H. banningiae Peck from MA, MD, NC, NJ, NY, PA, SC, VA (white to pale tan), H. lithuanicus T. Heinrichson-Normet from ON, CT, MI, NY, WI, Europe (cream-ocher to cinnamon), and H. petchii G. Arnold from New Zealand (apricot), (Castellano, but distribution from Poldmaa(2) and Rogerson (3)).
SOURCES  Poldmaa(2), Rogerson(3), Castellano(2)*, Phillips(1)*, Miller(14)*, Lincoff(2)*, Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, McKnight(1)*, Trudell(4)*, AroraPocket(1)*, Marrone(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
210
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces microspermus  Rogerson & Samuels^  Mycologia 81(3): 426. 1989
ENGLISH NAME(S)  bolete-eater
NOTES  Features of the usually observed stages are a white mold that gradually covers a recognizable bolete fruitbody, than starts turning bright yellow to golden, the bolete fruitbody often collapsing into decay.^ | It is very similar to Hypomyces chrysospermus and we have included it in a Hypomyces chrysospermus group because of the difficulty of telling them apart.
