In Mushrooms of the Redwood Coast, Siegel(2) say, "This common bolete-parasitic mold goes through two asexual-sporulating stages leading up to the sexual stage, which is rarely observed (the host is often buried in duff by this point)." The sexual stage is a reddish brown, pimply crust (Siegel(2)). The description is from Rogerson(1) except where otherwise specified. RANGE ^Collections were studied from MA (holotype), CA (Del Norte County in extreme northwest of state), QC, CT, ME, MI, NC, NH, NY, NY, OH, PA, VA, WV, Indonesia, Japan, and New Zealand, (Rogerson). H. microspermus has been reported from PQ, CA, CT, MA, MD, MI, NC, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, TN, VA, WV, Germany, Indonesia, Japan, and New Zealand, (Poldmaa).
FRUITING BODY  subiculum "at first white, becoming pale yellow"; perithecia spherical to ovoid, "yellow, buff, deep peach, red, brick red, orange-red, cinnabar red, reddish brown, pale brown, blackish brown when dry, often turning purplish red in 3% KOH"^, (Rogerson), second stage "bright yellow to golden colored"; odor indistinct to putrid, spore deposit white in first stage, golden yellow in second stage, (Siegel)
HABITAT  on many species of the Boletaceae
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES in white stage 5-17 x 3-7 um, "oblong to broadly elliptic", in yellow stage 8.5-15 um in diameter, "round, distinctly spiny, very thick walled", in sexual stage 8-15 x 2.5-4.5 um, "spindle to lance shaped"^, (Siegel), SPORES: CONIDIA 11-14 x 4-5 um, elliptic, 1-celled, "held in colorless slime heads at tips of macronematous, irregularly to verticillately branched, septate, hyaline conidiophores", ALEURIOSPORES 12-15 um in diameter, round, wall about 2 um thick, "usually prominently warted, bright yellow, golden yellow or yellow orange", warts 1-1.5 um high and often truncate; ASCOSPORES (8)10-15 x (2.3)3-4 um, "naviculate, fusiform-ellipsoid", "smooth or verrucose", verrucae less than 0.25 um high, apiculi less than 1 um long, bicellular, "septum usually submedian giving two unequal cells" (upper cell 6-8 x 3-4 um, lower cell (2.3)4-5(6) um), "sometimes median giving two equal cells, sometimes lacking and ascospores remaining unicellular", spores "uniseriate in the ascus, the ends overlapping"; ASCUS (110)112-120 x 4-6 um, cylindric to clavate, wall somewhat thickened, with apical pore; PERITHECIA (230)305-315(400) x (180)240-250(330) um, spherical to obovoid, perithecial wall 20-25 um wide, cells 6-10 x 2-3 um, walls less than 0.5 um thick, papilla 80 um high and 100 um wide at base, terminal wall cells 4-7 um in diameter, +/- clavate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-5 um wide. (Rogerson)
NAME ORIGIN  "refers to the small ascospores"
SIMILAR  Hypomyces chrysospermus differs most obviously in the ascospores [although these are not often available] which rarely range below 20 um, "are prominently verrucose, and unequally bicellular", whereas ascospores of H. microspermus rarely range above 15 um in length, "are not prominently verrucose, and vary from equally bicellular to unequally bicellular". Aleurospores and conidia of H. chrysospermus average somewhat larger, but measurements overlap. (Rogerson(1)). Hypomyces chrysospermus is much less common in California but is "only reliably distinguished by its much larger spores" which measure (10)12-25 um, (Siegel(2)).
SOURCES  Rogerson(1), Siegel(2)*
211
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces ochraceus  (Pers.) Tul. & C. Tul.^  Select. fung. carpol. (Paris) 3: 38. 1865;  = Hypomyces armeniacus  Tul.;  = Hypomyces apiculatus  (Peck) Seaver;  = Hypomyces terrestris  Plowr. & Boud.;  = Hypomyces xylophilus  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a profuse, white, cottony, mould-like growth on Lactarius and Russula, often extending over nearby substrate and rarely forming a white, buff, or orange teleomorph with a pimpled surface (usually after the host is destroyed), 2) up to three types of "spores": a) conidia 11-24 x 7-12 um, of various shapes, b) chlamydospores (thick-walled cells) about 20 um in diameter with wall 2 um thick, and c) when the rare teleomorph is present ascospores that are 2-celled, verrucose, and apiculate.^ | The anamorph (Cladobotrum verticillatum (Link) S.J. Hughes) is very common, but the teleomorph is rare, (Poldmaa). RANGE ^ Hypomyces ochraceus has been recorded from OR, northeastern, north central, and southeastern United States, eastern Canada, Cuba, Colombia, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Finland, Germany, Lithuania, Netherlands, Russia (northwest, Siberia), Ukraine, United Kingdom, and Japan, (Poldmaa). It has been found in OR, ON, PQ, AL, CT, DC, IL, IN, IA, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, NC, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, TN, VT, VA, WI, WV, Colombia, France, Germany, and the United Kingdom, (Rogerson).
FRUITING BODY  subiculum "profuse, white, buff or orange", not changing color in KOH, texture hyphal; perithecia "formed all over the subiculum, gregarious or scattered, immersed to semi-immersed in the subiculum to superficial", "buff, amber, orange or red, KOH reaction absent"; anamorph in nature "forming profuse white cottony mould" that covers the cap and spore-bearing surface or often the whole fruitbody of the host, and often extends also over the adjacent substrate of the host^, (Poldmaa), subiculum effused [spread out], thin to fairly thick, often to 5cm across, "at first white, then flesh or buff and finally deep ochraceous to apricot, remaining white or lighter at the margin"; perithecia "at first immersed in the subiculum then becoming half-free, on old specimens often appearing superficial, buff, yellowish orange or amber to reddish orange", KOH-, papilla prominent, (Rogerson)
HABITAT  anamorph growing on fruitbodies of fungi (covering spore-bearing surface but usually the whole fruitbody, the fruitbody becoming decayed), "teleomorph on litter, mosses, ground, wood or bark next to decayed agarics", hosts Lactarius spp. and Russula spp.^, (Poldmaa), anamorph common on members of Russulaceae, but also reported on boletes, the parasitism "on the agaric is usually so complete that by the time of perithecial formation there is usually no suggestion of an agaricaceous host", thus "the species appears to grow on detritus and not on other fungi" (teleomorph on the host substrate such as wood, mosses, or ground, developing where the host agaric decayed), (Rogerson)
MICROSCOPIC  ASCOSPORES 32-40 x 5-8 um, fusiform, "1-septate, septum median, wall grossly warted, verrucae arranged uniformly, 0.5-1.2 um high", spore ends apiculate, apiculi 3-4.5 um long, with acute tips^; ASCUS 170-180 x 6-8 um, "with apex thickened, penetrated by a pore"; PERITHECIUM "immersed to semi-immersed in the subiculum to superficial", 260-360 x 240-250 um, perithecial wall 15-20 um wide, perithecial papilla 90-100 um high, 60-80 um wide at base, tip conic, perithecium "of pseudoparenchymatous texture, with cells in divergent files, becoming narrower toward the ostiolar canal and more rounded towards the outer surface", cells at the surface 6-12 um in diameter; SUBICULUM with hyphal texture, cells becoming swollen, 5-10 um wide, or almost pseudoparenchymatous; CONIDIUM (7)11-24(30) x (5)7-12(14) um, broad ellipsoid to nearly round or round, obovoid, pyriform or rarely cylindrical, "equilateral, with a central or laterally placed basal hilum", colorless, 0(1)-septate; conidiogenous locus "with no proliferation observed, forming 1-3 conidia that are held in imbricate chains"; conidiogenous cells by 2-5(7) in a verticil, 35-60(70) um long, 3-6 um wide at base, proliferation not observed, "forming 1 conidiogenous locus or very rarely 2 loci"; CONIDIOPHORES "arising from aerial hyphae, hardly or not differentiated from these", 6 um wide, branching verticillate or irregular; aerial mycelium abundant or scanty, hyphae 6.5-7 um wide; thick-walled cells "formed in terminal position on lateral branches, intercalarly on vegetative hyphae or in soft sclerotia-like aggregations of irregular shape, on aerial or submerged hyphae", colorless or pale brownish yellow, "with cells subglobose to globose, 10-30 um in diameter, 22-42 x 20-35 um, held by 3-10 when in chains, wall 2 um thick, smooth", (Poldmaa), ASCOSPORES (27)32-40(45) x 5-8 um, fusiform, often curved, prominently verrucose (verrucae 0.5-1.2 um high) and apiculate (apiculi 3-4.5 um long, acute), 2-celled, septum median; ASCUS 170-180 x 6-8 um, long cylindric, "apex thickened and with a pore"; PERITHECIUM "at first immersed in the subiculum then becoming half-free, on old specimens often appearing superficial", 260-360 x 240-250 um, subspherical, ovate to obpyriform, papilla prominent, 90-100 x 60-80 um, perithecial wall 15-20 um wide, cells 15-20 x 5-7 um, fusiform, walls 1 um thick, non-pigmented, papilla composed of cells 5-12 um long, 6-10 um wide, walls 1 um thick, and arranged in diverging files, terminal cell of each file subspherical to clavate and somewhat enlarged, cells around the ostiolar opening 6 um wide, narrowly clavate, merging with the periphyses; subicular hyphae 5-10 um wide, much branched, septate, "usually remaining filamentous, sometimes forming inflated cells and appearing vesicular or pseudoparenchymatous, KOH-"; CONIDIA 11-22 x 6-11 um, 0(1)-septate, "with a small, flat, slightly protuberant basal abscission scar", apparently forming holoblastically, chlamydospores "intercalary or arising as lateral branches of hyphae, appearing as chains of 2-4 cells", each cell about 20 um in diameter with wall 2 um thick, colorless, smooth; conidiogenous cells "arising singly and terminating each branch or in whorls of a few, variable in length, 35-60 um long, 1.5-2.5 um wide at the tip, 2.5-4 um wide at the base", "tip lacking periclinal thickening and not swelled"; CONIDIOPHORES "irregular in length, 7 um wide, irregularly or verticillately branched and conidia joined at the base and held in pairs or dry heads of a few", CONIDIOPHORES "forming abundantly in the aerial mycelium", (Rogerson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ochraceous'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Poldmaa(2), Rogerson(3) (as Hypomyces armeniacus)
212
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypomyces rosellus  (Alb. & Schwein.) Tul.^  Ann. Sci. Nat. Ser. IV. Bot 13: 12, 13. 1960;  Hypomyces purpureus  Heinr.-Norm.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a mould-like, cottony growth on many kinds of fungi, especially Aphyllophorales, white becoming rose-colored or red, with dark red pimple-like perithecia, 2) large spores (usually over 30 um long) that are verrucose and conspicuously apiculate, 3) an anamorph in nature forming a delicate yellowish to red mycelium on which erect conidiophores are standing, each conidiophore bearing a number of conidia at the top that appear as white tufts, and 4) in addition to conidia 18-30 x 8-10 um, the anamorph produces thick-walled cells (chlamydospores) that are 60-90 x 15-20 um.^ RANGE ^Hypomyces rosellus was collected from BC by Kevin Trim (on the underside of Polyporus), It was also reported from BC in Redhead(5). It has been reported from NY, Estonia, Poland, and Ukraine, (Rogerson). It is probably cosmopolitan, with both the teleomorph and anamorph common: there are records from CA, NY, Cuba, Argentina, Estonia, Lithuania, Portugal, Russia (northwest, Siberia), Ukraine, United Kingdom, Iran, Japan, and New Zealand, (Poldmaa). There is a collection from VA at the University of British Columbia. The M Beug photograph represents a collection that probably came from near Sisters Oregon.
FRUITING BODY  subiculum up to 8cm in extent, cottony, spreading over a considerable area of the fungus host, often onto host substrate, at first white, becoming pink, rose-colored, or red, margin remaining lighter in color, subiculum KOH+ purplish red; perithecia "gregarious, immersed in the subiculum with apex free", "typically red but sometimes brown, purplish red in KOH"^, (Rogerson), subiculum profuse, red, turning purple in KOH, texture hyphal, perithecia "formed all over the subiculum, gregarious or scattered, semi-immersed in the subiculum", red, KOH reaction purple; anamorph in nature "forming a delicate yellowish to red mycelium on which erect conidiophores are standing", "each conidiophore bears a number of conidia at its top which appear as white tufts", (Poldmaa)
HABITAT  on many kinds of fungi but especially on fruitbodies of species of Aphyllophorales, sometimes on Agaricales and Auriculariales, spreading over a considerable area of the fungus host, "often spreading out on the substrate of the host"^, (Rogerson), growing "on fruitbodies of fungi or wood, bark, litter, mosses, or ground, next to decayed agarics"; covering host's spore-bearing surface or also host's cap and stem, host fruitbody becomes decayed or with no apparent change observed; recorded from Agaricus, Amanita, Armillaria, Clitocybe, Coprinus, Corticium, Crepidotus, Fomitopsis, Gomphidius, Gymnopus, Hydnellum, Hymenochaete, Hymenogaster, Hyphoderma, Inocybe, Inonotus, Lactarius, Nectria, Phellinus, Phlebiopsis, Piptoporus, Polyporus, Russula, Stereum, Trichaptum, Tricholomopsis, (Poldmaa)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (20)25-30(38) x (3)4-5(7.5) um, fusiform to lanceolate, prominently verrucose (verrucae up to 1 um high), two-celled, septum median, conspicuously apiculate, apiculus 4-6 um long, often curved^; ASCUS 150-160 x 5-7 um, cylindric, spore-bearing part 100-125 um long, apex thickened, with a pore; PERITHECIA gregarious, 250-460 x 150-360 um, ovate, obovoid to obpyriform, "immersed in subiculum with apex free, typically red but sometimes brown, purplish red in KOH", papillate or nonpapillate, papilla obtuse; hyphae 2.5-5 um wide, "the cells usually short, smooth, septate, much branched and loosely interwoven, walls smooth, KOH+ purplish red"; CONIDIUM (16)18.5-27.5(35) x (7)8-9.5(13) um, cylindric to narrowly clavate, (0)1-2(3)-septate, with conspicuous basal hilum, "produced singly and appearing to adhere in a dry radiating head"; conidiogenous cells 20-40 um long, 3-4.5 um wide at base, 2-3(3.5) um wide at tip, conidia forming at tip, "the conidiogenous locus proliferating percurrently with annellides sometimes seen, or sometimes proliferating sympodially as a short, thin-walled rachis"; CONIDIOPHORES "arising in aerial mycelium, indefinite in length and barely morphologically distinct from vegetative hyphae, main axis 3-5 um wide, verticillately branched, each branch a conidiogenous cell"; Blastotrichum-like chlamydospores "comprising large, 1-5 celled globular masses 60-90 x 15-20 um, brown, reddish brown, olivaceous to black and often sclerotioid", (Rogerson), SPORES 25-35 x 4-6(7.5) um, fusiform, verrucose, (verrucae up to 1 um high), ends apiculate, apiculi 4-6 um long, with acute tips, spores 1-septate, septum median; ASCUS 140-160 x 5-7 um, "with apex thickened, penetrated by a pore"; PERITHECIUM "semi-immersed in the subiculum", 250-460 x 150-360 um, "red, KOH reaction with the whole perithecium turning purple", perithecial papilla 80-150 um high, 75-140 um wide at base, 2.3-6 um wide at top, tip obtuse, "of pseudoparenchymatous texture, with cells in divergent files, becoming narrower toward the ostiolar canal and more rounded towards the outer surface"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-5(8) um wide, loosely interwoven with cells becoming swollen; CONIDIUM 18-30(36) x (6)8-10(12) um, cylindric to elliptic, equilateral, 1-3-septate, colorless, "with central or occasionally laterally placed basal hilum"; conidiogenous locus with no proliferation observed, forming 1 conidium; conidiogenous cells by 3-5 in a verticil, 20-50 um long, 3-4.4 um wide at the base, proliferating progressively; forming 1-10(15) conidiogenous loci; CONIDIOPHORES arising from aerial hyphae, hardly or not differentiated from these, 3-5 um wide, branching verticillate or irregular; thick-walled cells "formed in irregular globular masses in terminal position on lateral branches or in hard subglobose to globose sclerotia, among aerial or submerged hyphae", brown or red, "with cells subglobose to globose, held by 1-5", wall smooth; aerial mycelium scanty or abundant, (Poldmaa)
NAME ORIGIN  diminutive from 'rosa' meaning 'rose' and referring to color
SIMILAR  Hypomyces aurantius is orange and has shorter spores.
SOURCES  Poldmaa(2) but accessed July 2, 2005, Rogerson(2), Redhead(5), Siegel(2)*
213
FAMILY  Hypoxylaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypoxylon diathrauston  Rehm^  Hedwigia 21: 48. 1882;  == Anthostoma diathrauston  (Rehm) Cooke;  == Fuckelia diathrauston  (Rehm) Cooke;  == Rosellinia diathrausta  (Rehm) L.E. Petrini  Mycol. helv. 1(7): 562. 1986 (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on coniferous branches, 2) fruitbodies that are erumpent, small, composed of single perithecia or 3-12 coalesced, with a superficial, light gray-brown carbonous surface and white fleshy-leathery inside, the surface cracked, uneven from prominently projecting perithecia, 3) spores that are very variable in shape, widely elliptic and fusoid to elliptic-oblong, (young spores with a colorless sheath), dark brown to almost opaque, diagonally uniseriate or uniseriate in asci, with paraphyses present.^ | It was considered to be a Rosellinia by Petrini and Mueller (1986), but the taxonomic position is uncertain, (Ju). On September 12, 2022, the online Species Fungorum listed Rosellinia diathrausta as the current name but MycoBank listed Hypoxylon diathrauston as the current name. RANGE ^Hypoxylon diathrauston has been reported from BC (Redhead(5)). It has been found in OR, ID, CA, CO, MT, Switzerland, (Miller, J.H.)
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] erumpent, 0.2-1cm x 0.2-0.5cm, "small, composed of single perithecia or 3-12 coalesced, superficial, on small branches, light gray-brown surface and white inside, especially below the perithecia", "surface carbonous but interior fleshy-leathery, uneven from prominently projecting perithecia, rimose, ostiola papillate, often with a truncate area, sometimes collapsed"^, (Miller, J.H.)
HABITAT  on coniferous branches^ (Miller, J.H.)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 20-36 x 12-18 um, very variable in shape, widely elliptic and fusoid to elliptic-oblong, inequilaterally elliptic with obtuse ends, young spores with colorless sheath (readily dissolving from mature spores), thickened at ends, 1.5 um at sides and 2-3 um at ends, dark brown to almost opaque, diagonally uniseriate or uniseriate^; ASCUS 180-210 x 18 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, pedicel [stem] 20-40 um long; PARAPHYSES present; PERITHECIUM 700-1000 um in diameter, hemispheric, (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Miller, J.H.(1), Ju(2), Redhead(5)
214
FAMILY  Hypoxylaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypoxylon fuscum  Pers. ex Fr.^  Summa Veg. Scand. p.384. 1849;  == Sphaeria fusca  Pers.;  == Peripherostoma fuscum  (Pers.) Gray;  == Stromatosphaeria fusca  (Pers.) Grev.;  Sphaeria fragiformis  Hoffm.;  Sphaeria confluens  Willd.;  Hypoxylon confluens  (Willd.) Wettst.;  Sphaeria tuberculosa  Bolton;  Sphaeria castorea  Tode;  Hypoxylon glomerulatum  Bull.;  Sphaeria effusa  Sowerby;  Sphaeria coryli  DC. & Lam.;  Hypoxylon vinosum  Mont.;  Hypoxylon purpureum  Nitschke;  Hypoxylon commutatum  Nitschke  subsp. holwayanum  Sacc. & Ellis;  Hypoxylon bicolor  Ellis & Everh.;  Hypoxylon bicoloratum  P.M.D. Martin;  Hypoxylon subchlorinum  Ellis & Calk.;  Hypoxylon lianincolum  Rehm;  Hypoxylon pruinatoides  Kauffman;  Hypoxylon oregonense  Kauffman
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) irregular hemispheric to cushion-shaped fruitbodies that are very common on recently dead alder, 2) color that is purplish to brown vinaceous, blood color, chestnut, or fuscous, with regularly set, darker perithecial ostioles, the surface even with perithecial elevations not prominent, 3) spores that are elliptic-inequilateral, and brown, with the germ slit the length of the spore, borne in 8-spored asci. "This fungus is on almost every limb of Alnus that has recently died anywhere in the North Temperate Zone. The hemispherical shape of the stroma is due to being usually on small limbs with bark" (Miller, J.H., the word Alnus italicized).^ RANGE ^Hypoxylon fuscum has been found in WA, OR, ID, AK, AL, CA, CO, CT, DC, DE, FL, GA, IA, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MO, MT, NC, ND, NE, NJ, NY, OH, PA, SC, TN, TX, VA, VT, WI, WV, Canada (including NF), Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Poland, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, China, and Japan, (Miller, J.H.). It has also been found in BC, ON, Guyana, Philippines, and Taiwan, (Ju).
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] 0.1-6cm x 0.1-3cm and 0.04-0.2(0.25)cm thick, usually hemispheric to pulvinate [cushion-shaped], sometimes effused-pulvinate, flat or with inconspicuous perithecial mounds; surface brown vinaceous or dark vinaceous, becoming blood color, chestnut, fuscous when old; "buff, dull orange, dull orange-brown, or dull reddish brown granules immediately beneath surface and between perithecia", with KOH-extractable pigments amber, isabelline, olivaceous, gray olivaceous, or greenish olivaceous; "the tissue below the perithecial layer dark brown to blackish brown", inconspicuous to 0.15cm thick^, (Ju), 0.2-0.4cm across and 0.1-0.3cm thick when on bark, and on barkless wood usually effused [spread out], applanate, 1-3cm long and 0.1cm thick; erumpent, superficial, hemispheric or depressed; soft, fleshy-leathery; "young stroma a light purplish shade varying to a brownish purple or light purple-gray"; "surface fairly even with perithecial elevations usually not prominent", (Miller, J.H.), irregularly rounded to angular, +/- spherical stroma rests on the bark and can occur as isolated fruitbodies of 0.4-0.5cm or in compact groups, dark brown within, outer surface uneven, rough, and regularly set with darker, sometimes black, perithecial ostioles, perithecia "black, evenly embedded in one layer in a superficially red-brown stroma", (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  gregarious to single on dead limbs, chiefly Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), and Corylus (hazel)^, (Miller, J.H.), on dead branches of Alnus and Corylus, still with bark (according to the literature more rarely on barkless wood), fruiting all year, (Breitenbach), on Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Amelanchier (serviceberry), Carpinus (hornbeam), Corylus (hazel), Fagus (beech), Garrya (silk-tassel), Ostrya (hophornbeam), Prunus, Quercus (oak), (Ju)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-20 x 4-8 um, elliptic-inequilateral, with narrowly rounded ends, unicellular, brown to dark brown, with slightly sigmoid germ slit spore-length, "perispore dehiscent in 10% KOH, smooth or with inconspicuous coil-like ornamentation", epispore smooth^; ASCUS 85-202 x 6-9(12) um, the spore-bearing part 60-115 um long, stem 20-100 um long, with apical ring blueing to lightly blueing in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 0.5-2 um high and 1.2-3.5 um broad; PERITHECIUM 100-300(400) um across and 200-500 um high, spherical to obovoid, ostioles lower than stromatal surface, (Ju), SPORES 12-15 x 5-8 um, inequilaterally elliptic, nearly opaque, uniseriate or obliquely uniseriate; ASCUS 70-96 x 8-9.6 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, with stem 60-70 um long; PARAPHYSES copious; PERITHECIUM 150-300 um in diameter, small, spherical to angular from compression, "with umbilicate, impressed ostiola"; CONIDIA 4-5 x 3 um, elliptic, colorless, (Miller, J.H.), SPORES 12-13 x 5-6 um, irregularly elliptic, somewhat flattened on one side, "smooth, dark brown, with a germination cleft", uniseriate; ASCUS 8-spored, 130-140 x 8 um, amyloid; no PARAPHYSES observed; PERITHECIUM 300-400 um, "black, evenly embedded in one layer in a superficially red-brown stroma", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fuscous' in color
SIMILAR  Hypoxylon rubiginosum is sometimes similar externally but has smaller spores, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Ju(2), Miller, J.H.(1), Breitenbach(1)*
215
FAMILY  Hypoxylaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypoxylon howeanum  Peck^  24th Rep. N.Y. State Mus. p.98. 1871 [as H. howeianum];  Hypoxylon multiforme  (Fr.) Fr.  var. australe  Cooke;  Hypoxylon coccinellum  Sacc.;  Hypoxylon coccineum  Bull.  var. microcarpum  Bizz.;  Hypoxylon variolosum  (L.) J. Kickx f.  var. microcarpum  (Bizz.) Traverso;  Hypoxylon pulcherrimum  Hoehn.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) spherical to hemispheric fruitbodies that may coalesce, growing on hardwood, 2) color that is brick red or fulvous darkening to almost black, the surface having inconspicuous perithecial mounds near the periphery with umbilicate openings, the texture fleshy-leathery to woody, and the interior satiny black, 3) orange red granules immediately below surface, and white granules between perithecia, 4) KOH extractable pigments that are orange or rust, and 5) spores that elliptic-inequilateral and brown, with a slight germ slit spore-length on the convex side.^ RANGE ^Hypoxylon howeanum has been found in WA, OR, AL, CT, DE. DC, FL, GA, IA, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MS, NC, NE, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, SC, TN, VA, WI, WV, Canada, Cuba, Jamaica, Brazil, Chile, France, Germany, Sweden, United Kingdom, Africa, China, Japan, Sri Lanka, and Australia, (Miller, J.H.(1)). It is found in MA, NY, VT, Mexico, France, Germany, Italy, India, Japan, South Africa, Australia, and New Zealand, (Ju). It has been reported from BC (Redhead).
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] 0.2-1.1(2.0)cm across and (0.06)0.15-0.8cm thick, hemispheric to spherical, "sessile or nearly so, with inconspicuous to conspicuous perithecial mounds"; surface fulvous, rust, or dark brick; orange red granules immediately beneath surface, with KOH-extractable pigments orange or rust; white granules between perithecia; the tissue below the perithecial layer black, up to 0.75cm thick^, (Ju), stromata (fruitbodies) 0.3-1.2cm across, 0.3-0.8cm thick, spherical to hemispheric and symmetric except when crowded, "then tending to coalesce, but never widely effused", texture fleshy-leathery to woody, never carbonous; bright brick-red, varying to reddish purple or brown and when old darkening to almost black, perithecia small, in periphery of stroma, opening by umbilicate ostiola that do not protrude beyond the surface; interior "satiny black with one or more faint concentric zones", (Miller, J.H.)
HABITAT  erumpent from bark or from barkless wood^; on Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carpinus (hornbeam), Castanea (chestnut), Corylus (hazel), Fraxinus (ash), Malus (apple and crab-apple), Ostrya (hophornbeam), Quercus (oak), and others, (Miller, J.H.), hosts including Alnus, Carpinus, Ulmus (elm), Styrax (snowbell), Nothofagus (southern beech), and Pyrus (pear), (Ju)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9.5 (10) x 3-4.5 um, elliptic-inequilateral, with narrowly rounded ends, brown to dark brown, unicellular, "with slight sigmoid germ slit spore-length", perispore dehiscent in 10% KOH, smooth, epispore smooth^; ASCUS 80-130 x 4.5-6.3 um, the spore-bearing part 50-70 um long, the stem 30-77 um long, with apical ring turning blue in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 0.4-0.8 um high and 1.2-2 um broad; PERITHECIUM 100-300 um in diameter and 200-400 um high, spherical to obovoid, ostiole "lower than or at the same level as the stromatal surface", (Ju), SPORES 6-9 x 3-3.5 um, inequilaterally elliptic, almost opaque, "obliquely monostichous" [in one line or series]; ASCUS 50-60 um x 5-6 um in spore-bearing part, elongate, cylindric, with stem 40-50 um long; PERITHECIUM 200-300 um in diameter; CONIDIA on surface of stroma 4-6 um in diameter, round to oblong, colorless, (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Hypoxylon fragiforme is the only other Hypoxylon species with two colors of granules: it differs in the range of the spore size - (10.5)11-15 x 5-6.5(7) um - and occurs at least as far west as Michigan, (Ju).
SOURCES  Ju(2), Miller, J.H.(1), Redhead(5)
216
FAMILY  Hypoxylaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypoxylon macrosporum  P. Karst.^  Bidrag Kannedom Finlands Natur Folk 1873: 40. 1873;  Hypoxylon vogesiacum  (Pers.) Sacc.  var. macrosporum  J.H. Mill.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) cushion-shaped fruitbodies on willow wood, 2) fruitbody color purplish gray becoming black, the surface with conspicuous perithecial mounds, 3) dull reddish brown granules beneath the surface and between perithecia, with KOH-extractable pigments greenish olivaceous, and 4) spores that are elliptic, nearly equilateral, and brown, with a continuous to discontinuous germ slit much less than spore-length, and with dotted ornamentation on the entire epispore.^ | Miller, J.H.(1) considered H. macrosporum P. Karst. to be a synonym of H. mammatum (Wahlenb.) P. Karst. [== Entoleuca mammata (Wahlenb.) J.D. Rogers & Y.-M. Ju]. RANGE ^Hypoxylon macrosporum has been found in BC, WY, Russia, and Switzerland, (Ju).
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] 0.3-6cm x 0.2-1.5cm and 0.05-0.15cm thick; effused-pulvinate to pulvinate [cushion-shaped], surface purplish gray, becoming black when old; "with conspicuous perithecial mounds, usually with cracks along the valley of perithecial mounds"; "dull reddish brown granules immediately beneath surface and between perithecia, with KOH-extractable pigments greenish olivaceous"; the tissue below the perithecial layer grayish brown, inconspicuous to conspicuous, up to 0.1cm thick; perithecia spherical to obovoid, ostioles slightly higher than or at the same level as the surface^, (Ju) 
HABITAT  generally associated with Salix (willow) in glaciated areas^, (Ju)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 22-31 x (7.5) 8.5-11 um, elliptic, "nearly equilateral, with narrowly rounded ends, sometimes with one or both ends broadened", "brown to dark brown, unicellular", "with straight, continuous to discontinuous germ slit much less than spore-length", "perispore indehiscent in 10% KOH", epispore smooth, finely dotted beneath epispore^; ASCUS 190-260 x 13-16 um in total, spore-bearing part 130-180 um long, the stem 50-90 mm long, with apical ring lightly blueing in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 0.18-0.2 um high and 0.5-0.6 um broad; PERITHECIUM 100-400 um in diameter and 300-400 um high, spherical to obovoid, (Ju)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with large spores'
SIMILAR  "Hypoxylon macrosporum differs from H. vogesiacum in having greenish stromatal pigments, in having darker, larger, more inequilateral ascospores, in having a less than spore-length germ slit, and in having dotted ornamentation on the entire ascospore epispore", (Ju).
SOURCES  Ju(2), Miller, J.H.(1) (as Hypoxylon vogesiacum var. macrosporum)
217
FAMILY  Hypoxylaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypoxylon novemexicanum  J.H. Mill.^  Monogr. of the World Species of Hypoxylon, p. 57. 1961
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) cushion-shaped to spread out cushion-shaped fruitbodies on aspen wood, 2) a white surface that is flat or with inconspicuous to conspicuous perithecial mounds, the openings dark, 3) orange granules situated immediately beneath surface and between perithecia, and KOH-extractable pigments colored orange, 4) spores that are elliptic-inequilateral, and brown, with a straight germ slit the length of the spore.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC and NM, (Ju).
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] 0.4-2cm x 0.4-1cm and 0.04-0.07cm thick, pulvinate [cushion-shaped] to effused-pulvinate; surface white; plane [flat] or "with inconspicuous to conspicuous perithecial mounds"; "orange or dull orange granules immediately beneath surface and between perithecia, with KOH-extractable pigments orange"; "the tissue below the perithecial layer inconspicuous"; perithecia spherical to obovoid, ostioles "slightly higher than the stromatal surface"^, (Ju), stromata 0.2-1cm x 0.2-0.6cm, and 0.04-0.06cm thick, discrete, elliptic or oblong, applanate, with abrupt margin; "white, with ostiola papillate, black, inside dark brown", perithecia spherical or conic, (Miller, J.H.)
HABITAT  two collections on barkless wood of Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen)^, (Ju), on dead wood (Miller, J.H.)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (14)15-19(20) x 5.5-8 um, elliptic-inequilateral, with narrowly rounded ends, "brown to dark brown, unicellular", "with straight germ slit spore-length", "perispore indehiscent in 10% KOH", epispore smooth^; ASCUS 140-170 um x 8-11 um total, the spore-bearing part 100-117 um long, the stem 27-60 um long, with apical ring blueing in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 1.5-2 um high and 3-4 um broad; PERITHECIUM 200-400(500) um in diameter, 200-500 um high, spherical to obovoid, (Ju), SPORES 15-19 x 7.5-9 um, inequilaterally elliptic, dark brown to opaque, uniseriate; ASCUS 8-spored, 90-120 x 12 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, with stem 15-40 um long; PARAPHYSES present; PERITHECIUM 200-300 um in diameter, spherical or conic, (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from New Mexico'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Ju(2), Miller, J.H.(1)
218
FAMILY  Hypoxylaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypoxylon rubiginosum  (Pers.) Fr.^  Summa Veg. Scand. II, p. 384. 1849;  == Sphaeria rubiginosa  Pers.;  = Sphaeria granulosa  Pers.;  = Sphaeria multiformis  Fr.  var. granulosa  (Pers.) Fr.;  = Hypoxylon stereoides  Fr.;  = Hypoxylon botrys  Nitschke;  = Hypoxylon florideum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  This species in the strict sense of Ju(2) remains to be established for the Pacific Northwest. Features include 1) fruitbodies mainly on hardwood that are cushion-shaped to spread out flat, 2) color that is rusty to infrequently vinaceous, the surface flat or with conspicuous to inconspicuous perithecial prominences, 3) yellowish brown or brown granules immediately beneath the surface and between perithecia, with KOH-extractable pigments colored orange or rust, and 4) spores that are (8-) 9-12 x 4-5.5 um, elliptic-inequilateral, with dehiscent perispore.^ |The species concept of Miller, J.H.(1) is wider than that of Ju(2): "Miller (1961) extended the definition of H. rubiginosum to cover those specimens with the ascospore size range 9-12.8 x 4-6 [um], with stromata less than 3 mm thick, and with dark brown granules" [Latin name italicized bold], but Ju(2) restricted H. rubiginosum to "those specimens with yellowish brown to brown granules containing orange-series KOH-extractable pigments, with a rusty to infrequently vinaceous stromatal surface, with ellipsoid-inequilateral ascospores (8-) 9-12 x 4-5.5 um, with dehiscent perispore, and without massive basal tissue", (Ju). |The synonyms given here are those given by Ju(2). RANGE ^According to Miller, J.H.(1), Hypoxylon rubiginosum is found all over the world, not limited by thermal zones, and is the most common Hypoxylon species in the world and the most variable. Ju(2), who use the narrower concept, mention collections only from AZ, FL, GA, IL, MO, NJ, OH, SC, WI, France, Finland, Germany, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. It has been reported at least from BC (Redhead(5), 1997, and Callan(1), 1998), but it is not certain whether these reports refer to collections fitting the narrower concept of Ju(2) or merely the wider concept of Miller, J.H.(1).
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] 0.3-10cm x 0.3-5cm broad and 0.05-0.12(0.15)cm thick, effused-pulvinate, sometimes pulvinate or even hemispheric; surface dark brick, sepia, brown-vinaceous, or grayish sepia; plane [flat] "or with inconspicuous to conspicuous perithecial mounds", ostioles lower than the stromatal surface; "yellowish brown or brown granules immediately beneath surface and between perithecia", with KOH-extractable pigments orange or rust; tissue below the perithecial layer usually inconspicuous^, (Ju), stromata "variable in form depending on characters of substrate", indefinitely effused [spread out] and plane [flat], 1-20cm x 0.5-10cm, and 0.05-0.3cm thick on large logs, or irregularly pulvinate [cushion-shaped] to hemispheric, 0.1-0.5cm x 0.2-0.7cm and 0.1-0.3cm thick on small branches with bark, erumpent, superficial, texture coriaceous-fleshy or slightly carbonous when old; rusty red to bright red to dark purple-red; surface pulverulent [powdery], "smooth with no perithecial elevations or with elevations very pronounced with almost free perithecia"; interior dark brown up to vertices of perithecia; perithecia hemispheric to oblong and angular from compression, "with ostiola umbilicate and not extruded", (Miller, J.H.), spread-out thin crust with black perithecia 0.03-0.08cm across, embedded; brick-red to wine-red or ocher-brown to rust-brown, depending on stage of development; "when old blackish, tuberculate and uneven, often furrowed and dotted with the craterlike or papilliform perithecial ostioles, stroma ochre to brown", (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  including Acer, Fagus, Fraxinus, Populus, Quercus, (Ju), on almost all woody dicotyledonous plants, especially Acer and Fraxinus, also on the monocotyledonous Bambusae and occasionally found on gymnosperm wood, (Miller, J.H.)^, on dead, often barkless wood of various hardwoods, all year, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (8)9-12 x 4-5.5 um, elliptic-inequilateral, with narrowly rounded ends, "brown to dark brown, unicellular", "with straight germ slit spore-length", "perispore dehiscent in 10% KOH, smooth or with inconspicuous coil-like ornamentation", epispore smooth^; ASCUS 100-170 x 5.5-8 um, the spore-bearing part 63-83 um long, the stem 35-90 um long, with apical ring lightly blueing to blueing in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 0.8-1.5 um high and 2-3 um broad; PERITHECIUM 200-500 um in diameter and 300-600 um high, spherical to obovoid, (Ju), SPORES 9-12.8 x 4-6 um, inequilaterally elliptic, light to dark brown, obliquely uniseriate; ASCUS 60-80 x 8-9 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, with stem 40-50 um long; PARAPHYSES copious, filiform; PERITHECIUM 200-500 um in diameter and 300-700 um high, hemispheric to oblong and angular from compression, (Miller, J.H.), SPORES 10-12 x 4.5-5.5 um, broadly elliptic to bean-shaped, "rather flattened on one side, smooth, dark brown", with 1 droplet, germination cleft barely visible, spores uniseriate; ASCUS 8-spored, 120-130 x 5.5-8 um, amyloid; PARAPHYSES barely visible, filiform, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'rusty'
SIMILAR  Hypoxylon fuscum is sometimes similar externally but has larger spores, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Ju(2), Miller, J.H.(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Redhead(5), Callan(1)
219
FAMILY  Hypoxylaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hypoxylon vogesiacum  (Pers.) Sacc.^  Syll. Fung. I, p. 380. 1882;  == Sphaeria vogesiaca  Pers.;  = Hypoxylon omphalostoma  Fr.;  = Hypoxylon rubiginosum  (Pers.) Fr.  var. insigne  Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  This species in the strict sense of Ju(2) remains to be established for the Pacific Northwest. Features include 1) cushion-shaped fruitbodies growing on wood, 2) surface area that is purplish gray, vinaceous gray, or brown vinaceous, becoming black, and flat or with inconspicuous perithecial mounds, the ostioles lower or slightly higher than surface, 3) dull reddish brown granules beneath the surface, without apparent KOH-extractable pigments, and 4) spores that are elliptic-inequilateral, brown with germ slit spore-length at the center of a dotted band.^ RANGE ^The status of this taxon in the sense of Ju(2) is uncertain in the Pacific Northwest: they examined collections from Austria, Sweden, India and Pakistan. Miller, J.H.(1) had a different concept, including collections that he assigned to three varieties, from Oregon, Quebec, California, Colorado, Maine, North Carolina, New Hampshire, and Tennessee and giving the location as North America and Europe, but a) the Oregon specimen given as a synonym of the typical variety is the type of H. oregonense Kauffman, which Ju(2) give as a synonym of H. fuscum (Pers.) Fr., b) one Colorado specimens is var. microspora J.H. Mill., which Ju(2) give as a synonym of H. fuscopurpureum (Schwein.) W.W. Diehl and c) the other Colorado collection is var. macrosporum J.H. Mill., which Ju(2) give as the species Hypoxylon macrosporum P. Karst.; the sense of the report of Hypoxylon vogesiacum for British Columbia in Redhead(5) is unknown, but H. macrosporum has been reported from British Columbia (Callan(1)).
FRUITING BODY  stromata 0.1-1.4cm x 0.1-0.8cm and 0.05-0.08cm thick, pulvinate [cushion-shaped] to effused-pulvinate; surface purplish gray, vinaceous gray, or brown vinaceous, becoming black when old; plane [flat] or with inconspicuous perithecial mounds; "dull reddish brown granules immediately beneath surface and between perithecia, without apparent KOH-extractable pigments"; "tissue below the perithecial layer inconspicuous"; perithecia obovoid, ostioles "lower than to slightly higher than the stromatal surface"^, (Ju) 
HABITAT  collections studied from oak, maple, and unspecified wood^, (Ju)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (18) 20-25 x 8-10 um, elliptic-inequilateral, with narrowly rounded ends, "light brown to brown, unicellular", "with straight to slightly sigmoid germ slit spore-length, at the center of a dotted band 3-4.5 um broad", "perispore dehiscent or indehiscent in 10% KOH, smooth", epispore smooth or faintly striate^; ASCUS 207-240 x 15-18 um in total, the spore-bearing part 135-162 um long, the stem 58-90 um long, with apical ring blueing in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 1.5 um high and 4-5 um broad; PERITHECIUM 200-400 um in diameter and 300-500 um high, obovoid; "Two groups of collections can be discerned within this taxon with respect to whether or not the ascospore perispore is dehiscent in KOH. One group, which is represented by the type material of H. vogesiacum, has a dehiscent perispore. The other, represented by the type material of H. rubiginosum var. insigne, has an indehiscent perispore. Additional investigations might show that two distinct taxa are involved", (Ju, Latin names bold italicized, "var." italicized)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  "Hypoxylon macrosporum differs from H. vogesiacum in having greenish stromatal pigments, in having darker, larger, more inequilateral ascospores, in having a less than spore-length germ slit, and in having dotted ornamentation on the entire ascospore epispore", (Ju, Latin names bold and italicized).
SOURCES  Ju(2), Miller, J.H.(1), Redhead(5), Callan(1)
220
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Intextomyces contiguus  (P. Karst.) J. Erikss. & Ryvarden^  Cort. N. Europe 4: 737. 1976;  == Corticium contiguum  P. Karst.;  Corticium crustaceum  (P. Karst.) P. Karst.;  Corticium subcinereum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate, tightly attached fruitbodies growing on wood, 2) color that is chalky white but varying when old, the surface smooth to tuberculate, the consistency waxy, but when dried it is hard, 3) spores that are elliptic to oval, often somewhat angular, smooth, inamyloid, thick-walled, and cyanophilic, 4) basidia with a slight constriction, at the base narrowed into the bearing hyphae, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae mostly indistinct, narrow, thin-walled, and with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Intextomyces contiguus has been found in BC, WA, MB, NT, ON, PQ, FL, KS MA, MN, VT, and WV, (Ginns). It is widely distributed in boreal Eurasia and North America, and specifically noted for Sweden and Norway, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [tightly attached], "perennial, at first thin but thickening with time"; "ceraceous and greyish white when alive and wet, hard when dry, calcareously whitish or rose grey"; "smooth or when vigorously growing more or less tuberculate or even odontioid, continuous but when dried often cracked by shrinkage"; margins mostly determinate [clearly demarcated], fertile throughout^, (Eriksson) 
HABITAT  on bark of decayed wood (fallen trunks, branches, etc.) of hardwoods, in North Europe preferably on Salix (willow) but also known on other trees like Betula (birch) and Picea (spruce)^, (Eriksson), Abies (spruce), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Cornus (dogwood), Crataegus (hawthorn), Fraxinus (ash), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Prunus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Syringa (lilac), Ulmus (elm), Viburnum, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5(6) x 3.5-4 um, elliptic or oval, often subangulate, smooth, inamyloid, cyanophilic, thick-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, the "epibasidial part" 10-20 x 4-6(8) um, sterigmata 6-8 um long, rather long and stout, at first cylindric and obtuse, later conic, somewhat curved, basidia "start as swellings at the end of penetrating hyphae, when mature short cylindrical with suburniform constriction, at the base abruptly narrowed into the bearing hyphae, no clamp at the base of the true basidium", but the bearing hypha is clamped; HYPHAE monomitic, mostly indistinct, thin-walled, with clamp connections, 1-3 um wide, richly branched and densely interwoven into a texture, composed of two hyphal elements: 1) plasma-rich, very thin-walled, "irregularly sinuous hyphae, penetrating the fruitbody, mostly in vertical direction", and 2) "densely agglutinated hyphae, poor in protoplasm and together with remains of basidia and spores forming a pseudoparenchymatous texture", "subicular and subhymenial layers not distinguishable", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bordering, neighboring, near, contiguous'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Burt(1) (as Corticium crustaceum and Corticium subcinereum), Ginns(5)
221
FAMILY  Irpicaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Irpex lacteus  (Fr.) Fr.^  Elench. Fung. 1: 145. 1825;  == Sistotrema lacteum  Fr.;  Irpiciporus lacteus  (Fr.) Murrill;  Hydnum lacteum  Fr.;  Irpex rimosus  Peck;  Irpex tulipiferae  (Schwein.) Schwein.;  Polyporus tulipiferae  (Schwein.) Overh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  milk-white toothed polypore
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Features include 1) a white to cream pore surface on hardwood that becomes strongly tooth-like, and may bend outward to form white hairy caps, 2) spores that are oblong to cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 3) basidia developing in intricate candelabra, 4) conspicuously encrusted cystidia, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system: simple-septate generative hyphae and thick-walled skeletal hyphae.^ | It is common in North America. RANGE ^Irpex lacteus has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NWT, ON, PQ, AL, AR, CT, DE, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, ME, MN, MO, MT, NC, ND, NE, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, SC, SD, TN, VA, VT, WI, WV, and WY, common, (Gilbertson). It has also been found in NB, NS, NT, PE, AZ, CA, CO, DC, MD, MI, and OK, (Ginns). It occurs in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  usually bent outward to form cap from resupinate growth on wood with pore surface exposed, or entirely resupinate, but occasionally bracket-like, up to 1cm x 7cm x 0.5cm, usually imbricate (shingled), semicircular or laterally fused, annual; upper surface white to cream or pale buff, margin colored the same; not zoned or faintly zoned, densely tomentose to hirsute, smooth or shallowly grooved; flesh up to 0.2cm thick, soft-fibrous, not zoned, white to pale tan; pores angular, 2-3 per mm near the margin, with thin walls that split deeply at an early stage to form teeth; white to cream; tube layer up to 0.3cm, continuous with flesh and colored the same; stem none^, (Gilbertson), small caps 1-2cm across and extending 0.5-1(2)cm from the substrate, teeth up to 0.05cm long, consistency leathery-fibrous, (Breitenbach), effused, effused-reflexed or with a cap, "rarely single, more often gregarious or confluent and forming extensive patches or growing imbricately", in capped forms broadly sessile or attached with narrowed vertex, reflexed part or cap up to about 2cm radius and wide, wider by lateral confluence; cap dingy yellowish pallid to ochraceous; concentrically zoned and shallowly grooved, velvety to woolly-hirsute, sometimes with one or more concentric zones matted down and shiny; cap margin velvety, woolly, fringed, or matted; spore-bearing surface very variable, poroid, irpicoid, or hydnoid, with intergrading forms, irpicoid plates or hydnoid spines up to 0.5cm long and 0.1cm or more broad, fluted to ribbed or smooth, finely puberulous [powdery], often appearing almost bald, yellowish flesh color, with entire or incised tip; margin of effused part almost byssoid [cottony] to velvety, concolorous or paler; flesh up to about 0.1cm thick, somewhat duplex, leathery, inconspicuously zoned, whitish, (Maas Geesteranus) 
HABITAT  annual, on dead hardwood, frequently on dead branches or on trunks of dead standing trees, occasionally on dead conifer wood, causing white rot of dead hardwoods, rarely of conifers^, (Gilbertson), on dead wood or damaged parts of a wide variety of hardwood trees, also stated to occur on conifer wood, (Maas Geesteranus)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7 x 2-3 um, oblong to cylindric, straight to slightly curved, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 4-6 um, clavate, developing in intricate branched candelabra, simple-septate at base; CYSTIDIA conspicuous and abundant, "50-110 x 5-10 um, projecting up to 40 um, originating in the subhymenium from tramal skeletal hyphae", thick-walled, heavily encrusted apically; HYPHAE dimitic: context generative hyphae 2-4 um wide, thin-walled to firm-walled, with frequent branching, simple-septate, context skeletal hyphae 2.5-6 um wide, colorless, "thick-walled, occasionally simple-septate, with rare branching", trama hyphae similar, (Gilbertson), SPORES (4.9)5.4-6.3 x (2.2)2.5-3.1 um, elliptic, "adaxially flattened or concave, straight or somewhat curved and allantoid", smooth, colorless, with small oblique apiculus; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-25 x 3-6 um, cylindric to clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA "up to 7.2 um wide, scattered to evenly distributed, protruding, of tramal and subhymenial origin, thick-walled to almost solid, incrusted, cylindrical to more or less fusiform in distal part, occasionally with submoniliform tip, usually with obtuse apex (but sometimes also acute in subhymenial cystidia)"; HYPHAE dimitic: 1) generative hyphae 3-5.4 um wide, not inflated, thin-walled to moderately thick-walled (up to 1.5 um), branched, septate, without clamp connections, 2) skeletal hyphae "3.6-7.2 um wide, thick-walled to almost solid", (Maas Geesteranus), spore deposit white (Lincoff)
NAME ORIGIN  means "milky"^ (Gilbertson)
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Hydnochaete olivacea and Sistotrema confluens.
SOURCES  Gilbertson(1), Maas Geesteranus(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)
222
FAMILY  Amylocorticiaceae, Order Amylocorticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Irpicodon pendulus  (Alb. & Schwein.) Pouzar^  Folia geobot. phytotax. bohemoslov. 1: 371. 1966
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) small whitish brackets on wood, with a drooping fan-shaped to semicircular shape, sometimes with a short stem, 2) a lower surface (outer surface when flattened against wood) with prominent, blunt, laterally flattened to cylindric projections which are sometimes widened to gill-like structures, 3) an upper surface that is smooth to radially wrinkled, and 4) microscopic characters including amyloid spores and a monomitic hyphal system.^ RANGE ^The distribution includes WA (photographs attached) and (D. Parker, pers. comm.) ID. It also occurs in Finland, France, Germany, Sweden, and Norway, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  "mostly pileate, varying in shape but mostly flabelliform, dimidiate or basally substipitate, entire or lobed, sometimes imbricate", small (0.5-2.0cm) and thin (about 0.1cm); creamish white when young, later darkening, the upper side turning grayish, upper surface "variable, almost smooth to radially wrinkled"; "hymenial side in young specimens rarely smooth but usually with blunt, cylindrical or more commonly flattened, irregular aculei, in some cases radially widened to small lamellae"
HABITAT  in Washington a collection on Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), and in Idaho, on the same species, (D. Parker, pers. comm.), in Scandinavia on dead or dying, barked trunks of Pinus sylvestris (Scotch Pine), "sometimes in scars left from broken branches, in most cases on still fresh bark, at varying height above the ground", collections practically all October to April (fruitbodies dry up in summer and new ones start in late fall), (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5 x 2-2.5 um, "suballantoid to reniform, adaxial side more or less concave", smooth, amyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-15(20) x 4-5 um, forming a dense palisade reminiscent of the phlebioid fungi, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, mostly 3-4 um wide, with clamp connections, thin-walled, "rather straight and parallel, especially in the aculeal trama and close to the upper surface, hyphae of the inner trama of the pileus more or less widened, bladderlike", in parts reaching 10 or even 15 um, and irregularly constricted, some of the widened hyphae filled with oily protoplasm; in subhymenial layer, "hyphae are thinner and much more densely intertwined, forming a ceraceous layer, clearly distinguished from the tramal texture"; upper surface of cap of "appressed hyphae, not forming a pellicle"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'hanging' in Latin
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4)
223
FAMILY  Jaapiaceae, Order Jaapiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Jaapia argillacea  Bres.^  Ann. Mycol. 9: 428. 1911
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wet wood, typically partly submerged, along shores of lakes and streams, 2) whitish color, the surface flocculose-porulose, then more continuous, the consistency soft, 3) spores that are long, narrowly fusiform, and smooth, at first thin-walled but after discharge a thick inner cyanophilic wall contracts from each end of the spore leaving the ends empty, 4) cystidia that are long, tubular, and protruding, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Jaapia argillacea has been found in BC, Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson). Its distribution includes BC and ID, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused; whitish (but argillaceous or pale yellowish in herbarium); at first flocculose-porulose, then more continuous, of rather soft consistency; "margin not especially differentiated"^, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on wet wood (conifer or hardwood) under very humid conditions (therefore preferentially found on shores of lakes and streams)^, (Eriksson), wet wood, typically partly submerged, along shores of lakes and streams; on Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 16-20(25) x 5-7 um, narrowly fusiform, smooth, at first thin-walled but after discharge the protoplasm contracts from the ends of the spore and surrounds itself with a thick, strongly cyanophilic secondary wall, "leaving the spore ends empty and eventually they shrivel" (if the contraction occurs stepwise, extra septa may occur in the empty spore end)^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-50(60) x 6-9 um, "clavate, more or less sinuous", several oil droplets present at least when fresh, with basal clamp connection, old basidia often with one or several septa; CYSTIDIA numerous, (60)100-150(200) x 5-8 um, tubular, tapering to obtuse apex, smooth, at first thin-walled, "then with more or less thickened walls"; HYPHAE monomitic, thin-walled, mostly 3-4 um wide, distinct, with clamp connections, richly branched, branching preferably from the clamp connections, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'argillaceous', presumably referring to its color
SIMILAR  Jaapia ochroleuca has spores measuring 12-18 um long, that are fusiform and thick-walled, with "protoplasm homogeneous and not contracting", whereas J. argillacea has spores measuring 16-20 um long, narrowly fusiform and thin-walled, with "protoplasm contracting from the ends to a central, thick-walled body, leaving the ends collapsed", (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
224
FAMILY  Jaapiaceae, Order Jaapiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Jaapia ochroleuca  (Bres.) Nannf. & Eriksson^  Svensk Bot. Tidskr. 47: 184. 1953;  == Coniophora ochroleuca  Bres.;  Pellicularia ochroleuca  (Bres.) D.P. Rogers;  Peniophora ochroleuca  (Bres.) Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wet wood in humid habitats, 2) whitish to ocher-yellowish color, the surface porose-flocculose, the consistency soft, 3) spores that are fusiform, smooth, thick-walled when mature, and cyanophilic, 4) cystidia that are long, tubular, and protruding, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Jaapia ochroleuca has been found in OR, IL, MA, and NC, (Ginns), Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Norway and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused, adnate [tightly attached], "confluent, porose-flocculose, rather thick, of soft consistency"; "whitish - sordid yellowish", when old pale ochraceous; under a lens pilose from projecting cystidia; "margin not especially differentiated"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, loosely attached, "forming thin, furfuraceous patches several centimeters in extent", consistency soft, floccose; cream to ocher-yellow; surface openly farinose [mealy]; margin diffuse, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on wet wood (conifer or hardwood) in humid habitats^, (Eriksson), on rotten conifer wood, according to the literature more rarely also on hardwood; fall, (Breitenbach), on Abies fraseri (Fraser Fir), Acer (maple), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES fusiform, colorless to slightly yellowish, thick-walled when mature, strongly cyanophilic, mostly 12-18 x 4-6 um, (illustrated as smooth with droplets)^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-40(50) x 6-9 um, "clavate, more or less sinuous", with numerous oil droplets, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA numerous, 150-200 um (normally, but may reported grow to 360 um), 5-9 um wide in broadest part, "tubular, smooth, walls thickened basally, thinner in apical direction, tapering towards the apex, more or less sinuous"; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-5 um wide, distinct, thin-walled, richly branched, with clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 10-19 x 4.5-7 um, fusiform, smooth, inamyloid, light yellow, cyanophilic, thick-walled, with granular contents or droplets, with lateral apiculus; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-45 x 6-10 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA 80-280 x 6-10 um, more or less cylindric, smooth, "mostly thick-walled but thin-walled toward the tip", sinuous; HYPHAE monomitic, 4-6(8) um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ocher - white'
SIMILAR  Jaapia argillacea has spores measuring 16-20 um long, that are narrowly fusiform and thin-walled, with "protoplasm contracting from the ends to a central, thick-walled body, leaving the ends collapsed", whereas J. ochroleuca has spores measuring 12-18 um long, that are fusiform and thick-walled, with "protoplasm homogeneous and not contracting", (Eriksson)
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5)
225
FAMILY  Hypoxylaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Jackrogersella multiformis  (Fr.) L. Wendt, Kuhnert & M. Stadler^  in Wendt, Sir, Kuhnert, Heitkamper, Lambert, Hladki, Romero, Luangsa-ard, Srikitikulchai, Persoh & Stadler, Mycol. Progr.: 10.1007/s11557-017-1311-3, [24] (2017);  Annulohypoxylon multiforme  (Fr.) Y.M. Ju, J.D. Rogers & H.M. Hsieh  Mycologia 97(4): 859. 2005;  == Hypoxylon multiforme  Fr.;  == Sphaeria multiformis  Fr.;  = Hypoxylon granulosum  Bull.;  Sphaeria rubiformis  Pers.;  Sphaeria pulvinata  R. Hedw.;  Sphaeria cinereofusca  Schumach.;  Sphaeria peltata  DC. & Lam.;  Sphaeria deusta  Wahlenb.;  Stromatosphaeria elliptica  Grev.;  Stromatosphaeria rubiginosa  Grev.;  Sphaeria rubiginosa  Spreng.;  Sphaeria corrugata  Fr.;  Hypoxylon corrugatum  (Fr.) Fr.;  Sphaeria transversa  Schwein.;  Hypoxylon transversum  (Schwein.) Sacc.;  Hypoxylon hookeri  Berk. ex Cooke;  Rosellinia callimorpha  P. Karst.;  Hypoxylon callimorphum  (P. Karst.) P.M.D. Martin;  Hypoxylon granulosum  Bull.  var. luxurians Rehm;  Hypoxylon multiforme  (Fr.) Fr.  var. luxurians  (Rehm) Sacc. & Trotter
ENGLISH NAME(S)  birch woodwart
NOTES  Features include 1) hemispheric fruitbodies growing on birch, 2) color rusty red to reddish brown, turning black, 3) a surface with hemispheric perithecial elevations with prominent conic openings, 4) carbonous, interior tissue that is thin, black, and woody, and 5) spores that are elliptic-inequilateral, brown, and unicellular, with a straight germ slit less than the full length of the spore.^ | The genus Jackrogersella differs from the genus Annulohypoxylon "by containing cohaerin/multiformin type azaphilones as predominant stromatal pigments", a segregation supported by molecular phylogeny; Jackrogersella "comprises the group of species formerly included in Hypoxylon sect. Annulata s. Ju and Rogers (1996) and Annulohypoxylon that have papillate ostioles and are lacking very conspicuous ostiolar disks" (Wendt). RANGE ^Jackrogersella multiforme is found in the North Temperate Zone including all states except southern, [presumably then including WA, OR, ID], Canada, Europe, and Asia, "not in tropics except at high altitudes and not in South Temperate Zone": collections were examined from North America, Europe (including Belgium, France, United Kingdom), and Asia (including India, China), (Miller, J.H.). It is found throughout Asia, Europe, and North America: specimens were examined from ID, PA, Germany, Sweden, China, and Nepal, (Ju(2)). It has been reported from BC (Redhead(5), Callan(1)).
FRUITING BODY  stromata [fruitbodies] 0.5-4cm across and 0.15-0.7cm thick, "peltate, with convex top and constricted base, usually coalescent, with conspicuous perithecial mounds", surface dark brown to blackish brown, "blackish granules immediately beneath surface", with KOH-extractable pigments olivaceous or greenish olivaceous; "tissue below the perithecial layer conspicuous, blackish"; perithecia obovoid; ostioles conic-papillate^, (Ju(2)); stromata 1-3cm x 0.5-1cm, and 0.2-0.5cm high at center, "hemispheric, usually transversely erumpent from lenticels of bark", on barkless wood irregularly effused [spread out], "often one superimposed on another, and often several stromata confluent over wide areas", 2-8cm x 1-3cm; "at first rusty red or a darker reddish brown", finally black when old; "surface composed of symmetrically hemispheric perithecial elevations with prominent conic ostiola, carbonous, with a thin black woody entostroma", perithecia hemispheric, (Miller, J.H.), Ju(3) in 2004 say that KOH-extractable stromatal pigments are Sienna to Apricot not Olivaceous or Greenish Olivaceous
HABITAT  occurs on Betula (birch) throughout Asia, Europe, and North America, seems highly host specific^, (Ju(2)), on many woody plants, chiefly Betula, (Miller, J.H.)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8.5-12 x 3.5-5 um, ellipsoid-inequilateral, with narrowly rounded ends, light brown to brown, unicellular, with straight germ slit less than spore-length, perispore dehiscent in 10% KOH, smooth, epispore smooth^; ASCUS 150-170 um total length x 4.5-6 um, the spore-bearing part 70-82 um, the stem 75-100 um long, with apical ring blueing in Melzer's reagent, discoid, 1 um high and 2 um broad; PERITHECIUM obovoid, 400-700 um across and 500-700 um high; ostiole conic-papillate, (Ju(2)), SPORES 8-12 x 3.5-5 um, elliptic-navicular or inequilateral, light to dark brown, diagonally uniseriate; ASCUS 60-86 x 5-6.4 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, with stem 60-80 um long; PARAPHYSES copious, "filiform, branched"; PERITHECIUM 800-1000 um across, hemispheric, (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of many shapes'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Ju(2) (as Hypoxylon multiforme), Hsieh(1), Miller, J.H.(1) (as Hypoxylon multiforme), Ju(3) (as Hypoxylon multiforme), Redhead(5) (as Hypoxylon multiforme), Callan(1) (as Hypoxylon multiforme), Wendt(1)
226
FAMILY  Lentariaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Kavinia alboviridis  (Morgan) Gilb. & Budington^  J. Arizona Acad. Sci. 6: 95. 1970;  == Hydnum alboviride  Morgan;  Mycoacia alboviridis  (Morgan) L.W. Mill. & J.S. Boyle;  Oxydontia alboviride  (Morgan) L.W. Mill.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on rotten wood, 2) dense, narrow, greenish spines on a loose white subiculum that has rhizomorphs, 3) spores that are elliptic or somewhat fusiform, yellow, with cyanophilic warts, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae often encrusted, in some cases ampullately widened at the clamped septa.^ RANGE ^Kavinia alboviridis has been found in BC, ID, MB, NS, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, CT, IA, MA, MI, NM, NY, OH, and TN, (Ginns(5)). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach). It occurs in Denmark, Sweden, and Finland, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, effused, attached by a loose subiculum and numerous rhizomorphs"; hymenial aculei [narrow spines] dense, mostly 0.1-0.3cm long, narrow (about 0.03cm wide), cylindric, apically conic and tapering to the subulate [awl-shaped], sterile apex, spines "at first white, then greenish, olive green and lastly brownish"; subiculum white, cottony; margin variable, cottony or fibrillose; thin rhizomorphs present in periphery and subiculum^, (Eriksson), up to several centimeters in extent, resupinate, loosely attached, "consisting of an open, white, cottony subiculum" with geotropic, subulate, greenish spines on top; spines 0.1-0.2(0.3)cm long and up to 0.02cm thick, soft, fragile, surface covered with spore-bearing tissue; subiculum "very thin, open-arachnoid, cottony, permeated with numerous white rhizomorphs"; "margin thin, with rhizomorphs", (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on much decayed coniferous wood and hardwood^, (Eriksson), on rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers; spring - fall, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus, Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar); rotted log; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-10(12) x 3-4(5) um, "subfusiform, obliquely tapering to apiculus", yellow, with thickened walls, with cyanophilic warts, contents usually with one oil droplet^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-35(40) x 6-7 um, clavate, basally tapering to a stem-like part of varying length, with basal clamp connection, small oil droplets in protoplasm, "basidia in young hymenia (i.e. near the apex of the aculei) pleurobasidial"; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4 um wide, when young thin-walled and smooth, "older hyphae in subiculum and rhizomorphs with somewhat thickened walls", "often encrusted, in some cases ampullately widened at septa", "hyphae in the sterile apical part of the aculei densely parallel", (Eriksson), SPORES 7.5-9 x 3-4 um, elliptic, verrucose, inamyloid, yellow, cyanophilic, rather thick-walled; BASIDIA not seen, according to the literature 4-spored, 20-25(40) x 5-7 um, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-5(9) um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, "some incrusted and somewhat inflated", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white - green'
SIMILAR  Kavinia himantia has cyanophilic warts on the hyphae and smooth spores, whereas Kavinia alboviridis has cyanophilic warts on the spores and smooth hyphae, (Ginns(23)). K. himantia has smooth spores, asperulate hyphae, and smaller, more subulate spines, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Desjardin(6)*
227
FAMILY  Lentariaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Kavinia himantia  (Schwein.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1) 160. 1958;  == Hydnum himantia  Schwein.;  Mycoacia himantia  (Schwein.) L.W. Mill. & J.S. Boyle;  Hydnum subfuscum  Peck;  Hydnocristella himantia  (Schwein.) R.H. Petersen Ceska Mykol. 25(3): 130 (1971) (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on much decayed wood, often spreading over loose debris or soil, 2) dense, narrow spines that are at first white, then ochraceous and finally brownish, 3) a margin that is white, often fibrillose, with white to buff rhizomorphs, 4) spores that are smooth, inamyloid and nearly cylindric to narrowly oval, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae as a rule with dense cyanophilic warts.^ |On September 12, 2020, the online Species Fungorum listed Hydnocristella himantia as the current name but MycoBank listed Kavinia himantia as the current name. RANGE ^Kavinia himantia has been found in BC, WA, OR, NS, ON, AZ, CO, IA, MA, NC, NM, NY, PA, TN, and WI, (Ginns). It has been found in Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, effused, loosely adnate, consisting of a loose, white sterile subiculum", bearing dense aculei [narrow spines], which are "at first white, then ochraceous and at last brownish", about 0.5cm x 0.05cm, cylindric, slightly tapering toward apex which is rather obtuse in mature specimens; "margin white, variable, often fibrillose"; "rhizomorphs present in the periphery and in the subiculum"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, broadly effused [spread out], loosely adherent, byssoid [cottony], hydnaceous [spiny], the spines up to 0.05cm long, buff; margin white, arachnoid [cobwebby] to weakly fimbriate [fringed], "with abundant buff to white rhizomorphs, these penetrating the wood and surrounding humus", (Lindsey), resupinate, widely effused, consisting of waxy, pelliculose spore-bearing layer that is 0.005-0.02cm thick and avellaneous, and a loose, floccose, subicular layer that is 0.02-0.1cm thick and white, sometimes with large areas of white, cottony mycelium not covered by spore-bearing layer; margin floccose or fibrillose and with white rhizomorphic strands running over the substrate; spines 0.6cm or less long, round in cross-section, subulate [awl-shaped], pointed or obtuse, (Miller, L.W.)
HABITAT  on much decayed conifer wood or hardwood, often spreading over loose debris and soil^, (Eriksson), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Arbutus (madrone), Ostrya (hophornbeam), Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), Tilia (basswood); old bark and wood; leaves; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES "white or cream-coloured", 8-10(12) x 4-5 um, subcylindric to narrowly oval, smooth, thin-walled, contents with oil droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-35(45) x 6-8 um, clavate, "as a rule basally tapering into a hypha-like part of varying length", with basal clamp connection, contents with oil droplets; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-4 um wide, distinct, thin-walled in young parts, somewhat thick-walled in mature hyphae, as a rule with dense cyanophilic warts (the hyphae also described as asperulate), (Eriksson), SPORES 8.5-10 x 3-3.5 um, narrowly elliptic to subfusiform, smooth to bumpy, inamyloid, slightly olive-green; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-50 x 5-6 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection, "some pleurobasidia present, developing along edges of teeth and growing outward"; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBICULAR HYPHAE 1.5-3.5 um wide, colorless, "smooth to roughened, some with coarse crystalline encrustation, some becoming slightly thick-walled, some ampullate at the septa", (Lindsey), SPORES 10-12 x 3.5-4.5 um, cylindric-elliptic, attenuated at one end, smooth, colorless, granular or guttulate; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 25-40 x 6-8.5 um, sterigmata long; HYPHAE 2-4 um wide, "faintly roughened, with numerous clamp connections, often swollen at the septa, with scattered masses of crystalline material", (Miller, L.W.) 
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Kavinia alboviridis has cyanophilic warts on the spores and smooth hyphae, whereas Kavinia himantia has cyanophilic warts on the hyphae and smooth spores, (Ginns(23)). K. alboviridis has ornamented spores, hyphae are not asperulate, and spines are longer and less subulate, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Lindsey(2), Miller, L.W.(1) (as Oxydontia himantia), Ginns(5), Ginns(23)
228
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Kneiffiella abdita  Riebesehl & Langer^  Mycol. Progr. 16(6): 647 (2017);  == Hyphodontia latitans  (Bourdot & Galzin) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre  Mycol. Mem. 19: 89. 1993;  == Chaetoporellus latitans  (Bourdot & Galzin) Bondartsev & Singer;  == Chaetoporus latitans  (Bourdot & Galzin) Parmasto;  == Grandinia latitans  (Bourdot & Galzin) Julich;  == Poria latitans  Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Features include 1) flat growth on wood with pores facing outward, 2) soft fruiting body when fresh, the whitish then ochraceous surface with rounded pores or especially on vertical substrates lacerate or labyrinthine pores, 3) indistinct, pruinose margin, and 4) microscopic characters.^ | When Hyphodontia latitans was combined into Kneiffiella, a new species epithet was required due to the prior publication of Kneiffiella latitans based on a different holotype (Corticium latitans P. Karst. 1888). The description is derived from Eriksson(4) except where noted. RANGE ^In the Pacific Northwest, Kneiffiella abdita is known from one collection in BC, (J. Ginns, pers. comm.). It has also been found in AR, AZ, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, MD, MI, MS, NC, NM, SC, TN, and VA, (Ginns(5)). It also occurs in central Europe and Siberia in Russia, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  growing flat on wood, adnate [firmly attached], about 0.1-0.2cm thick, "at first whitish then ochraceous, when alive soft, when dried firm and friable"; spore-bearing surface "poroid with rounded pores" or, especially on vertical substrates, "with irregularly lacerate or labyrinthine pores"; margin indistinct, pruinose; subiculum very thin 
HABITAT  on wood, hosts including Pinus (pine) and Acer (maple); associated with a white rot, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  spores 3-4 x 0.8 um, narrowly allantoid, more or less curved, smooth, thin-walled, inamyloid^; basidia 4-spored, 8-10 x 3-3.5 um, short-cylindric, more or less constricted, with basal clamp connection; cystidia numerous in the hymenium, 30-35 x 4-5 um, slightly projecting, cylindric or slightly fusiform, "somewhat sinuous and constricted", thin-walled, "obtuse, without incrustation"; hyphal system monomitic, hyphae about 3 um wide, with clamp connections, "with somewhat thickened walls, frequently branching from clamp-cells or opposite clamp", hyphae of dissepiments arranged in parallel fashion, "those of the subiculum irregularly intertwined", "hyphae of the thickening subhymenium densely united", narrower and more thin-walled
NAME ORIGIN  means 'lying hiding, being concealed' (Latin)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Chaeteoporellus latitans), Ginns(5) (as Hyphodontia latitans)
229
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Kneiffiella cineracea  (Bourdot & Galzin) Julich & Stalpers^  Verh. K. ned. Akad. Wet., tweede sect. 74: 130. 1980;  == Hyphodontia cineracea  (Bourdot & Galzin) J. Erikss. & Hjortstam  in John Eriksson & Ryvarden, Cort. N. Europe 4: 629. 1976;  == Peniophora glebulosa  Bres.  ssp. cineracea  Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, especially of conifers, 2) whitish to grayish white, soft fruitbodies that are smooth, under a lens finely floccose or mealy, porose, and bristly, the periphery pruinose, and the margin indeterminate, 3) spores that are cylindric to allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, some with oily droplets, 4) cystidia that are numerous, long-cylindric, projecting, cyanophilic, and thick-walled except in the blunt tip, some with secondary clampless septa, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Kneiffiella cineracea has been found in BC, MT, Austria, Germany, Romania, and Sweden, (Langer), as well as Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], small, thin; whitish to grayish white; smooth or under 50x lens finely flocculose, porose, and pilose (from projecting cystidia); "margin indeterminate, in the periphery pruinose"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, attached tightly, forming thin, farinose patches several centimeters across, consistency "soft, easily wiped off"; gray-whitish; smooth, farinose [mealy], floccose, the projecting cystidia visible under a 20x lens; margin thin, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on decayed wood, especially of conifers^, (Eriksson), on "dead barkless hardwood lying on the ground", according to the literature principally on conifer wood; fall to spring, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-6.5(7) x 2-2.5(3) um, cylindric, allantoid, smooth, thin-walled, with oil droplets or grainy oily contents in the protoplasm^; BASIDIA 14-20 x 4-5 um, at first clavate, then subcylindric, "slightly constricted or sinuous", "with normally 4 sterigmata and with basal clamp"; CYSTIDIA numerous, 80-120 um long or sometimes more, 6-7 um wide, strongly projecting, distinctly cyanophilic, thick-walled except in apical part, some cystidia with secondary septa without clamp connections; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, somewhat cyanophilic, with clamp connections and frequently branched into a loose texture, (Eriksson), SPORES 5.5-7 x 2.5-3 um, narrowly elliptic to slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, some with droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA 90-130 x 6-8 um, long-cylindric, projecting, cyanophilic, thick-walled, tips thin-walled and obtuse; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'cineraceous' (ash-gray)
SIMILAR  Hyphodontia subalutacea and Kneiffiella floccosa also have allantoid spores and long-cylindric thick-walled leptocystidia: H. subalutacea has spores only 1.5-2 um wide, and K. floccosa has an odontioid fruitbody, (Breitenbach). H. subalutacea has thicker, creamy white to yellow, ochraceous, or tan fruitbodies and longer, narrower spores, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hyphodontia cineracea), Breitenbach(2) (as Grandinia cineracea), Langer(1) (as Hyphodontia cineracea)
230
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Kneiffiella floccosa  (Bourdot & Galzin) Julich & Stalpers^  Verh. K. ned. Akad. Wet., tweede sect. 74: 130. 1980;  == Hyphodontia floccosa  (Bourdot & Galzin)  J. Erikss.  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 104. 1958;  == Odontia alutacea  subsp. floccosa  Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)
