NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on much decayed wood, mostly of conifers, 2) a cream to ochraceous fruitbody that is furfuraceous, floccose, or more or less odontioid with small, close, conic spines, the tips brush-like under 50x lens, the margin mostly indeterminate, fertile or with a sterile pruinose zone, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, and thin-walled, 4) cystidia that are numerous especially in the tips of the spines, long-cylindric with constrictions, cyanophilic, thick-walled except apically, sometimes somewhat encrusted, and often with secondary clampless septa, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, frequently branched, and cyanophilic, with slightly thickened walls.^ RANGE ^Kneiffiella floccosa has been found in BC, ID, AB, PQ, AZ, CO, MN, MT, NC, NM, and NY, (Ginns). It has been found in AB, AZ, MN, MT, Austria, France, Germany, Norway, and Sweden, (Langer).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], soft; creamish white, then pale alutaceous and finally ochraceous; furfuraceous, floccose, or more or less odontioid with small, close conic aculei [spines], under 50x lens penicillate [brush-like] from projecting cystidia; subicular hymenium between the spines under 50x lens porose-reticulate; "margin mostly indeterminate, fertile throughout or with a sterile, pruinose zone"^, (Eriksson), ochraceous cream, alutaceous, grayish ocher, (Bourdot)
HABITAT  on much decayed, mostly barkless wood of conifers^, (Eriksson), on bark and wood of stumps and fallen pine branches; May to October, (Bourdot); Cowania stansburiana (Cliff Rose), Larix occidentalis (Western Larch), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus sp. (pine), P. banksiana (Jack Pine), P. ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), P. resinosa (Red Pine), Quercus gambelii (Gambel's Oak), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar); associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-7 x 1.5-1.8 um, allantoid, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA subclavate at first, then subcylindric, "usually with a median suburniform constriction", 12-20 x 3.5-5 um, normally 4-spored, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA numerous, especially in the tips of the spines, reaching 200 um or more in length, 6-7 um in width, tubular, cylindric but with several constrictions, distinctly cyanophilic, thick-walled except for the apical part, sometimes somewhat encrusted, secondary septa without clamp connections often occurring; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, distinct, cyanophilic, with slightly thickened walls, with clamp connections at all septa, frequently branched, "in the subiculum irregularly intertwined", in the center of the spines more or less parallel; CONIDIA found in one collection, subcylindric to narrowly oval, about 7 x 3 um, produced by subulate conidiophores in the hymenium (similar to the conidiophores of Alutaceodontia alutacea), (Eriksson), SPORES 4.5-7.5 x 1.5-2.5 um; BASIDIA 12-18(24) x 3-5 um; CYSTIDIA 125-300 x 4.5-8 um, (Bourdot)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'floccose'
SIMILAR  Hyphodontia subalutacea is normally smooth or almost so with scattered cystidia, but there are forms of H. subalutacea "which under the lens appear to have a slightly furfuraceous or floccose hymenium", (Eriksson). See also SIMILAR section of Kneiffiella cineracea.
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hyphodontia floccosa), Bourdot(1) (as Odontia), Ginns(5) (as Hyphodontia floccosa), Langer(1) (as Hyphodontia floccosa)
231
FAMILY  Xylariaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Kretzschmaria deusta  (Hoffm.) P.M.D. Martin^  J. S. African Bot. 36: 80. 1970;  Ustulina deusta  (Hoffm.) Lind;  Hypoxylon deustum  (Hoffm.) Grev.;  Nemania deusta  (Hoffm.) S.F. Gray;  Sphaeria deusta  Hoffm.  Veg. Crypt. 1: 3. 1787;  Discosphaera deusta  (Hoffm.) Dumort.;  Stromatosphaeria deusta (Hoffm.) Grev.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  carbon-cushion
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, usually at the base of old stumps, 2) a fruitbody forming a black, brittle, easily detached cushion or crust layer up to 0.5cm thick, sparsely dotted, the younger parts grayish white with a granulose surface, 3) the consistency fleshy-leathery when young, carbonous when old, 4) ascospores measuring 28-40 x 8-12 um that are elliptic, rather flattened on one side, smooth, and dark brown (light brown when young), with a germ slit, in a uniseriate arrangement inside the asci, 5) asci that are 8-spored and iodine positive, 6) paraphyses that are filiform and branched, 7) perithecia that are large, measuring about 1000 um, and 8) conidia measuring 5-6.5 x 2-3 um, that are narrowly ovate, smooth, and colorless.^ |The online Species Fungorum, accessed February 3, 2022, listed the current name as Sphaeria deusta, saying that Kretzschmaria deusta is an invalid name, but MycoBank, accessed the same day, listed the current name as Kretzschmaria deusta. RANGE ^The Forest Pathology Center in Victoria, British Columbia has a BC collection. Specimens were examined from Cuba, Brazil, Venezuela, Sweden, China, but the location is given as "In every country", (Miller). It is widely distributed in North America (Lincoff). It occurs also in the United Kingdom (Dennis), and in Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  4-10cm wide, 0.3-0.5cm thick, sometimes forming sheets up to 50cm long, "irregular cushion or thick, soft crust"; "grayish white when young, soon black, then brittle and easily detached from wood"; perithecia "large, with bump-like pores immersed in whitish flesh"^, (Lincoff), "irregular cushion or thick crust", up to 0.3cm thick, grayish white when young, "soon becoming black and then very brittle, easily detached", perithecia "large, with papillate ostioles, immersed in a whitish flesh which tends to break down" in old fruitbodies, "which are then easily crushed in the fingers", (Dennis), fruiting body consisting when mature of a black, brittle, undulating-tuberculate crust of several square centimeters area, embedded in it are spherical black perithecia about 0.1cm across, the ostioles [openings] of the perithecia sparsely dotting the surface; areas of new growth "form whitish to grayish farinose surfaces in spring and early summer, representing the conidial stage", then the perithecia with the asci and ascospores develop within them, (Breitenbach), orbicular [circular] to indefinitely effused, on uneven substrate variously distorted following the bark, "undulate-repand to subpulvinate", 0.15-0.3cm thick, on smooth wood flat, somewhat zoned and much thinner, consistency fleshy-leathery when young, becoming carbonous when old; when young grayish white, becoming black when old; the mature fruitbody separates easily along the line of the perithecial bases; perithecia very large with papillate ostiola rather far apart, (Miller)
HABITAT  on wood, usually at the base of old stumps^, (Miller), on stumps, butts, and dead roots of hardwoods, (Dennis), on stumps and dead roots of hardwoods, such as Acer (maple), Fagus (beech), or Fraxinus (ash); summer to early winter, overwinters, (Lincoff), on rotten stumps and roots of Fagus, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 32-33 x 7-8 um, elliptic, rather flattened on one side, smooth, dark brown, with a germ slit, uniseriate in the ascus, when young up to 12 um across and with 3-4 droplets and light brown^; ASCUS 8-spored, 300-337 x 12 um, iodine positive, with apical ring; PARAPHYSES filiform, (Breitenbach), SPORES 28-34 x 7-10 um, fusiform with one side somewhat flattened, black, uniseriate, ASCUS 8-spored, about 300 x 15 um, (Dennis), SPORES 28-40 x 8-12 um, elliptic to inequilaterally elliptic with acute ends, opaque at maturity, obliquely uniseriate; ASCUS cylindric and tapering, 190-260 x 10-15 um in spore-bearing part, with stem 50-60 um long; PARAPHYSES filiform, branched; CONIDIA 5-6.5 x 2-3 um, narrowly ovate, smooth, colorless, (Miller), spore deposit black (Phillips)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'burned up'
SIMILAR  Hypoxylon can look similar but K. deusta has "larger and crustose fruiting bodies, larger perithecia, and much larger spores"; the preferred occurrence of K. deusta on the sides of beech stumps and the whitish conidial stage are also typical, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Miller, J.H.(1) (as Hypoxylon deustum), Dennis(1) (as Ustulina deustum), Phillips(1)* (as Ustulina deustum), Lincoff(2)* (as Ustulina deustum), Breitenbach(1)* (as Ustulina deustum)
232
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Kurtia argillacea  (Bres.) Karasinski^  Index Fungorum 141: 1. 2014;  Hyphoderma argillaceum  (Bres.) Donk  Fungus 27: 14. 1957;  == Corticium argillaceum  Bres.;  Peniophora argillaceum  (Bres.) Bres.;  Peniophora fusca  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) thin, soft, grayish, waxy patches that are (under a lens) porous-reticulate and pubescent from cystidia with visible reddish brown excreted matter, 3) mostly elliptic spores that are smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) constricted mature basidia, 5) subulate-cylindric cystidia, 6), capitate hyphae often found between the basidia, slightly projecting, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Kurtia argillacea has been found in ID, ON, PQ, AL, AZ, CO, FL, IL, MI, MN, NM, and WI, (Ginns), Europe including Scandinavia (Eriksson) and Switzerland (Breitenbach(2) who also list Asia in the distribution).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, "forming thin, waxlike patches several centimeters to decimeters in extent", firmly attached, soft; "gray to gray-whitish when wet and fresh, then ocherish"; "surface porous under a hand lens, openly farinose to reticulate, finely pubescent from cystidia"; margin thin^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, mostly thin, 0.01-0.02cm thick, adnate [tightly attached]; white to grayish or ochroleucous [pale ochraceous], porose-reticulate under a 50x lens and also pilose from "projecting cystidia, which as a rule bear a reddish-brown, rounded or irregular aggregate of excreted resinous matter"; "margin not especially differentiated", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on "rotten wet wood of conifers and hardwoods, on the undersides of barkless branches and trunks"; spring, fall^, (Breitenbach), on both hardwood and coniferous wood, "generally on wet, strongly decayed pieces of wood, on logs, fallen branches etc.", (Eriksson), very rotten barkless wood; Abies concolor (White Fir), Acer sp. (maple), Betula sp. (birch), Juniperus deppeana (Alligator Juniper), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), P. ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), P. strobus (Eastern White Pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Poria sp. (a polypore), associated with a white rot, (Ginns), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9.5 x 4.5-5.5 um, broadly elliptic-oval, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets or granular contents^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 5-6 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA up to 180 um long and 10-25 um wide, subulate-cylindric with ventricose base, smooth, in part encrusted with small bits of amorphous yellowish matter (as seen in water); cystidia-like smooth capitate HYPHAL ENDS also seen, 25-50 x 7-9 um; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 3-7 um wide, most septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 6-9 x 4-5 um, most elliptic, with oblique apiculus, but varying from nearly round to short cylindric, with oil droplets or irregular oily bodies in protoplasm; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 5-6 um, "first clavate, when mature clearly constricted, suburniform", with basal clamp connection, some basidia may be filled with a yellowish oil; CYSTIDIA 100-200 x 10-20 um, considerably projecting, "tubular, basally widened, thin-walled", "generally with a yellow, brown or reddish excretion, visible under the lens but in microscopic slides usually crushed and therefore often difficult to observe", contents look watery except apex dense (e.g. with cotton blue or under phase contrast), and under phase contrast in well-developed specimens the apical region refractive; slightly projecting capitate hyphae will usually be seen between the basidia, and these can excrete the same way as the cystidia; HYPHAE monomitic about 3 um wide, thin-walled, richly branched, with clamp connections, context dense in the subhymenial part and looser next to the substrate, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'clayey'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as Hyphoderma argillaceum), Breitenbach(2)* (as Hyphoderma argillaceum), Ginns(5) (as Hyphoderma argillaceum), Buczacki(1)* (as Hyphoderma argillaceum)
233
FAMILY  Bondarzewiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Laurilia sulcata  (Burt) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykol. 13: 14. 1959;  == Stereum sulcatum  Burt in Peck;  Lloydella sulcata  (Burt) Lloyd;  Echinodontium sulcatum  (Burt) H.L. Gross
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth, or partly with a cap, on conifer wood, 2) a texture that is leathery to woody, 3) the cap when present brown, deeply and sharply and concentrically sulcate, often with tinder-like tomentum, especially when young, 4) a spore-bearing surface that is light yellow with a salmon tint, turning reddish where bruised, smooth becoming tuberculate or concentrically sulcate, 5) in a section of the cap, an uppermost tinder-like layer, separated from the layer corresponding to the subiculum by a thin, resinous, hard layer visible as a dark line, 6) spores that are round or nearly round, echinulate, and amyloid, with somewhat thickened walls, 7) cystidia that are conic and encrusted in their upper part, the lower part yellowish and tapering to bearing hyphae, and 8) a trimitic hyphal system, the septate hyphae with clamp connections.^ |Liu, Shi-Liang(1) provided evidence that this species should be in the family Bondarzewiaceae rather than Echinodontiaceae. RANGE ^Laurilia sulcata has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, ON, PQ, AK, CO, LA, MI, MT, NC, NH, NY, PA, TN, TX, UT, VT, WI, and WV, (Ginns). It has also been found in Norway, Sweden, and Finland, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate or effused-reflexed [partly with a cap], perennial, leathery or when old partly ligneous [woody], at first orbiculate [circular], with time confluent, reaching several square decimeters; upper side of cap often, especially in young specimens, covered with a brown, tinder-like tomentum, 0.1-0.5cm thick, "in old specimens mostly dark brown to blackish, often with concentric furrows and ridges", resulting from peripheral growth; "in section stratified with a superior tinder-layer, then a thin hard, resinous layer visible as a dark line, then a subicular trama which is lightcoloured like the subicular layer, in old fruitbodies the tinder may be worn off or filled with resinous substances into a single hard stratum"; spore-bearing surface when young smooth, then tuberculate or concentrically sulcate, light yellowish with a salmon tint, when old pale ochraceous (especially in herbarium); margin when young white, finely fibrillose, then more bald, "smooth or somewhat thickened", "in old specimens margin consisting of parallel ridges, the result of a receding hymenium, leaving a new sterile zone every year"; a drop of KOH on hymenium gives an orange color; the fresh trama turns reddish when bruised^, (Eriksson), resupinate or effuso-reflexed, confluent over areas 3-15cm x 1-8cm, reflexed margin 0.3-1.5cm broad, in structure 0.06-0.15cm thick; corky, rigid, with the reflexed part becoming bald, bister, irregular, deeply and concentrically sulcate; spore-bearing surface uneven or somewhat tuberculate, not polished, "drying between light buff and pinkish buff, assuming a reddish color where bruised", (Burt)
HABITAT  on Abies (fir), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Taxodium (baldcypress), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga (hemlock); fruitbodies produced on bark; broken or cut wood; logs and stumps; butt; associated with a white pocket rot of dead wood^; causes a minor trunk rot in Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce) and some root rot in Picea glauca (White Spruce), (Ginns), on fallen logs of Picea abies, preferably in virgin forests at higher altitudes; causes a white rot in fallen trunks, (Eriksson), May to November (Burt)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-6.5 x 5 um, round or nearly round, echinulate, with somewhat thickened walls, amyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-35 x 4-5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA "numerous, thickwalled, apically conical, encrusted, basal part tapering to the bearing hyphae, somewhat pigmented, yellowish or pale ochraceous in the proximal part, total length 40 - 65 um, encrusted part 20 - 30 um, greatest width 8 - 10 um", inner structure somewhat unclear, seeming to consist of 2 parts, "a proximal pigmented part, evidently formed by thickening of the wall", and a distal part that in old cystidia is as a rule colorless; HYPHAE trimitic: 1) skeletal hyphae, 2.5-4 um wide, thick-walled, straight, with sparse septa and clamp connections, 2) binding hyphae, 2-3 um wide, thick-walled, richly branched, and 3) generative hyphae, 2-3 um, thin-walled, richly branched, with clamp connections, "with some adventitious septa", "the upper tinder-layer consists mainly of brown skeletal hyphae, the subiculum of hyaline or pale yellowish, thickwalled, horizontal skeletals with numerous binding hyphae between them, as well as few generative hyphae, at least in young specimens; subhymenium of vertical skeletals, irregular binding hyphae, generative hyphae, cystidia, and old, shrunken basidia", (Eriksson), spores white in spore collection, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'sulcate' (grooved)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Burt(2) (as Stereum sulcatum), Ginns(5), Liu, Shi-Liang(1)
234
FAMILY  Hericiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Laxitextum bicolor  (Pers.) Lentz^  Agric. Monogr. U.S.D.A. 24: 19. 1955;  == Thelephora bicolor  Pers.;  Stereum bicolor  (Pers.) Fr.;  Stereum coffeatum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis 1873;  Stereum fuscum  (Schrad.) Quel.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  two-tone parchment
NOTES  Laxitextum bicolor is easily recognized due to its brown and white color and soft consistency. Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed hardwood, or bent outward to form cap on vertical surfaces, 2) a cap that when present is brown, tomentose or with appressed hairs, often subzonate and radially striate, 3) spore-bearing surface whitish, smooth, with scattered small tubercles, 4) soft though tough consistency when fresh, crustose and brittle when dry, 5) spores that are elliptic, finely spiny (also called verrucose), and amyloid, 6) gloeocystidia that when young are fusiform and often with a moniliform tip, (when old tubular and obtuse), the cystidia enclosed or protruding somewhat, 7) a monomitic hyphal system, with hyphae brown in the subiculum and colorless in the subhymenium, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ |"An Oregon sequence labeled as Laxitextum bicolor differs by more than 1% from European sequences. If this difference is consistent the North American synonym Stereum coffeatum may provide a species epithet." (D. Miller, pers. comm. April 10, 2022.) RANGE ^Laxitextum bicolor has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NS, ON, PQ, AL, AR, CT, DC, DE, FL, GA, IA, IN, KY, LA, MD, ME, MN, MO, MS, NC, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, SC, TN, TX, VA, VT, WI, and WV, (Ginns), NM (Phillips), Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Scandinavia, specifically Norway and Finland, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate [growing flat] to effuso-reflexed on vertical surfaces [bent outward to form a cap], attached tightly to substrate, forming coherent, crustose patches 0.1-0.2cm thick and several centimeters across, consistency "soft, rather tough, when dry crustose and brittle"; underside (= upper side of cap when formed) brown, tomentose; spore-bearing surface white when young, then cream, "smooth, with scattered small tubercles, also somewhat undulating", margin distinctly bounded^, (Breitenbach), resupinate or reflexed; in section about 0.1cm thick, upper side of cap brown, "in young specimens finely tomentose, in old specimens with more appressed hyphal hairs, often subzonate and radially striate"; spore-bearing surface when young and fresh pure white, "darkens slightly to cream and latterly becomes pale brownish", smooth and bald, "when dried more or less cracked"; in section subiculum brown and subhymenial part whitish; "margin white and finely fibrillose in young specimens", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead hardwood: on trunks both fallen and standing, and branches, both fallen and attached^, (Breitenbach), on decayed hardwood (Eriksson), rotting hardwood, particularly alder, April - December, sometimes overwinters, (Lincoff), usually hardwood, rarely conifer wood: Acer (maple), Aesculus hippocastanum (horsechestnut), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Celtis (hackberry), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Liquidambar styraciflua (Sweetgum), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Magnolia virginiana (Sweetbay), Malus (apple - crabapple), Nyssa (tupelo), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Prunus pensylvanica (Pin Cherry), Prunus persica (Peach), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Tsuga (hemlock), Ulmus (elm); "rotting limbs; dead trees; log; associated with white rot", (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-4 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, finely verrucose, amyloid, colorless, with droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-28 x 3.5-5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; GLOEOCYSTIDIA embedded and exserted beyond the hymenium, 80-190 x 8-10 um, cylindric to fusiform, with yellowish contents and droplets, sulfo-negative; HYPHAE monomitic, tramal hyphae 2-3.5 um wide, brown, thick-walled, subhymenial hyphae 1.5-2.5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, some encrusted, all septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 5-4.5 x 2.5 um [sic, perhaps should have been 3.5-4.5 x 2.5], oblong-elliptic, finely echinulate, amyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 3.5-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of variable length, 40-100 um or more, width 5-10 um, filled with yellowish oily substance, in dried material generally coalesced, dissolving in Melzer's reagent and filling cystidium evenly, when young the cystidia fusiform, subulate [awl-shaped], "often with a moniliform apical appendix, more or less projecting, in old specimens tubiform, mostly obtuse"; "in marginal parts of young fruitbodies cystidioid, oleiferous hyphae are sometimes found, 100-200 um long, with the same contents as the cystidia"; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae of light brown trama distinct, "with thin or somewhat thickened walls", usually 2.5-4 um wide, subhymenial hyphae thin-walled, "in old fruitbodies partly collapsed then forming a hyphal net with irregular meshes", penetrated by very thin-walled, plasma-filled generative hyphae 1-3 um wide, (Eriksson), spore deposit whitish (Phillips)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with two colors'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
235
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leptosporomyces fuscostratus  (Burt) Hjortstam^  Windahlia 17: 58. 1987;  == Corticium fuscostratum  Burt;  Athelia fuscostratum  (Burt) Donk;  Confertobasidium olivaceoalbum  (Bourdot & Galzin) Julich sensu Julich and N. Amer. auct.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) the soft membranous consistency of a cream colored pellicular layer, sometimes with an olive tint, a brownish cobwebby subiculum, and brownish rhizomorphs, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, and some hyphae encrusted.^ RANGE ^Leptosporomyces fuscostratus has been found in BC, OR, ID, NS, ON, PQ, AZ, CO, CT, FL, IL, MA, MD, MI, MN, MO, NH, NM, NY, PA, and WI, (Ginns). It has also been found in Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, Italy, Portugal, Sweden, United Kingdom, Turkey, and the USSR, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  thin, pellicular; whitish or pale cream; when dry more or less cracked; easily separable, with loose subiculum, "light brownish rhizomorphs in subiculum and periphery"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, forming thin membranous patches several centimeters across, attached loosely, consistency membranous, soft; "cream-colored, sometimes with an olive tint"; smooth; margin fringed; subiculum brownish, with rhizomorphs, (Breitenbach), resupinate, effused, soft, easily separated; spore-bearing layer a thin, compact pellicle; "light buff" to "ivory yellow" ("cinnamon buff" to "clay color"); cracking on drying to expose the pale brownish to pale buff, arachnoid [cobwebby] subiculum; "margin thinning out, usually with fine cream-colored rhizomorphs", (Gilbertson), 3-6cm x 2-3cm x 0.01-0.03cm, forming a thin, fragile, cartridge-buff to pale smoke-gray pellicle on an arachnoid [cobwebby] or fibrillose, wood-brown subiculum, the spore-bearing surface cracking into small polygonal masses about 0.1cm in diameter, the margin colored as the substance, fringed, (Burt), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on the underside of dead conifer wood, according to the literature more rarely on hardwoods^, (Breitenbach), on wood and bark of conifers (Eriksson), on bark of conifers, (Burt), on woody debris; on bark; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Ginns), fall, winter spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 4 x 2 um, narrowly elliptic to subcylindric, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 10-15 x 3-4.5 um, narrowly clavate, normally 4-spored; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4 um wide, thin-walled or slightly thick-walled, more or less encrusted, anastomoses especially in the rhizomorphs, somewhat nodulose in subhymenial area on old specimens, otherwise even, light brown in rhizomorphs and basally, otherwise colorless, clamp connections at all septa, (Eriksson), SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 2-2.4 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-15 x 3-4.5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHAE monomitic: subhymenial hyphae 1.5-3.5 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, colorless, some sparsely encrusted; subicular hyphae 2-5 um, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections, brownish, some encrusted, (Breitenbach), SPORES 3-4 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic to short cylindric, flattened on one side, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-12 x 4-4.5 um, clavate; CYSTIDIA none, HYPHAE monomitic, subicular hyphae with abundant clamp connections, subhymenial hyphae 2-3 um wide, "loosely arranged, with frequent branching", colorless, colorless to pale yellowish in KOH, thin-walled, basal hyphae 3-5 um, light brown in KOH, walls thin to moderately thickened, "some lightly to heavily incrusted with a fine, pale brownish crystalline material", (Gilbertson), SPORES 3-4 x 2 um, flattened on one side, colorless; hyphae 2.5 um wide, pale brownish, nodose-septate [septa with clamp connections], sometimes encrusted, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'olive-white'
SIMILAR  The rare Leptosporomyces montanus has larger spores (5.0-6.5 x 2.3-2.6 um) and larger basidia (18-25 x 4-5 um), but is otherwise similar, (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces galzinii has narrow hyphae (2-3 um wide) (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces septentrionalis has longer spores (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces mutabilis has slightly longer spores, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Eriksson(2) (as Confertobasidium olivaceoalbum), Breitenbach(2) (as Confertobasidium olivaceoalbum), Julich(3) (as Confertobasidium olivaceo-album), Gilbertson(6) (as Corticium fuscostratum) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Burt(1) (as Corticium fuscostratum), Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Buczacki(1)*
236
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leptosporomyces galzinii  (Bourdot) Julich^  Beih. Willdenowia 7: 192. 1972;  == Corticium galzinii  Bourdot;  Athelia galzinii  (Bourdot) Donk;  Corticium canum  Burt;  Athelia grisea  M.P. Christ.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed wood, 2) a spore-bearing layer that is thin, loose, easily separable, the color whitish with a yellowish or bluish green tint, the subiculum inconspicuous or virtually lacking, 3) spores that are small, narrowly elliptic to cylindric, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) small basidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, with narrow hyphae.^ RANGE ^Leptosporomyces galzinii has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NT, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, CT, LA, MD, ME, MT, NH, NJ, NM, and NY, (Ginns), as well as Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, Poland, Sweden, Turkey, and the USSR, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, effuse, mostly small, thin and loose, detachable in small pieces", soft; "whitish with a yellowish or greenish (glaucous) tint"; smooth, under a lens finely porulose (especially when dried); margin indeterminate [not distinct], "no real rhizomorphs but accidentally parallel hyphae may form very thin threads"^, (Eriksson), "resupinate, becoming widely effused, very thin, fragile", easily separated from substrate, spore-bearing layer "loosely pelliculose or finely tomentose, interrupted", white to grayish or slightly bluish white; subiculum inconspicuous or virtually lacking, (Gilbertson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed conifer wood, rarely on hardwood^, (Eriksson); primarily on decaying wood and bark; Abies (fir), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Tsuga (hemlock), Heterobasidion annosum (polypore), associated with a white rot, (Ginns), fall, winter, spring; also on bracken debris, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3-4 x 1.5-2 um, narrowly elliptic or subcylindric, smooth, inamyloid, not or only weakly cyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 8-12 x 3-4 um, subclavate, with basal clamp connection, normally 4-spored; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, thin-walled in subhymenium, with thin or slightly thickened walls in subiculum, the subiculum with "a loose, cobwebby texture of mostly straight, sparsely branched hyphae", clamp connections at all septa, branching from or close to septa, (Eriksson), SPORES 4-4.5 x 2 um, cylindric to oblong, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with a small apiculus; BASIDIA 9-12 x 3.5-4 um, in candelabrums, cylindric to clavate, mostly 4-spored but a few 2-spored, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4 um, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections, with frequent branching, often branching from a clamp connection, (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  probably after Amedee Galzin (1853-1925)
SIMILAR  Leptosporomyces fuscostratus and Leptosporomyces montanus have some hyphae in the subiculum 2.5-5 um wide with thickened, pale brown walls; L. montanus also has larger spores and basidia, (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces septentrionalis has oval spores (slightly wider at base) that measure 5-6 x 1.5-2 um, (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces mutabilis has spores that measure 3.5-5.5 x 1.8-2.8 um, slightly larger basidia, and slightly wider hyphae, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Gilbertson(6), Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Julich(3) (in German), Buczacki(1)*
237
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leptosporomyces montanus  (Julich) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre^  Mycologia Memoir 19: 97. 1993 [as montanum];  == Confertobasidium olivaceoalbum var. montanum  Julich;  Confertobasidium montanum  (Julich) Julich & Stalpers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features of this rare fungus include 1) a thin-membranaceous fruitbody loosely attached to conifer wood, 2) a spore-bearing surface that is cream-colored and smooth on a brown subiculum, 3) spores that are cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) colorless, thin-walled hyphae in the subhymenium, and brownish, thick-walled hyphae in the subiculum, and 5) clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Leptosporomyces montanus has been found in OR and the USSR, (Julich(5)).
FRUITING BODY  light cream-color, smooth, on a subiculum of brown hyphae, easily removed^, (Julich(3)), thin-membranaceous, loosely adnate; cream-colored; surface even, (Julich(5))
HABITAT  on Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Larix occidentalis (Western Larch), Larix sibirica (Siberian Larch)^, (Julich(3))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5 x 2.3-2.6 um, cylindric, basally somewhat wider, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, with small lateral apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-25 x 4-5 um, narrowly cylindric, with basal clamp connection, sterigmata slender, about 3 x 0.5 um, HYPHAE as in Confertobasidium olivaceo-album, (Julich(3)), SPORES 5.6-6.5 x 2.3-2.6 um, more or less cylindric; BASIDIA 18-25 x 4-5 um; HYPHAE as in Confertobasidium olivaceo-album: colorless and thin-walled in the subhymenium, brownish and thick-walled in the subiculum; with clamp connections, (Julich(5)), some hyphae in the subiculum 2.5-5 um wide, with thickened pale brown walls, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of mountains'
SIMILAR  Leptosporomyces fuscostratus has smaller spores (3.5-4.0 x 1.8-2.3 um) and basidia (9-15 x 3.5-4.5 um), (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces galzinii and Leptosporomyces mutabilis also have smaller spores and basidia, (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces septentrionalis has narrower spores and shorter basidia, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Julich(3) (as Confertobasidium olivaceo-album var. montanum, in German), Julich(5) (as Confertobasidium montanum), Ginns(5) (as L. montanum), Ginns(23) (as L. montanum)
238
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leptosporomyces mutabilis  (Bres.) Krieglst.^  Z. Mykol. 57(1): 53. 1991;  == Fibulomyces mutabilis  (Bres.) Julich  Beih. Willdenowia 7: 182. 1972;  == Athelia mutabilis  (Bres.) Donk;  == Corticium mutabile  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead wood, slash, or plant debris, 2) a fruitbody that is pellicular, white to cream, smooth, the margin not distinct, rhizomorphs sometimes present, 3) spores that are elliptic to subcylindric and rounded at base, 4) absent cystidia, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ |Hjortstam & Larsson (Windahlia 21, 1994) consider Fibulomyces a synonym of Leptosporomyces according to Ainsworth & Bisby's Dictionary of the Fungi, Ninth Edition: this would makes the correct name Leptosporomyces mutabilis (Bres.) Krieglst. Z. Mykol. 57(1): 53. 1991. Ginns(5) uses Fibulomyces in 1993, but Ginns(23) uses Leptosporomyces in 1998. On the other hand, the online Species Fungorum, accessed August 29, 2012, uses Fibulomyces mutabilis. RANGE ^Leptosporomyces mutabilis is found in BC, OR, ID, MB, ON, AZ, CO, IA, IL, IN, MI, MN, MO, PA, WV, (Ginns), Austria, Czechoslovakia, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Norway, Poland, Sweden, United Kingdom, Turkey, USSR, (Julich, but Eriksson suggests that the material cited is heterogeneous: "According to him to hyphae [sic] should be of about equal width... but in some specimens the basal hyphae are characteristically wider").
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin, pellicular (=athelioid), loosely attached "by a soft, scarcely developed subiculum"; white (in herbarium often yellowish); smooth; margin indeterminate [not distinct], rarely finely fibrillose under 50x lens; thin rhizomorphs present in some specimens^, (Eriksson), resupinate, forming thin but more or less dense membranous-tomentose patches several centimeters to decimeters across, loosely attached to substrate, cottony, soft, subiculum poorly developed; white becoming cream; smooth; margin "diffuse, sometimes with ill-defined rhizomorphs", (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead wood of conifers, according to literature on plant debris on ground^, (Breitenbach), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Carya sp. (hickory), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus gambelii (Gambel's Oak); slash; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on small debris on ground, (Eriksson), fall, winter, spring; also rarely on peaty soil, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (3)4-5 x (1.5)2-2.5 um, elliptic to subcylindric, rounded at base, "in side view both sides may be somewhat convex or the adaxial side or both sides are straight", (if the sides mainly straight, they may be parallel or somewhat converging in the apical direction), smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-15(20) x 4-5 um, clavate to subcylindric, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, "most of the hyphae thinwalled but the basal ones somewhat thickened, varying in width, in some forms of about equal width, in one form the basal hyphae are characteristically wide, 5-7(-10) um, with clamps, anastomoses frequent, crystalline encrustation especially on the subhymenial hyphae", (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 11-18 x 3.5-4 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic 3-4 um wide, BASAL HYPHAE rather thick-walled, the rest thin-walled, some hyphae encrusted with crystals, all septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'changeable'
SIMILAR  Leptosporomyces septentrionalis has somewhat narrower spores and has rhizomorphs, whereas L. mutabilis normally lacks rhizomorphs, (Breitenbach), Leptosporomyces septentrionalis has subcylindric to subfusiform spores that are 5-6.5 um long, often has a rose tint, and has rhizomorphs, (Eriksson), Leptosporomyces septentrionalis has oval spores (slightly broader at the base), 5-6 x 1.5-2.0 um, (Ginns(23)); Leptosporomyces fuscostratus has slightly shorter spores, (Ginns(23)); Leptosporomyces galzinii has spores 3.0-4.2 x 1.8-2.2 um, slightly smaller basidia, and slightly narrower hyphae, (Ginns(23)); Leptosporomyces montanum has larger spores and basidia (Ginns(23)). See also SIMILAR section of Leptosporomyces montanus.
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as Fibulomyces mutabilis), Breitenbach(2)* (as Fibulomyces mutabilis), Ginns(5) (as Fibulomyces mutabilis), Ginns(23), Julich(3) (as Fibulomyces mutabilis), Buczacki(1)*
239
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leptosporomyces septentrionalis  (J. Erikss.) Krieglst.^  Z. Mykol. 57(1): 53. 1991;  Fibulomyces septentrionalis  (J. Erikss.) Julich  Beih. Willdenowia 7: 187. 1972;  == Athelia septentrionalis  J. Erikss.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) thin, resupinate growth on wood, 2) a soft cottony consistency, a white color often with a rose tint, a smooth to slightly merulioid-tuberculate surface, and rhizomorphs, 3) spores that are subcylindric to subfusiform, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the subhymenial hyphae narrow, thin-walled, and richly branched, the subicular hyphae wider, somewhat thickened, straight, with sparse septa and clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Leptosporomyces septentrionalis has been found in BC, AZ, and MN, (Ginns), as well as Mexico, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Norway, Sweden, United Kingdom, Turkey, and the USSR, (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, effused, thin, pellicular (= athelioid)"; white, often with rose tint; usually merulioid, smooth and more or less cracked when dried; margin fibrillose, often with thin rhizomorphs which are also in the wood^, (Eriksson), resupinate, forming thin membranous patches several centimeters to decimeters wide, easily detached, cottony, soft; white, later ocher-yellowish, according to literature also with pink tinge; smooth to slightly merulioid-tuberculate, more or less fissured when dry; margin slightly filamentous, often with small rhizomorphs which are also seen in the wood, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on very decayed wood, mostly of conifers, but sometimes of hardwoods^, (Eriksson), on Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5 x 1.5-2 um, subcylindric to subfusiform, smooth, inamyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 4-5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic: branching from or close to clamp connections, anastomoses frequent especially in the rhizomorphs, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-3.5 um wide, thin-walled, richly branched, BASAL HYPHAE 5-7 um wide mostly, somewhat thickened, straight, with sparse septa and clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 5-6 x 1.5-2 um, "narrowly elliptic, some flattened on one side, broadest at the base", smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA (2-)4-spored, 10-18 x 4-5 um, clavate; HYPHAE monomitic: SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-4 um wide, thin-walled, BASAL HYPHAE 4-6 um wide, somewhat thick-walled; all septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'northern' after the seven bright stars of Septentriones, the big dipper
SIMILAR  Leptosporomyces mutabilis has somewhat broader spores and normally lacks rhizomorphs (Breitenbach). L. mutabilis has narrowly elliptic spores that are basally rounded and 4-5 um long, lacks a rose tint, and as a rule lacks rhizomorphs, (Eriksson). L. mutabilis has cylindric to elliptic spores measuring 3.5-5.5 x 1.8-2.8 um, (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces fuscostratus has shorter spores, (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces galzinii has small spores 3.0-4.2 x 1.8-2.2 um, (Ginns(23)). Leptosporomyces montanus has wider spores and longer basidia, (Ginns(23)). 
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as Fibulomyces septentrionalis), Breitenbach(2)* (as Fibulomyces septentrionalis), Ginns(5) (as Fibulomyces septentrionalis), Julich(3) (as Fibulomyces septentrionalis), Ginns(23)
240
FAMILY  Hygrophoropsidaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leucogyrophana mollusca  (Fr.) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykol. 12: 33. 1958;  == Merulius molluscus  Fr.;  Merulius subaurantiacus  Peck;  Leucogyrophana pseudomollusca  (Parmasto) Parmasto
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth (rarely bent outward to form a narrow cap) on wood and bark, but also leaves, needles, and soil, 2) color that is orange predominantly, 3) a merulioid surface with broad ridges, 4) a margin that is firmly attached, matted-tomentose, with white to orange, scattered hyphal strands, 5) spores that are broadly elliptic, smooth, dextrinoid, pale yellow to almost colorless, and cyanophilic, 6) cystidioles that are common, projecting, 2 um wide, and clavate or with a finger-like projection at the apex, 7) a monomitic hyphal system: generative hyphae with clamp connections, some encrusted with crystals.^ RANGE ^Leucogyrophana mollusca has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AK, AL, AZ, CA, CO, IN, MA, ME, MI, MT, NH, NM, NY, PA, TN, and VT, (Ginns(5)). It occurs in Scandinavia including specifically Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  (2)4-8(15)cm x 2-6cm, 0.1(0.2)cm thick, effused, rarely reflexed [bent outwards to form a cap] with the cap up to 1cm wide, separable, membranous, "soft and tender when fresh, drying as a hard, brittle, shiny crust"; orange principally, "also fawn to brownish, yellow-brown and occasionally with a pale olive tint"; finely pruinose to waxy shiny, merulioid, "ridges broad and inflated when fresh, drying narrow and where numerous they are drawn together into raduloid warts"; margin 0.1-0.3(1)cm wide, thin, adnate [firmly attached], matted-tomentose, "white or in mature specimens pallid to apricot-orange", context "white, pallid or sometimes pale olive next to the substrate, cottony, rather thick", up to 0.1cm, "with scattered or common strands"^, (Ginns(15)), "resupinate, effuse, loosely attached to the substrate, soft" (fragile when dried); yellowish when young, "then orange or sometimes reddish, when dried mostly dull orange or when old pale ochraceous"; spore-bearing surface merulioid, plicate [pleated] to gyrose-porose, thinning out into the margin; margin smooth, mostly finely arachnoid [cobwebby] or fibrillose, usually colored as the spore-bearing surface, sometimes paler and rarely whitish, (Eriksson), spore deposit yellowish (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on "Wood and bark, leaves, needles, sawdust, soil, discarded timbers, in buildings, greenhouses, and cellars, associated with a brown rot"^; Abies (fir), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Rhododendron, Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Tsuga (hemlock), Ulmus (elm), (Ginns), fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.6-7.2(7.6) x (3.8)4-4.8(5.2) um, broadly elliptic or occasionally slightly oboval, adaxially flattened, with a distinct broad, blunt apiculus, smooth, dextrinoid (but the reaction sometimes weak), pale yellow to almost colorless, cyanophilic, wall about 0.3 um thick^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (20)25-35(45) x (6.5)7-9(10) um, clavate, sterigmata 4.4 um long; CYSTIDIOLES common, projecting up to 40 um, "clavate, in some specimens with the apex elongated" and finger-like; HYPHAE monomitic, generative hyphae, of context (2.5)4-7.5(9) um wide, woven, distinct, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections, some hyphae "with segments heavily crystalline or granule incrusted"; "tramal hyphae in some specimens embedded in gelatinous matrix"; hyphal strands "scattered to numerous, when narrow (-15 um) composed of hyphae of the same diameter, when broad they are composed of one or a few broad core hyphae which are protected and bound together by narrower hyphae", (Ginns(15)), SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, dextrinoid, cyanophilic, thick-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-25 x 4-5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae thin-walled, with clamp connections, in the subhymenium 2-3 um wide, richly branched, in the subiculum 3-8 um wide, straighter and sparsely branched, "as a rule with attached doublepyramidic crystals", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'soft'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Leucogyrophana pulverulenta and Leucogyrophana romellii.
SOURCES  Ginns(15), Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)* (as Leucogyrophana pseudomollusca), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
241
FAMILY  Hygrophoropsidaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leucogyrophana montana  (Burt) Domanski^  Mala fl. grzybow 1(2): 57. Polska Akad. Nauk, Krakow. 1975;  == Merulius montanus  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features of this rare fungus include 1) effused growth on pine wood, 2) when dried, the spore-bearing surface folded or raduloid (the warts or ridges not crowded and up to 0.05cm high), lilac when young, brownish black when old, the border white, the context olive-yellow, 3) a yellow pigment that is exuded when sections are placed in KOH, 4) spores that are 3.4-4 x 2.4-2.5 um, smooth, dextrinoid, pale yellow, and cyanophilic, 5) context hyphae that are heavily encrusted with frequent swollen clamp connections, and 6) hyphal strands with branched hyphae clasping broader core hyphae.^ | The color of the fruitbodies in nature is not known. RANGE ^Leucogyrophana montana is known from seven collections originating in ID and NY (Ginns(15)).
FRUITING BODY  effused to 5cm across; margin up to 0.5cm wide, "rather thick, loosely woven, radiating", olivaceous yellow; with a few narrow (up to 0.02cm) hyphal strands, the 0.1-0.2cm next to the spore-bearing surface grayish lilac and granulose, appearing as if new growth "has occurred atop the coarser, olive-yellow mycelium"; spore-bearing surface lilac when young, "drying dark brownish black or lilac-brown", folded or raduloid, the warts or ridges not crowded and up to 0.05cm high, "shiny to pruinose, hard waxy, crustose"; context white or gray next to spore-bearing surface, "then olivaceous, homogeneous, coarsely fibrillose", about 0.05cm thick; in KOH, "sections exude a yellow pigment formed when the hyphal incrustations dissolve"^, (Ginns(15))
HABITAT  on well decayed wood of Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), P. monticola (Western White Pine), P. strobus (Eastern White Pine), and unspecified conifer wood; associated with a crumbly brown rot^, (Ginns(15))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (3)3.4-4(4.5) x (2)2.4-2.6 um, broadly elliptic to nearly oblong, "some with the adaxial surface flattened to slightly concave", smooth, dextrinoid, pale yellow, cyanophilic, wall slightly thickened, apiculus small, truncated^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 4.5-5 um, narrowly clavate; HYPHAE of context 2.2-4.6(6) um wide, heavily encrusted, with frequent swollen (up to 24 um), cushion-shaped clamp connections; marginal hyphae at the tips colorless, not encrusted, thin-walled, with clamp connections, soon encrusted with numerous, yellow, resin-like amorphous patches; hyphal strands next to substrate, "small with narrow, often branched hyphae clasping broader core hyphae, narrower hyphae arising from clamps on the broader hyphae", (Ginns(15)) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to the mountains'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Leucogyrophana sororia.
SOURCES  Ginns(15), Ginns(5)
242
FAMILY  Hygrophoropsidaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leucogyrophana olivascens  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Ginns & Weresub^  Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 28: 96. 1976;  == Corticium olivascens  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Coniophora olivascens  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Massee;  Corticium chlorinum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Corticium prasinum  Berk & M.A. Curtis;  Coniophora subochracea  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) thin crust-like growth on well-rotted wood, 2) an effused fruitbody that is golden yellow with an olivaceous tint, the surface smooth becoming minutely tuberculose, the margin thin, cottony, gray to olivaceous, the context olivaceous and usually with some visible hyphal strands, 3) spores that are broadly elliptic, (often) dextrinoid, pale yellow or pale brown, and cyanophilic, the wall thickened to 0.6 um, 4) context hyphae with clamp connections and sparsely to heavily crystalline encrusted, 5) hyphal strands composed of one to several wide core hyphae surrounded by narrower hyphae.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from ID, NS, ON, AL, AZ, FL, LA, MA, NC, NJ, OH, Bahamas, Cuba, France, India, and Okinawa, (Ginns(15)). It has also been recorded from CO, CT, DE, GA, MD, ME, MI, NH, NM, NY, PA, TX, VA, VT, and WI, (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  effused, about 4cm x 5cm and up to 0.04cm thick, spore-bearing surface a fragile, thin crust; golden yellow with an olivaceous tint; "smooth then becoming minutely tuberculose"; margin 0.3-0.5cm wide, thin, cottony, gray to olivaceous; "context of loosely woven, cottony, generally olivaceous mycelium", usually with some visible hyphal strands^, (Ginns(15))
HABITAT  associated with a brown rot of well-rotted wood and debris of conifers and hardwoods^, (Ginns(15)), on Picea pungens (Blue Spruce), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Platanus occidentalis (American Sycamore), Platanus wrightii (Arizona Sycamore), Populus deltoides (Eastern Cottonwood), Quercus sp. (oak), Taxodium distichum (Baldcypress), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Ulmus sp. (elm); on bark; slash; well-rotted wood and debris; boards; associated with a brown rot, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.8-6.0(6.8) x (3.2)3.6-4.4(4.6) um (rarely some 7.6-9 x 6 um), broadly elliptic, some almost short oblong, in face view some broadly oval, smooth, "dextrinoid or not or with only scattered spores dextrinoid", pale yellow or pale brown, cyanophilic, wall thickened to 0.6 um, apiculus about 0.5 x 0.5 um and truncated^; BASIDIA in candelabra, 4-spored, 20-27(40) x 5.5-6.5(7) um, narrowly clavate to clavate, staining blue in cotton blue, sterigmata up to 6 um long; CYSTIDIA "scattered to rare or absent, sometimes in fascicles at apices of tubercles", colorless, thin-walled, sometimes septate with clamp connections, cylindric to filiform, some tapered apically, 2-3(5) um wide, projecting up to 50 um; HYPHAE of context 2-7(10) um wide, loosely woven, colorless or some pale yellow or tan, thin-walled or occasionally with the wall slightly thickened, "with frequent clamp connections", "sparsely to heavily crystalline incrusted", sometimes with almost spherical swellings that give rise to 2 or 3 branches; hyphal strands 15-400 um wide, composed of one to several wide (up to 10 um wide) core hyphae surrounded by a number of narrower (4-6 um wide), essentially parallel hyphae, (Ginns(15))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming olive'
SIMILAR  Other Leucogyrophana species are different in their surface (typically merulioid, or odontioid) or the color of the surface (Ginns(15)). Hypochnopsis mustialaensis is similar in texture and color but different microscopically (for instance spores discolor blue-black or deep purple in KOH) (Ginns(15)).
SOURCES  Ginns(15), Ginns(5)
243
FAMILY  Hygrophoropsidaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leucogyrophana pulverulenta  (Sowerby:  Fr.) Ginns^  Can. J. Bot. 56: 1966. 1978;  == Auricularia pulverulenta  Sowerby;  Merulius pulverulentus  (Sowerby) Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on wood, often in buildings, 2) a brown to yellow brown, fleshy, waxy, merulioid fruitbody, typically 0.2cm thick, the margin white to pallid, with a few narrow hyphal strands, 3) spores that are broadly elliptic, smooth, nondextrinoid, yellow, and (sometimes slowly) cyanophilic, 4) context hyphae mostly with clamp connections, and 5) hyphal strands with one or more wide core hyphae surrounded by narrower hyphae.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, Washington, NS, Alaska, CO, ME, PA, TN, Austria, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, and it has also been recorded from the USSR, (Ginns(15)). The North American distribution is BC, NS, CO, IN, ME, PA and TN, (Ginns(5), who does not list the Washington and Alaska collections noted above).
FRUITING BODY  up to 30cm x 40cm, but normally 10cm in extent and typically 0.2cm but up to 0.65cm thick, effused, merulioid, ceraceous [waxy], fleshy; "hymenial texture when dry hard, brittle, powdery granulose (owing to a thick spore deposit) on the external surface, waxy shiny where broken, brown to yellow-brown with ridges darker than depressions, sometimes drying black"; surface "smooth next to margin, folded, raduloid or rarely with ridges anastomosing to form pits, ridges usually radiating, interrupted, branched", 0.1(0.15)cm high, 3-dimensional configuration also described as follows: "with ridges that are comparatively high and raduloid (i.e., the ridges often are short, not horizontally elongated, with several short branches that appear to be swept up into the center of the ridge to form a fluted, blunt spine)"; margin 0.2(2)cm wide, thick, matted, distinct from brown spore-bearing surface, white to pallid; "context pallid, white or pale yellow, when thick, soft and spongy to felty, homogeneous", 0.1cm thick or thicker, with a few very narrow, pallid hyphal strands; spore print brown, (Ginns(15): it is not clear which parts of the description may be describing fresh state, but in the key, this species has "hymenial surface brown to yellow-brown or drying blackish")
HABITAT  associated "with a brown rot of boards and timbers in buildings, cellars, mines, and logs and in live trees and stumps" of Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), other conifers, and once on Quercus (oak)^, (Ginns(15))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5)5.6-6.8(8) x 3.6-4.4(5) um, broadly elliptic, occasionally broadly oval, especially in face view, adaxially flattened, smooth, nondextrinoid, yellow, cyanophilic (but very slow reaction in some specimens, generally taking 10 to 20 hours), wall thickened to 0.6 um, apiculus 0.6 um broad, 0.4 um long and blunt^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-52 x 6-8 um, clavate, sterigmata up to 4.8 um long; cystidia lacking but some CYSTIDIOLES in one collection, 3-4 um wide, "scarcely projecting with apex papillate, forked or elongated"; TRAMAL HYPHAE 2-3(5) um wide, woven, frequently branched and septate; CONTEXT hyphae 2-7(18) um wide, distinct, loosely woven, colorless, thin-walled, "occasionally to frequently branched, with clamp connections and a few simple septa"; HYPHAL STRANDS uncommon, usually next to substrate, 12-25 um wide, "composed of one or a few core hyphae which are surrounded by narrower (2-7 um) hyphae", core hyphae 8-18 um wide, colorless, apparently simple-septate, walls thickened to 1.5 um, (Ginns(15))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pulverulent' (powdery)
SIMILAR  L. pulverulenta generally has a thicker context, a darker spore-bearing surface, and darker spores than other species of Leucogyrophana, (Ginns(15)). Leucogyrophana mollusca has, in contrast to L. pulverulenta, 1) a thin context, 2) a spore-bearing surface that is, when fresh, moist and shiny, 3) a different configuration (3-dimensional contours) of the spore-bearing surface, 4) hyphal strands that are rather obvious microscopically, and 5) slightly broader spores that are pale yellow and dextrinoid, (Ginns(15)). Leucogyrophana romellii has 1) a more thin and fragile nature than L. pulverulenta, 2) a different configuration (3-dimensional contours) of the spore-bearing surface, and 3) spores measuring 4.4-6.0 x 3.2-4.4 um "with the wall dextrinoid perhaps only weakly so and a buff spore print", (Ginns(15)). Hydnomerulius pinastri, like L. pulverulenta (and L. mollusca) occurs on wood in buildings, but H. pinastri has 1) thinner context up to 0.1cm, 2) an odontioid, yellow to olive-yellow-brown spore-bearing surface, 3) usually black hyphal strands between the substrate and the context, 4) sometimes black sclerotia, 5) paler, slightly shorter (about 5-6 um) spores, and 6) broad, parallel hyphae in the trama, (Ginns(15)).
SOURCES  Ginns(15), Ginns(5)
244
FAMILY  Hygrophoropsidaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leucogyrophana romellii  Ginns^  Can. J. Bot. 56: 1968. 1978
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) thin growth spread out on wood, 2) a yellowish, smooth to folded spore-bearing surface, the margin whitish, sometimes with hyphal strands, the context cottony or granulose, 3) broadly elliptic spores that are smooth, dextrinoid, pale yellow, and cyanophilic, with thickened walls, 4) context hyphae with clamp connections and encrusted with scattered cross-shaped or dentate crystals.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, ID, NS, ON, PE, PQ, ME, MT, NC, NH, NM, NY, SD, VT, WI, Estonia, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and Russia, (Ginns(15)), It has also been recorded from AZ and MI, (Ginns(5)), and MB, YT, and AK, (Thorn(6)).
FRUITING BODY  (2)5-10(25) x 1-5(10)cm, and up to 0.04cm thick, effused; "smooth (especially toward the margin) with scattered to rather common, low, randomly branched ridges, of various bright yellow to brown hues", particularly pale yellow, ochraceous to ochraceous-brown or ochraceous-pink and orange-yellow, "dry, fragile, thin, crustose, rarely shiny and somewhat waxy, sometimes fissured when dry"; margin 0.1-0.4(1)cm wide, thin, appressed, cottony becoming granulose next to the spore-bearing surface, "pallid to white, rarely with a slightly olive tint next to the substrate", some with hyphal strands; context thin (about 0.02cm thick), "cottony or occasionally granulose", "white to pallid, rarely with an olive tint next to the substrate"; spore deposit buff^, (Ginns(15))
HABITAT  associated with a brown rot of the wood of Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), one specimen on Betula (birch), (Ginns(15)), rarely also on live mosses (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.4-6.0 x 3.2-4.4 um, broadly elliptic to broadly oval, adaxially somewhat flattened, smooth, dextrinoid or occasionally only weakly so, pale yellow, cyanophilic, wall thickened, apiculus relatively broad and blunt^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (17)20-28 x 5-7(8) um, narrowly clavate, sterigmata 4.5 um long; cystidia lacking, CYSTIDIOLES not notable, occasionally with elongated, branched apices; TRAMAL HYPHAE "somewhat woven, not gelatinized"; CONTEXT HYPHAE 2.5-5(6.5) um wide, distinct, "loosely woven, flexuous", colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections, often branched at a clamp connection, "incrusted with distinctive but scattered, stauroid to dentate crystals", up to 6 um in diameter; HYPHAL STRANDS scattered to rare, 15(60) um wide, composed of one or a few broad (up to 9 um wide) core hyphae that are surrounded by a number of narrower (up to 3.5 um wide) hyphae, (Ginns(15)) 
NAME ORIGIN  after Lars Gunnar Torgny Romell (from Sweden, born 1891) who interpreted this species as the same species as Leucogyrophana mollusca
SIMILAR  Leucogyrophana mollusca and L. sororia have a spore-bearing surface that is "shiny, tough, and brittle", whereas in L. romellii it is "typically dry, dull, fragile, and crustose"; furthermore, L. mollusca further has large spores, and L. sororia has 1) narrower spores, 2) a translucent spore-bearing surface, and 3) a lack of roughened, stauroid crystals in the context, (Ginns(15)). Leucogyrophana lichenicola is a similar species that has been described from NT, ON, PQ - it differs in being lichenicolous (undersides of hyphal mats of Stereocaulon and Cladonia), in producing brightly colored (pale yellow to bright orange) sclerotia, and in certain culture characters (Thorn(6)). See also SIMILAR section of Leucogyrophana pulverulenta.
SOURCES  Ginns(15), Ginns(5), Thorn(6) (discussing Leucogyrophana lichenicola)
245
FAMILY  Hygrophoropsidaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leucogyrophana sororia  (Burt) Ginns^  Can. J. Bot. 56: 1970. 1978;  Merulius sororius  Burt;  Serpula sororia  (Burt) Zmitr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features of this rare fungus include 1) effused growth on wood, 2) a pallid to yellowish or pale orange surface, merulioid with scattered translucent hymenial folds, and a white margin, 3) spores that are small, broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and pale yellow, with thin to slightly thickened walls, and 4) context hyphae with large clamp connections, some segments granule-encrusted.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, MD, Sweden, United Kingdom, and New Zealand, (Ginns(15)).
FRUITING BODY  up to 5cm x 3cm and 0.05cm thick, effused, annual, separable from substrate; "pallid, pale orange or chamois with the ridges darker, shiny, brittle, translucent, the ridges short, interrupted, widely spaced", about 0.01cm wide and deep, "not anastomosing to form pits"; margin up to 0.2cm wide, granulose to cottony, white; context nearly 0.05cm thick, homogeneous, white to pallid^, (Ginns(15)), resupinate, effused, "merulioid, ceraceous, at first whitish, then yellowish to pale orange, when dried often somewhat ochraceous; margin white, indeterminately thinning out or finely fibrillose", (Eriksson), spore deposit yellow-brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  associated with a brown rot of Picea abies (Norway spruce), Pinus sylvestris (Scotch pine), Pinus sp., Beilschmiedia tawa (Tawa), and unspecified conifers, the associated wood always well decayed, (Ginns(15)), fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.8-4.6(5.6) x 2.4-3.2 um, short-oblong to broadly elliptic, adaxially flattened, smooth, nondextrinoid, generally pale yellow but sometimes colorless, cyanophilic or acyanophilic, wall thin or slightly thickened^; BASIDIA 15-24 x 4.5-6.5 um, clavate; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3.5 um wide, with walls appearing gelatinized; CONTEXT HYPHAE 2-6(10) um wide, occasionally branched, colorless, with large clamp connections, thin-walled, some segments granule-encrusted, some broad cells slightly inflated, (Ginns(15)), SPORES "not or very little dextrinoid (visible as a slight yellow brown colour when spores are lumped together)"; BASIDIA 4-spored, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae with clamp connections, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of a sister'
SIMILAR  Leucogyrophana romellii also has small spores but they are wider (3.2-4.4 um wide), its fruitbodies are athelioid, and the spore-bearing surface is dull and fragile, (Ginns(15)). Leucogyrophana montana also has small spores, but they are smaller, 3.4-4 x 2.4-2.6 um, and consistently dextrinoid, and the fruitbody is distinctly lilac in tint, (Ginns(15)).
SOURCES  Ginns(15), Eriksson(4) (as Leucogyrophana sp. Hjortst.), Ginns(12), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
246
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Limonomyces culmigenus  (J. Webster & D.A. Reid) Stalpers & Loer.^  Can. J. Bot. 60: 536. 1982;  == Exobasidiellum culmigenum  J. Webster & D.A. Reid;  Galzinia culmigena  (J. Webster & D. Reid) B.N. Johri & Bandoni
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features of this rare fungus are 1) thin, waxy, pink, resupinate growth on overwintered culms and senescent leaves of orchard grass and a sedge species, 2) spores that are 13-16 x 7-9.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 3) 2-spored basidia, and 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Limonomyces culmigenus has been found in BC (Ginns) and Europe (Stalpers).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused, adnate [firmly attached], ceraceous [waxy], very thin; pink; even^, (Stalpers), invisible to the naked eye, the presence of the fungus revealed as very thin pink patches under a lens or low-power microscope, when the projecting basidia may be seen, (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on Dactylus glomerata (orchard grass) and Carex sp., (Stalpers), parasitic; fruitbodies "produced on overwintered culms and senescent leaves"^, (Ginns), mainly winter; on grasses especially Dactilis (cock's-foot), "also perhaps on sedges and rarely on other organic substrates" including old fungal fruitbodies, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 13-16 x 7-9.5 um, elliptic to pip-shaped, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, distinctly apiculate^; BASIDIA (1)2(3)-spored, (25)50-150(215) x 7-12 um, typically urniform, originating from probasidia, probasidia 14-25 x 5-10 um, metabasidia basally 3.5-4.5 um wide, occasionally arising laterally rather than terminally on the probasidium, sterigmata 5-12(13.5) um long, stout, curved; HYPHIDIA absent; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4 um wide, branched, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Stalpers), spores 13-15 x 7-9.5 um, variable, +/- elliptic, smooth, inamyloid; basidia 1-2-spored, with stout curved sterigmata, very variable, usually "with long tapering stalk and club-shaped apex", 25-55 um long; cystidia absent; hyphal system monomitic, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'produced on stem'
SIMILAR  Limonomyces roseipellis is also a pink basidiomycete found on grasses, but spores are smaller, and basidia are typically 4-spored, (Stalpers). Laetisaria fuciformis, another pink basidiomycete on grasses, is widespread in humid and cool temperate areas of Europe, North America, and Australasia: it lacks clamp connections, and has "red threads" (masses of conglutinated parallel hyphae) that are separate from the rarely seen effused fruitbodies, (Stalpers). L. fuciformis has been recorded specifically for Maryland and Rhode Island, but as the name Corticium fuciforme has been used for collections of Limonomyces roseipellis, the records only include those which say that the fungus lacked clamp connections, (Ginns).
SOURCES  Stalpers(1), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)
247
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Limonomyces roseipellis  Stalpers & Loer.^  Can. J. Bot. 60: 534. 1982;  == Corticium fuciforme  ("Berk.") Wakef. sensu Wakef.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on grasses, 2) thin, pink fruitbodies that are waxy when fresh, pruinose when dry, with an even surface, 3) spores that are elliptic to subcylindric or pip-shaped, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) 4-spored basidia originating from probasidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections at nearly all primary septa.^ | Limonomyces roseipellis causes pink patch disease of turf grasses, thriving mainly when turf is relatively long and infrequently mown. RANGE ^Limonomyces roseipellis has been found in WA, OR, MD, MS, and RI, (Ginns), as well as Netherlands and the United Kingdom (Stalpers).
FRUITING BODY  0.005-0.035cm thick, resupinate, effused, adnate [firmly attached], ceraceous [waxy] when fresh, pruinose when dry; pink to reddish pink to orange red when wet, pale orange to pale ochraceous or cream when dry; surface even; "originally agglutinated onto the grass leaf, but may become detached and fissured after drying, often showing the pattern of the leaf surface on the under side"; sometimes sterile, cream to pale pink or reddish mycelium is present, "forming dots which surround and connect leaf blades"^, (Stalpers)
HABITAT  causes pink patch disease of turf grasses; "Agrostis alba, A. canina, A. palustris, A. tenuis, Briza media, Cynodon dactylon, Festuca myuros, F. ovina var. duriuscula, F. rubra, F. rubra var. commutata, Poa annua, P. pratensis"^, (Ginns, Latin names italicized)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (8)9-12(14) x (4.5)5-6(6.5) um, elliptic to subcylindric or pip-shaped, somewhat ovoid from above and then 6-7 um broad, inamyloid, colorless, distinctly apiculate^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 27-60(70) x 6.5-8.5 um, typically urniform, originating from probasidia, "sometimes clavate without probasidial swelling", probasidia 11-28 x (4.5)7.5-13 um, irregular to somewhat ovoid, metabasidia basally 2.5-3.5 um wide, "often arising laterally from the probasidia", sterigmata 4.5-7.5(9) um long, stout, curved; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-7 um wide, conglutinate, colorless, thin-walled to rarely somewhat thick-walled, with clamp connections at nearly all primary septa; STERILE MYCELIUM "consisting of conglutinate hyphae, which are arranged in fascicles or consist of loosely interwoven hyphae", hyphae colorless, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with or without clamp connections, (Stalpers)
NAME ORIGIN  from "roseus" meaning "pink" and "pellis" meaning "membrane"^, (Stalpers)
SIMILAR  Limonomyces culmigenus is also a pink basidiomycete found on grasses, but it is rare, spores are larger, and basidia are typically 2-spored, (Stalpers). Laetisaria fuciformis, another pink basidiomycete on grasses, is widespread in humid and cool temperate areas of Europe, North America, and Australasia: it lacks clamp connections, and has "red threads" (masses of conglutinated parallel hyphae) that are separate from the rarely seen effused fruitbodies, (Stalpers). L. fuciformis has been recorded specifically for Maryland and Rhode Island, but as the name Corticium fuciforme has been used for collections of Limonomyces roseipellis, the records only include those which say that the fungus lacked clamp connections, (Ginns).
SOURCES  Stalpers(1), Ginns(5)
248
FAMILY  Stephanosporaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lindtneria leucobryophila  (Henn.) Julich^  Persoonia 9: 418. 1977;  == Thelephora leucobryophila  Henn.;  Trechispora leucobryophila  (Henn.) Liberta;  Trechispora variecolor  (Bourdot & Galzin) Liberta;  Mycolindtneria leucobryophila  (Henn.) Rauschert;  Cristella leucobryophila  (Henn.) Parmasto;  Phlebiella leucobryophila  (Henn.) Bondartsev & Singer
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Features include 1) effused growth on wood, bark, leaves, moss, old hyphae, bone, or gravel, 2) a thin, buff to pale yellow or ocher, loosely attached, membranous crust with a meruloid to poroid surface, the margin floccose to fibrillose and the same color or slightly paler, 3) spores that are (mostly) oval, inamyloid, colorless to slightly yellowish, presumably cyanophilic, with spines 0.5-1.0 um long and small crests, 4) basidia that are 4-spored, with variable numbers of large globules, presumably with cyanophilic content, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with ampulliform swellings at the clamp connections.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed September 7, 2005 and September 8, 2012, gave the current name as Mycolindtneria leucobryophila (Henn.) Rauschert. The 10th Edition of Dictionary of the Fungi synonymizes Mycolindtneria with Lindtneria. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, OR, ON, IA, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, and the United Kingdom, (Liberta). It is known in Europe from Denmark, Germany, Spain, and Yugoslavia (Ryvarden).
FRUITING BODY  "effused, adnate, appearing membranous, subpelliculose, to occasionally floccose under a lens", 'pale luteous', 'buff', or 'ochreous'; margin "floccose or fibrillose to occasionally rhizomorphic", the same color as the spore-bearing surface or slightly paler^, (Liberta), resupinate, soft and membranaceous when fresh, brittle, loosely attached, hymenium meruloid (at first) to poroid (when more mature), pores 1-3 per mm, surface cream to pale straw or ochraceous; subiculum thin and white, (Ryvarden), resupinate, irregular, patchy, loosely attached to substrate; bruising rich yellow; smooth or poroid, context cottony, soft, pale yellowish; margin "variable, distinct to fibrous"; spore deposit "yellowish to white", (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on bone, gravel, bark, dried leaves, Abies alba (Silver Fir), Alnus (alder), Fagus (beech), Quercus (oak), Leucobryum vulgare (a moss), and old hyphae^, (Liberta), annual, dead hardwoods like Alnus, Carpinus (hornbeam), Fagus, Prunus and Quercus, originally described from dead mosses (Leucobryum species), (Ryvarden), Alnus sp., Pinus resinosa (Red Pine), (Ginns), on "rotting woody and herbaceous plant matter and on organic debris in soil"; perhaps all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-11.5 x 4-7(7.5) um, mostly oval, occasionally oval-elliptic, rarely broadly fusiform-elliptic, asperulate to spinulose, the spines 0.5-1.0 um long, inamyloid, colorless to slightly yellowish, wall thin to slightly thickened (0.5 um)^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-32(57) x 7-11 um, "flexuous, subclavate to clavate", "containing variously sized oily droplets", sterigmata 5-6 um long; in section up to 400 um; HYPHAE "monomitic, crystalline material scattered among the hyphae", hyphae 3-5.5 um wide (with ampulliform swellings at the clamp connections up to 13 um wide), colorless to slightly yellowish brown, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled (0.5 um), (Liberta), SPORES 8-10 x 6-7 m (including ornamentation), elliptic, strongly ornamented with spines and small crests, yellowish to pale brownish, inamyloid, slightly thick-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-55 x 7-10 um, clavate to sinuous and slender, with basal clamp connections, varying numbers of large globules; CYSTIDIA and other sterile elements absent from hymenium; HYPHAE monomitic: generative hyphae with clamp connections at all septa, in the trama usually 3-6 um wide, in the subiculum much wider and up to 12 um wide, (Ryvarden), SPORES 8-10 x 5.5-6.5 um excluding ornamentation, markedly spiny with spines 1.5-2.5 um long; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-55 um long, clavate; CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHAE monomitic, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'liking Leucobryum [one of its hosts]'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Liberta(1) (as Trechispora leucobryophila) (colors in single quotation marks from Rayner(2)), Ryvarden(3), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
249
FAMILY  Stephanosporaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lindtneria thujatsugina  M.J. Larsen^  Nova Hedwigia 43: 258. 1986
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Features include 1) resupinate growth in litter under conifers with the pore surface exposed, 2) pores that are pale purplish red when dried and poorly developed with thin tube layer, 3) spores that are round, inamyloid, coarsely spiny and often with a distinct flange that runs completely around the spore in the center or off to one side, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the subicular hyphae mostly simple-septate but with occasional clamp connections.^ | The description is derived from Gilbertson(1). RANGE ^Lindtneria thujatsugina is known from the type locality in ID.
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, in loose layer of partially decomposed needles and other organic matter; spore-bearing surface with pores up to 0.1cm in diameter, irregular; pale purplish red when dried, "the tubes poorly developed and shallow, with thick, entire, soft dissepiments", tube layer thin, soft, pale purplish red; subiculum less than 0.1cm thick, "arachnoid to floccose, soft and easily torn apart", pale purplish red 
HABITAT  "developing in loose layer of partially decomposed needles and other organic matter" under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-11 um in diameter (including spines), round, "coarsely spiny and often with a distinct flange that runs completely around the spore in the center or off to one side", inamyloid, colorless in KOH^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-42 x 10-14 um, irregular in shape, "broadly clavate or with a swollen base and narrower at the apex", with a basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHAE monomitic: SUBICULAR generative hyphae 3-7.5 um wide with occasional inflations up to 12 um wide, sometimes organized into cordons, thin-walled, colorless in KOH with frequent branching, "often cruciately branched at right angles, mostly simple-septate but with occasional clamps"; "also some dark, thick-walled hyphae present, these with rare branching, simple-septate or with clamps, dark brown in KOH, smooth or roughened with fine tuberculate incrustations"; TRAMAL HYPHAE "thin-walled, with frequent branching, simple-septate and with clamps more abundant than in subiculum"
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the fact type was found growing in litter under Thuja plicata and Tsuga heterophylla
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gilbertson(1), Ginns(5)
250
FAMILY  Polyporaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lopharia cinerascens  (Schwein.) G. Cunn.^  Trans. Roy. Soc. New Zealand, Bot. 83: 622. 1956;  Thelephora cinerascens  Schwein.;  Stereum cinerascens  (Schwein.) Massee;  Lloydella cinerascens  (Schwein.) Bres.;  Stereum dissitum  Berk.;  Corticium ephebium  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Stereum neglectum  Peck;  Peniophora occidentalis  Ellis & Everh.;  Stereum purpurascens  Lloyd;  Stereum moricola  Berk.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  bristly parchment
