NOTES  Features include 1) a leathery growth spread out on hardwood, or also bent outwards to form caps, 2) a cap when present that is brownish to gray, the margins buff, (sometimes) concentrically zoned, and hairy to tomentose, 3) a spore-bearing area that is buff to brown, the surface minutely bristly (from cystidia), and smooth, spiny or with shallow pores, 4) spores that are oval to cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) cystidia that are protruding, conic, colorless to dark brown, thick-walled, and coarsely encrusted, and 6) a dimitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Lopharia cinerascens has been found in OR, MB, NB, ON, PQ, AL, AR, CA, CO, CT, DC, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, MD, MI, MN, MO, MS, MT, ND, NE, NY, OH, PA, RI, SC, SD, TN, TX, VA, and VT, (Ginns), as well as Cuba, Jamaica, Mexico, Venezuela, and South Africa, (Welden).
FRUITING BODY  can spread over an area 15cm x 7.5cm, cap when present 0.3-1cm wide, leathery, often laterally fused, cinnamon-buff to brownish, (weathering gray), concentrically zoned; flesh 0.5-1cm thick; spore-bearing surface pinkish-buff to brown, "powdery to minutely bristly because of large cystidia", often slightly cracked; spore print white^, (Lincoff), effused [spread out] to effuso-reflexed [spread out on surface but bent outwards to form a cap], coriaceous [leathery], surface of cap "strigose-hirsute to tomentose, gray except at buff margins, occasionally zoned"; spore-bearing surface buff or darker, "densely setulose, smooth, spiny, or irregularly and shallowly poroid", "delicately cracked in some", (Welden)
HABITAT  on dead hardwood, especially mulberry and elm, also linden and locust; June to February^, (Lincoff), Acer, Carya, Elaeagnus, Euonymus, Magnolia, Morus, Platanus, Populus, Prunus, Quercus, Rhamnus, Robinia, Salix, Sambucus, Tilia, Ulmus, Umbellularia, Vitis; decaying wood, fallen limbs; logs, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-15.5 x 5.5-10 um, oval to cylindric, smooth, colorless^; CYSTIDIA 80-180 x 16-26 um, conic, coarsely encrusted, (Lincoff), SPORES 8-14 x 4.5-6.5 um, on the basis of the genus description smooth, inamyloid, and colorless; BASIDIA 50-62 x 9-10 um; CYSTIDIA 17-21 um in diameter, colorless to dark brown, thick-walled, encrusted; HYPHAE dimitic, with clamp connections; in section, the layers are hymenium, subhymenium, hymenophore, context, cuticle, and epicutis; HYMENOPHORE interwoven, with many skeletal hyphae, generative hyphae 2-4 um wide, skeletal hyphae 4-6 um wide (some form the cystidia); CONTEXT similar to cap cuticle but not as compact; CUTICLE of densely compact, longitudinally parallel, mostly skeletal hyphae; EPICUTIS of mixed generative and skeletal hyphae, (Welden)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming ash-gray'
SIMILAR  Other Lopharia species lack the cuticle (except Lopharia sharpiana from Mexico, which has spores 5-8 x 2-4 um), and some lack clamp connections, (Welden).
SOURCES  Welden(3), Lincoff(2)*, Ginns(5)
251
FAMILY  Hyphodermataceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lyomyces crustosus  (Pers.) P. Karst.^  Revue mycol., Toulouse 3(no. 9): 23. 1881;  == Hyphodontia crustosa  (Pers.) J. Erikss.  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 104. 1958;  == Grandinia crustosa  (Pers.) Fr.;  == Basidioradulum crustosum  (Pers.) Zmitr.;  == Kneiffiella crustosa  (Pers.) Julich & Stalpers;  == Odontia crustosa  Pers.;  == Xylodon crustosus (Pers.) Chevall.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood or less often conifer wood, 2) a somewhat waxy, whitish to ocherish fruitbody, smooth when young but becoming odontioid with short spines, the margin variable, 3) spores that are narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, with one droplet, 4) basidia that sometimes show internal repetition, 5) cystidia-like hyphal ends that are slightly projecting, fusiform, and tapering toward the tip which is sometimes constricted to form a conidium-like structure, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, in older fruitbodies encrusted with coarse crystals.^ | As in Lyomyces juniperi, the fruitbodies of L. crustosus "often contain living, single-celled, green-algae abundantly making the sections through the fruitbody look green" [at least in Europe], (Eriksson(6)). RANGE ^Lyomyces crustosus has been found in BC, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, ON, AK, AR, AZ, CA, CO, FL, GA, IA, MD, MI, MN, MS, MT, NY, and WI, (Ginns). It has been found in BC, MA, WI, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Spain, Sweden, Iran, Russia (Siberia), and Taiwan, (Langer), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and all parts of Scandinavia from Denmark to northern Lappland, (Eriksson(4)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, orbicular [circular] and confluent when growing on bark, on barkless wood more or less irregularly effused; subceraceous [somewhat waxy], when dried crustaceous, 0.01-0.03cm thick; whitish, yellowish white, or cream, when postmature darkening to pale ochraceous; surface varying, when young smooth with small, distinctly separated aculei [spines], when old closer, finally crowded; subiculum continuous at first, when old or especially when dried, cracked into small polygons; "margin variable but mostly determinate and fertile throughout, sometimes with a sterile marginal zone, under the lens finely fibrillose or in the periphery pruinose"^, (Eriksson(4)), resupinate, tightly attached, forming thin, membranous patches several centimeters across, consistency wax-like and soft when fresh, "crustose and brittle when dry"; white to ocherish; smooth when young, then verrucose with short teeth (odontioid); fissured when dry; "margin distinctly bounded to fringed", (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  mostly on hardwood, especially on dead barked or barkless branches, either fallen or still hanging, less often on lying logs, also on coniferous wood^, especially on dead, still hanging branches of Pinus and Juniperus, (Eriksson(4)), on dead wood and bark of hardwoods, according to the literature also of conifers, "principally on branches, with and without bark, attached or lying on the ground"; spring, (Breitenbach), on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Arbutus (madrone), Arctostaphylos (manzanita), Betula (birch), Cornus (dogwood), Corylus (hazel), Cupressus (cypress), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Sambucus (elder), Taxodium (baldcypress); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5 x 2.5-3 um, narrowly elliptic to subcylindric, smooth, thin-walled, mostly with one oil droplet^; BASIDIA 20-30(35) x 4-5 um, sometimes longer, at first narrowly clavate, then subcylindric with median constriction, with basal clamp connection, internal linear basidial repetition seems to occur occasionally, normally 4-spored; CYSTIDIA none, but in the hymenium and in the aculeal apices numerous subulate hyphal ends (cystidioles), "slightly projecting, sometimes with an apical enlargement, making them look like conidiophores with an apical conidium", thus simulating parasitic hyphomycetes that frequently occur in hymenia of resupinate fungi; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, richly branched, thin-walled, with clamp connections; "basal hyphae rather loosely intertwined, subhymenial hyphae densely joined"; "in old specimens lots of crystals in the texture", (Eriksson(4)), SPORES 5-6.5 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, oval, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with 1 droplet; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-28 x 2.5-4.5 um, cylindric-clavate, somewhat constricted, with basal clamp connection, some basidia with internal repetition; LEPTOCYSTIDIA projecting, fusiform, tapering toward the tip, sometimes constricted at the tip to form conidium-like structure, usually with basal septum and clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3.5 um, encrusted with coarse crystals in older fruitbodies, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'crustose'
SIMILAR  Three others share the subulate leptocystidia and internal repetition of basidia: Lyomyces pruni (broader spores measuring 5.5-6.5 x 3.5-4.5 um), Lyomyces juniperi [spores measuring 5-7 x 3-4 um], and Hyphodontia quercina (longer spines and longer spores measuring 6-7.5 x 2.5-3 um), (Breitenbach). L. juniperi has "whiter, thicker, less odontioid fruitbodies" and broader (elliptic) spores, (Eriksson(6)). 
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hyphodontia crustosa), Breitenbach(2)* (as Grandinia), Ginns(5) (as Hyphodontia crustosa), Langer(1) (as Hyphodontia crustosa), Buczacki(1)* (as Hyphodontia crustosa), Eriksson(6) (under Hyphodontia juniperi), Riebesehl(1)
252
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lyomyces juniperi  (Bourdot & Galzin) Riebesehl & Langer^  Mycol. Progr. 16(6): 647. 2017;  == Hyphodontia juniperi  (Bourdot & Galzin) J. Erikss. & Hjortstam  in Eriksson & Ryvarden, Cort. N. Europe 4: 666. 1976;  == Grandinia juniperi (Bourdot & Galzin) Julich;  == Kneiffiella juniperi (Bourdot & Galzin) Julich & Stalpers;  == Xylodon juniperi  (Bourdot & Galzin) Hjortstam & Ryvarden;  == Corticium serum  var. juniperi  Bourdot & Galzin;  = Hyphodontia stratosa  Hjortstam
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifers of the family Cupressaceae, especially juniper, 2) a white to yellowish fruitbody that is smooth to tuberculate, with hemispheric nodules, the margin well demarcated, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) basidia showing internal repetition, 5) subulate cystidia, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled, with considerable crystalline matter, especially in old fruitbodies.^ | As in Lyomyces crustosus, the fruitbodies of L. juniperi "often contain living, single-celled, green-algae abundantly making the sections through the fruitbody look green" [at least in Europe] (Eriksson(6)). RANGE ^Lyomyces juniperi has been found in BC, Germany, Greece (Crete), Macedonia, Spain, Sweden, Ethiopia, Kenya, Tanzania, and Iran, (Langer), and TX (Ginns). It has been reported also from France (Eriksson(6)). It is apparently fairly common in south Europe, especially on Juniperus (Eriksson(4)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused up to 5cm, crustose; white to cream, "hydnaceous with short, scattered aculei", spore-bearing surface continuous over surfaces between teeth, "cracking deeply into small, irregular blocks on drying"; margin thinning out, colored as the rest of the spore-bearing surface, floccose or radially fimbriate [fringed]; subiculum less than 0.03cm thick, soft-fibrous, white, (Gilbertson), resupinate, 0.005-0.1cm thick; white to yellowish; smooth to finely warty (in herbarium surface often cracked); margin sharp, (Langer), resupinate, "orbicular confluent", crustaceous, closely adnate, thickening to about 0.05cm; "white-cream-colored"; almost smooth at first "but becoming more or less tuberculose"; "margin abrupt but not especially differentiated in the mature specimens, sometimes partly fimbriate in young specimens", (Eriksson(6)), corticioid, rather thick, white; more or less tuberculate, with semiglobose nodules; margin determinate, (Eriksson(4))
HABITAT  on Juniperus (juniper), Cupressus (cypress), Thuja, also Pinus (pine), Buxus (box)^, (Langer), on Juniperus ashei (Ashe Juniper); on dead branches; associated with a white rot, (Ginns, for Texas), mainly on dry branches of Juniperus, "but also found on hard deciduous wood", (Eriksson(6))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5 x 3.5-4 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-35 x 5-5.5 um, "narrowly clavate with a median constriction", with a basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA "represented by subulate hyphal ends present at apices of aculei and in hymenium", HYPHAE monomitic, SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-4 um wide, thin-walled to firm-walled, "lightly to heavily incrusted with coarse crystalline material present throughout the subiculum", with abundant clamp connections, frequently branching out of clamp connections or adjacent to septa, (Gilbertson), SPORES 5-7 x 3-4 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, containing droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 4-5 um, suburniform with one or two constrictions, with basal clamp connection, frequently with basidial internal repetition, sterigmata 3-4 um long; CYSTIDIA subulate, variable in size and shape (referred to by Eriksson(4) as cystidioles); HYPHAE monomitic, basal, subicular and subhymenial hyphae 2-3 um wide, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled (up to 0.5 um); all hyphae with clamp connections; many collapsed hyphae in the subhymenial zone; hyphae may be incrusted, the crystalline matter not dissolving in 5% KOH, in old fruitbodies there is a layered accumulation of crystalline material, (Langer), SPORES 4.5-6 x 3-4 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, not cyanophilic; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-25 x 3.5-5 um, with basal clamp connection, linear basidial repetition occurs; CYSTIDIA (cystidioles) "usually numerous", 25-30 x 2-3 um, "hypha-like, tapering to the acute apex, often with attached crystals"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, "thin-walled, richly ramified and densely intertwined, in older texture with abundant crystalline encrustations", hyphae with clamp connections, (Eriksson(6)), SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic; numerous subulate cystidioles in the hymenium (Eriksson(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Juniperus' (juniper)
SIMILAR  Lyomyces crustosus 1) prefers hardwoods, 2) has a surface that is fine-warty to odontioid as opposed to smooth to fine-warty for L. juniperi, 3) has spores that are slightly narrower at 5-7 x 2.5-3.5 um instead of 5-7 x 3-4 um for L. juniperi, and 4) sometimes has an apical enlargement on the subulate cystidia, (Langer). Lyomyces crustosus is similar but L. juniperi has "whiter, thicker, less odontioid fruitbodies" and broader (elliptic) spores, (Eriksson(6)). Lyomyces pruni is similar but L. juniperi differs by being corticioid, with a rather thick, white fruitbody that has determinate margins, (Eriksson(4)).
SOURCES  Gilbertson(4) (as Hyphodontia juniperi), Langer(1) (in German) (as Hyphodontia juniperi), Eriksson(6) (as Hyphodontia juniperi), Eriksson(4) (under Lyomyces pruni as Hyphodontia pruni), Ginns(5) (as Hyphodontia juniperi), Riebesehl(1)
253
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lyomyces pruni  (Lasch) Riebesehl & Langer^  Mycol. Progr. 16(6): 649. 2017;  == Hyphodontia pruni  (Lasch) Svrcek  Ceska Mykol. 27(4): 204. 1973;  == Hyphodontia pruni  (Lasch) J. Erikss. & Hjortstam;  Grandinia pruni (Lasch) Julich;  == Hyphoderma pruni  (Lasch) Julich;  == Hyphodontia pruni  (Lasch) Svrcek;  == Pteridomyces subsphaericosporus  Boidin, Duhem & Gilles;  == Xylodon pruni  (Lasch) Hjortstam & Ryvarden;  == Phanerochaete pruni  (Lasch) S.S. Rattan;  == Odontia pruni  Lasch;  = Hyphodontia bugellensis  (Ces.) J. Erikss.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) a somewhat waxy fruitbody that is white or cream becoming ochraceous, and odontioid with small, narrow, conic to cylindric spines, sometimes in parallel rows, under a 50x lens the spines apically brush-like, 3) a fruitbody margin that is usually well demarcated, 4) spores that elliptic or subcylindric, smooth, and have 1 droplet, 5) basidia showing linear basidial repetition, 6) sterile hyphal ends in the hymenium that are generally obtuse or capitate, the capitate ends often with a cap of resinous encrustation, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae richly branched, with clamp connections, the texture with considerable crystalline material, and the hyphae projecting from the tips of the spines normally encrusted.^ RANGE ^Lyomyces pruni has been found in BC, PQ, Germany, Italy, Sweden, Spain, Turkey, and China, (Langer), and AZ (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, at first orbicular [circular] but then confluent and effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], subceraceous [somewhat waxy] when alive and moist, subcrustaceous when dried; white or cream, finally pale ochraceous; odontioid with small, narrow, conic or subcylindric aculei [spines], "in some specimens arranged in parallel rows", apically penicillate [brush-like] from projecting hyphae; subiculum between the spines in dry mature specimens cracked into polygons; "margin variable but generally determinate, sometimes under the lens finely fimbriate"^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on decayed hardwood, usually without bark, most often on Ulmus (elm), also on Corylus (hazel), Fraxinus (ash), Prunus, Salix (willow), and Sorbus (mountain-ash)^, (Eriksson for Scandinavia), on Chilopsis linearis (Desert-willow), Platanus wrightii (Arizona sycamore), Populus, (Ginns), Prunus, Ulmus, Corylus, Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Myrica (bayberry), (Langer)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-6.5(7) x 3.5-4.5 um, elliptic or subcylindric, smooth, thin-walled, normally with 1 droplet^; BASIDIA at first narrowly subclavate, then subcylindric with a suburniform constriction, 22-28 x 4-5 um, normally 4-spored and with a basal clamp connection, "linear basidial repetition seems to occur"; CYSTIDIA "none, but sterile hyphal ends occur in the hymenium, generally obtuse or capitate", and could be regarded as cystidioles: the capitate hyphal ends often have a cap of resinous encrustation; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, distinct, richly branched, with thin or slightly thickened walls, with clamp connections; texture in old fruitbodies almost filled with crystalline matter, in such cases the hyphae more or less collapsed; apical projecting aculeal hyphae "mostly tapering, sometimes slightly capitate, normally with numerous attached crystals", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Prunus' one of its hosts
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Lyomyces crustosus and Lyomyces juniperi.
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hyphodontia pruni), Langer(1) (as Hyphodontia pruni), Ginns(5) (as Hyphodontia pruni)
254
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Megalocystidium montanum  Ginns & G.W. Freeman^  Bibl. Mycol. 157: 82. 1994
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Megalocystidium montanum is distinguished from others in the genus Megalocystidium and North American Gloeocystidiellaceae by delicately ornamented, large spores. Features (in the herbarium) include 1) resupinate growth on wood of Abies (fir), 2) a crustose fruitbody that is whitish to pale brown, waxy, smooth but fissured, the margin typically indistinct, the subiculum very thin or nonexistent, 3) spores measuring (8.4)9.6-12.0(14.0) x (4.0)4.4-5.6(6.0) um, mostly elliptic, minutely verrucose (with warts 0.2 um tall, 0.2-0.3 um wide), amyloid, and colorless, 4) sulfo-negative gloeocystidia that are fusoid to cylindric with the outline wavy, some with a small bulbous swelling at the apex, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, the subhymenium comprising most of the fruitbody and consisting of vertically oriented gloeocystidia, hyphae and old basidia, typically layered.^ RANGE ^Megalocystidium montanum has been found in ID and CA (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  effused, adnate [firmly attached], crustose, extent in nature unknown but the largest piece studied was 10cm x 4cm and 0.026 x 0.06cm thick; pallid, grayish tan, tan, tawny, fawn, pale brown; smooth, ceraceous [waxy], "typically with numerous deep fissures oriented at right angles to the grain of the wood", some fruitbodies with areas lacking fissures; margin "typically indistinct, but sometimes white to pallid, thin", byssoid [cottony] to matted tomentose, up to 0.1cm wide; "subiculum nonexistent or very thin, pallid"
HABITAT  on barkless wood that varied from firm to well-rotted, of Abies magnifica var. shastensis (Shasta Red Fir), A. concolor (White Fir), and Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir); "associated with a white rot in some collections"
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (8.4)9.6-12.0(14.0) x (4.0)4.4-5.6(6.0) um, elliptic, "a few nearly oblong", "adaxially slightly concave or basally bent", "the wall often appearing smooth but minutely verrucose" (with warts 0.2 um tall, 0.2-0.3 um wide), amyloid, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-50 x 7-8 um, narrowly clavate, sterigmata 5-6 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 52-85 x 7-14 um, "fusoid to cylindric with the outline wavy, some basally swollen", "some with a small bulbous swelling at the apex, the contents in KOH indistinct, finely granular, subhyaline, sulfo-negative with the contents finely granular and pale yellow"; HYPHAE monomitic, subhymenium comprising most of the thickness of the fruitbody, "of vertically oriented gloeocystidia, hyphae and old basidia, typically stratose", hyphae 2-3 um wide, septa with clamp connections, walls colorless, inamyloid, and thin, subiculum "typically less than 100 um thick, a layer of relatively loosely woven, tortuous hyphae"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of the mountains'
SIMILAR  Gloeocystidiellum leucoxanthum (also known as Megalocystidium leucoxanthum) has smooth spores that measure (12.8)15.2-17.6(21.0) x 4.5-7.0 um, and are elliptic to suballantoid, with a distinct blunt apiculus, (Ginns). Megalocystidium luridum, a European species with which M. montanum has been confused, has very similar spores but they are smooth and somewhat shorter (7-10(12) um) and it occurs on hardwood and rarely on conifers: collections reported as Gloeocystidiellum luridum from North America were found to be almost all M. montanum or Gloeocystidiella leucoxanthum, (Ginns).
SOURCES  Ginns(24)
255
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Melzericium udicola  (Bourdot) Hauerslev^  Friesia 10: 316. 1975;  == Corticium udicola  Bourdot;  Corticium areolatum  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead branches of trees and bushes and on dead herbaceous substrates, 2) thin, white fruitbodies that are smooth without an especially differentiated margin, 3) smooth, elliptic to bean-shaped, amyloid spores often somewhat constricted in the middle, 4) terminal or lateral basidia that are 4-spored, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae narrow and richly branched, with clamp connections, and in the subhymenium ampullately widened.^, RANGE ^Melzericium udicola has been found in BC, WA, ID, ON, (Ginns). It also occurs in Norway, Sweden, and the Canary Islands, (Eriksson), and France (Bourdot).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], thin, submembranous; white; smooth; margin not especially differentiated^, (Eriksson), irregularly effused, pellicular, porous or continuous, white then cream, border similar, scarcely farinose or fibrillose, (Bourdot)
HABITAT  on "dead branches of deciduous trees and bushes, also on dead herbaceous substrates, near the ground in humid habitats with mould-soil"^, (Eriksson), on rotten wood; Alnus tenuifolia (Thinleaf Alder), Populus sp., Salix sp. (willow), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), (Ginns), Idaho specimen as Corticium areolatum on Alnus tenuifolia (Bresadola), in marshland, on twigs, willow, broom, apple, rushes, leaves, (Bourdot)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-10(12) x 3-4.5 um, elliptic, bean-shaped or kidney-shaped, "often somewhat constricted in the middle", smooth, amyloid, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 16-22 x 5-7 um, "varying in shape, generally terminal but some pleurobasidia observed, broadly clavate when terminal, sometimes slightly constricted, when pleurobasidial subcylindrical"; with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 1-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, richly branched, especially in the subhymenial layer, "where they are also more or less ampullately widened; subicular hyphae straighter, more distinct, and more sparsely branched", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living in damp'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Bourdot(1) (as Corticium udicolum, in French), Bresadola(1), Ginns(5)
256
FAMILY  Coniophoraceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Meruliporia incrassata  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Murrill^  Mycologia 34(5): 596. 1942;  Serpula incrassata  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Donk;  == Merulius incrassatus  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Poria incrassata  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Burt;  == Merulius incrassatus  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Merulius spissus  Berk.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Features include 1) resupinate growth on coniferous and hardwood structural timbers, 2) a whitish to buff to ochraceous gray finely pored surface that appears merulioid, this layer distinct from the thin, soft, buff subiculum, and rhizomorphs present, 3) spores that are broadly elliptic, smooth, dextrinoid, and pale brown, the inner spore layer cyanophilic, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ | This species is an important cause of decay in houses and other wooden structures: masses of mycelium in walls and under floors give rise to coarse rhizomorphs that transport water from wet areas to structural wood far removed from the wet area. RANGE ^Meruliporia incrassata has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, NB, ON, AL, CA, CT, DC, FL, GA, IL, KY, LA, MI, MS, NC, NE, NY, OK, PA, SC, TN, TX, and VA, (Ginns(5)). It was not yet reported in Europe (Davidson, R.W.(1) 1953).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate on wood over a wide area, soft when fresh, pores out to margin or almost to margin, easily separable; "pores" 2-3 per mm, appearing merulioid, thick-walled; whitish to buff to ochraceous gray; "tube layer" up to 0.6cm thick, distinct from subiculum; subiculum up to 0.7cm thick, soft-fibrous, buff, not zoned^, (Gilbertson), annual, resupinate, 0.1-1.2cm thick, becoming 10-20cm or more long; spore-bearing surface poroid to merulioid in appearance, 2-4 round "tubes" per millimeter, 0.01-1cm deep, grayish brown to blackish, sometimes at first white; context separable from substrate, "whitish to cream or tan or light wood brown"; subiculum very thin, papery, peeling from the "tubes", whitish gray; rhizomorphs 0.3-1cm wide, "compressed, oval or round, extending from a source of water supply for great distances to the white, papery mycelial fans which cover large areas" and which, in favorable places, terminate in the fruitbody, (Cooke), fruitbody in type 'fragmentary, originally "effused for several inches, resupinate with the margin shortly reflexed, dirty white and slightly silky"; hymenium overgrown by an extraneous fungus, dark brown to blackish, hard, horny, the folds "forming minute, shallow brownish pores"; context now lacking, originally described as "substance thick, fleshy."' (Ginns(17))
HABITAT  annual, causes brown cubical rot of coniferous and hardwood structural timbers, especially in areas where high relative humidity often occurs^, (Gilbertson), rarely on decaying wood in the forest, "more commonly on structural timbers, flooring and other wood in buildings as well as on railroad ties and on lumber in lumber yards", (Cooke), Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), Magnolia sp., Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus palustris (Longleaf Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus borealis var. maxima (Northern Red Oak), Robinia pseudoacacia (Black Locust), Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), Sequioadendron giganteum (Giant Sequoia), Taxodium distichum (Bald Cypress), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), (Ginns(5)), "present occasionally though not abundant in houses but is very destructive when present under favorable moisture conditions", (Davidson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 10-16 x 5-8 um, broadly elliptic, rather variable in size and shape, smooth, dextrinoid, pale brown in KOH, spore print rusty brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-60 x 7-9 um, narrowly clavate; CYSTIDIA and other sterile hymenial elements absent; HYPHAE monomitic, subicular hyphae 2.5-9 um wide, colorless in KOH, thin-walled, often branched, with simple septa and clamp connections, hyphae of trama 3.5-4.5 um wide, colorless, parallel, thin-walled, with simple septa and clamp connections, (Gilbertson), SPORES 9-12 x 5-7 um, ovate, somewhat flattened on one side, smooth, greenish to olive-brown or dark brown, walls 0.7-1 um thick, in Melzer's reagent brown with faint blue halo, in lacto-phenol cotton-blue, blue with no colored walls or contents visible, apiculate; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 5-6 um; hymenium simple, composed exclusively of basidia; CYSTIDIA not seen, CONTEXT formed of generative hyphae 2.5-5 um wide, rather loosely interwoven to parallel-arranged, colorless, when old with yellowish coloring material on surface, more or less parallel with substrate, branching irregularly, with rare clamp connections, (Cooke), SPORES 9.6-13.6(16.8) x 5.6-8.0(8.8) um, oval to broadly oval, adaxially flattened, smooth, dextrinoid (red-brown), pale yellow brown, rather thin-walled, the wall colorless in lactic-blue with a dark blue zone immediately inside; BASIDIA and CYSTIDIA not found; HYPHAE monomitic, tramal hyphae 3.2-4.8 um wide, "parallel, closely packed, not readily separating even in squash mounts", colorless, thin-walled, septate with clamp connections, (Ginns(17))
NAME ORIGIN  means "thickened, made stout"^ (Gilbertson)
SIMILAR  Serpula lacrimans has cyanophilic skeletal hyphae, and Serpula himantioides has acyanophilic skeletal hyphae that are primarily confined to the hyphal strands, whereas Meruliporia incrassata lacks skeletal hyphae, and also has a more poroid spore-bearing surface and prominent thick hyphal strands, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Gilbertson(1), Cooke(5), Ginns(17), Davidson, R.W.(1) (as Poria incrassata), Ginns(5) (as Serpula incrassata), Ginns(23) (as Serpula incrassata)
257
FAMILY  Hyphodermataceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Metulodontia nivea  (P. Karst.) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort., 118. 1968;  == Kneiffia nivea  P. Karst.;  Peniophora nivea  (P. Karst.) Bourdot & Galzin;  Hyphoderma karstenii  Julich
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) fruitbodies that are whitish to pale yellowish ochraceous, and tuberculate (grandinioid), often with branched rhizomorphs, 3) spores that are small, elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) cystidia of two types: a) cylindric, encrusted when projecting with double-pyramidic crystals, yellow when enclosed, and b) smaller sulfo-positive gloeocystidia containing small oil droplets, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Metulodontia nivea has been found in BC, ON, PQ, Northwest Territories, MD, ME, MN, MT, NY, and TN, (Ginns), as well as Finland, Norway, Sweden, central Europe, and the USSR, (Eriksson), and Austria, France, and Germany, (Bourdot).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused, adnate [firmly attached], rather firm, mostly 0.01-0.02cm thick; creamish white to pale yellowish ochraceous; more or less tuberculate (grandinioid), under 50x lens with projecting cystidia; margin "mostly abrupt, often continuing in branched rhizomorphs, which can also be found in the substrate", especially under bark or in much decayed wood^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on decayed wood, mostly of conifers, but also on hardwood^, (Eriksson); Abies (fir), Ostrya (hophornbeam), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak); associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-4.5 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 3.5-5 um, clavate or subcylindric, basally tapering, sometimes with a short stem-like part, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of two types: 1) "encrusted cystidia in varying numbers, in some specimens numerous and easily visible, in others few", size variable, in well-developed specimens 60-100 x 10-15 um, in others not exceeding 50 x 6 um, encrustation especially in projecting cystidia "coarse, consisting of double-pyramidic crystals, in enclosed cystidia more or less dissolved and the whole cystidium changing to yellow", [illustrated as more or less cylindric], 2) small gloeocystidia, relatively few, 30-40 x 3-5 um, fusiform, thin-walled, containing small oil droplets, turning dark blue in sulfovanillin, in rare cases with an apical rounded appendage; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae 2-3 um wide, densely branched and irregularly interwoven, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "in some specimens a layer of parallel hyphae next to the substrate, in old fruitbodies sometimes strata of parallel hyphae in the subicular trama", in mature fruitbodies subicular hyphae colored more or less yellow, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'snow-white'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Julich(1) (transferred to Hyphoderma karstenii), Bourdot(1) (as Peniophora nivea), Ginns(5)
258
FAMILY  Hyphodermataceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mutatoderma mutatum  (Peck) C.E. Gomez^  Boln Soc. argent. Bot. 17(3-4): 346. 1976;  Hyphoderma mutatum  (Peck) Donk  Fungus 27: 15. 1957;  == Corticium mutatum  Peck;  Peniophora mutata  (Peck) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Peniophora allescheri  (Bres.) Sacc. & P. Syd.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) fruitbodies that are membranous, tightly attached, white to cream, and smooth (cracked when old), the margin distinct to fringed, 3) spores that are long, straight or curved, smooth, inamyloid, and homogeneous, 4) 2 types of cystidia: a) numerous mostly enclosed gloeocystidia that are thin-walled and almost cylindric, and b) fewer thick-walled cystidia with an encrusted conic part, somewhat protruding, 5) a monomitic hyphal system with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Mutatoderma mutatum has been found in BC, WA, ID, MB, NB, NS, ON, PE, PQ, AL, CA, CO, FL, GA, IL, IN, KY, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MS, NC, ND, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, SD, VT, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, 0.01-0.03cm thick, adnate [tightly attached], orbicular [circular] to confluent, consistency membranaceous; white to cream, when old darker, in exsiccates [dried specimens] often grayish ochraceous; smooth, when old more or less rimose [cracked] with white cottony subiculum showing in the cracks^, (Eriksson), resupinate, tightly attached, forming membranous patches up to 0.05cm thick and several centimeters to decimeters across, consistency in hymenium wax-like, in subiculum fibrous; white to cream; "smooth to slightly undulating-tuberculate", fissured when dry; margin "distinctly bounded to fringed", (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on hardwood, mostly on bark^, (Eriksson), on dead wood of hardwoods, "on trunks and branches with and without bark and lying on the ground"; summer-fall, (Breitenbach), bark; bark of dead fallen branches; twigs; slash; underside of barkless log; decaying logs; associated with a white rot; on a variety of hardwood species, also reported on Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 12-16 x 3-4 um, allantoid, straight or slightly curved, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, contents homogeneous without oil droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-45 x 7-10 um, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) numerous enclosed GLOEOCYSTIDIA, almost cylindric, thin-walled, "apically rounded, more or less constricted", when mature 60-120 x 7-10 um, (also rounded cystidia in some specimens that may represent an early stage), and 2) mostly few, thick-walled cystidia (metuloids), the encrusted conic part 30-40 x 8-12 um; HYPHAE monomitic 3-4 um wide, with clamp connections at all septa, "closely united in the subhymenial part, loosely interwoven in the subiculum, next to the substrate mostly horizontal and parallel", (Eriksson), SPORES 13-14 x 3.5-4 um, cylindric, slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-35 x 8-9 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) GLOEOCYSTIDIA in hymenium +/- exserted, cylindric with blunt tip, more rarely clavate-capitate, also subglobose and bladder-like, some with granular encrustation at the base, up to 110 x 10 um, sulfo-negative, 2) sparse lamprocystidia somewhat projecting, conic to subulate [awl-shaped], thick-walled, encrusted, encrusted part up to 40 x 10 um; HYPHAE monomitic 2.5-4 um, thin-walled to thick-walled, some encrusted with crystals, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'changed'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as Hyphoderma mutatum), Breitenbach(2)* (as Hyphoderma mutatum), Ginns(5) (as Hyphoderma mutatum)
259
FAMILY  Meruliaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mycoacia aurea  (Fr.) J. Erikss. & Ryvarden^  Cort. N. Europe 4: 877. 1976;  == Hydnum aureum  Fr.;  Hydnum fasciculare  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Odontia stenodon  (Pers.) Bres.;  Mycoacia stenodon  (Pers.) Donk;  Phlebia aurea  (Fr.) Nakasone  Sydowia 49(1): 55. 1997
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) dense spines that are waxy, cream to yellow-ochraceous, often with branched tips, and as a rule serrate with lateral projections, 3) a fruitbody margin that is light colored with shorter spines and ending smoothly, 4) short allantoid spores that are smooth and inamyloid, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, and 6) absent cystidia and a negative KOH reaction.^ RANGE ^Mycoacia aurea has been found in BC, ON, IA, MI, MN, NY, and SC, (Ginns(5)). Distribution includes OR, ON, MT, NC, WI, Costa Rica, Armenia, Austria, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Georgia, Lithuania, Norway, Russia, Slovak Republic, Spain, Sweden, Turkey, Ukraine, Iran, India, Japan, Uzbekistan, (Nakasone(11) who says also reported from Portugal and Korea). It occurs in Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson), and Europe (including Switzerland) and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], often rather large; aculei dense, 0.2-0.3cm long, subcylindric, often branched in 2 or 3 tips, as "a rule also serrate with small lateral projections", ceraceous [waxy], "creamish when young, yellow-ochraceous when mature"; margin light colored, "under the lens finely fibrillose or indeterminately thinning out"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, tightly attached, forming patches several centimeters across, surface consisting of thin wax-like subiculum, from which arise "crowded, slender, pointed spines", 0.1-0.2cm long, cream to pale yellow, ocher when old, "smooth or sometimes with small lateral outgrowths, ends usually with 2-3 small points", usually single but fused here and there at base; "marginal zone with shorter spines and ending smoothly"; KOH does not change the color of the fruitbody, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on the underside of dead branches and trunks of hardwoods, summer to fall^, (Breitenbach), on decayed hardwood (Eriksson), Alnus rubra (Red Alder), Populus sp., P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Ulmus sp., (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-4.5(5.5) x 1.5-2 um, suballantoid, adaxially concave, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-15(20) x 4-5 um, in a dense palisade, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA and cystidioles usually none but in one specimen near the tips of the aculei projecting hyphal end that could be designated as cystidioles; HYPHAE monomitic, the hyphae 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "in the aculeal trama densely parallel, in the thickening subhymenium intertwined into a pseudoparenchymatic context, in the aculeal apices glued together to projecting bundles", when young the hyphal texture clean, but when old more or less loaded with crystals, (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5.5(6) x 1.5-2 um, cylindric-elliptic [but some illustrated as curved], smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 13-15 x 3.5-4.5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-4 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections, sometimes "crystals are stored in old fruiting bodies", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'golden'
SIMILAR  Mycoacia fuscoatra has a pale yellow to ochraceous spore-bearing surface that stains red to purple in KOH on the yellow parts, whereas M. aurea does not stain in KOH, (Ginns(23)). Mycoacia uda has a yellow spore-bearing surface, the yellow parts staining red in KOH, and narrowly elliptic spores 2.0-3.0(3.2) um wide, (Ginns(23)). M. fuscoatra and M. uda have 1) longer spores that are straight, narrowly elliptic, or subcylindric, 2) cystidioles, and 3) spore-bearing surface red in KOH at least when young, (Eriksson). M. uda is hardly distinguishable by appearance but differs in KOH reactions and microscopic characters, (Breitenbach). Mycoacia austro-occidentale Canf., found in Arizona, is pale buff to cream, with spores that measure 4.0-4.5 x 2.0-2.5 um, (Ginns(23)). Mycoacia is separated from other resupinate, odontioid fungi by its wax-like consistency, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Nakasone(11), Buczacki(1)*
260
FAMILY  Meruliaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mycoacia fuscoatra  (Fr.) Donk^  Medd. Nedl. Myc. Ver. 18-20: 152. 1931;  == Hydnum fuscoatra  Fr.;  Odontia fuscoatra  (Fr.) Bres.;  Steccherinum fuscoatrum  (Fr.) Gilb.;  Hydnum carbonarium  Peck;  Phlebia fuscoatra  (Fr.) Nakasone  Sydowia 49(1): 59. 1997
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on the underside of rotten hardwood, 2) dense spines that are waxy, whitish to yellowish or yellow-ochraceous when young, darkening to brown or blackish, the tip fringed under a lens, the fruitbody margin pruinose or indeterminately thinning out, 3) the young yellow parts of the fruitbody turning red with drops of KOH, 4) subcylindric spores that are smooth and inamyloid, 5) cystidia present as needle-like cystidioles projecting beyond the hymenium, 6) cystidia-like, encrusted hyphal ends at the tips of the spines, 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Mycoacia fuscoatra has been found in WA, ID, MB, NS, ON, AZ, CO, GA, IA, MI, MN, NC, NY, OH, WI, (Ginns(5) - some of which might be regarded as Mycoacia nothofagi by Nakasone(11)). It has been found in BC, MB, NS, ON, YT, AK, AL, GA, ID, IL, IA, LA, MD, ME, MT, NM, NY, OH, OR, WI, Czech Republic, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Lithuania, Russia, Slovak Republic, Sweden, and Japan, (Nakasone(11)). It occurs in Europe (including Switzerland) and Asia, (Breitenbach). It has been recorded from all parts of Scandinavia, from Denmark to N. Lappland, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], when young ceraceous [waxy], when mature firmer; when young cream, citrine or ochraceous-yellow, when mature "darkening to brown or black-brown and when old almost black"; aculei [spines] dense, conic to subcylindric, apically tapering, the tip fimbriate to penicillate [brush-like] under lens, the bases often joined in pairs or in small groups; margin when young fimbriate [fringed] under lens, "pruinose or indeterminately thinning out"; subiculum "thin, fertile only in the marginal part"; "young yellow parts of the fruitbody turning red by drops of KOH" ^, (Eriksson), resupinate, tightly attached, forming patches several centimeters to decimeters across, consisting of thin (about 0.01-0.03cm), wax-like subiculum, from which arise cylindric to somewhat subulate [awl-shaped] spines that are pointed in the distal part and 0.1-0.3cm x 0.02-0.04cm, the spines sometimes fused at base, "whitish yellowish when young, brown to blackish when old", wax-like and soft, brittle when dry; according to the literature, young fruitbodies turn dark red with KOH, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on the underside of rotten hardwood, summer-fall^, (Breitenbach), on decayed hardwood, one collection on Pinus (pine); "causes a rather intense white decay", (Eriksson), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Populus, Quercus (oak); slash; burnt log; logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 x 2-2.5 um, subcylindric "with almost parallel sides or with slightly concave adaxial side", smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA narrowly clavate, mostly 15-22 x 4-5 um, 4-spored, with basal clamp connection "from which new basidia develop"; CYSTIDIA present as thin-walled, needle-like cystidioles in the hymenium, 30-40 x 4-5 um, "projecting beyond the basidia", "and cystidia-like, encrusted hyphae in the apical part of the aculei"; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "densely parallel in the aculeal trama, projecting in the aculeal apex, such projecting hyphae as a rule strongly encrusted and may look like differentiated cystidia"; "beside the crystalline encrustation also many non-crystalline grains in the texture which dissolve and in young fruitbodies turn red in KOH, in Cotton-blue floating together to yellow, oil-like drops or bodies with a foamy interior structure, often joined to irregular bodies, floating in the medium or sticking to hyphae or hymenial elements", (Eriksson), SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 2-2.5 um, cylindric-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA up to 45 x 4 um, fusiform; HYPHAE monomitic, the hyphae 2-4 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections; HYPHAL ENDS at the tips of the spines strongly encrusted, up to 10 um across, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fuscous-black'
SIMILAR  Mycoacia nothofagi differs microscopically (Nakasone(11)). Mycoacia uda has a distinctly yellow spore-bearing surface, the yellow parts staining red in KOH, and narrowly elliptic spores 2-3(3.2) um wide, whereas M. fuscoatra has a pale yellow to ochraceous spore-bearing surface that stains red to purple in KOH on the yellow parts, and its spores are subcylindric, only 1.7-2.5 um wide, (Ginns(23)). In M. uda 1) mature fruitbodies are ochraceous rather than dark brown to almost black as in M. fuscoatra, 2) encrusted hyphae if present are few and inconspicuous (M. fuscoatra has apical hyphae strongly encrusted, conspicuous, and cystidia-like in mature specimens), 3) cystidioles are short, and not acicular like those of M. fuscoatra, and 4) the yellow, oily bodies in cotton-blue are absent, (Eriksson). Mycoacia aurea does not stain in KOH, (Ginns(23)). M. aurea 1) does not stain red in KOH when young like M. fuscoatra, 2) has spores that are shorter and suballantoid, and 3) normally lacks cystidioles, (Eriksson). Mycoacia austro-occidentale Canf., found in Arizona, is pale buff to cream, with spores 4.0-4.5 x 2.0-2.5 um, (Ginns(23)). Mycoacia is separated from other resupinate, odontioid fungi by its wax-like consistency, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Nakasone(11) (as Phlebia fuscoatra), Buczacki(1)*
261
FAMILY  Meruliaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mycoacia nothofagi  (G. Cunn.) Ryvarden^  in Hjortstam, Tellera, Ryvarden & Calogne Nova Hedwigia 34(3 & 4): 534. 1981;  Phlebia nothofagi  (G. Cunn.) Nakasone  Sydowia 49(1): 67. 1997;  Odontia nothofagi  G. Cunn.  Trans. Roy. Soc. N.Z. 86(1-2): 88. 1959
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Mycoacia nothofagi is distinguished particularly by soft, brittle teeth and abundant, thick-walled, encrusted cystidia (Nakasone(11) who says it is variable in form and color but shows little variation in microscopic characters). Other features include flat growth on hardwoods, a somewhat waxy surface with soft white membranous flesh, the surface color shades of brown, orange-brown, orange, gray-brown, or yellowish brown, often darker between and at base of teeth, the teeth 0.1-0.6cm long and glaucous to velvety, the margin of the fruitbody lighter in color.^ |The description is derived from Nakasone(11). RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, ID, CA, DC, FL, LA, MT, NC, NY, TN, WI, Azerbaijan, Macedonia, Czech Republic, France, Georgia, Germany, Russia, Slovak Republic, Spain, Switzerland, United Kingdom, Australia, and New Zealand, (Nakasone(11) who says also reported from Portugal, Romania, and Thailand).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate (flat on wood with spore-bearing surface facing outwards), "beginning as small coalescing, circular patches that become widely effused" [spread out], up to 15cm x 7cm, moderately thick, up to 0.1cm thick, surface layer subceraceous [somewhat waxy], up to 0.01cm thick, with infrequent cracks exposing the white, soft, felty, fibrous-membranous context layer that is up to 0.053cm thick, spore-bearing surface spinose, 1-2 teeth per millimeter, "occasionally smooth with scattered teeth", the teeth in cross-section round to flattened, "single, fused at base or laterally throughout length, gradually tapering toward apex", 0.1-0.6(1)cm long and 0.1cm wide at base, "soft, brittle, with an overall glaucous and velutinous appearance from protruding cystidia, apices acuminate, entire or blunt and tufted"; color of surface "variable, typically darker between and at base of teeth", brown, then becoming brownish orange, light brown, grayish brown, light orange, grayish orange or yellowish brown toward apex, sometimes brownish orange or brown throughout; margins "typically distinct, ropy, abrupt, closely appressed, adherent", 0.2-0.4cm wide, sterile, lighter in color than spore-bearing surface, pale yellow, light yellow, pale orange, light orange to grayish orange, "odontoid to warted or with ridges, edges deeply lacinate and incised or sometimes indistinct, thinning out"; "light colored specimens turning pinkish red to dark brown in KOH"
HABITAT  annual, on bark and wood of hardwoods
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4.5)5-5.5(6) x 2.2-2.5(2.9) um, elliptic, "adaxial side straight or slightly concave", smooth, inamyloid, the walls colorless, thin, distinct^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-32(36) x 4-6 um, clavate, tapering to 2-2.5 um wide at base, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of two types 1) tramal - fusiform, rarely cylindric, with a long stalk, up to 180 um long, 3.5-8(14) um wide including crystals, tapering to 3.5-4 um wide at base, with basal clamp connection, "often with secondary septa, apex acute to rounded", walls colorless to yellowish brown, "thin throughout but sometimes slightly thickened at distal end, smooth or lightly to moderately encrusted at apex" with colorless, "loosely adherent, coarse, crystalline materials", "originating in subiculum or tooth trama, often curving into subhymenium and hymenium", becoming embedded or protruding up to 55 um beyond the hymenium, "also extending into tooth apex, numerous in tooth trama", 2) hymenial - cystidia fusiform, 35-90 x 5-7 um, tapering to 1.5-2.5 um wide at base, with basal clamp connection, walls colorless, slightly thickened, up to 0.1cm thick, but often thinning at base, "basal part smooth, distal part lightly to moderately encrusted" with closely adherent, colorless crystalline materials, "embedded or protruding" up to 45 um, "arising from subhymenium, numerous in subhymenium and hymenium"; HYMENIUM "a dense palisade of basidia and cystidia, not agglutinated but difficult to separate individual elements, occasionally interspersed with clumps of reddish brown, resinous materials"; SUBHYMENIUM thickening, 25-80 um thick between teeth and near apices of teeth, up to 300 um thick at base of teeth, "hyphae oriented perpendicular to substrate or to long axis of teeth, dense, compact, agglutinated, often indistinct and collapsed", hyphae 2-3.5 um wide, nodose-septate, "frequently branched, conglutinate, short-celled", walls colorless, thin, smooth; TOOTH HYPHAE - teeth with "central core of vertically arranged, parallel, subicular hyphae that may be smooth or encrusted, and smooth or encrusted cystidia enclosed by subhymenium and hymenium", sometimes with elongate clusters of acerose or flattened, colorless crystals and resinous materials, "often with cystidia protruding at apex and through hymenium"; SUBICULUM of smooth areas between teeth up to 900 um thick, "sometimes stratose, with a very thin, yellow-orange basal layer", up to 50 um thick, "of agglutinated hyphae arranged parallel to substrate and a thicker layer of non-agglutinated hyphae, first arranged more or less parallel to substrate in a loose, open textura intricate that develops into a dense vertical palisade near subhymenial interface", hyphae 2.5-5.5 um wide, rarely orange, nodose-septate, "sparingly to moderately branched, often branching from clamps and forming H-connections", walls colorless, "thin to slightly thickened, smooth"; HYPHAE monomitic
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Nothofagus' because type was found on Nothofagus menziesii (Silver Beech) in New Zealand
SIMILAR  Mycoacia fuscoatra differs microscopically (Nakasone(11)).
SOURCES  Nakasone(11) (as Phlebia nothofagi)
262
FAMILY  Meruliaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mycoacia uda  (Fr.) Donk^  Medd. Nedl. Myc. Ver. 18-20: 151. 1931;  == Hydnum udum  Fr.;  Odontia uda  (Fr.) Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on the underside of dead branches and trunks of hardwoods, 2) dense spines that are waxy, yellow to ochraceous, the tip usually smooth, the margin of the fruitbody with smaller spines and ending smoothly, sometimes pruinose or rather fringed, 3) the young yellow parts of the fruitbody turning deep red with drops of KOH, 4) narrowly elliptic spores that are smooth and inamyloid, 5) cystidia present as small subfusiform cystidioles somewhat projecting beyond the hymenium, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Mycoacia uda has been found in BC, WA, OR, MB, ON, IA, IN, LA, MI, MT, NY, TN, and WI, (Ginns(5)). Distribution includes BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, ON, QC, IA, IL, MT, NY, SD, TN, VA, WI, Armenia, Austria, Azerbaijan, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, France, Georgia, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Russia, Spain, Sweden, and Turkmenistan, (Nakasone(11) who says also reported from Portugal, Turkey, Iran, Ethiopia, and Morocco). Distribution includes Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], effused [spread out], "mostly of small to moderate size", citrine to sordid yellow, when old ochraceous; aculei [spines] conic to subcylindric, ceraceous [waxy], mostly 0.1-0.2cm long, seldom more, "as a rule simple, but sometimes apically divided or basally joined"; margin thinning out, pruinose or finely fimbriate [fringed] under lens; "subiculum thin, fertile only in the marginal part"; "young yellow parts of the fruitbody turn deep red in a drop of KOH"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, tightly attached, forming expanses several centimeters across, more rarely several decimeters; thin, wax-like subiculum from which arise densely crowded, slender, pointed spines that are 0.1-0.2cm long, usually single but here and there fused at the base, sulfur-yellow, wax-yellow, or ocher-yellow, tips smooth or more rarely somewhat fringed; margin "with shorter spines and ending smoothly, sometimes rather fringed or farinose"; KOH colors the fruitbody purple-red, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on "underside of dead branches and trunks of hardwoods, with and without bark", throughout the year but matures only in the summer half^, (Breitenbach), on much decayed hardwood, (Eriksson), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Arbutus (madrone), Cytisus scoparius (broom), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow); associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 x 2-2.5 um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, often with 1-2 small oil droplets^; CYSTIDIA present as small cystidioles, about 25 um long, subfusiform, "somewhat projecting and apically provided with a cap of non-crystalline matter, easily dissolved in mounting media"; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae 2-3 um wide, with clamp connections, "with thin or slightly thickened walls", packed in parallel fashion in the aculeal trama, "subhymenial hyphae densely intertwined"; "in mature specimens aculeal trama filled with rod-like crystals, in old specimens often united to larger lumps", "in such specimens apical hyphae end more or less encrusted", (Eriksson), SPORES 5-6 x 2-3 um, oval, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with 1-2 droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate; CYSTIDIA inconspicuous, 20-25 x 4 um, fusiform; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, some with clamp connections; CRYSTALS in the trama of the aculei, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'damp'
SIMILAR  Mycoacia fuscoatra has a pale yellow to ochraceous spore-bearing surface that stains red to purple in KOH on the yellow parts, and its spores are subcylindric and only 1.7-2.5 um wide, whereas M. uda has a distinctly yellow spore-bearing surface, the yellow parts staining red in KOH, and spores are narrowly elliptic and 2-3(3.2) um wide, (Ginns(23)). In M. fuscoatra 1) mature fruitbodies are dark brown to almost black rather than ochraceous as in M. uda, 2) apical hyphae are strongly encrusted, conspicuous, and cystidia-like in mature specimens (in M. uda encrusted hyphae if present are few and inconspicuous), 3) cystidioles are acicular, whereas those of M. uda are short, and not acicular, and 4) yellow, oily bodies are present in cotton-blue, (Eriksson). Mycoacia aurea does not stain in KOH, (Ginns(23)). M. aurea 1) does not stain red in KOH when young like M. uda, 2) has spores that are shorter and suballantoid, and 3) normally lacks cystidioles, (Eriksson). Mycoacia austro-occidentale Canf., found in Arizona, is pale buff to cream, with spores measuring 4.0-4.5 x 2.0-2.5 um, (Ginns(23)). Mycoacia is separated from other resupinate, odontioid fungi by its wax-like consistency, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Nakasone(11) (as Phlebia uda), Buczacki(1)*
263
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Naohideales, Class Cystobasidiomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Naohidea sebacea  (Berk. & Broome) Oberw.^  Rep. Tottori Mycol. Inst. 28: 114. 1990;  Platygloea sebacea  (Berk. & Broome) McNabb  Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc. 48: 188. 1965;  == Dacrymyces sebaceus  Berk. & Broome;  Platygloea miedzyrzecensis  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Naohidea sebacea is characterized by extremely long, narrow basidia. Features include 1) resupinate growth on pyrenomycetes, 2) small whitish patches starting as soft-gelatinous to mucous fruitbodies that are cushion-shaped, spherical, or oblong, anastomosing to form elongated areas up to 0.9cm long, 3) obovate to oblong spores, 4) 4-cellular basidia, with a very long thin-walled basidial stem cut off from the lower part of the spore-producing part, and 5) hyphae with numerous clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Naohidea sebacea has been found in BC, CA, and GA, (Ginns), Poland (Bandoni(10)), and France, (McNabb).
FRUITING BODY  soft-gelatinous, almost mucoid, pulvinate [cushion-shaped], rounded or oblong, 0.3-0.6cm across; pale whitish to opalescent when moist, drying to an inconspicuous, shining, gray film^, (Bandoni(10), adapted from Bourdot & Galzin, 1928), pulvinate, erumpent, anastomosing, very soft, gelatinous, individual pustules 0.05-0.25cm across (Bresadola 0.2-0.4cm), not exceeding 0.6cm in thickness, anastomosing to form patches up to 0.8cm long; white; surface smooth, (Olive), soft-gelatinous, pulvinate [cushion-shaped], erumpent, individual pustules up to 0.3cm across, anastomosing to form elongated areas up to 0.9cm long, colorless when fresh, drying to an inconspicuous, opalescent gray film, (McNabb)
HABITAT  on stroma of pyrenomycetes, on decaying wood^, (Raitviir), mycoparasitic on sphaeriaceous fungi on dead wood, growing from the perithecial stromata; on or in fructifications of other fungi; on Botryodiplodia sp., Botryosphaeria sp., B. quercuum, Phialophorophoma-like fungus, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-16 x 5-8 um, "obovate or oblong, sometimes subfusiform, attenuate at the base and often laterally depressed", germinating by repetition^; BASIDIA 120-300 x 4-6 um, "flexuous, finally almost circinate, 3-septate", "epibasidia thick, becoming filiform", HYPHAE 1-3 um wide, with numerous clamp connections, (Bandoni(10), adapted from Bourdot & Galzin, 1928), SPORES 9-12.3 x 5.5-8 um, oboval, often flattened on one side, smooth, colorless, apiculate, germination by repetition or by colorless, nearly round to round conidia, 2.5-6.5 x 2.5-5.5 um (similar conidia occasionally produced by the basidia); BASIDIA terminal, composed of a long stem cell "and a straight or flexuous, 4-celled metabasidium", overall length from clamp connection at base of stem cell 90-275 um, 5-7.5 um wide, sterigmata variable in shape and length, up to 25 um long, a "distinctive feature of P. sebacea is the presence of a thin-walled basidial stipe which is cut off from the lower portion of the probasidium"; INTERNAL HYPHAE thin-walled, with clamp connections, (McNabb, Latin name italicized), SPORES mostly obovate, apiculate, 9.1-12 x 5.9-8.1 um (Bresadola 10-13 x 7-9 um); BASIDIA "borne at the tips of long branched hyphae with clamp connections, composed of a long stalk and a four-celled spore-producing part", measuring in all 97-268 x 5.1-7.2 um, (Olive), in BC collection, spores were 8-10 x 5-7 um; basidia were up to 190 um long and were (3.5)4-4.5 um long, (Bandoni(9))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fatty', 'greasy'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Bandoni(10) (as Platygloea miedzyrzecensis), Bandoni(9) (as Platygloea sebacina), McNabb(9) (as Platygloea sebacina), Olive(3) (as Platygloea miedzyrzecensis), Ginns(5) (as Platygloea sebacina), Raitviir(1) (as Platygloea miedzyrzecensis)
264
FAMILY  Nectriaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Nectria cinnabarina  (Tode) Fr.  group^  Summa veg. Scand., Section Post. (Stockholm): 388. 1849;  Nectria purpurea  (L.) G.W. Wilson & Seaver;  Nectria fuscopurpurea  Wakef.;  Nectria ochracea  (Grev. ex Fr.) Sacc. & Roum.;  Sphaeria cinnabarina  Pers.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  coral spot
NOTES  Features of Nectria cinnabarina group include fruiting with many dense clusters (each with a more or less circular outline) of tiny cushion-shaped red to red-brown fruitbodies with an apical papilla, growth on hardwood, and microscopic characters. The pink to light red to light orange cushions of the conidial state (known as 'coral spot') are usually associated. These anamorphs are Tubercularia vulgaris or close spp.^ |Hirooka(1) examined and sequenced collections labeled as this species and found at least four species: 1) Nectria dematiosa (up to 2-septate ascospores, stemless anamorphs, known from British Columbia, Poland, Japan, and New Zealand), 2) Nectria cinnabarina (up to 2-septate ascospores, anamorph fruitbodies predominantly (70%) long-stemmed, known from eastern North America and Europe), 3) Nectria nigrescens (up to 3-septate ascospores - 4% are 3-septate. 5% 2-septate, anamorph fruitbodies that are 65% short-stemmed and 35% long-stemmed, known from eastern North America and Europe), and 4) Nectria asiatica (up to 1-septate ascospores, anamorph fruitbodies short-stemmed, known from China and Japan). |The length of the stems is not specified but the illustration of N. cinnabarina appears to show a stem almost as high at the rest of the fruitbody and almost as wide across as the fruitbody is across. Note that the stems of the stemmed anamorph antibodies may be obscured by masses of conidia so that they appear to be stemless. |Note also that there are subclades within N. dematiosa that could represent separate species, but evidence is insufficient. RANGE ^There are collections labeled as Nectria cinnabarina at the University of British Columbia from BC, WA, and OR.
FRUITING BODY  individual fruitbodies 0.02-0.04cm, spherical to oval, with a papilla, "resting in dense groups on a cushionlike, somewhat lighter colored stroma which emerges from the bark"; "bright vermilion to brown-red"; surface roughened; "Even more conspicuous is the light orange to pink cushionlike conidial stage Tubercularia vulgaris Tode ex Fr., which in the course of development forms the stroma for the perithecia"^, (Breitenbach, Latin name italicized), 0.04cm across, "densely crowded on a small erumpent, cushion-like, stromatic base"; "cinnabar-red", darkening when old; "minutely warted, each with a small apical, papillate ostiole"; conidial state is pink to light red cushions [also referred to as bright coral-red], (Dennis), perithecia distinctly warty-rugulose, (Hansen, L.)
HABITAT  in groups, often covering whole dead branches of hardwood trees and shrubs^, (Breitenbach), on dead sticks of all kinds, including Ribes, throughout the year, (Dennis), asexual spores appear in the spring (Bacon), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-19 x 5.5-6 um, cylindric-elliptic, smooth, colorless, slightly constricted with a septum in center^; asci 8-spored, 75-90 x 9.5 um, irregularly biseriate; paraphyses not observed, (Breitenbach), spores 12-25 x 4-9 um, elliptic-cylindric, with median transverse septum, colorless; paraphyses branched, colorless, (Dennis), spores 12-20 x 4.5-6.5 um, (Hansen, L.)
NAME ORIGIN  presumably referring to the cinnabar color
SIMILAR  Other Nectria species undoubtedly occur in the Pacific Northwest but they have not been comprehensively studied. Nectria pithoides was first described in BC. The University of British Columbia has BC collections labeled as Nectria coccinea, N. sanguinea, N. sulphurea, N. galligena, N. episphaeria, N. inventa, and N. pithoides. The University of Washington has WA collections of N. coccinea and N. episphaeria. O. Ceska has reported Nectria fuckeliana var. macrospora from B.C. Some of these have been recombined into Neonectria.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Bessette(2)*, Barron(1)*, McNeil(1)*, Bacon(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Hirooka(1)*
265
FAMILY  Nectriaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Nectria pithoides  Ellis & Everh.^  Proc. Acad. nat. Sci. Philad. 43: 247. 1891
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Nectria pithoides is distinguished "by the bright red perithecia which are decidedly barrel-shaped when dry". Other features include the yellowish stroma on bark of dead alders, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^The type description is from BC.
FRUITING BODY  stroma erumpent, yellowish; perithecia seated on the stroma in dense clusters 0.15-0.25cm in diameter, "individual perithecia bright red, collapsing so as to become truncate, resembling the head of a barrel" with the ostiolum appearing as a light translucent dot in the center, 0.01-0.025cm in diameter
HABITAT  on bark of dead alders
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-10 x 3-4 um, elliptic, colorless, 1-septate, with an oil droplet in each cell^; asci 8-spored, 70-80 x 5 um, cylindric
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Other Nectria species undoubtedly occur in the Pacific Northwest but they have not been comprehensively studied. In addition to Nectria cinnabarina, note the following collections: the University of British Columbia has BC collections labeled as Nectria coccinea, N. sanguinea, N. sulphurea, N. galligena, N. episphaeria, N. inventa, and N. pithoides. The University of Washington has WA collections of N. coccinea and N. episphaeria. O. Ceska has reported Nectria fuckeliana var. macrospora from B.C. Some of these have been recombined into Neonectria.
SOURCES  Seaver(5)
266
FAMILY  Bionectriaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Nectriopsis violacea  (J.C. Schmidt ex Fr.) Maire^  Annls mycol. 9(4): 323. 1911;  Byssonectria violacea  (J.C. Schmidt ex Fr.) Seaver;  Nectria violacea  (J.C. Schmidt ex Fr.) Fr.;  Peckiella violacea  (J.C. Schmidt ex Fr.) Sacc.;  Hyphonectria violacea  (J.C. Schmidt ex Fr.) Petch;  Sphaeria violacea  J.C. Schmidt ex Fr.;  Acremonium fungicola  (Sacc.) Samuels
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Nectriopsis violacea forms a layer on Fuligo septica of purplish subiculum and purple pear-shaped bodies each with an opening at the top.^ | The anamorph is Acremonium fungicola (Sacc.) Samuels. RANGE ^The accompanying photograph by John Davis from WA on Fuligo septica. There is a collection at University of British Columbia from BC on Fuligo, and it is also reported from Haida Gwaii in BC. N. violacea is presumably found elsewhere in North America (Seaver(6) was examining a collection from Maine which referred here except that although the spores were sometimes pseudoseptate they were not septate). It occurs in Europe including Denmark, Finland Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen, L.(1)), and United Kingdom (Dennis(1)).
FRUITING BODY  perithecia and subiculum forming a layer in shades of violet^, (Hansen, L.), stroma consisting of "a thin, white mycelial growth overspreading the substratum"; "perithecia thickly scattered, globose or subglobose, smooth or only minutely roughened, vertically collapsing, violaceous", (Seaver)
HABITAT  on Fuligo septica^ (Seaver, Hansen, L.)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 2.5-3 um, ornamentation spinulose, 2-celled, hardly constricted at septum^, (Hansen, L.), spores 6-7 x 2-3 um, elliptic, granular within, sometimes pseudoseptate but not septate, 1-seriate or with the ends slightly overlapping; asci 8-spored, cylindric, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to violet color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1), Seaver(6) (as Byssonectria violacea), MacKinnon(1)*
267
FAMILY  Xylariaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Nemania aenea  (Nitschke) Pouzar  var. macrospora  (J.H. Mill.) Y.-M. Ju & J.D. Rogers^  Nova Hedwigia 74: 85. 2002;  == Nemania serpens  (Pers.) Gray  var. macrospora  (J.H. Mill.) Pouzar;  == Hypoxylon serpens  (Pers.) J. Kickx  var. macrosporum  J.H. Mill.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Nemania aenea var. macrospora is a member of the Hypoxylon serpens complex for which Petrini(1) discusses 9 different taxa. See Nemania serpens.^ RANGE ^Collections of Nemania serpens var. macrospora were from WA, ID, CA, Costa Rica, and Czechoslovakia, (Petrini), and ID (Ju).
FRUITING BODY  stroma 0.2-6cm x 0.2-1.5cm, and 0.1-0.15cm thick; dark brown to black; contours of perithecia on the stroma surface not present or only at margin, ostioles barely protruding or finely papillate^, (Petrini)
HABITAT  
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (13)15-18.5(22) x 5-7.5 um, light brown, apices narrowly or broadly rounded, germ slit short, obscure to conspicuous^; ASCUS stem (50)70-121(157) um, ratio of spore-bearing part to stem (0.6)0.8-1.6(2.4), ascus tip blueing in iodine; PERITHECIUM up to 1000 um wide, (Petrini), SPORES 15-19(21) x (5.5)6-7 um, light brown to brown, elliptic-inequilateral, with narrowly to broadly rounded ends occasionally pinched; ASCUS with stem 65-120 um long; PERITHECIUM 500-900 um in diameter, spherical, (Ju)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Nemania serpens var. serpens has spores measuring 10-14(16) x 4-6 um, whereas Nemania aenea var. macrospora has spores 15-19(21) x (5.5)6-7 um, (Ju). Nemania serpens var. serpens has smaller spores and smaller, shorter-stemmed asci, (Petrini). Nemania serpens var. colliculosa has spores measuring (9)10-14 x 4.5-6 um whereas N. aenea var. macrospora has spore 15-19(21) x (5.5)6-7 um, (Ju). Nemania serpens var. colliculosa (as Hypoxylon atropurpureum var. brevistipitatum) has smaller spores and smaller, shorter-stemmed asci, (Petrini).
SOURCES  Miller, J.H.(1) (as Hypoxylon serpens var. macrospora), Ju(4), Petrini(1) (as Hypoxylon serpens var. macrosporum)
268
FAMILY  Xylariaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Nemania serpens  (Pers.) Gray^  Nat. Arr. Brit. Pl.: 516. 1821.;  == Sphaeria serpens  Pers.;  == Hypoxylon serpens  (Pers.) J. Kickx f.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features of the Nemania serpens complex include 1) growth on many kinds of wood, in the form of rounded to oval, coal-like crusts that can coalesce to cover large surfaces, the dark brown to black surface carpeted with dots representing the openings of the perithecia, 2) an absence of pigments released in 10% KOH (presence of these pigments being a general feature of Hypoxylon species), 3) spores that are usually within the range 10-18 x 4-7.5 um, and brown, with an inconspicuous or conspicuous germ slit, 4) the ascus tip blueing in iodine in some species.^ |Miller, J.H.(1) used the name Hypoxylon serpens in this wide sense that has been considered untenable by more recent investigators: Rogers, J.D.(3) and Ju(4) favor a narrower concept and refer for descriptions to Petrini(1) and to Granmo, A., T. Laessoe & T. Schumacher, The genus Nemania s.l. (Xylariaceae) in Norden. - Sommerfeltia 27: 1-96. 1999. RANGE ^Collections were examined of Nemania serpens var. serpens from BC, WA, OR, ID, AZ, ME, NC, PA, SC, Chile, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France, Germany, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom, (Petrini). It also occurs in Norway (Ju). Note however that while Ju(4) states that the type of H. atropurpureum var. brevistipitatum in Petrini(1) is Nemania serpens var. colliculosa, Petrini(1) synonymizes Sphaeria colliculosa Schwein. with Hypoxylon serpens, so that it is possible some of the records above for Nemania serpens var. serpens are actually Nemania serpens var. colliculosa. Another variety of Nemania serpens is var. hydnicola (Schwein.) Y.-M. Ju & J.D. Rogers which 'differs from the typical variety in that its ascus rings are amyloid, the ascospores have abruptly narrowed or "pinched" ends, and it is frequently fungicolous on Fomitopsis pinicola': this variety has been found in BC as well as Norway, Sweden, Finland, and France, (Callan, Latin name italicized).
FRUITING BODY  stroma 0.5-7cm x 0.2-3cm, and 0.08-0.1cm thick; dark brown to black, "sometimes covered with greenish mass of spores"; contours of perithecia on the stroma surface not present or only at margin, ostioles finely, seldom coarsely papillate, occasionally in annulate depressions, (Petrini), stromata superficial, orbicular [circular] to elliptic, small or widely effused [spread out], 0.2-4cm x 0.2-2cm and 0.1-0.15cm thick, "varying with irregularities of bark or wood", carbonous; at first white and when old varying to pruinose-gray, "later bronze and finally dark purple or black"; "smooth or very uneven with projecting perithecia and conic papillate ostiola"^, (Miller), stroma rounded-oval, dark coal-like, 1-2cm long, (can fuse with others to form larger surfaces), black perithecia "irregularly embedded in a single layer" in stroma; stromal surface "blackish, tuberculate and uneven, and carpeted with dots (the projecting perithecial ostioles)"; when young the stroma is light-colored within, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on "many kinds of wood, usually on old logs or stumps"^, (Miller), single or in groups, "often covering entire branches", on bare rotten wood of various hardwoods; all year, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (10)11.5-14(18) x 4-6.5 um, light brown, apices broadly rounded, germ slit short, obscure^; ASCUS stem (32)60-103(138) um, ratio of spore-bearing part to stem 0.6-1.5(1.8), ascus tip mostly not blueing in iodine, but sometimes blueing; PERITHECIUM up to 900 um wide, (Petrini), SPORES 10-14(16) x 4-6 um, brown, with broadly or less frequently narrowly rounded ends; ASCUS with apical ring not blueing in Melzer's reagent; PERITHECIUM 400-800 um, (Ju), SPORES 10-15 x 5-7 um, "oblong to inequilaterally elliptic with obtuse ends, light to dark brown"; ASCUS 75-100 x 6-9 um in spore-bearing part, cylindric, long-stemmed, with stem 40-60 um long; PARAPHYSES filiform, copious; PARATHECIA 500-1000 um in diameter, spherical to compressed-ovate, (Miller), SPORES 12-13(15) x 5.5-7 um, oval, sometimes flattened on one side, smooth, brown, with one droplet, without germination cleft, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Nemania serpens var. colliculosa is differentiated by Ju(4) from var. serpens by 1) its smaller perithecia (0.02-0.05cm diameter in key lead rather than 0.04-0.08cm diameter for var. serpens), 2) ascal apical rings blueing in Melzer's reagent (not blueing in var. serpens), and 3) spores that are light brown to brown, (9)10-14 x 4.5-6 um (in var. serpens brown, 10-14(16) x 4-6 um), (Ju). N. serpens var. colliculosa is differentiated by Petrini(1) from var. serpens by its spores narrowly rounded at each end, (spores of var. serpens broadly rounded), (Petrini). |Nemania aenea var. macrospora differs from Nemania serpens var. serpens by having spores 15-19(21) x (5.5)6-7 um, versus 10-14(16) x 4-6 um for N. serpens var. serpens, (Ju). N. aenea var. macrospora differs from N. serpens var. serpens in having larger spores (13)15-18.5(22) x 5-7.5 um, (Petrini). |Nemania serpens var. hydnicola differs from var. serpens and var. colliculosa "primarily in having ascospores with narrow to acute ends and in being frequently fungicolous", (Ju).
SOURCES  Ju(4), Petrini(1) (as Hypoxylon serpens var. serpens), Miller, J.H.(1) (as Hypoxylon serpens), Breitenbach(1)* (as Hypoxylon serpens), Redhead(5) (as Hypoxylon serpens), Rogers, J.D.(3), Callan(2)
269
FAMILY  Xylariaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Nemania serpens  (Pers.) Gray  var. colliculosa  (Schwein.) Y.-M. Ju & J.D. Rogers^  Nova Hedwigia 74: 106. 2002;  == Sphaeria colliculosa  Schwein.;  == Hypoxylon colliculosum  (Schwein.) M.A. Curtis;  == Nemania colliculosa  (Schwein.) Granmo;  = Hypoxylon atropurpureum  (Fr.) Fr.  var. brevistipitatum  L.E. Petrini & J.D. Rogers;  = Nemania prava  Granmo, Laessoe & T. Schumach.;  = Hypoxylon epirhodium  Berk. & Ravenel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Nemania serpens (Pers.) Gray var. colliculosa is a member of the Hypoxylon serpens complex for which Petrini(1) discusses 9 different taxa (see Nemania serpens).^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from ID, NC, PA, SC, Norway, and Switzerland, (Ju), and France and Switzerland (Petrini).
FRUITING BODY  stroma 0.5-2.5cm x 0.1-1cm, and 0.08cm thick; dark brown to black; contours of perithecia on the stroma surface not present, ostioles barely protruding or finely papillate^, (Petrini)
HABITAT  
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (10)11-12.5(14) x 4.5-6 um, brown to light brown, apices narrowly rounded, germ slit short, conspicuous^; ASCUS stem (34)47-73(90) um, ratio of spore-bearing part to stem (0.8)1-1.6(2.1), ascus tip blueing in iodine; PERITHECIUM up to 700 um wide, (Petrini), SPORES (9)10-14 x 4.5-6 um, light brown to brown, with broadly or less frequently narrowly rounded ends, (Ju)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Nemania serpens var. serpens is differentiated by Ju(4) from var. colliculosa by 1) its larger perithecia (0.04-0.08cm diameter, rather than 0.02-0.05cm diameter in key lead for var. colliculosa), 2) ascal apical rings not blueing in Melzer's reagent (blueing in var. colliculosa), and 3) brown spores measuring 10-14(16) x 4-6 um, (in var. colliculosa light brown to brown, (9)10-14 x 4.5-6 um), (Ju). |Nemania aenea var. macrospora has spores measuring 15-19(21) x (5.5)6-7 um, whereas N. serpens var. colliculosa has spores measuring (9)10-14 x 4.5-6 um, (Ju).
