N. aenea var. macrospora (as Hypoxylon serpens var. macrosporum) has larger spores and larger, longer-stemmed asci, (Petrini). |Nemania serpens var. hydnicola differs from var. colliculosa in having ascospores with narrow to acute ends and in being frequently fungicolous (Ju).
SOURCES  Ju(4), Petrini(1) (as Hypoxylon atropurpureum var. brevistipitatum)
270
FAMILY  Xylariaceae, Order Xylariales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Nemania serpens  (Pers.) Gray  var. hydnicola  (Schwein.) Y.-M. Ju & J.D. Rogers^  Nova Hedwigia 74: 109 (2002);  Sphaeria hydnicola  Schwein.;  Hypoxylon hydnicolum  (Schwein.) Sacc.;  Hypoxylon reticulatum  P. Karst.;  Nemania reticulatum  (P. Karst.) Granmo;  Hypoxylon discoideum  Ellis and Everh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Nemania serpens var. hydnicola differs from var. serpens and var. colliculosa "primarily in having ascospores with narrow to acute ends and in being frequently fungicolous", (Ju).^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC (Callan), and NC, NJ, and Finland, (Ju).
FRUITING BODY  
HABITAT  on Fomitopsis pinicola, on dead stems of climbing Rhus toxicodendron, on Hydnum, (Ju), on pore layer of a rotting Fomitopsis pinicola conk placed hymenium-side down on mossy outcrop one year earlier, (Callan)
MICROSCOPIC  ascospores 10-12 x 4-5 um, elliptic-inequilateral, often with pinched ends, brown, germ slit easily visible and extending about half the length of the spore on the least convex side^, (Callan)
NAME ORIGIN  'hydnicola' means 'living on Hydnum'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Nemania serpens var. colliculosa.
SOURCES  Ju(4), Callan(2)
271
FAMILY  Boliniaceae, Order Boliniales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Neohypodiscus cerebrinus  (Fee) J.D. Rogers, Y.-M. Ju, & Laessoe^  Mycologia 86: 686. 1994;  Hypoxylon cerebrinum  (Fee) Cooke  Grevillea 11: 128. 1883
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on dead wood, 2) blackish fruitbodies, sometimes with brown or gray tones, that are hemispheric, nearly spherical or irregular, several often joined, at first smooth but becoming rough from protruding warts, the ostioles in valleys between, the exterior carbonous and the interior woody, 3) spores that are elliptic to almost rectangular, 1-celled or unequally 2-celled, light brown to dark, many with thickening or appendage on each end, occasionally with a germ pore, and diagonally uniseriate in an ascus that has a minute apical ring not staining in Melzer's reagent, 4) paraphyses that are numerous and filiform, much longer than the asci.^ RANGE ^Neohypodiscus cerebrinus has been reported from BC (Redhead)., It has been found in the US (FL and west coast, including CA), Canada, Central America, West Indies (including Dominican Republic, Jamaica, Trinidad), and South America including Brazil, (Miller, J.H.). Collections were examined from OR (site of northernmost report) and also from CA, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Jamaica, Trinidad, Guyana, Peru, and Suriname, (Rogers).
FRUITING BODY  1-6cm broad and 1-4cm thick "and reported to be considerably larger", nearly spherical to hemispheric to pulvinate [cushion-shaped], "with narrow to broad connection to substrate"; outer perithecium-bearing layer about 0.1cm thick, very hard, inner layer below perithecia fibrous to woody; externally "blackish, sometimes with brown or gray tones, internally satin brown, sometimes faintly zonate"; surface roughened with conic warts, perithecia about 0.07cm in diameter, ostioles "umbilicate, lying in valleys between warts"^, (Rogers), 2-10cm across, 1-4cm high, hemispheric, massive, sessile [without stem], several stromata [fruitbodies] often connate, "at first smooth but later very rough from protruding perithecial elevations", the latter triangular or compressed-conic, 0.05-0.1cm high; interior very woody but exterior carbonous, light to dark brown, (Miller, J.H.)
HABITAT  on dead wood^ (Miller, J.H.), on wood (Rogers)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (14.5)18.5-25.5(34.0) x (7.5)8.5-11.0 um, elliptic to somewhat elliptic-inequilateral or nearly rectangular, smooth, brown, 1-celled or unequally 2-celled, "many with apical thickening or noncellular appendage on each end", "occasionally with a germ pore at one end"^; ASCUS 8-spored, 160-170 um total length x 10-12 um wide, cylindric, short-stemmed, the spore-bearing part 130-140 um, with minute apical ring not staining in Melzer's reagent; PARAPHYSES abundant, 2.5-10 um wide, "septate, mostly unbranched, much longer than asci"; anamorph unknown, (Rogers, J), SPORES 21-30 x 8-10 um, elliptic to navicular [boat-shaped] with acute ends, diagonally uniseriate, light brown to dark; ASCUS 120-150 x 12-15 um in spore-bearing part, stem 30-40 um long; PARAPHYSES numerous, filiform; PERITHECIUM 500-700 um across and 700-1000 um high, hemispheric with rather long neck, ostiola conic-papillate, (Miller, J.H.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'brain-like'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Miller, J.H.(1) (as Hypoxylon cerebrinum), Rogers, J.D.(4), Redhead(5) (as Hypoxylon cerebrinum)
272
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Odonticium romellii  (S. Lundell) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort. 127. 1968;  == Odontia romellii  S. Lundell in J. Erikss.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a whitish surface with teeth up to 0.1cm long, 3) tough consistency, 4) spores that are allantoid, smooth, and inamyloid, 5) basidia in candelabra form, 6) cylindric hyphae in a tuft at the tips of the teeth, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae thick-walled without clamp connections.^ | Note that the Gilbertson(11) description says "The allantoid spores, abundant cystidia, and simple-septate hyphae distinguish this species", but Eriksson(5) says there are no cystidia (probably regarding the abundant cystidia at the tips of the teeth as hyphal ends), and that "There should be no problem recognizing O. romellii [name italicized] thanks to its tough consistency, its afibulate, thickwalled hyphae and its allantoid spores". RANGE ^Odonticium romellii has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MT, and NC, (Ginns). It is rare in northern Scandinavia (Finland, Norway, and Sweden) (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], mostly of small or moderate dimensions, but confluent and may cover several square decimeters or more, tough consistency, odontioid, with small dense aculei [spines], mostly 0.05-0.1cm long, conic to nearly cylindric, with bristles at tips under a lens; whitish to cream, when old pale grayish white; margin thinning out and usually fertile throughout; "subiculum very thin and porulose"^, (Eriksson), annual, spread over 10cm or more, up to 0.15cm thick, "light ochraceous-buff" to "cinnamon-buff"; "varying from crumbly to felt-like and readily separable"; teeth up to 0.15cm long, "crowded, mostly flattened to awl-shaped", strongly fimbriate [fringed] at the tips and along the sides; "margin fertile or rarely sterile and cottony to felt-like"; subiculum up to 0.05cm thick, felt-like or cottony, white to cream, (Gilbertson)
HABITAT  on decayed coniferous wood, usually barkless^, (Eriksson), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Ginns), associated with a white rot (Gilbertson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-4.5 x 1.2-1.5 um, allantoid - suballantoid, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-15(20) x 4-5 um, subclavate then subcylindric, often with slight median constriction, walls thin but thickening in basal half and upper limit of thicker layer sometimes visible; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae of the spines 4-5 um wide, straight, parallel, thick-walled, with numerous constrictions and septa but no clamp connections, apically thin-walled "and with rounded and obtuse apices", "hyphae of the subiculum besides with thinwalled, narrower (2.5-3 um) hyphae", generative hyphal branches 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, "richly branched and in older parts of the fruitbodies forming a subhymenium of densely interwoven hyphae"; all hyphae inamyloid and acyanophilic, (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5 x 1-1.5 um, allantoid, smooth, colorless; basidia 4-spored, 4-5 um wide, clavate, in distinct candelabra; CYSTIDIA in tufts at tips of teeth, projecting up to 30 um, 4-5 um wide, thick-walled at the base, the wall gradually thinning out toward the tip; HYPHAE in the core of each tooth with a distinct parallel arrangement, continuing to form the tuft of cystidia at the tip of the tooth; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, colorless, moderately thick-walled, often with slight constrictions, irregular in outline, with frequent branching, simple-septate, (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  probably after Romell who identified some collections as Hydnum lunatum
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(5), Gilbertson(11) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway(1)), Ginns(5)
273
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ofella glaira  (Lloyd) V. Spirin & V. Malysheva^  in Spirin, Malysheva, Roberts, Trichies, Savchenko & Larsson, Nordic Jl Bot. 37(e02394): 18. 2019;  Stypella glaira  (Lloyd) P. Roberts  Mycotaxon 69: 219. 1998;  Tremella glaira  Lloyd;  Sebacina sphaerospora  Bourdot & Galzin;  Myxarium sphaerosporum  (Bourdot & Galzin) D.A. Reid;  Tremella gangliformis  Linder;  Myxarium leptocystidiatum  Hauerslev
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a waxy-gelatinous fruitbody that is whitish drying to a varnish-like ochraceous layer or disappearing, 3) round to broadly elliptic spores, 4) (2)4-spored myxarioid basidia, 5) hyphidia that are simple or branched, 6) no cystidia, and 7) hyphae that are narrow, colorless, and thin-walled, with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from OR, MA, MO, Puerto Rico, Denmark, France, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Roberts).
FRUITING BODY  fruitbodies "expand laterally with age and then appear pustular", after further lateral growth the fruitbodies coalesce to form an effused compound fruitbody, tuberculate at first, finally becoming smooth^, (Roberts), effused, thin, gelatinous, drying ochraceous-vernicose or evanescent, (Hauerslev for Myxarium leptocystidiatum), 0.02-0.2cm long, 0.0064-0.0144cm wide, resupinate, gelatinous, gangliform ("the pustules, under a hand lens, can be seen to be connected by strands, of various shapes and sizes, which run over the surface of the substratum ... Some of the connecting strands are almost flat and of equal width throughout their length, but the majority are more or less rounded and with occasional swellings and hence resemble the ganglia of certain of the invertebrates"), rarely pulvinate [cushion-shaped]; white drying to cream color; context colorless, (Linder for Tremella gangliformis), thin, gelatinous, (Hauerslev for Myxarium sphaerosporum)
HABITAT  on fallen hardwood or coniferous wood^, (Roberts), on wood of Picea (spruce), (Hauerslev for Myxarium longicystidiatum), on decayed wood of Ulmus (elm), (Linder)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-7.5 x 3.5-6.5 um from mount of holotype, (3.5-6 x 3.5-5 from spore prints of English collections), round to broadly elliptic, some producing secondary spores, germinating by germ tube^; BASIDIA myxarioid; HYPHIDIA present but cystidia absent, (Roberts(3)), SPORES 4-5.5 x (3)3.5-5.5 um, round to nearly round, smooth, thin-walled, apiculate, some forming secondary spore; BASIDIA myxarioid, up to 30 um long, the head 6.5-9 x 5-8 um, becoming (2)4-celled by longitudinal division, sterigmata 5-17 um long; leptocystidia up to 35 x 4 um, clavate to cylindric [Roberts(3) considered these to be simple elements in the hymenium, probably representing elongated or aborted probasidia]; HYPHIDIA simple or branched; HYPHAE 0.5-2 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Hauerslev for Myxarium leptocystidiatum), SPORES 5.5-6 x 4-5 um [4.5-5.5 x 3.5-4.5 um when remeasured by Roberts(3)], nearly round to oval and obliquely apiculate, smooth, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, when young subspherical, later ovoid and longitudinally cruciate-septate, 8.5-12 x 6.5-7.5 um, [Roberts(3) says these basidia spheropedunculate and 6-7 um wide], sterigmata 36-40 x 1.5-2 um; HYPHAE slender, less than 1 um wide, much branched, without clamp connections, embedded in a gelatinous matrix, (Linder), SPORES 4.5-6 um in diameter, round to nearly round; BASIDIA myxarioid, apical part 7-10 x 5.5-7.5 um; HYPHAE indistinct, 0.5-3 um, with clamp connections, (Hauerslev for Myxarium sphaerosporum, but note that Reid's spore measurement for the lectotype selected by Roberts(3) was 3.5-4.75 um and almost uniformly globose)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Stypella grilletii has similar fruitbodies, hyphae, and hyphidia, but spores are different, (Roberts). Stypella subgelatinosa forms a distinctly hydnoid compound fruitbody, (Roberts). Stypella subhyalina has inconspicuous thin-walled cystidia, (Roberts). Stypella dubia has thick-walled cystidia, (Roberts).
SOURCES  Roberts(3) (as Stypella glaira), Linder(1) (as Tremella gangliformis), Hauerslev(1) (as Myxarium leptocystidiatum and Myxarium sphaerosporum)
274
FAMILY  Oliveoniaceae, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Oliveonia subviolacea  (Peck) M.J. Larsen^  Mycologia Memoir 4: 128. 1974;  == Hypochnus subviolaceus  Peck;  Ceratobasidium atratum  (Bres.) D.P. Rogers;  Hydrabasidium subviolaceum  (Peck)  J. Erikss. & Ryvarden;  Corticium atratum  Bres.;  Scotomyces subviolaceus  (Peck) Julich
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood and debris, 2) fruitbodies that are hypochnoid to submembranous, mealy, and dull, the color pale at first, becoming dark gray or dark gray-violet or with an olive tint, 3) a diffuse margin, 4) spores that are elliptic to nearly round, smooth, and inamyloid, and germinate by repetition, 5) basidia that are colorless becoming fuscous, with long sterigmata, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, and colorless to fuscous.^ | Breitenbach(2) gave it as a synonym of Scotomyces subviolaceus (Peck) Julich and the online Species Fungorum, accessed June 7, 2016, did the same. RANGE ^Oliveonia subviolacea has been found in OR, MB, ON, PQ, NC, and TN, (Ginns). It has been found in "Ontario, Manitoba. Quebec to Oregon south to North Carolina and Tennessee", Panama, Belize, Brazil, and Europe, (Martin). It occurs also in France, Norway, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Eriksson). It has been recorded from Europe (including Switzerland), and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], effused [spread out], mostly of small dimensions, 0.005-0.01cm thick, at first hypochnoid and soft, "then tightening and when old becoming submembranaceous"; "at first pale, then darkening and finally greyish black"; "margin not especially differentiated"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, bound loosely to substrate, forming patches 0.02-0.08cm thick and several centimeters across; dark gray-violet; "farinose, dull, slightly uneven"; "subhymenium and subiculum layered (old fruiting bodies), brown, watery, soft, open-textured flesh"; according to the literature young fruitbodies only up to 0.01cm thick and unlayered; margin diffuse; initial stage arachnoid [cobwebby], farinose, (Breitenbach), broadly effused "in small or large and then interrupted patches"; "dull olivaceous or blackish, becoming grayish-olive and subfleshy to waxy when soaked", (Martin), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on conifers; badly decayed wood; dead wood; exposed root of live tree; root bark^, (Ginns), on decayed wood (including boards) and other kinds of debris, (Eriksson), on the underside of trunks and branches of Abies (silver fir) lying on the ground, according to the literature "on rotten wood of the most diverse kinds, as well as on plant debris", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), on rotting conifer wood and also on bracken debris; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9 x 4-5.5 um, elliptic, broadly ovate or somewhat pip-shaped, smooth, inamyloid, colorless to somewhat brownish, acyanophilic, thin-walled, germinating by repetition^; BASIDIA 20-30 x 6-7.5 um, clavate or funnel-shaped, thin-walled "but in the distal part with somewhat thickening walls", "sometimes pedunculately prolonged to 40 or even 50 um", usually 4-spored, the sterigmata at first obtuse, then prolonged, divergent and subulate [awl-shaped], 8-12(15) um long, in young fruitbodies most basidia colorless but a few with fuscescent protoplasm, in old specimens all basidia more or less fuscous; CYSTIDIA "none, but sometimes sterile hyphal ends in the hymenium, mostly obscure but in rare cases subulate and then simulating cystidial organs"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, richly branched from clamp connections, thin-walled, in young fruitbodies colorless or partly fuscescent, "in old ones all hyphae more or less fuscous", "irregularly intertwined into a texture, which in the young fruitbody is loose and porulose, in the old ones rather dense and firm", "no clear limit between subhymenium and subiculum", (Eriksson), SPORES 6-9 x 4.5-6 um, broadly elliptic, nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets or granular contents, some spores forming secondary spores; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-25 x 7-9 um, cylindric-clavate, some with basal clamp connections, sterigmata up to 15 um long; CYSTIDIA "not seen, sometimes with scattered cystidium-like hyphal ends in the hymenium"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-4 um wide, colorless to brownish, thin-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 6-9 x 6-8 um, round to broadly ovate, germinating by repetition; PROBASIDIA "broadly cylindrical or clavate, borne in terminal clusters, with conspicuous, proliferating clamp-connections", finally 12-15 x 9-11 um, developing 4, rarely 3 or 2, thick, conic or subfusiform epibasidia; "in section composed or one or two distinct layers, each about 75 um thick, and each composed of a thin layer of basal hyphae which gives rise to erect pillar-like strands which support a continuous hymenium", (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(5) (as Hydrabasidium subviolaceum), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Ceratobasidium atratum), Ginns(5), Breitenbach(2)* (as Scotomyces subviolaceus), Buczacki(1)* (as Scotomyces subviolaceus)
275
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Paullicorticium ansatum  Liberta^  Brittonia 14: 220. 1962
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  A distinctive feature of Paullicorticium ansatum species is the clamp connections that are open like teapot handles, so that there is a gap between the middle of the clamp connection and the two cells it connects, or where a branch arises from a clamp connection appearing like a loop at the junction of three hyphae. Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed conifer wood, 2) a very thin, firmly attached fruitbody that is waxy when wet, and fibrillose-porulose-reticulate when dry, the margin not differentiated, 3) spores that are narrowly elliptic with oblique tapering apiculus, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) 6-8-spored basidia, proliferating from a terminal hyphal cell or from a clamp connection, 5) hyphae contorted with numerous clamp connections (that are open like handles as described above).^ RANGE ^Collections of Paullicorticium ansatum were examined from OR, ON, and ME, (Liberta), and Germany and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached], "very thin, often almost invisible", when wet ceraceous [waxy], "when dried porulose-reticulate"; grayish white; "without differentiated margin"^, (Eriksson), effused, thin (in section 0.003-0.004cm thick), inconspicuous, adnate; grayish white; "soft-ceraceous, when dry fibrillose-incrusting", under a lens appearing as a pruinose reticulum scattered over the substrate, (Liberta) 
HABITAT  on much decayed wood of conifers; July to October^, (Eriksson), on decayed wood of Pinus rigida (Pitch Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and probably Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), and Abies (fir), (Liberta)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7 x 2.5-3.5 um, narrowly elliptic, with oblique, tapering apiculus, smooth, colorless, thin-walled, inamyloid [by genus description], thin-walled^; BASIDIA (4)6(8)-spored, 12-18 x 6-8 um, clavate-pyriform, basal clamp loop-like; "fruitbodies develop from a net of basal hyphae, with short basidia-bearing branches, which intertwine into a thin subhymenial layer with indistinct hyphal details"; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, clamp connections "very open, loop- or handle-like" [with a gap between the clamp connection and the two cells it connects], "basal hyphae with the same clamps but partly seemingly simple-septate as the loops may become so wide that they are mistaken for simple-septate hyphae", (Eriksson), SPORES 5-6.5 x (2)2.5-3.5 um, spores "often clinging together in groups of 2 or more", "suboblong to occasionally subnavicular, tapering obliquely toward the apiculus", smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA 6-8-spored, 11-17(18.5) x 7-9 um, "obpyriform, proliferating from a terminal hyphal cell or from a clamp" ("basidial proliferation from the open clamp subtending the initial terminal basidium"), sterigmata 3.5-6 um long, divergent, recurved; HYPHAE 1.5-3.5 um wide, contorted, distinct, clamp connections numerous, ansiform [open like handles], (Liberta)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'having a handle', presumably referring to the clamp connections
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Liberta(4), Eriksson(5), Ginns(5)
276
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora aurantiaca  (Bres.) Hoehn. & Litsch.^  Sitzungsber. Kaiserl. Akad. Wiss., Math.-Naturwiss. Kl., Abt. I, 115: 1583. 1906;  == Corticium aurantiaca  Bres.;  Aleurodiscus zelleri  Burt;  Peniophora lepida  Bres.;  Peniophora shearii  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on alder and willow, 2) an orange-red to pale orange fruitbody, with a distinct gray-whitish border that is fibrillose in young specimens, 3) large elliptic spores, 4) cystidia of 2 types: thick-walled encrusted metuloids and thin-walled sulfocystidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Peniophora aurantiaca has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, NT, ON, PE, YT, AK, MA, ME, MI, MS, MT, NC, NH, NY, PA, and WI, (Ginns). It also occurs in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach). It is common in subalpine region of central and southern Europe (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  forming patches several centimeters across, resupinate, attached tightly, swollen up to 0.1cm thick when moist, consistency "waxlike, cartilaginous, when dry thin and crustose"; "orange-red to pale orange"; smooth to irregularly tuberculate; "margin distinctly bounded, gray-whitish, sometimes fringed when young"^, (Breitenbach), about 0.02-0.05cm thick, "resupinate, mostly totally adnate, only when old somewhat loosening from the substrate, at first orbicular round lenticels and other holes in the outer bark, then confluent and covering undersides of branches", consistency ceraceous [waxy] when young, membranaceous when older; "lighter or darker orange-red depending on age"; more or less tuberculate especially in the center; margin "lighter, pale yellow or white, fibrillose in young specimens", (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on dead wood; small dead twigs; dead stems and branches; associated with a white rot; primarily on Alnus and Salix^: on Abies grandis (needs confirmation), Alnus viridis ssp. crispa (Green Alder), Alnus rubra (Red Alder), Alnus rugosa (Speckled Alder), Alnus sinuata (Sitka Alder), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Betula sp. (birch), Menziesia ferruginea (false azalea), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Salix sp. (willow), Ulmus sp. (elm), (Ginns), on dead wood of Alnus viridis (Green Alder) usually with bark, "on attached and fallen branches, at mountain and subalpine elevations", (Breitenbach for Switzerland), on Alnus viridis in Europe in subalpine areas, on Alnus rubra, A. rugosa, and A. sinuata in North America extending down to sea-level, (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 14-17 x 7.5-10 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, with droplets, colorless, yellow-pink in deposit^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 55-80 x 6-12 um, cylindric-clavate with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA: 1) "lamprocystidia, thick-walled with fusiform incrusted upper part 30-50 x 7-10 um", 2) gloeocystidia 100-130 x 5-8 um, sulfo-positive, "thin-walled, with granular contents, arising ascuslike out of the base"; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-5 um wide, branched, thin-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES elliptic, smooth, thin-walled, mostly 14-16 x 8-10 um, colorless (but in spore print yellow or light orange depending on thickness of print); BASIDIA varying but mostly cylindric, "more or less sinuous and constricted, reaching a size of 60-90 x 10-15 um", with 4 conic sterigmata, "in young fruitbodies some pleurobasidia seen"; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) encrusted, thick-walled metuloids, the distal encrusted part 30-50 x 8-12 um, the basal unencrusted part of varying length, often with adventitious septation, 2) thin-walled sulfocystidia, numerous especially in young specimens, "reaching a length of 100 or 150 um and a width of 10-15, sometimes 20 um", with granular protoplasm reacting to sulfovanillin, "elongate, obtuse, or tapering to an apex"; section showing a basal subicular layer 100-200 um thick, of dense parallel hyphae, and a subhymenial layer "of mainly vertical hyphae and hymenial elements", at first about 100 um thick, then increasing in thickness, HYPHAE monomitic, "with thin or slightly thickened walls", with clamp connections, the subhymenial hyphae 3-4 um wide, richly branched, the subicular hyphae 4-5 um long, straight, sparsely branched, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'orange'
SIMILAR  Peniophora erikssonii also has large spores and is only reliably separated by clampless septa, (Eriksson). See also SIMILAR section of Peniophora incarnata.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Eriksson(5), Ginns(5)
277
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora carnea  (Berk. & Cooke) Cooke^  Grevillea 8: 21. 1879;  == Corticium carneum  Berkeley & Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features of this rare fungus include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is ochraceous flesh-color, the margin whitish and fibrillose, 3) cylindric, slightly curved spores, 4) encrusted cystidia of 2 types as well as thin-walled cystidia, and 5) a dark, semi-opaque zone next to the substrate.^ |The description is derived from Burt. Ginns(5) says the following. The two specimens cited in the protologue are 1016 and 1025. Burt apparently regarded 1025 as Peniophora cinerea, and presumably that is why he designated Ravenel 78, labeled as C. carneum, as type and based the description on that and a specimen from Cuba. Hjortstam studied those two California specimens cited in the prologue, concluding 1016 was indeterminate and 1025 was not Peniophora cinerea. But it is uncertain whether the two collections Burt used are conspecific with 1025: if 1025 can be used to characterize the species, Burt's designation of Ravenel 78 as type is irrelevant. (Ginns(5)). RANGE ^It has been found in WA, CA, and TX, (Ginns). It is found in Texas and Cuba (Burt).
FRUITING BODY  1-6cm long, 0.5-2cm wide, thin, 0.01-0.012cm thick, resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached]; ochraceous flesh-color drying avellaneous, cracked when dry; "margin whitish and fibrillose"
HABITAT  on logs and fallen decaying hardwood limbs, (Burt), fallen decaying limbs; logs; Pinus contorta, angiosperm, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-12 x 3-4 um, slightly curved, colorless^; CYSTIDIA "incrusted, of two kinds - very large cystidia resembling conical or subglobose crystalline masses 45-75 x 30-75 um are seated on the opaque zone, other cystidia 25-35 x 6-8 um are scattered throughout the region between the dark zone and the surface of the hymenium", "gloeocystidia flexuous, 40-50 x 4-4 1/2 um, not numerous"; "in section brownish, 100-120 um thick, with a dark semi-opaque zone next to the substratum; hyphae densely interwoven, 3-3 1/2 um in diameter, slightly colored, somewhat longitudinally interwoven next to the substratum"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'flesh-colored'
SIMILAR  Peniophora cinerea lacks the large cystidia (Burt).
SOURCES  Burt(7), Ginns(5)
278
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora cinerea  (Pers.) Cooke^  Grevillea 8: 20. 1879;  == Corticium cinereum  Pers.;  Corticium fumigatum  Thuem.;  Thelephora lilacina  Schwein.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth generally on hardwoods, 2) a gray-lilac to bluish-gray fruitbody with an undifferentiated margin, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia of 2 types: thick-walled encrusted metuloids and thin-walled gloeocystidia (no sulfocystidia), and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, a basal layer usually absent.^ RANGE ^Peniophora cinerea has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PE, PQ, AL, CA, CO, CT, FL, GA, IL, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MS, NC, ND, NE, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, TN, VA, VT, and WI, (Ginns). It occurs in Europe including Switzerland, Asia, (Breitenbach). It has also been found in Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  forming thin-crustose patches 0.005-0.01cm thick and several centimeters to decimeters across, resupinate, attached tightly, consistency "waxlike when moist, crustose and hard when dry"; "gray-lilac to bluish-gray, fading to whitish to brownish when old"; even, smooth to slightly verrucose [warty], dull; margin "thin and somewhat lighter when young, distinctly bounded when old, always appressed tightly to the substrate"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached to substrate], orbicular as patches round lenticels etc., then confluent, or effused from the beginning, "mostly thin (0.5-0.1mm) [sic] and smooth, sometimes thicker and more or less tuberculate", consistency when very young ceraceous [waxy], "then very firm, hard when dry"; "mature specimens when dry mainly grey but with considerable variation, young specimens reddish grey, wet mature ones dark violaceous gray, old specimens mainly brown"; "often cracked in small polygons"; margin "generally not differentiated, except in some young specimens, in which there may be a narrow, light-coloured, finely fimbriate sterile zone", (Eriksson), spore deposit pale pink (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on fallen branches of hardwoods, less often on dead hanging branches or on fallen logs^, never seen on conifers, (Eriksson for Scandinavia), on bark of dead branch; bark of fallen limb; pulpwood; associated with a white rot, on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Amelanchier (serviceberry), Arbutus (madrone), Arctium (burdock), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Cercocarpus (mountain mahogany), Cornus (dogwood), Corylus (hazel), Cotoneaster, Eucalyptus, Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Holodiscus (oceanspray), Juglans (walnut), Lagerstroemia (crape myrtle), Liquidambar, Malus, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Purshia, Quercus (oak), Rhus, Rubus, Salix (willow), Symphoricarpos, Syringa, Tilia (basswood), Ulmus (elm), Vitis (grape), Weigelia, (Ginns), "on dead hardwoods, on trunks and branches of Fagus (beech) and Corylus (hazel) and others, with and without bark and both fallen and standing or attached respectively", (Breitenbach for Switzerland), especially sycamore and beech; all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7.5-9 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, spore deposit pale pink^, BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50 x 5-6 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA: lamprocystidia "cylindrical with round to conical tips, incrusted part 20-25 x 7-9 um, thick-walled, young cystidia fusiform, smooth, thick-walled, brownish"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-5 um wide, colorless to brownish, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections, no basal layer, (Breitenbach), SPORES 7-9(10) x 2.5-3.5 um, allantoid to subcylindric, smooth, colorless, thin-walled, spore print pale red; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-40 x 5-6 um, subcylindric-subclavate, somewhat sinuous, thin-walled, with basal clamp connection, "pleurobasidia observed in young fruitbodies"; CYSTIDIA of two types: 1) a few gloeocystidia sometimes present in young specimens, 20-30 x 5-10 um, oblong, thin-walled, "terminal or lateral on the bearing hyphae, protoplasm not darkening in sulfovanillin", 2) encrusted metuloid cystidia, starting in the hymenium as thin-walled cystidioles, "then with thickened walls, in time strongly pigmented brown in the basal part", distal part 15-20 x 7-10 um, "not or only weakly pigmented with an outer layer of encrustation, often dissolving in old, enclosed cystidia, and an inner crystalline filling", "number of cystidia varying, as a rule numerous, in young specimens often sparse"; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, embryonal ones in growing marginal zone 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, colorless, secondary hyphae about 3 um wide, with thickened walls, more or less pigmented brown; subhymenium "of vertical hyphae, very closely united into a pseudoparenchymatic tissue"; subiculum "as a rule lacking or present only as a very thin layer", occasionally 10-20 um thick, "composed of horizontal, densely united hyphae", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ash-colored'
SIMILAR  Peniophora quercina (AZ, CA, NY) is thicker and has a margin that is loose and often somewhat rolled upward, the erect marginal zone being caused by a microscopically distinguishable basal layer, (Breitenbach). Peniophora carnea is rare and has cystidia with large crystalline masses, (Burt). See also SIMILAR section of Peniophora decorticans.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Eriksson(5), Ginns(5), Burt(7) (discussing Peniophora carnea), Buczacki(1)*
279
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora decorticans  Burt^  Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 12: 344. 1926
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  "Its most noteworthy character, by which it may be recognized at a glance, is its curious habit of forming the fructification on bark-covered limbs between the bark and the wood, so that the loosened bark - very noticeable on Quercus limbs - curls back, disclosing the fructification closely adnate on the wood.", (Burt, hyphen replaced by long dashes and genus name italicized). Other features of Peniophora decorticans include 1) color that is pale pinkish buff and pale gray to whitish, 2) antler-shaped paraphyses and 3) encrusted cystidia, seen only in the region next to the bark.^ | The description is derived from Burt(7). It is common locally in Washington and Oregon, (Burt). RANGE ^It has been found in BC, WA, and OR, (Ginns). 
FRUITING BODY  2-600cm long, 1-2cm wide, flat on substrate, closely attached, "very thin, growing on the wood, spreading longitudinally and laterally between the wood and bark, loosening the latter"; "pale pinkish buff and pale gull-gray to whitish"; pruinose, with occasionally tubercles in some collections
HABITAT  on Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Rhus diversiloba (poison-oak)^, (Ginns), February to December, (Burt)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-9 x 3 um, slightly curved, even, colorless, few seen^; CYSTIDIA few, up to 20-25 um x 15 um, encrusted, ovoid to subglobose, seen only in the region next to the substrate; PARAPHYSES "with slender, antler-shaped branches protrude from hymenium"; in section brownish, 50-90 um thick, not zoned, "composed of densely arranged, interwoven, slightly colored, erect hyphae 3 um in diameter, with no darker and opaque zone next to the substratum"
NAME ORIGIN  probably refers to its habit growing between bark and wood, loosening the bark
SIMILAR  P. decorticans differs from Peniophora cinerea, Peniophora nuda, and Peniophora violaceolivida in not being so dark as to be opaque next to the substrate, (Burt).
SOURCES  Burt(7), Ginns(5)
280
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora erikssonii  Boidin^  Bull. Soc. Hist. Nat. Toulouse 92: 286. 1957
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Peniophora erikssonii is similar to the common Peniophora aurantiaca but without clamp connections. Features include 1) resupinate growth on alder, 2) a yellowish to orange-yellow fruitbody, with a pale yellowish or white border that is pruinose or finely fimbriate, 3) large elliptic spores, 4) cystidia of 2 types: thick-walled encrusted metuloids and thin-walled sulfocystidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^It has been found in WA, OR, NWT, PQ, YT, AL, IN, NY, and PA, (Ginns). It has also been found in Finland, France, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], orbicular [round] around lenticels in the bark, then confluent to moderate dimensions, generally 0.02-0.03cm thick, but with a thicker central tubercle, consistency soft and ceraceous [waxy] when young, becoming membranaceous when older; yellowish to orange-yellow; margin pruinose or finely fimbriate [fringed] and pale yellowish or white^, (Eriksson), spore deposit pale pink (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead hanging branches of Alnus (alder) species, late summer through fall^, (Eriksson), on Alnus (alder), associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 15-20 x 10-13 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless but orange-yellow in thick spore prints, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-100 x 12-15 um, mainly cylindric, "more or less sinuous and constricted", sterigmata about 8 um long; CYSTIDIA of two types: 1) thick-walled metuloids, more numerous in mature fruitbodies, 100 um or more long, the distal encrusted part 30-50 x 8-15 um, 2) thin-walled sulfocystidia (gloeocystidia), more numerous in young fruitbodies, up to 100-200 um long, cylindric, more or less sinuous and constricted, with granular protoplasm that reacts to sulfovanillin; HYPHAE monomitic, thin-walled, without clamp connections: SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-4 um wide, richly branched, densely interwoven, the subhymenial layer growing in thickness, mostly 100-200 um thick, mainly vertically arranged, SUBICULAR HYPHAE straight with sparser septa and sparser branching, forming thick layer of hyphae parallel to substrate
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Peniophora aurantiaca is very similar and the only reliable differentiating characteristic is that P. erikssonii lacks clamp connections, (Eriksson). See also SIMILAR section of Aleurodiscus aurantius and Peniophora incarnata.
SOURCES  Eriksson(5), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
281
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora incarnata  (Pers.) P. Karst.^  Hedwigia 28: 27. 1889;  == Thelephora incarnata  Pers.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  rosy crust
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) an orange-red to brown-orange fruitbody (when young and wet violaceous red and in the herbarium ochraceous) that is smooth to tubercular, 3) margin that is distinctly bounded and when young may be whitish to yellowish and slightly fringed, 4) spores that are cylindric to elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, and in a spore print faintly pink, 5) cystidia of 2 types: thin-walled sulfocystidia and thick-walled encrusted metuloids, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Peniophora incarnata has been found in BC, WA, OR, AB, MB, NF, NS, ON, AK, AL, CA, CO, DC, FL, GA, IA, IL, KS, KY, MA, MD, ME, MI, MO, ND, NH, NM, NY, OH, PA, SC, VT, WI, and WV, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland, and Asia, (Breitenbach), and Scandinavia (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  forming patches a few centimeters to several decimeters across, resupinate, attached tightly, swollen up to 0.1cm thick when moist, waxy-cartilaginous, when dry crustose and thin; orange-red to brown-orange; surface smooth to irregularly tuberculate; margin more or less distinctly bounded, slightly fringed when young^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached], on bark orbicular [circular] and confluent, on bare wood effused [spread out], "size small to moderate but may reach considerable dimensions, covering undersides of branches", 0.01-0.03cm thick, sometimes more, ceraceous [waxy] in the youngest specimens, then firmer, membranaceous; "pale to bright orange, when young and wet watery violaceous red, in the herbarium fading to ochraceous"; smooth or when old more or less tuberculate, "finally cracking into polygons"; "margin in young specimens sometimes whitish or yellowish, finely fibrillose under the lens, older fruitbodies without differentiated margin", (Eriksson), spore deposit pale pink (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead wood of hardwoods and more rarely conifers^, with and without bark, on fallen and standing trunks, on fallen and attached branches, (Breitenbach), on all sorts of wood, most frequently on hardwoods: "fallen or still attached branches, lying trunks and stumps, rarer on coniferous wood, where it is usually seen on upper surfaces of stumps" and on sawn ends of piled wood, left for a couple of years or more in the forest, (Eriksson), dead branches on live trees; wood and bark of fallen limbs; on a garden stake; associated with a white rot; on Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Arbutus (madrone), Arctostaphylos, Baccharis, Bambusa (bamboo), Cercocarpus (mountain mahogany), Chrysanthemum, Corylus (hazel), Crataegus (hawthorn), Cytisus (broom), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Holodiscus (oceanspray), Juglans (walnut), Magnolia, Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Rhus, Rosa (rose), Rubus, Salix (willow), Sambucus (elderberry), Symphoricarpos, Tilia (basswood), Vaccinium, (Ginns), often on ivy and gorse; all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7.5-9.5 x 3.5-4.5 um, cylindric to elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, spore deposit faintly pink^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50 x 5-6 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of two types: 1) gloeocystidia 100 um and longer, 8-12 um wide, sulfo-positive, "thin-walled, arising ascuslike out of the base", 2) lamprocystidia thick-walled, with fusiform, encrusted upper part 40-60 x 8-13 um; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae 3-4 um wide and branched, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 8-12 x 3.5-5 um, broadly cylindric - narrowly elliptic, smooth, thin-walled, light red in spore print; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-45 x 5-7 um, "narrowly clavate, often somewhat sinuously constricted, thin-walled", "smaller in old fruitbodies than in young ones", with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) numerous thin-walled sulfocystidia with granular contents, "growing to long tubes with the thickening of the fruitbody, reaching a length of 200 um or more and a width of 10-15 um", 2) fewer encrusted metuloids, at first thin-walled and naked, "then covered with an outer layer of encrustation, the interior filled with a crystalline substance, leaving only a narrow central lumen", total size of encrusted part 30-60 x 7-15 um; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-4 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "densely united, richly branched in the thickening hymenium, basally often a thin subiculum of straight, parallel hyphae", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  'incarnate', presumably referring to color
SIMILAR  Peniophora aurantiaca has much larger spores. Peniophora erikssonii has clampless septa and larger elliptic spores. See also SIMILAR section of Eichleriella deglubens.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Eriksson(5), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
282
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora nuda  (Fr.) Bres.^  Atti Imp. Regia Accad. Rovereto, Ser. III, 3: 114. 1897;  == Thelephora nuda  Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwoods often outside of forests, 2) gray pink color (with violet tint when moist, more red when young), the surface mostly smooth with a low central wart, the margin rose or whitish and finely fringed when young, abrupt when old, 3) spores that are cylindric-allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) a pink spore print, 5) cystidia of 2 types: a) bladder-like to almost cylindric, thin-walled sulfocystidia, in the basal layer and the hymenium, and b) conic to almost cylindric, thick-walled, encrusted cystidia, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Peniophora nuda has been found in WA, MB, NB, NS, ON, PE, AL, AZ, CO, FL, GA, IL, LA, MD, MI, MN, NJ, NY, OH, SC, TX, VA, VT, and WI, (Ginns), as well as in Switzerland, in Asia, (Breitenbach), and in Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  forming patches up to 0.02cm thick and several centimeters across, resupinate, attached tightly, consistency wax-like when fresh, crustose and hard when dry; "gray-pink, with violet tint when moist"; "smooth to slightly uneven, dull", when dry finely reticulate-fissured; "margin tightly appressed and distinctly bounded to thinning out somewhat"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached], orbicular [circular] and confluent, "but normally of small or moderate size", mostly thin (about 0.01cm thick, sometimes up to 0.02cm thick); surface of growing fungus reddish gray "but variable with age and water content" ("more red when young, more violaceous when wet", while old, postmature specimens tend to be grayish brown); "mostly smooth with low central wart", when old often cracking; margin of young fruitbodies rose or whitish, finely fimbriate [fringed] under lens, in old fruitbodies "not especially differentiated, more or less abrupt", (Eriksson), spore deposit pale pink (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead wood or hardwood trees and shrubs, usually on standing trunks and attached branches with bark, "in parks, hedges, more rarely in forests"^, (Breitenbach), on recently dead, fallen or still attached branches of hardwoods, mostly on branches with bark, "penetrating the secondary bark layer or more effuse on the primary bark", but found also on barkless branches, (Eriksson), branches; dead still attached branches; fallen limbs; slash; associated with a white rot, on Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Celtis (hackberry), Cercocarpus (mountain mahogany), Corylus (hazel), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Juniperus (juniper), Ostrya (hop hornbeam), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Prosopis (mesquite), Prunus, Quercus (oak), Ribes, Syringa, Tilia (basswood), Weigelia, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-10.5 x 2.6-4 um, cylindric, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-40 x 6-7.5 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA: 1) gloeocystidia 30-50 x 6-16 um, bladder-like, clavate, sulfo-positive, 2) lamprocystidia 25-50 x 6-11 um, "thick-walled, smooth to incrusted"; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae 3-5 um wide, colorless to brownish, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 7.5-11 x 2.5-3.5 um, cylindric-suballantoid, smooth, colorless, thin-walled, spore print light red; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-45 x 6-8 um, subcylindric, thin-walled, with basal clamp connection, old basidia often with adventitious septa, basidia difficult to separate, except in young specimens; CYSTIDIA of two types: 1) sulfocystidia, 30-60 x 8-20 um, rounded or oblong to almost cylindric, numerous in basal layer [illustrated with somewhat thickened walls, basally or overall], "within the hymenial layer thin, then at the least basally thickened walls", "protoplasm granular, with positive aldehyde reaction", 2) encrusted cystidia, conic or subcylindric-obtuse, basal part thick-walled and becoming brown, encrusted part 25-40 x 8-12 um, "young cystidia thinwalled, pointed, projecting from the hymenium"; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, the young ones colorless, thin-walled, the old hyphae with thickened walls, more or less brown; "subhymenium thickening and in old specimens often stratified with 2 or more layers of vertically arranged, densely united hyphae, together with basidia and cystidia forming a pseudoparenchymatic tissue"; "basal layer generally lacking or very thin", but may reach 30 um thick, "composed of parallel, densely united hyphae", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'naked'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Peniophora decorticans and Peniophora violaceolivida.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Eriksson(5), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
283
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora piceae  (Pers.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 10 (5): 49. 1950;  == Thelephora piceae  Pers.;  Peniophora separans  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a fruitbody that is reddish gray then purple gray or dark violaceous gray, the surface more or less tuberculate, 3) a detaching margin that is narrow and white soon darkening to brown, 4) spores that are allantoid, smooth, and colorless, 5) thick-walled encrusted cystidia but no gloeocystidia, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, the subhymenium with vertical hyphae, and the subiculum with horizontal hyphae.^ | The Burt description is for the synonym Peniophora separans Burt, which Burt described from a log in BC. RANGE ^Peniophora piceae found in BC, AB, NB, NF, and MN, (Ginns). It is widespread and locally abundant in the continental Europe, and has been found once in Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  0.01-0.03cm thick, sometimes more, resupinate, confluent, at first adnate [firmly attached] and continuous "but soon loosening from the margins and cracking in irregular pieces"; when young reddish gray then pure gray or dark violaceous gray, "old postmature specimens more or less brown"; surface more or less tuberculate; margin "in young vividly growing fruitbodies with a narrow, white border, but soon darkening to brown, and not especially differentiated"^, (Eriksson), fruiting bodies probably large, because those studied were 4cm long by 4cm wide and broken off on three sides, broadly effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], "somewhat membranaceous, small pieces separable when moistened"; "between pale ochraceous buff and avellaneous in the herbarium"; "even, somewhat cracked and showing the darker substance in the sides of the fissures"; the margin thinning out, adnate, slightly darker, somewhat radially fibrillose, (Burt), Breitenbach(2) notes that P. piceae has margin "clearly detaching"
HABITAT  on dead, mostly still attached branches, or small fallen trunks^ of Abies spp., (Eriksson), on bark of coniferous log, (Burt), on bark; on log; on Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), A. lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), P. glauca (White Spruce), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-8.8 x 2.3-2.8 um, allantoid, smooth, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-40 x 5-7 um, subcylindric, slightly constricted and sinuous, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA usually numerous, at first thin-walled and colorless, then "with an outer encrustation and an inner crystalline filling in the distal part, basally not encrusted and with thick, brown walls", "cystidia larger in first hymenial layer (encrusted part reaching 35 x 15 um), smaller in the later layers" (20-25 x 5-8 um), sulfocystidia not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-4 um wide, with clamp connections, young hyphae thin-walled, colorless, "old ones with thickened brown walls", "subhymenium thickening of vertically arranged hyphae together with residua of basidia and of old cystidia forming a pseudoparenchymatic tissue", subiculum 40-100 um thick, "partly even more, composed of densely united, mainly horizontal and parallel hyphae with thick, brown walls", (Eriksson), SPORES 8-10 x 2-3 um, colorless, smooth; no gloeocystidia or conducting hyphae, CYSTIDIA numerous, 40-50 x 8-15 um, encrusted, immersed, starting from base of hymenial layer; "in section 300-350 um thick, colored, stratose, each stratum 2-layered, the supporting layer composed of densely and longitudinally interwoven, slightly colored hyphae 3 - 3 1/2 um in diameter, the hymenial layer 75-120 um thick, composed of densely arranged, erect tissue", (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'separating'
SIMILAR  Peniophora pithya does not loosen in the same way at the margin, and has sulfocystidia, (Eriksson). Peniophora piceae (as P. separans) shows some resemblance to Stereum sanguinolenta when the latter is flat, but P. separans has cystidia and lacks conducting hyphae, (Burt).
SOURCES  Eriksson(5), Burt(7) (as Peniophora separans), Ginns(5), Breitenbach(2)
284
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora pithya  (Pers.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 10 (5): 45. 1950;  == Thelephora pithya  Pers.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a reddish gray to violet-gray or blue-gray fruitbody, waxy and tough, smooth, with an abrupt margin, often with a narrow darker zone, 3) spores that are cylindric, slightly curved, smooth, and colorless, 4) a reddish spore print, 5) cystidia of two types: a) encrusted, conic, thick-walled cystidia, and b) thin-walled sulfocystidia, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, the subhymenial hyphae vertically arranged, contrasting against the darker horizontally arranged subicular hyphae.^ RANGE ^Peniophora pithya has been found in BC, AB, NB, NS, ON, PQ, AZ, and UT, (Ginns), as well as in Switzerland, in Asia, (Breitenbach), and in Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  forming irregular patches 0.01-0.02cm thick, resupinate, attached tightly, "at first in the form of rounded spots, later coherent" and several centimeters across, consistency wax-like and tough when fresh, "brittle and hard when dry"; "blue-gray when moist, later with a lilac tint"; "smooth, dull, somewhat undulating, slightly fissured when dry"; margin "distinctly bounded, irregularly undulating, sometimes notched, barely detached from the substrate"^, (Breitenbach), mostly 0.1-0.2cm thick, resupinate, "closely adnate but through flaking off of the outer bark layer seemingly loosening from the margins"; "reddish or violaceous grey, when wet darker, sometimes bluish violaceous"; "smooth and continuous on wood, more uneven on bark, when dried more or less cracked"; "margin abrupt, in many specimens with a dark, narrow sterile zone", rarely light-colored, but most often fertile throughout, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on dead conifer wood, on branches and trunks, summer to fall, according to the literature also on lumber^, (Breitenbach), on bark and wood of conifers, both on logs and fallen branches, also on sawn wood, most often Picea abies (Norway Spruce), also Pinus sylvestris (Scotch Pine), Juniperus communis (Common Juniper), Larix (larch), and Salix (willow), (Eriksson), bark and wood of logs; fallen branches; lumber; on Abies concolor (White Fir), A. lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Alnus sp. (alder), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), P. glauca (White Spruce), P. mariana (Black Spruce), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-7 x 2.5-3 um, cylindric, slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, some with droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-45 x 4.5-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA: 1) lamprocystidia thick-walled, brownish, encrusted part 20-25 x 10-15 um, total length up to 60 um, some projecting, 2) sulfo-positive gloeocystidia 50-70 x 7.5-10 um; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4.5 um wide, colorless to brown, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES (6)6.5-7.5(9) x 2.5-3 um, allantoid, smooth, colorless, thin-walled, reddish in spore print, it is noted that the "spore size 5.5-6.5 um given by Eriksson 1950 is true mainly for N. Sweden"; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-40 x 5-7 um, subcylindric or subclavate, sometimes constricted or sinuous, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA numerous, of 2 types, 1) encrusted, 35-65 x 12-15 um, encrusted part 25-35 um long, cystidia generally conic, at first thin-walled and colorless, "then apically encrusted and at least in basal part brown", those of the first hymenial layer largest and basally brown, later cystidia smaller and more or less colorless, 2) sulfocystidia, 50-70(100) x 8-10 um, oblong to subcylindric, "as a rule obtuse, with thin or basally thickened walls", "contents continuous, granular, or with oily droplets, aldehyde reaction weak in many herbarium specimens but strong at least in vividly growing ones", sulfocystidia not always found in old specimens; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, young ones thin-walled and colorless, old hyphae brown and more or less thick-walled; subhymenial layer "of dense, vertically arranged hyphae", colorless in young specimens, "more or less pigmented in older ones but as a rule sharply contrasting against the darker subiculum, subhymenium generally not stratified but in some specimens two or three layers visible"; "subiculum varying in thickness from an inconspicuous layer of horizontal hyphae to a considerable (up to 40 um) thickness, composed of parallel, dense, dark brown hyphae", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Peniophora pithya is somewhat macroscopically similar to Amylostereum and Veluticeps species, "which, however, form distinctly thicker fruiting bodies with projecting margins and a tendency toward semipileate growth", and are microscopically different, (Breitenbach). Peniophora piceae differs by lacking sulfocystidia and by the marginal zone clearly detaching, (Breitenbach). Peniophora septentrionalis has a fruitbody that is lighter in color and less firmly attached, (Eriksson). Peniophora exima H.S. Jacks. & Dearden, found on Abies magnifica in California, differs in having much shorter, almost elliptic spores, (Eriksson). Spores of P. exima measure 5.5-6.5 x 2.5-3 um (Jackson(4)).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Eriksson(5), Ginns(5), Jackson(4) (discussing Peniophora exima)
285
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora polygonia  (Pers.) Bourdot & Galzin^  Hym. France. 320. 1928;  == Corticium polygonium  Pers.;  Cryptochaete polygonia  (Pers.) P. Karst.;  Gloeocystidium polygonium  (Pers.) Hoehn. & Litsch.  var. fulvescens  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth in rounded to elongated patches on aspen and other hardwoods, 2) fruitbodies that are pink and whitish-pruinose, bruising dark red, and smooth to tuberculate, 3) a margin that whitish and finely fringed when young to undifferentiated when mature, 4) spores that are slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, with a light red spore print, 5) sulfo-positive gloeocystidia that are bladder-like to clavate, 6) richly branched dendrohyphidia covering the hymenium, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Peniophora polygonia has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NF, NS, NT, ON, PQ, YT, AK, AZ, CO, MN, and NM, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  "forming rounded to elongate spots" several centimeters across, "more rarely confluent patches", 0.01-0.02cm thick, resupinate, attached tightly, consistency "crustose and hard, friable when dry"; "pink and whitish-pruinose (from dendrohyphidia)"; "smooth to slightly tuberculate, dull"; margin "filamentous to distinctly bounded, tightly appressed"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached], "appearing through holes in the outer bark and growing radially" to round patches with a wart-like thickening in the center, then often confluent to aggregated fruitings of moderate size (5-10cm), "consistency firm, after drying hard"; "pale red with a whitish pruina, when bruised dark red"; at first smooth except for central wart, in time irregularly tuberculate; margin adnate, in the young round state white or reddish white, finely fimbriate [fringed], when fruitbody mature margin not differentiated, (Eriksson), spore deposit pale pink (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead bark; dead branches; especially fallen branches; slash; saprophytic on rotten wood; associated with a white rot^, "causes heart rot, top rot and incipient staining in aspen"; on Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), P. grandidentata (Bigtooth Aspen), P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Acer glabrum (Rocky Mountain Maple), Alnus sp. (alder), (Ginns), on dead branches of Populus tremula (European Aspen) still attached and with bark, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), on dead bark of Populus tremula, especially on fallen or hanging branches 1-3cm thick, less often on fallen trunks, usually "on branches with intact outer, secondary bark, when occurring on the inner, primary bark tending to be more effuse", (Eriksson), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8.5-10.5 x 3-4 um, cylindric, slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-45 x 5-8 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection, some with secondary septa; CYSTIDIA: gloeocystidia in hymenium up to 90 x 10-20 um, bladder-like to clavate, sulfo-positive; DENDROHYPHIDIA "strongly branched, on the surface of the hymenium (difficult to observe)"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-3 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 9-12 x 2.5-4 um, cylindric, suballantoid, smooth, colorless, thin-walled, light red in spore print; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50 x 5-6 um, "narrowly clavate with prolonged, intertwined bases", with clamp connection, "old basidia sometimes with adventitious septa"; CYSTIDIA: conspicuous sulfocystidia, total length reaching 100 um, width 15-25 um, bladder-like with a stem-like part of varying length, "with granular contents with a strong reaction to sulfovanillin and sulfobenzaldehyde", "hymenial sulfocystidia more or less tube-like", 5-10 um wide, "some of them pointed and then projecting beyond the dendrohyphidia"; DENDROHYPHIDIA 1-2 um wide, richly branched, "covering the hymenium, visible to the naked eye as a white pruina"; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae about 3 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "densely interwoven in an interhyphal matrix", subiculum of varying thickness, thickest in the center of the fruitbody (often more than 0.1cm thick), (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  presumably referring to polygonal pattern created by fruiting body
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Eriksson(5), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
286
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora pseudopini  Weresub & I.A.S. Gibson^  Canad. J. Bot. 38: 863. 1960
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on pine, 2) a fruitbody that is cream to pinkish or brownish or brownish purple, lighter and fringed / radially fingered toward the margin, the surface with umbos at various points, 3) spores that are cylindric to almost kidney-shaped, 4) cystidia of 2 types: thick-walled encrusted and thin-walled, and 5) often individual brown-walled hyphae traversing a colored area.^ | The description is derived from Weresub(2). RANGE ^Peniophora pseudopini has been found in BC, OR, AB, MB, NT, ON, PQ, MA, ME, NH, NY, PA, and WI, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  round or confluent to somewhat spread out but not broadly so, "typically distinctly umbonate at one or several points, to irregularly tuberculate" to convoluted brain-like, often raised or reflexed when old, texture soft-ceraceous [waxy] to subindurated [somewhat hardened] or tough; "cream or rose-tan or flesh, to rosy brown to brown, to dusky or brownish purple, generally darkest in color centrally, particularly at umbos, usually abruptly lighter toward edge", rarely concolorous throughout; more or less pruinose; margin of actively growing fruiting body "typically white fimbriate, often with pronounced radial fingering", when old still fingered but lacking fimbriation or subvernicose [appearing somewhat varnish-like], or abruptly entire, raised or downcurved and incurved
HABITAT  on pine, rarely other conifers, usually attached dead branches or dead saplings^, (Weresub), on bark of dead branches; fallen limbs; bark of dead saplings; associated with a white rot; associated with red heartwood stain in mature Pinus contorta [Lodgepole Pine]; on Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5.5)6-7.2(7.7) x (1.7)2.2(2.5) um, cylindric, straight to almost kidney-shaped^; BASIDIA about 4.5-5.5 um broad at apex, flexuous-clavate; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) "abundant to rare, projecting or not; when mature, wall of stalk thin, emphasized, or thickened, swollen sometimes to the point of capillarity of the lumen; where brown hyphae frequent, sometimes arising from these with brown stalks; full length as much as 60 um though frequently shorter, particularly in the hymenium; apex sometimes capped only with a scatter of crystals but characteristically heavily encrusted, from 8 x 5.5 um to as much as 40 x 15 um", 2) gloeocystidia generally abundant, but varying from rare, "observed throughout the context and in the hymenium, but typically and most regularly in the upper subicular, transition, and lower subhymenial areas", variable in shape, "most typically strongly vesiculose to globoid", on narrowed stem, "with or without a hyphal rostrum", variable also in size of expanded part: up to 50 um long (averaging 25 um), up to 20 um or more wide but generally 10-15 um wide; IN SECTION, either colorless or browned "in zones (a) in the basal part of the subiculum or (b) from the transition area halfway or fully into the hymenium or in patches throughout the context, brownish due either to a deposit between hyphae or an impregnation of the walls or cytoplasmic content of the hyphae", context depth (less hymenium) typically 175-350 um, subiculum "typically looking as if hyphae embedded in a matrix, composed of clearly parallel and mainly horizontal hyphae" (in radial section), transition area more or less gradual, HYPHAE 3.5-7 um wide (occasionally up to 9.5 um), "with walls only slightly thickened or swollen to as much as 3 um in width", subhymenial hyphae "usually with walls considerably narrower than those of the subiculum" "where hyphal outlines may become indefinite through gelatinization, erosion, or cross-striation", most hyphae with colorless walls except in darker-colored patches, but individual brown-walled hyphae traversing a predominantly colorless area, with swollen, attenuate, or contorted or dichotomously branched tips in subhymenium or hymenium, when present, are strongly diagnostic of this taxon
NAME ORIGIN  means 'false [Peniophora] pini'
SIMILAR  Peniophora pini of eastern North America differs microscopically: brown-walled hyphae and tips are not seen traversing colorless areas; and vesiculose gloeocystidia (over 12 um wide and 2:1 in ratio of width to length) may be rare to absent (subsp. duplex), or radial section with distinct subiculum as in pseudopini but of mainly interwoven rather than parallel hyphae, these separable, brittle, often exceeding 7 um wide with walls typically greatly swollen, sometimes to as much as 4.5 um in width (as opposed to hyphae that rarely exceed 7 um, with walls only slightly thickened or to as much as 3 um in width), (subsp. pini), (Weresub).
SOURCES  Weresub(2), Ginns(5)
287
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora rufa  (Fr.) Boidin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 74: 443. 1959;  == Thelephora rufa  Fr.;  Stereum rufum  (Fr.) Fr.;  Cryptochaete rufa  (Fr.) P. Karst.;  Tubercularia pezizoidea  Schwein.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  red tree brain
NOTES  Peniophora rufa may be recognized on sight by 1) occurrence on fallen aspen and other Populus limbs and logs, and 2) small vinaceous to red pruinose fruitbodies with the surface gyrosely wrinkled. Microscopic characters include 3) spores that are suballantoid, smooth, colorless, and white to pale red in spore print, 4) cystidia of 2 types: apically encrusted cystidia with the basal part thin-walled, and sulfo-positive gloeocystidia with granular contents, thick walls, and often an outer layer of crystals, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae densely branched and intertwined, with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Peniophora rufa has been found in BC, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, NT, ON, PE, PQ, SK, YT, AK, AZ, CO, IA, MA, ME, MI, MN, MT, ND, NE, NH, NM, NY, PA, VT, WI, and WY, (Ginns). Its distribution includes NF to MA and westward to ND and CO, (Burt). It occurs in Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson). It is reported from WA by Andrew Parker, pers. comm.
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached], wart-like, round in outline, normally not confluent, mostly 0.3-1cm across, about 0.1cm thick, consistency firm, when dry hard; red to reddish brown, when mature with whitish pruina; irregularly tuberculate; margin in most cases undifferentiated but "when growing on secondary bark a white margin may be seen in fruitbodies still growing radially"; in section whitish except for red spore-bearing layer^, (Eriksson), 0.5-1cm wide, wart-like, single or laterally fused, with free margin, without stem, bursts out from bark, convex to flat, becoming coarsely wrinkled, consistency waxy to cartilaginous; red to purple-brown, often with grayish bloom; smooth, (Lincoff), 0.2-0.4cm across, bursting out from the bark, coriaceous-fleshy, verruciform, plicate-tuberculose, peltate, the margin free all round; vinaceous-brown to hematite-red; often grayish pruinose, underside bald, (Burt)
HABITAT  dead branches; slash; associated with a white rot^, on Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), P. grandidentata (Bigtooth Aspen), P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Salix sp. (Willow), (Ginns), on dead twigs and branches of Quaking Aspen and other poplars, March to December, sometimes overwinters, (Lincoff), scattered or gregarious on dead fallen Populus tremuloides, March to December, (Burt), on branches of Populus tremula (European Aspen) on ground in dry habitats (Eriksson for Scandinavia)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9 x 2.5-3 um, suballantoid, spore print pale red^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50 x 5-6 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection, "basal part prolonged and interwoven", CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) numerous, small, apically encrusted cystidia, the encrusted part 10-12 x 5-6 um, the basal part thin-walled, 2) sulfocystidia "of varying size, generally large, reaching a length of 200 um" and a width of 20-25 um, with granular contents, thick gelatinous walls, and often an outer layer of granular crystals, "larger cystidia emanating like pseudocystidia from the subicular layer", "with the thickening of the subhymenium, smaller sulfocystidia with thinner walls appear"; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, densely branched and intertwined, hyphae next to the substrate 3-4 um wide, brown, and not swelling in KOH, those of the main part of the fruitbody colorless, swelling more or less, 5-8 um wide or even more, "often with a grainy layer of crystals on the surface", hymenial hyphae 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, not swelling, (Eriksson), SPORES 6-8.5 x 1.5-2 um, cylindric, curved, smooth, colorless, GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, spore deposit white, (Lincoff), spores 6-8 x 1.5-2 um, "even, curved", deposit white; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 50-90 x 7-10 um, flexuous [wavy], "scattered in or near the hymenium but not protruding"; hymenium 1000-2000 um thick at center, 600-800 um thick in marginal part, composed of ascending, loosely interwoven, encrusted, colorless hyphae 4-4.5 um wide over the encrustation, (Burt) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'red'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(5), Burt(2) (as Stereum rufum), Lincoff(2)*, Ginns(5)
288
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora septentrionalis  Laurila^  Ann. Bot. Soc. Zool.-Bot. Fenn. "Vanamo" 10(4): 10. 1939
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifers, 2) pinkish or reddish color with a conspicuous white margin, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, and colorless, 4) a pale red spore print, 5) cystidia of 2 types: a) thick-walled encrusted metuloids, and b) elongated thin-walled sulfo-positive gloeocystidia, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Peniophora septentrionalis has been found in BC, AB, NF, NS, NT, ON, PQ, SK, and CO, (Ginns), as well as Finland, Sweden, and the USSR, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  0.01-0.04cm thick, resupinate, adnate [firmly attached] but loosening from the margin, orbicular [circular], then confluent and irregularly effused; when young rose-red to light grayish red, fading in herbarium, when older gray-violaceous and finally gray-brown; "at first smooth, then more or less tuberculate or with irregular ridges"; sterile margin of growing specimens 0.1-0.2cm wide, white, finely fimbriate [fringed], "disappearing in older, rolled back specimens"^, (Eriksson), at first small, orbicular [circular], and remaining so or coalescing and spreading over large areas, at first adherent, later often loosening at margin; when fresh pinkish or reddish, fading on drying to pinkish gray or violaceous, or brownish gray; "smooth or with slightly raised ridges or knobs"; "the margin usually white and conspicuous", (Nobles)
HABITAT  fruiting bodies typically on bark of fallen branches; logs; associated with a white rot^; causes "a red heart rot in pines; commonly isolated from hail wounds; commonly enters trunk wounds"; causing decay in Picea glauca (White Spruce); causes a minor trunk rot in Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), P. engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce) and P. mariana (Black Spruce), also on A. balsamea (Balsam Fir), Picea rubens (Red Spruce), Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns), on bark of trunks and branches of fallen trees of Picea abies (Norway Spruce), (Eriksson for Scandinavia)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-8 x 2-2.5 um, allantoid, smooth, colorless, thin-walled, spore print pale red^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50 x 5-6 um, subcylindric or subclavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) thin-walled, acute hymenial cystidia that become encrusted and develop into strongly encrusted metuloids with the encrusted part 20-30 x 7-12 um, 2) thin-walled sulfocystidia, 60-120 x 7-10 um, "varying in number but always present"; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, young growing hyphae thin-walled and colorless, "older ones with thickened walls, more or less pigmented brown"; thickening subhymenium "composed of densely united, vertically arranged hyphae and cystidia, in older fruitbodies stratified"; subicular layer "well developed, composed of mainly horizontal hyphae, next to the substrate and to the subhymenium with dark brown pigmentation, less in the middle part of the subiculum" which in young fruitbodies is almost colorless, (Eriksson), SPORES 7.0-10.5 x 2.5-2.8(3.5) um, cylindric, slightly curved, smooth, colorless, minutely apiculate; BASIDIA 4-spored, 4.9-6.3 um wide, long, slender, flexuous [wavy], with clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) numerous throughout vertical layer, (23.0)35.0-70.0 x 7.7-15.6 um, "at first thin-walled, pointed, with contents uniformly stained, the walls increasing in thickness until lumen is almost obliterated, colorless except for those cystidia or bases of cystidia in the brown layer", 2) gloeocystidia "fairly numerous in hymenium, frequently extending through whole vertical layer", 49.0-84.0 x 6.3-7.7 um, long and flexuous [wavy] with obtuse apex, "thin-walled, the contents deeply stained, with oily inclusions"; IN SECTION, 268-320 um, consisting of broad basal layer, 160-260 um, in which hyphae are horizontally arranged, brown in a zone up to 20 um wide next to the substrate, colorless elsewhere, "and a layer 47-100 um wide in which hyphae are vertically arranged, brown in transition zone up to 20 um wide, becoming paler toward the hymenium"; HYPHAE nodose-septate, those in the horizontal layer 2.8-4.2 um wide, "densely interwoven but the individual hyphae remaining distinct", at first thin-walled, with contents stained in phloxine, "the majority soon empty, with walls more or less thickened, so that in section the horizontal layer is mainly unstained, occasionally traversed by a thin-walled hypha with stained contents", in brown zone next to substrate and in transition zone between horizontal and vertical layers "hyphae thick-walled, brown, cemented to form a compact, parenchyma-like layer with a continuous zone of parallel, brown hyphal tips at base of basidia", (Nobles)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'northern' after the seven bright stars of "Septentriones", the big dipper
SIMILAR  Peniophora pithya has a darker, more firmly attached fruitbody, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Nobles(2), Eriksson(5), Ginns(5)
289
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora unica  H.S. Jacks. & Dearden^  Canad. J. Res., C, 27: 148. 1949
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Among Peniophora species Peniophora unica is characterized by 1) the wax-like character, 2) large cystidia and 3) minute spores, (Jackson). Other features include 4) effused growth on subalpine fir, 5) a white to cream buff fruitbody that is thin, firmly attached, and pruinose or minutely bristly, 6) spores that are smooth and inamyloid, 7) cystidia that are obclavate or cylindric, when young thin-walled, often with slight encrustation, becoming thick-walled, and 8) hyphae with clamp connections.^ | The description is derived from Jackson(1). RANGE ^Peniophora unica was described from BC and is known only from the type specimen.
FRUITING BODY  widely effused [spread out on substrate], ceraceous [waxy], thin (0.008-0.015cm), adnate [firmly attached to substrate]; white to cream buff; surface pruinose or minutely hispid [bristly] due to projecting cystidia, fruitbody dries to a varnish-like film
HABITAT  on wood of Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir)
