MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3-3.5 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic, laterally flattened with minute apiculus, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-20 x 3-4 um, clavate to cylindric, with slender, nearly straight sterigmata; CYSTIDIA 55-75 x 12-16 um, broadly obclavate or subcylindric, rarely fusiform, tapering to a narrow, obtuse apex, when young thin-walled and often with slight encrustation at apex, becoming thick-walled and devoid of contents, often with 1 to 4 pseudosepta at maturity, embedded in the upper layer of the substrate or extending one third to one half of length above hymenium; "subiculum of two layers of about equal thickness, the lower layer made up of loosely interwoven, nodulose hyphae, 2-3 um in diameter, the upper layer somewhat obscure but made up of closely compacted upright hyphae, all hyphae with clamps"
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin 'unicus' meaning 'only, sole, single'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Jackson(1), Ginns(5)
290
FAMILY  Peniophoraceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophora violaceolivida  (Sommerf.) Massee^  J. Linn. Soc. Bot. 25: 152. 1890;  == Thelephora violaceolivida  Sommerf.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, especially Populus and Salix, 2) a blue-violet to gray-violet or reddish gray fruitbody with a waxy consistency, the surface smooth to tuberculate, and the margin indeterminate or narrow, white, and finely fringed, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia of two types, a) thin-walled, awl-shaped cystidia that become encrusted and thicker walled, and b) thin-walled to slightly thick-walled sulfo-positive gloeocystidia, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^It has been found in ID, AB, NS, ON, PQ, AK, AZ, CA, CO, DC, GA, IL, LA, MA, MD, MI, MN, NC, NJ, NY, VT, and WI, (Ginns). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia and collections from WA and MS at the University of Washington. It has been found also in Europe including Switzerland, and Asia, (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, southern, central, and eastern Europe, and north Asia, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  forming thin patches several centimeters to decimeters across, and about 0.03cm thick, resupinate, attached tightly, consistency "waxlike and tough, when dry crustose and brittle"; blue-violet to gray-violet, when dry ocher-gray with slight lilac tint; smooth to tuberculate, when dry rimose-areolate [cracked]; margin "distinctly bounded and appressed, in part also somewhat filamentous"^, (Breitenbach), thin (seldom more than 0.02cm), resupinate, adnate [firmly attached]; grayish with a varying tint of reddish or violaceous, "in wet weather darker, more bluish", young fruitbodies fading in herbarium to pale ochraceous gray, "old sterile fruitbodies brownish gray"; "sometimes quite smooth but commonly more or less tuberculate", in dry weather cracking into small polygons; margin indeterminate, or with a narrow, white, finely fringed (under lens) periphery, (Eriksson), spore deposit pale pink (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on rotting wood; barkless branches; fallen limbs; slash; dead stem; associated with a white rot^, on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Baccharis, Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Ligustrum (privet), Liquidambar (sweetgum), Ostrya (hop hornbeam), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja, (Ginns), on dead hardwood, commonly on Populus (poplar) and Salix (willow), on fallen and standing trunks and fallen and attached branches, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), on dead, still attached or fallen branches and smaller trunks of hardwoods, especially Salix and Populus, (Eriksson), hardwoods, shrubs including Fuchsia and bramble; all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-9 x 2.5-3 um, cylindric, some rather curved, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-35 x 2.5-4.5 um, cylindric, some sinuous, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) lamprocystidia 30-50 x 7-13 um, conic to cylindric, upper half strongly encrusted, 2) sulfo-positive gloeocystidia 40-50 x 9-12 um, clavate to ventricose, slightly thick-walled; HYPHAE monomitic 1-2.5 um wide, colorless to brownish, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 7.5-9 x 3 um, allantoid, colorless, thin-walled, spore print pale red; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-40 x 5-6 um, subcylindric-subclavate, with basal clamp connection, old basidia sometimes septate; CYSTIDIA of two types: 1) thin-walled, subulate [awl-shaped], hymenial cystidia that develop into encrusted metuloids with the encrusted part 15-25 x 6-9 um, varying in number, few to frequent, 2) thin-walled sulfocystidia, at first subclavate, then oblong, fusiform to subcylindric, filled with granular protoplasm, and varying in length with thickness of fruitbody (up to 75 um), width in most cases about 10 um, but up to 15 um; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, young hyphae thin-walled, colorless, "older hyphae with brown thickened walls"; thickening subhymenium "composed of densely united, vertical hyphae and cystidia", often stratified in 2 or 3 layers; subiculum "usually very thin or almost lacking but sometimes a distinct basal layer can be seen", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'violaceous-livid' referring to color of fruitbody
SIMILAR  Peniophora nuda can be similar in young states, but its "first hymenial layer is provided with numerous rounded gloeocystidia" while in P. violaceolivida "all gloeocystidia are narrower and all of about the same shape": a taxon that is frequent in eastern Canada "agrees in most respects with P. violaceolivida but the gloeocystidia are often wider than in European material, thus intermediate to P. nuda" [Latin names in italics], (Eriksson). See also SIMILAR section of Peniophora decorticans.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Eriksson(5), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
291
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophorella guttulifera  (P. Karst.) K.H. Larss.^  Mycol. Res. 111(2): 192. 2007;  == Hyphoderma guttuliferum  (P. Karst.) Donk;  == Gloeocystidium guttuliferum  P. Karst.;  Peniophora guttulifera  (P. Karst.) Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) tightly attached patches that are whitish or cream at first, becoming darker and finally ochraceous, the surface with watery droplets when fresh, and when dry globules visible under 50x lens (on the cystidia), 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) blunt-cylindric cystidia that are crystal-encrusted and bear an apical globule, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Peniophorella guttulifera has been found in BC, OR, MB, ON, AL, AZ, AR, IL, LA, ME, MI, MN, NH, NJ, NY, OH, and VT, (Ginns), as well as Finland and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin, adnate [tightly attached]; whitish or cream at first, when old darker, and finally ochraceous; when fresh small watery droplets are visible on the surface, in the dry fruitbody under a 50x lens, there are "conspicuous cystidia with an easily visible, apical, rounded, excreted globule"; margin "varying but usually indeterminate"^, (Eriksson), fruitbodies 2-5cm long, 1-2.5cm wide, "more or less studded with minute, hard, globular masses of resinous color which are visible under a lens but dissolve and disappear in aqueous mounts", (Burt)
HABITAT  on decayed barkless hardwood^, (Eriksson); on hardwood and conifer wood; Acer negundo (Boxelder), A. saccharum (Sugar Maple), Alnus oblongifolia (Arizona alder), Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Platanus wrightii (Arizona Sycamore), Populus grandidentata (Bigtooth Aspen), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Quercus arizonica (Arizona White Oak), Salix sp. (willow); associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 9-12 x 3-4 um, allantoid, inamyloid, thin-walled, containing oil droplets or oily inclusions^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-30 x 5-6 um, subclavate to almost cylindric, slightly constricted or sinuous, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA conspicuous, 60-80 x 10-20 um, "mostly cylindric, apically blunt, with thickened walls, in the upper part encrusted with doublepyramidic crystals and with an apical globule of non-crystalline, yellowish or brownish matter"; HYPHAE monomitic 3-4(5) um wide, thin-walled, richly branched, with clamp connections at all septa, (Eriksson), SPORES 7-10 x 3-4.5 um, even, in a spore collection white, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing a droplet', referring to the cystidia
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as Hyphoderma guttuliferum), Burt(7) (as Peniophora guttulifera), Ginns(5) (as Hyphoderma guttuliferum)
292
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophorella pallida  (Bres.) K.H. Larss.^  Mycol. Res. 111(2): 192. 2007;  Hyphoderma pallidum  (Bres.) Donk;  == Corticium pallidum  Bres.;  Corticium ochrofarctum  Burt;  Corticium tsugae  Burt;  Hyphoderma tsugae  (Burt) J. Erikss. & A. Strid
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) flat, waxy growth on wood, mostly coniferous, 2) color that is whitish maturing to ochraceous, pale brown or reddish brown, the surface porose when dry, dotted by reddish brown matter under a 50x lens, 3) allantoid or sometimes elliptic spores that smooth and inamyloid, with oily inclusions, 4) acute, fusiform cystidia that project, 5) capitate hyphal ends in the hymenium and context that are apically surrounded by excreted, reddish brown matter, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system with small clamp connections.^ | Ginns(5) notes that de Vries found some specimens to have elliptic as well as allantoid spores, and therefore de Vries placed H. tsugae (distinguished by spore shape) in synonymy. RANGE ^Peniophorella pallida has been found in BC, ID, ON, PQ, AZ, FL, NC, NH, NM, and TN, (Ginns). It has also been found in Denmark and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, mostly less than 0.01cm, closely adnate [tightly attached], ceraceous [waxy] when alive and moist; whitish maturing ochraceous to pale brownish or pale reddish brown; porose when dry, dotted by reddish brown excreted matter under 50x lens^, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed barkless wood, mostly of conifers but also of hardwoods^, (Eriksson); on bark; trunk; tree base; stump; log; Abies (fir), Pinus (pine), Picea (spruce), Juniperus (juniper), Tsuga (hemlock), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Rubus spectabilis (salmonberry), associated with a white rot, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9(10) x 2.5-3.5(4) um, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, with oily inclusions in protoplasm^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 22-25(30) x 5-6 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA projecting, 50-60(90) x 6-8 um, fusiform, acute, thin-walled, homogeneous, also cystidia-like capitate HYPHAL ENDS in the hymenium and context, "apically surrounded by excreted, reddish brown matter, at first as a rounded body, at last irregular and in the slides usually crushed to pieces"; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 3-4 um wide, closely interwoven, richly branched, thin-walled, with small clamp connections at all septa; on small branches from the hyphae there are small bladder-like echinulate cells about 10 x 5 um, which "may be present but difficult to observe", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pale'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as Hyphoderma pallidum), Ginns(5) (as Hyphoderma pallidum), Buczacki(1)* (as Hyphoderma pallidum)
293
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophorella praetermissa  (P. Karst.) K.H. Larss.^  Mycol. Res. 111(2): 192. 2007;  Hyphoderma praetermissum  (P. Karst.)  J. Erikss. & A. Strid  Cort. N. Europe 3: 505. 1975;  == Corticium praetermissum  P. Karst.;  Peniophora albugo  Burt;  Peniophora pertenuis  (P. Karst.) Burt;  Peniophora taxodii  Burt;  Peniophora tenuis  (Pat.) Massee sensu Aucts.;  Hyphoderma tenue  (Pat.) Donk sensu Aucts.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) thin, soft, waxy patches that are whitish, and smooth to slightly bumpy, 3) spores that are narrowly elliptic or suballantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, with numerous oil droplets or with grainy oil contents, 4) cystidial organs of three types: a) cystidia that are generally more or less capitate but sometimes cylindric, apically rounded, projecting, usually naked but when intact apically encrusted with crystals or covered with amorphous matter, b) gloeocystidia that are enclosed, mostly fusiform, always tapering to the apex, with yellowish, homogeneous contents, and c) stephanocysts that are about 10-12 um wide, with rounded dense homogeneous protoplasm, surrounded by a whorl of small teeth, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, usually with clamp connections.^ | Eriksson & Strid say that H. praetermissum in the sense they describe is a complex rather than a single species, (Eriksson(3)). RANGE ^Peniophorella praetermissa has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, ON, PQ, AZ, CO, CT, DC, FL, IA, IL, LA, MA, MD, MI, MN, MS, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, TX, VA, and WI, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach) and Scandinavia (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin, soft, wax-like patches several centimeters across, loosely attached; "gray-whitish, light ocherish when old and dry"; "smooth to slightly tuberculate"; "distinctly bounded to thinning out at the margin"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, mostly thin (about 0.1cm), adnate [tightly attached], ceraceous [waxy] when alive and wet; watery white when alive or wet, in herbarium white, creamish, argillaceous, or in old states ochroleucous; smooth; margin normally not especially differentiated, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on rotten wood and bark of hardwoods and conifers; summer to fall^, (Breitenbach), on wood and bark of all kinds of trees, (Eriksson), on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Cornus (dogwood), Juniperus (juniper), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Prunus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Taxodium (baldcypress), Thuja (red-cedar); decaying wood and bark; "dead branches; dead, fallen trees; log; trail stairway"; poles, stakes; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-10 x 3.5-4.5 um, "cylindric-oval, some flattened or concave on one side, smooth", inamyloid, colorless, with droplets or granular contents^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-28 x 6.5-7.5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 3 types: 1) exserted [projecting] cystidia 30-70 x 7-9 um, cylindric to somewhat capitate, some encrusted at the tips, or according to the literature surrounded by amorphous material, 2) cystidia imbedded in hymenium, 60-90 x 8-14, +/- fusiform, sulfo-negative, and 3) stephanocysts enclosed in hymenium, pyriform [pear-shaped], "some with toothed equatorial zone" that is difficult to see; HYPHAE monomitic up to 7 um wide, septa usually with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 8-11 x 4-5 um, narrowly elliptic or suballantoid, "adaxial side often but not always somewhat concave", inamyloid, thin-walled, with numerous oil droplets or with grainy oil contents; BASIDIA 22-28 x 6-7 um, "subclavate, sometimes constricted or slightly sinuous", "with normally 4 sterigmata and with basal clamp"; CYSTIDIAL ORGANS of three types: 1) cystidia generally more or less capitate but sometimes cylindric, apically rounded, 10-90 x 6-10 um, the apical head 4-10 um wide, neck 3-5 um wide, these cystidia "projecting and always present but varying in number, sometimes few or rare", "in the slides as a rule naked but when intact apically encrusted with crystals or covered with excreted, amorphous matter", 2) gloeocystidia, 50-100 x 8-12 um, enclosed, always frequent, mostly fusiform, always tapering to the apex, thin-walled, with yellowish, homogeneous contents, and 3) stephanocysts about 10-12 um wide, "rounded bladders with dense homogeneous protoplasm, surrounded by a whorl of small teeth", "very variable in number", in some slides not found at all, in others numerous and easily found; HYPHAE monomitic about 3-4 um, thin-walled, "forming a very dense context in the subhymenial part, as a rule looser next to the substrate but with great variation", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as Hyphoderma praetermissum), Breitenbach(2)* (as Hyphoderma praetermissum), Ginns(5) (as Hyphoderma praetermissum)
294
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peniophorella pubera  (Fr.) P. Karst.^  Bidr. Kdnn. Finl. Nat. Folk 48: 427. 1889;  Hyphoderma puberum  (Fr.) Wallr.;  == Thelephora pubera  Fr.;  Peniophora pubera  (Fr.) Sacc.;  Phlebia pubera  (Fr.) M.P. Christ.;  Peniophora tenuissima  Peck;  Peniophora tenella  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood and timber, 2) waxy patches that are attached tightly, colored white to cream-ocher, and velvety under 50x lens from cystidia, the margin thinning out or abrupt, 3) spores that are nearly cylindric to nearly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, with droplets or granular contents, 4) basidia narrowly that are clavate and often somewhat constricted, 5) strongly encrusted cystidia that are fusiform and projecting, 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Peniophorella pubera has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AL, AZ, CO, DC, FL, IL, KY, LA, MA, MD, MI, MN, MO, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, RI, VA, and WI, (Ginns). It has also been found in Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Scandinavia (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin, membranous, soft, wax-like patches several centimeters across, attached tightly; white to cream-ocherish; dull, smooth; margin diffuse^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, up to 0.03cm thick, ceraceous [waxy], adnate [tightly attached]; at first whitish, when mature "argillaceous, ochraceous, or isabellinous"; under 50 x lens velvety from numerous projecting cystidia, "porose when young and dry, then totally continuous; margin mostly thinning out, in other cases abrupt or in some fruitbodies finely fibrillose under the lens (50 x)", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead wood of hardwoods, according to the literature more rarely also on conifer wood; summer-fall^, (Breitenbach), on decayed, barkless wood of hardwoods or less often on bark, sometimes on conifers, (Eriksson), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Arbutus (madrone), Betula (birch), Juglans cinerea (Butternut), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar); bark; dead wood; "logs and limbs; test stakes; house sills; shingles", poles; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-9 x 3.5-4.5 um, cylindric-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets or granular contents^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-35 x 7-10 um, narrowly clavate, suburniform, with basal clamp connection, sometimes also with secondary septa; LAMPROCYSTIDIA common, 80-100 x 10-17 um, narrowly fusiform, thick-walled, strongly encrusted; gloeocystidia-like LEPTOCYSTIDIA and SPHAEROCYSTS "are found only rarely in certain collections"; HYPHAE monomitic 2.5-5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 7-10 x 3.5-5 um, subcylindric or narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, with oily inclusions, site of nucleus often visible; BASIDIA 4-spored, 22-30 x 5-6 um, "subclavate to clavate, often somewhat constricted", with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 1 to 3 types: 1) numerous, 60-130(200) x (9)12-18 um, tapering to an acute apex, "strongly projecting but with time enclosed in the subhymenial layer, starting in the basidial level in the hymenium" and at first thin-walled and naked, "later with much thickened walls and strongly encrusted", 2) in most specimens no other cystidia but in some there are also enclosed, thin-walled gloeocystidia, 30-60 x 7-10 um, 3) stephanocysts [structure that is typically bicellular with basal cell cup-like and terminal cell spherical] present in cultured media; HYPHAE monomitic 3-4 um wide, richly branched, thin-walled, with clamp connections at all septa, context often rather loose next to the wood but otherwise "densely united into an almost pseudoparenchymatic structure", especially in the subhymenium "which in mature specimens forms the major part of the section", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'downy'
SIMILAR  Hyphoderma species have different cystidia and lack the dense Phlebia-like context that gives the fruitbodies a waxy consistency and makes them more Phlebia-like in outward appearance, (Eriksson). In Phlebia species, "the basidia are cylindric-clavate and not suburniform", (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as Hyphoderma puberum), Breitenbach(2)* (as Hyphoderma puberum), Ginns(5) (as Hyphoderma puberum), Buczacki(1)*
295
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phaeophlebiopsis ravenelii  (Cooke) Zmitr.,^  Folia Cryptogamica Petropolitana (Sankt-Peterburg) 6: 95. 2018;  Phlebiopsis ravenelii  (Cooke) Hjortstam  Windahlia 17: 58. 1987;  == Peniophora ravenelii  Cooke;  Phanerochaete ravenelii  (Cooke) Burds.;  Peniophora roumeguerii  (Bres.) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Metulodontia roumeguerii  (Bres.) Parmasto;  Phlebiopsis roumeguerii  (Bres.) Julich & Stalpers;  Peniophora stratosa  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) a pale whitish or grayish fruitbody with the margin distinct but not fringed, 3) spores that are oblong to narrowly elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) cystidia that are conic, encrusted in the apical part which is also filled with a crystalline matter, leaving a narrow lumen, the basal part with somewhat thickened walls, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae interwoven and mainly vertical, the subhymenium stratified and the subiculum barely discernible.^ | The description, derived from Eriksson(6), is for Phlebiopsis roumeguerii (Bres.) Julich & Stalpers, given by Ginns(5) as a synonym. (Burt(7) distinguished them, saying the P. roumeguerii "is similar in aspect but becomes much thicker and has longer, slenderer, and more taper-pointed cystidia and is more distinctly layered"). RANGE ^Phaeophlebiopsis ravenelii has been found in BC, OR, ID, AL, AR, CA, CO, DC, FL, GA, LA, MN, MO, MT, PA, and SC, (Ginns), as well as Mexico, Guam, and Japan, (Burt). It is quite common in the Mediterranean area of Europe (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached], effused [spread out] and sometimes large, varying in thickness to 0.1cm or more; pale whitish or grayish; when old densely cracked; margin determinate [distinct], not fimbriate [not fringed]^, (Eriksson), 2-8cm long, 1-3cm wide, broadly effused, adnate, thin (in section 0.01-0.03cm), small pieces separable when moistened; "becoming pale pinkish buff to pinkish buff in the herbarium, and somewhat cracked, the margin thinning out", (Burt), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed hardwood^, (Eriksson), on bark and wood of decaying logs of Quercus (oak) and other hardwoods, (Burt), dead wood; bark; fallen branches; decaying logs; associated with a white rot; Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Carya (hickory), Crataegus (hawthorn), Diospyros (persimmon), Eucalyptus, Ligustrum (privet), Notholithocarpus (Tanoak), Picea (spruce), Quercus (oak), (Ginns), summer, fall, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5(6) x 2.5-3(3.5) um, oblong - narrowly elliptic, "adaxial side straight or slightly concave in the mature spores", smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-22(30) x 4-5 um, apically dilated, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA numerous, 50-70(90) x 10-15 um, conic, "encrusted in the apical part which is also filled with a crystalline matter, leaving a central capillary lumen", basal part bald with somewhat thickened walls; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4 um wide, "with thin walls in the hymenial part, otherwise, thicker, densely interwoven but the hyphal direction mainly vertical", subhymenium stratified, subiculum hardly discernible, (Eriksson), CYSTIDIA 30-40 x 12-18 um when deeply immersed, (or 30 x 8-10 um in the hymenium), heavily and coarsely encrusted, conic, with apex obtuse or barely acute, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  after H.W. Ravenel, who collected the type
SIMILAR  Phaeophlebiopsis ravenelii is distinguished from Phlebiopsis gigantea "in lacking subiculum, and having thinner walls in the base of the cystidia", (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(6) (as Phlebiopsis roumeguerii), Burt(7) (as Peniophora ravenelii), Ginns(5) (as Phlebiopsis ravenelii), Buczacki(1)* (as Phlebiopsis ravenelii)
296
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phanerochaete affinis  (Burt) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort. 84. 1968;  == Peniophora affinis  Burt;  Peniophora laevis  (Fr.) Burt in Peck sensu Burt 1902;  Phanerochaete laevis  (Fr.) J. Erikss. & Ryvarden sensu J. Eriksson & Ryvarden 1978;  Peniophora gilvidula  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) ochraceous fruitbodies, often with a grayish or even pink or orange tint, (often becoming red in 2% KOH), uneven to tuberculate or with radial ridges, the margin abrupt, concolorous or paler, varying but mostly fringed to fibrillose, and occasionally with rhizomorphs, the subiculum paler than the spore-bearing surface, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, with droplets, 4) cystidia that are numerous, most embedded but some projecting, narrowly cylindric with acute apex, encrusted in the apical half, and thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections, except in the subiculum where scattered clamp connections occur, sometimes 2 at a single septum.^ | The description is derived from that of Phanerochaete laevis (Pers.) Erikss. & Ryvarden for which Burdsall(5) and Breitenbach(2) give Phanerochaete affinis (Burt) Parmasto as a synonym. RANGE ^It has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NB, NS, ON, PE, PQ, AK, AL, AZ, CA, CT, IL, KY, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MT, NC, NE, NH, NJ, NY, SC, TN, TX, VT, and WI, (Ginns). It also occurs in Europe including Switzerland, in Asia, (Breitenbach), in Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, (Eriksson), and in Czechoslovakia, Estonia, France, Latvia, and Armenia, (Burdsall).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, +/- closely attached (detaches when dry), membranous patches up to 0.05cm thick and several centimeters across, consistency membranous, wax-like; gray-ocher, pink-ocher, to orange-ocher, also somewhat spotted with orange; "surface when fresh uneven to tuberculate", when dry +/- smooth and fissured; margin lighter in color to whitish, "slightly fringed to distinctly bounded", according to the literature also with rhizomorphs^, (Breitenbach), 0.03-0.05cm thick, resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached] "or at least gradually becoming detachable", membranaceous; at first light-colored, then turning darker, light to dark ochraceous, often with a grayish hue, many specimens in herbarium more or less flesh-colored or orange-colored, some even bright orange; "when fresh more or less tuberculate or with radial ridges", becoming smoother on drying, "dried old specimens often cracked, showing the white subiculum in the cracks"; "margin abrupt, varying but mostly fibrillose, sometimes with distinct rhizomorphs but generally without", (Eriksson), "broadly effused, loosely adherent", up to 0.035cm thick; spore-bearing surface usually grayish orange: 'greyish yellow' to 'greyish orange', occasionally as dark as 'light brown', often becoming red in 2% KOH; margin nearly colored as spore-bearing surface or paler, thinning slightly, fimbriate [fringed] to strongly fibrillose [also described as having a "fibrillose or cordonic margin"]; subiculum paler than spore-bearing surface, (Burdsall)
HABITAT  on decayed wood of all kinds^, especially Alnus (alder) and Betula (birch), (Eriksson), on dead wood of hardwoods still with bark, especially Fagus (beech); throughout the year, (Breitenbach), bark; slash and woody debris; barkless logs and limbs; causing a white rot; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carpinus (hornbeam), Castanea (chestnut), Cornus (dogwood), Corylus (hazel), Crataegus (hawthorn), Fagus (beech), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Ulmus (elm), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6(7.5) x 2.5(3.5) um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-38 x 4.5 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA: lamprocystidia cylindric, "pointed, thick-walled, strongly incrusted but some smooth apically, thin-walled and smooth when young", 40-75 x 4-7.5 um; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-6 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, without clamp connections, but hyphae of subiculum thin-walled and scattered septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 4.5-6 x 2.5 um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, with one or more oil droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-35 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA numerous, 40-65 x 5-7 um, projecting 15-30 um, narrowly cylindric and tapering to acute apex, at first thin-walled and unencrusted, developing thicker walls and encrustation (in apical half, but under microscope top often naked as encrustation falls off easily), very young cystidia containing many oil droplets; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-5 um wide, thin-walled or in the subiculum walls slightly thickened, clamp connections absent in hymenium and subhymenium but in the subiculum clamp connections often found, sometimes 2 together at one septum, "subhymenial hyphae richly and irregularly branched and densely united", subicular hyphae straight, sparsely branched and mainly horizontally arranged; "in mature specimens crystals richly attached to the hyphae"; in the reddish or orange specimens a yellow substance "occurs between the hyphal elements of the subhymenium and in the hymenium", (Eriksson), SPORES 5-7 x 2.5-3 um, narrowly elliptic to nearly cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-40(45) x 5-5.5 um, "clavate with a slight constriction below apex", colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata 3.5-4 um long; CYSTIDIA 60-80(100) x 6-8(10) um, mostly embedded but some projecting up to 25 um, heavily encrusted over distal 1/3 to 1/2 by colorless crystals, "in squash mounts crystals frequently breaking away leaving an apparently smooth cystidium, very young cystidia having only a fine granular coating", walls colorless, 1-2(2.5) um thick in middle and becoming thin-walled at apex and slightly thick-walled at base; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBHYMENIUM not well defined, a loose textura intricata, hyphae 2.5-4 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, simple-septate, "encrusted irregularly and lightly with small yellow granules that dissolve and turn red in KOH"; SUBICULUM a compact textura intricata, hyphae of lower subiculum 5-9 um wide, colorless, with walls up to 0.5-1(1.5) um thick, mostly simple-septate, "with scattered single and rare multiple clamp connections", smooth or encrusted with large colorless crystals, hyphae of upper subiculum 4-7 um wide, densely branched, slightly thick-walled, colorless, simple-septate, or rarely nodose-septate, "with regularly scattered yellow granules that dissolve and turn red in KOH", (Burdsall)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'related to, neighboring'
SIMILAR  Phanerochaete sordida and Phanerochaete velutina can be differentiated on the basis of the shape and number of cystidia and the structure of the subiculum hyphae, (Breitenbach). P. sordida and P. velutina have cystidia that are less narrow and less tapering than in P. affinis, (Eriksson). P. velutina may be similar and like P. affinis has a fibrillose or cordonic margin, but P. velutina 1) is tan to pale tan to brownish red to burgundy (often with a violet tint), whereas P. affinis is usually orange brown to brownish orange, 2) has cystidia mostly greater than 9 um wide, whereas those of P. affinis are up to 8 um wide, and 3) usually possesses white cordons, (Burdsall). P. sordida 1) lacks a fibrillose to cordonic margin, 2) is usually less orange than P. affinis, and 3) has a different subiculum: P. affinis has a more compact and somewhat agglutinated subiculum with less rigid-appearing hyphae, whereas P. sordida has a more lattice-like appearance, (Burdsall). |Cylindrobasidium laeve can be macroscopically similar, but is easy to separate microscopically, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Burdsall(5) (as Phanerochaete laevis) (colors in single quotation marks from 1967 edition of Kornerup(1)), Eriksson(5) (as Phanerochaete laevis), Breitenbach(2)* (as Phanerochaete laevis), Ginns(5)
297
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phanerochaete carnosa  (Burt) Parmasto^  Izv. Akad. Nauk Estonsk. SSR, Ser. Biol. 16: 388. 1967;  == Peniophora carnosa  Burt;  Peniophora firma  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on bark and wood of coniferous logs, 2) a yellowish fruitbody that is fleshy-membranous, firmly attached, the surface usually turning green to greenish black in KOH, the margin white or colored as the rest of the surface, sometimes reddish brown, usually fringed to fibrillose, the subiculum colored as the spore-bearing area or paler, 3) spores that are narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) abundant cystidia that are tapered or awl-shaped, projecting, smooth or with occasionally granules on apex, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae mostly encrusted with granules that dissolve in KOH, mostly without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Phanerochaete carnosa has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, AK, AZ, CA, CO, MA, ME, MI, MN, MT, NH, NM, NY, SD, and VT, (Ginns). It is common in Rocky Mountain forests (Burt). It also occurs in Russia (Burdsall).
FRUITING BODY  annual, effused [spread out] up to at least 20cm, up to 0.1cm thick, membranous, adherent; spore-bearing area continuous, 'light yellow', 'dull yellow', 'greyish yellow', to occasionally 'brownish yellow', usually becoming green to dark greenish black in KOH; surface smooth, sometimes cracked into small, angular blocks; margin up to 0.1cm wide, mostly fimbriate [fringed] to fibrillose, rarely cordonic, white or colored as the rest of the spore-bearing surface, sometimes dark reddish brown; subiculum colored as the spore-bearing area or paler, cordons usually poorly developed, colored as the spore-bearing area^, (Burdsall), 3-12cm long, 1.5-6cm wide, long and broadly effused, thick, adnate [firmly attached], fleshy-membranaceous; "barium-yellow to honey-yellow, of the same color within where cracked", (Burt), 0.02-0.08cm thick, membranaceous, hyphal strands absent; yellow; surface even, (Julich), "becoming widely effused, adnate"; yellow ocher to antimony yellow at margin, membranous but not readily separable from substrate; "margin fimbriate or rhizomorphic, rhizomorphs yellowish", (Gilbertson)
HABITAT  May to October, on bark and wood of coniferous logs^ such as Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Juniperus (juniper), and Larix (larch), rarely on hardwood species, (Burt), bark and wood; rotten wood; underside of prostrate rotten limb; logs; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Arctostaphylos, Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Robinia (locust), Thuja, Umbellularia, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6 x 2-3 um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-45 x 5-6.5 um, narrowly clavate, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata 3-5 um long; CYSTIDIA 40-60 x 4-6.5 um, tapered to apex or subulate [awl-shaped], (sometimes somewhat flexuous), thin-walled or rarely with thickened walls, "smooth or with scattered granules on apex", projecting 25 um beyond the hymenium, "mostly aseptate but with occasional secondary septa"; HYPHAE monomitic; SUBHYMENIUM a compact textura intricata-porrecta, "thickening, sometimes more or less layered due to interrupted growth", hyphae 3-4.5 um wide, thin-walled, colorless, "encrusted with yellow granules that dissolve in KOH", simple-septate, "with frequent and regular branching, often at nearly right angles"; SUBICULUM a textura intricata, hyphae 4-9 um wide, walls slightly thickened or up to 2 um thick, colorless with frequent branching in most specimens, "mostly simple-septate, multiple clamp connections rare", "mostly encrusted with fine granules that dissolve in KOH" and often with persistent colorless crystals, (Burdsall), SPORES 4-5 x 2-2.5 um, smooth, spore collection white; BASIDIA 4-spored; CYSTIDIA numerous in hymenial surface, 4 um wide at base, "protruding up to 30 um beyond the basidia", hair-like, not encrusted, tapered to a sharp tip, gloeocystidia absent; IN SECTION 400-700 um thick, colored like hymenium in thick sections but very thin sections colorless, "somewhat zoned, composed of a very broad hyphal layer bearing a hymenial layer 50-60 um thick", the hyphae colorless, (Burt), SPORES 4-5 x 2-2.5 um, narrowly elliptic; BASIDIA 25-45 x 4.5-6 um; CYSTIDIA abundant, 45-60 x 3-5 um, projecting, cylindric, thin-walled; hyphae 2-8 um wide, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, (Julich), SPORES 4-5.5 x 2-2.5 um, short-cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 5-6 um wide, clavate; CYSTIDIA abundant, projecting up to 20 um, 3-8 um wide, tapering to the tip, thin-walled, not encrusted, often septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-9 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, "simple-septate, with some simple and double clamp connections, these more numerous in the marginal strands", hyphae loosely arranged in lower subiculum, (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Burdsall(5) (colors in single quotation marks from 1967 edition of Kornerup(1)), Burt(7) (as Peniophora carnosa), Gilbertson(9), Julich(5), Ginns(5)
298
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phanerochaete chrysosporium  Burds.^  Mycotaxon 1: 124. 1974
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is cream to ochraceous, smooth, with the margin rather abrupt or up to 0.2cm wide, powdery, white, and non-rhizomorphic, and with the subiculum cottony and white, 3) spores that are cylindric to narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia that are protruding, arising at various levels of the subhymenium and subiculum, cylindric, obtuse at the apex, and thin-walled or with slight wall thickening, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae lacking clamp connections, 6) sometimes with oval to spherical chlamydospore-like thick-walled cells near the substrate.^ | Phanerochaete chrysosporium associated with an imperfect state Chrysosporium which is commonly isolated from wood chip piles, (Burdsall(3)). It causes substantial wood loss in chip piles and attempts have been made to harness its white rotting ability in a biomechanical pulping procedure, (Burdsall(5)). The anamorph is given as Sporotrichum pulverulentum Novobr. citing Burdsall 1981 in Ginns(5). RANGE ^Phanerochaete chrysosporium has been found in BC, NB, AZ, CA, GA, IL, MD, ME, MS, NY, and WI, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.025cm thick, broadly effused, indeterminate, membranous, "loosely attached or separable in small pieces"; 'yellowish white' to 'light brown'; moist when fresh, "smooth, continuous, not cracking"; margin rather abrupt or up to 0.2cm wide, "sterile, very thin, powdery or finely granular, irregular in outline, white, non-rhizomorphic"; subiculum byssoid [cottony], white, (Burdsall(3)), cream to ochraceous (Julich)
HABITAT  fallen branches; piles of wood chips; causing a white rot; Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Fagus grandifolia (American Beech), Heteromeles arbutifolia (Christmasberry), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus resinosa (Red Pine), Platanus wrightii (Arizona Sycamore), Populus fremontii (Fremont Cottonwood), Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), Ulmus americana (American Elm), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5.5)6-7.5(9) x 3-4 um, depressed ovoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 22-35 x 5-6 um, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, septate at base but lacking clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 60-150 (250) x 6.5-9 um, projecting up to 70 um, "arising at various levels of the subhymenium and subiculum", cylindric, obtuse at apex, thin-walled or with slight wall thickening, colorless, smooth, septate only at base and lacking clamp connections; HYPHAE monomitic; SUBHYMENIUM up to 75 um thick, a compact textura intricata-porrecta, hyphae 2.5-4 um wide, somewhat agglutinated, walls thin or slightly thickened; SUBICULUM a textura intricata, hyphae (3.5)4.5-6(7) um wide, branched at nearly right angles, colorless, thin-walled or with walls up to 1 um thick, lacking clamp connections, smooth near substrate to heavily encrusted with large colorless crystals near subhymenium, "sometimes with oval to spherical chlamydospore-like thick walled cells near substrate", (Burdsall(3)), SPORES elliptic, adaxially flattened, acyanophilic, CYSTIDIA arising at various levels in the thickened subhymenium, (Burdsall(5)), SPORES 6-9 x 3-4 um, cylindric to narrowly elliptic; BASIDIA 20-35 x 6-8 um; HYPHAE 2.5-7 um wide, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  after the imperfect state Chrysosporium
SIMILAR  Phanerochaete sordida has shorter cystidia than P. chrysosporium, and in the latter, they are thin-walled and more or less enclosed, (Eriksson(5)).
SOURCES  Burdsall(3) (colors in single quotation marks from 1967 edition of Kornerup(1)), Julich(5), Burdsall(5), Ginns(5), Eriksson(5)
299
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phanerochaete crassa  (Lev.) Burds,^  Mycologia Memoir 10: 67. 1985;  == Thelephora crassa  Lev.;  Laxitextum  crassum  (Lev.) Lentz;  Lopharia crassa  (Lev.) Boidin;  Stereum umbrinum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Hymenochaete multispinulosa  Peck;  Hymenochaete scabriseta  Cooke;  Hymenochaete purpurea  Cooke & Morgan;  Peniophora intermedia  Massee
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on fallen hardwood branches, 2) a fruitbody that is violet brown, reddish brown, light brown, or grayish brown, the surface smooth but becoming cracked, under a lens appearing mealy, 3) a margin loosely appressed to narrowly reflexed, and fringed to downy, 4) spores that are narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) cystidia that are cylindric or tapered to an acute apex, encrusted, sometimes embedded but usually projecting, with walls pale yellow to brownish yellow, 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae brownish yellow to yellow-brown, the subicular hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Phanerochaete crassa has been found in ID, AL, AR, AZ, CT, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, KS, KY LA, MD, MO, MS, NC, NH, OH, PA, SC, TN, TX, and VA, (Ginns). It is also found in South Africa, Democratic Republic of Congo, Vietnam, and Australia, (Burdsall).
FRUITING BODY  effused on small patches or coalescing with adjacent fruitbodies and up to about 15cm wide, up to 0.05cm thick; fertile area at first 'violet brown', central area becoming 'reddish brown', 'light brown', or 'greyish brown' often surrounded by a band of 'violet brown'; appearing slightly farinaceous [mealy] under a 10x lens, "smooth at first but much cracked later and on drying"; margin up to 0.2cm wide, loosely appressed to narrowly reflexed, fimbriate [fringed] to pubescent, 'greyish rose'^, (Burdsall)
HABITAT  on fallen hardwood branches^, (Burdsall), Acacia, Agave palmeri (Palmer's Agave), Alnus (alder), Canotia holocantha (Canotia), Carpinus (hornbeam), Carya (hickory), Castanea (chestnut), Dasylirion wheeleri (Desert Spoon), Fagus (beech), Fouquieria (ocotillo), Ilex (holly), Juglans (walnut), Liquidambar styraciflua (Sweetgum), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Platanus (sycamore), Prosopis (mesquite), Prunus, Quercus (oak), Vitis (grape); on dead trunks and branches; dead fallen branches; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8 x 3-3.5(4) um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (30)40-45 x 6-8 um, clavate, pale yellow with colorless apex and sterigmata, sterigmata up to 7 um long; CYSTIDIA 75-100 x 7.5-13 um, cylindric or tapered to acute apex, "encrusted with pale yellow crystals near apex, pale yellow to brownish yellow walls, thick-walled, sometimes embedded", but usually projecting up to 50 um; HYPHAE monomitic; SUBHYMENIUM a textura intricata, hyphae 2.5-3.5 um wide, brownish yellow to yellow-brown, walls thin to slightly thickened, "smooth, giving rise to cystidia and overgrowing and embedding older ones"; SUBICULUM a textura intricata, hyphae 4-7(9) um wide, brownish yellow to yellow-brown, walls thin or slightly thickened, "regularly branched, frequently at right angles, smooth", simple-septate, "aseptate cystidial bases also present", (Burdsall)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'thick, stout'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Burdsall(5) (colors in single quotation marks from 1967 edition of Kornerup(1)), Ginns(5)
300
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phanerochaete sanguinea  (Fr.) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykol. 27: 26. 1973;  == Thelephora sanguinea  Fr.;  Peniophora sanguinea  (Fr.) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Peniophora limonea  Burt;  Peniophora miniata  sensu Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Phanerochaete sanguinea is easily recognized in the field by the combination of reddish or red-spotted surface, reddish rhizomorphs, and reddish-stained wood, (Breitenbach). The red color can be seen at least in the rhizomorphs or as patches on the surface, though young specimens may lack the red (old specimens are wholly red), (Eriksson). Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood of conifers, less often of hardwoods, 2) a fruitbody that is membranous, soft, smooth, and whitish to ocherish, spotted red in places or when old wholly red, 3) a margin varying but mostly fibrillose and often growing out into rhizomorphs, 4) a subiculum that is cottony, colored as the surface or more orange when the surface is pale, 5) an olive green reaction in 2% KOH of the orange areas and the rhizomorphs, 6) spores that are narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, with droplets, 7) cystidia that are cylindric to awl-shaped or fusiform, projecting, thin-walled or slightly thick-walled, smooth or encrusted on the distal third (the encrustation dissolving in KOH), the tips smooth and blunt (cystidia not always easy to find), 8) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with frequent branching (in the subiculum at right angles), without clamp connections (except scattered on subicular hyphae, these clamp connections sometimes multiple), the subicular hyphae thick-walled, colorless or sometimes with orange to orange-brown content, and 9) crystals present in the context of mature fruitbodies.^ RANGE ^Phanerochaete sanguinea has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, NS, ON, PQ, AL, AZ, CA, CO, FL, GA, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MS, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, PA, SC, TN, VA, and WI, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland, and Asia, (Breitenbach), Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson), and Czechoslovakia, France, United Kingdom, and Russia, (Burdsall).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached tightly to substrate, forming thin, membranous patches several centimeters across, consistency membranous, soft; whitish, cream, to ocherish, spotted red in places; smooth to slightly poroid; "margin filamentous with reddish rhizomorphs"; "wood is stained reddish by the fungus"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, effused [spread out], of moderate size, 0.02-0.05cm thick, closely adnate [firmly attached] or partly detachable, soft when alive, after drying pellicular when young, membranous when mature; at first white or cream, "with time turning reddish, at least in patches", finally dark red and staining the wood red; "margin varying but mostly fibrillose and often growing out into rhizomorphs of varying sizes, normally red", (Eriksson), effused [spread out], up to 15 x 10cm, up to 0.05cm thick, "membranous, easily separable, cracking only slightly if at all", continuous; pale yellow to 'yellowish red' when fresh, orange areas olive green in 2% KOH; smooth; margin up to 0.1cm wide, fimbriate [fringed] or with cordons, irregular in outline, colored as the fertile area, including the cordons which turn olive green in 2% KOH; subiculum byssoid [cottony], colored as the spore-bearing surface or more orange when surface is pale, (Burdsall), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood, preferably of conifers, but sometimes on hardwood in mixed forests; "growing on fallen trunks, slash, branches on the ground, pieces of board", etc.^, (Eriksson), on dead wood of conifers, according to the literature also on hardwoods in mixed conifer-hardwood forest; fall, (Breitenbach), on wood or hardwoods and conifers, (Burdsall), on bark; decayed wood; twig; branch; bark on root; slash; fallen limbs; log; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Robinia (locust), Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 x 2.5-3 um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 22-38 x (4)5-6 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 40-60 x 5-7 um, projecting beyond the hymenium, subulate [awl-shaped] to fusiform, encrusted on distal third, tips smooth, the encrustation dissolves in KOH in several minutes; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-7 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa without clamp connections except scattered clamp connections on basal hyphae, (Breitenbach), SPORES narrowly elliptic to subcylindric, mostly 4.5-5.5 x 2.5-3 um, sometimes longer (up to 7 um), smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, containing 1-2 oil droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-35 x 4-5 um, narrowly cylindric, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA "varying in number and not always easy to find", projecting 25-35 um, cylindric or tapering, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled, mostly obtuse, not acute, naked or with varying degrees of encrustation; HYPHAE monomitic, without clamp connections "except for some few on the basal hyphae, singly, in pairs or in whorls"; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, "richly branched and densely intertwined", thin-walled; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 4-10 um wide, "straight, more or less parallel", with sparse septa and branching, "most hyphae with more or less thickened walls"; lots of CRYSTALS in the context of mature fruitbodies, (Eriksson), SPORES 4.5-6 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, adaxially flattened, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-45 x 4-6 um, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata 3-4 um long; CYSTIDIA 35-70 x 3-6 um, projecting 10-25 um, cylindric or slightly tapered to apex, smooth, colorless, thin-walled or slightly thick-walled; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBHYMENIUM a textura intricata, hyphae 3-5 um wide, much branched, colorless, smooth, walls thin or slightly thickened; SUBICULUM a textura intricata, hyphae 4.5-8 um, with frequent branching, at right angles, thick-walled, colorless, sometimes with orange to orange-brown content, simple-septate or nodose-septate [without or with clamp connections], with occasional multiple clamp connections; CORDONS a textura intricata-porrecta parallel to the axis, "hyphae like those of the subiculum", (Burdsall)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of blood, blood-red'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Burdsall(5) (color in single quotation marks from 1967 edition of Kornerup(1)), Eriksson(5), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
301
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phanerochaete sordida  (P. Karst.) J. Erikss. & Ryvarden^  Cort. N. Europe 5: 1023. 1978;  == Corticium sordida  P. Karst.;  Peniophora sordida  (P. Karst.) Burt;  Corticium glabrum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Peniophora cremea  (Bres.) Sacc. & Syd.;  Phanerochaete cremea  (Bres.) Parmasto;  Peniophora arachnoidea  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Phanerochaete sordida is distinguished by subicular hyphae that are broad and more or less thick-walled, branched at right angles and running in all directions, forming a well intertwined but open context (rigid lattice-work appearance). Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, occasionally on conifer wood, 2) a fruitbody that is waxy to membranous, soft, whitish cream to ocher, (sometimes tinted yellow to red, at least in the herbarium), and smooth or velvety, with or without cracks, 3) a margin that is narrow and mealy and/or finely fringed, without rhizomorphs, 4) subiculum that is cottony to fibrous, 5) a KOH reaction that is negative or sometimes vinaceous red, 6) spores that are narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 7) (2)4-spored basidia, 8) cystidia that are projecting, mostly cylindric or fusiform, the tip usually blunt, thin-walled at the apex and thick-walled in the lower part, smooth to strongly encrusted (the encrusting material either colorless crystals or yellow - red brown resinous matter), and 9) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae smooth or encrusted with colorless crystals, clamp connections occurring only rarely on basal hyphae, the subicular hyphae wide, branching at nearly right angles, forming a lattice-work, becoming thick-walled, sometimes encrusted with crystals.^ RANGE ^Phanerochaete sordida has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, NT, ON, PE, PQ, AK, AL, AZ, CA, CO, DC, FL, GA, IL, LA, MA, MD, MI, MS, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, TN, VT, and WI, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach), all forested parts of Scandinavia including Denmark, (Eriksson), and Mexico, Brazil, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Sweden, United Kingdom, South Africa, USSR, Japan, and New Zealand, (Burdsall).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached loosely to substrate, forming thin, membranous patches several centimeters to decimeters across, consistency wax-like and soft; surface whitish cream to ocher, KOH usually without reaction; smooth, velvety and dull, when dry somewhat fissured; "margin finely farinose-filamentous or in part distinctly bounded, without rhizomorphs"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, 0.02-0.05cm thick, mostly of moderate size (about 1 decimeter) but sometimes confluent into larger ones, adnate [firmly attached], not detachable or detachable only in small pieces, ceraceous [waxy] when alive, "firm membranaceous when dried"; at first whitish, then cream, "often with a slight greenish tint", changing with age, generally to sordid yellowish, "in the herbarium turning into pale ochraceous, sordid buff or vividly orange red" (yellow or reddish specimens appear under the lens to have an amber-colored encrustation on the cystidia, which immediately turns vinaceous red when touched with KOH, a drop of KOH on the hymenium gives a vinaceous patch in half of the specimens); as a rule smooth, old herbarium specimens often with more or less cracked surface; margin varying, abrupt, indistinct or finely fimbriate [fringed] under a lens, "not conspicuously fibrillose and without rhizomorphs", (Eriksson), broadly effused [spread out], up to 15cm x 4cm, membranous to nearly crustaceous, adherent, continuous; 'yellowish white' to 'brownish orange', sometimes red in KOH; smooth or slightly velvety, with or without cracks; margin up to 0.1cm wide, farinaceous [mealy], thin, 'yellowish white', regular in outline; subiculum byssoid [cottony] to fibrous, showing through cracks in surface, (Burdsall), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood of all kinds (branches, trunks, etc.) on hardwoods, and even if not quite so often, also on conifers^, (Eriksson), on hardwood, occasionally on conifer wood, (Burdsall), on dead wood of hardwoods, barked and barkless, (according to the literature also more rarely on conifer wood); throughout the year, (Breitenbach), barked and barkless fallen branches; slash; barkless wood on ground; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Corylus (hazel), Crataegus (hawthorn), Delonix regia (Royal Ponciana), Elaeagnus commutata (Silverberry), Fagus (beech), Juglans (walnut), Heteromeles arbutifolia (Christmasberry), Larix (larch), Liquidambar styraciflua (Sweetgum), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Nyssa (tupelo), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Quercus (oak), Rhododendron, Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), Viburnum obovatum (Small-leaf Viburnum), Piptoporus betulinus (polypore), (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7 x 2.5-3.5 um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, sometimes with droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, more rarely 2-spored, 25-30 x 4.5-5 um, narrowly clavate; without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 60-90(130) x 6-10 um, thin-walled, somewhat thicker-walled toward base, smooth to +/- strongly encrusted; HYPHAE monomitic, subicular hyphae 2.5-6 um wide, thick-walled, sometimes encrusted with crystals, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES mostly 5-7 x 2.5-3 um, may be longer but in most specimens shorter than 6 um, narrowly elliptic or subcylindric, "adaxial side almost straight, abaxial side more or less convex", smooth inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 4-5 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA varying in shape and number, mostly 60-70 x 6-10 um (but may reach 120 um or more), mostly cylindric or fusiform, "tapering to the apex which usually is obtuse", "walls at first thin, more or less thickening but may in some cases remain thin", encrustation varying with the age of the fruitbody and other factors, may be none but "usually there are grains or crystals on the apical or middle part", and in some specimens the cystidia are strongly encrusted, the encrusting material is either colorless crystals or yellow - red brown resinous matter, in the latter case turning red in KOH, rarely cystidia have side branches which occur mostly in the apical part; HYPHAE monomitic, without clamp connections (occurring only rarely on the basal hyphae), SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE "thin-walled, richly branched into a dense texture, forming a thickening subhymenium"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 5-7 um wide, "in young specimens with quite thin walls, later with more or less thickened walls, mostly very distinct, branched at right angles in all directions into an open context", hyphae next to the wood more parallel to the substrate, (Eriksson), SPORES 5-7.5 x 2.5-3.5 um, narrowly elliptic to elliptic, adaxially flattened, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-35 x 4.5-5.5 um, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata up to 3 um long; CYSTIDIA 60-120 x 6-8 um, projecting up to 30 um, nearly cylindric, tapered to obtuse apex, occasionally nearly subulate [awl-shaped], smooth or encrusted with large, colorless crystals, thin-walled at apex, thick-walled in lower part; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBHYMENIUM a compact textura intricata, hyphae 3.5-5.5 um wide, colorless, with frequent branching, thin-walled, short-celled, simple-septate, smooth or encrusted with colorless crystals; SUBICULUM a loose textura intricata, hyphae 5-9 um wide, "branched regularly and at nearly right angles", colorless, walls up to 2 um thick, rigid in appearance, long-celled, mostly simple-septate, rarely nodose-septate, clamp connections often entirely absent, smooth or encrusted with large colorless crystals, (Burdsall)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'dirty'
SIMILAR  Phanerochaete affinis can be differentiated on the basis of the shape and number of cystidia and the structure of the subiculum hyphae, (Breitenbach). P. affinis has cystidia that are more numerous, narrower and more tapering than in P. sordida, (Eriksson). P. affinis 1) has a fibrillose to cordonic margin, 2) is usually more orange than P. sordida, and 3) has a more compact and somewhat less agglutinated subiculum with less rigid-appearing hyphae than P. sordida, (Burdsall). Phanerochaete chrysosporium has longer cystidia than Phanerochaete sordida and they are thin-walled and more or less enclosed, (Eriksson(5)). Phanerochaete tuberculata lacks cystidia (Breitenbach). Phanerochaete velutina does not have the lattice-work appearance of the subiculum, its cystidia are wider, and the fruitbody is typically pale tan to dark burgundy brown rather than typically cream-colored, (Burdsall).
SOURCES  Burdsall(5) (colors in single quotation marks from 1967 edition of Kornerup(1)), Eriksson(5), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
302
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phanerochaete tuberculata  (P. Karst.) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort., 83. 1968;  == Corticium tuberculatum  P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) a membranous fruitbody that is whitish, later cream to ocherish, and smooth to somewhat tuberculate when fresh, 3) a margin that is whitish, fibrillose and sometimes has fine rhizomorphs, as well as larger rhizomorphs on the underside of the bark it is growing on, 4) a subiculum that is cottony and white, with rhizomorphs, 5) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 6) absent cystidia, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the septa without clamp connections except sometimes scattered single to multiple clamp connections in the subiculum.^ RANGE ^Phanerochaete tuberculata has been found in BC, ON, AZ, CO, MI, MN, PA, and WI, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach). It is rather common in south Scandinavia, north to central Finland, (Eriksson). It occurs also in Estonia and France, (Burdsall).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached +/- tightly to substrate, forming patches up to about 0.05cm thick and several centimeters across, consistency wax-like and soft; white when young, later cream to ocherish; "smooth to somewhat verrucose when fresh", smooth and somewhat fissured when dry; "margin whitish to white, filamentous and sometimes with fine rhizomorphs"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, effused [spread out], "confluent and sometimes becoming very large, covering the underside of trunks and branches", generally 0.01-0.05cm thick, adnate [firmly attached]; "at first white then turning creamish or when old darkening to pale ochraceous"; when fresh more or less tuberculate, becoming smoother on drying, "dry old fruitbodies more or less cracked"; "margin varying, often at least partly fibrillose, small rhizomorphs sometimes present in the periphery" and larger ones on the underside of the bark on which it grows, (Eriksson), effused [spread out], up to 4cm x 2cm, up to 0.03cm thick, membranous, adherent, continuous, "initiated on cordons and then filling in between"; pale cream, not changing in KOH; smooth; "margin fibrillose to cordonic, white", subiculum byssoid [cottony], white, thin, with cordons, (Burdsall), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood, preferably of hardwoods^, (Eriksson), on rotten hardwood; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on decayed wood; slash; associated with a white rot; Acer (maple), Agave, Betula (birch), Carnegiea gigantea (Saguaro Cactus), Celtis (hackberry), Chilopsis linearis (Desert Willow), Condalia mexicana (Mexican Bluewood), Fouquieria (ocotillo), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Lycium, Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Prosopis (mesquite), Quercus (oak), Vauquelinia californica (Desert Rose), Yucca, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5 x 2.8-4 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, some with droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-35 x 5-6.5 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa without clamp connections, sometimes with scattered clamp connections in the subiculum, (Breitenbach), SPORES 5-6.5 x 3-4 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, "with oily plasmatic contents"; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-35 x 4-5 um, clavate - subclavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, with thin or slightly thickened walls; subhymenial hyphae 2-3 um wide, in a dense context; subicular hyphae 3-5 um wide, "more or less parallel to the substrate and sparsely branched into an open texture", clamp connections "sometimes present on the subicular hyphae, rarely in pairs", (Eriksson), SPORES 5.5-7 x 3.5-4.5 um, broadly elliptic, adaxially flattened, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 33-48 x 6-7 um, clavate to broadly clavate, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata up to 4 um long; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, SUBHYMENIUM a compact textura intricata, hyphae 3-4 um wide, frequently branched, often candelabrate at bases of basidia, colorless, smooth, thin-walled; SUBICULUM a textura porrecta, hyphae 5-8 um wide, "infrequently branched, branches at nearly right angles", colorless, smooth, "thin-walled or with slight wall thickening", mostly simple-septate, "with rare single and multiple clamp connections"; CORDONS up to 500 um wide, rind not differentiated, hyphae a textura porrecta, "hyphae like those of subiculum", (Burdsall)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'tuberculate, with swellings or lumps'
SIMILAR  Phanerochaete sordida and Phanerochaete velutina are similar, but those species and Phanerochaete species in general have cystidia, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Burdsall(5), Eriksson(5), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
303
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phanerochaete velutina  (DC.) P. Karst.^  Kritisk Ofversigt Finlands Basidsvampar Tillagg III, 33. 1898;  == Thelephora velutina  DC;  Peniophora velutina  (DC.) Cooke;  Peniophora rhodochroa  Bres.;  Corticium rhodellum  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is membranous, soft, variable in color (pale tan to ochraceous, brownish red or burgundy, sometimes violet tinted, at first whitish to watery grayish), and smooth to slightly tuberculate, under a lens velvety from cystidia, 3) a margin that is whitish to pale reddish, fibrillose, and sometimes has rhizomorphs, 4) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) cystidia that are cylindric or tapered somewhat, blunt, thick-walled, and densely encrusted, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae branching at near right angles, without clamp connections or scattered single or multiple clamp connections on the subicular hyphae, the subhymenial hyphae smooth or encrusted with brownish orange granular to mucilaginous appearing material, the subicular hyphae smooth or encrusted with colorless granules.^ RANGE ^Phanerochaete velutina has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AL, AZ, CA, CO, CT, IL, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, PA, TN, VT, and WI, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland, and Asia, (Breitenbach), Estonia, Finland, Latvia, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson), and Jamaica, Austria, Denmark, France, Italy, Russia, and Armenia, (Burdsall).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached loosely to substrate, forming membranous patches several centimeters to decimeters across, consistency wax-like, soft; gray-ocherish to pink-cream; smooth to slightly tuberculate, velvety and dull, when dry somewhat fissured; "margin filamentous, sometimes with rhizomorphs"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, adnate [firmly attached] or when old detachable in pieces, effused [spread out] and sometimes reaching considerable size (several decimeters in length), when dried mostly 0.01-0.05cm thick; very variable in color, "in the beginning whitish and when wet watery greyish, then often getting a reddish colour, in all shades from very weak to clearly vinaceous red or even orange red, especially when dried", also described as "from white to greyish or reddish to dark vinaceous grey and all shades of ochraceous"; mainly smooth, under a lens visible cystidia give a velvety appearance (and in old specimens a whitish color from their rich encrustations); margin white or pale reddish, lighter than the spore-bearing surface, "mostly fibrillose and often with some rhizomorphs"; subiculum normally thick and easily visible in the surface cracks or as a fringe in the margin, but sometimes thin, and consistency given by subhymenium, which when thickened imparts a ceraceous [waxy] appearance; the most typical specimens "have a more or less red hymenium and a margin which in the periphery is white, then an orange-coloured zone, inwards changing to the pale vinaceous red of the hymenium"; there is usually no reaction to KOH except for some orange specimens in which there is a weak red reaction, (Eriksson), broadly effused [spread out], up to 15cm x 10cm, up to 0.05cm thick, membranous, adherent, continuous; occasionally tan, usually 'brownish orange' to 'light brown' or 'reddish brown', not changing color in KOH; velvety, cracking only slightly; margin up to 0.2cm wide, fimbriate [fringed] to fibrillose, irregular in outline, 'greyish yellow', sometimes cordonic; cordons up to 0.05cm wide, colored as margin, no color change in KOH; "Cordons are absent in some specimens and extensively developed in others. Usually, however, the cordons are reasonably well developed."; "There is great variability in the macroscopic aspect of P. velutina. Hymenium color and extent of cordon development is particularly variable. The color varies from pale tan to dark burgundy brown, but never takes on the orange tints found in P. laevis [=P. affinis] and occasionally in P. sordida and rarely exhibits the cream color typical of P. sordida.", (Burdsall, Latin names in italics), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  "on all kinds of decayed wood, generally on logs, big branches or stumps near the ground"^, (Eriksson), on dead hardwood, with and without bark, more rarely also on conifer wood; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on hardwood and conifer wood, (Burdsall), on decaying limbs; slash; decaying logs; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Amelanchier (serviceberry), Arbutus (madrone), Arctostaphylos (manzanita), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Castanea (chestnut), Corylus (hazel), Crossosoma, Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Liquidambar styraciflua (Sweetgum), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Magnolia, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-6.5 x 2.5-3.5 um, elliptic, flattened on one side, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 28-38 x 4-6 um, cylindric-clavate, without basal clamp connection; LAMPROCYSTIDIA 50-100 x 10-15 um, projecting beyond hymenium, thick-walled, distal half strongly encrusted; HYPHAE monomitic, subicular hyphae 2.5-5 um wide, thin-walled, "some sparsely encrusted with crystals", septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 5-7 x 2.5-3 um, normally elliptic with an oblique apiculus, but single spores vary to oval or subcylindric, adaxial side straight or slightly concave, contents oily plasmatic; BASIDIA 30-35 x 4-6 um, subclavate, normally 4-spored and without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA very numerous, reaching a length of 100 um or more and a width of 10-15 um, shape varying but normally subcylindric-subfusoid and obtuse, "walls of young cystidia thin but becoming finally very thick", cystidia richly encrusted; HYPHAE monomitic, subhymenial hyphae 2-4 um wide, forming a dense, ceraceous context, thin-walled, without clamp connections; "subicular hyphae in young specimens with thin, later with more or less thickened walls, straight, more or less parallel to the substrate, 5-10 um wide, in mature specimens normally richly encrusted, sparsely branched, with some clamps, singly, in pairs or sometimes in whorls", (Eriksson), SPORES 5.5-6.5 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, adaxially flattened, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-24 x 5-5.5 um, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata up to 4 um long; CYSTIDIA 90-150 x 10-16(20), projecting up to 45 um, cylindric or tapered somewhat to apex, with walls up to 3 um thick, with infrequent secondary septa, densely encrusted with colorless crystals, occasionally cystidia are dextrinoid; HYPHAE monomitic; SUBHYMENIUM a compact textura intricata, hyphae 4-6 um wide, branching at right angles or nearly so, colorless, thin-walled, simple-septate, "smooth or encrusted with brownish orange granular to mucilaginous appearing material"; SUBICULUM a loose to compact textura intricata to textura intricata-porrecta, hyphae 5-9 um wide, regularly branching at right angles, colorless, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, simple-septate with rare single and multiple clamp connections, smooth or more often heavily encrusted with colorless granules; CORDONS up to 500 um wide, rind not differentiated, arranged in a textura porrecta-intricata, hyphae 7-10(12) um wide, branching infrequent, walls slightly thickened or up to 2.5 um thick, simple-septate with occasional single and multiple clamp connections, densely incrusted with colorless granules, (Burdsall)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'velvety'
SIMILAR  Phanerochaete affinis can be differentiated on the basis of the shape and number of cystidia and the structure of the subiculum hyphae, (Breitenbach). P. affinis has cystidia that are narrower and more tapering than in P. velutina, (Eriksson). P. affinis may be similar macroscopically and like P. velutina has a fibrillose or cordonic margin, but P. affinis 1) is usually orange brown to brownish orange whereas P. velutina is pale tan to brownish red or burgundy (often with a violet tint), 2) has smaller cystidia mostly up to 8 um wide, whereas those of P. velutina are mostly greater than 9 um wide, and 3) only occasionally possesses cordons, (Burdsall). Phanerochaete tuberculata lacks cystidia (Breitenbach). Phanerochaete sordida has a lattice-work appearance in the subiculum, cystidia are narrower, and the fruitbody is typically cream-colored, rather than pale tan to dark burgundy brown, (Burdsall).
SOURCES  Burdsall(5) (colors in single quotation marks from 1967 edition of Kornerup(1)), Eriksson(5), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
304
FAMILY  Meruliaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phlebia celtidis  W.B. Cooke^  Mycologia 48: 394. 1956
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on dead wood of hackberry, 2) a fruitbody that is reddish and firmly attached, the spore-bearing surface covering elongate warts radiating from the center of growth, the margin discrete and whitish, 3) cylindric spores that are smooth and colorless, 4) a simple hymenium without cystidia, 5) hyphae with clamp connections, and 6) cubic crystals in the context.^ RANGE ^Phlebia celtidis has been found in WA and ID (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached]; reddish; "hymenium covering elongate warts radiating from center of growth", with discrete whitish margin^, (Cooke)
HABITAT  on dead wood of Celtis (hackberry)^, (Cooke), on dead wood; Celtis sp., Celtis reticulata (Netleaf Hackberry), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 x 2.5-3 um, cylindric, smooth, colorless, apiculate^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-22 x 3-4 um; CYSTIDIA none; CONTEXT "very compact, 300-600 um thick, with warts raised 200-600 um farther, formed of parallel hyphae" arranged parallel with the substrate, "within 50 um of the hymenium the hyphal direction changed to perpendicular, forming the hymenium"; HYPHAE 3-4 um wide (except those 1.5-2.5 um wide in the subhymenium), with clamp connections throughout; CRYSTALS present in context, 8-10 um across, cubic, (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to habitat on dead wood of Celtis
SIMILAR  Phlebia celtidis is distinct from other red Phlebia species because of the simple hymenium and context and the cylindric spores, (Cooke).
SOURCES  Cooke(4), Ginns(5)
305
FAMILY  Meruliaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phlebia centrifuga  P. Karst.^  Meddeland. Soc. Fauna Fl. Fenn. 6: 10. 1881;  Phlebia mellea  Overh.;  Phlebia subalbida  W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a whitish to grayish fruitbody with a radially wrinkled to papillose surface that is "very juicy" when fresh, 3) a whitish margin that is fibrillose-hairy, 4) spores that are elliptic-subcylindric, smooth, and inamyloid, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Phlebia centrifuga has been found in BC, NB, ON, AZ, CA, CO, MI, MT, and NY, (Ginns). It has also been found in Austria, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], orbicular [round], confluent, and finally widely effused [spread out], rarely "reflexed-pileate" [bent outward to form a cap] with whitish upperside; at first ceraceous [waxy] and whitish, then gelatinous and watery gray, when old darkening to violaceous gray, often with patches of rose or brownish color; "densely and irregularly papillose and partly radially or unevenly wrinkled", "very juicy"; when dried "darkening to brownish with an irregular yellowish or ochraceous pattern, smooth, brittle and sometimes loosening from the margins"; margin whitish, fibrillose-strigose^, (Eriksson) 
HABITAT  in spruce forests on the underside of fallen trunks and sides of stumps, (Eriksson), decaying sticks; rotting log; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Arbutus (madrone), Betula (birch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga (hemlock); associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
