MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3-4 x 1-1.5 um, sausage-shaped to elliptic, smooth, colorless, often containing 2 droplets, spore deposit white^, (Bessette), SPORES 3-4 x 1-1.5 um, cylindric to narrowly elliptic, (Lincoff), SPORES 3.5-4 x 1-1.3 um, cylindric, allantoid, smooth, amyloid but weak, colorless, with 2 droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-16 x 3-4 um, clavate, clamped; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, "hyphae of the trama and subhymenium thin-walled and sometimes with cross-banded structure", 3-5 um wide, "richly branched, septate with large perforated clamps", hyphae of the cap surface thick-walled, all hyphae swell in KOH, (Breitenbach), SPORES 3-4.5 x 0.75-1.25 um, exceptionally larger, allantoid, smooth, amyloid reaction distinct to difficult to observe, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-22 x 3.5-4.5 um, subclavate, clamped; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic 3-5(7) um wide with large clamp connections that often have a conspicuous "eye"; hyphae of trama 3-5 um wide, coarse, thick-walled, swelling in KOH or Melzer's reagent, ends of such hyphae form the tomentum on the upper side, in old fruitbodies these more or less glued together into bristles, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'curly'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Bessette(2)*, Eriksson(6), Breitenbach(2)*, Lincoff(2)*, Miller(14)*. Ginns(5) (as Plicatura crispa), Courtecuisse(1)*, Barron(1)*, Buczacki(1)*
327
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Protodontia oligacantha  G.W. Martin^  J. Wash. Acad. Sci. 43: 16. 1953
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  The outstanding features are "the sparse development of the spines and the broad, spineless, fimbriate margin" (Martin). Features include 1) growth on dead wood of black cottonwood, 2) a brown, waxy fruitbody with spines sparsely and irregularly distributed, that fades to buff or pallid near the margin, the margin broad and fringed, without spines, 3) spores that are cylindric to allantoid, usually with numerous small droplets, germinating by repetition, 4) basidia that become cruciate-septate, and 5) dendrophyses.^ | The description is derived from Martin. Roberts(3) says, "Based on the type description and illustrations, this Canadian taxon is clearly unrelated to Protodontia, having an effused brown basidiome with fimbriate margin, non-myxarioid basidia, and comparatively large allantoid spores. It would appear to be referable to the genus Heterochaete" (genus names italicized). RANGE ^Protodontia oligacantha was described from BC. It is known only from the type and three paratype specimens (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  broadly effused [spread out], up to 1.3cm by 0.5cm in extent, possibly larger, waxy when moist, the spore-bearing surface drying horny; "benzo brown" to "cinnamon drab", fading to buff or pallid near the margin; margin broad, thin, fimbriate [fringed], white (no suggestion that margin is ever determinate); spines sparsely and irregularly distributed, (where most abundant, 3-5 per square millimeter), blunt, broad, somewhat fimbriate, white, up to 0.06cm long and 0.035cm across at base, tapering toward tips
HABITAT  on dead wood of Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), July 26-August 11
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (9)10-12(13) x (4)4.5-5(5.5) um, cylindric to allantoid, usually with numerous small droplets, sometimes with 1-3 large droplets and numerous smaller ones, germinating by repetition^; PROBASIDIA spherical to ovate or pyriform, "mostly 13-20 x 9-12 um, becoming cruciate-septate, each cell producing a thick, rather short epibasidium, 2-2.5(3) um in diameter"; DENDROPHYSES "3-4 um in diameter at base, branching subdichotomously several times and irregularly attenuated toward the tips, sometimes with clamp-connections"; spines "fertile over most of the surface, as is the hymenium between them, but the extreme tip is often sterile", "owing to protrusion of an extension of the intermediate yellow layer, giving them a fimbriate appearance when examined dry under a binocular", spines "tend to be borne in lines on whitish strands, which makes the hymenial surface appear faintly reticulate under a lens"; hymenium "composed of colorless basidia and dendrophyses", the latter rather difficult to see since the terminal part does not stain; "in section 65-230 um thick between the spines, composed of a colorless hymenial layer 20-40 um thick, a yellowish basal layer of horizontal hyphae and an intermediate layer of variable thickness, clear yellow by transmitted light, which penetrates the spines, composed of indistinct agglutinated hyphae intermingled with crystalline accretions"
NAME ORIGIN  from 'oligos', meaning 'few', and 'akantha', meaning 'spine', in reference to the sparsely distributed spines
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Martin, G.W.(5), Ginns(5), Roberts(3)
328
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Protohydnum piceicola  (Kuehner) Bourdot^  Bull. trimest. Soc. mycol. Fr. 48: 205. 1932 (as piceicolum);  Protodontia piceicola  (Kuehner) G.W. Martin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a colorless to grayish white, resupinate fruitbody with distinct spines up to 0.3cm long, and little detectable subiculum, 2) growth on conifer wood, and 3) microscopic characters.^ | Roberts(3) considered this species in a study of Stypella but concluded that its relationship with Stypella (and Protodontia which he synonymized with Stypella) is doubtful, and referred it to "Protohydnum pro tem." (in italics). The online Species Fungorum, accessed June 10, 2016, gave the current name as Protodontia piceicola (Kuehner ex Bourdot) G.W. Martin. RANGE ^It has been reported from ON and WI, (Ginns). Collections from OR by A.M. and D.P. Rogers and from CA by K. Wells examined by Klett(1). Collections were also examined from Sweden, India, and Japan, (Roberts).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, firm-gelatinous, often widely effused [spread out]; colorless to grayish white; spines up to 0.3cm long, colorless, becoming yellowish on drying, sterile at tips; subiculum thin^, (Klett), macroscopically resembles Mucronella, having a multitude of distinct spines (up to 0.3cm long in well-developed specimens) with little or no subiculum, spines may according to Strid be branched, (Roberts)
HABITAT  on decayed conifer wood^, (Klett)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5(6) x 3-4.5 um, mostly subglobose to globose [nearly round to round], germinating by repetition^; BASIDIA clavate to pyriform, becoming spheropedunculate, the oval fertile part 7-10.5 x 6-8 um, becoming longitudinally septate, epibasidia 8-10 x 2 um; HYPHAE of spines 2-4 um wide, "thick-walled, walls swollen at tips, with few clamp connections", hyphae of subiculum 2-3 um wide, with scattered clamp connections, (Klett), spines fertile except at extreme apex and have a context of pseudo-dimitic, often brownish and occasionally encrusted hyphae, (Roberts)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living on Picea (spruce)'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Klett(1), Roberts(3) (as Protodontia), Ginns(5) (as Protodontia)
329
FAMILY  Tapinellaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudomerulius aureus  (Fr.) Julich^  Persoonia 10: 330. 1979;  == Merulius aureus  Fr.;  Plicatura aurea  (Fr.) Parmasto;  Merulius vastator  Fr. sensu W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed, barkless, confer wood, especially pine, 2) a radial or net-like spore-bearing surface (folded-wrinkled, often raduloid), soft, wax-like, yellow or almost orange, then yellow-brown, darkening when touched, 3) a margin that is narrow, and bright yellow to whitish, 4) a cap when present that is pallid or yellowish, tomentose, not zoned, 5) spores that are cylindric to suballantoid, smooth, yellow, in Melzer's reagent with slight reddish brown tint, and cyanophilic, with walls slightly thickened, 6) basidia formed from the area opposite to a basal clamp connection, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the clamp connections often large or handle-like, some hyphae with conidia-like outgrowths, some hyphae with bands at intervals, the subicular hyphae with grainy encrustation.^ RANGE ^Pseudomerulius aureus has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, ON, PQ, AL, AZ, CA, CT, GA, IN, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, PA, SC, VA, and VT, (Ginns(5)). It has also been found in Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson), Switzerland, (Breitenbach), and Mexico, Austria, France, Italy, Poland, USSR (Europe), India, Japan, and Russia (Siberia), (Ginns(12)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate or partly reflexed, adnate [firmly attached] but when dried easily detached, about 0.1cm thick, mostly orbicular [circular], 1-2cm wide, but often confluent and larger, spore-bearing surface ceraceous [waxy], (brittle when dried), at first yellow or almost orange, then yellow-brown, darkening when touched, (in herbarium "more lurid brown, sometimes with a tint of olivaceous"), "folded into an irregular net of angular, composed pores", 0.1-0.3cm wide, when young "sometimes radiate in a cantharelloid way"; margin narrow, soft, white or yellow, finely velvety under lens^, (Eriksson), "annual, effused or effused-reflexed, frequently confluent, separable when fresh", generally 2cm x 1cm and average 0.1cm thick; 'cap' when present firm, up to 0.5cm wide and less than 0.5cm thick, "pallid or yellowish, finely tomentose to matted tomentose", not zoned; margin when fresh white at the extreme edge becoming sulfur-yellow to bright greenish yellow, tomentose, abrupt, mound-like, but when dry usually pallid, abruptly demarcated from the spore-bearing surface, raised, tomentose to cottony, and up to 0.2cm wide; spore-bearing surface when fresh yellow to brownish, (bright yellow at the margin), "when dry darker, fawn, ochraceous to brown, crust-like", the folds narrow, up to 0.2cm deep, "continuous, radiating, frequently raduloid, sometimes anastomosing to form irregular pits", one or two per millimeter; "context fragile, white when fresh, pallid in dried specimens, homogeneous", (Ginns(12)), resupinate with a tendency to have a recurved margin, attached loosely, forming patches up to 0.2cm thick and several centimeters across, wax-like, soft; spore-bearing surface more or less radially folded-wrinkled, "sometimes also forming rudimentary angular pores", orange-brown to golden brown, marginal zone tomentose, sulphur-yellow to ocher-yellow, (Breitenbach), spore deposit yellowish (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed, barkless wood, also on old wooden fences^, in north Europe on conifers but reported by Bourdot & Galzin from hardwood, (Eriksson), on Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock); associated with a brown rot, (Ginns(5)), on wood and bark of conifers, particularly Pinus, collected principally in August and September, rarely in June and November, in southern US and Mexico from December through June, (Ginns(12)), on the underside of dead barkless wood of conifers, especially Pinus; fall-spring, (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-4.5(5) x 1.3-1.8 um, cylindric, "straight or with slightly concave adaxial side, or suballantoid", smooth, inamyloid (in Melzer's reagent with a slight reddish brown tint), yellow, cyanophilic, with thickened walls, spore print brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 4-5 um (sometimes longer up to 40 um with prolonged base), clavate, with basal clamp connection, new basidia "as a rule formed not from the basal clamp but opposite to it, forming a characteristic subbasidial hyphae [sic] with lateral hooks marking the sites of earlier basidia"; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, "thin-walled or in the subiculum slightly thick-walled", with clamp connections and anastomoses; subhymenial hyphae 2-3 um wide (swelling in KOH), richly branched, "some hyphae with peculiar bands or rings at irregular intervals, sometimes also with capitate projections looking like conidium formation but evidently something else", deviating clamp connections often seen - ampullate or with wide ansiform [handle-like] clamp connections; subicular hyphae normally 3-5 um wide, not swelling, "provided with a sparse fine-grainy encrustation", with scattered clamp connections and branches, "forming a loose context without interhyphal substance", (Eriksson), SPORES 3.5-4.5(5) x 1.5-2(2.5) um, short-oblong, in profile cylindric or tapering apically to reniform [kidney-shaped], some with 2 droplets, smooth, IKI-, colorless to pale yellowish, quickly distinctly blue in lactic-blue, slightly thickened, spore print distinctly yellowish or olive-yellow on paper and pallid on glass slides; BASIDIA 14-20 x 4-6 um, "clavate, often with the basal 5 um flared"; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic; "subhymenium about 30 um thick with hyphae closely woven"; context hyphae 2-5 um wide, "loosely woven to relatively closely packed, branching frequently" and often at a clamp connection, "with large clamp connections, thin-walled, anastomosing", "often incrusted with amorphous, yellowish, resin-like deposits", (Ginns(12)), SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 1.3-1.8 um, cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, yellowish, cyanophilic; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-24 x 3-4 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 1.5-3.5 um wide, "branched with anastomoses and short outgrowths", some hyphae swelling in KOH, some septa with large medallion clamp connections, according to the literature sometimes with conidia-like offshoots and band-like hyphal thickenings, but these not seen, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'golden'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(6), Breitenbach(2)*, Phillips(1)*, Ginns(12) (as 'Merulius' aureus), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
330
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella atrofusca  M.J. Larsen^  Bull. Torrey Bot. Club 98: 39. 1971
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on spruce, pine, or willow, 2) a cobwebby to pellicular fruitbody, the surface blackish brown and smooth, the margin paler and the subiculum much paler, rhizomorphs evident under 10x lens, 3) spores that are irregularly round to lobed, dull brown to pale yellowish, with warts that are sometimes bifurcated, 4) 2-4-spored basidia with encrusting material and contents bright green to blackish green in KOH, 5) a dimitic hyphal system, without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Pseudotomentella atrofusca has been found in BC, ID, AB, AZ, and Sweden, (Larsen, M.J.(8)).
FRUITING BODY  annual, resupinate, effused [spread out] up to 7cm x 4cm, up to 0.04cm thick, arachnoid [cobwebby] to pellicular, separable; spore-bearing area continuous, blackish brown, smooth; sterile margin fimbriate [fringed] to arachnoid, paler than spore-bearing surface; subiculum byssoid [cottony] to arachnoid, much paler than spore-bearing surface; cordons evident under 10x lens^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
HABITAT  on Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Salix (willow)^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-6.5(7) um, irregularly round to distinctly symmetrically lobed, often appearing roughly triangular when immature, "warted, the warts sometimes bifurcate, parts often greenish in KOH, walls dull brown to pale yellowish"^; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 40-60 x 6-8 um, spheropedunculate to napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, clavipedunculate when mature, sterigmata up to 7 um long, encrusting material and contents of basidia bright green to blackish green in KOH, "simple-septate at the base, median simple septa present"; HYPHAE dimitic; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, simple-septate, thin-walled, walls colorless, parts greenish in KOH; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) generative, 2-2.5 um wide, "simple-septate, contents often dull yellowish brown", walls dull brown to colorless, adhering encrusting material sometimes purplish in KOH, 2) skeletal, 1.5-2 um wide, aseptate, thick-walled, walls pale yellowish; CORDONS up to 30 um wide, dull brown, individual hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, simple-septate, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
NAME ORIGIN  from "atro" meaning "black or blackish" and "fuscus" meaning "brown"^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
SIMILAR  Pseudotomentella tristis also has brown spores and lacks clamp connections, but spores are larger, (Larsen, M.J.(4)).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(8), Larsen, M.J.(7), Larsen, M.J.(4)
331
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella flavovirens  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Svrcek^  Ceska Mykol. 12: 68. 1958;  == Tomentella flavovirens  Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a membranous to pellicular fruitbody with a dull green to grayish green, smooth spore-bearing surface, the margin cobwebby to fibrillose and paler, the subiculum firm-fibrous and paler than the spore-bearing area, 3) spores that are irregular to lobed or somewhat round, with bifurcate warts, and pale yellowish to colorless walls, 4) a dimitic hyphal system, 5) rhizomorphs of three types: generative, skeletal, and combined.^ RANGE ^Pseudotomentella flavovirens has been found in ID, ON, CO, NY, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France, and Sweden, (Larsen, M.J.(8)).
FRUITING BODY  annual, resupinate, patches finally becoming confluent, effused up to 10cm x 8cm, up to 0.05cm thick, "separable when fresh, densely membranous to pelliculose", spore-bearing area becoming continuous, dull green to grayish green, smooth; sterile margin arachnoid [cobwebby] to fibrillose, sometimes villose, paler than the spore-bearing area; subiculum paler than spore-bearing area, firm-fibrous^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
HABITAT  Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Picea (spruce), Populus, soil^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-8(10) um in diameter, irregular to lobed or somewhat round, often appearing roughly triangular when immature, "strongly warted with the warts normally bifurcate", walls pale yellowish to colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-80(90) x 5-6(7) um, "often with median simple septa, simple-septate at the base", normally spheropedunculate to napiform when immature, clavipedunculate when mature, "sterigmata up to 7 um long and often with simple septa"; HYPHAE dimitic; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3.5 um wide, colorless to pale yellowish, parts faintly purple in KOH, thin-walled, simple-septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) generative, 2-3(3.5) um wide, "simple-septate, thin-walled, walls pale yellowish brown to pale brown, some parts greenish in KOH", 2) skeletal, 1-2.5 um wide, "rarely simple-septate, thick-walled, unbranched, walls yellowish to citrine"; CORDONS of 3 types: 1) up to 40 um wide, dull golden brown, the individual generative hyphae 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, 2) up to 30 um wide, the individual skeletal hyphae 1-2(2.5) um wide, thick-walled, walls yellowish, lumen absent in many, 3) composed of both generative and skeletal hyphae, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), immature spores are 4-lobed (usually appearing roughly triangular), (Larsen, M.J.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means "green stained with yellow, yellowish green"^ (Larsen, M.J.(8))
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Pseudotomentella griseoveneta.
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(8), Larsen, M.J.(3)
332
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella fumosa  M.J. Larsen^  Mycologia 75: 558. 1983
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood of Douglas-fir, 2) a fruitbody that is gray with a brown tint, continuous to discontinuous, the margin not determinable, the subiculum cobwebby and somewhat darker than the spore-bearing area, and rhizomorphs evident at 10x, 3) spores that are inamyloid, lobed and warted, with the warts normally bifurcate, 4) basidia with secondary wall thickenings and median transverse septa, 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections, and 6) rhizomorphs normally constructed of generative hyphae but with randomly associated skeletal hyphae.^ RANGE ^The holotype was found in OR (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  effused, arachnoid [cobwebby], spore-bearing areas continuous to discontinuous, gray with brown tint; margin not determinable; subiculum arachnoid, somewhat darker than spore-bearing area; "cordons evident at 10x"^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  type on wood of Pseudotsuga menziesii^ (Douglas-fir)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8(9) um in diameter, amyloid, distinctly lobed and warted, with the warts normally bifurcate^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-70 x 7-8(9) um, napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, "clavipedunculate when mature, with secondary wall thickenings and median transverse septa"; HYPHAE dimitic, without clamp connections; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3.5-4.5 um wide, pale brown to tan, thin-walled, septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) generative, 2-3 um wide, pale tan to colorless, thin-walled, septate, 2) skeletal, 2 um wide, pale citrine, thick-walled, aseptate; CORDONS frequent, 10-20 um wide, "pale brown, normally constructed of generative hyphae but with randomly associated skeletal hyphae"; fungal parts not reacting with Melzer's reagent, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  from "fumosus", meaning "gray with tints of brown"^, (Larsen)
SIMILAR  Pseudotomentella griseoveneta "is similar, but possesses a dull honey-yellow brown subiculum and smaller basidiospores [5.5-6.5(-7) um]", (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(5)
333
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella griseoveneta  M.J. Larsen^  Mycologia 66: 165. 1974
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pseudotomentella griseoveneta is distinguished from other Pseudotomentella species by its pale blue to bluish green spore-bearing area and spore size, (Larsen). Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifers, 2) a cobwebby to cottony fruitbody with a spore-bearing surface that is smooth and grayish blue to grayish blue-green, sometimes with purple tints, the subiculum yellow-brown, with rhizomorphs evident at 10x, 3) spores measuring 5.5-6.5(7) um in diameter, triangular to irregularly round or lobed, with bifurcate warts, 4) basidia that often have transverse septa, 5) a dimitic hyphal system without clamp connections, and 6) rhizomorphs consisting of generative hyphae.^ RANGE ^Pseudotomentella griseoveneta was found in OR (Larsen). It is known only from the type and 2 paratype specimens (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  effused, up to 0.02cm thick, arachnoid [cobwebby] to byssoid [cottony], separable, becoming pelliculose in some parts; spore-bearing area "continuous, grayish blue to grayish blue-green, sometimes with tints of purple", smooth; "subiculum arachnoid, dull honey-yellow brown"; cordons evident at 10x^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  on wood of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga sp. (hemlock)^, (Larsen)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-6.5(7) um in diameter, approximately triangular when immature, irregularly round to distinctly symmetrically lobed, warted with the warts normally bifurcate, colorless to pale yellow^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-70(80) x 6-7.5 um, napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, clavipedunculate when mature, often with transverse septa, sterigmata up to 7 um long, basidia septate at the base; HYPHAE dimitic, without clamp connections; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-4 um wide, pale yellow, thin-walled, septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) generative, 2.5-3.5 um wide, nearly colorless to yellowish brown, thin-walled, septate, 2) skeletal, 1.5-2(2.5) um wide, yellow, thick-walled, aseptate; CORDONS up to 30 um wide, pale yellowish brown, the individual generative hyphae 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, septate, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  from "griseo" Latin, meaning "gray" and "veneta" Latin, meaning "blue-green"^, (Larsen)
SIMILAR  Pseudotomentella flavovirens may be confused but has spore-bearing area dull green to grayish green (Larsen). See also SIMILAR section of Pseudotomentella fumosa.
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(4), Ginns(5)
334
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella humicola  M.J. Larsen^  Mycologia 60: 547. 1968
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pseudotomentella humicola is characterized by greenish fertile areas of the fruitbody, dichotomously warted spores measuring (5.5)6-8(9) um in diameter, and nodose-septate, brown subicular hyphae, (Larsen, M.J.(3)). Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a somewhat crustose to mostly pelliculose fruitbody with spore-bearing area continuous, greenish, and smooth, the margin not distinctive, and the subiculum dull ferruginous brown to pale brown, 3) spores that are irregular, irregularly round, or triangular, with bifurcate warts, and moderately thick, colorless to pale yellowish walls, 4) fine granular material encrusting the basidial walls becoming greenish in KOH, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae nodose-septate, the subicular hyphae pale yellowish to dull ferruginous brown.^ RANGE ^Pseudotomentella humicola has been found in BC, WA, and ON, (Ginns), and in Sweden, (Larsen, M.J.(8)).
FRUITING BODY  annual, resupinate, effused up to 12cm x 4cm, up to 0.05cm thick, "somewhat crustose to mostly pelliculose, cracking somewhat or apparently tearing upon drying, separable in small pieces"; spore-bearing area continuous, greenish, smooth; margin not distinctive; subiculum fibrous, dull ferruginous brown to pale brown^, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), subiculum up to 0.02cm thick; fruitbodies black in KOH (Larsen, M.J.(3))
HABITAT  on wood of Picea mariana (Black Spruce), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), (Ginns), on wood of Picea, Pinus, Thuja, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5.5)6-8(9) um in diameter, irregular to irregularly round when mature, often appearing roughly triangular when immature, "warted, the warts usually bifurcate", walls colorless to pale yellowish^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-70 x 8-10.5(11) um, spheropedunculate to napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, clavipedunculate when mature, thin-walled, "nodose-septate at the base, median simple septa rare", "sterigmata up to 9 um long and rarely with simple septa", "fine granular material encrusting basidial walls becoming greenish in KOH"; HYPHAE monomitic; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-3.5(4) um wide, pale yellowish to colorless, some parts becoming green in KOH, thin-walled, nodose-septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2-3.5(4.5) um wide, "pale yellowish to dull ferruginous brown, apparently with some brown encrusting material on walls of older hyphae, sometimes associated with a grayish green diffusate in KOH", wall thickening apparent, in some cases the lumen invisible, "commonly nodose-septate, some simple septa also present"; CORDONS up to 200 um wide, branched, dull yellowish brown, composed of compactly arranged hyphae that are 2-3 um wide, nodose-septate and with noticeable wall thickening, commonly associated with helicoid hyphae, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), SPORES moderately thick-walled, when immature distinctly 4-lobed, (appearing roughly triangular); BASIDIA somewhat distended 10-20 um above the basal septa when mature, width 8-10.5(11) um taken just below the apex; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE arising from hyphae of the subiculum and cordons, usually branching from the clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE moderately thin-walled to thick-walled, in some cases the lumen invisible, (Larsen, M.J.(3), additional information) 
NAME ORIGIN  from "humi" Latin adverbial form of "humus" meaning "on the ground" + "-cola" Latin, meaning "dweller"^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
SIMILAR  Pseudotomentella vepallidospora also has clamp connections but has chlamydospores associated with the rhizomorphs, (Larsen, M.J.(4)).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(3), Larsen, M.J.(4), Larsen, M.J.(8), Ginns(5)
335
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella kaniksuensis  M.J. Larsen^  Mycologia 75: 560. 1983
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pseudotomentella kaniksuensis is separated from other Pseudotomentella species by the size and shape of spores and the dimensions of basidia, (Larsen). Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood of Douglas-fir, 2) a cobwebby to cottony fruitbody with smooth surface dark gray with a faint green tint, the subiculum dull gray, and rhizomorphs evident at 10x, 3) spores that are 7-8(8.5) um wide, inamyloid, pale yellow, irregular in outline to irregularly round, and spiny to warted with spines and warts frequently becoming bifurcate, 4) basidia that are 4-spored, measuring 60-80 x 6-8 um, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the hyphae lacking clamp connections.^ RANGE ^The holotype was found in ID (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  effused, up to 0.2cm thick, arachnoid [cobwebby] to byssoid [cottony], separable in small pieces, spore-bearing areas continuous to discontinuous, dark gray with a faint green tint, smooth; margin arachnoid to byssoid; subiculum byssoid, dull gray; cordons evident at 10x^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  on wood of Pseudotsuga menziesii^, (Larsen)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-8(8.5) um wide, amyloid, pale yellow, irregular in outline to irregularly round, echinulate to warted with echinulae and warts frequently becoming bifurcate^, BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-80 x 6-8 um, napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, long-clavate to clavipedunculate when mature; HYPHAE dimitic, lacking clamp connections; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-3.5 um wide, septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) generative, 2-3 um wide, pale brown, thin-walled, septate, 2) skeletal, 2-3 um wide, pale yellowish brown, thick-walled, aseptate; cordons in the subiculum up to 35 um wide, "abundant and composed of both generative and skeletal hyphae"; fungal parts not reacting with Melzer's reagent, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  from Kaniksu + -ensis, indicating origin and proximity of the specimens to Kaniksu National Forest in northern Idaho and eastern Washington^, (Larsen)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(5)
336
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella longisterigmata  M.J. Larsen^  Can. J. Bot. 45: 1298. 1967
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pseudotomentella longisterigmata is distinguished from other Pseudotomentella species by the blackish green spore-bearing area, its spores which measure 10-12 um across, basidial sterigmata measuring up to 18 um long, and thick-walled brown subicular hyphae, (Larsen, M.J.(6)). Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a pelliculose fruitbody that is grayish green to greenish black, smooth but cracking on drying, 3) spores that are round to irregular or lobed, with bifurcate warts, 4) basidia often with median simple septa, the long sterigmata often with simple septa, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections, and 6) rhizomorphs up to 150 um wide, ferruginous brown to olive brown.^ RANGE ^Pseudotomentella longisterigmata has been found in WA, CO, and NY, (Larsen), and MN (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  annual, resupinate, effused up to 7cm x 5cm, up to 0.15cm thick, "separable, distinctly pelliculose, cracking on drying"; spore-bearing area continuous, grayish green, smooth; sterile margin darker than spore-bearing area, colored as the subiculum; "subiculum thick, loose-fibrous, ferruginous brown"; cordons obscure, frequently formed in crevices of the substrate^, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), "annual, resupinate, occurring in small patches that enlarge and eventually anastomose", up to 0.15cm thick, separable when fresh and when dry, "distinctly crustose, cracking on drying"; spore-bearing area continuous, smooth, "dull greenish gray when fresh, parts dull greenish black", "mostly dark grayish olive to ivy green when dry"; margin "irregular, narrow, often absent", paler than the fertile area, colored as the subiculum; "subiculum thick, loose-fibrous, ferruginous brown"; cordons obscure, formed in crevices of the substrate; fruitbody becoming black in KOH, (Larsen, M.J.(6))
HABITAT  on wood of Abies (fir) and Tsuga (hemlock)^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-10(12) um in diameter, irregularly round to irregular when mature, round or irregularly round or 3-lobed to 4-lobed when immature, strongly warted, the warts normally bifurcate, spore walls pale yellowish to colorless, rarely with brown tinges^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-80(100) x (8)10-15 um, "often with median simple septa, simple-septate at the base", normally napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, clavate to clavipedunculate when mature, sterigmata up to 18 um long and often with simple septa, basidia associated with a green diffusate in KOH; HYPHAE monomitic; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-3.5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, simple-septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-4.5(6) um wide, olive brown to dark olive-brown, thick-walled, simple-septate; CORDONS up to 150 um wide, ferruginous brown to olive brown, individual hyphae 2-4 um wide, thick-walled, simple-septate, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), basidia clavate when mature, approaching spheropedunculate when immature, sterigmata 1-2 um wide at base, subhymenial hyphae branching near the septa and often oppositely, subicular hyphae often with localized thickenings, branching near the septa, (Larsen, M.J.(6) - additional information)
NAME ORIGIN  from "longi-" meaning "long" and "sterigmata", referring to long basidia sterigmata, (Larsen)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(8), Larsen, M.J.(6), Ginns(5)
337
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella mucidula  (P. Karst.) Svrcek^  Ceska Mykol. 12: 68. 1958;  == Hypochnus mucidulus  P. Karst.;  == Tomentella mucidula  (P. Karst.) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  = Hypochnus epimyces  (Bres.) Sacc. & D. Sacc.;  = Tomentella epimyces  (Bres.) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  = Hypochnus roseogriseus  Wakef. & A. Pearson;  = Tomentella roseogrisea  (Wakef. & A. Pearson) Bourdot & Galzin;  = Tomentella gilbertii  Bourdot & Galzin;  = Tomentella verrucispora  Bourdot & Galzin;  = Pseudotomentella verrucispora  (Bourdot & Galzin) Svrcek
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a spongy-membranous, tomentose fruitbody that is smooth to somewhat tuberculate and tan to pale yellow-brown, orange-brown, or lavender-brown, the margin lighter to whitish, the subiculum slightly paler than the spore-bearing surface, and fine rhizomorphs present, 3) spores that are mostly round, often appearing roughly triangular when immature, warted or spiny, the warts normally bifurcate, the walls nearly colorless to pale yellow or pale tan, 4) basidia often with median simple septa, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Pseudotomentella mucidula has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, ON, AZ, NM, and NY, (Ginns), Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Portugal, and Sweden, (Larsen), and Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  annual, resupinate, effused up to 20cm x 7cm, up to 0.05cm thick, "adherent to somewhat separable, cracking slightly, tomentose, rarely pelliculose"; spore-bearing area continuous when mature, tan to pale lavender-brown, smooth; sterile margin paler, almost white; subiculum paler than spore-bearing area^, (Larsen), resupinate, attached loosely, forming spongy-membranous patches about 0.05cm thick and several centimeters across, spongy, soft; ocher-brownish to yellow-brownish or orange-brownish, smooth to somewhat tuberculate, dull; margin lighter to whitish, finely fringed with fine rhizomorphs; subiculum colored as the spore-bearing area, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on Castanea dentata (American Chestnut), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), P. ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), T. plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Ginns), on Abies (fir), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Picea, (spruce), Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), Thuja, Trametes (polypore), (Larsen), on rotten wood of conifers and hardwoods, also on wood used in construction; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-11 um in diameter, mostly round, frequently appearing roughly triangular when immature, "normally warted or sometimes echinulate, the warts normally bifurcate", walls nearly colorless to pale yellow or pale tan^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-45(50) x 7-9 um, spheropedunculate to napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, clavipedunculate when mature, "simple-septate at the base, often with median simple septa", sterigmata up to 8 um long; HYPHAE dimitic; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, pale brown to nearly colorless, thin-walled, simple-septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of two types 1) generative, 2-3 um wide, pale brown, with wall thickening apparent, simple-septate, 2) skeletal, 1-2(2.5) um wide, yellowish, thick-walled, simple septa rare; CORDONS up to 20 um wide, yellowish brown, the individual generative hyphae 1.5-2.5 um wide, thin-walled, simple-septate, (Larsen), SPORES 6-9 um excluding warts, nearly round, verrucose to spinose, some warts dichotomously forked, yellow-brown; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-60 x 7-10 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE dimitic, 1) generative hyphae 2-3 um wide, light yellow, thin-walled, without clamp connections, 2) skeletal hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, brown, thick-walled, without septa; HYPHAL STRANDS up to 15(20) um wide, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  from "mucidus" Latin, meaning "mouldy" + "-ula" Latin, meaning "minutely", (Larsen)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(8), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
338
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella nigra  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Svrcek^  Sydowia 14: 178. 1960;  == Tomentella nigra  Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  The combination of a dark blue to violaceous black subiculum, with a surface lighter in color is distinctive. Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is somewhat loosely constructed, becoming pelliculose, the spore-bearing area smooth and tan to pale brown, the subiculum dark blue or violaceous black, and the margin not determinable, 3) spores that are irregular to round or triangular, and pale yellowish to colorless, with bifurcate warts, 4) basidia with median simple septa, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, with generative hyphae that are blue in water or brownish citrine in KOH, and somewhat thick-walled, and skeletal hyphae that are yellow and thick-walled, all hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Pseudotomentella nigra has been found in BC, ID, AB, ON, CO, and NY, (Ginns). It has also been found in Austria, Czechoslovakia, and France, (Larsen, M.J.(8)).
FRUITING BODY  annual, resupinate, effused up to 10cm x 5cm, up to 0.15cm thick, "somewhat loosely constructed, becoming pelliculose"; spore-bearing area continuous, tan to pale brown, smooth; margin not determinable, probably darker than the spore-bearing area and colored as the subiculum; "subiculum dark blue or violaceous black, fibrous"; "cordons present at the sterile margin", but obscure at 10x^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
HABITAT  Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine); charred wood; log, (Ginns), Fagus (beech), Picea, Pinus, soil^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-12 um in diameter, mostly irregularly round, often round or becoming very irregular, when immature round or less frequently appearing roughly triangular, "warted, warts normally bifurcate", walls pale yellowish to colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-80(110) x 8-12 um, distinctly spheropedunculate to napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, clavipedunculate when mature, "simple-septate at the base, median simple septa present", sterigmata up to 8 um long; HYPHAE dimitic; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, "pale blue in water and associated with a blue or bluish green diffusate in KOH", thin-walled, simple-septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) generative, 2-3(4) um wide, "usually blue to bluish gray in water and brownish citrine in KOH, hyphae associated with a blue or bluish green diffusate in KOH", wall thickening apparent (often minutely spinulose), simple-septate, 2) skeletal, 1-2.5 um wide, yellow, thick-walled, aseptate; CORDONS up to 150 um wide, "yellowish brown with bluish tinges in water, bleaching slightly or some parts becoming blue to green in KOH", individual generative hyphae (1)2-3(4) um wide, "often closely simple-septate, thick-walled", (Larsen, M.J.(8)) 
NAME ORIGIN  from "nigra" Latin, meaning "black", especially glossy black^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
SIMILAR  Other Pseudotomentella species in the Pacific Northwest do not have a dark blue to violaceous black subiculum, with a surface lighter in color, (Larsen, M.J.(4)).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(8), Larsen, M.J.(4), Ginns(5)
339
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella tristis  (P. Karst.) M.J. Larsen^  Nova Hedwigia 22: 613. 1972;  == Hypochnus subfuscus subsp. tristis  P. Karst.;  == Tomentella tristis  (P. Karst.) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  = Hypochnus rhacodium  Berk. & M.A. Curtis ex Burt;  = Pseudotomentella umbrina  (Fr.) M.J. Larsen sensu Aucts.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood and other substrates, 2) a fruitbody usually becoming pelliculose, the spore-bearing areas ferruginous to brown or bluish black, smooth and undulating, often becoming colliculose, the margin narrow, colored as the ferruginous brown subiculum or paler, 3) spores that are round to irregular or triangular, with bifurcate warts, the walls pale yellowish to brown, 4) basidia with median septa, and sterigmata often with septa, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections, the subicular hyphae brown (parts becoming green or blue in KOH).^ RANGE ^Pseudotomentella tristis has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NS, ON, AZ, CO, MA, MI, MN, MT, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, and SD, (Ginns). It has also been found in Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Netherlands, Sweden, United Kingdom, and Morocco, (Larsen, M.J.(8)).
FRUITING BODY  "becoming extensive and covering large areas", up to 0.2cm thick, "separable, usually becoming strongly pelliculose"; spore-bearing area continuous, "ferruginous to brown or bluish black", "smooth and undulating, often becoming colliculose"; sterile margin fibrillose, narrow, colored as subiculum or paler; "subiculum ferruginous brown, thick, fibrous"^, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  Abies(fir), Acer (maple), Amelanchier (serviceberry), Betula (birch), Carpinus (hornbeam), Fagus (beech), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), Ulmus (elm), decayed organic debris, soil, stone^, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), fall, winter, spring; also recorded on dead heather stems, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-10(11) um in diameter, round to nearly round or irregular, when immature normally round but sometimes appearing roughly triangular, "rarely echinulate, usually warted, the warts normally bifurcate, walls pale yellowish when immature and pale to medium brown or umbrinous when mature"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-60(80) x 8-12 um, often napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, "clavate to clavipedunculate when mature, simple-septate at the base, median simple septa present", "sterigmata up to 10 um long and often with simple septa", basidia "associated with a green, bluish green, or bluish black diffusate"; HYPHAE monomitic; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-4 um wide, colorless to pale brown, thin-walled or wall thickening apparent, simple-septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-3.5(6) um wide, "light brown to dark ferruginous brown, parts often becoming green, bluish green, or blue due to the reaction of crystalline material with KOH", thick-walled, simple-septate, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
NAME ORIGIN  means "dull-colored"^ (Larsen, M.J.(8))
SIMILAR  Pseudotomentella atrofusca also has brown spores and lacks clamp connections, but the spores are smaller, (Larsen, M.J.(4)).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(8), Larsen, M.J.(4), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
340
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudotomentella vepallidospora  M.J. Larsen^  Can. J. Bot. 45: 1299. 1967
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pseudotomentella vepallidospora is characterized among Pseudotomentella species by the dark greenish surface, the pale color and bifurcate ornamentation of the spores, and the presence of clamp connections, (Larsen, M.J.(6)). Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a cottony to cobwebby or somewhat tomentose fruitbody with a smooth, dark green spore-bearing area, the margin darker and fringed, the subiculum darker than the spore-bearing area and fibrous, rhizomorphs present but obscure, 3) spores that are irregular to irregularly round, with bifurcate warts, the walls moderately thickened and pale yellowish to nearly colorless, 4) basidia with greenish or yellowish contents in KOH, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections (nodose-septate), and grayish blue in water, becoming dull purplish brown, greenish, or yellowish in KOH, and 6) rhizomorphs associated with colorless to golden brown chlamydospores.^ RANGE ^Pseudotomentella vepallidospora has been found in BC, WA, and OR, (Larsen, M.J.(8)).
FRUITING BODY  annual, resupinate, effused up to 8cm x 4cm, up to 0.04cm thick, "separable, pelliculose"; spore-bearing area continuous, dark green, "smooth, frequently cracking and exposing the subiculum"; sterile margin fimbriate [fringed], darker than the spore-bearing area and colored as the subiculum; subiculum fibrous, darker than the spore-bearing area; cordons present but obscure^, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), annual, resupinate, in small patches or effused up to 8cm x 4cm, separable in both fresh and dry state, byssoid [cottony] to arachnoid [cobwebby] or somewhat tomentose; spore-bearing area "continuous in small patches and then discontinuous and exposing the subiculum, dark green when fresh, dusky green to dusky blue green when dry", smooth, conforming to substrate; "subiculum loose, fibrous", darker than the spore-bearing area, colored as the subiculum; "cordons present, obscure"; fruitbody becoming blackish green in KOH, (Larsen, M.J.(6))
HABITAT  on Pinus (pine), Thuja, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), Pinus, Thuja, Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar); on rotten wood, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-11(12) um in diameter, mostly irregular to irregularly round when mature, irregularly round when immature, "strongly warted, the warts normally bifurcate", walls pale yellowish to nearly colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-80 x 9-11(13) um, somewhat spheropedunculate to napiform [turnip-shaped] when immature, "clavate to clavipedunculate when mature, contents greenish or yellowish in KOH", "nodose-septate at the base, occasionally with median simple septa", "sterigmata up to 8 um long and often with simple septa"; HYPHAE monomitic; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-4.5 um wide, "grayish blue in water becoming pale green to yellowish in KOH", thin-walled, nodose-septate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3.5-5.5(6.5) um wide, "dark grayish blue in water and becoming dull purplish brown, dull greenish, or yellowish in KOH", wall thickening apparent, nodose-septate; CORDONS up to 45 um wide, "dark grayish blue in water and becoming greenish or yellowish in KOH", individual hyphae 2.5-4.5 um wide, nodose-septate, (Larsen, M.J.(8)), SPORES 8-11(12) um in diameter, mostly irregular (often somewhat round), "strongly warted, the warts usually dichotomously branched", walls moderately thick, pale yellowish to nearly colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-80 x 9-11(13) um, "arising from the hyphae of the subhymenium", clavate when mature, somewhat spheropedunculate when immature, "contents greenish or yellowish in KOH", "nodose-septate at the base, occasionally with median simple septa", "sterigmata up to 8 um long and often with simple septa"; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-4.5 um wide, "arising from hyphae of the subiculum and cordons", "grayish blue in water, becoming pale green to yellowish in KOH", thin-walled, nodose-septate, branching at and from the clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3.5-5.5(6.5) um wide, "dark grayish blue in water, becoming dull purplish brown, dull greenish, or yellowish in KOH", moderately thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled, nodose-septate, branching at or adjacent to the clamp connections; CORDONS up to 45 um wide, "arising from the hyphae of the subiculum", "dark grayish blue in water, becoming greenish or yellowish in KOH", composed of individual hyphae that are 2.5-4.5 um wide, nodose-septate, (Larsen, M.J.(6)), chlamydospores closely associated with cordons, up to 35 um across, terminal or intercalary, colorless to pale yellow when first formed, becoming dark golden brown when mature, (Larsen, M.J.(4)) 
NAME ORIGIN  from "vepallidus" Latin, meaning "very pale" + "spora" Latin, meaning "spore"^, (Larsen, M.J.(8))
SIMILAR  Pseudotomentella humicola also has clamp connections, but lacks the chlamydospores associated with the rhizomorphs, (Larsen, M.J.(4)).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(6), Larsen, M.J.(8), Larsen, M.J.(4), Ginns(5)
341
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Punctularia strigosozonata  (Schwein.) P.H.B. Talbot^  Bothalia 7: 143. 1958;  == Merulius strigosozonata  Schwein.;  Phlebia strigosozonata  (Schwein.) Lloyd;  Phaeophlebia strigosozonata  (Schwein.) W.B. Cooke;  Phlebia orbicularis  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Phlebia anomala  Berk. & Ravenel;  Phlebia rubiginosa  Berk. & Ravenel;  Phlebia zonata  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Phlebia pileata  Peck;  Phlebia spilomea  Berk. & M.A. Curtis ex Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  zoned Phlebia
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate or often reflexed growth on Populus and sometimes other hardwoods, 2) a gelatinous fruitbody with warts and folds, dark red-brown when fresh with bright yellow to yellow-brown margins, becoming dark brown to black when old or on drying, (sometimes developing a bloom), the margin often reflexed to form narrow shelf-like cap that is yellow to dark brown, short-hairy, and becomes zonate, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) numerous richly branched dendrohyphidia, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Punctularia strigosozonata has been found in BC, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PE, PQ, SK, AL, AR, CO, CT, DE, GA, IA, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, ME, MI, MN, MO, MT, ND, NH, NY, OH, PA, RI, SC, SD, TN, VT, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Estonia, and widely distributed in warm-temperate and tropical areas all over the world, (Eriksson). Distribution includes Mexico, Brazil, Chile, Venezuela, Russia, Madagascar, China, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Taiwan, Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Australia, Indonesia, and New Zealand, (Cooke).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate or often reflexed [bent outwards to form cap], orbicular [circular] and confluent to rather large size; upper side of reflexed area ('cap') "zonate with black brown concentric furrows of totally conglutinate hyphae, and lighter brown ridges, velutinous by projecting hyphal ends; oldest part often ash-gray"; margin bright yellow brown to reddish brown; spore-bearing surface dark brown - violaceous, "gelatinous in the wet living state, drying hard, in the youngest state smooth, then with elongate, radial ridges or irregular tubercles, when fertile with a whitish pruina of spore deposits"^, (Eriksson), "resupinate or more commonly reflexed, becoming confluent for large patches", individual fruitbodies remaining noticeable by centers of radiation of warts and ridges on the spore-bearing area, and by the appearance of merged areas; upper side of reflexed areas yellow to golden or dark brown when fresh (when dry or old fawn to gray), short-hairy, becoming zonate; spore-bearing area covered by warts and folds, "dark red-brown when fresh with bright yellow to yellow-brown margins", becoming dark brown to black when old or on drying, (sometimes developing a bloom), (Cooke), 0.5-3cm wide, often laterally fused and up to 15cm long, leathery-waxy, spore-bearing surface smooth at first, soon developing radially elongated, crowded wrinkles and knobs; flesh 0.02-0.05cm thick, "glistening, sometimes gelatinous", reddish brown to purplish black, (Lincoff)
HABITAT  on "decaying wood of hardwood trees, in North America primarily on species of Populus but occasionally found on other hosts"^, (Cooke, Latin name italicized), on branches and dead trees of poplar, beech, and oak; year round, (Lincoff), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Corylus (hazel), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Malus, Picea (spruce), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Ulmus (elm); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), in Scandinavia only on Populus tremula (European aspen) and Alnus incana (Gray Alder), (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-8.5 x 3.5-4.5 um, elliptic to ovate, "adaxial side straight or somewhat convex, rarely slightly concave, smooth, thin-walled", inamyloid, acyanophilic, new spores colorless or yellowish, old enclosed spores brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, when immature tube-like, flexuous [wavy], "when mature apically widened and projecting", 40-50(80) x 4-5 um; DENDROHYPHIDIA "numerous, richly branched", at first colorless then yellowish and in older hymenia gray-brown, "in the furrows between the hymenial ridges the hymenial layer may be formed by dendrohyphidia alone", in such areas sometimes covered with a layer of crystals, visible as white patches; "in hymenia with rich development of dendrohyphidia a catahymenium-like structure is formed"; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, all hyphae with clamp connections, "those of the upperside and next to the substrate pigmented brown", about 5 um wide, "often encrusted with lumps of excreted resinous matter", and forming a layer 30-50 um thick or sometimes more; major part of the trama composed of mainly colorless, more or less horizontal hyphae with thick walls, swelling in KOH and with sparse clamp connections and branches, this layer reaching a thickness of 500-1000 um; "from this trama layer the subhymenium is formed, thickens with age to about 100 um, composed of vertical, densely interwoven hyphae with thinner walls producing the basidia"; "in older fruitbodies the hyphae producing the dendrohyphidia may become pigmented brown", other hyphae colorless or slightly yellowish, (Eriksson), SPORES 6.5-7.5(8) x 3-4 um, ovate, flattened on one side, apiculate, smooth, nearly colorless to pale yellow or pale brown in color when mature, with granular contents; HYMENIUM "formed of a compact palisade" composed of colorless basidia and yellow dendrophyses and gloeocystidia; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 3-4 um, "difficult to demonstrate in most sections"; DENDROPHYSES 20-35 x 1-2 um, "not dichotomously but irregularly branched, or simple, yellow, ultimate branches thread-like"; GLOEOCYSTIDIA abundant, 20-35 x 3.5-5 um, "irregular to highly distorted in outline", yellow; CONTEXT in 2 zones: 1) next to the substrate of hyphae 5 um wide, olive-black, parallel, compactly arranged, with clamp connections, forming a trichoderm on the surface of the pileate parts, 2) hyphae 3-5 um wide, colorless, fairly compactly arranged, "walls gelatinously thickened, with clamp connections", the hymenium arising directly from this tissue, (Cooke), SPORES 6-8 x 3.5-4 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, spore print white, (Lincoff)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'strigose-zonate'
SIMILAR  Phlebia radiata has raised radial ridges, not concentrically furrowed zones, (Lincoff).
SOURCES  Eriksson(6), Cooke(4) (as Phaeophlebia strigosozonata), Lincoff(2)*, Ginns(5)
342
FAMILY  Cerrenaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Radulodon americanus  Ryvarden^  Can. J. Bot. 50: 2074. 1972;  Radulum casearium  Aucts.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on Populus species, 2) a spore-bearing surface with teeth up to 0.5cm long, often fused at the base, smooth or slightly fringed to finely dentate along the edges and at the tips, ochraceous to pale buff, cartilaginous, 3), a subiculum up to 0.2cm thick, cracking, 4) spores that are round to nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) absent cystidia, and 6) hyphae with clamp connections.^ | The true Radulon casearium (Morgan) Ryvarden was known only from the type specimen by 1972, and reports of it were misidentified specimens of Radulon americanus. RANGE ^Radulodon americanus has been found in BC, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, SK, AZ, CO, MI, MN, MT, NH, NY, and WI, (Ginns). It is apparently restricted to North America (Ryvarden).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached to substrate], hydnaceous, the teeth 0.1-0.5cm long, often fused at the base, smooth or slightly fimbriate [fringed] to finely dentate along the edges and in the apices, ochraceous to pale buff, cartilaginous, "when dry with clusters or slender semipyramids of fused teeth"; subiculum up to 0.2cm thick, white, when dry cracking^, (Ryvarden)
HABITAT  apparently restricted to Populus species^, found on Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), P. balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), P. grandifolia (Bigtooth Aspen), and P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), (Ryvarden), causing heart rot in live aspen; associated with a white stringy rot; also reported on Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-6.5 um in diameter, round to nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-40 x 5-10 um, suburniform, sterigmata 2-5 um long, basally curved; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE 1.5-4.5 um wide, colorless, with clamp connections, (Ryvarden)
NAME ORIGIN  means "American"
SIMILAR  Other hydnoid, resupinate species generally do not have round spores (Ryvarden).
SOURCES  Ryvarden(1), Ginns(5)
343
FAMILY  Pterulaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Radulomyces confluens  (Fr.) M.P. Christ.^  Dansk Bot. Ark. 19: 230. 1960;  == Thelephora confluens  Fr.;  Cerocorticium confluens  (Fr.) Julich & Stalpers;  Corticium confluens  (Fr.) Fr.;  Coniophora avellanea  Burt;  Corticium rubellum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) a fruitbody that is soft, watery-waxy, hygrophanous, cream to grayish ocher or grayish, often with a bluish, pinkish or violet tint, drying to whitish, grayish, or buff, the surface tuberculate when wet, the margin fringed when growing, 3) spores varying from elliptic to nearly round in shape, smooth, inamyloid, oily and granular, the walls slightly thickened, 4) basidia often with oil droplets, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Radulomyces confluens has been found in WA, MB, NF, NS, NT, ON, AL, AZ, CO, DC, FL, IA, IL, LA, MA, MD, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, VT, and WI, (Ginns). It has also been found in Switzerland (Breitenbach), and France, Germany, and Sweden, (Julich). It is a common species in Scandinavia (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached], effused [spread out] or orbicular - confluent, "varying from small to quite large", about 0.01-0.05cm thick; when wet, watery ceraceous [waxy] and hygrophanous, grayish, often with a rosaceous or violaceous tint, on drying changing to whitish, grayish or pale buff; "more or less tuberculate in the wet state, smoothing on drying"; margin in the growing fruitbody fimbriate [fringed], then fertile throughout; normally turning yellow in KOH^, (Eriksson), resupinate, tightly attached when fresh (partly detachable when older and dry), forming small rounded spots that coalesce and can form expanses several decimeters across, consistency waxy, soft; when moist cream to grayish ocher with bluish gleam, hygrophanous and somewhat opalescent, when dry ocherish; surface tuberculate-verrucose, when dry often somewhat fissured; "margin slightly filamentous-fringed to distinctly bounded", (Breitenbach), cream or ochraceous, sometime slightly grayish; rhizomorphs lacking (Julich), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on "bark and decayed wood of fallen or hanging branches, on logs and stumps", especially of hardwoods, but in suitable localities also on conifers; favors humid conditions, and especially common near water, "also a characteristic species in parks and gardens, where it grows on dead branches of cultivated bushes and hedges"^, (Eriksson), on a variety of hardwood species, also reported from Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar); associated with a white rot; barkless wood; limbs; dead branches; slash, (Ginns), on "dead trunks and branches of various hardwoods, on cut surfaces of stumps, with and without bark"; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), occasionally on sawn timber (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-12 x 6.5-9 um, elliptic - nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, oily and granular, walls slightly thickened in mature spore^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-55 x 6-9 um, clavate, sinuose, with numerous oil droplets, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none, but simple or somewhat branched hyphae often seen that are not differentiated as dendrohyphidia; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections; those of subhymenium 1-3 um wide, richly branched, thin-walled; those of the subiculum about 3 um wide, "mainly parallel with the substrate, sparsely branched, with thin or thickened walls", (Eriksson), SPORES 7.5-9 x 5-7.5 um, elliptic to nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, some with granular contents; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-50 x 7-10 um, clavate and sinuous, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen, but hyphidia-like hyphal ends present; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 7-10 x 6-8 um with rather large and distinct apiculus, inamyloid, but sometimes slightly cyanophilic; basidial sterigmata about 5 x 1.2 um (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'confluent, flowing together'
SIMILAR  Radulomyces notabilis has narrower spores, (Julich). See also SIMILAR section of Radulomyces cremoricolor.
SOURCES  Eriksson(6), Julich(1), Breitenbach(2)* (as Cerocorticium confluens), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
344
FAMILY  Pterulaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Radulomyces cremoricolor  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre^  Mycologia Memoir 19: 135. 1993;  == Corticium cremoricolor  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Cerocorticium cremoricolor  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Ginns
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwoods, 2) a fruitbody that becomes cream and pinkish buff to wood-brown in the herbarium, more or less colliculose, with broad, slightly elevated granules, the margin narrow, fibrillose, sometimes radiate, 3) spores that are 8-12 x 5-8 um, smooth, and colorless, and 4) hyphae 2-3 um wide, mixed with mineral material, somewhat longitudinally interwoven and then ascending to a compact hymenium.^ | According to Hjortstam (1989) quoted by J. Ginns, the type "is obviously an extreme form of the familiar and variable Radulomyces confluens" (Ginns(5), Latin name italicized). RANGE ^Radulomyces cremoricolor has been found in BC, NS, AL, CA, DC, FL, IL, IN, MA, MD, MI, MN, MO, NJ, NM, MY, OH, PA, TX, and WI, (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  2-10cm long, 1.5-3cm wide, often confluent, broadly effused [spread out], "rather thick, membranaceous, small pieces separable when moistened", in section 0.02-0.08cm thick; becoming cream and pinkish buff to wood-brown in the herbarium; cracking into areolae 0.2-0.3cm across "and with a distinct radial arrangement of the principal cracks frequently", more or less colliculose with broad, slightly elevated granules; "the margin narrow, fibrillose, sometimes radiate"^, (Burt)
HABITAT  on bark of decaying Quercus (oak) and other hardwoods; April to December, (Burt), Abies magnifica (California Red Fir), Ilex sp., Prunus sp., Quercus sp., (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-12 x 5-8 um, flattened on one side, smooth, colorless^; no gloeocystidia; HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, rarely wider, "not incrusted but mixed with more or less mineral matter", "somewhat longitudinally interwoven and then ascending to a compact hymenium"; section not colored, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'cream-colored'
SIMILAR  Radulomyces confluens is similar to and has not been compared critically to R. cremoricolor, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Burt(1) (as Corticium), Ginns(5), Ginns(23)
345
FAMILY  Pterulaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Radulomyces notabilis  (H.S. Jacks.) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort., 110. 1968;  == Corticium notabile  H.S. Jacks.;  == Cerocorticium notabile  Julich & Stalpers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifers, less often on hardwoods, 2) a somewhat waxy fruitbody that is cream to yellow, and smooth, the margin well demarcated and undifferentiated, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, with a minute apiculus, 4) hyphidia that are abundant to rare, sometimes subacuminate, often nodulose, occasionally forked, or with prongs, and 5) hyphae that are thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Radulomyces notabilis has been found in BC, AB, MB, NF, NS, ON, CA, CT, MI, and MN, (Ginns), as well as Europe (Julich).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.065cm thick, adherent, in elongate irregular patches, subceraceous [somewhat waxy], somewhat indurated when dry; whitish to ivory yellow; becoming rimose [cracked]; margin determinate [well demarcated] and undifferentiated^, (Jackson), effused, membranaceous; cream to distinctly yellow; even, (Julich)
HABITAT  on wood of conifers and hardwoods^, (Jackson), on Castanea dentata (American Chestnut), Picea glauca (White Spruce), P. mariana (Black Spruce), Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), P. resinosa (Red Pine), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), T. plicata (Western Red-cedar); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on conifers, rarely on hardwoods, (Julich)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9 x 4.5-7 um, ovoid, slightly compressed laterally, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, with minute apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50 x 7-8 um, clavate, somewhat flexuous [wavy], sterigmata 7.5-8.5 um long, subulate [awl-shaped], nearly straight; PARAPHYSES abundant, hypha-like, "sometimes subacuminate, often nodulose, occasionally furcate, or with stout prongs"; SUBICULUM "not sharply differentiated into layers, basal horizontal portion of hyphae with thickened, highly refractive, somewhat gelatinized walls from which arises an indistinctly stratose portion of vertical hyphae that ultimately form the hymenium"; upright hyphae 1.5-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "interwoven with granular-appearing collapsed hyphae", (Jackson), SPORES 8-9 x 5-6 um; BASIDIA 30-65 x 6.5-8 um, stemmed-clavate; HYPHIDIA 1.5-2.5 um wide, sometimes rare; HYPHAE (1.5)2-4 um, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, with clamp connections, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'remarkable'
SIMILAR  Radulomyces confluens has wider spores (Julich).
SOURCES  Jackson(3), Ginns(5), Julich(5) (as Cerocorticium notabile)
346
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ramaricium albo-ochraceum  (Bres.) Julich^  Persoonia 9: 417. 1977;  == Corticium albo-ochraceum  Bres.;  Trechispora albo-ochracea  (Bres.) Liberta
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a spore-bearing surface that is pale ochraceous, smooth, contrasting with the white subiculum, the subiculum continuing into a diffuse or rhizomorphic mycelium, 3) spores that are narrowly oval-elliptic-subfusiform, with an elongate apiculus, ornamented with hemispheric warts, walls somewhat thickened, both walls and warts cyanophilic, inamyloid, 4) basidia clavate with a stem-like part, and pleurobasidia frequent, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with frequent ampullaceous swellings, and with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^It has been found in BC, MB, NB, NS, ON, MI, and OH, (Ginns), as well as Austria, Finland, Poland, Sweden, and Tanzania, (Eriksson), and Colombia (Liberta).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], irregularly effused [spread out], of small to moderate size; spore-bearing surface "pale ochraceous, smooth, under the lens in the young state hypochnoid, then continuous, together with the subhymenium forming a layer, which is in the dry state fragile and easily separable from the white subiculum, this continuing into a diffuse or rhizomorphic mycelium"; margin not differentiated^, (Eriksson), "effused, adnate, appearing hypochnoid under a lens", between 'pale luteous' and 'ochreous'; margin "white, byssoid, fibrillose, or rhizomorphic", (Liberta)
HABITAT  Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Betula (birch), Dactylis glomerata (Cock's foot), Picea mariana (Black Spruce), Populus, Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock); associated with a white rot^, (Ginns), in basal part of moss carpets, under Juniper bushes, and on decayed wood, (Eriksson), also on Alnus incana (Gray Alder), (Liberta)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-8(9) x 3.3-3.9 um, narrowly oval-elliptic-subfusiform, with elongate apiculus, ornamented with hemispheric or rarely conic warts, walls somewhat thickened, both walls and warts cyanophilic, inamyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-45 x 5-7 um, clavate, flexuous-sinuose, basally narrowed to stem-like part, with basal clamp connection, pleurobasidia frequent especially in young hymenia; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic; "hyphae with clamps, 1.5-3 um wide, thin-walled, straight and sparsely branched in the subiculum, densely branched and interwoven in the subhymenium, with branches from or opposite clamp connections as well as between septa; ampullaceous swellings frequent"; anastomoses usual, especially in the rhizomorphs, (Eriksson), SPORES 4.5-7.5(10) x 3.5-5.5 um, oval-elliptic to fusiform-elliptic, regularly warted, inamyloid, thin-walled, yellowish to light ochraceous; BASIDIA 4-spored, 17-30(49) x 5-7(9) um, "clavate, sometimes flexuous and slightly pedunculate", sterigmata 4-8 um long; IN SECTION "up to 350 um thick, monomitic, the basal context white, loosely arranged, the upper context concolorous with the hymenium, crystalline material scattered among the hyphae"; HYPHAE 1-3 um wide, colorless, "thin-walled to slightly thick-walled (0.5 um)", "with frequent ampulliform swellings at the clamp connection up to 9(12) um wide", (Liberta)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white - ochraceous'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(6), Liberta(1) (as Trechispora albo-ochracea, colors in single quotation marks from Rayner(2)), Ginns(5)
347
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ramaricium flavomarginatum  (Burt) Ginns^  Bot. Not. 132: 94. 1979;  == Coniophora flavomarginata  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on Oregon White Oak, 2) a membranaceous fruitbody that is smooth to colliculose, that is colored ochraceous with a yellow growing margin, and that has short hyphal strands, 3) cylindric smooth spores, 4) basidia that are stemmed and clavate, 5) hyphidia that are cylindric, colorless, and sometimes branched, and 6) hyphae that are colorless, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled, and smooth or covered with acyanophilic warts, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Ramaricium flavomarginatum has been found in BC and WA (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  1-3cm long, 0.5-3cm wide, "effused, thick, membranaceous, separable, when growing avellaneous, with the margin flavous, fading in the herbarium to pinkish buff with margin whitish, even or somewhat colliculose, velvety, the margin radiate-fimbriate", fruitbody also referred to as tan-colored with yellow margin^, (Burt), effused, up to 0.1cm thick, membranaceous, with short hyphal strands; spore-bearing surface ochraceous, even, (Julich)
HABITAT  in crevices of the rough bark of large branches of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak)^, (Burt), on Quercus garryana; bark of large dead branches; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 12-15 x 4.5-6 um, cylindric, smooth, slightly colored^; no cystidia or gloeocystidia; IN SECTION "500 um thick, chamois-colored, becoming stratose", the hyphae 3-3.5 um wide, "suberect, densely arranged and interwoven, slightly colored, thin-walled, collapsing", "not incrusted, not nodose-septate", fruitbodies also referred to as composed of 3 strata, (Burt), SPORES 10-16.5 x 4.5-4.8 um, cylindric, smooth, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA stemmed, clavate, 60-100 x 8-10 um; HYPHIDIA 2-4 um wide, cylindric, colorless, sometimes branched; HYPHAE 2-4 um wide (locally inflated up to 7.5 um wide), colorless, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled, smooth or covered with acyanophilic warts, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with a yellow margin'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Burt(1) (as Coniophora flavomarginata), Julich(5), Ginns(5)
348
FAMILY  Repetobasidiaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Repetobasidium canadense  J. Erikss. & Hjortstam^  Cort. N. Europe 6: 1253. 1981
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Repetobasidium canadense is like R. mirificum but with elliptic spores.^ RANGE ^Repetobasidium canadense is known only from the type specimen from Vancouver Island in BC.
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, very thin, in the living state ceraceous [waxy], "like a greyish or whitish pruinose bloom on the wood", under the lens porulose [with fine pores]; margin not differentiated^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on wood^ (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8 x 4-5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 9-12 x 5-6 um, subglobose-pyriform, with basal clamp connection, subbasidial stem reaching 50 um; CYSTIDIA "35-45 x 4-6 um, cylindrical or somewhat tapering, capitate with an excreted globule, in the dry state composed of a grainy yellow - red substance; globules easily seen under the lens (50 x) as gold or amber-colored pearls; in the basal part of the cystidium normally one clamp"; HYPHAE monomitic: "hyphae 3-4 um wide, with clamps, basal hyphae forming a sparse net on the wood, with short perpendicular hymenial branches", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means "from Canada"
SIMILAR  Repetobasidium mirificum has nearly round spores, 5-7 x 4.5-5.5 um, [and cystidia are said to be somewhat smaller, but the actual measurement given is 30-45 x 5-7 um], (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(6), Ginns(5)
349
FAMILY  Repetobasidiaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Repetobasidium conicum  (Oberw.) J. Erikss. & Hjortstam^  Cort. N. Europe 6: 1255. 1981;  == Repetobasidium mirificum var. conicum  Oberw.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Repetobasidium conicum is similar to Repetobasidium mirificum but with conic cystidia.^ RANGE ^Repetobasidium conicum has been found several times in BC, was also found once in Sweden, and was originally described from Germany, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused, very thin, in the living state ceraceous [waxy]; margin not differentiated^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on Picea [spruce]^, (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-7 x 4-5 um, round to nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 8-12 x 5-7 um, subglobose-pyriform, with basal clamp connection, subbasidial stem generally less than 25 um; CYSTIDIA 30-40 x 5-7 um, conic [widest at base], "not capitate or with a very slight apical enlargement, without coloured resinous encrustation but sometimes with a small oil-drop", with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic: basal hyphae 2-4 um wide, closely attached to wood, with clamp connections, short perpendicular hymenial branches, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'conic'
SIMILAR  Repetobasidium conicum is similar to R. mirificum in its spores but Repetobasidium conicum has conic cystidia, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(6), Oberwinkler(6) (German), Ginns(5)
350
FAMILY  Repetobasidiaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Repetobasidium macrosporum  (Oberw.) J. Erikss. & Hjortstam^  Cort. N. Europe 6: 1257. 1981;  == Repetobasidium vile var. macrosporum  Oberw.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a very thin, waxy fruitbody, forming a whitish-grayish bloom on the wood, under a lens finely pored, with the margin not differentiated, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) microscopic features (characterizing the genus) of the basidium which forms perpendicularly from the sparse basal hyphae by "internal repetition" from a previous basidium, forming a stem that has no septa but has clamp connections and other traces from previous basidia at intervals, 5) tube-like cystidia that are thick-walled and homogeneous, and have one or two transverse septa with clamp connections, 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae thin-walled, with short perpendicular branches, and clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Repetobasidium macrosporum has been found in BC, (Ginns), and Germany, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  very thin, effused, ceraceous [waxy], forming a whitish-grayish bloom on the wood, under the lens finely porulose, not continuous; margin not differentiated^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on wood^ (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-10 x 3.5-5 um, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 8-15 x 5-7 um, pyriform [pear-shaped], with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 30-50 x 3.5-6(10) um, "more or less tube-like, obtuse, often somewhat sinuose or constricted", "thick-walled, contents homogeneous, more or less light-refracting in phase", with one or two septa with clamp connections; HYPHAE monomitic; "hyphae thin-walled, with clamp, basal hyphae 2-3 um wide, spreading over the substrate; short perpendicular hymenial branches, to 50 um long", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with large spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(6), Oberwinkler(6) (as Repetobasidium vile var. macrosporum), Ginns(5)
351
FAMILY  Repetobasidiaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Repetobasidium mirificum  J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 70. 1958
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed conifer wood, 2) a fruitbody that is waxy, visible as an inconspicuous bloom on the wood, 3) spores that are nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, and acyanophilic, 4) microscopic features (characterizing the genus) of the basidium which forms perpendicularly from the sparse basal hyphae by "internal repetition" from a previous basidium, forming a stem that has no septa but has clamp connections and other traces from previous basidia at intervals, and 5) capitate cystidia bearing a granular droplet.^ RANGE ^Repetobasidium mirificum has been found in BC, NM, and PQ, (Ginns). It has also been found in Finland, Germany, Norway, Sweden, and the USSR, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, very thin, in the living state ceraceous [waxy], when dried grayish to pale yellowish, porulose [with fine pores], not continuous under lens; margin not differentiated^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on very decayed conifer wood, like other very thin corticioid fungi mostly found during wet conditions^, (Eriksson)
