MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7 x 4.5-5.5 um, nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (8)10-13 x (5)7-8 um, subglobose-pyriform, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 30-45 x 5-7 um, capitate, with apical round drop about 10 um wide, granular, at first colorless, drying to amber or yellow-red, visible under lens also in herbarium; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 2-3(4) um wide, the basal ones close to the wood with perpendicular basidial branches, basal hyphae not gelatinous, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Repetobasidium conicum has conic cystidia (Eriksson). Repetobasidium canadense has elliptic spores (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(6), Oberwinkler(6) (German), Ginns(5)
352
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Resinicium bicolor  (Alb. & Schwein.) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort., 98. 1968;  == Hydnum bicolor  Alb. & Schwein.;  Odontia bicolor  (Alb. & Schwein.) Quel.;  Hydnum serratum  Peck;  Hydnum balsameum  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) waxy fruitbodies that are cream to ocher, often with reddish, greenish or brownish areas, the surface with conic teeth up to 0.03cm long, the margin not distinct, 3) spores that are oblong, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia of 2 types: a) halocystidia, smooth with a bladder-like swelling at the tip, and b) astrocystidia, smooth and pointed with a star-like tuft of crystals, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Resinicium bicolor has been found in BC, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, SK, AZ, CO, FL, GA, IA, LA, MA, MI, MN, MS, MT, NC, NM, NY, and TN, (Ginns). It occurs in all forested parts of Scandinavia (Eriksson). It has been found in Switzerland and in Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached tightly, forming patches several centimeters to decimeters across, thin, consistency wax-like (brittle when dry); cream to ocher, "often also with slight reddish, greenish, or brownish spots"; irregularly densely verrucose-odontioid, teeth up to 0.03cm long "and extreme tips sometimes colored dark brown"; "thinning out at the margin"^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached], effused [spread out], thin, in the living state ceraceous [waxy]; whitish or cream, "sometimes with a red tint and rather often greenish from overgrown green algae", darkening when old "and may turn brownish in patches"; odontioid, usually with small, conic teeth, scattered or more crowded, "in more vigorous fruitbodies the teeth may be bigger", giving a more hydnoid appearance, under a 50x lens "the teeth often showing an apical tuft of sterile hyphae", in older specimens turning brown, especially when touched; margin usually indeterminate and colored as the spore-bearing surface, (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on rotten barkless conifer wood, more rarely also on wood of hardwoods^, (Breitenbach), on barked or more common barkless wood, causing an intense white decay; common on slash in lumbered forests, (Eriksson), on a variety of conifers and hardwoods; causes a root and butt rot in Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), root rot in Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir) and Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), and trunk rot in Abies balsamea and young Abies grandis (Grand Fir), (Ginns), all year; including worked timber, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-7.5 x 2.5-3.5 um, irregularly elliptic, "flattened on one side and sometimes slightly curved", smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-23 x 5-9 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types 1) halocystidia smooth with bladder-like swelling at tip, 2) cystidioles smooth and pointed with star-like tuft of crystals; HYPHAE monomitic, 1.5-4 um wide, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 5.5-8 x 2.5-3.5 um, oblong, adaxial side straight or slightly convex, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, usually without oil droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, when young clavate, 15-25 x 4-6 um, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types, both as a rule numerous: 1) halocystidia which are capitate, with a distal, thin-walled bladder, 10-20 um wide, that contains "resinous or oily grains or drops", and 2) astrocystidia, from hyphal ends narrowing into a peg, bearing a star-like cluster (about 10 um across) of radially arranged crystals; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, fairly densely septate and with clamp connections at all septa; in the center of the teeth packed in parallel fashion, "joined by anastomoses, and continuing into the apical tuft of sterile hyphae"; "hyphae of the thin subiculum densely branched and intertwined", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with 2 colors'
SIMILAR  Skvortzovia furfuracea lacks cystidia with crystal stars (astrocystidia), (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(6), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
353
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Resinicium praeteritum  (H.S. Jacks. & Dearden) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre^  Mycologia Memoir 19: 138. 1993;  == Corticium praeteritum  H.S. Jacks. & Dearden
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood (Red Alder), 2) a thin, adherent fruitbody that is white, with a dry surface, the margin thinning out, 3) spores that are cylindric or subelliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and thin-walled, 4) 2 types of cystidia a) halocystidia, broadly clavate to capitate, and b) gloeocystidia, long cylindric, obtuse, and not projecting, and 5) hyphae with clamp connections, mostly thin-walled but a few with thickened walls and others intermixed with fine encrustation.^ | Nakasone(9) maintains this species does not belong in Resinicium sensu stricto (as characterized by the presence of astrocystidia) and suggests it may have affinities to Ceraceomyces. RANGE ^Resinicium praeteritum is known from the type, collected on Vancouver Island in BC.
FRUITING BODY  effused [spread out] in small areas, adherent, submembranous, rather thin (0.01-0.02cm); white; dry; margin thinning out^, (Jackson)
HABITAT  type on Alnus rubra (Red Alder)^, (Jackson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-7.5 x 2.5-3.5 um, cylindric or subelliptic, "flattened and appearing straight on one side with prominent lateral apiculus", smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 5-8 um, slender, "slightly ventricose above the middle", sterigmata 3.5-4.5 um long, slender, slightly arcuate; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 30-60 x 4-6 um, long cylindric or flexuous-cylindric, arising in the subhymenium, "sometimes tapering gradually from below, obtuse at apex, not projecting"; other structures [designated halocystidia by Ginns(5)] 13-20 x 6.5-9 um, subpyriform or abruptly spherical capitate arising in the hymenium; HYPHAE for the most part thin-walled, 1.5-3 um wide, not gelatinized, a few present with thickened walls and other intermixed with fine encrustation, clamp connections regularly present, (Jackson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Jackson(1), Ginns(5), Nakasone(9)
354
FAMILY  Phanerochaetaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Rhizochaete sulphurina  (P. Karst.) K.H. Larss.^  in Chikowski, Larsson & Gibertoni, Nova Hedwigia 103(3-4): 561. 2016;  == Ceraceomyces sulphurinus  (P. Karst.) J. Erikss. & Ryvarden  Cort. N. Europe 5: 895. 1978;  == Tomentella sulphurina  P. Karst.;  Peniophora sulphurina  (P. Karst.) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Phanerochaete sulphurina  (P. Karst.) Budington & Gilb.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, especially conifers, 2) a tightly attached, bright yellow fruitbody that is waxy when wet, and smooth, the margin white, irregular, and fringed, or not well differentiated, and rhizomorphs present, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia that are few, cylindric, and projecting, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, all hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Rhizochaete sulphurinus has been found in BC, OR, ID, AB, ON, AL, AZ, DC, KY, NH, NJ, NM, NY, PA, and SD, (Ginns), and Finland, France, Russia, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [tightly attached] but detachable in pieces when dry, becoming quite large (20cm in length), 0.01-0.05cm thick, when wet soft ceraceous [waxy] in the hymenial part, "when dried membranaceous and brittle, cracking in pieces"; bright yellow, drying dull yellow, sometimes with a reddish tint; surface smooth; margin irregular, white, fimbriate [fringed] or not especially differentiated; "subiculum well developed, running out in rhizomorphs of varying length and thickness"^, (Eriksson), 2-6cm long, 1-2cm wide, in section 0.015-0.04cm thick, "effused, adnate, the hymenium drying clay color, thin, brittle, even, here and there cracked and showing the mustard-yellow subiculum, the margin fibrillose-byssoid, mustard-yellow", (Burt)
HABITAT  on decayed wood (logs etc.) on conifers and also reported on hardwood^, (Eriksson), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, some with oily inclusions^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-35 x 5-6 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA few, 60-90 um long, almost cylindric, "slightly tapering, obtuse, with apical encrustation", encrusted part 40-60 x 10-12 um, basally thin-walled, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, all hyphae with clamp connections, subhymenium composed of hyphae 2-3 um wide, densely interwoven, richly branched, thin-walled, "subiculum with mainly parallel hyphae, sparsely septated and branched, 4-8 um wide, often anastomosing, with somewhat thickened walls, and forming an open context"; "basal hyphae often encrusted with lumps of joined crystals", (Eriksson), SPORES 3-4 x 2-2.5 um, smooth, colorless; CYSTIDIA not numerous, 3-6 um wide, protruding up to 30 um, hair-like, not encrusted; hyphae 4-6 um wide, loosely arranged, thin-walled, "occasionally nodose-septate, some hyphae granule-encrusted", (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to sulphur', indicating the color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(5) (as Ceraceomyces sulphurinus), Burt(7) (as Peniophora sulphurina), Ginns(5) (Ceraceomyces sulphurinus)
355
FAMILY  Ceratobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Rhizoctonia fusispora  (J. Schroet.) Oberw., R. Bauer, Garnica & R. Kirschner^  Mycol. Progr. 12(4): 774. 2013;  == Thanatephorus fusisporus  (J. Schroet.) Hauerslev & P. Roberts  in Knudsen & Hansen, Nordic Jl Bot. 16(2): 218. 1996;  == Uthatobasidium fusisporum  (J. Schroet.) Donk;  == Hypochnus fusispora  J. Schroet. in F. Cohn;  Botryobasidium flavescens  (Bonord.) sensu D.P. Rogers;  Pellicularia flavescens  (Bonord.) sensu D.P. Rogers pro parte
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, occasionally on coniferous remnants, and rarely on herbaceous plants, 2) fruitbodies that are soft, cottony, floccose, and whitish or grayish to pale ochraceous, 3) spores that are fusiform to lemon-shaped (with 2 apiculi), smooth, and inamyloid, producing secondary spores, 4) basidia that are (1,2)4-spored, and short-cylindric to short-clavate, with long sterigmata, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections,^ RANGE ^Rhizoctonia fusispora has been found in BC, MB, ON, PQ, CA, FL, IA, MA, ME, MO, NH, NY, and PA, (Ginns). It is distributed in the whole of Scandinavia (Hjortstam), and occurs in Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, attached loosely to substrate, forming filmy patches" several centimeters across, consistency soft and cottony; "whitish to cream-colored, sometimes also with an olive tint"; surface floccose, cottony; margin diffuse^, (Breitenbach), "resupinate, loose in consistency, hypochnoid to mucedinoid, rarely pellicular", rather wide-spread over the substrate; grayish to pale ochraceous "or in the herbarium sometimes yellowish", (Hjortstam), arachnoid [cobwebby], floccose or membranaceous; "white to yellowish, sometimes with olivaceous tinge"; even, (Julich), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  normally on hardwood, but now and then also found on coniferous remnants, and more rarely on herbaceous plants and on ferns^, (Hjortstam), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), A. magnifica (California Red Fir), Acer negundo (Boxelder), A. spicatum (Mountain Maple), Betula sp. (birch), Carpinus caroliniana (American Hornbeam), Carya sp. (hickory), Juglans cinerea (Butternut), Phytolacca decandra (poke root), Picea glauca (White Spruce), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Salix sp. (willow), Ulmus americana (American Elm), Kretzschmaria deusta (carbon-cushion, Xylariales); rotten wood; decaying wood, (Ginns), on rotten hardwood (Breitenbach), on "rotting wood, soil, herbaceous debris, old grass stalks, decaying fungal fruit bodies and other organic substrates"; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 10-15(24) x 6-8 um, fusiform to lemon-shaped, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, containing droplets, some forming secondary spores^; BASIDIA 18-23 x 9-11 um, cylindric to short-clavate, with (2)4 sterigmata 15(20) um long, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic 6-10 um wide, thin-walled, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 10-15(18) x 8-10 um at first obliquely subglobose then biapiculate and distinctly citriform [lemon-shaped], "smooth, moderately to distinctly thick-walled", some producing secondary spores; BASIDIA 15-25(30) x 10-15 um, short-cylindric, generally 4-spored; HYPHAE monomitic, basal hyphae mostly thin-walled to moderately thick-walled, colorless or pale yellowish, straight and parallel next to the substrate, 8-12(15) um wide, "rarely some of the hyphae are distinctly thick-walled, up to 20 um wide and pale brown", hyphal walls faintly cyanophilic and sometimes lightly dextrinoid, subhymenial hyphae thin-walled, slightly narrower, all hyphae without clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 8-18(21) x 5-8 um; BASIDIA (1)2-4-spored, 15-27 x 8.5-12 um, broadly clavate to subcylindric, sterigmata up to 15 um long; HYPHAE 5-10(12) um wide, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to fusiform spores
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6) (as Uthatobasidium fusisporum), Breitenbach(2)* (as Hypochnus fusisporus), Julich(5) (as Hypochnus fusisporus), Ginns(5) (as Uthatobasidium fusisporum), Buczacki(1)* (as Thanatephorus fusisporus)
356
FAMILY  Ceratobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Rhizoctonia ochracea  (Massee) Oberw., R. Bauer, Garnica & R. Kirschner^  Mycol. Progr. 12(4): 775. 2013;  == Thanatephorus ochraceus  (Massee) P. Roberts  Sydowia 50(2): 252. 1998;  == Uthatobasidium ochraceum  (Massee) Donk;  == Coniophora ochracea  Massee;  Botryobasidium ochraceum  (Massee) Donk in D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) fruitbodies that are soft, fibrous, floccose, and cream to ochraceous, 3) spores that are nearly round to oval or broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) 4-spored basidia that are short-cylindric to broadly clavate, with long sterigmata, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Rhizoctonia ochracea has been found in BC, MI, (Ginns). Distribution includes Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, closely appressed to substrate, forming thin patches several centimeters across, consistency soft and fibrous, easy to wipe off; cream to ocherish; surface openly floccose-fibrous; margin thin^, (Breitenbach), "hypochnoid to membranaceous"; ochraceous; even, (Julich)
HABITAT  on dead wood of Picea (spruce), according to the literature on rotten wood; fall^, (Breitenbach), on decaying wood (Julich), on bark and dead wood; Picea glauca (white spruce), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-8.5 x 5.5-7.5 um, nearly round to oval, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-25 x 8-10 um, cylindric-clavate, sterigmata up to 12 um, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, subhymenial hyphae 5-7 um wide, colorless, thin-walled to thick-walled, basal hyphae up to 13 um wide, brownish, thick-walled (2 um thick), all septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 8-10 x 5-6.5 um, nearly round, oval, or broadly elliptic; BASIDIA 4-spored, 14-20 x 8-10 um, short-cylindric or broadly clavate, sterigmata up to 14 um long; basal and subhymenial HYPHAE 6-8 um wide, colorless, with thin to somewhat thickened walls, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to ochraceous color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)* (as Uthatobasidium ochraceum), Julich(5) (as Uthatobasidium ochraceum), Ginns(5) (as Uthatobasidium ochraceum)
357
FAMILY  Ceratobasidiaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Rhizoctonia solani  J.G. Kuehn^  Ann. Sper. agr., N.S.: 224. 1858;  Thanatephorus cucumeris  (A.B. Frank) Donk  Reinwardtia 3: 376. 1956;  Hypochnus cucumeris  A.B. Frank;  Hypochnus filamentosus  Pat.;  Pellicularia filamentosa  (Pat.) D.P. Rogers sensu D.P. Rogers;  Hypochnus filamentosus  Pat.;  Corticium praticola  Kotila;  Pellicularia praticola  (Kotila) Flentje;  Corticium vagum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis sensu Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on living stems of herbaceous plants, sometimes on leaves, or on soil, or on wood and bark lying on the ground, 2) a fruitbody that is cobwebby to pellicular, whitish to cream, more or less separable, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia that are 4-(6-)spored and short-cylindric, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections, the basal hyphae light brown.^ | Thanatephorus cucumeris is best known under the names of the anamorph (Rhizoctonia solani Kuhn or Moniliopsis solani (Kuhn) R.T. Moore). The online Species Fungorum, accessed August 25, 2020, lists the former as its current name, presumably because basidiomycetes and their anamorphs are now supposed to have a single name and the Rhizoctonia name has priority. MycoBank, accessed the same day, listed the current name as Thanatephorus cucumeris. RANGE ^Thanatephorus cucumeris has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, SK, AK, AL, AR, AZ, CA, CO, CT, DC, DE, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MS, MT, NC, ND, NE, NJ, NY, OH, OK, PA, RI, SC, SD, TX, UT, VA, WI, WV, and WY, (Ginns). Distribution includes the West Indies, Europe, India, and Australia, (Burt), as well as Denmark (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  "loosely adnate, hypochnoid to pellicular", usually whitish or cream, (Hjortstam), 5-15cm long on logs, 5-10cm broad, in a collar 1-10cm long sheathing the base of living stems, a thin, arachnoid [cobwebby] perforate membrane more or less separable; pale olive-buff to cream; parasitic as the Rhizoctonia solani stage "in underground portions of various plants and forming at their surface underground minute sclerotia", (Burt), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on "bare earth, wood and bark lying on the ground, and on living stems of potatoes, beans, rhubarb, horseradish, tomatoes, Amaranthus etc. at or near the ground", (Burt, genus name italicized), causes a variety of diseases, including Rhizoctonia root rot, brown patch of turf, web blight of seedlings of Aleurites fordii, Catalpa spp., and Ficus sp.; fruiting bodies typically produced on live stems; also on wood and bark lying on the ground; over 400 genera of host plants, (Ginns), mainly growing on stems of Solanum tuberosum (potato) but also collected on leaves of other herbaceous plants (Hjortstam), on rotting herbaceous and vegetable debris, woody remains, litter, soil and living stems and leaves; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-12 x 5-6 um but varying in size, elliptic (adaxial side mostly convex or straight), smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, thin-walled, some producing secondary spores although not seen in all specimens^; BASIDIA (12)15-20 x (8)10-12 um, short-cylindric, normally 4-spored with rather stout 8-10 um long sterigmata; HYPHAE monomitic, without clamp connections, basal ones colorless or some with a light brown color, "thin or usually with walls thickened or more rarely distinctly thick-walled, 10-12 um wide, other hyphae thin-walled and forming a very thin subhymenial tissue", (Hjortstam), SPORES 8-14 x 4-6 um, even, flattened on one side, colorless; BASIDIA 10-20 x 7.5-11 um, not forming a compact hymenium, "with 4-6 sterigmata 6-10 um long and more or less swollen towards the basidium"; in section "60-100 um thick, composed of a few loosely interwoven hyphae running along the substratum and sending out short branches which bear the basidia", "hyphae in contact with substratum may be slightly brownish", colorless elsewhere, "not incrusted, not nodose-septate, up to 6-10 um in diameter, with branches smaller", (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of cucumber'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6) (as Thanatephorus cucumeris), Burt(1) (as Corticium vagum), Ginns(5) (as Thanatephorus cucumeris), Buczacki(1) (as Thanatephorus cucumeris)
358
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Schizopora flavipora  (Cooke) Ryvarden^  Mycotaxon 23: 186. 1985;  == Poria flavipora  Cooke;  = Polystictus subiculoides  Lloyd;  = Schizopora trichiliae  (Van der Byl.) Ryvarden;  = Tyromyces hypolateritia  (Berk.) Ryvarden;  = Schizopora carneolutea  (Rodway & Cleland) Kotl. & Pouzar
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, 2) a whitish to cream pore surface with angular to maze-like small pores that split to form teeth, 3) spores that are small, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) fusoid cystidioles that barely project, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with abundant small clamp connections, terminal inflations on some hyphae, others with thick-walled, nonseptate, terminal segments that resemble skeletal hyphae.^ RANGE ^Schizopora flavipora has been found in OR, CA, FL, LA, TX, (Gilbertson). It has been found in BC, Argentina, Brazil, Venezuela, Austria, Czech Republic, Germany, Romania, Spain, Cameroon, Gabon, Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi, South Africa, Tanzania, Uganda, Iran, China, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and Australia, (Langer).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, usually developing from fusion of smaller fruitbodies and becoming widely spread out, "leathery when fresh, becoming corky or tough-fibrous when dried, not readily separable"; margin usually sterile, up to 0.2cm wide, whitish, fimbriate [fringed]; pores 3-5 per mm, angular to daedaloid [maze-like], with thin walls that split to form irpiciform teeth; whitish to cream, discoloring to buff on drying; tube layer up to 0.3cm, colored as flesh and continuous with it; context less than 0.1cm thick, corky when dry, not zoned; cream to buff, (Gilbertson), resupinate, irregular, forming spreading patches, "tightly attached to substrate, poroid", margin usually distinct, paler and sterile; pores 3-5 per millimeter, angular, tubes 0.1-0.4cm deep, whitish; flesh "white-cream, soft, fibrous"; spore deposit white, (Buczacki)
HABITAT  annual, on dead hardwoods, associated with white rot of dead hardwoods^, (Gilbertson), on dead wood or hardwood trees, also sometimes on shrubs, conifers and structural timbers in buildings; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-5 x 2.5-3.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-15 x 5-6 um, clavate with slight median constriction, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA absent, CYSTIDIOLES scarcely projecting, 3-4 um wide, fusoid; HYPHAE monomitic, generative hyphae of subiculum 2-6 um wide, colorless in KOH, thin-walled to thick-walled, often branched, with abundant small clamp connections, some ending in spherical thin-walled swollen apex up to 12 um wide, others with thick-walled nonseptate terminal segments that resemble skeletal hyphae, these with wall often thinning toward the apex; hyphae of trama similar, (Gilbertson), SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid; CYSTIDIA obscure; HYPHAE monomitic, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means "with a yellow pore surface"^ (Gilbertson)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gilbertson(1), Langer(1), Buczacki(1)*
359
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Schizopora paradoxa  (Fr.) Donk^  Persoonia 5(1): 104. 1967;  == Hydnum paradoxum  Fr.;  = Polyporus versiporus  Pers.;  = Polyporus laciniatus  Velen.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, especially hardwood, 2) a fruitbody that is white to yellowish, with a maze-like toothed surface or sometimes poroid, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia when present originating in the hymenium, capitate, with a rounded exudate (but hyphal ends from the outer edges of the pores are obtuse not capitate) and 5) a hyphal system that is either dimitic (Hallenberg) or pseudodimitic (Langer), the hyphae with clamp connections.^ | Schizopora radula was separated from Schizopora paradoxa in 1983, and previous descriptions of Schizopora paradoxa refer to both species; Langer(1) and Hallenberg(5) separate them slightly differently, see SIMILAR. With respect to Schizopora radula and Schizopora paradoxa, "Usually there are no problems in distinguishing the two species just by a look at the hymenophore (25 X) - at least for C. and N. European specimens. However, there are also specimens which are difficult to interpret, especially among perennial ones or when the fruitbody has grown on a vertical substrate. In these cases the microstructure is distinctive.", (Hallenberg) RANGE ^Schizopora paradoxa has been found in WA, AK, TN, Brazil, Columbia, Germany, Italy, Norway, Romania, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom, Iran, Taiwan, and Australia, (Langer), BC, Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Hallenberg), LA (Gilbertson(4)), and CA (Desjardin(6)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, whitish - cream-colored; "irregularly hydnoid - denticulate - labyrinthiform, denticles thin - rather thick, often provided with small projections"^, (Hallenberg), resupinate; white when young, cream to yellowish when old; irpicoid to poroid; pore walls up to 0.5cm deep, (Langer, who refers to the photograph in Breitenbach(2)), growing flat on wood with pore surface exposed, tightly attached to substrate; margin usually distinct and coarsely granular; flesh soft, when dry hard; white; surface usually +/- poroid with 2-5 pores per mm, angular, but also tending to become irregularly labyrinthine or almost toothed on vertical substrates; tubes 0.1-0.4cm deep, whitish, (Buczacki) 
HABITAT  collections examined from Corylus (Hallenberg), Alnus (alder), Araucaria, Betula (birch), Carpinus (hornbeam), Eucalyptus, Fagus (beech), Laurus, Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), Syringa, Sorbus (mountain-ash), Taxus (yew), (Langer), on dead wood of hardwoods causing white soft rot, occasionally on conifers, shrubs and herbaceous plants and old polypore fruitbodies; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-5.5 x 3.3-4 um, when measured from spore prints, elliptic^; capitate CYSTIDIA rare; HYPHAE DIMITIC: "skeletals very thick-walled with a narrow lumen, not branched", acyanophilic, generally abundant (the presence of skeletal hyphae most easily observed in the byssoid margins of the fruitbody or in the trama); generative hyphae with clamp connections, more or less thick-walled; incrustation of hyphae in the pore mouth variable, often absent, (Hallenberg), SPORES 5.5-6.5 x 3.5-4.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 17-21 x 4-5 um, suburniform; CYSTIDIA capitate cystidia, about 30 um long, 4-6 um wide, (with a rounded, apical, colorless exudate), originating in the hymenium; hyphal ends on the edges of the pores are obtuse, not capitate, HYPHAE pseudodimitic, (Langer), SPORES 5-6.5 x 3-4 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid; CYSTIDIA-like structures clavate, spindle-shaped or broadly swollen, not projecting, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Schizopora radula has 1) a poroid spore-bearing surface, with angular pores, sometimes lacerate, 2) spores measuring 4-5 x 2.8-3.8 um, 3) capitate hyphal endings that are frequent in the hymenium and in the pore mouths, and 4) a monomitic hyphal system, whereas Schizopora paradoxa has 1) a hydnoid-denticulate-labyrinthiform spore-bearing surface, 2) spores measuring 5-5.5 x 3.3-4 um, 3) capitate hyphal endings that are few in number, and 4) a dimitic hyphal system, the skeletals with a narrow lumen (generative hyphae in S. radula are thick-walled and could be mistaken for skeletal hyphae but the cell lumen is wide and the septa have clamp connections), (Hallenberg). S. radula has 1) an orange-tinged fruitbody, 2) spores measuring 4-5.5 x 3-4 um, and 3) hyphal ends from the outer edges of the pores that are capitate, whereas Schizopora paradoxa has 1) a white to yellowish fruitbody, 2) spores measuring 5.5-6.5 x 3.5-4.5 um, and 3) hyphal ends from the outer edges of the pores that are obtuse, (Langer).
SOURCES  Hallenberg(5), Langer(1), Eriksson(7) (S. paradoxa sensu lato), Breitenbach(2)* (S. paradoxa sensu lato), Gilbertson(4), Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*
360
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Schizopora radula  (Pers.) Hallenb.^  Mycotaxon 18(2): 308. 1983;  Poria radula  Pers.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, especially hardwood, 2) a fruitbody that is white to yellowish, with a poroid or sometimes maze-like toothed surface, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) capitate cystidia in the hymenium, and capitate hyphal ends in the subiculum and outer edges of the pores, and 5) a hyphal system that is either monomitic (with generative hyphae often thick-walled) (Hallenberg) or pseudodimitic (Langer), the hyphae with clamp connections.^ | Schizopora radula was separated from Schizopora paradoxa in 1983, and previous descriptions of Schizopora paradoxa refer to both species. Langer(1) and Hallenberg(5) separate them slightly differently, see SIMILAR. With respect to Schizopora radula and Schizopora paradoxa, "Usually there are no problems in distinguishing the two species just by a look at the hymenophore (25 X) - at least for C. and N. European specimens. However, there are also specimens which are difficult to interpret, especially among perennial ones or when the fruitbody has grown on a vertical substrate. In these cases the microstructure is distinctive.", (Hallenberg). RANGE ^Schizopora radula has been found in BC, SC, Argentina, Denmark, France, Norway, Spain, Turkey, and Taiwan, (Langer). It has been found in BC, Austria, Denmark, and Sweden, (Hallenberg).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, cream-colored - ochraceous - pale reddish brown; poroid, pores of variable size, 1-3 per millimeter, "angular, in some specimens strongly lacerate", "pore walls thin, in old specimens sometimes rather thick"^, (Hallenberg), resupinate, irpicoid to poroid, beige with light orange tinge, 1-4 pores per millimeter, pore walls up to 0.01cm thick and pores about 0.2cm deep; subiculum apart from pores up to about 0.01cm thick, (Langer), tightly attached; pores 2-4 per mm, angular but becoming elongated or +/- labyrinthine; flesh soft, fibrous, cream; spore deposit white, (Buczacki)
HABITAT  collections examined from Abies (fir), Alnus (alder), Castanea (chestnut), Fraxinus (ash), Quercus (oak), (Hallenberg), on Eucalyptus, Populus, Sorbus (mountain-ash), Quercus, (Langer), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5 x 2.8-3.8 um, elliptic^; CYSTIDIA: capitate cystidia frequent; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae more or less thick-walled, regularly with clamp connections; "some hyphal endings in the trama are - in limited parts - very thick-walled, with a narrow, but unevenly wide lumen"; hyphal endings in pore mouth generally thin-walled, much incrusted, (Hallenberg), SPORES 4-5.5 x 3-4 um; BASIDIA 4-spored, 13-18 x 3.5-5 um; CYSTIDIA capitate in the hymenium and also capitate hyphal ends in the subiculum and in the outer edges of the pores, the hyphal ends in the outer edges of the pores incrusted with small crystal masses; HYPHAE pseudodimitic: skeletoid hyphae 3.5-4.5 um wide, walls up to 1.5 um thick, generative hyphae 2-4 um wide, walls up to 1 um thick; primary septa of all hyphae with clamp connections, (Langer), SPORES 3-4.5 x 2-3 um, elliptic to nearly round, smooth, inamyloid; CYSTIDIA sparse, clavate, projecting, heavily encrusted; HYPHAE dimitic, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Schizopora paradoxa has 1) a hydnoid-denticulate-labyrinthiform spore-bearing surface, 2) spores measuring 5-5.5 x 3.3-4 um, 3) capitate hyphal endings that are few in number, and 4) a dimitic hyphal system, the skeletals with a narrow lumen, whereas Schizopora radula has 1) a poroid spore-bearing surface, with angular pores, sometimes lacerate, 2) spore measuring 4-5 x 2.8-3.8 um, 3) capitate hyphal endings that are frequent in the hymenium and in the pore mouths, and 4) a monomitic hyphal system (generative hyphae in S. radula are thick-walled and could be mistaken for skeletal hyphae but the cell lumen is wide and the septa have clamp connections), (Hallenberg), Schizopora paradoxa has 1) a white to yellowish fruitbody, 2) spores measuring 5.5-6.5 x 3.5-4.5 um, and 3) hyphal ends from the outer edges of the pores that are obtuse, whereas Schizopora radula has 1) an orange-tinged fruitbody, 2) spores measuring 4-5.5 x 3-4 um, and 3) hyphal ends from the outer edges of the pores that are capitate, (Langer).
SOURCES  Hallenberg(5), Langer(1), Buczacki(1)*
361
FAMILY  Meruliaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scopuloides hydnoides  (Cooke & Massee) Hjortstam & Ryvarden^  Wiesner Festschrift (Wien): 57, 58. 1979;  Peniophora hydnoides  Cooke & Massee in Massee;  Phlebia hydnoides  (Cooke & Massee) M.P. Christ.;  Odontia hydnoides  (Cooke & Massee) Hoehn.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on barked and barkless hardwood, 2) fruitbodies that are wax-like, subgelatinous, semitranslucent to grayish or with a tint of lilac or blue, generally with scattered to crowded brush-like teeth up to 0.03cm long, 3) spores that are short-cylindric to somewhat curved, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia of 2 types: a) thick-walled, conic, encrusted, and b) hyphal ends obtuse, septate, encrusted, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphal septa without clamp connections, the basal hyphae easily observed and thin-walled, and the subhymenial hyphae indistinct in a dense layer.^ | Ginns(5) synonymizes Scopuloides hydnoides (Cooke & Massee) Hjortstam & Ryvarden with Scopuloides rimosa (Cooke) Julich and lists the distribution for the latter; however, later Ginns(23) says that one species of Scopuloides, being Scopuloides hydnoides (Cooke & Massee) Hjortstam & Ryvarden, occurs in North America [other species have been described since that publication]; other authors maintain Scopuloides hydnoides separate from Scopuloides rimosa, including Eriksson(7) "microscopically they are quite similar, though slightly different in spore-size, they differ considerably in outer appearance. The aculei of P. rimosa [italicized] are typically cylindrical and scattered over the hymenium, not crowded and penicillate as in P. hydnoides [italicized]"; the online Species Fungorum, accessed August 10, 2005 and August 23, 2020, maintained two species. RANGE ^Scopuloides hydnoides has been found in BC, NS, ON, AL, AZ, DC, FL, GA, IA, IL, LA, MI, MN, NC, NY, PA, TN, VT, and WI, (Ginns(5), who synonymizes Scopuloides hydnoides with Scopuloides rimosa and lists the distribution for the latter).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached tightly, forming thin patches several centimeters across, consistency wax-like when fresh; mouse gray to gray-blue or gray with a hint of lilac; smooth with small, sparsely scattered, brush-like teeth, at most 0.03cm long; marginal zone ending indistinctly^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, effused [spread out], thin, subgelatinous; semitranslucent when fresh and wet, whitish or grayish when dried; "odontioid and at least in older specimens distinctly cracked in irregular pieces", individual aculei crowded, velvety by projecting cystidia and hyphal ends (50 x lens); "margin thinning out, usually with numerous projecting cystidia", (Eriksson), smooth to slightly hydnoid, when young more or less pilose from projecting cystidia (Hjortstam), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on both barked and barkless wood of hardwoods, rarely seen on coniferous wood^, (Eriksson), on rotten wood of hardwoods, especially on the underside of small trunks and branches of Fagus (beech) lying on the ground, (Breitenbach), on Acer (maple), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Nyssa (tupelo), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Tilia (basswood), Ulmus (elm); bark and wood; charred wood; dead branches; rotten trunks; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), especially Alnus and Salix in wet habitats; spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-4 x 1.5-2 um (according to Burdsall 1985 4.5-5 x 2-2.5 um), elliptic, flattened on one side or slightly concave, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, some with droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-15 x 3.5-5 um, cylindric-clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types 1) lamprocystidia conic, "smooth when young, later strongly incrusted, rarely with 1 septum, thick-walled", 40-70 x 4-9 um, and 2) septocystidia cylindric, "blunt, multiply septate, thick-walled, incrusted", projecting beyond the basidia, up to 100 x 10 um; HYPHAE monomitic, 3.5-8 um wide, tightly interwoven, short-celled, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 3.5-4(5) x 1.8-2(2.2) um, short-allantoid, smooth, thin-walled; BASIDIA in a dense palisade, 4-spored, 12-15 x 3.5-4.5 um, subclavate, thin-walled or basally thickened, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA (metuloids, lamprocystidia) about 40-60 x 8-12 um, often projecting 10-30 um beyond the basidia, basally thick-walled, conic or more rarely obtuse, strongly encrusted, hyphal ends present, "especially in the top of the hymenial aculei, usually projecting 20-50 um or more, septate and strongly incrusted"; HYPHAE monomitic, without clamp connections; "subhymenium with densely interwoven hyphae"; subiculum "as a rule very thin and composed of relatively long-celled hyphae", arranged in parallel fashion next to the substrate, with somewhat thickened walls, 4-7 um wide, (Eriksson), SPORES "generally suballantoid to short cylindric, smooth and thin-walled, 4.5-5 x 2-2.5 um", inamyloid; BASIDIA 4-spored, small, about 8-12 x 3-5 um; CYSTIDIA numerous, about 50-70 um long and 10 um wide at base, conic, "thick-walled and strongly encrusted, sometimes lateral, especially in young fruitbodies"; hyphal ends present in most specimens, obtuse, projecting, as a rule septate, and strongly encrusted; HYPHAE monomitic, basal hyphae easily observed, 3-4 um wide, thin-walled, without clamp connections, subhymenial hyphae indistinct and forming a dense layer, (Hjortstam)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'rimose' = 'cracked'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)* (as Scopuloides rimosa (Cooke) Julich but gives Scopuloides hydnoides (Cooke & Massee) Hjortstam & Ryvarden as a synonym), Eriksson(7), Hjortstam(9), Ginns(5) (for Scopuloides rimosa), Ginns(23), Buczacki(1)*
362
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scytinostroma galactinum  (Fr.) Donk^  Fungus 26: 20. 1956;  == Thelephora galactina  Fr.;  Corticium galactinum  (Fr.) Burt  
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood of conifers or less often hardwoods, 2) pliant, tough-leathery fruitbodies that are whitish to buff, the surface smooth to tuberculate, the margin abrupt or thinning out, 3) spores that are 4-5.5(8) x (2)2.5-3 um, elliptic to cylindric, flattened on the adaxial side, smooth, colorless, and amyloid or not (amyloid reaction distributed evenly or limited to a small part of the adaxial surface), 4) cystidia that are cylindric, often with refractive contents, sulfo-positive or sulfo-negative, embedded or projecting, 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the generative hyphae with clamp connections, the skeletal hyphae dextrinoid.^ RANGE ^Scytinostroma galactinum has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PE, PQ, SK, AK, AL, AR, AZ, CA, CO, CT, DE, FL, GA, IL, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MS, MT, NC, NH, NM, NY, OK, SC, SD, TN, TX, VA, VT, WI, WV, and WY, (Ginns(5) in 1993). Nakasone(7) commented that descriptions by previous researchers (previous to 1988) are S. galactinum and S. protrusum combined or of S. protrusum.
FRUITING BODY  annual, adherent, broadly effused [spread out], (occasionally occurring as small circular patches about 0.1cm across), up to 0.1cm thick, stratose [layered] or not, "when fresh pliant, tough-coriaceous and peeling away easily from substrate", when dry coriaceous [leathery] or ligneous [woody] and brittle; white or "light-buff" to "cream-buff", sometimes "chamois" or "ochraceous-buff", rarely darkening to "ochraceous tawny"; smooth to tuberculate; margin adnate [firmly attached], abrupt or thinning out, colored as spore-bearing surface or lighter, (Nakasone), spore-bearing surface cream-colored to pale buff (Martin), spore-bearing surface white to pale ochraceous, even, (Julich)
HABITAT  found on a variety of conifers and hardwoods; causes a root and butt rot of woody plants; fruitbodies produced on slash, rotten logs, stumps, wood and roots, old conk; associated with a white rot^, (Ginns), associated with a white rot of conifer wood and occasionally of hardwood throughout North America, (Nakasone)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5.5(8) x (2)2.5-3 um, elliptic to cylindric, flattened on adaxial side, smooth, "amyloid or not, amyloid reaction distributed evenly or limited to a small part of the adaxial surface", colorless, acyanophilic, thin-walled^, BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-35 x 3-4 um, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connection at base, CYSTIDIA scattered to numerous throughout subiculum and hymenium, 40-60(120) x 2-5 um, embedded or slightly projecting, best observed in phloxine, cylindric, with rounded or tapered apex, colorless, thin-walled, clamped at base, flexuous [wavy], often with refractive, globular contents, positive or negative in sulfobenzaldehyde; HYPHAE dimitic; SUBICULUM consisting of fiber [skeletal] hyphae, generative hyphae and cystidia in a dense, tightly interwoven tissue, subicular hyphae 2-8 um wide, "thin-walled, nodose septate, moderately to frequently branched, hyphae next to substrate arranged horizontally, otherwise vertical"; fiber [skeletal] hyphae 1-3.5 um wide, colorless, "thick-walled, aseptate, sparingly branched, dextrinoid", abundant throughout fruitbody, best observed in Melzer's reagent, (Nakasone), DENDROHYPHIDIA densely interwoven, strongly dextrinoid in Melzer's reagent; gloeocystidia embedded or projecting, (Martin), SPORES 3.5-5.5(7) x (2)2.3-3(3.2) um; BASIDIA (15)25-40 x (2)3-5 um; GLOEOCYSTIDIA abundant, 30-120 x 3-6.5 um, cylindric to fusoid; SKELETAL HYPHAE 1.5-3.5 um, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to milk'
SIMILAR  See Scytinostroma protrusum for the differences from that very similar species.
SOURCES  Nakasone(7) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Martin, K.J.(3), Julich(5), Burt(1) (as Corticium), Ginns(5)
363
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scytinostroma jacksonii  Boidin^  Naturaliste Canad. 108: 199. 1981
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) fruitbody (in the herbarium) cream to tan, may become very granulose, tuberculate, 3) spores that are short-oblong to oval, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) gloeocystidia that are slender and thin-walled, the projecting ones often terminated by a small papilla, 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the generative hyphae with clamp connections, the skeletal hyphae strongly dextrinoid and branching.^ RANGE ^Scytinostroma jacksonii has been found in BC and MT (Ginns). The holotype is from BC.
FRUITING BODY  in the herbarium: effused, nearly smooth toward the narrow, very pale cream margin, may become very granulose, tuberculate, cream to alutaceous, adherent, not membranous, not friable, easy to section^, (Boidin(1))
HABITAT  on Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Tsuga sp. (hemlock); associated with a white rot^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5.25(6) x 2.8-3.2 um, short, oblong in side view, sometimes weakly depressed next to the apiculus, somewhat oval in face view because a little wider (up to 4 um) in the apicular part, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 22-25 um long and 3-4 um wide at the top, narrow in the middle (2 um wide for example), sterigmata 4-8 um long at maturity; GLOEOCYSTIDIA slender, 30-35 x 2.5-4.2 um, thin-walled, contents in part refringent, the emergent ones tapered and often terminated by a small papilla [illustrated as a small sphere], 1.2 um in diameter; IN SECTION 100 to 300 um excluding the tubercles; consisting of an upper dense zone that is strongly dextrinoid and a lower part of variable thickness appearing very pale in Melzer's reagent due to its loose structure and formed of the clamped generative hyphae, and of fibers more or less branched, 0.8-1.5-2 um wide, and moderately dextrinoid; the very dextrinoid fibers of the surface layer branch more or less dichotomously, they may have a thick-walled trunk 2.5-3 um wide, and branches irregularly disposed, long or short, strongly dextrinoid except near the thin-walled tips; in the wood fibers of the underlying wood, there are generative hyphae about 2 um wide, thin-walled, and non-dextrinoid; in the interstices of the substrate is formed a mycelial felt composed of generative hyphae but particularly of long, slender, dextrinoid hyphae, 0.8-1.2 um wide, not or rarely branched, and one can also distinguish fusiform gloeocystidia, 4-5 um wide, bearing 1-3 lateral papillae, (Boidin(1))
NAME ORIGIN  in honor of Professor H.S. Jackson
SIMILAR  Other Scytinostroma species have spores of a different size or shape (Boidin(1)).
SOURCES  Boidin(1) (in French), Boidin(2) (in French), Ginns(5)
364
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scytinostroma ochroleucum  (Bres. & Torrend) Donk^  Fungus 26: 20. 1956;  Gloeocystidium ochroleucum  Bres. & Torrend;  Gloeocystidium ochroleucum  Bres. ex Bourdot & Galzin  Bull. Soc. mycol. Fr. 28(4): 365 (1913) [1912]  (proposed current name);  Scytinostroma lusitanicum  (Trotter) P.M. Kirk  Index Fungorum 120: 1. 2014;  Corticium abeuns  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood and less often hardwood, 2) a fruitbody that is pale ochraceous to cinnamon-buff, and smooth, 3) spores that are broadly cylindric, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) sulfo-positive gloeocystidia that may show 1 or more lateral papillae, 5) a basal layer of dextrinoid, dichotomously branching skeletal hyphae, and a more superficial layer containing generative hyphae that are thin-walled and simple-septate.^ | 'Rogers and Jackson ... hesitated in placing C. abeuns in synonymy because then had not seen the type of S. ochroleucum. They, having examined all the other collections cited by Burt, found only one New York and one British Columbia collection to "resemble the type". Julich and Stalpers ... and Boidin and Lanquetin ... accept C. abeuns as a synonym but do not give supporting evidence.' (Ginns). |The online Species Fungorum, accessed September 12, 2022 listed the current name as Gloeocystidium ochroleucum Bres. ex Bourdot & Galzin, Bull. Soc. mycol. Fr. 28(4): 365 (1913) [1912], but MycoBank, accessed on the same date, listed the current name as Scytinostroma ochroleucum (Bres. & Torrend) Donk. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, AL, AZ, CA, NH, and NY, (Ginns). Collections were examined from Guadeloupe, France, Canary Islands, Gabon, Morocco, and India, and it has been reported also from Scandinavia, Transcaucasus, Azores, Himalayas, and Japan, (Boidin).
FRUITING BODY  effused, thin-membranous, solid, detaching like a skin without strong traction, then thickening, with waxy surface that is smooth, cream, chamois, cinnamon or a little paler, isabelline or a little lighter, more rarely ash-gray or argillaceous; margin paler, thinning out rapidly, sometimes villose or powdery, (Boidin), coriaceous [leathery], adnate [firmly attached]l spore-bearing surface pale ochraceous to cinnamon-buff, even, (Julich), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock); on bark; on decaying wood, (Ginns), on hardwoods and conifers (Julich), on yew in United Kingdom; probably all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-11(13) x 5-6.5(7) um, broadly cylindric, smooth, inamyloid^; BASIDIA (2)-4-spored, 40-60-80 x 6.5-8 um, narrowly clavate; hymenium continuous, composed of basidia and gloeocystidia; narrow non-dextrinoid hyphae sometimes project above the basidia; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 80-130-250 x (3)4.5-9(12) um, sulfo-positive, walls somewhat thickened in the basal part (they may have septa, and some show 1-(2-3) lateral papillae); IN SECTION 130-800 um thick, formed of two distinct layers, a basal layer of 100-600 um, composed of dextrinoid skeletal hyphae 1.5-2 um wide, and the hymenium at first thin but thickening, 50-220 um thick, without skeletal hyphae or showing only rare scattered skeletal hyphae; generative hyphae are 1.5-3.5(5) um wide, thin-walled and simple-septate; the skeletal hyphae have a short stem, bifurcating the first time to give to long, spreading arms that may in their turn branch 1-2(3) times, (Boidin), SPORES (8)10-13(15) x 4.5-6.5(8), elliptic; BASIDIA 30-70 x 6-11 um; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 50-110(130) x (4)5-11(13) um, clavate to fusoid; SKELETAL HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ocher - white'
SIMILAR  Other Pacific Northwest species of Scytinostroma have different spores (Boidin).
SOURCES  Boidin(2) (in French), Julich(5), Burt(1), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
365
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scytinostroma portentosum  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Donk^  Fungus 26: 20. 1956;  == Corticium portentosum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Corticium diminuens  Berk. & M.A. Curtis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on a variety of hardwoods and shrubs, 2) fruitbodies that are cream to pale ocher, and smooth to somewhat uneven, the margin distinctly bounded, in part thinning out, 3) spores that are round, smooth, amyloid, and colorless, with a distinct apiculus, 4) 2-4-spored basidia, 5) gloeocystidia that are scarce or absent, and 6) a dimitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections, the skeletal hyphae dextrinoid. Adolf and Oluna Ceska report that patches on Robinia (locust) have a strong naphthalene (mothball) odor.^ RANGE ^Scytinostroma portentosum has been found in BC, ID, ON, AK, AL, AZ, CA, FL, IN, KY, LA, ME, MO, NY, OH, PA, TX, VA, and VT, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland, and in Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, attached tightly but detachable in separate pieces, forming patches up to about 0.1cm thick and several centimeters across; cream to ocherish; "smooth, dull, somewhat uneven"; "margin distinctly bounded, in part somewhat thinning out"^, (Breitenbach), effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], membranaceous; cream to pale ochraceous, (Julich), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on Acacia, Acer (maple), Aleurites, Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Bouganvillea, Carya (hickory), Crossosoma (rockflower), Gleditsia (locust), Juniperus (juniper), Mortonia, Prosopis, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Sambucus (elderberry), Sapindus (soapberry), (Ginns), on Hedera helix (ivy), according to literature on Salix (willow) as well as other hardwoods and shrubs; spring to fall, (Breitenbach), usually on underside of fallen branches or trunks; probably all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-5.5(6) um in diameter, round, smooth, amyloid, colorless, with distinct apiculus^; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 25-40 x 5-6 um, cylindric-clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE dimitic; GENERATIVE HYPHAE 1.5-2.5 um wide, "thin-walled, sparsely septate", without clamp connections; SKELETAL HYPHAE 1.5-2.5 um wide, "thick-walled, branched, dextrinoid, some solid", ends generally straight; subhymenium and subiculum stratified by parallel skeletal hyphae (stratification also visible with a hand lens), (Breitenbach), SPORES 4.5-6 x 4.5-5.5 um, round to broadly elliptic; BASIDIA 30-55(65) x (4)4.5-6(7) um; GLOEOCYSTIDIA scarce or absent, 30-70 x 3-5 um; GENERATIVE HYPHAE 1.2-3 um wide; SKELETAL HYPHAE 1.5-2.5 um wide, ultimate part "simple or rarely once branched, branches then very long, not dendroid, almost forming a layer, parallel to and along the hymenium", (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Julich(5), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
366
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scytinostroma protrusum  (Burt) Nakasone^  Mycologia 80: 555. 1988;  Corticium protrusum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Scytinostroma protrusum is very similar to Scytinostroma galactinum (Fr.) Donk, except that S. protrusum subsp. protrusum 1) has slightly smaller and narrower spores on average, 2) the amyloid reaction is limited to a small part of the adaxial spore surface (in S. galactinum amyloid or not, amyloid reaction distributed evenly or limited to a small part of the adaxial surface), 3) has slight cultural differences, 4) grows on hardwoods (S. galactinum on conifers and occasionally hardwoods), and 5) is distributed within North America in the southeastern United States (S. galactinum throughout U.S.), (Nakasone). S. protrusum subsp. septentrionale has spore width in the range of S. galactinum, but 1) has slight cultural differences from the other two, 2) grows on hardwoods (rarely on conifer wood), and 3) is distributed within North America in the northern United States, (Nakasone).^ RANGE ^Subsp. protrusum has been found in FL, GA, IL, IN, KY, and MD, and subsp. septentrionale in ID, MI, MN, NY, and WI, (Ginns). Members of the S. galactinum complex do occur in Europe: in particular a collection from France was found to be similar to S. protrusum subsp. septentrionale, (Nakasone).
FRUITING BODY  see Scytinostroma galactinum, which is macroscopically indistinguishable
HABITAT  subspecies protrusum is often associated with a root rot of various hardwoods, especially apple, subspecies septentrionale is found typically on hardwoods such as Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), and Populus^, (Nakasone)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES of subsp. protrusum (4)4.5-5(6) x 2-2.5(3) um, amyloid reaction limited to a small part of the adaxial spore surface, SPORES of subsp. septentrionale (4)4.5-5.5(6) x (2)2.5-3 um, (Nakasone)^
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Scytinostroma galactinum is similar (see NOTES above).
SOURCES  Nakasone(7), Ginns(5)
367
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scytinostromella arachnoidea  (Peck) Hjortstam^  Mycotaxon 54: 192. 1995;  == Scytinostroma arachnoideum  (Peck) Gilb.;  == Hydnum arachnoideum  Peck;  Corticium quaesitum  H.S. Jacks. & Dearden  
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a soft-cottony to somewhat waxy, easily separable fruitbody that is cream to pale buff, smooth to papillate or strongly hydnaceous, the margin abrupt, floccose, and rhizomorphic, 3) spores that are oval to nearly round, minutely echinulate, amyloid, and colorless, 4) projecting gloeocystidia that are cylindric or with irregular constrictions and swellings, and are not incrusted, and 5) subicular hyphae of 3 types: a) narrow, thick-walled, aseptate, dextrinoid, b) narrow, thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, and non-dextrinoid, and c) wide and with rare clamp connections, non-dextrinoid.^ RANGE ^Scytinostromella arachnoidea has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AK, AZ, FL, NC, NH, NM, and NY, (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  "annual, soft-cottony, easily separable"; cream to pale buff; "smooth to papillate or strongly hydnaceous"; margin rhizomorphic, (Gilbertson), widely effused, 0.04-0.06cm thick, subceraceous [somewhat waxy]; cream buff; "broken into tufted areolae, exposing the woolly floccose subiculum"; "margin abrupt floccose", (Jackson)
HABITAT  Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce), P. rubens (Red Spruce), P. sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock); rotted log; log; associated with a white rot^, (Ginns(5))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 2.5-3.5 um, oval to nearly round, minutely echinulate, amyloid, colorless in KOH solution^; BASIDIA 14-16 x 5-5.5 um, clavate, with median constriction; CYSTIDIA hymenial, "as projecting ends of large, thin-walled hyphae", "cylindric or with irregular constrictions and swellings", 6-8 um wide and projecting up to 70 um, not encrusted; subicular hyphae of 3 types: 1) 2-2.5 um wide, thick-walled, aseptate, moderately to strongly dextrinoid, 2) 2-2.5 um, thin-walled, nodose-septate (septa with clamp connections), not dextrinoid, and 3) 5-8 um wide, thin-walled, with rare clamp connections, not dextrinoid, (Gilbertson), gloeocystidia cylindric or with irregular constrictions and swellings; hyphae of 2 types: some thick-walled, aseptate, dextrinoid, (Martin), SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 3-3.5 um, nearly round or broadly elliptic, "slightly depressed on one side with inconspicuous apiculus", minutely asperulate, strongly amyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-45 x 5-5.5 um, narrowly clavate, sterigmata upright, subulate; GLOEOCYSTIDIA numerous, 60-120 x 5.5-8 um, cylindric to clavate, somewhat flexuous [wavy], "contents guttulate becoming pseudoseptate after withdrawal of contents"; an upper layer of more or less upright, thin-walled hyphae with clamp connections gives rise to the gloeocystidia and basidia; subiculum made up in part of densely interwoven basal layer of fibrous, nonseptate hyphae, 1.5-2.5 um wide, with thick walls, turning brown in Melzer's reagent, (Jackson), SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 3-3.5 um, oval, finely asperulate, and strongly amyloid; gloeocystidia, sulfo-reaction unknown; possesses dextrinoid, sparsely branched hyphae, (Boidin)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'arachnoid' or 'cobwebby'
SIMILAR  Scytinostromella heterogenea has gloeocystidia and thick-walled, encrusted cystidia, and Scytinostromella humifaciens has thin-walled cystidia and no gloeocystidia, whereas S. arachnoidea has gloeocystidia but no cystidia, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Gilbertson(9) (as Scytinostroma), Boidin(2) (as "Scytinostroma" arachnoideum, in French, not full description), Martin, K.J.(3) (as Scytinostroma), Jackson(1) (as Corticium quaesitum), Ginns(5) (as Scytinostroma), Ginns(23)
368
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scytinostromella heterogenea  (Bourdot & Galzin) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort., 171. 1968;  == Peniophora heterogenea  Bourdot & Galzin;  Gloeocystidiellum heterogeneum  (Bourdot & Galzin) Donk
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on bark and barkless wood of hardwoods and conifers, 2) a somewhat pellicular fruitbody that is delicate, easily separated from the substrate, white then yellowish, and smooth (cystidia visible under 50x lens), the margin not differentiated, the subiculum thin and loosely cottony, rhizomorphic strands white and fine, 3) spores that are small, nearly round to elliptic, asperulate with small, mostly rounded warts, amyloid and colorless, 4) cystidia of 2 types: a) gloeocystidia that are cylindric to fusiform or narrowly clavate, with granular contents, and either sulfo-positive (Eriksson) or sulfo-negative (Ginns(24)), and b) pseudocystidia that are thick-walled, encrusted tips of skeletal hyphae that often penetrate the hymenium, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, with thin-walled generative hyphae that have clamp connections, and thick-walled skeletal (or pseudoskeletal) hyphae that have a pink tint in Melzer's reagent, the skeletal hyphae predominating in the rhizomorphic strands.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, ON, CA, MI, and NM, and it has also been reported from AZ, (Ginns). It occurs from Denmark in the south of Scandinavia to N. Lappland in the north, but also in other parts of Europe, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  effused [spread out], subpellicular to submembranous, easily separated from substrate; "at first white, then yellowish, in the herbarium often darkening to pale buff"; smooth (under 50x lens with projecting cystidia); margin not differentiated; subiculum loose, cottony; white rhizomorphic strands present in subiculum and periphery^, (Eriksson), effused, pellicular, the largest piece studied 7cm x 3cm and very thin; pale yellow, "light ochraceous buff", "pinkish buff", "warm buff" to "cartridge buff"; smooth, a delicate brittle crust; margin white to pale yellow, thin, adnate [firmly attached], typically with uncommon, thin (up to 0.015cm wide), branched, white to pallid strands; subiculum thin, loosely cottony, white to pallid, (Ginns(24)), surface smooth, cracking sparingly; margin pale yellow, byssoid [cottony] or with rhizomorphs, (Freeman)
HABITAT  on bark and barkless wood of hardwoods and conifers^, Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Pinus (pine), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns(24)), on decayed wood in humid forests, many from much decayed wood of Picea (spruce), but also on Alnus (alder), Pinus, and Salix (willow), (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.2-4.0 x (2.4)2.6-3.2 um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, asperulate, amyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, walls slightly thickened, spore with a small, rounded, indistinct apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 14-24 x 4-6 um, suburniform, typically broadly clavate, sterigmata 4 um long; GLOEOCYSTIDIA "arising in the subiculum, or from subhymenial hyphae", cylindric to narrowly clavate, "some with apex fusoid", 40-110 x 7-8 um, sulfo-negative, the walls thin, colorless, encrusted with scattered yellow granules or crystals in KOH; CYSTIDIA-LIKE elements "are the thick-walled, incrusted tips of skeletal hyphae which penetrate the hymenium"; HYPHAE dimitic; generative hyphae 1.6-4.4(6.0) um, "loosely woven, distinct", "with a single clamp connection at each septum, frequently branched and septate", the walls thin, colorless, inamyloid, and acyanophilic; skeletal hyphae "scattered in the subiculum but easily found, predominating in the strands", 2.0-3.6 um wide, unbranched, aseptate except for a clamp connection at the base, pale yellow in KOH, pale yellow with a pink tint in Melzer's reagent, cyanophilic, the walls up to 1.4 um thick on the broadest skeletal hyphae, some with the terminal 30 um heavily encrusted "and projecting through the hymenium as cystidia", (Ginns(24)), SPORES 3.5-5 x 2.5-3.5 um, nearly round to elliptic, "with thin or somewhat thickened walls, asperulate with small, mostly rounded warts, some oval or oblong, amyloid"; BASIDIA 15-20 x 3.5-5 um, clavate-suburniform, often constricted, with a basal clamp connection, normally 4-spored; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) gloeocystidia developed from generative hyphae, 60-100 x 5-12 um, "thin-walled, generally fusiform, often with apical schizopapillae, protoplasm with droplike, granular, or irregular oily contents with sulfoaldehyde reaction", strongly stained in cotton blue, especially in the apical part, and 2) "pseudocystidia, formed by thick-walled hyphae, developed from thin-walled hyphae in the subiculum", bending towards and often penetrating the hymenium, apical part 79-100 x 10-15 um, encrusted by crystalline matter; HYPHAE dimitic; generative hyphae 1.5-4 um wide, thin-walled, in the subhymenium richly branched and with clamp connections, in the subiculum straighter and with more sparse clamp connections and branches; pseudoskeletal hyphae 1.5-2.5 um wide, straight and thick-walled, rarely with clamp connections and branches; RHIZOMORPHS composed of pseudoskeletal and generative hyphae of varying width (up to 5 um), "often encrusted by crystals or by rounded resinous bodies", (Eriksson), gloeocystidia sulfobenzaldehyde positive (Freeman)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'heterogeneous'
SIMILAR  Scytinostromella humifaciens has thin-walled, awl-shaped cystidia, (Freeman). Cystidia (gloeocystidia) of S. humifaciens arise from thin-walled hyphae, (Eriksson). Scytinostromella arachnoidea has gloeocystidia but no cystidia, and S. humifaciens has thin-walled cystidia and no gloeocystidia, whereas S. heterogenea has gloeocystidia and thick-walled, encrusted cystidia, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Ginns(24) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Eriksson(7), Freeman, G.W.(1), Ginns(23)
369
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scytinostromella humifaciens  (Burt) G.W. Freeman & R.H. Petersen^  Mycologia 71: 86. 1979;  == Peniophora humifaciens  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a fruitbody that is a delicate white crust covering a loose, cottony, white subiculum, the surface smooth to sometimes wrinkled, the margin cottony and pale cream, rhizomorphic strands pallid to brown in the subiculum and in the periphery of the fruitbody, 3) spores that are small, broadly elliptic to nearly round, amyloid, and finely verrucose with rounded or oblong warts, but sometimes appearing smooth, 4) suburniform basidia, 5) cystidia that are awl-shaped, projecting, thin-walled, and sulfo-negative, and 6) a dimitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, the narrower rhizomorphic strands with only generative hyphae, the wider ones with both generative and skeletal hyphae.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, ID, and MT, (Ginns(24)). It has not yet been recorded from Scandinavia (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  effused [spread out], about 3cm x 2cm, pellicular, a delicate crust loosely attached to a sparse subiculum; when fresh white, in the herbarium becoming "cartridge buff", "cream buff" to "olive buff", cream to pale yellow; surface smooth to sometimes rugose [wrinkled], sparsely fissured; margin up to 0.2cm wide, byssoid [cottony], pale cream; subiculum delicate, of a loose cottony texture, white; hyphal strands up to 0.02cm wide, "extending beyond the margin and beneath the subiculum" pallid to brown^, (Ginns(24)), effused [spread out], athelioid, smooth, soft and light-colored when fresh, very brittle when dried; pale buff, "with brown rhizomorphic strands in the subiculum and in the periphery of the fruitbody", (Eriksson)
HABITAT  on the "underside of 1) a very rotten stick on ground, 2) rotted log and 3) charred and rotted wood of conifers"; Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)^, (Ginns(24))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.0-3.8 x 2.6-3.2 um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, "finely verrucose but sometimes appearing smooth", amyloid, thin-walled, with a small, rounded, indistinct apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-26 x 4.0-5.0 um, suburniform, finally cylindric to subclavate, sterigmata 4.8 um long; the hymenial elements (basidia and cystidia) appear to arise from small clavate cells, 12-14 x 5 um: a relatively broad cylindric extension occurs from the apex of these cells and becomes either a cystidium or a basidium; CYSTIDIA 35-60 x 3.5-5.0 um, projecting to 24 um, subulate [awl-shaped], thin-walled, some containing a few oil droplets, the contents sulfo-negative, colorless in KOH; gloeocystidia none; HYPHAE dimitic, subicular hyphae "loosely arranged and distinct, becoming more compact near the subhymenium"; subhymenium about 30 um thick, "the hyphae densely compacted, with all hymenial elements arising at the same level"; generative hyphae (1.6)2.0-5.0(6.0) um wide, colorless, with clamp connections, thin-walled or up to 2.0 um thick and obscuring the lumen; HYPHAL STRANDS when narrow (15-60 um) pallid, monomitic, the hyphae colorless, 3-4(7) um wide, with thin walls, "in KOH encrusted with numerous granules that are slightly refractive", 0.5-0.8 um in diameter, hyphal strands when broad (+/- 100 um wide) tan to brown, the generative hyphae 3-6 um wide, with wall thin to moderately thick, the skeletal hyphae (2)3-4(5.5) um wide, "with the rare clamp connection joining two thick-walled cells, occasionally branched, with walls pale yellow brown to pale brown, thick (typically with capillary lumen), with resinous drops on the surface", (Ginns(24)), SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 3-3.5 um, broadly elliptic, asperulate with rounded or oblong warts, amyloid; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 3-5 um, clavate-suburniform, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA (gloeocystidia) 45-60 x 3.5-5 um, pointed, thin-walled, with oily contents and evidently also resinous excretions; HYPHAE "thin-walled generative hyphae, 1.5-4 um wide, and thick-walled fibre-hyphae, 1-2 um wide; rhizomorphic strands composed of thin-walled hyphae of various types, some very narrow and sparsely septate, some wide, more closely branched", (Eriksson), SPORES 3.0-4.0 x 2.0-3.0 um, oval to nearly round; usually both hyphal types (generative and skeletal) can be observed in the rhizomorphs but not in the fruitbody; in addition, pseudoskeletals (thick-walled with true septa) can be observed in the rhizomorphs; the rhizomorphs arise from hyphal cordons that intertwine: it is necessary to tease these tissues apart under a dissecting scope with fine needles, because they are brittle and shatter in a crush mount, (Freeman)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Scytinostromella heterogenea has thick-walled encrusted cystidia (Freeman). Cystidia (pseudocystidia) of Scytinostromella heterogenea arise from thick-walled hyphae, (Eriksson). Scytinostromella heterogenea has gloeocystidia and thick-walled, encrusted cystidia, and Scytinostromella arachnoidea has gloeocystidia but no cystidia, whereas S. humifaciens has thin-walled cystidia and no gloeocystidia, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Ginns(24) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Eriksson(7), Freeman, G.W.(1), Ginns(23)
370
FAMILY  Sebacinaceae, Order Sebacinales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sebacina epigaea  (Berk. & Broome) Neuhoff^  Z. Pilzk. 10: 71. 1931;  == Tremella epigaea  Berk. & Broome;  Sebacina atrata  Burt;  Sebacina cokeri  Burt;  Tremella gyrosoalba  Lloyd
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sebacina epigaea is characterized among Sebacina species by 1) its pustulate origin, followed by confluence to form interrupted or wavy effused gelatinous sheets, 2) the striking palisade layer of slender paraphyses, and 3) the usually numerous angular or apiculate cells, (Martin). Other features include 4) resupinate growth on hardwood or soil, rarely conifer wood, sometimes debris or dung, 5) a fruitbody that is waxy, gelatinous, firmly attached, whitish to grayish, and undulate-tuberculate, 6) spores that are oval, colorless, smooth, and inamyloid, with granular contents, 7) longitudinally septate hypobasidia with 4 epibasidia, and 8) hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Sebacina epigaea has been found in OR, NS, ON, CA, GA, IA, LA, MA, MO, NC, NH, NY, and WI, (Ginns). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland, and in Asia, (Breitenbach). There is a collection from BC by O. Ceska deposited at the University of British Columbia.
FRUITING BODY  when moist appears like a flat waxy patch up to 0.1cm thick and several centimeters across, but barely visible when dry, fruiting body attached firmly to substrate, consistency wax-like, gelatinous; white-gray; "opalescent, surface uneven, shiny when moist, but dull when dry"; "margin distinctly bounded and irregular"^, (Breitenbach), arising in small patches with indeterminate margins that expand and coalesce to form rather thick, interrupted to continuous fruitings, adnate [firmly attached], consistency soft-gelatinous to cartilaginous; "white to grayish-hyaline", "drying to a hyaline or yellowish-brown vernicose film"; surface undulate-tuberculate, often pruinose on drying; "margins indeterminate to somewhat abrupt", (Martin)
HABITAT  on hardwood, rarely conifer wood; Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Elaeagnus, Fraxinus (ash), Juniperus (juniper), Mimosa, Populus, Quercus (oak); rotten wood; branches; old hard heart of branch; bark at bases of live trees; underside of logs; fallen leaves and debris; underside of very old cow dung; soil^, (Ginns), "on plant remains lying on the ground, also commonly growing over soil, rocks, etc.", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), "on soil, bases of living trees, and the lower sides of very rotten logs", (Martin)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 10-13 x 8-10 um, oval, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with granular contents, some germinating, also "scattered so-called resting spores with inflated tubercules present"^; HYPOBASIDIA 15-18 x 12-13 um, "longitudinally septate, with 4 epibasidia"; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE 1.5-2.5 um wide, "in part with undulating surface", septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 8-11-13.5 x 6-8(10) um, obovate to broadly ovate, flattened on one side, guttulate, "germinating by repetition or a stout germ tube, or frequently becoming transformed into angular thick-walled resting cells with several hyaline subulate projections"; PROBASIDIA 14-16-19 x 10-12-14 um, "at first clavate, often tapering to a blunt point, finally ovate, conspicuously granular or guttulate", "becoming 4-celled by longitudinal division, each cell bearing a tubular epibasidium 1.5-2.5 um in diameter, up to 100 um long, the tips expanded, rarely bearing two sterigmata, only one of which functions"; hymenium of erect fertile hyphae 2-3 um wide, "bearing basidia in a zone varying with age up to 70 um wide", and a palisade-like layer of erect, simple to little-branched PARAPHYSES 1.5-2 um wide, "rising 40-80 um above the basidia, frequently with short spur-like branches near the tips, bearing minute granules"; in section 150-500 um thick, with a thick basal region of distinct, colorless, loosely interwoven hyphae, without clamp connections, 1.5-2.5 um wide, giving rise to hymenium, (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'on earth'
SIMILAR  Sebacina incrustans in eastern North America also covers plant debris and soil, but has a "white-ocherish, non-opalescent color, is thicker and waxlike-crustose, and does not have tuberculate resting spores", (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Martin, G.W.(1), Ginns(5), Desjardin(6)*
371
FAMILY  Sebacinaceae, Order Sebacinales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sebacina lactescens  Burt^  Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 13: 336. 1926
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Sebacina lactescens is characterized by firm-gelatinous fruitbodies, stalked basidia, and conspicuous golden to brownish yellow gloeocystidia, (McNabb). Other features include dingy hyaline, dingy white, or pallid ochraceous fruitbodies that originate as pustules and become smooth or convoluted, coalescing to form irregular areas up to 10cm long, growth on hardwood and conifer bark and wood, spores that are short-cylindric to broadly elliptic and often slightly curved, and dikaryophyses. This is a common species on the west coast (R. Bandoni, pers. comm.): it has usually been known as Ductifera sucina (Moeller) K. Wells.^ | But at least one of Moeller's specimens of Exidia sucina was later found to be the same as Ductifera pululahuana (Pat.) Donk, and the earliest valid name for Ductifera sucina appears to be Sebacina lactescens Burt (K. Wells, pers. comm.). The description is derived from McNabb(10). RANGE ^There are collections of this species (as Ductifera sucina or D. succina) from BC and WA at the University of British Columbia. Worldwide distribution includes CA, NC, NM, Panama, Jamaica, Windward Islands, Brazil, Australia, (Klett(1)), and New Zealand (McNabb(10)).
FRUITING BODY  "firm-gelatinous, determinate, originating as pustules, becoming smooth or convoluted", coalescing to form irregular areas up to 10cm long, in section 0.3-1.2cm thick "sordid hyaline, dingy white or pallid ochraceous when fresh, drying to an ochraceous brown, irregular film"; margins abrupt^, (McNabb), arising as colorless pustules 0.05-0.2cm in diameter, becoming confluent to form a cerebriform [brain-like] to erumpent, somewhat convolute fruiting, waxy-gelatinous to firm waxy-gelatinous; white or gray to light ochraceous; margins free, determinate, (Klett), up to 0.035cm thick, waxy-gelatinous; grayish white when fresh, drying to a dark film, (Lowy) 
HABITAT  hardwood and conifer bark and wood^, (McNabb), on dead wood (Klett)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 9.3-13(15.4) x 5-8.7 um, short-cylindric to broadly elliptic, often slightly curved, colorless, apiculate, germination by repetition or by germ tubes^; PROBASIDIA 18-31(37) x 8-13 um, forming in groups on fertile hyphae, stalked, racket-shaped, with basal clamp connections, "becoming 2-celled by longitudinal or oblique septa or longitudinally cruciate-septate", sterigmata cylindric, up to 45 x 4.5 um; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 35-85 x 6-9(13) um, "clavate, subclavate or subfusiform, occasionally irregular, arising below probasidia", at first colorless, contents becoming golden to brownish yellow, granular; DIKARYOPHYSES simple or irregularly branched apically, 1-3 um wide, not or rarely arising from fertile hyphae; ascending layer below hymenium composed of loosely interwoven HYPHAE 1.5-4.5 um wide, distinct, colorless, clamp connections present; basal layer when present composed of hyphae lying parallel with substrate, compact, interwoven, distinct, colorless, (McNabb), SPORES (9)10-15 x (5)6-9 um, inequilateral-elliptic, apiculate, germinating by repetition, usually guttulate; BASIDIA formed in clusters on the fertile hyphae which are 1-2 um wide, proliferating through conspicuous clamp connections at the base of the probasidia, the basidia "arising as elongate structures, becoming ovate, obovate to pyriform", 14-30(40) x (9)10-15 um, "becoming 2-4-celled by longitudinal to oblique septa", epibasidia 3-4.5 um wide; GLOEOCYSTIDIA not emergent, 30-80 x 5-16.5 um, clavate to cylindric to subfusiform, at first colorless, "becoming yellow or brownish granular and flexuous"; DIKARYOPHYSES 1-3 um wide, simple to little-branched, "becoming indistinct, rarely arising from the fertile hyphae";
