HYPHAE 1.5-4.5 um wide, thin-walled, smooth, with clamp connections; mineral crystals sometimes scattered throughout, (Klett), SPORES 10.5-14.5 x 8-9.5 um, subcylindric, germinating by repetition; PROBASIDIA subclavate, metabasidia becoming ovoid, 4-celled with septa mostly oblique, 14.5-22.5 x 8.5-14 um, sterigmata long-cylindric, up to 50 x 5 um; GLOEOCYSTIDIA (55)70(80) x 12.5 um, subclavate with brownish granular contents; HYPHAE with clamp connections, (Lowy)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  McNabb(10) (as Ductifera sucina), Klett(1) (as Ductifera sucina), Lowy(2) (as Ductifera sucina)
372
FAMILY  Serpulaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Serpula himantioides  (Fr.) P. Karst.^  Bidrag Kannedom Finlands Natur Folk 48: 344. 1889;  == Merulius himantioides  Fr.;  Serpula lacrimans var. himantioides  (Fr.) W.B. Cooke;  Merulius brassicaefolius  Schwein.;  Merulius lacrimans var. tenuissimum  Berk. ex Cooke;  Merulius tenuis  Peck;  Merulius americanus  Burt;  Serpula americana  (Burt) W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  wild dry-rot
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on litter and decaying wood of confers and hardwoods, 2) a fleshy to tremelloid fruitbody with a merulioid or somewhat poroid surface that is brown with a cream-colored margin, sometimes with rhizomorphs, 3) spores that are elliptic or ovate, smooth, dextrinoid, and brown, 4) hyphae that are colorless or brown, both with clamp connections and both sometimes encrusted, skeletal hyphae acyanophilic and primarily confined to the hyphal strands.^ | Carlsen(1) have used molecular studies to demonstrate 5 phylogenetic species within the Serpula himantioides complex, 4 of them in North America. RANGE ^Serpula himantioides sensu lato has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, AL, AZ, CA, CO, DC, FL, GA, IA, IL, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MO, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, NV, OH, PA, SC, TN, VA, VT, WI, WV, and WY, (Ginns(5)). It has also been found in Cuba, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Latvia, Sweden, United Kingdom, South Africa, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka, (Cooke)
FRUITING BODY  single to confluent, forming large patches up to 100cm x 10cm; usually up to 0.05cm thick, sometimes up to 0.07cm thick; "when fresh more or less fleshy to tremelloid", at least in the areas close to the spore-bearing surface; spore-bearing surface "gyrose-plicate to gyrose-porose", pores up to 0.5cm across and from 0.05-0.5cm deep when labyrinthiform, "when shallow, net-like, more or less irregularly arranged, when young, very shallow, grey, then gold to cinnamon, olive or dark brown, when dry honey-brown, with a white margin"; subicular layers easily separable from the substrate in large sheets; sometimes with rhizomorphs; "odor not apparent to strong"^, (Cooke), spore-bearing surface merulioid, light brown to raw umber; margin cream-colored, (Martin), spore deposit yellow (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on litter and decaying wood of conifers and hardwoods^, (Cooke); on litter and rotten wood; dead trees; associated with a brown rot; conifers and hardwoods; causes significant butt rot in Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), trunk rot in Chamaecyparis nootkatensis (Alaska cedar), and heart rot in Picea glauca (White Spruce) and P. rubens (Red Spruce), (Ginns(5)), fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (7)10-11.5(12) x (4)5-7(8) um, ovate, flattened on one side, tawny or light brown in KOH-phloxine mount, apiculate^; BASIDIA 4-spored, averaging 36 x 7.3 um, sterigmata 7.2 um long; BASAL LAYER next to substrate with colorless and brown hyphae parallel with the substrate, 120 um thick, SUBHYMENIAL LAYER "appearing partly gelatinized, loosely arranged", parallel with the substrate but without brown hyphae, near the hymenium forming a denser layer perpendicular to the substrate, about 150 um thick; brown hyphae 5-8 um wide, colorless hyphae 2-5 um wide, both types sometimes encrusted, both types with simple or compound clamp connections, (Cooke), SPORES 10-14 x 5-6 um, narrowly elliptic, dextrinoid; hyphae with clamp connections, (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Serpula lacrimans has cyanophilic skeletal hyphae, and Meruliporia incrassata lacks skeletal hyphae, whereas Serpula himantioides has acyanophilic skeletal hyphae that are primarily confined to the hyphal strands, (Ginns(23)). M. incrassata also has a more poroid spore-bearing surface and prominent thick hyphal strands (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Cooke(5) (as Serpula lacrymans var. himantoides), Martin, K.J.(3), Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Buczacki(1)*, Carlsen(1), Desjardin(6)*
373
FAMILY  Serpulaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Serpula lacrimans  (Jacq.) J. Schroet.^  in F. Cohn, Kryptogamen-Flora Schlesien 3 (1): 466. 1888;  == Boletus lacrimans  Jacq.;  Merulius lacrimans  (Jacq.) Schumach.;  Merulius terrestris  (Peck) Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  dry-rot
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on horizontal timber, or sometimes bracket-like on vertical wood surfaces, mostly often indoors, 2) a cap surface when present that is silvery-white to gray (discoloring red-brownish when bruised), thick, lubricous-tomentose, and tuberculate-inflated, with a blunt white-tomentose margin, 3) a spore-bearing surface that is merulioid, and olive-yellow to brownish yellow or orange-brown or cinnamon, with a whitish-tomentose marginal zone and whitish to grayish rhizomorphs, 4) a spore print that is orange-brown to orange-yellow to brownish, 5) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and yellow, 6) smooth, fusiform cystidioles, and 7) a dimitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ | Serpula lacrimans is one of the principal dry rot fungi: the fungus can, according to Breitenbach(2), produce its own moisture after the initial stages of growth (and can therefore attack dry wood). RANGE ^Serpula lacrimans has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NS, ON, PQ, SK, AK, AL, AZ, CA, CO, CT, DC, FL, GA, IA, IL, KS, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MO, MT, NC, NE, NH, NJ, NM, NV, NY, PA, SC, UT, VA, VT, WV, and WY, (Ginns(5)). It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland, and in Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  5-100cm across or more, annual, forming widely spreading, nearly flat, fan-like sheets on horizontal surfaces, but sometimes bracket-like if growing on vertical surfaces, "soft and spongy when fresh"; upper surface or free margin "silvery-white to gray, hairy"; spore-bearing surface consisting of very shallow (0.1cm deep), 'large, irregular pits or "pores" formed by a honeycomb-like network of folds and ridges', olive-yellow to brownish yellow, rusty brown, orange-brown, or cinnamon; whitish or grayish mycelial strands often present; flesh dingy yellowish; "odor often unpleasant, musty"^, (Arora), resupinate to effuso-reflexed [bent outwards to form shelf-like cap], initially consisting of rounded, white, +/- smooth spots, forming pancake-like patches 0.3-1cm thick and several centimeters to decimeters across, "consistency spongy, gummy, soft but fibrous and tough"; when present, caps inflated, bracket-like, projecting up to 10cm and up to 2cm thick, the upper surface whitish to cream, "discoloring red-brownish when bruised", "lubricous-tomentose, tuberculate-inflated", margin "inflated, blunt, white-tomentose"; underside "merulioid, irregularly porose-labyrinthine-reticulate, pores also slit, pore layer mustard-yellow, olive-brown to rust-brown, marginal zone sterile and whitish-tomentose"; odor pleasantly fungoid when fresh, strongly unpleasant when old; taste mild, (Breitenbach), grayish white rhizomorphs up to 10cm long, (Lincoff), spore deposit yellow (Buczacki)
HABITAT  "serious pest of structural wood in old houses, buildings, ships, etc., usually developing indoors or in poorly ventilated situations, often hiding under floorboards"; bulging wood and musty odor are signs of its presence^, (Arora), on "conifer wood used in construction, more rarely on hardwood, commonly in old cellars, staircases, and other poorly ventilated rooms, grows over wood, walls, carpets, etc."; throughout the year, (Breitenbach); associated with a brown rot; wood of Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Abies magnifica [California Red Fir], Pinus contorta [Lodgepole Pine], Pinus ponderosa [Ponderosa Pine], Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata [Western Red Cedar], Tsuga mertensiana [Mountain Hemlock], (Ginns(5)), on conifer logs in woods, but more often encountered on indoor wood; June to January, but year-round indoors, (Lincoff)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-12.5 x 4-6 um, elliptic, smooth, thick-walled, spore print "orange-brown to orange-yellow to brownish"^, (Arora), SPORES 11-13(14) x 5.5-8 um, elliptic, smooth, yellow, some with droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 45-70 x 6-10 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIOLES between the basidia, 50-80 x 5.5-8 um, "fusiform, some sinuous, smooth"; HYPHAE dimitic; generative hyphae 2.5-6 um wide, colorless, with clamp connections; skeletal hyphae in basal layer and rhizomorphs 2-7 um wide, brownish, thick-walled, some encrusted with crystals, (Breitenbach), SPORES has cyanophilic inner wall (Lincoff), skeletal hyphae cyanophilic (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'weeping'
SIMILAR  Serpula himantioides is found on conifers in forests: it is thinner and smaller, (Breitenbach). S. himantioides is leathery and entirely crust-like (Lincoff). S. himantioides has acyanophilic skeletal hyphae that are primarily confined to the hyphal strands and Meruliporia incrassata lacks skeletal hyphae, whereas Serpula lacrimans has cyanophilic skeletal hyphae, (Ginns(23)). M. incrassata also has a more poroid spore-bearing surface and prominent thick hyphal strands, (Ginns(23)). Merulius species have white spores (Arora). Coniophora puteana ("wet rot") is another pest of structural lumber, with a similar growth habit, but the surface is irregularly wrinkled to bumpy, (Arora).
SOURCES  Arora(1), Breitenbach(2)*, Lincoff(2)*, Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Buczacki(1)*
374
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema adnatum  Hallenb.^  Mycotaxon 21: 397. 1984
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sistotrema adnatum is a member of the Sistotrema brinkmannii group, described as follows, "Fruitbodies effuse, smooth or grandinioid; hyphae with clamps, walls hyaline; gloeocystidia absent; basidia urniform, normally with 6-8 sterigmata; spores less than 9 um long, ellipsoid, subcylindrical, suballantoid, or subglobose, uninucleate (except for S. binucleosporum)", (Hallenberg, Latin name underlined). It is "distinguished by the adnate fruitbody with a continuous hymenium, the wide subicular hyphae with large ampullate clamps and the compact subhymenium", (Hallenberg).^ RANGE ^The holotype is from BC (Hallenberg).
FRUITING BODY  effused, thin, adnate [firmly attached]; yellowish white to cream; smooth, continuous; margin narrow, thinning out^, (Hallenberg)
HABITAT  type on fallen coniferous log^, (Hallenberg)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8 x 2.8-3.3 um, elliptic, adaxial side straight, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 6-spored, 19-27 x 4.5-5.5 um, urniform, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections that frequently are ampullate (up to 15 um wide); SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3.5-6 um wide, richly branched, thin-walled, contents somewhat oily; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 4-7.5 um wide, interwoven (but more or less parallel to the substrate), straight, colorless, slightly thick-walled, sparsely septate, (Hallenberg)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'adnate' referring to adnate (firm) attachment to substrate
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hallenberg(1), Ginns(5)
375
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema athelioides  Hallenb.^  Mycotaxon 21: 400. 1984
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sistotrema athelioides is a member of the Sistotrema brinkmannii group, the group described as follows, "Fruitbodies effuse, smooth or grandinioid; hyphae with clamps, walls hyaline; gloeocystidia absent; basidia urniform, normally with 6-8 sterigmata; spores less than 9 um long, ellipsoid, subcylindrical, suballantoid, or subglobose, uninucleate (except for S. binucleosporum)", (Hallenberg, Latin name underlined). Sistotrema athelioides is "distinguished from closely related taxa by the smooth, athelioid fruitbody with fibrillose margin (no cordons)".^ RANGE ^The type was found in BC, (Hallenberg).
FRUITING BODY  effused, athelioid; spore-bearing surface detachable, yellowish white to cream, smooth; subiculum thick, cobwebby, composed of narrow strands, whitish; margin fibrillose, no cordons^, (Hallenberg)
HABITAT  type on fallen coniferous log^ (Hallenberg)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8 x 3-4 um, subcylindric, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA (4)6-8-spored, 16-32 x 5-6 um, urniform, with basal clamp connection, mostly with a swollen base, some distinctly stemmed; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections that frequently are ampullate, 3.3-6.5 um wide, "usually with a yellowish, resinous content, stained brownish in sulfo-vanilline"; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE "richly branched with crystalline deposits"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE "somewhat thick-walled, frequently united in strands", (Hallenberg)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'athelioid'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hallenberg(1), Ginns(5)
376
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema binucleosporum  Hallenb.^  Mycotaxon 21: 409. 1984
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sistotrema binucleosporum is a member of the Sistotrema brinkmannii group, described as follows, "Fruitbodies effuse, smooth or grandinioid; hyphae with clamps, walls hyaline; gloeocystidia absent; basidia urniform, normally with 6-8 sterigmata; spores less than 9 um long, ellipsoid, subcylindrical, suballantoid, or subglobose, uninucleate (except for S. binucleosporum)", (Hallenberg, Latin name underlined). "Even if the cultured SS-mycelia are of some other origin I am convinced that these specimens represent a distinct taxon. Among the hitherto known species in Sistotrema it seems to be rather isolated due to the binucleate spores, the very thin and firm fruitbody and the small basidia and spores", (Hallenberg, genus name underlined).^ RANGE ^The holotype was found in BC (Hallenberg).
FRUITING BODY  very thin; effused, closely adnate [firmly attached], when dry almost invisible; spore-bearing surface grayish, smooth, porulose; margin indeterminate^, (Hallenberg)
HABITAT  type on fallen coniferous log^ (Hallenberg)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.3-3.8 x 1.5-1.8 um, elliptic to subcylindric, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 6-8-spored, 7-12 x 3-4 um, urniform to ovate, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, 1.5-3 um wide, colorless, thin-walled; subhymenial hyphae "richly branched and densely united, short-celled, originating from more straight and sparsely branched, basal hyphae", (Hallenberg)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'having spores with 2 nuclei'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hallenberg(1), Ginns(5)
377
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema brinkmannii  (Bres.) J. Erikss.^  Kungl. Fysiogr. Sallsk. Lund Forh. 18: 17. 1948;  == Odontia brinkmannii  Bres.;  Grandinia brinkmannii  (Bres.) Bourdot & Galzin;  Trechispora brinkmannii  (Bres.) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sistotrema brinkmannii is a member of the Sistotrema brinkmannii group, the group described as follows, "Fruitbodies effuse, smooth or grandinioid; hyphae with clamps, walls hyaline; gloeocystidia absent; basidia urniform, normally with 6-8 sterigmata; spores less than 9 um long, ellipsoid, subcylindrical, suballantoid, or subglobose, uninucleate (except for S. binucleosporum)", (Hallenberg, Latin name underlined). The features of Sistotrema brinkmannii include 1) resupinate growth on wood and other substrates, 2), a fruitbody that is soft and white, and becomes grandinioid, 3) suballantoid spores that are smooth, inamyloid, and acyanophilic, 4) 6-8-spored basidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, 6) crystalline matter that is frequent, especially in old fruitbodies.^ RANGE ^Collections were used from OR, PQ, AZ, MI, Austria, Denmark, France, and Sweden, (Hallenberg). Other reports of S. brinkmannii could be from various members of the Sistotrema brinkmannii complex in North America: British Columbia, Alberta, Manitoba, New Brunswick, Newfoundland, Northwest Territories (Mackenzie District), Nova Scotia, Ontario, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Georgia, Idaho, Iowa, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Missouri, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Rhode Island, Tennessee, and Virginia, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  effused, "soft when live, very brittle when dry"; spore surface whitish, grandinioid (smooth and porulose when very young), (Hallenberg, who refers to Eriksson(7) for detailed description), resupinate, effused, small to moderate in size, soft (very brittle when dried); white in live state (in herbarium white - cream - pale ochraceous); spore-bearing surface "becoming more or less grandinioid with sparse to dense aculei", rounded-conic-subcylindric, usually less than 0.1cm long; "margin not especially differentiated", (Eriksson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  both in hardwood and coniferous forests, in gardens etc.; mostly "on much decayed wood, but may be found on all kinds of debris as well as on peat, soil, old paper, dead fruitbodies of Aphyllophorales", etc.; early spring to late fall^, (Eriksson), on rotting wood and bark, herbaceous and fern debris, old leather articles, old fungal fruitbodies, and other organic substrates; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (3.5)4-4.5(5.5) x 2-2.2(2.5) um, suballantoid "with the abaxial side always convex and the adaxial side more or less concave", smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled, sometimes with 1 or 2 oil droplets^; BASIDIA 6-8-spored (rarely 4-spored), 12-20(24) x 3-5(7) um, at first ovoid, then urniform, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-6 um wide, with clamp connections, "those of the subiculum loosely interwoven in an open texture, in the subhymenium denser and more richly branched, some straight basal hyphae with somewhat thickened walls, other hyphae thin-walled", protoplasm rich in oily inclusions as droplets (in the living state) or irregular strands; crystalline matter frequent, especially abundant in old fruitbodies, "which finally get a chalky consistency", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Sistotrema oblongisporum distinguished from S. brinkmannii "by a smooth, adnate fruitbody of a more firm consistency, and by narrower, frequently straight spores", (Hallenberg) . See also SIMILAR section of Sistotrema coroniferum.
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Hallenberg(1), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
378
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema confluens  Pers.^  Neues Mag. Bot. 1: 108. 1794
ENGLISH NAME(S)  confluent Sistotrema, aromatic earthfan
NOTES  Also listed in Toothed category. Sistotrema confluens forms small white fan-shaped or part-funnel-shaped caps with thin, lobed margins, that often grow together so that a cap has several stems. The color may turn yellowish, orange, or brownish when the fruitbodies are old or bruised. The underside forms spines of various shapes and lengths (often flattened) and also ridges, sometimes even appearing poroid or gill-like. The cap surface is smooth to wrinkled: under a hand lens the surface is tomentose. The lateral stem tapers to a black base. There is a vanilla to disagreeable odor and mild taste. It fruits on needles, leaves, and other litter in the summer and fall. Microscopic characters include narrowly elliptic spores, 6-8-spored basidia, and a monomitic hyphal system.^ RANGE ^The accompanying photograph is from a WA collection. S. confluens is reported from AB, NS, QC, AZ, MI, MT, NC, NH, NY, VT, WI, (Ginns(5)), examined from ON, MI, NC, NH, TN, VA, and reported from AL, (Coker(1)), and found in the British Isles (Buczacki) and Finland and Sweden (Eriksson(7)). There is a collection from BC by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia.
FRUITING BODY  generally pileate [with a cap] "but may sometimes be resupinate on underside of leaves etc.", mostly 1-2cm wide, more or less flabellate [fan-shaped] "and often radially incised"; caps as a rule concrescent [growing together as a unit] with several stems, stem(s) narrowing downward, lateral, seldom central; fruitbody soft (young specimens brittle when dried, older ones more tough); white or pale cream but when old or when bruised "turning yellow or brownish", base of stem blackish; upperside of fruitbody "smooth or irregularly-concentrically wavy or wrinkled, under the lens appressed tomentose", spore-bearing surface underneath "varying from reticulate pores or flattened irpicoid plates, sometimes lamelloid", to 0.1-0.2cm long cylindric spines; odor 'distinct and characteristic, described by some people as vanilla, by others as "disagreeable" '^, (Eriksson), 1-2cm high and 1-2cm wide, "often formed like half a morning glory, i.e. fan-shaped with margin reflexed or lobed", tapering to a small lateral stem with a blunt base, stem rarely central, margin "lobed, thin, sterile"; cap "white, becoming creamy or buffy when rubbed"; cap surface "at first finely tomentose with rather loosely set, slender hairs", soon practically bald "but inherently fibrous, irregularly ridged and pitted or nearly smooth, very slightly viscid"; flesh about 0.1cm thick, "white, soft, tender and moderately but distinctly fibrous"; spore-bearing surface "originating as irregular, rarely anastomosing ridges and teeth, the ridges growing quite irregularly in height and soon forming small, interrupted plates and flattened teeth of different lengths", like a miniature Irpex, the longest about 0.1cm, "densely fimbriated at their ends by slender hyphae of irregular length which give a frosted appearance under low power", spore-bearing surface "of subwaxy character, not very decurrent", leaving about 0.5-0.7cm of stem smooth; mycelium "white, rather stringy, conspicuous, running extensively among the rotting pine needles"; odor faint, "taste sweetish-woody", (Coker, with Latin italicized), 1-2cm across, cap surface villous, tomentose, white, cream, then yellowish or pale orange when old or bruised, stem more or less excentric, 1-2cm x 0.2-0.3cm, pruinose, white, then yellowish or ochraceous orange; not edible, (McNeil), flesh waxy to powdery, soft; stem usually flattened (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on ground "among mosses and fallen leaves and other litter in hardwood or conifer forests, less often in open fields"^ (Eriksson), needles and wood on the ground, hosts Pinus sp., P. contorta, Populus sp., (Ginns), our collections occurring "in mats of pine straw" [pine needle beds], (Coker), gregarious, forming colonies more or less spread out on the soil among plants and mosses in forests that are coniferous, mixed, or hardwood; fruiting in summer and fall, (McNeil)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6 x 2-2.5 um, narrowly elliptic - suballantoid, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 6-8 spored (a few 4-spored), (12)14-18(22) x 3.5-4.5(6) um, subglobose when young, urniform when mature, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, with many oil droplets, hyphal inflations to 5 or 7 um wide sometimes present, "hyphal direction mainly parallel in the trama" of the stem, cap, and spore-bearing surface, (Eriksson), SPORES measurement of one collection 3.8-5 x 1.8-2 um, "smooth, white", "with an excentric mucro and a droplet"; BASIDIA 6-spored, about 4 um wide, (Coker), SPORES measurement 4-5 x 2-3 um, white in deposit, (McNeil), SPORES measurement 4.5-6 x 2-2.5 um, inamyloid, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'confluent', referring to the tendency of fruitbodies to intergrow
SIMILAR  Irpex lacteus can be somewhat similar, generally forming larger fruitbodies.
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Ginns(5), Coker(1), McNeil(1)* (in French), Buczacki(1)*
379
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema coroniferum  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Donk^  Fungus 26: 4. 1956;  == Gloeocystidium coroniferum  Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Trechispora coronifera  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.;  Corticium atkinsonii  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a loosely attached fruitbody that is soft, membranous, white, and smooth to floccose-granular, the margin not differentiated, 3) spores that are suballantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) gloeocystidia present but often difficult to recognize, enclosed or somewhat projecting, somewhat tube-like, flexuous [wavy] and often constricted, thin-walled, obtuse, sulfo-negative, and contents grainy or oily, colorless or yellowish, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, the subhymenial hyphae richly branched, and the basal hyphae wider and more sparsely branched.^ RANGE ^Sistotrema coroniferum has been found in OR, ON, AZ, CO, IA, LA, MA, NY, OH, and VT, (Ginns), as well as Austria (Rogers), Denmark, Finland, and Sweden, (Eriksson), and Switzerland and Asia (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, "loosely adnate and as a rule detachable in small pieces or even subathelioid", mostly rather thin (0.005-0.01cm), consistency soft (brittle when dried); white (usually remaining so in the herbarium); smooth; margin not differentiated, no rhizomorphs^, (Eriksson), resupinate, loosely attached, "forming thin, membranous patches" several centimeters across, consistency "membranous, powdery, soft"; white; "smooth to floccose-granular"; margin diffuse, (Breitenbach), when fresh, very thin, waxy; pure white (when dry whitish); under binocular continuous or minutely granular (under binocular when dry delicate reticulate-poroid), (Rogers), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on "much decayed, moist wood of conifers", especially Picea (spruce), but also of hardwoods^ such as Fagus (beech), Betula (birch), Populus, and Salix (willow), (Eriksson), on dead, barkless wood; throughout the year, (Breitenbach); on fallen cones and dead wood; decaying, charred wood; associated with a white rot; Acer (maple), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Quercus (oak), Ulmus (elm), (Ginns), on rotting wood, dead bramble stems, and old fungal fruitbodies; all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4.5)5-6(7) x 2-2.5 um, "suballantoid, adaxial side somewhat concave, but may be straight in some spores", smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 15-20(25) um long, urniform, 4-5 um at the narrowest point, 6-8 um at the basal part, with basal clamp connection, usually 6-spored, often 7-spored, and rarely 4-spored or 8-spored; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 60-100 x 6-10 um, flexuous [wavy], thin-walled, often constricted, obtuse, enclosed or somewhat projecting (20-40 um), "varying in number, often few and irregularly distributed in the hymenium, difficult to find, areas of hymenium with groups of several cystidia may alternate with spaces with few or none", contents grainy or oily, colorless or yellowish, "in the dry material forming irregular strings of contracted oil-rich protoplasm", gloeocystidia difficult to recognize, especially in dried material, "as they are easily confused with segments of oil-rich hyphae"; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-4 um wide, short-celled, richly branched, thin-walled; BASAL HYPHAE 4-6 um, "straight, with sparse branches, with thin or slightly thickened walls, in some specimens with ampullate inflations near septa", (Eriksson), SPORES 4.6-4.9 x 2.1-2.4 or 5.6-6.5 x 2.4-3 um (in one collection), "elliptic to cylindric-elliptic, slightly allantoid", smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-6-8-spored (rarely also 1-spored, 2-spored, or 3-spored), 14-24 x 4-7 um, urniform, with basal clamp connection; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 30-80 x 6-9 um, cylindric, sulfo-negative; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-5 um wide, septa with clamp connections, swollen up to 12 um at the septa, (Breitenbach), SPORES 4.5-6 x 2-3 um, oblong-elliptic to subcylindric, slightly depressed on inside to curved; BASIDIA "when immature short-ellipsoid, forming a prolongation truncate-cylindric or slightly expanded at the summit", 10-27.5 x 5-7 um, 6-8-spored, sterigmata 3-4 um long, slender, peripheral; GLOEOCYSTIDIA (13)20-100 x (4.5)5-7(9.5) um, "elongate, obtuse, contorted, sometimes subcylindric, usually irregular, filled with yellow resinoid material", may be difficult to detect in "specimens with coarse basal mycelium having the same content as the gloeocystidia"; HYPHAE mostly distinct, (2)3-7(10.5) um, with clamp connections throughout, SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE more slender than basal hyphae, richly branched, BASAL HYPHAE thick, long-celled, "sometimes filled with yellow refractive resinoid material, ampullate at the septa, not always well developed"; CRYSTALS (calcium oxalate) may be present or absent, (Rogers)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing a crown', perhaps referring to the basidia
SIMILAR  Sistotrema resinicystidium (which also has gloeocystidia) differs in several respects: 1) it is white even when dried, 2) it is "smooth and brittle, easily detachable, at least in small parts", 3) the spore-bearing surface is "smooth or nearly so, not densely tuberculate-grandinioid under the lens", 4) the spores are suballantoid, mostly with a clearly concave adaxial side, 5) the neck of the basidium is shorter, not prolonged into a tube, and 6) "gloeocystidia are colorless or pale yellow, with stringy, oily contents", (Eriksson). Sistotrema sernanderi, found at least in Ontario and Europe, also has gloeocystidia, but has (1-2-)4-spored basidia, (Eriksson). S. coroniferum is a form "not notably differing" from Sistotrema brinkmannii, but distinguishable, (Rogers).
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Breitenbach(2)*, Rogers, D.P.(2) (as Trechispora coronifera), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
380
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema diademiferum  (Bourdot & Galzin) Donk^  Fungus 26: 4. 1956;  == Corticium diademiferum  Bourdot & Galzin;  Trechispora diademifera  (Bourdot & Galzin) D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sistotrema diademiferum is a member of the Sistotrema brinkmannii group, the group described as follows, "Fruitbodies effuse, smooth or grandinioid; hyphae with clamps, walls hyaline; gloeocystidia absent; basidia urniform, normally with 6-8 sterigmata; spores less than 9 um long, ellipsoid, subcylindrical, suballantoid, or subglobose, uninucleate (except for S. binucleosporum)", (Hallenberg(1), Latin name underlined). It is distinguished from others in the group by the closely adnate fruitbody, with nearly round spores measuring 4-5.5 x 3-3.5 um, (Hallenberg).^ RANGE ^Sistotrema diademiferum has been found in OR, PQ, CO, IA, MA, and NY, (Ginns), Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and the Carpathian Mountains, (Eriksson), and France and the United Kingdom (Bourdot).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached], thin, "texture loose and in the dry state brittle"; "whitish, greyish white or pale yellow when dried"; "young fruitbodies finely porulose under the lens, then more or less continuous"; margin not differentiated; "no obvious hyphal strands"^, (Eriksson), effused, adnate, very thin, pruinose, puberulent, then dry waxy, without coherence, whitish, cream-isabelline [pale tan]; margin similar, pruinose; var. perfuga farinose, white, (Bourdot), very thin, a pruinose or waxy-crustose film, closely adnate, (when dry pruinose or vernicose [varnish-like]); whitish; the large specimens agree in most respects with the description of var. perfuga in Bourdot(1), (Rogers), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on coniferous and hardwood wood and bark, "mostly seen on fallen twigs and branches, less often on trunks"^, (Eriksson), Gossypium barbadense (creole cotton), Picea sp. (spruce), Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Populus sp., Pyrus malus (Apple), Quercus sp. (oak); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), spring to fall (Bourdot), on rotting wood, litter, and old herbaceous and fern debris; probably all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (3.5)4-5.5(6) x (2.5)3-3.5 um, oval to nearly round, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 15-21 x 5-7 um, urniform, with basal clamp connection; mostly 6-spored, sometimes 7-spored, rarely 4-spored or 8-spored; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, "thin-walled, less filled with oily inclusions that what is normal in the genus"; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE "short-celled, richly branched, mostly 2-3 um wide, sometimes wider"; BASAL HYPHAE 3-4(5) um wide, "straight, sparsely branched", (Eriksson), SPORES 3-5 x 3-4 um; BASIDIA 6-8-spored, 6-23 x 3-5 um (7-8 um wide at the base), hyphae 2.5-5 um wide, var. perfuga spores 6-6.5 x 4.5-5 um, widely oboval or pyriform, pointed at the base, basidia 4-6-spored, 27-33 x 4.5-6 um, accompanied by rare cystidioles that are narrowly fusiform, projecting and with a rounded head 8-9 um in diameter, hyphae 3-4 um wide, (Bourdot), SPORES 3-4.5(6) x 2-4(5) um, oboval - nearly round, or short-elliptic, "abruptly attenuate at the base"; BASIDIA at first nearly spherical or short-pyriform, 6.5-8(13.5) x 5-7(10) um, "developing a short apical prolongation, at maturity expanded at the summit", 9-27(31) x 4.5-8(9) um, 6-8-spored, sterigmata peripheral, recurved, 2-4(4.5) um long; contorted; STERILE BODIES present in some hymenia among the basidia, 17-30 x 4-6 um, irregular in width, with colorless content; HYPHAE 1.5-5 um, with clamp connections throughout, "fairly distinct or (in dried material) sometimes completely disintegrated and invisible", (Rogers)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing a diadem', likely referring to the appearance of the basidia
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Rogers, D.P.(2) (as Trechispora), Bourdot(1) (as Corticium diademiferum, in French), Ginns(5), Hallenberg(1), Buczacki(1)*
381
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema farinaceum  Hallenb.^  Mycotaxon 21: 406. 1984
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sistotrema farinaceum is a member of the Sistotrema brinkmannii group, described as follows, "Fruitbodies effuse, smooth or grandinioid; hyphae with clamps, walls hyaline; gloeocystidia absent; basidia urniform, normally with 6-8 sterigmata; spores less than 9 um long, ellipsoid, subcylindrical, suballantoid, or subglobose, uninucleate (except for S. binucleosporum)", (Hallenberg, Latin name underlined). It is "distinguished by the farinaceous fruitbody with abundant crystals and the small basidia and spores" (Hallenberg).^ RANGE ^The holotype was found in BC.
FRUITING BODY  thin, effused, loosely adnate; whitish; smooth, farinaceous; margin indeterminate^, (Hallenberg)
HABITAT  type on a fallen log of Populus^ (Hallenberg)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 2.5-3.5 x 2.3-2.5 um, nearly round, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 6-8-spored, 8-9.5 x 3-4 um, urniform to ovate, with basal clamp connection, true hymenium lacking: "basidia scattered in clusters on basal hyphae between abundant crystalline material"; whitish color and farinaceous appearance of the fruitbody caused by abundant crystal material; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, slightly ampullate, 2-3.3 um wide, thin-walled, (Hallenberg) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'farinaceous'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hallenberg(1), Ginns(5)
382
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema hirschii  (Donk) Donk^  Fungus 26: 4. 1956;  Corticium hirschii  Donk;  Trechispora hirschii  (Donk) D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a thin, crustose fruitbody that is firmly attached, waxy-mucedinoid, and grayish (with a rosy tint when dried), 3) curved-cylindric spores, 4) 4-spored, urniform basidia and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Sistotrema hirschii has been found in OR, the Alberta - Northwest Territories area, PQ, AZ, and IA, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  thin crustose, closely adnate [firmly attached], when fresh waxy-mucedinoid; when fresh grayish, when dry cinereous [ash-gray] with a rosy tint; "under the binocular conglutinate, finely rimose with a few fibrils visible in the cracks, the areoles with a minutely granular surface"^, (Rogers)
HABITAT  Betula sp. (birch), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Populus grandidentata (Bigtooth Aspen), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Salix gooddingii (Goodding Willow), (Ginns), on debarked wood of Populus grandidentata and Quercus garryana, (Rogers)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-8 x 2-2.5 um, "evenly cylindric, strongly curved, especially toward the apiculus, obtuse", according to Donk description should have some spores larger (7-11 x 2-4 um)^; BASIDIA "in small clusters (from proliferation of the subtending clamps) and also at various levels along the fertile hyphae, arising as evenly ellipsoid bodies" about 7 x 5 um, developing a cylindric prolongation slightly expanded at the very top, "at maturity narrowly urniform", 4-spored, 15-25 x 4.5-5(6) um, sterigmata 2-3 um long; HYPHAE 2.5-4.5 um wide, distinct, with clamp connections throughout; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE thin-walled but rigid; BASAL HYPHAE long-celled, with walls somewhat thickened, (Rogers)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Rogers, D.P.(2) (as Trechispora), Ginns(5)
383
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema oblongisporum  M.P. Christ. & Hauerslev^  Dansk Bot. Ark. 19: 82. 1960
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sistotrema oblongisporum is a member of the Sistotrema brinkmannii group, described as follows, "Fruitbodies effuse, smooth or grandinioid; hyphae with clamps, walls hyaline; gloeocystidia absent; basidia urniform, normally with 6-8 sterigmata; spores less than 9 um long, ellipsoid, subcylindrical, suballantoid, or subglobose, uninucleate (except for S. binucleosporum)", (Hallenberg, Latin name underlined). As a rule it is recognized from its thin, dense, grayish, smooth fruitbodies, in a characteristic way lining dead branches of hardwoods, especially branches 1-2cm thick, (Eriksson).^ RANGE ^It is a common species in Scandinavia (Eriksson). There is cultured material from BC, Sweden, and Australia, (Hallenberg).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached], very thin, ceraceous [waxy]; grayish-whitish gray; smooth, when young pruinose, "when dried more developed ones reticulately cracked under the lens"; margin not differentiated^, (Eriksson), effused, tightly adnate, thin; spore-bearing surface grayish white; smooth, porulose - continuous, (Hallenberg), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on smooth bark of only slightly decayed, fallen or hanging branches of hardwoods; some collections on conifer branches (Picea, Pinus) also seem to belong here^, (Eriksson), fallen branch of Alnus (alder); stump of Pinus radiata (Monterey Pine); fallen or hanging branches of hardwood trees, (Hallenberg), on rotting wood and litter of hardwood trees and old herbaceous and fern debris; probably all year, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4.5)5-6 x 1.5-2 um, "suballantoid with a more or less concave adaxial side", smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 15-18(22) x 4-6 um, at first rounded-ovoid, "when mature urniform with a rounded basal part" and a cylindric neck, 3-4 um wide, with a basal clamp connection, normally 6-8-spored; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-3.5 um wide, with clamp connections; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE "richly branched into a dense tissue"; BASAL HYPHAE "straight, glued to the substrate, with sparse septa", (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5 x 1.5-1.8(2) um, type "has slightly longer spores (5-6 um) which are straight or only slightly bent", (Hallenberg)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with oblong spores'
SIMILAR  Sistotrema oblongisporum is distinguished from Sistotrema brinkmannii "by a smooth, adnate fruitbody of a more firm consistency, and by narrower, frequently straight spores", (Hallenberg). See also SIMILAR section of Sistotrema porulosum.
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Hallenberg(1), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
384
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema porulosum  Hallenb.^  Mycotaxon 21: 407. 1984
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sistotrema porulosum is a member of the Sistotrema brinkmannii group, described as follows, "Fruitbodies effuse, smooth or grandinioid; hyphae with clamps, walls hyaline; gloeocystidia absent; basidia urniform, normally with 6-8 sterigmata; spores less than 9 um long, ellipsoid, subcylindrical, suballantoid, or subglobose, uninucleate (except for S. binucleosporum)", (Hallenberg, Latin name underlined). Sistotrema porulosum is characterized by a thin, adnate, gray, porulose fruitbody,^ | (and by the pluri-nucleate SS-mycelia in culture). RANGE ^Sistotrema porulosum has been found in BC, ON, and PQ, (Hallenberg).
FRUITING BODY  effused, thin, closely adnate [firmly attached]; spore-bearing surface grayish, smooth, porulose; margin indeterminate^, (Hallenberg)
HABITAT  type on fallen branch of Acer (maple), paratype on fallen branch, second paratype on Populus^, (Hallenberg)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA (4)6-8-spored, 10-20 x 3.5-4.5 um, urniform; with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, sometimes ampullate, with an oily content, 2-4.5 um wide; SUBICULUM very thin and with rather sparsely septate hyphae, running parallel to substrate, with thickened walls, (Hallenberg)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'porulose'
SIMILAR  Sistotrema oblongisporum has different spores (Hallenberg).
SOURCES  Hallenberg(1), Ginns(5)
385
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema raduloides  (P. Karst.) Donk^  Fungus 26: 4. 1956;  == Hydnum raduloides  P. Karst.;  Grandinia raduloides  (P. Karst.) Bourdot & Galzin;  Trechispora raduloides  (P. Karst.) D.P. Rogers;  Hydnum populinum  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a light yellowish buff fruitbody with teeth 0.1-0.4cm long, or sometimes varying to smooth, 3) subcylindric to subfusiform spores, 4) urniform basidia that are usually 6-8 spored, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections and oily inclusions.^ RANGE ^Sistotrema raduloides has been found in BC, WA, OR, AB, NB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AK, AZ, CO, IA, MI, MN, MT, NC, NY, TN, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Estonia, Finland, Norway, Poland, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached]; light-colored when young, pale buff when mature; when young with small papilla-like aculei, when mature odontioid-hydnoid, with normally cylindric, rarely irregular teeth 0.1-0.4cm long, that as a rule are conically acute [sharp] but sometimes obtuse [blunt], spore-bearing surface pruinose; subiculum thin, first arachnoid [cobwebby] then finely porulose, and finally membranaceous; margin thinning out without definite demarcation, sometimes finely fibrillose, (Eriksson(7) for European material, they comment that North American material is more variable in configuration from totally smooth to as hydnoid as Scandinavian material, and add, "The American specimen is often also somewhat light coloured, more yellow than the European, which is, in the dry state, paler buff.")
HABITAT  on very decayed wood of hardwoods with a preference for Populus tremula [European Aspen] but also on other hardwoods (e.g. Betula, Quercus, Malus), rarely on coniferous wood (Picea), seen from North America on Populus spp. and coniferous wood^, (Eriksson), on bark; decayed barkless wood; logs; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Picea (spruce), Populus, Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns) 
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (6)7-9 x (2.5)3-3.5 um, subcylindric to subfusiform, "apically obtuse, often broader below the middle, thin-walled, often clinging together in groups of 4-6"^; BASIDIA (4)6-8-spored, 18-23 x 5-7 um, urniform, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, "with clamps and oily inclusions", SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, richly branched, BASAL HYPHAE "and those of the central part of the aculei 2-6 um wide, with somewhat thickened walls, straight and sparsely branched", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Ginns(5)
386
FAMILY  Hydnaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotrema resinicystidium  Hallenb.^  Mycotaxon 11: 466. 1980
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sistotrema resinicystidium is easily distinguished from other Sistotrema species due to peculiar cystidia and resin-filled subicular hyphae (Hallenberg). Features include 1) resupinate growth on decayed hardwood and conifer wood, 2) a fruitbody that is hypochnoid becoming continuous and firm, white to cream or light ochraceous, nearly smooth to tuberculate-grandinioid, the margin indistinct, 3) spores that are elliptic (adaxial side usually straight or convex), smooth, and inamyloid, 4) (4)6-7(8)-spored basidia that are narrowly urniform to almost tube-like, with a widened, rounded basal part, 5) gloeocystidia that are sinuous (often with moniliform constrictions), with yellowish resinous content, turning dark brown in sulfovanillin, and embedded or slightly projecting, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, with clamp connections, in the subiculum with resinous, oily content.^ RANGE ^Sistotrema resinicystidium has been found in BC, Norway, Sweden, and Iran, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], thin (0.005-0.01cm when dried), "when young hypochnoid-porulose", then continuous and firm; white-cream (when dried darkening, pale buff to pale ochraceous); "almost smooth to more or less tuberculate-grandinioid"; "margin not especially differentiated"^, (Eriksson), "resupinate, effused, closely adnate, thin, hypochnoid"; spore-bearing surface whitish - light ochraceous, minutely tuberculate; margin indistinct, (Hallenberg)
HABITAT  on decayed hardwood and coniferous wood^, (Eriksson), on brown-rotted wood of Quercus (oak) (Hallenberg)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5.5 x 2-3 um, elliptic-subovoid, "often broadest below the middle, adaxial side straight or somewhat convex, in a few spores slightly concave", smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA (4)6-7(8)-spored, 17-30 um long, narrowly urniform to almost tube-like, "with a widened, rounded basal part", 5-6 um wide, and a tubular neck, 3.5-4.5 um wide, basidia with a basal clamp connection; GLOEOCYSTIDIA "present and usually fairly numerous", usually not more than 50 um long and 8 um wide, "sinuous, often with moniliform constrictions, thin-walled, in herbarium material filled with a yellow-brown substance, which is homogeneous in most cases but sometimes granular (in phase), darkening to brown in sulfovanillin but without distinct aldehyde-reaction"; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, "often with oily contents"; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE about 2-2.5 um wide, richly branched, very thin-walled; BASAL HYPHAE few, 2-4.5 um wide, straight and sparsely branched, with thin or slightly thickened walls, (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5.5 x 2-2.8 um, elliptic, "adaxial side flattened or a little convex", smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-8-spored, 17-30 x 4-5 um, urniform, basal part up to 6 um wide, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 20-40 x 4.5-8 um, submoniliform, sinuous, with a yellowish, resinous content, turning dark brown in sulfovanillin, "embedded or slightly projecting, often connected with the resin-filled, subicular hyphae"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4.5 um wide, "with thin but distinct walls", with clamp connections; "in subiculum very loosely interwoven; partly with a yellowish, resinous content; lots of crystalline material in the context", (Hallenberg)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with resin cystidia'
SIMILAR  Sistotrema coroniferum 1) is white even when dried, 2) is smooth and brittle, easily detachable, at least in small parts, 3) has a spore-bearing surface that is smooth or nearly so, not densely tuberculate-grandinioid under the lens, 4) has spores that are suballantoid, mostly with a clearly concave adaxial side, 5) has the neck of its basidium shorter, not prolonged into a tube, and 6) has gloeocystidia that are colorless or pale yellow, with stringy, oily contents, (Eriksson). Sistotrema sernanderi, found at least in Ontario and Europe, also has gloeocystidia, but has (1-2-)4-spored basidia, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Hallenberg(4), Eriksson(7), Ginns(5)
387
FAMILY  Hydnodontaceae, Order Trechisporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotremastrum niveocremeum  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 62. 1958;  Corticium niveocremeum  Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Paullicorticium niveocremeum  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Oberw.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a waxy, soft fruitbody that is whitish and smooth, the margin filamentous or not differentiated, 3) spores that are elliptic to suballantoid, smooth, inamyloid, cyanophilic, and colorless, 4) basidia that are 2-6-spored, and obconic to tubular, sometimes constricted, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae richly branched, with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Sistotremastrum niveocremeum has been found in BC, ON, PQ, AZ, FL, IA, MA, MD, MO, NY, PA, RI, VA, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson), and Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], mostly thin (about 0.01cm), ceraceous [waxy] and continuous when fresh, "when dried mostly porulose due to shrinking"; white or when dried yellowish; margin not differentiated; no rhizomorphs^, (Eriksson), resupinate, attached loosely, "forming filmy, farinose patches" several centimeters across, "consistency soft, easy to wipe off"; white to gray-whitish; "smooth, finely farinose, somewhat fissured in thicker places"; "margin thinning out and filamentous", (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood of hardwoods (e.g. Quercus, Corylus, Alnus) and sometimes on Picea (spruce)^, (Eriksson), "on the underside of dead, barkless hardwood"; fall to winter, (Breitenbach), on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Populus, Quercus (oak), Sassafras, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-9 x 2.5-3(4) um, narrowly elliptic-subcylindric-suballantoid, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-6-spored, 15-26 x 4-6(7) um, obconic to tubular, sometimes somewhat constricted, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, colorless, with clamp connections, richly branched, "few straight basal hyphae", (Eriksson), SPORES 7-8.5 x 3-4 um, elliptic to cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, cyanophilic, colorless, some with droplets; BASIDIA 2-4(6)-spored, 20-27 x 5-7.5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 1.5-3 um wide, with clamp connections, "sometimes rather inflated at the septa", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white - cream-colored'
SIMILAR  Sistotremastrum suecicum has thicker fruitbodies, narrowly elliptic spores 4.5-6 um long, and typically grows on conifer wood, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Breitenbach(2)* (as Paullicorticium niveocremeum), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
388
FAMILY  Hydnodontaceae, Order Trechisporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sistotremastrum suecicum  J. Erikss.^  as Litsch. ex J. Erikss., Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 62. 1958
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a waxy fruitbody that is white or cream, the margin not differentiated, 3) narrowly elliptic spores, 4) (4)-6-spored basidia that are clavate-tubular and often somewhat constricted, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, rarely forming a basal layer and with no definite distinction between subhymenial and tramal hyphae.^ RANGE ^Sistotremastrum suecicum has been found in OR, NS, ON, PQ, MA, NH, NY, OH, and PA, (Ginns), as well as Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached] or detachable in small pieces, ceraceous [waxy] and continuous when fresh; white or cream (when old in the herbarium "sometimes discolored to argillaceous or pale buff"); specimens on barkless wood when dried usually "longitudinally cracked and often also transversely into small squares or irregular pieces"; margin not differentiated^, (Eriksson)
HABITAT  Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Juniperus (juniper), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja^, (Ginns), mostly on conifer wood, especially of Pinus (pine), but not rare on Picea (spruce), a few collections on Juniperus (juniper) and on hardwood, also on old fallen fences, (Eriksson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6 x 1.5-2 um, narrowly elliptic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 16-21 x 4-6 um, "clavate-tubular, often somewhat constricted, with slightly thickened walls", usually 6-spored (less often 4-spored), with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, with thin or slightly thickened walls, with clamp connections, "rarely forming a basal layer or strands of parallel hyphae", "no definite distinction between subhymenial and tramal hyphae", (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'Swedish'
SIMILAR  Sistotremastrum niveocremeum has thinner fruitbodies, subcylindric-allantoid spores 6-9 um long, and typically grows on hardwood, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Ginns(5)
389
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Skvortzovia furfuracea  (Bres.) G. Gruhn & Hallenberg^  Bull. Mycol. Bot. Dauphine-Savoie 231: 10. 2018;  == Resinicium furfuraceum  (Bres.) Parmasto  Consp. Syst. Cort. 98., 1968;  == Corticium furfuraceum  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) fruitbodies that are thin, whitish, watery grayish or yellowish color, with a surface that is smooth becoming more or less granular, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) halocystidia that have an apical bladder (the "halo") filled with an oily or grainy substance, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ | Nakasone(9) maintained this species does not belong in Resinicium sensu stricto (as characterized by the presence of astrocystidia) and it was later moved back to the genus Skvortzovia which had been described in 1987 (Hjortstam(10)) to accommodate this species. RANGE ^Skvortzovia furfuracea has been found in BC, WA, ID, NS, ON, PQ, AZ, CO, FL, MA, MI, MN, MT, NC, NH, NM, TN, VA, and WI, (Ginns), as well as in Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, closely adnate [firmly attached], thin; white, watery grayish or yellowish; when living, ceraceous [waxy] and continuous, when dry crustaceous and then becoming porulose [finely pored] and cracked into small pieces, smooth when young, more or less granular (grandinioid) when older; margin "pruinose, not especially differentiated"^, (Eriksson); thin, adnate [firmly attached], ceraceous; cream-colored; surface even; often cracked when dry, (Julich)
HABITAT  on decayed, mostly barkless coniferous wood^, (Eriksson), on decaying wood of logs; moss-covered bark; charred wood; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5 x 2-3 um, elliptic, (and by the generic description smooth, inamyloid, colorless, and thin-walled)^; BASIDIA 11-13 x 4-5 um, clavate; CYSTIDIA apically swollen, 2-4 um in diameter, the halo up to 6 um wide; HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, rather indistinct, thin-walled, (Julich), spores and basidia left out of description; CYSTIDIA 'varying in number, sometimes difficult to find, in other cases numerous, nearly cylindrical or with widened base, thin-walled, capitate with the distal part (the "halo") filled with some oily or grainy matter', apparently "the apical wall of the cystidium becomes double, the outer layer expanding to a rounded bladder"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "subhymenial hyphae mainly vertical, rather densely septate, with numerous anastomoses", subiculum a thin layer of richly branched hyphae, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means "with bran-like scales"
SIMILAR  Resinicium bicolor has numerous cystidia with crystal stars (astrocystidia) (Eriksson). See also SIMILAR section of Phlebia cretacea.
SOURCES  Eriksson(6) (as Resinicium furfuraceum), Julich(5) (as Resinicium furfuraceum), Ginns(5) (as Resinicium furfuraceum), Nakasone(9) (as Resinicium furfuraceum), Hjortstam(10)
390
FAMILY  Hydnodontaceae, Order Trechisporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sphaerobasidium minutum  (J. Erikss.) Julich^  as Oberw. ex Julich, Persoonia 10: 335. 1979;  == Xenasma minutum  J. Erikss.;  Paullicorticium minutum  (J. Erikss.) Liberta
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is an inconspicuous gray or whitish bloom, the margin not differentiated, 3) spores that are narrowly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, and colorless, 4) 4-spored basidia that are subspherical to obconic, 5) cystidia that are conic with a spherical head that is covered with a globe of resinous matter, 6) hymenial elements that are scattered on a network of narrow horizontal hyphae branching at more or less right angles, the elements arising sessile from them or on short vertical branches, and 7) septa with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Sphaerobasidium minutum has been found in OR, PQ, AZ, CO, CT, IL, MA, MT, NM, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Liberta).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, adnate [firmly attached], effused [spread out], "forming small or confluent, very thin and inconspicuous patches on the wood"; grayish bloom when living, "drying as a thin pruina"; margin not differentiated^, (Eriksson), effused, adnate, thin (in section 0.001-0.003cm), almost invisible; white or yellow-white to bluish gray; pruinose, (Liberta)
HABITAT  on old, barkless, conifer wood (Pinus, Picea, Abies), also on wooden fences, (Eriksson), on decayed hardwood, and wood or bark of Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), and stems of Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern), (Liberta)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (3.5)4-5.5 x (2.5)3-3.5 um, narrowly elliptic, "adaxial side straight or slightly depressed", inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, subspherical - obconic, "mostly borne singly on the hyphae, when fully developed 7-9 x 5-6 um", with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA numerous, 15-25(35) um long, 4-5 um wide at base, conic, tapering upwards toward tip, which, with few exceptions, is formed as a spherical head, 3-4 um wide, "covered with an excreted cap of oily resinous matter, sticky in the living fungus and often with attached spores"; HYPHAE monomitic, 1-2 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "forming a net of branches at more or less right angles, densely attached to the substrate", (Eriksson), SPORES (3)4-5(6.5) x (2)3-3.5(4) um, elliptic to oblong-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 7-8(9.5) x 5-5.5(7) um, subspherical to obpyriform, "either sessile on the horizontal hyphae or arising on short vertical branches"; CYSTIDIA "either sessile on horizontal hyphae or arising from short vertical branches, subtended by a clamp connection", (18.5)20-37 x (3.5)4-5 um, tibiiform, the bulbous apex 3-4.5 um wide, "often surrounded by a halo of amorphous material including some crystals", that is enclosed by a membrane, 4-8 um wide, or occasionally with an apical projection; HYPHAE mostly parallel to the substrate, "at first distinct, the walls soon becoming gelatinized, nodose-septate", 1-2 um wide, (Liberta)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'very small'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Liberta(3), Ginns(5)
391
FAMILY  Hypocreaceae, Order Hypocreales, Class Sordariomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sphaeronaemella helvellae  (P. Karst.) P. Karst.^  Hedwigia 23: 18. 1884
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sphaeronaemella helvellae grows on living fruitbodies of Gyromitra infula and Gyromitra ambigua. It is "easily recognized in the field by the long perithecial necks protruding from the hymenium of the host, giving it a velvety appearance" (Malloch(4)). The Gyromitra fruitbodies appear withered, but "ascospores are always present, indicating that the infection does not occur until host maturity", (Malloch).^ |The family and genus placement of this species is uncertain: it may be a member of the Microascales. |The description is derived from Malloch(4). RANGE ^Sphaeronaemella helvellae has been reported from WA, ID, ON, AK, CO, MI, NH, NY, and Finland, (Malloch).
FRUITING BODY  fruitbodies (ascocarps) superficial to semi-immersed in the spore-bearing area of the host (Gyromitra), 0.009-0.025cm in diameter, densely gregarious, nearly spherical to ovoid, bright yellow-orange, bald, smooth, with a long neck [somewhat gourd-like in appearance]
HABITAT  on fruitbodies of Gyromitra infula, Gyromitra ambigua
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8.2-10.6 x 3.3-4.5 um, unilaterally flattened-elliptic in side view, elliptic in face view, smooth, colorless by transmitted light, yellowish in mass, "lacking gelatinous appendages, lacking germ pores", [illustrated as irregularly disposed within asci]^; ASCUS 8-spored, 14-25 x 10.5-16 um, clavate to ovoid, irregularly disposed, extremely delicate and evanescent, occasionally substipitate; PERIDIUM of ascocarp "about 8.5-17 um thick at maturity", peridial cells "relatively thick-walled, and yellowish at the surface", thinner-walled and colorless toward the interior, forming a texture angularis to textura epidermoidea in surface view, flattened in side view, 2-12 um in diameter, 1-4 um thick, NECK of ascocarp "composed of vertically oriented parallel hyphae, terminated by a ring of ostiolar setae" 20-50 um long, bald, up to 600 um long, 8.5-30 um in diameter; CONIDIA 7-15 x 3.0-4.5 um, elliptic to oval, truncated at one end, smooth, colorless, produced on phialides; PHIALIDES 37-83 x 4.0-5.0 um, "clavate to lanceolate, occasionally with a single septum, rarely with a small collarette", borne by phialophores; PHIALOPHORES "short to nearly absent, usually represented only by a short side branch of the vegetative hyphae"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'on Helvella', an older genus name for the Gyromitra host species
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Malloch(4)
392
FAMILY  Steccherinaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Steccherinum bourdotii  Saliba & A. David^, Cryptog. Mycol. 9(2): 100. 1988 sensu aucts.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a fruitbody that is effused-reflexed or forming a somewhat semicircular bracket with a whitish upper surface, 2) a toothed spore-bearing surface with conic teeth up to 0.25cm long, colored cream to orange, 3) an abrupt whitish margin, 4) growth on oak wood, 5) microscopic characters including nearly round to elliptic spores and encrusted pseudocystidia.^ | Steccherinum bourdotii is the only Steccherinum of the 17 species treated in Bernicchia(2) with some pileate fruitbodies and nearly round spores, and the name has been applied in North America for such fruitbodies. RANGE ^This species is primarily known in Europe (holotype from France), but there are North American reports as well as well as reports from Argentina. There are at least two different reports from WA. The ITS sequence of one of the Washington collections matches S. bourdotii collections in GenBank. Both of these collections had caps and nearly round spores (see images).
FRUITING BODY  "effuse-reflexed to pileate, upper surface dimidiate, white"; spore-bearing surface odontioid with conic teeth 0.2-0.25cm long; "cream to pale ochraceous"; "margin abrupt, whitish"^, (Bernicchia(2)), "annual, resupinate and effused on margin", sometimes forming small caps up to 0.5cm wide and up to 0.3cm thick, "the upper surface cream, tomentose, indistinctly zonate, margin sharp"; spore-bearing surface hydnoid with cylindric spines 3-4(5) per millimeter [sic], 1-4 millimeters long, "cream or orange and slightly reddish (not ochraceous)", (Piatek)
HABITAT  found on wood of Quercus (oak) and Carpinus betulus (European hornbeam), (Bernicchia(2)), on host trees of 14 genera, only one occurrence on conifer wood, (Piatek)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5.5 x 3-4.5(5) um, nearly round to elliptic, smooth, IKI negative, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 14-20 x 4-5 um, "subclavate, slightly sinuous", with a basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA (pseudocystidia) numerous in the teeth, "strongly encrusted in the obtuse apex", encrusted part 40-60 x 6-8 um; HYPHAE dimitic, generative hyphae 3-4 um wide, thin-walled, ramified, with clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 2.5-3 um wide, thick-walled, rarely ramified, (Bernicchia(2)), SPORES (3.12)3.74-4.16(4.57) x 3.12-4.16 um, nearly round, colorless, thin-walled, usually with one oil drop; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 4-5 um, subclavate, with basal clamp connection; SKELETOCYSTIDIA "narrowly clavate, strongly encrusted at the apex, and projecting over hymenium"; HYPHAE dimitic, "generative hyphae thin-walled, with clamp connections", skeletal hyphae 3-4 um wide, thick-walled, without clamp connections, (Piatek)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Steccherinum ochraceum has spores measuring about 3.2-4.5 x 1.8-2.5 um.
SOURCES  Bernicchia(2), Piatek(1), McAdoo(2)*
393
FAMILY  Steccherinaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Steccherinum ciliolatum  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Gilb. & Budington^  J. Arizona Acad. Sci. 6: 97. 1970;  == Hydnum ciliolatum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Odontia ciliolata  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) L.W. Mill.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is whitish, somewhat waxy, and firmly attached, with spines about 0.15cm long, the margin finely fibrillose to fringed, sometimes forming runners or rhizomorphs, 3) spores that are elliptic to short-cylindric, smooth, and colorless, 4) cystidia arising from the trama, projecting, evenly distributed over the spine, encrusted, cylindric to somewhat fusiform in distal part, 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Steccherinum ciliolatum has been found in BC, AB, NB, ON, PE, PQ, AZ, CO, IA, MA, MD, MI, MN, MT, NC, NM, NY, and SC, (Ginns), as well as Europe (Maas Geesteranus).
FRUITING BODY  effused [spread out], eventually covering an area of several square centimeters, inseparable from substrate without damage, spore-bearing surface at first minutely porous, becoming subceraceous [somewhat waxy] to ceraceous; milk-white to pale cream; finally areolately cracked; spines up to about 0.15cm long, 0.01-0.02cm wide, moderately crowded to subdistant, subulate [awl-shaped], terete [round in cross-section] to more or less flattened, straight, simple or connate, rarely furcate [forked], pulverulent [powdery] or pubescent [downy] to almost hispid [bristly], cream in younger parts of fruitbody, pale ochraceous in center, tip fimbriate [fringed] to lacerate, white; flesh "very thin, soft, whitish"; margin finely fibrillose to fimbriate, sometimes forming runners or rhizomorphs, whitish^, (Maas Geesteranus), annual, less than 0.1cm thick, toothed surface "light buff" to "ochraceous-buff", the teeth appearing somewhat farinaceous [mealy], cylindric, tapering to the tip, 0.02-0.05cm long, the apices finely fimbriate; "margin finely fimbriate, fertile to the edge"; "subiculum pale buff, very thin", (Gilbertson)
HABITAT  on decayed wood; slash; logs^; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Malus, Picea (spruce), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5.4 x 1.8-2.7 um, elliptic to somewhat elongate, adaxially flattened, smooth, colorless, with small oblique apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-22 x 4.5-6 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection, sterigmata 2.7-3.6 um long; CYSTIDIA 3.5-8 um wide, "of tramal origin, evenly distributed over length of spine, numerous to abundant", more or less projecting, encrusted, cylindric to somewhat fusiform in distal part, with obtuse or more acute tip; HYPHAE dimitic, CONTEXT consisting of generative and skeletal hyphae, generative hyphae up to 5.4 um wide, not inflating, branched, thin-walled to moderately thick-walled, septate with clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 2.7-5.4 um wide, thick-walled to solid, context of spines similar, skeletal hyphae usually somewhat narrower, (Maas Geesteranus), SPORES 4-4.5 x 2-2.5 um, short-cylindric, smooth, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 4-5 um wide, clavate; CYSTIDIA 6-8 um wide, completely imbedded or projecting up to 30 um, "abundant, sometimes projecting in clusters, scattered along sides of teeth and at apices", thick-walled, heavily encrusted; SUBICULAR HYPHAE closely interwoven, of 2 types: 1) 3-3.5 um wide, "thin-walled, often branched, with frequent clamp connections", 2) 3-4 um wide, thick-walled, aseptate, often encrusted, rarely branched, apparently ending in encrusted cystidia, (Gilbertson), SPORES 3.5-5 x 2-2.5 um, (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Steccherinum ciliolatum and Steccherinum fimbriatum may be distinguished by the differences in the nature of the spore-bearing surface and the distributional pattern of the cystidia, (Maas Geesteranus). See also SIMILAR section of Steccherinum subcrinale.
SOURCES  Maas Geesteranus(2), Gilbertson(8) (as Hydnum ciliolatum), Martin, K.J.(3), Ginns(5)
394
FAMILY  Steccherinaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Steccherinum fimbriatum  (Pers.) J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 134. 1958;  == Odontia fimbriata  Pers.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a spore-bearing surface that is dingy yellowish gray flushed with violaceous or pink tints, with conic or fringe-tipped spines, the margin filamentous to rhizomorphic, and often lighter to cream-colored, 3) spores that are small, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia that are numerous in the spines especially at the tips, originating in the trama, cylindric in their distal part, projecting, thick-walled, and encrusted, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the generative hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Steccherinum fimbriatum has been found in BC, WA, OR, MB, NB, NS, ON, PE, AZ, CA, CO, GA, IA, MI, MN, MT, NC, NM, NY, OH, PA, and WI, (Ginns). It is the most common species of the genus in Scandinavia (Eriksson). It is widely distributed in the northern hemisphere (Maas Geesteranus). It occurs in Switzerland and Asia (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, loosely adnate, often widely spread out; spore-bearing surface "odontioid, fairly soft but tough", usually pale violaceous or gray-reddish (in herbarium dark ochraceous or sometimes grayish, even yellowish gray); aculei [spines] spines conic, penicillate [brush-like], about 0.02-0.03cm long, 4-5 per millimeter; subiculum 0.01-0.2cm thick, colored as the spore-bearing surface or slightly paler; margin "more or less filamentous to rhizomorphic" with several centimeter long threads^, (Eriksson), resupinate, attached loosely, forming membranous patches several centimeters to decimeters across, consistency membranous-tough; "gray-pink to gray-lilac or pink-brown"; surface uneven, tuberculate-wrinkled, finely verrucose, warts up to 0.5cm long, "but usually shorter and finely fringed on the tips" (from projecting cystidia); "margin lighter to cream-colored and strongly fringed", often also with conspicuous rhizomorphs, (Breitenbach), effused [spread out], often attaining considerable size, partly separable; dingy yellowish gray flushed with pink, pinkish gray, "sometimes partly flushed with purple or violaceous tints, or dingy purplish brown"; "porous, somewhat floccose, or areolate, sometimes shiny as if suffused with some glutinous matter, smooth or veined or marked by raised rhizomorphic strands"; spines up to 0.05cm long, 0.01-0.02cm wide, "subdistant to crowded or aggregated into dense clumps, rarely simple, usually variously connate, wart-like to more elongate and then usually flattened or with fluted sides", pulverulent [powdery] to granular, colored as the rest of the spore-bearing surface, "tip conspicuously shaggy or spiny with tufts of white bristles"; margin fimbriate and forming rhizomorphs, whitish, becoming colored as the rest of the spore-bearing surface; flesh less than 0.05cm thick, leathery-tough, (Maas Geesteranus), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on bark and barkless wood, slash; logs^; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Amelanchier (serviceberry), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Liriodendron (Tuliptree), Notholithocarpus (Tanoak), Ostrya (hophornbeam), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Rhus, Salix (willow), Umbellularia, (Ginns), associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on bark as well as on barkless hardwood, more rarely on Juniperus and other coniferous substrates, (Eriksson), on rotten hardwood, more rarely conifer wood, usually on underside; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on fallen branches and decaying wood of hardwoods and conifers, (Maas Geesteranus), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.2-3.5(4) x (2)2.2-2.5 um, elliptic, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-20 x 4-4.5 um, "subclavate, slightly sinuous", with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA (pseudocystidia) numerous in the spines, more rare or lacking in the spore-bearing layer between the spines, strongly encrusted toward the obtuse tip, "the encrusted part normally 40-50 x 8-10 um"; HYPHAE dimitic, generative hyphae 3.5-4 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections and sparse branching, in the spine trama together with skeletal hyphae that are (2.5)3 um wide, thick-walled, rarely branched, without clamp connections, interwoven with the generative hyphae; subhymenial layer thin, with short-celled hyphae, always with clamp connections; RHIZOMORPHS composed of generative and skeletal hyphae, (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic-oval, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, some with droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-18 x 3.5-5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA (skeletocystidia) thick-walled, upper half +/- strongly encrusted, projecting part 20-40 x 2.5-9 um, aggregated on the tips of the spines; HYPHAE dimitic, generative hyphae 2-4 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 2-6 um wide, thick-walled, (Breitenbach), SPORES 3.3-4 x 2.5-3 um, broadly elliptic to oboval, adaxially little flattened, smooth, colorless, with small oblique apiculus; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 3.5-5.5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 3-9 um wide, "of tramal origin, numerous to abundant at tip of spine, rare to absent further back", conspicuously projecting, usually heavily encrusted, cylindric in the distal part, with obtuse tip, HYPHAE dimitic, of generative and skeletal hyphae, generative hyphae 2.5-4.5 um wide (not inflating), branched, thin-walled to moderately thick-walled, septate, with clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 3.6-5.4 um wide, "thick-walled to almost solid", those adjoining substrate frequently brownish, context of spines similar, with most skeletal hyphae solid, (Maas Geesteranus)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fimbriate, fringed'
SIMILAR  Steccherinum ciliolatum and S. fimbriatum may be distinguished by the differences in the nature of the spore-bearing surface and the distributional pattern of the cystidia, (Maas Geesteranus). See also SIMILAR section of Steccherinum subcrinale.
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Maas Geesteranus(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
395
FAMILY  Steccherinaceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Steccherinum laeticolor  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Banker^  Mycologia 4: 316. 1912;  == Hydnum laeticolor  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Hydnum floridanum  Berk. & Cooke;  Hydnum parasitans  Berk. & M.A. Curtis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, more rarely bent outward to form cap, 2) the cap when present projecting up to 0.4cm, pale dingy salmon, concentrically grooved, and woolly-hairy, 3) the spore-bearing surface dingy salmon to reddish brick, with scattered to crowded, awl-shaped spines, their surface downy or scabrous, their tips smooth or fringed and whitish, the margin of the spore-bearing area contrasting whitish, fringed, at times forming short runners, 4) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and colorless, 5) cystidia of tramal origin, cylindric to fusiform in their distal part, little projecting, evenly distributed over the length of the spine, encrusted, with an obtuse apex, and 6) dimitic hyphal system, the generative hyphae with clamp connections.^ | The relation to Steccherinum ochraceum is discussed under SIMILAR. RANGE ^Steccherinum laeticolor has been found in ID, AL, AZ, FL, IA, LA, MI, NY, and TX, (Ginns), as well as Germany, Latvia, Sweden, and the USSR, (Maas Geesteranus).
FRUITING BODY  spreading out to cover several square centimeters, "effused, more rarely effused-reflexed" [bent outward to form shelf-like cap]; reflexed part up to 0.4cm radius and wide, "conchate or laterally fused and flange-like, horizontal or pendent", pale dingy salmon, (somewhat pallescent [becoming paler] toward the vertex), "concentrically grooved, woolly-hirsute", "margin hirsute or obscurely running out into spines"; spore-bearing surface tomentose to membranous, dingy salmon to reddish brick, smooth to [cracked like dried mud] or slightly alveolate, hydnoid (only once seen poroid-irpicoid), spines up to 0.35cm long, 0.01-0.03(0.05)cm wide, wider when confluent, "scattered to crowded, somewhat unevenly arranged, giving untidy impression", subulate [awl-shaped], terete [round in cross-section] to flattened, straight to flexuous [wavy], "simple or confluent, pubescent to scabrous, dingy salmon to reddish brick", tip smooth and colored as the rest of the spore-bearing surface or fimbriate and whitish; margin of effused part contrasting whitish, fimbriate, at times forming short runners, more or less easily separable from substrate; undersurface of fruitbody pale salmon or almost colored as the spines; flesh up to 0.05cm thick, "uniform, soft, spongy, yellowish to pale salmon"^, (Maas Geesteranus), type annual, effused up to 0.6cm, slightly reflexed, upper surface of reflexed part "light buff"; toothed surface "pinkish cinnamon" to "Mikado brown", the teeth up to 0.2cm long, "cylindric, tapering to the tip, the apices of some white-incrusted, entire or finely fimbriate with whitish projections; subiculum pale buff, very thin", (Gilbertson)
