MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-10(13) x 4-5 um, obovate to cylindric, flattened on one side, usually somewhat curved, germinating by repetition^; PROBASIDIA 8.5-11.5 x 6-8 um, "at first clavate, with basal septa and clamps 5-15 um below the swollen tips, tardily cut off by secondary septa at the bases of the swollen tips, finally obovate, conspicuously guttulate, yellowish opaque", becoming cruciate-septate or sometimes only 2-celled, epibasidia 15-30 x 1.5-2 um; sinuous, basidia "borne terminally and on proliferations from clamps at primary septa some distance below the enlarged portions of young basidia"; PARAPHYSES "subdistinct, guttulate, erect, tortuous, sparingly forked near the broad apices, 2-2.5 um thick, forming a layer extending 5-20 um above the basidia"; CYSTIDIA: a very few small, subulate [awl-shaped] cystidia sometimes present; in SECTION, 50-1000 um thick, in thin fruitings consisting of a basal layer of densely interwoven hyphae, 2-2.5 um wide, in thick fruitings this is much wider and the hyphae are brownish, thick walled, clamp-bearing, 2.5-3.5 um wide, and 2 or more successive hymenial layers may be present, fertile hyphae 2-2.5 um wide bearing paraphyses and basidia in a narrow zone near surface, (Martin), SPORES very variable within a single spore print, oblong to cylindric, often depressed, constricted or allantoid, (4)5.5-9.5(12) x (2.5)3-4(5.5) um from prints, some producing secondary spores, germinating by germ tube; BASIDIA 2-4-celled, similar to those in Ofella glaira [as Stypella glaira], CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHIDIA [paraphyses] and HYPHAE similar to those of Ofella glaira [as Stypella glaira], (Roberts)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Ofella glaira [as Stypella glaira] has similar fruitbodies, hyphae, and hyphidia, but spores are round to broadly elliptic, (Roberts). Stypella subgelatinosa forms a distinctly hydnoid compound fruitbody, (Roberts). Stypella subhyalina has inconspicuous thin-walled cystidia, (Roberts). Stypella dubia has thick-walled cystidia (Roberts).
SOURCES  Roberts(3), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Sebacina podlachica Bres.), Ginns(5) (as Myxarium grilletii and Sebacina podlachica), Buczacki(1)
410
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Stypella subgelatinosa  (P. Karst.) P. Roberts^  Mycotaxon 69: 232. 1998;  == Hydnum subgelatinosum  P. Karst.;  == Protodontia subgelatinosa  (P. Karst.) Pilat;  == Protohydnum subgelatinosum  (P. Karst.) S. Lundell;  = Protohydnum lividum  Bres;  = Protodontia uda  Hoehn.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on fallen wood, 2) individual fruitbodies that coalesce to form effused compound fruitbodies with a colorless water-soaked appearance, colored blue-gray with a purple tint, the surface odontioid, drying to an almost invisible film that under a lens has hair-like spines, 3) spores that are nearly round to elliptic, and colorless, 4) basidia that are myxarioid with a rounded head and a stem, and 5) absent cystidia.^ |The Reid(2) description is for the United Kingdom: he included North America, but adds "although there is some doubt as to whether the North American fungus is identical with the European material", and Roberts(3) gives the known distribution as Europe. RANGE ^Stypella subgelatinosa has been found in OR, ON, IA, LA, MO, NC, and New England, (Ginns), as well as Austria, Czechoslovakia, Finland, France, Norway, Poland, Russia, Sweden, United Kingdom, (Reid), and Denmark, France, Norway, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Roberts). Distribution includes OR, ON, IA, LA, MO, New England, and Europe, (Martin for P. uda). 
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, extending over an area of 2 square centimeters; blue-gray with a purple tint; "under a lens densely covered with minute papillate warts", when fresh has a colorless water-soaked appearance, when dried almost invisible but under a lens has hair-like spines^, (Reid), resupinate, 1-10cm in extent, margins indeterminate; white or pallid; subiculum waxy, very thin, spines waxy, slender, round in cross-section, mostly 0.01-0.1cm long, more or less fimbriate-branched, (Martin), arising as individual fruitbodies, then coalescing to form effused compound fruitbodies, each individual fruitbody developing an apical tuft or peg of sterile hyphae giving the compound fruitbody an odontioid appearance, (Roberts), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on fallen hardwood and conifer wood^, (Roberts), on Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Quercus (oak), Pinus (pine), (Reid), dead hardwood, (or coniferous wood?), (Martin), probably all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.0-6.5 x 3.0-3.75(4) um, 5.2-7.2 x 3-3.75 um in spore deposit, elliptic, colorless, thin-walled, germinating by repetition^; BASIDIA myxarioid, consisting of a globose head 5.0-6.5 um wide, "which becomes 4-celled by the development of longitudinal cruciately arranged septa", and an elongated stalk cell 9.75-15.2 x 1.0-1.5 um. "The latter is separated from a fertile globular portion by a septum devoid of a clamp-connexion, but the stalk cell possesses a clamp at its base.", epibasidia about 12 um long; the hymenium has besides the basidia DIKARYOPHYSES consisting of a trunk 0.75-1.5 um wide, "which becomes variously branched towards the apex"; BASAL LAYER undifferentiated, 18-20 um thick, "of densely compacted, parallel, horizontal, thin-walled, narrow hyphae", up to 2 um wide, with clamp connections at the septa; SPINES 110-150 um long arise from the upper part of the basal tissue: they have a sterile apex but are fertile over the lower half or two thirds and the space between spines is fertile, (Reid), SPORES 5-7.5 x 2.5-4 um, oval or short cylindric, slightly curved; PROBASIDIA 12-14 x 5-6 um, clavate, becoming cruciate-septate, each cell producing a rather short epibasidium, (Martin), SPORES 4-7.5 x 3.5-5(5.5) um from spore print, nearly round to elliptic (a few occasionally oblong), "frequently producing secondary spores, germinating by germ tube"; BASIDIA myxarioid, similar to Stypella grilletii; CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHIDIA and HYPHAE similar to S. grilletii, "hyphae in pegs are normally weakly branched towards the apex, hyphidia-like, closely or loosely intertwined in a gelatinous matrix", hyphal pegs projecting 50-500 um above the hymenial surface, (Roberts)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Stypella grilletii and Ofella glaira [as Stypella glaira] either form a smooth or tuberculate fruitbody, or are composed of discrete gelatinous granules, (Roberts). Stypella subhyalina has inconspicuous thin-walled cystidia (Roberts). Stypella dubia has thick-walled cystidia (Roberts).
SOURCES  Roberts(3), Reid(2) (as Protodontia subgelatinosa), Ginns(5) (as Protodontia subgelatinosa), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Protodontia uda), Buczacki(1)*
411
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Auriculariales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Stypella subhyalina  (A. Pearson) P. Roberts^  Mycotaxon 69: 234. 1998;  Myxarium subhyalinum  (A. Pearson) D.A. Reid;  == Sebacina subhyalina  A. Pearson;  Sebacina sublilacina  G.W. Martin;  Exidiopsis sublilacina  (G.W. Martin) Ervin;  Myxarium sublilacinum  (G.W. Martin) Raitv.;  Myxarium vernicosum  Hauerslev
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a fruitbody forming a thin, firmly attached, waxy-gelatinous blue-gray film with numerous, small, white, calcareous inclusions but drying to an indistinct varnish-like film, 2) elliptic spores, 3) myxarioid basidia consisting of a spherical, cruciately divided head and a long stem-like cell with a basal clamp connection, and 4) projecting lanceolate 'cystidia' and dikaryophyses.^ RANGE ^Stypella subhyalina has been found in OR, AB, ON, PQ, CA, GA, IA, MA, MO, NC, NY, and OH, (Ginns). Collections were examined from IA, Denmark, France, Ireland, Netherlands, Norway, United Kingdom, and the Canary Islands, (Roberts). R. Bandoni collections from WA and BC were deposited at the University of British Columbia (as Sebacina sublilacina).
FRUITING BODY  "forming a thin, adnate, waxy-gelatinous blue-grey film with numerous small calcareous inclusions" but drying to an indistinct vernicose [varnish-like] film^, (Reid), arising as individual fruitbodies, but soon expanding laterally to form a smooth, effused, compound fruitbody; typically bluish gray; with small but visible, white mineral inclusions, (Roberts), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on fallen hardwood, occasionally on old polypore fruitbodies^, (Roberts), on rotten, barkless wood; on limb; thelephoraceous fungus, Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Populus sp., Prunus sp., Quercus sp. (oak), Salix sp. (willow), Tilia sp. (basswood), Ulmus sp. (elm), (Ginns), on Fagus (beech), (Reid), probably all year; on rotting hardwood, rarely on rotting polypore fruitbodies, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5.75)6.2-8 x (3.5)3.75-4 um, elliptic, sometimes laterally depressed, thin-walled, colorless, germinating by repetition^; BASIDIA "myxarioid", "consisting of a globular, cruciately divided head, 8-10 x 6.5-8 um and a stalk-cell up to 16 um in length with a basal clamp-connexion", epibasidia up to 8 um long; 'CYSTIDIA' very numerous, 24-60 x 3.5-5.2 um, "lanceolate, tapering gradually toward the acute, or rarely obtuse, apex, and projecting for up to 30 um", thin-walled, colorless; DIKARYOPHYSES 2-2.5 um wide, thin-walled, colorless, "often tortuous and either unbranched or slightly branched at the apex"; hymenium 8-20 um thick consists of a single layer of basidia, dikaryophyses, and cystidia; fruit body in section "varies from 11 to 70 um in thickness and consists of a dense granular basal layer of very indistinct, highly gelatinized narrow hyphae, which lie parallel to the substratum in the basal region but gradually curve upward and give rise to the hymenium", (Reid), SPORES (5)6-8.5(10) x (2.5)3-4 um from prints, elliptic to cylindric, "some often constricted or weakly depressed", "frequently producing secondary spores, germinating by germ tube"; HYPHIDIA similar to Stypella grilletii; CYSTIDIA sparse (but always present if searched for), up to 60 um long, "typically projecting from the hymenium for approximately half their length", thin-walled, colorless, acute, swollen towards the base; HYPHAE similar to Stypella grilletii, (Roberts)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Stypella grilletii, Stypella subgelatinosa, and Ofella glaira [as Stypella glaira] lack cystidia, (Roberts). S. grilletii differs chiefly in lacking cystidia (Reid, actually discussing its synonym Sebacina podlachica). Stypella dubia has thick-walled cystidia, (Roberts).
SOURCES  Roberts(3), Reid(3) (as Myxarium subhyalinum), Ginns(5) (as Myxarium subhyalinum), Buczacki(1)*
412
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Subulicium lautum  (H.S. Jacks.) Hjortstam & Ryvarden^  Mycotaxon 9: 513. 1979;  Peniophora lauta  H.S. Jacks.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on coniferous wood, less often on hardwood or ferns, 2) a fruitbody that is whitish, and hairy under a 50x lens from projecting cystidia, the margin indeterminate, 3) spores that are round to elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) cystidia that are projecting, awl-shaped, thick-walled and generally lateral, often with a globe of excreted matter, gloeocystidia often present as well, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Subulicium lautum has been found in OR and ON (Ginns), as well as Denmark, Norway, Poland, and Sweden, (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, usually thin and small; whitish; "under the lens pilose by protruding cystidia"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached]; whitish; when young inconspicuous, when old pilose through projecting cystidia; margin indeterminable [indistinct], (Hjortstam)
HABITAT  mostly on coniferous wood, also on dead or decaying ferns, (Eriksson), Thuja occidentalis, Tsuga canadensis, (Ginns), both on coniferous wood and hardwood, also collected on lumber, (Hjortstam)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES round to nearly round, 6-7 um in diameter, or 6-8 x 4.5-7 um, round or nearly round, smooth, thin-walled or slightly thick-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25(30) x 6-8 um, "broadly clavate, wider in the middle part", sterigmata about 7-9 um long; CYSTIDIA numerous, coming from subiculum, often projecting up to 50 um or more, 100-120(150) um long and 10-13 um wide near base, mostly lateral [from the sides of hyphae], "smooth, thick-walled except in upper part", often "with a globe of excreted matter, easily seen under a lens with strong magnification", [illustrated as tapering throughout their length to a point]; gloeocystidia 30-40 x 5-7 um "may occur now and then in almost all known collections", easily observed because of denser protoplasm and may just be immature form of usual cystidia; HYPHAE monomitic: hyphae 3-3.5(4) um, "thin-walled, without or with only slight incrustations", without clamp connections, in well-developed specimens a dense subiculum consists of closely packed hyphae next to the wood, (Eriksson), SPORES round to nearly round or in some cases elliptic, 6-7 um in diameter, or 6-8 x 4.5-7 um, smooth, inamyloid, with slight cyanophilic reaction, thin-walled or becoming thick-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 25-30 x 6 um, clavate to subcylindric, constricted, thin-walled; CYSTIDIA about 90-120 um long, projecting and subulate [awl-shaped], "with thickened walls, not or slightly encrusted, distinctly bi-rooted (laterocystidia), in some cases mucronate toward the apex"; gloeocystidia also present, but not always occurring; HYPHAE monomitic, about 3-3.5(4) um wide, "distinct and not or very slightly encrusted, thin-walled", without clamp connections, (Hjortstam)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'washed, neat, elegant'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Hjortstam(9), Ginns(5)
413
FAMILY  Hydnodontaceae, Order Trechisporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Subulicystidium longisporum  (Pat.) Parmasto^  Consp. Syst. Cort., 121. 1968;  == Hypochnus longisporus  Pat.;  Peniophora longispora  (Pat.) Hoehn.;  Peniophora asperipilata  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Subulicystidium longisporum is recognized because of the characteristic cystidia and spores. Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) soft, open membranous, whitish to grayish patches, with a smooth surface, 3) spores that are narrowly cylindric to fusiform (usually somewhat curved or sigmoid), inamyloid, acyanophilic, and colorless, 4) 4-spored basidia, often surrounded near the base by another wall thought to be the remnant of a previous basidium, 5) abundant cystidia that are projecting, cylindric, tapering to a narrow tip, bearing longitudinal rows of flat crystal-like bodies (except near the tip), and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, all hyphae with clamp connections.^ | Subulicystidium longisporum has been found in BC, WA, ID, MB, ON, PQ, AZ, CO, FL, GA, IL, LA, ME, MI, MN, MT, NC, NY, and TX, (Ginns). RANGE ^It has also been found in Scandinavia, (Eriksson), in Europe including Switzerland, Asia, (Breitenbach), and in Jamaica, France, Germany, Netherlands, United Kingdom, and Sweden, (Julich(1)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, loosely attached to substrate, "forming thin, open-membranous patches" a few centimeters across, consistency soft, open; surface whitish to grayish, smooth, dull, arachnoid-farinose [cobwebby-mealy]^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, effused [spread out], "often very thin and small"; whitish to pure white (in the herbarium somewhat yellowish or pale sordid); under a 50x lens hispid [bristly] or velvety because of projecting cystidia, (Eriksson), effused, adnate [firmly attached], "hypochnoid or membranaceous, easily separable"; surface even, whitish or light grayish brownish (in older specimens); rhizomorphs lacking, (Julich(1)), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on hardwood, rarely conifer wood^, on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fraxinus (ash), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Picea (spruce), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Ulmus (elm); bark and decaying wood; barkless wood; bark of rotten limb; slash; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on decayed wood of hardwoods and other debris on the ground, also collected on herbs (Aconitum), (Eriksson), on dead barkless conifer wood, according to the literature also on hardwood; fall, (Breitenbach), on rather rotten wood (Julich)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 10-11 x 1.8-2.2 um, narrowly cylindric to fusiform, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-14 x 4.5-6 um, suburniform, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 40-70 x 4 um, slender, acuminate [gradually narrowing to a point], thick-walled toward base, midpart strongly encrusted, tip usually smooth; HYPHAE monomitic, 1.5-3 um wide, "thick-walled, weakly incrusted", septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 12-15(25) x (2)2.5-3 um, usually slightly sigmoid (but may be narrowly fusiform), inamyloid, thin-walled, containing varying numbers of oil droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-15 x 3.5-4.5 um, subclavate-suburniform, "often with a membrane-like incrustation in the basal part"; CYSTIDIA numerous, 40-80(100) x 3-4 um, of subicular origin, subulate [awl-shaped], "mostly of uniform width but sometimes basally thick-walled except for the apical, acute part", +/- cyanophilic, "provided with a characteristic encrustation of unknown matter, in the microscope at low magnification in KOH visible as longitudinal ridges, at higher magnification as rectangular plates dissolving in sulfovanillin", in phase contrast "the crystalline plates appear to have concave horizontal sides"; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-4 um wide, colorless, "thin-walled or with slightly thickened walls", somewhat cyanophilic, encrusted; SUBICULUM "little developed, composed of rather long-celled hyphae, branching at right angles"; all hyphae with clamp connections, (Eriksson), SPORES 10-16 x 1.5-3 um, more or less cylindric, "straight or somewhat curved, slightly narrowed at both ends", inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, thin-walled, often with several droplets, apiculus not distinctive; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-25 x 4-6 um, cylindric to narrowly clavate, somewhat flexuose, with clamp connection at base, sterigmata about 2-3 x 0.5 um, subulate, "in well developed specimens the basal half of most of the basidia is loosely surrounded by a wall (which may be slightly incrusted); there is strong evidence that these are the remaining walls of the former basidia, inside which a new basidium has developed" (= basidial repetition); CYSTIDIA abundant, 40-80 x 4-5 um, (projecting up to 50 um), cylindric, acuminate, brittle, with thickened walls (about 1-1.5 um), "bearing flat circular crystal-like bodies normally arranged in two longitudinal rows" (although in phase contrast there seem to be "3-4 rows of small oblong crystals"), the basidial base mostly bifurcate; HYPHAE 2.5-4 um wide, colorless, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled (up to about 0.8 um), with clamp connections at all septa, (Julich(1)), "The cystidia of the genus Subulicystidium have been studied with the scanning electron microscope. Their ornamentation consists of two rows of ribbon-shaped structures, arranged cross-wise to the main axis of the cystidia. The free ends of these structures are double-refractive and have formerly been described as 'four rows of short crystals'." (Julich(7), from summary)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with long spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Eriksson(7), Julich(1), Julich(7) (German, summary in English), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
414
FAMILY  Carcinomycetaceae, Order Tremellales, Class Tremellomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Syzygospora subsolida  Ginns^  Mycologia 78(4): 633. 1986
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Syzygospora subsolida forms a thin layer on the surface of hypertrophied cap of Pseudomarasmius pallidocephalus, sometimes completely obscuring the cap.^ |The species was named as a species of Syzygospora in 1986, but Liu, X.-Z.(1) in 2015 regarded the genus as polyphyletic, assigning Syzygospora effibulata to Carcinomyces and assigning Syzygospora solida, Syzygospora bachmannii, and Syzygospora physciacearum to Heterocephalacria. It is unclear where Syzygospora subsolida fits in their arrangement, but it is similar to Heterocephalacria solida. Both the online Species Fungorum and MycoBank listed the current name in Syzygospora when accessed January 2, 2022. RANGE ^It was known by 1986 only from the type collection made in BC in Glacier National Park.
FRUITING BODY  fruitbody a thin layer about 50 um thick, "when fresh gelatinous and subhyaline, when dry glossy and crustose", covering the surface of hyphertrophied caps (0.1-0.2cm diam) of host fungus, which in the type is Pseudomarasmius pallidocephalus
HABITAT  on surface of hypertrophied caps of Pseudomarasmius pallidocephalus, sometimes completely obscuring the cap
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.6(8.8) x 3.2-4 um, obliquely lacrymoid with broad, blunt base, smooth, wall colorless, typically with refractive oil droplet at point of attachment, "obliquely attached to sterigmata, some producing blastoconidia"^; basidia "initially broadly clavate, essentially pedicellate", about 15 x 8 um, when mature suburniform to cylindric-clavate, (27)32(40) x 7-9 um "with simple septum at base and incompletely cruciately septate at apex", the apical septum extending downward 3 um into the basidium, sterigmata (2-3)4, each 6-10 um long, "typically with refractive, oily deposit at tip"; conidia blastic, arising from basidiospores, 1.5-3.5 x 1.5-2 um, ovoid, broadly elliptic to nearly round, smooth, thin-walled, wall colorless; conidiophores not seen; subiculum about 10 um thick, of repent, scattered, colorless, thin-walled, simple-septate hyphae 2-2.4(3) um wide; haustorial branches typically 3-4 um in diam, "subglobose, almost pedicellate knobs projecting from the hyphae with a narrow hypha that attaches to the host cell"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like [Syzygospora] solida'
SIMILAR  Heterocephalacria solida Berthier, Mycotaxon 12(1): 114 (1980) (as Syzygospora solida) also occurs on the hypertrophied caps of Pseudomarasmius pallidocephalus, but has clamp connections and was known by 1986 only from the type in Colorado, (Ginns). |Syzygospora marasmoidea also grows on hypertrophied caps of Pseudomarasmius pallidocephalus but has 2-spored basidia and the known range in 1986 was ON, QC, and PE, (Ginns).
SOURCES  Ginns(6), Liu, X.-Z.(1) (regarding the genus)
415
FAMILY  Cyphellaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Thujacorticium mirabile  Ginns^  Mycologia 80: 69. 1988
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on barkless, decayed logs of Western Red-cedar, 2) a pulvinate to crustose fruitbody that is rosy when fresh, smooth to slightly undulating, dull, pruinose or shiny where polished, in sections minutely layered, in layer specimens the margin abrupt, 3) spores that are elliptic to cylindric, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) rather large basidia, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae ascending through scattered basidial zones, with clamp connections, and 6) crystals forming when sections are placed in hot cotton blue - lactic acid.^ | The crystals form when microscopic sections are heated but not boiled in a drop of cotton-blue - lactic acid, crystal formation beginning from 30-120 seconds after heating and attaining maximum size in 10-15 minutes, the crystals basically circular, 15-20 um in diameter when mature, each composed of a series of fan-shaped segments that grow radially, (Ginns(14)). RANGE ^Thujacorticium mirabile is known from the type specimen found in BC, (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  pulvinate [cushion-shaped] to crustose, 1.0-8.0 x 0.5-1.5cm and 0.1-0.2cm thick, gregarious, (discontinuous in habit in illustration); rosy when fresh (the color of Fomitopsis roseus), cream when dry; "surface smooth to slightly undulating, dull, pruinose or shiny where polished, fissured when dry"; in stratose [layered] fruitbodies the margin abrupt, determinate; "context lacking; vertical sections white, firm-chalky, minutely stratose"^, (Ginns(14))
HABITAT  on old, barkless, decayed logs of Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), but 2 collections on unidentified logs were presumably on T. plicata^, (Ginns(14))
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.8-7.6(9.2) x 3.4-4.0(4.4) um, elliptic to subcylindric, adaxially flattened or slightly concave, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, colorless, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, clavate to distinctly pedicellate, 34-40 x 7-9.6 um, acyanophilic; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4.6 um wide, "ascending, no horizontal layer next to substrate, scattered through thickened hymenial zones, branched, somewhat woven", the walls colorless, typically 0.6-0.8 um thick or thin, inamyloid, acyanophilic, with single clamp connections; "strata are primarily composed of collapsed basidia and the detail is difficult to determine", (Ginns(14)) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'wonderful'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Ginns(14), Ginns(5)
416
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella asperula  (P. Karst.) Hoehn. & Litsch.^  Sitzungsber. Kaiserl. Akad. Wiss., Math.-Naturwiss. Kl., Abt. 1, 115: 1570. 1906;  == Hypochnus asperulus  P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody firmly constructed, separable and continuous, and brownish olive, with the surface granulose to colliculose, sometimes smooth, the margin whitish, fringed to fibrillose, the subiculum fibrous and whitish, 3) round to nearly round, pale yellowish brown spores, 4) hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tomentella asperula has been found in ID, AB, ON, FL, LA, MI, and MN, (Ginns), as well as Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, Germany, United Kingdom, Pakistan, and Turkey, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.1cm thick, firmly constructed, separable, continuous; brownish olive; granulose to colliculose, sometimes smooth; sterile margin almost white or very pale yellow, fimbriate [fringed] to fibrillose; subiculum fibrous, much paler than spore-bearing upper surface, almost white or pale yellow^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  Juniperus virginiana (Eastern Juniper), Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), Thuja sp., (Ginns), the Idaho collection "lignicolous"^, (Larsen)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9(10.5) um in diameter, round to nearly round, aculeolate to echinulate, pale yellowish brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-55(65) x 8-10(12) um, clavate, colorless, with clamp connection, sterigmata up to 9 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-4 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-3.5 um wide, straight and rather uniform, colorless to pale yellow, thin-walled or wall thickening slightly, septate, clamp connections frequent; CORDONS up to 80 um wide, branched, colorless, the individual hyphae normally 2.5-3.5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections, but some hyphae are 6-8 um wide, colorless, with clamp connections, "appearing tortuous in relation to other hyphae of a cordon", (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  diminutive of 'asper', Latin for 'rough'
SIMILAR  Tomentella cinerascens also has a pale subiculum, a granulose to colliculose surface, and round spores, but the spores of T. asperula are much smaller, (Larsen). Other Tomentella species recorded from the Pacific Northwest do not have the combination of almost white subiculum, round brown spores 7-9(10.5) um in diameter, and non-distended basidia, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5)
417
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella avellanea  (Burt) Bourdot & Galzin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 40: 153. 1924;  == Hypochnus avellaneus  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood or humus, 2) a mould-like, continuous fruitbody that is avellaneous to wood brown, smooth to deeply fissured, with a darker subiculum, and a fringed to fibrillose margin that is paler than the spore-bearing area, 3) spores that are irregularly roundish to lobed, spiny, and with yellowish brown to pale brown walls, 4) basidia often with transverse septa, and 5) hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tomentella avellanea has been found in BC, WA, ON, AZ, CA, NY, and TX, (Ginns), as well as France and the United Kingdom, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.15cm thick, mucedinoid [mould-like], mostly continuous; avellaneous to wood brown; smooth, sometimes cracking and becoming deeply fissured, exposing the darker subiculum below; margin fimbriate [fringed] to fibrillose, paler than spore-bearing area, almost white to pale brown when dry, cordons evident under 10x lens^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  on wood or humus^ (Larsen), Abies sp. (fir), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus sp. (pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-10 um in diameter, irregularly subglobose [nearly round] to lobed, often elongated along one axis, echinulate, walls yellowish brown to pale brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-70 x 9-14 um, "stout-clavate, somewhat attenuated at the base", with clamp connection at base, often with transverse septa; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3.5-5(6) um wide, wall thickening apparent, colorless, with clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 4-6(7) um wide, pale yellowish brown, wall thickening apparent, septa with frequent clamp connections; CORDONS 15-75 um wide, "pale yellowish brown to dark brown, branched", individual hyphae 3-3.5 um, pale yellowish brown, wall thickening apparent, with clamp connections, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'avellaneous' in color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5)
418
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella badia  (Link) Stalpers^  Revue Mycol., Paris 39(2): 98 (1975);  Tomentellastrum badium  (Link) M.J. Larsen  Nova Hedwigia 35: 5. 1981;  == Sporotrichum badium  Link;  Thelephora floridana  Ellis & Everh.;  Tomentellastrum floridanum  (Ellis & Everh.) M.J. Larsen;  Tomentella fimbriata  M.P. Christ.;  Tomentella atroviolacea  Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on a variety of woody substrates, 2) a firm to cobwebby fruitbody that is colored brown with the surface mealy-granulose to smooth, the subiculum darker, thin, and fibrous, 3) spores that are usually irregular in outline, (often somewhat round), are echinulate to rarely aculeate, and are dull to olive-brown, 4) basidial contents often blue or blue-green in KOH, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections, colorless to yellowish brown, parts becoming green to blue in KOH.^ |Dictionary of the Fungi Tenth Edition regards Tomentellastrum as a synonym of Tomentella (fide Donk 1963) and this species had the current name Tomentella badia (Link) Stalpers in the online Species Fungorum, accessed December 24, 2009 and September 12, 2022. By the latter date, MycoBank listed the same current name. RANGE ^It has been found in ID, ON, YT, AZ, CO, FL, MN, NM, NY, (Ginns(5)). A collection from BC was deposited by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia. It has also been found in Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Netherlands, Poland, Sweden, United Kingdom, and Turkey, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.05cm thick, firm to arachnoid [cobwebby], sometimes encrusting; medium to dull brown; mealy-granulose to smooth; subiculum thin, fibrous, darker than the spore-bearing area^, (Larsen), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on a variety of woody substrates, of both angiosperms and gymnosperms^, (Larsen), Alnus tenuifolia (Thinleaf Alder), Betula alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), Fagus sp. (beech), Picea glauca (White Spruce), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus sp., P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), (Ginns(5)), early summer to fall; also rarely on soil, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-11(12) in diameter, usually irregular in outline, (often somewhat round), echinulate to rarely aculeate, dull to olive-brown^; BASIDIA 40-75 x 7-9(11) um, contents often blue or blue-green in KOH; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-5(6) um wide, colorless to yellowish brown, parts becoming green, bluish green or blue in KOH, septate, clamp connections absent; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-5.5(7) um wide, dull brown to olive brown, some parts becoming green in KOH, septate, clamp connections absent; CORDONS rare, up to 40 um wide, brown, (Larsen), SPORES 7-12 um across, globose to irregular, usually aculeate to echinulate, brown, (Ginns(23))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'brown, chestnut-colored'
SIMILAR  Two other species that were formerly in Tomentellastrum occur in western North America, as Tomentellastrum montanense and Tomentellastrum brunneofirmum. They have both been synonymized with Tomentella fuscocinerea (Pers.) Donk in the online Species Fungorum, accessed September 12, 2022, but MycoBank, accessed on the same date, has both with the current name Tomentella alutaceoumbrina (Bres.) Bourdot & Galzin. These two species formerly in Tomentellastrum have spores nearly round to elliptic (rarely round), regular in outline, and echinulate to warted, whereas T. badium has spores round to irregular, usually aculeate to echinulate, (Ginns(23)). Tomentellastrum montanensis, found in AB, MT, NM, (Ginns(5)), has smaller spores and a relatively dark spore-bearing surface, (Ginns(23)). Spores of Tomentellastrum montanensis are "7-10.5 um across, somewhat irregular in outline and elongated along one axis, irregularly subglobose to oval and flattened slightly on one side, aculeolate to echinulate, walls pale yellowish brown", (Larsen). Tomentellastrum montanensis is purplish brown, the surface becoming colliculose, and cordons are absent, whereas T. badium is medium to dull brown, the surface becoming mealy-granulose, and cordons are rare, (Larsen). Tomentellastrum brunneofirmum M.J. Larsen, found in AZ, CO, and NM, (Ginns(5)) has a purplish brown to dark brown spore-bearing surface, spores 7.5-9.5 x 6-8 um with greenish contents, and narrow hyphae 2.0-3.5(4.5) um, (Ginns(23)). Tomentellastrum brunneofirmum has subicular hyphae usually 2-3.5 um wide, whereas T. badium has subicular hyphae usually 3-7 um wide, (Larsen). 
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(2) (as Tomentellastrum badium), Ginns(5) (as Tomentellastrum badium), Ginns(23) (as Tomentellastrum badium), Buczacki(1)*
419
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella bryophila  (Pers.) M.J. Larsen^  Mycologia Memoir 4: 51. 1974;  == Sporotrichum bryophilum  Pers.;  Tomentella pallidofulva  (Peck) Litsch.;  Tomentella subferruginea  (Burt) Donk
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) membranous-tomentose, mould-like, continuous growth on wood, 2) a ferruginous brown fruitbody (gray to somewhat violet when young) that is smooth, mealy, and faintly reticulate, the subiculum and margin darker, 3) round to nearly round, yellow spores with spines up to 3 um long, and 4) basidia with transverse septa, and pale yellow encrusting material often on walls, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, and 6) subicular hyphae of 2 types.^ | Tomentella bryophila is "for the most part, readily diagnosed by its bright ferruginous fertile areas and large, normally globose, aculeate, yellow basidiospores. However, it grades morphologically into T. fuscoferruginosa, which has irregular spores and apparently only one kind of subicular hyphae. The distinction between the two is by no means clear." (Larsen, Latin name in italics). RANGE ^Tomentella bryophila has been found in BC, ID, MB, ON, AZ, CO, DC, FL, GA, IL, IN, LA, MA, MD, MI, MN, MT, NC, NM, NY, OH, PA, TN, and VT, (Ginns), as well as Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Sweden, United Kingdom, Tunisia, and Pakistan, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.1cm thick, mucedinoid [mould-like], adherent to separable, continuous; bright to dull ferruginous brown, sometimes approaching reddish orange; faintly reticulate; margin darker than spore-bearing area, normally colored the same as the subiculum^, (Larsen), resupinate, thin, membranous-tomentose patches several centimeters across, attached loosely, consistency "soft, fibrous, cottony"; "gray-somewhat violet when young, later light rust-brown with a yellowish tint"; smooth, farinose [mealy], dull; "subiculum gray and darker than the brown hymenium (more easily seen when dry than fresh)"; "thinning out to bounded at the margin, without hyphal strands", (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on the underside of rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, summer-fall^, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Amelanchier (serviceberry), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking aspen), Quercus (oak), Robinia (locust), Thuja sp., Tsuga (hemlock), Fomes sp. (polypore), (Ginns), in Belgium, recorded on moss, and in France lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen), on rotting wood and bark of hardwoods, "rarely on other organic materials such as old leather"; summer to fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-11(12) um in diameter, round to nearly round, sometimes irregularly round, normally aculeate, sometimes echinulate, pale to bright yellow^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-60 x 7-9(11) um, clavate, with clamp connection at base, transverse septa present, "pale yellow encrusting material frequently present on basidial walls", sterigmata up to 6 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 4-6 um wide, "thin-walled, sometimes with local thickenings", with clamp connections, pale olivaceous brown to colorless, or becoming bright yellow due to yellow encrusting material; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) some 4.5-6(7) um wide, closely spaced, dull olive brown, "thick-walled and often with localized thickening", with clamp connections frequent, 2) some 4-6 um wide, violaceous brown, thin-walled to thick-walled, often with localized thickenings, "clamped, septa without clamps infrequent", (Larsen), SPORES (7)8-10 um in diameter, excluding spines, nearly round, with pointed spines up to 3 um long, spore brown; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-60 x 8-11 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic brown, thin-walled to thick-walled, hyphae of subhymenium 4-6 um wide, of subiculum 4-8 um wide, septa with clamp connections; hyphal strands absent, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'liking moss'
SIMILAR  Tomentella fuscoferruginosa is similar (see NOTES), (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
420
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella calcicola  (Bourdot & Galzin) M.J. Larsen^  Taxon 16: 511. 1967;  == Caldesiella ferruginosa var. calcicola  Bourdot & Galzin;  Caldesiella calcicola  (Bourdot & Galzin) M.P. Christ.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a cottony, separable, continuous fruitbody that is dull ferruginous, the surface smooth to granulose or toothed, the margin paler and fringed to fibrillose, the subiculum thin and dark ferruginous brown, and cordons usually visible under 10x lens, 3) spores that are round to nearly round, verrucose to aculeolate, and brown, and 4) subicular hyphae of three types.^ RANGE ^Tomentella calcicola has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, CO, IA, MT, and NY, (Ginns), as well as Belgium, France, and Russia, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.2cm thick, byssoid [cottony], separable, spore-bearing area continuous; dull ferruginous, paler towards the margin; surface smooth to granulose or distinctly toothed, teeth up to 0.15cm long; sterile margin wide to narrow, fimbriate [fringed] to fibrillose, paler than spore-bearing area; subiculum thin, dark ferruginous brown; cordons spreading out over the substrate and usually visible at the margin under a 10x lens^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  Acer sp. (maple), Alnus sp. (alder), A. incana (Speckled Alder), A. tenuifolia (Thinleaf Alder), Picea sp. (spruce), Populus sp., P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood)^, (Ginns), in Europe also on Juniperus (juniper) and lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4)5-6 um diameter, or 5-6 x 4.5 um, round to nearly round, verrucose to aculeolate, "pale brown to umbrinous"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-40 x 6-7(8) um, clavate, often with a median constriction, with a clamp connection at the base, rarely with transverse septa, sterigmata up to 6 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3.5 um wide, pale yellow, thin-walled, with clamp connections; TRAMAL HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) some generative, 2-4.5 um wide, "forming a distinct central core and projecting somewhat at the sterile apices", yellowish brown, wall thickening apparent, with clamp connections, "often with an ochre or brown agglutinating material which dissolves, resulting in a similarly colored diffusate", 2) some skeletal, 1-2 um wide, yellow, thick-walled, aseptate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 3 types: 1) some generative, 2-3(4) um wide, yellowish brown, wall thickening apparent, normally septate, with frequent clamp connections, "often encrusted with granular material which sometimes gives the hyphae a spinulose appearance", 2) some generative, 3-5 um wide, "thin-walled, often collapsed, rarely branched", usually septate, with infrequent clamp connections, "often aseptate for relatively long distances", 3) some skeletal, 1-2 um wide, bright yellow to citrine, thick-walled, usually aseptate, rarely with septate; CORDONS up to 40 um wide, yellowish brown, individual hyphae "mostly thin-walled, 2-3.5 um diam, clamped", (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living on stone': Bourdot and Galzin collection was lapidicolous
SIMILAR  Tomentella ferruginea and Tomentella crinalis also have a dimitic hyphal system: they both have larger spores, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5)
421
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella cinerascens  (P. Karst.) Hoehn. & Litsch.^  Sitzungsber. Kaiserl. Akad. Wiss., Math.-Naturwiss. Kl. Abt. 1, 115: 1570. 1906;  Hypochnus cinerascens  P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a tomentose, separable fruitbody that is gray to dull buff, the surface papillose to colliculose, the margin and subiculum almost white, 3) spores that are mostly round to nearly round, aculeolate to echinulate, and brown, 4) subicular hyphae that are colorless to pale brown (some with yellow-brown contents), with frequent clamp connections, and 5) white cordons.^ RANGE ^Tomentella cinerascens has been found in BC, WA, ON, AZ, MI, MT, NY, and SD, (Ginns), as well as Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Poland, Sweden, Algeria, and Turkey, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.03cm thick, separable, tomentose, somewhat arachnoid [cobwebby] when young, spore-bearing areas "at first discontinuous, becoming continuous in older specimens"; gray to dull buff; sometimes smooth, mostly papillose or colliculose, rarely granulose; "sterile margin fibrillose to mostly byssoid", much paler than spore-bearing areas, almost white; subiculum loose-fibrous, almost white; cordons obscure, white^, (Larsen), spore deposit pale brown, (Buczacki)
HABITAT  Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Populus, Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock)^, (Ginns), also Phragmites (reed), Salix (willow), Aesculus, moss, (Larsen, in Europe), summer to fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 um in diameter, or 5-6 x 5 um, mostly round to nearly round, sometimes irregular to irregularly round, "aculeolate to echinulate, walls hazel to dull brown"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-45 x 6.5-8 um, clavate, sterigmata up to 5 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-4 um, colorless (parts sometimes green in KOH), thin-walled, with clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-4(5) um wide, walls colorless or light tan to pale brown (some with contents dull yellowish brown), thin-walled or with wall thickening slight, septate, with frequent clamp connections; CORDONS up to 90 um wide, pale brown to almost colorless, individual hyphae 1.5-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming ash-gray'
SIMILAR  Tomentella asperula also has a pale subiculum, a granulose to colliculose surface, and round spores, but spores of T. asperula are much larger, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
422
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella coerulea  (Bres.) Hoehn. & Litsch.^  Sitzungsber. Kaiserl. Akad. Wiss., Math.-Naturwiss. Kl., Abt. 1, 116: 831. 1907;  == Hypochnus coeruleus  Bres.;  Tomentella papillata  Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Hypochnus cervinus  Burt;  Tomentella cervina  (Burt) Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a pinkish buff to buff fruitbody with a granulose to colliculose surface, the margin pale and radiate-fibrillose, 3) spores that are lobed, irregular, irregularly round, or nearly round, echinulate, and pale brown, 4) basidia with red contents in water mount, and with transverse septa, and 5) hyphae with clamp connections.^ |According to rules of Latin and Latinization, "coerulea" should be corrected to "caerulea", but this is not done here because the change would affect the first syllable: "The liberty of correcting a name is to be used with reserve, especially if the change affects the first syllable and, above all, the first letter of the name.", Article 60.3 International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (St. Louis Code). RANGE ^It has been found in BC, WA, AB, MB, NS, ON, AZ, CO, KY, MD, MI, MN, MT, and NM, (Ginns), Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France, Germany, Poland, Sweden, United Kingdom, and Turkey, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.05cm thick, mucedinoid [mould-like], adhering to substrate, spore-bearing area sometimes discontinuous, mostly continuous; pinkish buff to buff; granulose, papillose or colliculose; "sterile margin irregular, narrow, distinctly radiate-fibrillose, paler than the fertile areas, gray to almost white when dry", subiculum cobwebby, very pale tan-brown^, (Larsen), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Alnus sp. (alder), Betula sp. (birch), Fraxinus nigra (Black Ash), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Prosopis juliflora (Mesquite), Quercus gambelii (Gambel's Oak), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Tsuga sp. (hemlock)^, (Ginns), noted with some collections in Europe to be terricolous as well as lignicolous, (Larsen), on rotting wood and occasionally on soil; fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (6)7-8(8.5) um in diameter, lobed, irregular, irregularly round, or nearly round, echinulate, pale brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-60 x (6)7-8.5 um, clavate, with clamp connection at base, transverse septa present, "contents often composed of red granular material which is visible in water mounts but becoming ochre in KOH, adhering crystalline material becoming green in KOH", sterigmata up to 5 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE (2)2.5-3(4) um wide, colorless to dull brown, thin-walled, with clamp connections, adhering crystalline material becoming green in KOH; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-3(4) um wide, pale yellowish brown to infrequently dull brown, wall thickening discernible, septate, with clamp connections frequent, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'sky-blue'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5) (as T. caerulea), Buczacki(1)*
423
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella crinalis  (Fr.) M.J. Larsen^  Taxon 16: 511. 1967;  == Hydnum crinale  Fr.;  Caldesiella ferruginosa  (Fr.) Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a ferruginous to dull brown fruitbody that has teeth up to 0.2cm long, the margin fringed and the same color or lighter, the subiculum the same color as the upper surface, 3) spores that are brown, irregular to mostly irregularly round, warted or ridged to more rarely echinulate, the warts often with 2 tubercles, 4) basidia often with transverse septa, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the generative hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tomentella crinalis has been found in WA, ID, AB, MB, NS, ON, AZ, CA, CO, IA, IN, KY, LA, MD, ME, MN, MT, NY, and SD, (Ginns). There is a collection from BC deposited by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia.
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.2cm thick, "often separable, felty to tomentose", fertile areas discontinuous; dark ferruginous to dull brown; distinctly toothed, teeth up to 0.175cm long; sterile margin fimbriate [fringed], colored the same as or lighter than the fertile areas; subiculum thin, colored the same as the fertile areas; cordons present but obscure under 10x lens^, (Larsen), resupinate, thin, tomentose, cottony, felty patches several centimeters to decimeters across, +/- easily detached; rust-brown to dark brown; surface distinctly bluntly verrucose to slightly hydnoid, teeth up to 0.1(0.2)cm long; margin distinctly bounded, growth zones filamentous, forming rhizomorphs, (Breitenbach), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on rotten wood of conifers and hardwoods, fall-spring^, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fraxinus (ash), Pinus (pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Quercus (oak), Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9(10) um in diameter, irregular to mostly irregularly round, warted or ridged to more rarely echinulate, warts often bifurcate, spore pale brown or umbrinous^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-55(65) x 7-9 um, clavate, with clamp connection at base, often with transverse septa, sterigmata up to 6 um and often with septa; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-4 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, with clamp connections; TRAMAL HYPHAE of two types: 1) some generative hyphae 2.5-4(5) um wide and forming a distinct central core, citrine to pale brown, thin-walled, with clamp connections, 2) some skeletal hyphae 1-2.5 um wide, thick-walled, unbranched, aseptate; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) some generative hyphae 2.5-4.5 um wide, pale yellow to yellowish brown, wall thickening apparent, septate with clamp connections frequent, 2) some skeletal hyphae 1-2.5 um wide, bright yellow to citrine, thick-walled, rarely septate; CORDONS of 2 types: 1) some up to 25 um wide, yellowish brown, the individual generative hyphae 2-3 um wide, with clamp connections, 2) some up to 15 um wide, yellow, the individual skeletal hyphae 1-2.5 um wide, thick-walled, rarely septate; apices of teeth sterile, (Larsen), SPORES 9-10 x 8-9 um (excluding warts), nearly round, coarsely verrucose to slightly crested, warts sometimes with 2 tubercles, brown; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50 x 7-10 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE dimitic: 1) generative hyphae 2-5 um wide, yellowish, +/- thick-walled, most septa with clamp connections, 2) skeletal hyphae 2-3 um wide, brown-yellow, thick-walled, sparsely septate and without clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tomentella calcicola and Tomentella ferruginea also have a dimitic hyphal system: Tomentella calcicola has smaller spores, and Tomentella ferruginea has a fruitbody that is granulose to colliculose, colored olive green to olive brown, and the fungal tissues assume a green or bluish green color in KOH, (Larsen). See also SIMILAR section of Amaurodon viridis.
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
424
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella ellisii  (Sacc.) Julich & Stalpers^  Verh. Kon. Ned. Akad. Wetensch., Afd. Natuurk., Tweed Sect., 74: 236. 1980;  == Zygodesmus ellisii  Sacc.;  Tomentella microspora  (P. Karst.) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Tomentella ochracea  (Sacc.) M.J. Larsen;  Tomentella sparsa  (Burt) Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, or sometimes on humus or on the ground, 2) fruitbodies that are normally brown vinaceous to dull purplish brown, the appearance mould-like with a smooth surface that is continuous when mature, the margin (up to 1cm wide) and the subiculum pale yellow to distinctly yellow, and cordons visible under hand lens, and 3) spores that are round or nearly round, aculeolate to echinulate [spiny], and pale to medium brown.^ RANGE ^Tomentella ellisii has been found in BC, ID, ON, PQ, AZ, MN, NH, NJ, and NY, (Ginns), as well as Austria, Czechoslovakia, Finland, France, Germany, Macedonia, Netherlands, Sweden, United Kingdom, Morocco, India, and Sri Lanka, (Larsen). It was reported for WA by Luther(2).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.05cm thick, mucedinoid [mould-like], "normally adherent to occasionally separable", fertile area continuous when mature; brown vinaceous to dull purplish brown, sometimes dull avellaneous to buff; smooth; sterile margin up to 1cm wide, fibrillose to fimbriate [fringed], pale yellow to distinctly yellow; subiculum firm-fibrous, very pale tan or colorless to pale yellow (also said to be pale yellow to distinctly yellow); cordons evident at 10x; fruitbodies often acquiring a dark green tint when exposed to KOH^, (Larsen), spore deposit pale brown, (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on wood, also humicolous [on humus] and terricolous [on ground]^, (Larsen), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Spiraea, Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns), on rotting wood of hardwoods and conifers, "also recorded on debris of bulrush and common reed"; summer to fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-8.5(9) um in diameter, "globose, irregularly subglobose or globose, usually elongated along one axis [all italicized]", aculeolate to echinulate, pale to medium brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-40 x 7-9 um, clavate, colorless, contents sometimes pale yellowish brown in KOH, parts frequently dull green in KOH, clamp connection at the base, transverse septa infrequent, sterigmata up to 6 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3.5-6(7) um wide, thin-walled, colorless, contents often dull yellowish brown in KOH, "exterior parts of cell walls often dull green in KOH", with clamp connections, "constricted at the septa, septa often closely spaced and then appearing torose"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE (2.5)3-5(7) um wide, "very variable in form and dimension", septate, with clamp connections frequent, often ampullate and appearing constricted at the septa, wall thickening slight or noticeably thick-walled, some hyphae becoming irregular or swollen, normally colorless, "infrequently pale yellowish brown, hyphal contents infrequently dull yellow brown in KOH"; CORDONS up to 80 um wide, colorless to very pale tan, individual hyphae 2-4 um wide, colorless, with clamp connections, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9) (as Tomentella ochracea), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*, Luther(2)*
425
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella ferruginea  (Pers.) Pat.^  Hym. Eur., 154. 1887;  == Thelephora ferruginea  Pers.;  == Hypochnus ferrugineus  (Pers. per Pers.) Fr.;  == Corticium ferrugineum  (Pers. per Pers.) Fr.;  = Grandinia coriaria  Peck;  = Tomentella coriaria  (Peck) Bourdot & Galzin;  = Grandinia rudis  Peck;  = Tomentella fusca  (Pers.) J. Schroet.;  = Tomentella suberis  Pat.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth, usually on wood, 2) a green to dull brown, cobwebby to mould-like fruitbody, the surface colliculose to sometimes smooth, the margin and subiculum yellowish brown to ferruginous brown, the margin fringed, 3) spores appearing 3-lobed or 4-lobed to irregular, echinulate, and pale brown, 4) fungal tissue normally assuming a green, bluish green, or purple color in KOH, basidial contents becoming green to purple, the basidia often and sterigmata sometimes with transverse septa, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, with 3 types of subicular hyphae.^ RANGE ^Tomentella ferruginea has been found in BC, WA, ID, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, AZ, CO, FL, IA, KY, MA, MD, MI, MN, MT, NH, NM, NY, OH, SC, TN, VA, VT, WI, and WV, (Ginns), as well as Costa Rica, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Netherlands, Sweden, United Kingdom, Tunisia, India, and New Zealand, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.1cm thick, arachnoid [cobwebby] to mucedinoid [mould-like], "separable in small felt-like pieces", spore-bearing area continuous; bright green to olive green to olive brown or dull brown; colliculose to sometimes smooth, individual colliculi hemispheric to blunt conic; subiculum yellowish brown to ferruginous brown, fibrous; sterile margin fimbriate [fringed], colored the same as the subiculum to somewhat paler^, (Larsen), spore deposit pale brown, (Buczacki)
HABITAT  usually on wood^, also recorded as "humicolous, lignicolous", as "on angiospermous wood, terricolous", and as "lignicolous, leather scraps", (Larsen), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Juniperus (juniper), Liriodendron, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Tilia (basswood), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga (hemlock), Yucca, (Ginns), on rotting hardwood, also recorded on rush debris; summer to fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-8 um in diameter, appearing 3-lobed or 4-lobed to irregular, echinulate, pale brown^; fungal tissue normally assuming a green, bluish green, or purple color in KOH; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-45 x 6-8 um, clavate, with clamp connection at base, often with transverse septa, "sterigmata up to 5 um long and sometimes with septa", "basidial contents becoming green, bluish green, or purple, a brown incrusting material on basidial walls sometimes present but tends to dissolve, producing a similarly colored diffusate" [quotation in italics, it is not specified whether this is applying to KOH preparations]; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2-3(4) um wide, colorless, thin-walled, septate, with clamp connections frequent, sometimes with brown encrusting material; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of three types 1) some generative, 3-4(5) um wide, citrine to yellowish brown, (contents frequently becoming dark ocher), thick-walled, septate, with clamp connections frequent, 2) some generative 4-6(7) um wide, pale citrine, wall thickening apparent, septate, clamp connections rare, rarely branched, 3) some skeletal, 2-2.5(3) um wide, citrine, thick-walled, rarely branched, normally aseptate; CORDONS of 2 types: 1) some up to 90 um wide, brown, composed of generative hyphae that are 2-3 um wide, with clamp connections, 2) some up to 30 um wide, "citrine, composed of skeletal hyphae" that are 2-2.5 um wide, citrine, citrine, thick-walled, and with rare septa, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'rust-colored'
SIMILAR  Tomentella calcicola and Tomentella crinalis also have a dimitic hyphal system: Tomentella calcicola has smaller spores, and Tomentella crinalis has a fruitbody that is distinctly toothed, colored dark ferruginous to dull brown, and fungal tissues do not assume green or bluish green color in KOH, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
426
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella fibrosa  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Koeljalg^  Syn. Fung. (Oslo) 9: 122. 1996;  Tomentellina fibrosa  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) M.J. Larsen  Mycologia Memoir 4: 115. 1974;  Zygodesmus fibrosus  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Kneiffiella fibrosa  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) M.J. Larsen;  Hypochnus canadensis  Burt;  Tomentella ferruginosa  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Sacc. & Trotter
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on rotten wood, 2) thin, tomentose, cottony patches that are rust-brown to dark brown, the surface tomentose to slightly verrucose, 3) when fresh, cystidia that may be detected with a hand lens: microscopically they are cylindric, thick-walled, multiply septate, and brown, and arise in clusters, 4) spores that are brown, nearly round, and coarsely verrucose, some of their warts with double tubercles, and 5) a dimitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections.^ |Ginns(5) listed Tomentellina fibrosa (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) M.J. Larsen as the current name, but Ginns(23) said that Tomentellina is a synonym, giving as the authority the publication where the name Tomentella fibrosa (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Koeljalg was published in 1996. RANGE ^Tomentella fibrosa has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NF, ON, PQ, YT, AK, AL, AZ, CO, ME, MI, MN, MT, NH, NM, NY, SC, UT, VT, and WY, (Ginns(5)). It occurs also in Europe (including Switzerland) and Asia (Breitenbach(2)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin, tomentose, cottony patches several centimeters across, easily detached; rust-brown to dark brown, surface tomentose to slightly verrucose, (occasionally slightly hydnoid), in part permeated with rhizomorphs; when fresh, the cystidia are visible with a hand lens; margin distinctly bounded to diffuse^, (Breitenbach), spore deposit brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on rotten wood, as well as bark of hardwoods and conifers^, (Breitenbach), Betula (birch), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); decayed leaves; organic debris, (Ginns(5)), summer to fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-9(11) um in diameter, excluding warts, nearly round, coarsely verrucose, some warts with double tubercles, spore brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 35-45 x 7-8 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA arising in clusters from the subiculum, up to 200 x 4-7 um, cylindric, blunt, thick-walled, multiply septate, brown; HYPHAE dimitic: 1) generative hyphae 2-4 um wide, colorless to yellowish, thin-walled, septa without clamp connections, 2) skeletal hyphae 3-5 um wide, brownish, thick-walled, septa without clamp connections; hyphal strands present, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fibrous'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)* (as Tomentellina fibrosa), Ginns(5) (as Tomentellina fibrosa), Ginns(23), Buczacki(1)*
427
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella fuscoferruginosa  (Bres.) Litsch.^  Ann. Mycol. 39: 377. 1941;  == Hypochnus fuscoferruginosus  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a mould-like to floccose fruitbody continuous and normally adherent, colored ferruginous to dark brown, the surface smooth to punctate, the subiculum fibrous, dark brown, and darker than the spore-bearing area, the margin cobwebby, colored as the subiculum, 3) spores that are irregularly round to lobed when mature, echinulate to aculeate, and bright yellow to dull yellowish brown, 4) basidia 2-spored to 4-spored, often with transverse septa, 5) subicular hyphae with frequent clamp connections, with wall thickening apparent or becoming very thick-walled.^ RANGE ^Tomentella fuscoferruginosa has been found in WA, ON, GA, NC, NY, and TN, (Ginns), as well as Macedonia and Poland (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.05cm thick, mucedinoid [mould-like], becoming floccose in some parts, normally adherent, spore-bearing surface continuous; ferruginous, dull ferruginous or dark brown; "smooth to punctate"; subiculum "fibrous, dark brown", darker than the spore-bearing area; sterile margin arachnoid [cobwebby], colored as subiculum^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  Abies sp. (fir), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Acer sp. (maple), Betula sp. (birch), Pinus sp. (pine), Populus sp., Quercus sp. (oak)^, (Ginns), in Poland on Alnus (alder), (Larsen)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (7)8-10(12) um in diameter, irregularly round to lobed when mature, echinulate to aculeate, bright yellow to dull yellowish brown^; BASIDIA 2-spored to 4-spored, 30-45 x 8-11 um, clavate, contents often dull yellowish brown in KOH, with clamp connection at base, often with transverse septa, sterigmata up to 7 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 4-5 um wide, pale brown, wall thickening apparent, with clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 4-6.5 um, dull brown to yellowish brown, wall thickening apparent or becoming very thick-walled, thickening often localized, septate, with clamp connections frequent, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tomentella bryophila grades into T. fuscoferruginosa and the distinction is not clear: however, T. bryophila has two types of subicular hyphae and T. fuscoferruginosa apparently has one kind, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5)
428
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella kootenaiensis  M.J. Larsen^  Beih. Nova Hedwigia 51. 174. 1975
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a mould-like adherent fruitbody colored dull grayish brown, the surface smooth, the margin farinaceous to pruinose, the subiculum thin and colored as the spore-bearing surface, 3) spores that are round or irregularly round, echinulate, and pale brown, 4) subicular hyphae that are noticeably thick-walled, with clamp connections, and often irregular with swollen and torose segments.^ RANGE ^Tomentella kootenaiensis has been found in BC and AB (Ginns(5)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, up to 0.025cm thick, mucedinoid [mould-like], adherent, spore-bearing area continuous; dull grayish brown; smooth; sterile margin farinaceous [mealy] to pruinose; subiculum "thin and not easily discernible", colored as fertile area; annual^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  on Populus sp., also on coniferous wood^, (Larsen)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-11 um in diameter, round to less frequently irregularly round sometimes flattened adaxially, echinulate, pale brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-60 x 6-7(8) um, clavate, with clamp connection at base, sterigmata up to 6 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, pale yellow to colorless, with clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 4-7 um wide, noticeably thick-walled, with clamp connections, often irregular and then with swollen and torose segments up to 9 um wide, pale yellowish brown, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Kootenay', referring to Kootenay National Park, where type was found
SIMILAR  Tomentella sublilacina is similar but has spores that are irregular in outline to strongly lobed and are usually elongated along one axis (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(10), Ginns(5)
429
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella lilacinogrisea  Wakef.^  Trans. Br. mycol. Soc. 49(3): 360. 1966;  Tomentella neobourdotii  M.J. Larsen  Mycologia 60: 1179. 1968
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a cobwebby to cottony or floccose fruitbody (usually mould-like), that is dark brown to dull grayish blue, granulose to colliculose, the sterile margin sometimes paler, the subiculum fibrous, dark brown or sometimes dull grayish blue, 3) spores that are round to irregularly round, spiny, and dull brown, 4) basidia 4-spored to rarely 5-spored or 6-spored, sometimes with transverse septa, 5) subicular hyphae of 2 types but mostly the type that is dull brown, frequently with clamp connections, wall thickening apparent, and with dull brown encrusting material giving the walls a rough or spinulose appearance.^ |The online Species Fungorum, accessed September 9, 2012 and March 17, 2022, listed Tomentella neobourdotii as a synonym of Tomentella lilacinogrisea Wakef., as did MycoBank on the second date. RANGE ^Tomentella lilacinogrisea (as Tomentella neobourdotii) has been found in BC, ON, PQ, AZ, KY, MA, MI, MT, NC, NM, NY, TN, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Macedonia, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.04cm thick, arachnoid [cobwebby] to byssoid [cottony] or sometimes floccose, usually mucedinoid [mould-like], adherent to separable, spore-bearing area discontinuous to continuous; dark brown to dull grayish blue; granulose to colliculose, rarely smooth; sterile margin usually colored as spore-bearing area "but sometimes much paler and then pale tan"; subiculum "fibrous and usually dark brown, sometimes dull grayish blue"^, (Larsen), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carpinus (hornbeam), Fagus (beech), Larix (larch), Pinus (pine), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja, Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), Polyporus (polypore)^, (Ginns), also in Europe on Castanea (chestnut), Cerasus, Crataegus (hawthorn), Juniperus (juniper), Picea (spruce), in France on coniferous wood, lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen), fall; also on fern debris, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6.5(7.5) um in diameter, round, nearly round, irregularly round, or rarely irregular when mature, "aculeolate to echinulate, sometimes aculeate, walls dull brown"^; BASIDIA 4-spored to rarely 5-spored or 6-spored, 20-35 x 5.5-7.5 um, clavate, with clamp connection at base, infrequently with transverse septa; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-4.5 um wide, pale to dark brown near the subiculum and paler toward the hymenium, thin-walled, with clamp connections, often encrusted as in subicular hyphae, in some specimens a bluish to greenish diffusate is apparent in KOH; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types: 1) some 3-5(6.5) um wide, dull brown, frequently with clamp connections, wall thickening apparent, with dull brown encrusting material giving the walls a rough or spinulose appearance, walls rarely smooth, 2) some rare 2-4 um wide, pale to dark brown, "thick-walled with the lumen sometimes not evident", usually septate without clamp connections, "with brown encrusting material giving the walls a rough or spinulose appearance"; CORDONS infrequent or rare, up to 35 um wide, dark brown, individual hyphae 2-4.5 um wide, brown, with clamp connections, often encrusted as above, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'new Tomentella bourdotii'
SIMILAR  Tomentella ramosissima has subicular hyphae that "are very thick-walled and normally smooth (without encrustation)", and scattered spores occur "that are wholly, or in part, green or bluish green when mounted in KOH", (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9) (as Tomentella neobourdotii), Ginns(5) (as Tomentella neobourdotii), Buczacki(1)
430
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella nitellina  Bourdot & Galzin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 40: 151. 1924
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood or on rock, 2) a mould-like, mealy-velvety, or furfurescent fruitbody, mostly adherent, the mostly discontinuous spore-bearing surface colored pale yellowish brown, smooth or minutely punctate or granulose, the margin cottony to fibrillose, paler, the subiculum also paler, 3) spores that are irregularly round to irregular, aculeolate to echinulate, and brown, 4) basidia that are distended up to 20 um wide, 5) subhymenial hyphae that are thin-walled, colorless to pale yellow or brown, with clamp connections, 6) subicular hyphae with wall thickening, that are brown to yellowish brown, with frequent clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tomentella nitellina has been found in WA, BC, NS, ON, and NC, (Ginns), and also in France (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.03cm thick, mucedinoid [mould-like], mealy-velvety, or furfurescent, "mostly adherent, some parts becoming separable", spore-bearing areas mostly discontinuous; pale yellowish brown; "smooth, sometimes appearing minutely punctate or granulose"; sterile margin paler than the spore-bearing area, byssoid [cottony] to fibrillose; subiculum pale yellowish brown, paler than the spore-bearing areas^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  in Washington on Picea (spruce), in France lapidicolous [on rock]^, (Larsen), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Picea sp. (spruce), Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Populus sp., Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Thuja plicata (Western Red-Cedar); on twig (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8(9) um in diameter, or 7-10(11) um across, irregularly round to sometimes irregular, aculeolate to echinulate, pale brown to umbrinous^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-80 x 10-15 um, up to 20 um wide 10-15 um above the basal septa, colorless or somewhat umbrinous, with clamp connection at base, sterigmata up to 6 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, colorless to pale yellow, often umbrinous, thin-walled, with clamp connections, "(this stratum also contains elements that appear to be basidia that have failed to mature)"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 3-4.5(6) um wide, brown to yellowish brown, wall thickening apparent, septate, with clamp connections frequent, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bright'
SIMILAR  Tomentella terrestris also has distended basidia but spores are smaller, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5)
431
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella pilosa  (Burt) Bourdot & Galzin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 40: 151. 1924;  == Hypochnus pilosus  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a cobwebby to cottony, separable fruitbody colored dull brown, the surface smooth to sometimes granulose or colliculose, the margin irregular, fibrillose, and paler, the subiculum thin, fibrous, and dark brown, 3) spores that are irregular, echinulate to aculeate, and yellowish to dark golden brown, 4) basidia often with transverse septa, 5) projecting capitulate cystidia, colored as and arising from subicular hyphae, somewhat thick-walled, with a clamp connection at the base and with unclamped septa occurring along their length, often finely encrusted or bearing large granules at apex, 6) subicular hyphae that are golden brown, with clamp connections, and 7) abundant cordons.^ RANGE ^Tomentella pilosa has been found in WA, MB, ON, AZ, CO, KY, LA, MD, MI, MN, MT, NC, NM, NY, PA, and WI, (Ginns). Distribution also includes Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France, Germany, United Kingdom, India, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.1cm thick, arachnoid [cobwebby] to byssoid [cottony], separable from substrate; spore-bearing areas continuous; dull brown to rarely olive brown; smooth to sometimes granulose or colliculose (cystidia barely distinguishable under 10x lens); sterile margin irregular, fibrillose, paler than the spore-bearing areas; subiculum thin, fibrous, dark brown; cordons visible under 10x lens^, (Larsen), resupinate, attached loosely, "forming thin, membranous patches" several centimeters across, consistency fibrous-tomentose; light ocher to olive-brownish; surface granular-tomentose; margin diffuse and with brownish rhizomorphs, (Breitenbach), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, commonly on the underside of rotten branches^, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Liriodendron, Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Tilia (basswood), Ulmus (elm), (Ginns), also Alnus (alder), Carpinus (hornbeam), Fagus (beech), Thymus (thyme), moss, (Larsen, in Europe), fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8(9) x 5-6(7) um or 7-9(10) um in diameter, irregular, echinulate to aculeate, yellowish to dark golden brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-60 x 6-9 um, clavate, contents often becoming ocher, with clamp connection at base, often with transverse septa, sterigmata up to 5 um long; CYSTIDIA up to 130 um long, projecting up to 80 um, capitulate, the apex expanded up to 12 um, cystidia colored as and arising from subicular hyphae, somewhat thick-walled, with clamp connection at the base "and with unclamped septa occurring along their length", often finely encrusted or bearing large granules at apex; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-4 um wide, tan to golden brown, thin-walled to rarely thick-walled, with clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of two types: 1) some 2.5-5(8) um wide, golden brown, thick-walled, septate, with clamp connections frequent, 2) some 2.5-3(4) um wide, golden brown, thick-walled, septate; CORDONS abundant, up to 200 um wide, pale yellow to dark brown, branched, individual hyphae 2-3(4) um wide, dark brown, with clamp connections, (Larsen), SPORES (5)6-8(9) um excluding spines, round, some rather lobate, spinose (spines up to 2 um long), brown; BASIDIA 4-spored, 30-60 x 7-10 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 50-100 x 12 um, "clavate, yellow-brown, somewhat thick-walled toward the base", with granular contents; HYPHAE monomitic 3-6 um wide, brownish, thin-walled to thick-walled, CORDONS up to 200 um wide, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'hairy'
SIMILAR  Other Tomentella species recorded from the Pacific Northwest lack cystidia, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
432
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella ramosissima  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Wakef.^  Mycologia 52: 927. 1960;  == Zygodesmus ramosissimus  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  = Tomentella fuliginea  (Burt) Bourdot & Galzin;  = Tomentella lapida  (Pers.) Stalpers [as 'lapidum'] (in part)  Stud. Mycol. 24: 65 (1984) (also proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a mould-like, fuligineous fruitbody that is smooth or more rarely granulose or colliculose, the sterile margin darker and fibrillose, and the subiculum darker than the spore-bearing area and fibrous, 3) spores that are round to nearly round, aculeate, and brown, 4) basidia often with transverse septa, the sterigmata often with septa, 5) subhymenial hyphae that are pale brown, wall thickening apparent or thin-walled, with clamp connections, scattered crystalline material adhering to hyphae becoming green in KOH, 6) subicular hyphae that are brown to dark golden brown, wall thickening apparent or thick-walled, with frequent clamp connections, rarely with encrusting material.^ |The online Species Fungorum, accessed August 27, 2020 and September 12, 2022, listed the current name as Tomentella lapida (Pers.) Stalpers [as 'lapidum'], Stud. Mycol. 24: 65 (1984), but MycoBank, accessed September 12, 2022, listed the current name as Tomentella ramosissima (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Wakef. RANGE ^T. ramosissima found in BC, WA, ID, AB, NF, ON, PQ, AZ, CO, MN, MI, MS, MT, NC, NH, NM, NY, and SC, (Ginns). Distribution also includes Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Portugal, Sweden, and Turkey, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.05cm thick, adherent to separable, normally mucedinoid [mould-like], spore-bearing area finally continuous; fuligineous; "smooth, more rarely granulose or colliculose"; subiculum fibrous, darker than the spore-bearing area; sterile margin fibrillose, colored as subiculum^, (Larsen), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
