HABITAT  Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tilia (basswood)^, (Ginns), also Cedrus (cedar), Carpinus (hornbeam), (Larsen), fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7-8.5(9) um in diameter, round to nearly round, aculeate, tan to medium brown or dull golden brown^; BASIDIA 35-50 x 8-10 um, 4-spored, clavate, with clamp connection at base, often with transverse septa, sterigmata up to 6 um long and often with septa; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 4-6 um wide, pale brown, "wall thickening apparent or thin-walled", with clamp connections, scattered crystalline material adhering to hyphae becoming green in KOH; SUBICULAR HYPHAE (3.5)4-7(10) um wide, "brown to dark golden brown", "wall thickening apparent or thick-walled", septate, with frequent clamp connections, rarely with encrusting material, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'very branched'
SIMILAR  Tomentella lilacinogrisea (as Tomentella neobourdotii) has subicular hyphae that are encrusted and mostly less thick-walled, and spores are not observed that are green or bluish green in KOH, (Larsen, M.J.).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1) (as Tomentella lapidum)
433
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella rubiginosa  (Bres.) Maire^  Ann. Mycol. 4: 335. 1906;  == Hypochnus rubiginosus  Bres.;  Tomentella punicea  (Alb. & Schwein.) J. Schroet.  in Cohn, Krypt.-Fl. Schlesien (Breslau) 3.1(25-32): 420 (1888) [1889] (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, dead leaves, or sedge, 2) a cobwebby to mould-like fruitbody that is normally ferruginous brown, with the surface granulose to colliculose, the margin cobwebby and from yellowish brown to golden brown, the subiculum thin, cobwebby, and paler than spore-bearing area, and cordons abundant, dark brown, 3) spores that are mostly irregular to lobed, echinulate to aculeate, mostly yellow, 4) basidia often with transverse septa, often with granular material adhering that becomes green in KOH, 5) subhymenial hyphae that are colorless to pale yellow, with clamp connections, and 6) subicular hyphae that are citrine to brown, with frequent clamp connections, some spinulose or rough-walled.^ |The online Species Fungorum, accessed August 27, 2020 and September 12, 2022 listed the current name as Tomentella punicea (Alb. & Schwein.) J. Schroet., in Cohn, Krypt.-Fl. Schlesien (Breslau) 3.1(2532): 420 (1888) [1889] but MycoBank, accessed September 12, 2022, listed the current name as Tomentella rubiginosa (Bres.) Maire. RANGE ^Tomentella rubiginosa has been found in OR [the Oregon collection is not listed in Larsen's 1974 monograph and may require confirmation], also AR, AZ, FL, IA, IL, IN, KY, LA, MD, MI, NH, NY, OH, PA, VA, and WV, (Ginns), MB, (Martin, K.J.(3)), and Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Macedonia, Sweden, and Pakistan, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.1cm thick, separable, arachnoid [cobwebby] to becoming mucedinoid [mould-like] in older specimens, spore-bearing areas "discontinuous when immature, continuous when mature"; normally ferruginous brown (in some European specimens becoming slightly olive to pale green); granulose to colliculose; sterile margin "arachnoid, yellowish brown to golden brown"; subiculum thin, arachnoid, paler than spore-bearing area; cordons abundant and conspicuous, dark brown^, (Larsen), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  Carya (= Hicoria) sp., Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Liriodendron, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tilia (basswood), Rhododendron, Carex (sedge), Cymophyllus fraseri (Fraser's sedge); dead leaves and wood^, (Ginns), also in Europe Carpinus (hornbeam), Crataegus (hawthorn), Sorbus, leaves of Juniperus (juniper) and of Quercus, (Larsen), late summer to fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6.5-8.5(9) um in diameter, mostly irregular to lobed, echinulate to aculeate, mostly yellow, sometimes citrine or pale brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 45-60 x 7-9 um, clavate, with clamp connection at base, often with transverse septa, "often with granular material adhering to the walls which becomes green or dark green in KOH", sterigmata up to 6 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-4 um wide, colorless to pale yellow, thin-walled, with clamp connections; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2-5.5 um wide, "citrine to mostly medium brown or dark brown", septate, with frequent clamp connections, "some hyphae appearing spinulose or rough-walled"; CORDONS abundant, up to 70 um wide, citrine to dark brown, individual hyphae 2-3.5 um wide, some wall thickening apparent, with clamp connections, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'rusty'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5), Martin, K.J.(3), Buczacki(1)* (as Tomentella punicea)
434
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella stuposa  (Link) Stalpers^  Stud. Mycol. 24: 86. 1984;  Tomentella ruttneri  Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifers, hardwoods, and polypores, 2) a hypochnoid to tomentose or submembranous fruitbody that is dark brown to purplish brown, the surface smooth to minutely punctate, the subiculum and the cottony margin colored as or darker than spore-bearing surface, 3) spores that are round to nearly round, strongly echinulate, and brownish, 4) 2-4-spored basidia with transverse septa, 5) hyphae that are brown, often wavy, the subicular walls (and often subhymenial hyphae) swelling in KOH, and 6) clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tomentella stuposa has been found at least in BC (J. Ginns, pers. comm.), also AB, NF, ON, AR, AZ, MD, MI, MN, NJ, NM, NY, OH, TN, and VT, (Ginns(5)). The distribution also includes Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Sweden, Turkey, and India, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  "hypochnoid to tomentose or submembranous"; dark brown to purplish brown; even; subiculum and margin colored as spore-bearing surface or darker^, (Stalpers), up to 0.1cm thick, hypochnoid to mucedinoid [mould-like], normally adherent, spore-bearing area usually continuous; dark brown; smooth to minutely punctate; sterile margin byssoid [cottony], colored as or darker than the spore-bearing area; subiculum colored as or darker than spore-bearing area, (Larsen), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  associated with conifers and hardwoods^, (Stalpers), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Magnolia, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Thuja, Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), Polyporus sp. (polypore), (Ginns), also in Czechoslovakia Carpinus (hornbeam), Cornus (dogwood), Quercus (oak), Rubus (berry cane), Salix (willow), Sorbus (mountain-ash), Trametes, (polypore), (Larsen), late summer, fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (7)8-9.5(11.5) um in diameter, round to nearly round, strongly echinulate, brownish^; BASIDIA 35-60 x 8-11(13) um; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 4-6(8) um wide; SUBICULAR HYPHAE (2.5)3-6(8) um wide, brown, often wavy, becoming thick-walled, subicular hyphal walls swelling in 10% KOH, (Stalpers), SPORES (7)8-9.5(11.5) um in diameter, round to nearly round, aculeate or more rarely echinulate, pale brown to deep hazel; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 45-55(60) x 8-11(12) um, clavate, clamp connection at base, transverse septa present, sterigmata up to 9 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 4-6(8) um wide, with clamp connections, "thin-walled, localized wall thickening apparent in some instances", cell walls often reacting to KOH by swelling (upon continuous exposure to 2% KOH and immediately so upon exposure to 10% KOH), dull brown to yellowish brown; SUBICULAR HYPHAE (2.5)3-5.5(6.5) um wide, hyphal cells up to 70 um long and irregular in outline or wavy (not straight or uniform), septate, with frequent clamp connections, "becoming thick-walled, with the lumen sometimes not evident (wall thickening frequently localized and cell wall strata often discernible)", cell walls swelling in KOH as for subhymenial hyphae, dark brown to yellowish brown, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'full of coarse fibers'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Stalpers(2), Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5) (as Tomentella ruttneri), Buczacki(1)*
435
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella sublilacina  (Ellis & Holw.) Wakef.^  Mycologia 52: 931. 1960;  == Zygodesmus sublilacinus  Ellis & Holw. in J.C. Arthur et al.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood and occasionally on polypores or other substrates, 2) a mould-like, sometimes floccose fruitbody colored wood brown to vinaceous brown, the surface smooth, the margin paler and villose, and the subiculum firm and colored as spore-bearing area or darker, 3) spores that are irregular to strongly lobed, frequently appearing slightly elongated along one axis, echinulate, and brown, 4) basidia often with transverse septa, the sterigmata often with septa, 5) subhymenial hyphae that are colorless to pale brown, with clamp connections, the hyphae often appearing torose, 6) subicular hyphae that are brown, with clamp connections frequent, becoming thick-walled, often swollen and ampullate at the septa and appearing torose.^ RANGE ^Tomentella sublilacina has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, NF, NS, ON, PQ, AZ, KY, MA, MD, MI, MN, NC, NM, NY, TN, and WV, (Ginns). Distribution also includes Jamaica, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Netherlands, Sweden, United Kingdom, and New Zealand, (Larsen, M.J.(9)).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.05cm thick, mucedinoid [mould-like], sometimes floccose, spore-bearing area "continuous, discontinuous when immature or towards the margin"; wood brown to vinaceous brown; smooth; sterile margin paler, villose; subiculum firm, colored as spore-bearing area or darker^, (Larsen, M.J.(9)), spore deposit pale brown (Buczacki)
HABITAT  Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Juglans (walnut), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Prunus, Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), Fomes (polypore), Ganoderma (polypore), Polyporus (polypore), Hypoxylon, Lycopodium, moss^, (Ginns), also in Europe Carpinus (hornbeam), Cornus (dogwood), Juniperus (juniper), Juncus (rush), lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen, M.J.(9)), on "rotting wood, leaves, litter and on soil" in wet habitats "in woodland, marshes, pond margins and similar sites especially when the soil is drying out"; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 7.5-10(11) um in diameter, irregular to strongly lobed, frequently appearing elongated along one axis, "echinulate, medium to dark brown"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-65 x 7-12 um, with clamp connection at base, transverse septa often present, sterigmata up to 8 um long and often with septa; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 4-7(11) um wide, colorless to pale brown, "some wall thickening noticeable to becoming thick-walled", with clamp connections, hyphae often appearing torose; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 4-6.5(8) um wide, "dark brown to dull pale-brown", septate, with clamp connections frequent, becoming thick-walled, often swollen and ampullate at the septa and appearing torose, (Larsen, M.J.(9))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tomentella kootenaiensis has round to irregularly round spores, while the spores of T. sublilacina "are irregular in outline to strongly lobed and are usually elongated along one axis", (Larsen, M.J.(10)).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Larsen, M.J.(10), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
436
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella subvinosa  (Burt) Bourdot & Galzin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 40: 146. 1924;  == Hypochnus subvinosus  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a loosely constructed fruitbody (that becomes mould-like), adherent, and colored vinaceous brown, the surface smooth to granulose, the subiculum colorless to faintly brown, cobwebby, the sterile margin colored as the subiculum or paler, 3) spores that are irregular to predominantly 3-lobed or 4-lobed, echinulate, and pale brown, 4) basidia sometimes with transverse septa, basidial contents appearing with red granular contents in water mounts, 5) subhymenial hyphae that are colorless to pale brown, with clamp connections, a bright red granular material apparent in water mounts, and 6) subicular hyphae of 2 types.^ RANGE ^Tomentella subvinosa has been found in WA [the Washington collection is not listed in Larsen's 1974 monograph and may require confirmation], also ON, PQ, AZ, MN, NH, NJ, and NY, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  up to 0.1cm thick, "loosely constructed", becoming mucedinoid [mould-like], adherent, spore-bearing areas "discontinuous to somewhat continuous"; uniformly vinaceous brown; smooth to granulose; subiculum colorless to faintly brown, arachnoid [cobwebby]; sterile margin colored as subiculum to paler^, (Larsen)
HABITAT  Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Populus, Sassafras, Tilia (basswood)^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5.5)6-8(9.5) um in diameter, irregular to predominantly 3-lobed or 4-lobed, echinulate, pale brown^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 40-50(80) x 5-7 um, "slender-clavate when mature, with the apex slightly expanded", with clamp connection at the base, sometimes with transverse septa, basidial contents appearing with red granular contents in water mounts "and becoming brown to ochre in KOH", sterigmata up to 4 um long; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 2.5-4 um wide, colorless to pale brown, thin-walled, with clamp connections, a bright red granular material apparent in water mounts, "this material becoming yellowish brown to ochre in KOH"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE of 2 types, 1) some 3.5-6(7) um wide, colorless or pale to medium brown, wall thickening apparent, with clamp connections, becoming somewhat torose, 2) some 2-2.5 um wide, colorless to pale brown, thin-walled, with the clamp connections widely spaced; CORDONS rare, up to 15 um wide, pale yellowish brown, individual hyphae 2-3 um wide, pale brown, with clamp connections; VESICLES "rare, arising from, and found in, the subiculum or subhymenium", 12-20 um in diameter, spherical, colorless, thin-walled to thick-walled, with clamp connection at the base, (Larsen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Ginns(5)
437
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentella terrestris  (Berk. & Broome) M.J. Larsen^  Mycologia Memoir 4: 105. 1974;  == Zygodesmus terrestris  Berk. & Broome;  Tomentella badiofusca  Bourdot & Galzin;  Tomentella umbrinella  Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, soil, or sometimes rock, 2) a mould-like, dark brown to reddish brown fruitbody, often with a slight vinaceous tint, the surface smooth to irregularly tuberculate, the subiculum thin, paler, the sterile margin narrow, fibrillose to villose, colored as subiculum, 3) spores that are irregularly round to somewhat round, often flattened on one side, aculeolate to echinulate, and brown, 4) basidia that are distended, 60-90 x 9-14 um, up to 20 um wide 10-15 um above the basal septa, often with transverse septa, 5) subhymenial hyphae that are dull brown near the subiculum, paler toward hymenium, with frequent clamp connections, this layer containing what appear to be aborted basidia, 6) subicular hyphae that are pale yellowish brown, with frequent clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tomentella terrestris has been found in BC, ID, NS, ON, AZ, FL, MI, MT, NC, NM, and NY, (Ginns). It also occurs in Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Larsen).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, up to 0.05cm thick, annual, mucedinoid [mould-like], spore-bearing area continuous; dark brown to bister, often with a slight vinaceous tint; smooth, "often stretching and tearing on drying and exposing the subiculum"; subiculum compact, thin, somewhat paler than the spore-bearing area; sterile margin "even, appressed, narrow, fibrillose to villose", colored as the subiculum^, (Larsen), resupinate, "forming membranous, densely tomentose, relatively thick patches" several centimeters across, attached loosely to substrate, consistency fibrous-tomentose; reddish brown to dark brown; irregularly tuberculate; margin lighter in color and thin, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on the underside of very rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, "also growing over the soil"; summer to fall^, (Breitenbach), Abies sp. (fir), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Acer sp. (maple), Betula sp. (birch), Castanea sp. (chestnut), Picea sp. (spruce), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), Pinus sp. (pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus sp., Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), Quercus sp. (oak), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga (hemlock), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), (Ginns), also in Europe on Sorbus (mountain-ash), Diatrype (a pyrenomycete), lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-7(8.5) um, irregularly round to somewhat round, often flattened on one side, "aculeolate to echinulate, pale tan to yellowish brown"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-90 x 9-14 um, up to 20 um wide 10-15 um above the basal septa, often with transverse septa, with clamp connection at base; SUBHYMENIAL HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, dull brown near subiculum and paler toward hymenium, "thin-walled or with some wall thickening (walls becoming thinner towards the hymenium)", septate, with frequent clamp connections, this layer containing what appear to be aborted basidia, giving vertical sections a layered appearance; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2.5-4(5) um wide, pale yellowish brown, wall thickening apparent, septate, with frequent clamp connections; CORDONS infrequent, up to 40 um wide, dark brown, individual hyphae 2-4.5 um wide, with clamp connections, (Larsen), SPORES 6-8 um in diameter (excluding spines), irregularly subglobose, spiny, brown; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-90 x 10-20 um, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none, but "in hymenium with many ventricose-clavate elements"; HYPHAE monomitic, 4-5.5 um wide, brownish, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, CORDONS up to 50 um wide, dark brown, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of the earth, terrestrial' 
SIMILAR  Tomentella nitellina also has distended basidia, but spores are larger, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen, M.J.(9), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5)
438
FAMILY  Thelephoraceae, Order Thelephorales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tomentellopsis echinospora  (Ellis) Hjortstam^  Svensk Bot. Tidskr. 64: 426. 1970;  == Corticium echinosporum  Ellis;  Tomentella echinospora  (Ellis) Bourdot & Galzin;  Hypochnus pennsylvanica  Overh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on the underside of rotten wood, mosses, leaves, or rocks, 2) irregular cobwebby fruitbodies that are yellow-whitish to pale sulphur-yellow, the surface densely cobwebby-mealy to finely tomentose, the margin thinly cobwebby, 3) spores that are light yellow, and round to nearly round, with fine pointed spines, 4) (2)4-spored basidia that are somewhat urniform, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the septa without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tomentellopsis echinospora has been found in WA, ID, MB, NJ, and PA, (Ginns(5)), Collections from BC were deposited by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia. It has also been found in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, forming thin, irregular, arachnoid [cobwebby], filamentous patches several centimeters across, easily detached; yellow-whitish to pale sulphur-yellow; surface densely arachnoid-farinose to finely tomentose; marginal zone thinly arachnoid^, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on the underside of very rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, according to the literature also on the underside of mosses, leaves, and rocks; winter half of the year^, (Breitenbach); Carya sp. (hickory), Pinus sp. (pine), Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), Populus spp.; on bark, (Ginns(5)), fall; also recorded on old horse dung, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6 um in diameter, round to nearly round, "with fine pointed spines, light yellow"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (according to the literature also 2-spored), 20-35 x 7-9 um, suburniform; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic 3-5 um wide, colorless, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with spiny spores'
SIMILAR  4 other species are found in other parts of western North America: Tomentellopsis pallidoaurantiaca (AB, NT, AZ, NM, NY) is distinguished from the other four species by echinulate spores, clamp connections, and a dimitic hyphal system, (Ginns(23)).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Ginns(23), Buczacki(1)*
439
FAMILY  Hydnodontaceae, Order Trechisporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trechispora farinacea  (Pers.) Liberta^  Taxon 15: 318. 1966;  == Hydnum farinaceum  Pers.;  Grandinia farinacea  (Pers.) Bourdot & Galzin;  Trechispora sphaerospora  (Maire) Parmasto
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on well decayed wood, or occasionally other plant debris, humus, moss, or polypores, 2) a whitish to ochraceous fruitbody that is smooth to grandinioid or odontioid, the surface farinose (mealy) under a lens, the margin thinning out, sometimes fibrillose or rhizomorphic, 3) spores that are nearly round to broadly elliptic, with dense warts (spines) evenly spread around the spore, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae often inflated at the septa, the septa with clamp connections, and 5) arthoconidia irregularly shaped with the ends truncate, sometimes present in cushion-shaped areas of the fruitbody.^ | Trechispora farinacea "is here taken in the broad sense outlined by Liberta (1973). It then includes several taxa which definite delimitation needs further study.", (Hjortstam). RANGE ^Trechispora farinacea has been found in WA, ID, AB, MB, NS, NT, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, FL, IA, IL, IN, MD, MI, MN, MS, MT, NC, NM, NY, OH, UT, VT, and WI, (Ginns). Collections from BC were deposited by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia. It has also been found in the West Indies, Hawaii, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Argentina, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, United Kingdom, Azerbaijan, and Australia, (Liberta). It is widespread in Scandinavia (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], "fragile, thin to moderately thick"; whitish to ochraceous; "smooth to grandinioid to odontioid, when smooth porose or cracked"; "margin thinning out, sometimes fibrillose", cordons [rhizomorphs] "not so often seen"; sometimes with white, cushion-like, byssoid [cottony], conidia-forming mycelium "either growing in contact with the fertile mycelium or separate"^, (Hjortstam), effused, thin (in section up to 0.02cm thick); white or 'pale mouse grey' to cream or 'buff'; "texture variable, ranging from pruinose, arachnoid, floccose-pelliculose, laxe membranous, grandinioid to hydnoid, under a lens the surface appearing farinose, when hydnoid the teeth soft, farinose, cylindrical to slightly subulate, often several fused at their bases to form groups of four or five", teeth up to 0.16cm long and 0.016cm wide; compact pulvinate [cushion-shaped] sectors sometimes scattered about the surface, "under a lens appearing farinose-floccose", producing arthrospores; margin colored as the rest of the spore-bearing surface, "pruinose-reticulate, byssoid, radiating-fibrillose to rhizomorphic", rhizomorphs up to 0.05cm wide, (Liberta), resupinate, fused with substrate, "consisting of individual small patches or coherent expanses", consistency open, soft; white to cream; "surface arachnoid-farinose when young, then verrucose to finely hydnoid", teeth crowded and up to 0.2cm long; "margin finely filamentous and sometimes with fine rhizomorphs", (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on well decayed wood of both hardwoods and conifers^, (Hjortstam), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Celtis (hackberry), Fraxinus (ash), Juniperus (juniper), Liquidambar, Malus, Phoenix canariensis (Dwarf Date Palm), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Rhododendron, Tsuga (hemlock), Ulmus (elm); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on a variety of substrates, including decayed stems, wood and bark of hardwoods and conifers, Typha latifolia (cat-tail), Viburnum, humus, leaves, moss, and fruitbodies of Ganoderma, (Liberta), on rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, "on the undersides of fallen branches, as well as in cavities in rotten stumps"; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on rotting wood, old polypore fruitbodies, and occasionally herbaceous debris; summer to fall, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-4.5(5) x 3.3-3.7 um, nearly round to broadly elliptic, "densely verrucose with the warts evenly spread around the spore", slightly thick-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (9)11-14(18) x 4.5-5 um, cylindric, "often slightly waisted or sinuous", with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, "subicular hyphae mostly few but frequently seen at the margin, thin-walled, straight", mainly 2-3 um wide, with ampullate septa, "subhymenial hyphae broader, short-celled, richly branched", often inflated to triangular and 2.5-5(6) um wide; CONIDIA as arthroconidia, cylindric or irregular with remnants of clamp connections easily seen, about 5 x 2.5 um, "formed through fragmenting of straight, short-celled hyphae", (Hjortstam), SPORES 3-4(4.5) x 2.5-3(3.5) um, oval to oval-elliptic, sometimes slightly depressed on one side, echinulate, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, (7.5)8.5-17 x 3.5-5(6) um, clavate, cylindric or slightly constricted in the middle, "also producing occasionally pleurobasidia", sterigmata (2)3-5(5.5) um long; HYPHAE monomitic, CONTEXT HYPHAE (1.5)2-4 um wide, colorless, thin-walled to rarely slightly thick-walled (0.5 um), "frequently ampulliform at the clamp connection" or with short, swollen cells up to 8 um in diameter, "variously shaped crystalline material scattered among the hyphae and adhering to the walls"; TRAMAL HYPHAE and RHIZOMORPH hyphae similar; ARTHROCONIDIA sometimes present, 4-8 x 2.5-4.5 um, "formed by the segmentation of the hyphae in the pulvinate sectors, irregularly shaped, the ends truncate", wall colorless, smooth, thin to slightly thickened (0.5 um), (Liberta), SPORES 3.5-4 x 2.5-3 um, oval-elliptic, spinose, inamyloid, colorless, with 1-2 droplets; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 12-15 x 3-6 um, cylindric-clavate, sometimes rather constricted; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-3.5 um wide, "often swollen toward the septa", septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'farinaceous'
SIMILAR  Trechispora microspora has acicular crystals (Hjortstam). T. microspora has irregularly warted spores while T. farinacea has regularly echinulate spores and occasional irregularly shaped arthrospores, (Liberta).
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Liberta(1) (colors in single quotation marks from Rayner(2)), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
440
FAMILY  Hydnodontaceae, Order Trechisporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trechispora microspora  (P. Karst.) Liberta^  Taxon 15: 319. 1966;  == Grandinia microspora  P. Karst.;  Athelia microspora  (P. Karst.) Gilb.;  Corticium subnullum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood and hardwood, less often on other substrates, 2) a white to light brown fruitbody that is thin, easily detached, cobwebby, smooth or minutely granular, the margin fibrillose to rhizomorphic, 3) spores that are nearly round to irregular, with warts, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, frequently inflated near septa, often with needle-like crystals present.^ |The name Grandinia microspora P. Karst. has been applied to at least two fungi. In Liberta(1), Liberta, having seen a lectotype specimen, described the spores as having "irregularly scattered obtuse warts". However, the drawing in Hjortstam(6) seems to have much smaller ornamentation on the spore wall than the warts described by Liberta and may be a second fungus, (Ginns), (note also that rhizomorphs are mentioned in the Hjortstam(6) description but not the Liberta(1) description). RANGE ^Trechispora microspora has been found in BC, ON, PQ, CO, OH, PA, RI, (Ginns). Distribution includes Idaho, Manitoba, California, New York, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Estonia, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Liberta), Denmark, and Sweden, (Hjortstam), and Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], thin and fragile, easily detachable, arachnoid [cobwebby], "smooth or minutely granular, always strongly porose"; "margin thinning out, often fibrillose", cordons [rhizomorphs] "regularly present in the subiculum and extending beyond the margin"^, (Hjortstam), "effused, thin, arachnoid, appearing farinose-reticulate to laxe membranous under a lens", in section up to 0.015cm thick; "white or cream to honey"; margin narrow to broad, colored as the rest of the spore-bearing area, "pruinose-reticulate, fibrillose, to fan-shaped", (Liberta), resupinate, attached +/- loosely to the substrate, "forming non-coherent, open, and irregular patches" several centimeters across, consistency soft; whitish to ocherish; surface farinose-granular, in part arachnoid-porous; margin irregular, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on both hardwood and coniferous wood, and also collected on fern remains^, (Hjortstam), on hardwood, conifer wood, moss, and leaf debris, (Liberta), on very rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), on woody plant debris, also occasionally on rotting fronds of male fern; summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-4.5(5) x (3)3.3-3.5 um including ornamentation, nearly round to lacrymoid [teardrop-shaped], with a prominent apicular region, verrucose except in apicular region^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 9-11 x 4-5 um, cylindric, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic; subhymenial hyphae "short-celled, richly branched, of even width or slightly inflated", 2-4(5) um wide; subicular hyphae and hyphae of cordons 1.5-2.5(3.5) um wide, straight, thin-walled, "frequently with ampullate septa, provided with acerose crystals", (Hjortstam), SPORES 3-3.5 x 2-2.5 um, "appearing irregularly ovoid or oblong as a result of the irregularly scattered obtuse warts", inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, "at first ovate or oblong, becoming clavate or subcylindrical and slightly constricted in the middle to short clavate", (7)8-12 x 4-5 um, sterigmata 3.5-5.5 um long, arcuate; HYPHAE monomitic, CONTEXT HYPHAE (1.5)2-3(3.5) um, colorless, thin-walled, "with frequent ampulliform swellings at the clamp connection" or short-celled segments up to 7 um in diameter, "occasionally encrusted with irregularly shaped or lanceolate crystalline material", (Liberta), SPORES 3-3.5 x 2.5-3 um, nearly round, with irregularly distributed blunt warts, inamyloid, colorless, with 1 droplet; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 9-15 x 3.5-5 um, cylindric to clavate; HYPHAE monomitic, 1.5-2.5 um wide, colorless, septa with clamp connections, sometimes rather thickened at the septa, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with small spores'
SIMILAR  The acicular crystals distinguish this species from Trechispora farinacea (Hjortstam). T. farinacea has regularly echinulate spores and occasional irregularly shaped arthrospores, while T. microspora has irregularly warted spores, (Liberta).
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Liberta(1), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
441
FAMILY  Hydnodontaceae, Order Trechisporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trechispora mollusca  (Pers.) Liberta^  Can. J. Bot. 51: 1878. 1973;  == Boletus molluscus  Pers.;  Cristella mucida  (Pers.) Donk;  Polyporus candidissimus  Schwein.;  Trechispora candidissima  (Schwein.) Bondartsev & Singer;  Phlebiella candidissima  (Schwein.) W.B. Cooke;  Poria candidissima  (Schwein.) Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Polypores category. Trechispora mollusca differs from other resupinate white pore surfaces in its cottony-delicate consistency and spiny spores. It differs from crust fungi in general in its distinct pore-like surface. Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a soft, fragile, white fruitbody, the pores sometimes splitting to become almost hydnoid, the margin cobwebby to fringed or rhizomorphic, 3) spores that are oval to nearly round, finely spiny, inamyloid, and colorless, and 4) hyphae that are monomitic, the septa with or without clamp connections, often inflated at the clamp connections or septa.^ RANGE ^Trechispora mollusca has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PE, AK, AZ, CA, CO, LA, MA, MO, MT, NC, NM, NY, PA, SC, TN, and VA, (Gilbertson), also NT, PQ, and MN, (Ginns), and MI, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Poland, Russia, Sweden, Australia, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom, (Liberta). It is common in the whole of Scandinavia (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  up to 6cm across, resupinate, very soft and fragile, readily separable; margin white, often very thin, arachnoid, rhizomorphic; flesh less than 0.05cm thick, soft, not zoned; white; pores 2-4 per mm, angular, with thin pubescent [downy] walls that become torn when old; white to cream; tube layer up to 0.2cm thick, colored as flesh and continuous with it; taste mild^, (Gilbertson), resupinate, easily separable; margin white, arachnoid to fimbriate or rhizomorphic; flesh thin, soft; white, pores mostly 1mm long, rarely as long as 2mm, rounded, angular, or sinuate, (2)3-4(5) per mm, fragile, the edges fimbriate [fringed] or splitting to become almost hydnoid [tooth-like], (Liberta), up to 0.2cm thick, resupinate, soft, fragile, easily separable from wood; "cordons often seen at the margin which is thinning out, often broad, arachnoid and often finely fibrillose"; pores 2-5 per mm and of unequal width when dried; rounded, angular or sinuous; white, changing to ochraceous when dried, (Hjortstam), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  annual, on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, associated with a white rot of conifer and hardwood logs and slash^, (Gilbertson), usually growing in well sheltered places on strongly decayed trunks and branches, (Hjortstam(6)), on the underside of rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, also on leaves and other plant remains, (Breitenbach), also on Fomes fomentarius (Liberta), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 2.5-3.5 um, oval to nearly round, echinulate [with slender sharp spines], inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, up to 14 um long, 4.5-5.5 um wide, short-cylindric, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE monomitic, hyphae of subiculum 2.5-5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, "often ampullate and incrusted, frequently branched, with clamp connections", (Gilbertson), SPORES 4-5.5 x 3.5-4.5 um including warts, broadly elliptic to elliptic, verrucose; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-15 x 5-6 um, short-cylindric often with slight median constriction, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, "in the subhymenium and in the dissepiments straight, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled 2-5 um wide, encrusted, forming byssoid mats and cordons in the subiculum, septa in the cordons often ampulliform, hyphae in the byssoid mats often with large, globose vesicles 20-25(40) um, subhymenium lacking or composed of a few layers of richly branched, very short-celled, nearly isodiametric or irregular hyphae but often basidia are born directly on the dissepiment hyphae", (Hjortstam), SPORES 2.5-4 x 2.5-3 um (not including spines), oval to nearly round, echinulate, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 8.5-16.5(18) x 4-6 um, subcylindric to clavate; CYSTIDIA absent; HYPHAE monomitic 2-4 um, colorless, thin-walled, frequently encrusted with irregularly shaped crystalline material, septate with or without clamp connections, frequently with ampulliform swellings at the clamp connection or septum up to 8 um wide; hyphae of trama similar, (Liberta), SPORES 4-5 x 3-4 um, broadly elliptic, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means "soft"^ (Gilbertson)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Liberta(1), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Gilbertson(1), Buczacki(1)*
442
FAMILY  Hydnodontaceae, Order Trechisporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicium vermiferum  (Bourdot) Julich^  as Oberw. ex Julich, Persoonia 10: 335. 1979;  == Peniophora vermifera  Bourdot;  Epithele vermifera  (Bourdot) Boquiren;  Xenasma vermiferum  (Bourdot) Liberta
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Tubulicium vermiferum is identified easily under the microscope by its conic cystidia sheathed in narrow dendritic hyphae, and spores that are curved or flexuous [wavy] and pointed more at one end than the other. Features include 1) resupinate growth on a variety of genera, 2) a white to cream-yellow fruitbody, smooth but often cracked, the surface bristly under a lens, the margin abrupt or indistinct, 3) spores that are sigmoid or flexuous-navicular, pointed at both ends but more obtuse at the apiculate end, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia that are conic, many-rooted, thick-walled with a capillary lumen, strongly encrusted and also covered with narrow, dendritic hyphae, the cystidial walls slightly amyloid, partly dissolving in KOH, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae somewhat agglutinated, with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tubulicium vermiferum has been found in BC, CA, and FL, (Ginns). It also occurs in Norway and Sweden, (Hjortstam), and HI, Denmark, France, and New Zealand, (Liberta).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, spot-shaped or more normally widely effused [spread out]; white to cream-yellow; smooth but often cracked, conspicuously hispid [bristly] due to projecting cystidia; margin indeterminate or abrupt^, (Hjortstam), resupinate, maculiform [spot-shaped] to widely effused, thin, though sometimes attaining a depth of up to 0.01cm or 0.02cm, dense, more or less separable from substrate; creamy yellow; "usually though not always cracking on drying"; margin more or less clearly defined, (Weresub), effused or maculiform, in section up to 0.02cm thick, arid crustaceous, adherent; white or cream to "buff yellow"; smooth or cracked, under a lens appearing densely hispid [bristly], (Liberta), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dicotyledonous wood (Weresub), Antidesma, Calluna, Cibotium, Citharexylum, Cocos, Dysoxylum, Erica, Eugenia, Gaultheria, Livistonia, Metrosideros, Olearia, Osmaronia, Pseudopanax, Salix cinerea, Senecio, Vaccinium, Vitex, (Ginns), usually on bark of living trees and bushes of Salix and Corylus (Hjortstam), late summer to winter (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES "sigmoid, flexuose-navicular or vermicular, smooth, thin-walled", generally 20-25 x 3.5-4 um^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-35(40) x 10-12 um, terminal, thin-walled, subclavate to more or less stemmed, sterigmata fairly stout; CYSTIDIA narrowly conic to cylindric, usually 80-100 um long and 8-12 um wide near base, "thick-walled and slightly amyloid, with a narrow capillary lumen, strongly encrusted and besides also covered with narrow, dendroid hyphae", only 0.5-1 um wide; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-2.5 um wide, "thin-walled or with slight wall thickening, somewhat agglutinated", septa with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES (10)15-25(30) x (3)4-5.5 um, flexuous-navicular, usually somewhat pointed toward the distal end, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 20-45 x (5)8.5-11.5 um, sinuately clavate, usually 4-spored, the sterigmata 6.5-7.5 um long, 2.5 um wide at base, fleshy, divergently arcuate; CYSTIDIA 75-185 um long, 10-25 um wide just above base, conic, narrowing to more or less pointed apex, "typically sheathed in dendroid branching hyphae" 0.75-1.5 um wide, sometimes also encrusted, cystidial walls "lightly but positively amyloid", thick, 3.5-7 um wide, "dissolving in KOH, though apices and outer layer of wall often left standing after KOH action", "lumina usually fairly broad at base, frequently becoming capillary well below the middle, often completely obscured apically, though sometimes not narrowing to capillarity even at the tip"; HYPHAE in subiculum indistinct, perhaps agglutinated, apparently with frequent clamp connections, some with thickened walls dissolving in KOH, others thin-walled, 2-2.25 um wide, (Weresub(3)), SPORES (10)15-25(30) x (3)4-5.5 um, flexuous-navicular, pointed at both ends, but broader at the apiculate end, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-45 x (5)8.5-11.5 um, sinuately cylindric to subclavate, "borne directly on the horizontal hyphae, the base bifurcate, often obscure, or occasionally terminal on short upright hyphae" and subtended by a clamp connection, sterigmata 6.5-7.5(10.5) x 2.5 um, divergent, arcuate; CYSTIDIA 75-185 x 10-25 um, conic, "perpendicular to the horizontal hyphae, the base several-rooted, the walls thick, lamellate, externally covered with a roughened crystalline shell" or more often sheathed by dendritic hyphae about 1 um wide; HYPHAE mostly parallel to the substrate, septa with clamp connections, 1.5-2.5 um wide, conglutinate or the walls becoming gelatinized, (Liberta)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing worms', presumably referring to the spores or cystidia
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Weresub(3) (as Peniophora vermifera), Hjortstam(6), Liberta(2) (as Xenasma vermiferum, colors in quotation marks from Ridgway), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
443
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis accedens  (Bourdot & Galzin) Donk^  Fungus 26: 14.  1956;  == Peniophora glebulosa subsp. accedens  Bourdot & Galzin;  Peniophora accedens  (Bourdot & Galzin) Wakef. & A. Pearson
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, usually of conifers, 2) the fruitbody as inconspicuous, filmy, gray-whitish patches, its surface smooth and delicately farinose, with cystidia visible under a 20x lens, the margin thinning out, 3) spores that are narrowly elliptic to nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia that dissolve in KOH and are thick-walled with a thin-walled head, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tubulicrinis accedens has been found in BC, OR, ON, PQ, CO, IA, IL, IN, MA, and RI, (Ginns). It also occurs in Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hjortstam), Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach), and France (Weresub).
FRUITING BODY  when living "inconspicuous to very thin, when dried more whitish"; cystidia protruding and easily observed under 50x lens, glittering due to the amorphous secretion at the apex^, (Hjortstam), resupinate, attached tightly, forming filmy, +/- continuous patches several centimeters across; gray-whitish; smooth, delicately farinose [mealy], under 20x lens pubescent from projecting cystidia; thinning out at the margin, (Breitenbach), delicate, closely adnate [firmly attached], often discontinuous; white to gray to creamy; porous-reticulate, pruinose, somewhat tomentose under lens; margin indeterminate, (Weresub), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed wood^; Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), (Ginns), especially on Pinus (pine), but often on Picea (spruce), Juniperus (juniper), and fencing, very occasionally on hardwood, (Hjortstam), on rotten conifer wood, especially Picea; fall, (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5 x 3-3.5(4) um, narrowly elliptic, elliptic to more rarely nearly round, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, about 10-15 x 4 um, somewhat variable in shape from almost conic to stemmed or even lateral but "as a rule subclavate with a median constriction", inamyloid, thin-walled, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA often numerous, 50-90 um long and about 4-6 um wide in middle part, narrowing slightly from the base toward the 2.5-4 um wide neck, "apically widened to a distinct thin-walled head", usually 8-9 um wide, "capillary lumen gradually expanded to the thin-walled apex", cystidia weakly amyloid, almost grayish, encrusted with amorphous matter that quickly dissolves in KOH but is discernible in water; HYPHAE monomitic, basal hyphae as a rule distinct, 1.5-2.5 um wide, branching at right angles, thin-walled, "forming together with the subhymenial hyphae a very thin, inamyloid tissue", all hyphae with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 4-5(5.5) x 3-3.5 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 12-14 x 4-5 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection; LYOCYSTIDIA 40-60 um long, capitate, usually rooting [bifurcate at base], head 6-8 um wide, neck 2.5-3 um wide, thick-walled, inamyloid, dissolving in KOH; HYPHAE monomitic, 1.5-2.5 um wide, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), spores (3)3.5-5.5 x 2-3(3.75) um, subcylindric to almost pyriform [pear-shaped], smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, (7)8.5-12(17.5) x 3.5-4.5(5) um, clavate to subcylindric, stemmed or not, "usually rising perpendicular to basidiophores even when in clumps", sterigmata more or less divergent, up to 4(5) um long; CYSTIDIA (30)45-65(90) um long, 2.5-4(5) um wide near base of stem, thick-walled, slender cylindric, narrowing slightly to a neck width of 2-4 um, capillary lumen expanding toward tip with thinning of walls to form apical bulb 5-8.5(10) x (4)5-7.5(10.5) um, cystidia smooth, inamyloid, swelling and dissolving in KOH; SUBICULUM of hyphae 1.5-2 um wide, usually collapsed or otherwise indistinct, with clamp connections, (Weresub)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'approaching'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Breitenbach(2)*, Weresub(3) (as Peniophora accedens), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
444
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis angustus  (D.P. Rogers & Weresub) Donk^  Fungus 26: 14. 1956;  == Peniophora angusta  D.P. Rogers & Weresub
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood or on hardwood, 2) a grayish white to yellowish fruitbody, poroid-floccose and reticulate under a hand lens with visible cystidia, the margin indistinct and the subiculum usually sparse, 3) spores that are slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia that are cylindric and thick-walled, often dissolving in KOH, slightly to distinctly amyloid, usually slightly flexuous [wavy], narrowing slightly towards the obtuse apex with the narrow lumen gradually expanded so that the apex is thin-walled, the base bifurcate, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tubulicrinis angustus has been found in BC, OR, ON, PQ, MA, RI, and WI, (Ginns). It also occurs in Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hjortstam), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], thin to moderately thick; grayish white; porulose [finely pored] to more or less continuous, minutely pilose from protruding cystidia; margin indeterminable [not distinct]^, (Hjortstam), resupinate, closely appressed to substrate, forming "thin, open, poroid-floccose", +/- continuous patches several centimeters across, consistency soft, wax-like; cream to yellowish; "surface under a hand lens farinose, poroid-reticulate"; margin diffuse, (Breitenbach), delicate, closely adnate, under a lens more or less porose-reticulate, pilose from projecting cystidia, rarely a creamy and denser reticulum; when fresh waxy pruinose or farinose; pure white, when dry grayish or whitish-pruinose; "subiculum usually sparse, rarely substantial, loose", (Weresub), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on decayed conifer wood, mostly on Pinus (pine), sometimes on fencing and occasionally on hardwood^, (Hjortstam), on rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns), summer to fall (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (8)9-10(11) x 1.8-2 um, suballantoid, smooth, thin-walled, "in some specimens slightly flexuose"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-15(18) x 4-4.5 um, subclavate, narrowing toward the base but not distinctly stemmed, (often with a suburniform appearance), in fairly loose clusters, thin-walled, inamyloid, with a basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA cylindric, "usually with a slightly flexuose appearance", generally up to 100 um long and with a width of 5 um in the middle part, "narrowing slightly towards the obtuse apex with the capillary lumen gradually expanded" so that apex is thin-walled, in Melzer's reagent varying from grayish to a distinct bluish reaction; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-2.5 um wide, "thin-walled or with slightly wall thickening", "composed of a fairly dense, inamyloid tissue", all hyphae with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 7-9 x 1.5-2 um, cylindric, slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 8-15 x 4-6 um, clavate, with clamp connection; LYOCYSTIDIA 60-130 x 4-6 um, narrowly cylindric, thick-walled, "lumen gradually enlarging toward the tip, soluble in KOH", amyloid, base rooting; HYPHAE monomitic, 1.5-3.5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES (6)7-10(11.5) x 1.5-2(2.5) um, narrow cylindric, "sometimes slightly broadened and somewhat curved just above the base"; BASIDIA 4-spored, (7.5)8.5-14(18.5) x (2.75)3.5-4.5 um, subclavate, sterigmata about 4.5 um long, slender, erect; CYSTIDIA (20)50-100(135) um long, subcylindric, 3.5-5.5(6) um wide near base, narrowing to (2.5)3-4.5(5.5) um at apex, smooth, inamyloid to slightly amyloid, walls thick but thinning with a gradual expansion of the capillary lumen to end in an obtuse, thin-walled apex, (1/10)1/8-1/3(1/2) the length of the cystidium, "the thickened walls sensitive to KOH, in some specimens showing a delayed solubility especially in the upper half of the cystidium", the stem in some collections showing a series of constrictions along its length; SUBICULUM composed of hyphae 2-3 um wide, rigid-walled or sometimes thick-walled, with clamp connections, the "walls swelling more or less, sometimes dissolving in 10% KOH", (Weresub)
NAME ORIGIN  means "narrow"
SIMILAR  Tubulicrinis gracillimus has less slender cystidia and as a rule a thicker fruitbody, (Hjortstam).
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Breitenbach(2)*, Weresub(3) (as Peniophora angusta), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
445
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis borealis  J. Erikss.^  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 79. 1958
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a whitish to grayish white, soft, waxy fruitbody that is finely pored to continuous, under a lens bristly from cystidia, the margin thinning out, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia that are subclavate, thick-walled except for the upper part, and strongly amyloid, 5) cystidia that are amyloid, dissolving in KOH, cylindric, thick-walled with capillary lumen except at the obtuse apex where the wall is thin and mostly incrusted, the base bifurcate (rooting), and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, in the subhymenial layer thick-walled and invariably amyloid.^ RANGE ^Tubulicrinis borealis has been found in BC and OR, (Ginns). Its distribution also includes Switzerland (Breitenbach), and northern Scandinavia including Sweden, (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], thin or when fully developed often up to 0.007-0.01cm thick; whitish, grayish white, or especially when dried, pale ochraceous; porulose to continuous, with a pilose appearing from the protruding cystidia; margin thinning out^; (Hjortstam), resupinate, tightly attached, "forming thin, floccose-pubescent, more rarely open-membranous patches" a few centimeters across, consistency soft, wax-like; white to gray-white; under a hand lens finely pubescent-hispid [downy-bristly]; margin diffuse, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on all kinds of barkless conifer wood, "often on fencing and other timber lying on the ground"^, (Hjortstam), on rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, as well as old resupinate polypores; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5)5.5-6.5(7) x (1.8)2(2.2) um, allantoid, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, "in dense clusters, subclavate", more or less stemmed, after sporulation usually shrunken and with a conic appearance, about 12-18 x 4-4.5 um, "thick-walled except for the upper part, strongly amyloid", with a basal clamp connection that is difficult to see; CYSTIDIA cylindric, strongly amyloid, generally 60-80 um long and 5-7 um wide in the middle part, "narrowing slightly towards the neck, then slightly widened to the obtuse apex, mostly encrusted with crystalline matter at the thin-walled upper part, capillary lumen narrow, gradually expanded or more commonly abruptly widened, occasionally asymmetric"; HYPHAE monomitic, "thin-walled or more often with slight wall thickening, in the subhymenial layer distinctly thick-walled, 2-3 um wide, and invariably amyloid", all hyphae with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 5-6 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic-cylindric, slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 8-12 x 4-5 um, short-clavate, with basal clamp connection; LYOCYSTIDIA 60-90 x 4-7 um, thick-walled, cylindric "with a slightly widening tip in some and abruptly thin-walled, tip sometimes encrusted", base rooting, cystidia dissolving in KOH, amyloid in Melzer's reagent; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-5 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'northern'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5)
446
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis calothrix  (Pat.) Donk^  Fungus 26: 14. 1956;  == Corticium calothrix  Pat.;  Peniophora calothrix  (Pat.) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, usually coniferous, 2) a whitish to pale yellow or ochraceous fruitbody, interrupted to reticulate/tufted and continuous, and bristly under a strong lens from cystidia, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) basidia that are basally thick-walled, and are amyloid, dissolving in KOH, 5) cystidia that are cylindric, narrowing to the obtuse and encrusted apex, thick-walled with the capillary lumen gradually or more often abruptly expanded, the apex thin-walled (usually on one side), obtuse, and encrusted, the cystidia usually strongly amyloid, and walls dissolving in KOH, 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tubulicrinis calothrix has been found in BC, OR, AB, ON, PQ, AZ, CO, IA, IL, LA, MA, NM, NY, PA, TN, and WI, (Ginns), as well as HI, Latvia, (Weresub(3)), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, at first thin and discontinuous, mostly porulose but as a rule well distinguishable", then thicker and up to 0.01-0.025cm thick; "whitish to pale yellow or ochraceous"; "continuous but with more or less pronounced tufts", not or very rarely rimulose [finely cracked], under a strong lens pilose from projecting cystidia; margin thinning out^, (Hjortstam), "thin and delicate to almost cushiony" (rarely up to 0.02cm in depth), usually easily separable; "white, sometimes somewhat grayish, rarely creamy"; "interrupted to densely reticulate and continuous, broadly effused, with indeterminate margin, pruinose, and hispid", (Weresub(3)), a densely knit reticulum, cushiony, continuous to glebulous [lumpy, clod-like]; creamy; smooth or somewhat punctate, distinctly and regularly hispid, (Weresub(4))
HABITAT  on all kinds of coniferous wood, scattered on fencing and other barkless timber^, (Hjortstam), usually on coniferous wood (Weresub(3)), on Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Tsuga (hemlock); slash; logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-7(8) x 1.5-1.8(2) um, "allantoid, smooth, thin-walled"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 12-15 x 4-5 um, "subclavate, in relatively dense clusters", after sporulation often stemmed and basally thick-walled, mostly with a strong amyloid reaction, basidia with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA cylindric, often numerous, 80-120 um long and 6-8 um wide in the middle part, "narrowing to the obtuse and encrusted apex, with the capillary lumen gradually or more often abruptly expanded, with an asymmetric wall thickening", amyloidity variable, but usually strong; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-2.5 um wide, "thin-walled or with slightly wall thickening", "in the subhymenial tissue fairly dense, inamyloid but remnants of old basidia often intermingled in the tissue giving it a more or less strong amyloid reaction", all hyphae with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES (4.5)5-7 x (1.5)2-3 um, cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, (8.5)11-17.5 x (3.75)4-5.5 um, with basal walls thickened, typically amyloid, also dissolving or swelling in KOH, sterigmata 3.5-4 um long, more or less erect; CYSTIDIA 45-75(125) um long, (4.5)5-7.5(8.5) um broad just above the branching base, usually narrowing slightly to a neck width of 4-5.5(7) um, then most frequently broadening somewhat to an apical width of (4)4.5-6(7) um, capillary lumen "sometimes obliterated toward the base, expanding more or less abruptly about one-sixth to one-third of the distance from the apex", "walls amyloid, thick, thinning toward the tip, typically extending somewhat like a hood along one side and over the summit of the otherwise comparatively thin-walled, obtuse head, the walls swelling and dissolving in KOH, the 'hood' often showing a more delayed reaction"; HYMENIUM "apparently proliferating anew above the husks of old basidia, generally amyloid"; SUBICULAR HYPHAE 2-2.5(4.5) um wide, comparatively rare or obscure, with clamp connections, "walls more or less thickened, swelling in KOH and usually dissolving, typically more or less pronouncedly amyloid", (Weresub(3)), cystidial base bi-rooted (Weresub(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with beautiful hairs'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Weresub(3) (as Peniophora calothrix), Weresub(4) (as Peniophora calothrix), Ginns(5)
447
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis chaetophorus  (Hoehn.) Donk^  Fungus 26: 14. 1956;  == Hypochnus chaetophorus  Hoehn.;  Peniophora chaetophora  (Hoehn.) Hoehn. & Litsch.;  Peniophora dissoluta  Overh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, usually of conifers, 2) a thin, delicate, densely porous-reticulate fruitbody that is whitish to grayish then pale ochraceous, the surface bristly from long protruding cystidia, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) cystidia of 2 types: a) awl-shaped, protruding, thick-walled, the capillary lumen with a slight expansion toward the thin-walled apex, dissolving in KOH, amyloidity usually strong, the cystidia often with more than 2 roots, and b) capitate, often with several constrictions, sometimes with amorphous encrustation, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tubulicrinis chaetophorus has been found in BC, OR, ID, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, MA, NM, NY, and PA, (Ginns), as well as Austria, France, (Weresub(3)), Norway, and Sweden, (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, fairly conspicuous when well developed and consisting of aggregated tufts" that only rarely form a more continuous surface; at first grayish then pale ochraceous; strongly hispid [bristly] from cystidia; margin thinning out to inconspicuous^, (Hjortstam), "thin and delicate to thick and continuous, densely porous reticulate", usually easily separable though sometimes more or less adherent to substrate, sometimes as much as 0.025cm thick and cracked, hispid from long cystidia, "usually broadly effused with indeterminate margin"; "white, grayish, cream, creamy yellow to greenish yellow"; subiculum indistinct, (Weresub(3))
HABITAT  on coniferous wood, but also reported on Alnus (alder)^, (Hjortstam), Abies magnifica (California Red Fir), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock); on rotting wood, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-6.5 x 3-3.5(3.8) um, elliptic, with adaxial side concave or straight, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 4.5-5 um, subclavate (often with median constriction and oily protoplasm), thin-walled, inamyloid, with a basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) lyocystidia, conic - awl-shaped, often with more than 2 roots, 100-200 um long and in the middle part 10 um wide, thick-walled, "capillary lumen normally with a very slight expansion towards the thin-walled apex", amyloidity variable but usually strong, and 2) capitate subhymenial cystidia, sparse, 20-30 um long, "often with several constrictions", "sometimes with amorphous encrustation"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-3 um wide, with clamp connections, "thin-walled or with slight wall thickening", "forming a thin and in most cases inamyloid, fairly dense tissue, subhymenial layer loose with hyphae and basidia often clinging slightly to the cystidia-bases", (Hjortstam), SPORES (4)5-7(7.5) x 2.25-3.5(4) um, broadly elliptic to cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-18 x 3.5-4.5(5.5) um, "cylindric, rarely subclavate, often with decumbent base", sterigmata 5-5.5(7) um long, slender, more or less arcuate; CYSTIDIA 60-180 um long and (4.5)7-10(12.5) um wide just above the branching base, conic, pointed, (some hypha-like, only 2.75-3 um wide throughout), lumina more or less capillary, walls thick, smooth, "in different specimens differing in amyloidity from questionably amyloid to deeply so, very sensitive to KOH, swelling and finally dissolving", cystidial stem "usually more or less entwined with clamped hyphae 2-2.5 um wide"; SUBICULUM indistinct, of hyphae 1.75-2.5(3) um wide, with clamp connections and with more or less pronounced walls, (Weresub(3)), CYSTIDIA bi-rooted or multi-rooted, at maturity mainly 100-200 um long, typically conic and tapering uniformly, (occasional cylindric or subclavate types, these usually immature, some hyphal cystidia also present), varying from inamyloid to amyloid, all but outer wall soluble in 10% KOH, also CYSTIDIOLES (?basidioles) 15-25 um long and 3-5 um wide at base, with head 3.5-4.2 x 4.5-5.5 um, "sometimes haloed by an oily mass", (Weresub(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing long hairs'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Weresub(3) (as Peniophora chaetophora), Weresub(4) (as Peniophora chaetophora), Ginns(5)
448
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis globisporus  K.H. Larss. & Hjortstam^  Mycotaxon 7: 123. 1978
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, 2) a whitish to grayish white fruitbody, very thin, porulose and discontinuous, thickening somewhat when old, slightly bristly from projecting cystidia, the margin thinning out and indistinct, 3) spores that are round, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) basidia that are clavate and inamyloid, with basal wall thickening, 5) cystidia that are subcylindric, strongly amyloid, bi-rooted, blunt, thick-walled in the lower part, the walls gradually thinning out toward the apex, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tubulicrinis globisporus has been found in BC (Ginns). It has also been found in Sweden and reported from France, Germany, and Italy, (Hjortstam(4)), as well as Norway and Sweden, (Hjortstam(6)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], "when young very thin and somewhat inconspicuous, with age thickening, whitish to greyish white, under a lens slightly pilose due to the projecting cystidia"; margin indistinct^, (Hjortstam(4)), resupinate, as a rule very thin, porulose and discontinuous; whitish or in the herbarium sometimes pale ochraceous; pilose from projecting cystidia; margin thinning out, not determinable, (Hjortstam(6))
HABITAT  on fallen branches and trunks of coniferous wood, mostly on Pinus (pine) but also on Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir)^, (Hjortstam(4)), mostly on Pinus, (Hjortstam(6)), in BC on fallen trunk of Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 4 um across, nearly round, inamyloid^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 13-15 x 5-7 um, clavate, inamyloid, basal wall thickening; CYSTIDIA frequent, 90-120 x 5-7 um, subcylindric, strongly amyloid, bi-rooted, "thick-walled in lower part, the walls gradually thinning out towards the apex, upper part not expanded"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-4 um wide, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, inamyloid, with clamp connections, (Hjortstam(4)), SPORES 4.5-5(5.5) um in diameter, obliquely round [also referred to as "subglobose", illustrated with definite apiculus], smooth, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-15(18) x 5-7 um, subclavate, "basally with slight wall thickening, forming rather loose clusters, inamyloid", with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 70-120 x 5-7 um, cylindric, "not or only slightly widened toward the obtuse apex, capillary lumen expanded gradually with the upper, thin-walled part more than 10 um long", the cystidia usually very strongly amyloid; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-3.5 um wide, with clamp connections, "thin-walled or with slight wall thickening", "arranged in a very thin and inamyloid tissue", (Hjortstam(6))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with spherical spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(4), Hjortstam(6), Ginns(5)
449
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis gracillimus  (D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.) G. Cunn.^  New Zealand Dept. Sci. Ind. Res. Bull. 145: 141. 1963;  == Peniophora gracillima  Ellis & Everh. ex D.P. Rogers and H.S. Jacks.;  Corticium glebulosum  (Fr.) Bres.;  Peniophora glebulosa  (Bres.) Sacc. & P. Syd.;  Tubulicrinis glebulosus  (Fr.) Donk  [as 'glebulosa'], Fungus, Wageningen 26(1-4): 14. 1956 (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) whitish or cream or sordid ochraceous color, under a 50x lens flocculose or granular when young, bristly from projecting cystidia, the margin indeterminate to filamentous, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia that are subclavate, slightly stemmed, thin-walled or with slight wall thickening, 5) cylindric cystidia, the amyloidity varying from a strong blue to a grayish reaction, dissolving in KOH, generally encrusted with crystalline material, thick-walled with a capillary lumen that expands abruptly to the slightly narrower, thin-walled, blunt apex, and 6) a hyphal system that is normally monomitic, the hyphae with clamp connections, thin-walled to moderately thick-walled, but in some specimens thick-walled skeletal hyphae are found in a layer next to the substrate, weakly amyloid and seemingly without septa.^ |The online Species Fungorum, accessed August 27, 2020 and September 12, 2022, gave the current name as Tubulicrinis glebulosus (Fr.) Donk, but MycoBank, accessed September 12, 2022, listed the current name as Tubulicrinis gracillimus (D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.) G. Cunn. RANGE ^Tubulicrinis gracillimus has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, MB, NS, ON, PQ, AZ, CA. CO, IL, ME, MI, MT, NC, NE, NH, NJ, NM, NY, VT, and WI, (Ginns), as well as Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hjortstam), and Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], in most specimens relatively thick, up to 0.025cm thick or more, "at first discontinuous then continuous and widely spread" over the substrate; whitish or more commonly cream to sordid ochraceous; in young parts minutely flocculose or granular (under 50x lens), "especially when dried cracking in small and irregular pieces", distinctly pilose from projecting cystidia; margin mostly indeterminate^, (Hjortstam), resupinate, attached tightly to substrate, forming thin, continuous patches several centimeters across, consistency thin-membranous, wax-like; whitish to cream; smooth, under a 10x lens finely hispid [bristly] from cystidia; margin filamentous, (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on hardwood and conifer wood^, (Hjortstam), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Salix (willow), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); "Bark; rarely bark; decaying wood; twig; slash; bark or between loose bark and wood of logs; associated with a white rot", (Ginns), on rotten conifer wood, especially of Picea and Pinus; fall, (Breitenbach) 
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (6)7.5-8.5(9) x (1.5)1.75-2(2.25) um, allantoid, smooth, thin-walled^, variation in size noted, between normally 6-8 um long up to 8-10 um long; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 4-4.5 um, "in a fairly dense palisade, clustered relatively loose", subclavate, "thin-walled or with slight wall thickening", slightly stemmed, inamyloid, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA cylindric, robust, generally 100-200 um long and 6-10 um wide in the middle part, "narrowing to the obtuse and slightly contracted thin-walled apex, generally encrusted with crystalline matter, capillary lumen narrow, expanding more or less abruptly at the apex, amyloidity variable from a very strong blue to a greyish reaction"; HYPHAE normally monomitic but sometimes with thick-walled skeletal hyphae; generative hyphae 2-2.5(3) um wide, "arranged in a dense tissue, inamyloid", thin-walled to moderately thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, skeletal hyphae occurring in some specimens forming a thin layer next to the substrate, 2.5-3 um wide, weakly amyloid, thick-walled and seemingly without septa, (Hjortstam(6)), SPORES 6-8 x 1.5-1.8 um, cylindric, slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 4.5-5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; LYOCYSTIDIA 105-140 x 8-12 um, +/- cylindric with blunt tip, weakly amyloid, dissolving in KOH, thick-walled, lumen at the tip enlarging abruptly, dissolving in KOH; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tubulicrinis angustus "has more slender cystidia and as a rule a thinner fruitbody", (Hjortstam). Tubulicrinis subulatus is similar but in well-developed specimens it is distinguished by awl-shaped cystidia, (Hjortstam).
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Breitenbach(2)* (as Tubulicrinis glebulosus), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)* (as Tubulicrinis glebulosus)
450
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis inornatus  (H.S. Jacks. & D.P. Rogers) Donk^  Fungus 26: 14. 1956;  == Peniophora inornata  H.S. Jacks. & D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on well decayed, barkless conifer wood, 2) a whitish fruitbody consisting of small, discontinuous tufts, minutely bristly from projecting cystidia, the margin thinning out, 3) spores that are nearly round to oblong or ovate, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) cystidia that are cylindric with pointed tips, the base bifurcate, the stem thick-walled with a capillary lumen that expands forming a thin-walled awl-shaped tip that occupies as much as a third to a half of the cystidial length, apically covered or shielded on one side by a duncecap-like encrustation of different composition, the cystidia inamyloid (or with a grayish reaction in Melzer's reagent), dissolving somewhat in KOH, and 5), a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tubulicrinis inornatus has been found in OR and ON, (Ginns), as well as Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  "resupinate, consisting of small, discontinuous tufts"; whitish; minutely hispid [bristly] from projecting cystidia; margin thinning out^, (Hjortstam), "varying from a sparse cream hispidity to a delicate network", inseparable, (Weresub)
HABITAT  on well decayed and barkless wood of both Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), (Hjortstam), on Abies balsamea (Subalpine Fir), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), P. strobus (Eastern White Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5(5.5) x 3-3.5 um, ovate to short-elliptic, (adaxial side convex), smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA subclavate, ordinarily 12-15 x 4-4.5 um, "constricted, thin-walled, inamyloid", with a basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA usually bifurcated [bi-rooted], "originating from basal hyphae or from the lower parts of the basidial clusters, dissolving slightly in strong KOH", inamyloid or with grayish reaction in Melzer's reagent, generally 70-90 um long and 4-6 um wide near base, with a fairly wide capillary lumen that "widens gradually to the thin-walled pointed apex, apically covered with cowl-like encrustation"; HYPHAE monomitic, basal hyphae 2.5-3 um wide, "distinct, straight, thin-walled or with slightly wall thickening", tissue fairly dense and inamyloid, subhymenial layer loose, all hyphae with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 4.2-5.5 x 3-3.5 um, nearly round to oblong or ovate, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-15 x 4-5 um, flexuously cylindric, sterigmata about 3.5 um long, slender, erect; CYSTIDIA up to 70 um long, 4-5.5 um wide, when mature "characteristically looking like rifles with bayonet-insertions", the stem more or less cylindric, "thick-walled with more or less capillary lumen", this extending beyond the neck "as a slender, thin-walled projection as much as one-third to one-half the full length", bald 'or typically capped or one-sidedly shielded by an acutely pointed conical "dunce-cap" of different composition', not as readily soluble in KOH as the thickened walls of the cystidial stems, cystidial base usually distinctly bifurcate or even trifurcate, "arising from a horizontally placed hypha, frequently but not always truly bi-rooted, sometimes clearly the apical extension of an erect or simply horizontally deflected hypha", thickened wall of cystidia inamyloid, "the middle layer swelling drastically and eventually dissolving in 10% KOH", "inner and outer membranes insoluble"; context composed of HYPHAE up to 3 um wide, distinct, firm-walled, septa with clamp connections, branching frequently right-angled; "subiculum of few horizontal hyphae from which arise cystidia or erect branches producing cystidia and basidia, with little build-up of trama", (Weresub)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'unadorned'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Weresub(4) (as Peniophora inornata), Ginns(5)
451
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis juniperinus  (Bourdot & Galzin) Donk^  Fungus 26: 14. 1956;  == Peniophora glebulosa subsp. juniperina  Bourdot & Galzin;  Peniophora juniperina  (Bourdot & Galzin) Bourdot & Galzin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, oak, and heath, 2) a white to sometimes grayish or creamy fruitbody, ranging from thin, delicate, more or less interrupted and somewhat pruinose, to densely continuous, cracked, almost membranous, the surface usually smooth but occasionally sparsely and minutely odontioid, the fruitbody closely adherent to separable, the margin indistinct, 3) spores that are cylindric, curved (when narrow), smooth, and inamyloid, 4) cystidia that are long-conic and capitate, the base bifurcate, the cystidium narrowing uniformly towards the apical bulb, the capillary lumen enclosed by the thick walls expanding rapidly at the neck to form the thin-walled apical bulb, sometimes collared by crystals, sometimes haloed or capped by an amorphous or crystalline mass, the cystidial wall inamyloid to strongly amyloid, the middle layer of the wall dissolving in 10% KOH, 5) occasional different cystidia that are subconic and lack a bulb, the lumen not capillary except in roots or not even there, relatively broad in the stem, with the wall thinning gradually to an elongate, thin-walled apex, and 6) context composed of hyphae with clamp connections.^ |The description derived from Weresub(4) is of var. subquercina, but Weresub considered it to be more or less typical Peniophora juniperina and placed the name in synonymy with Peniophora juniperina, despite its occurrence on oak instead of conifer or heath. RANGE ^Tubulicrinis juniperinus has been found in BC, OR, ID, ON, PQ, and MA, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  most often broadly effused [spread out] with indeterminate margin, "ranging from thin, delicate, more or less interrupted and somewhat pruinose, to densely continuous, cracked, sometimes almost membranous", "closely adherent or more or less separable"; "usually white, sometimes grayish or creamy"; "usually smooth, though occasionally sparsely and minutely odontioid"; "subiculum often appreciable in depth"^, (Weresub(3)), "white, from delicate thin meshwork to dense reticulum with occasional slight papillation"; more or less separable, (Weresub(4))
HABITAT  on coniferous wood^ (Weresub(3)), on Picea sp. (spruce), conifer, (Ginns)
