MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (4)4.75-7.25(8.5) x (0.75)1.0-2(2.5) um, narrowly cylindric, where very narrow almost allantoid, (where broader scarcely curved), smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 7-15(18) x 3.5-4.25(5) um, cylindric to clavate, "basal walls sometimes pronounced, more or less soluble in KOH", CYSTIDIA 50-95 um long, (3.5)5.5-7.5(9) um wide near base, stem narrowing to a neck width of 3-5(5.5) um, "where the capillary lumen expands more or less abruptly to form thin-walled apical bulbs" (5)7-10(11) x (6)7-9(11.5) um, "apices sometimes heavily massed with crystals", stem walls smooth, dissolving in KOH, inamyloid to amyloid; SUBICULUM "composed mainly of indistinct hyphae", 2-2.75 um wide, with clamp connections, sometimes with somewhat thickened walls that dissolve in KOH, (Weresub(3)), SPORES (few seen) 5.5 x 1.5 um, cylindric, curved, (according to Donk 5-6 x 1.5-1.75-2 um), smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA (few measured) about 15 x 4.3 um, flexuous cylindric to clavate to obovoid, usually narrowing sharply in lower part; CYSTIDIA "self-capitate", with subconic stem, 30-65 um long (according to Donk up to 75 um), (3)4.5-6.5 um wide just above base, the base usually furcate, "sometimes distinctly truly bi-rooted", cystidia narrowing more or less uniformly to a neck width of (2)3-3.8(5) um, "lumen capillary in base and stem, expanding abruptly at neck to form thin-walled apical bulbs" (4)9-11 x (4)8.5-10 um, "sometimes collared by crystals, sometimes haloed or capped by an amorphous or crystalline mass", "wall varying in amyloidity from negative to strongly positive, smooth, thick, middle layer soluble in 10% KOH"; occasional cystidia subconic and lacking bulb, "lumen not capillary except in roots or not even there, relatively broad in stem, with wall thinning gradually to elongate, thin-walled apices"; context composed of HYPHAE up to 3 um wide, firm-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Weresub(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to juniper'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Weresub(3) (as Peniophora juniperina), Weresub(4) (as Peniophora juniperina var. subquercina), Ginns(5)
452
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis prominens  (H.S. Jacks. & Dearden) Donk^  Fungus 26: 14. 1956;  == Peniophora prominens  H.S. Jacks. & Dearden
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on rotting wood of conifers, 2) a delicate, mould-like, whitish fruitbody that is discontinuous, formed of loosely aggregated tufts, under a lens bristly from cystidia, the margin not differentiated, 3) spores that are nearly round to broadly elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) branched clusters of basidia frequently centering on a cystidium, after maturity clusters of basidial bases remaining, 5) numerous inamyloid cystidia that are cylindric, obtuse at the apex, the walls thickened in their proximal part, gradually thinning out toward the apex so that the distal third is thin-walled, the lumen capillary at base, gradually expanding toward the apex, the middle layer of the wall soluble in KOH, and 6) basal hyphae that are few, more or less horizontal, with clamp connections, not forming a distinct subiculum, giving rise at intervals to upright branches terminated by clusters of basidia with scattered cystidia.^ RANGE ^Tubulicrinis prominens has been found in ID, AZ, and NM, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  delicate, mucedinous [mould-like], "discontinuous, formed of loosely aggregated floccose tufts"; white; delicately hispid [bristly] under a lens due to projecting cystidia; margin not differentiated^, (Jackson), easily separable (Weresub), "very thin, a grayish film hardly visible to the naked eye when dry" (Gilbertson)
HABITAT  on Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine); on rotting wood^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4 x 3.5-4 um, nearly round, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, "with conspicuous lateral peg-like apiculus"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-17 x 4.5-5 um, cylindric or somewhat inflated in distal part, sterigmata subulate [awl-shaped], slightly arcuate, "after maturity clusters of basidial bases remain as stalked cyathiform structures with thick rigid walls, proliferation of basidia is acropetal through subtending clamps, giving rise to branched clusters of basidia frequently centering around a cystidium"; CYSTIDIA numerous, 80-110 x 4-4.5 um, cylindric or slightly tapering in distal part, obtuse at apex, walls thickened in proximal part, gradually thinning out toward apex, "more or less soluble in KOH", inamyloid, lumen capillary at base, gradually expanding toward the apex, thin-walled in distal third; BASAL HYPHAE "few, more or less horizontal", with clamp connections, "not forming a distinct subiculum, giving rise at intervals to upright branches terminated by clusters of basidia with scattered cystidia", (Jackson), middle layer of wall of CYSTIDIA soluble in strong alkali (Weresub), SPORES 5-7 x 3.5-5 um, nearly round to broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; CYSTIDIA frequent, up to 70 um long and 3-8 um wide, "with rounded apex, wall thick at base, lumen expanding above base gradually to form a long apical bulb", inamyloid; SUBICULAR HYPHAE difficult to discern, some 3-13 um wide, thin-walled, rigid, simple-septate, others 3-4 um wide, thick-walled, nodose-septate, (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'projecting, standing out'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Jackson(4) (as Peniophora prominens), Weresub(4) (as Peniophora prominens), Gilbertson(9), Ginns(5)
453
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis regificus  (H.S. Jacks. & Dearden) Donk^  Fungus 26: 14. 1956;  == Peniophora regifica  H.S. Jacks. & Dearden
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on bark and barkless wood of conifers, 2) a whitish to pale ocher, waxy-submembranous fruitbody that is at first powdery to porulose then gradually thicker, under a lens bristly from cystidia, the margin thinning out abruptly but not clearly demarcated, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) cystidia that are cylindric and thick-walled except for a spherical thin-walled head, in most cases has attached brownish amorphous matter, the cystidial base bi-rooted to several-rooted, the middle wall layer soluble in 10% KOH, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^the holotype is from OR (Jackson). It has also been found in Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, at first very thin and pulverulent [powdery] to porulose, then gradually thicker; whitish to more rarely pale ocher; tufted and in well-developed specimens with slightly odontioid appearance, cystidia projecting conspicuously; margin not determinable^, (Hjortstam), widely effused [spread out], thin, 0.005-0.017cm thick, adnate [firmly attached], ceraceous [waxy] to submembranous; white; under a lens appearing somewhat tufted and hispid [bristly] due to projecting cystidia; margin thinning out abruptly, (Jackson)
HABITAT  on bark and barkless wood of conifers^, (Hjortstam), type on coniferous wood, (Jackson)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-8(9) x 3.5-5 um, elliptic, adaxially straight or slightly convex, more rarely concave, smooth, thin-walled^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 6-7 um, subclavate, inamyloid, thin-walled, with oily contents, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA 80-120 um long (in the type considerably longer, reaching 170 um), normally 5-8 um wide in the middle part, narrowing slightly toward the neck, "then abruptly widened to a distinct, thin-walled head" about 8-15 um wide, "in most cases provided with brownish amorphous matter", "capillary lumen widening gradually or abrupt to a thin-walled and almost circular apex"; HYPHAE monomitic, inamyloid, with clamp connections; subhymenial hyphae short-celled, twisted, thin-walled, "with more oily contents than in other species"; basal hyphae 2-3 um wide, cells 30-50 um long, "thin-walled or with slight wall thickening, straight and branching at more or less right angles", (Hjortstam), SPORES 7-8.5 x 4.5-5.5 um, broadly elliptic, "laterally flattened with minute apiculus", smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-22 x 6.5-7 um, broadly clavate or cylindric, sterigmata 6-8 um long, subulate [awl-shaped], straight; CYSTIDIA numerous, 100-150 x 7.5-8.5 um, cylindric except for the inflated subspherical or obovate apex that is 10-12 um wide, "walls thick except for the expanded apex, dissolving in KOH", lumen capillary, abruptly dilated before the apex, light encrustation may be present on the dilated part; SUBHYMENIUM "of loosely branched suberect thin-walled hyphae" with clamp connections at the septa, "becoming collapsed and indistinct"; lower SUBICULUM "forming a narrow basal layer of more or less horizontal hyphae with gelatinized walls", (Jackson), CYSTIDIA more or less embedded or, most frequently, emergent to as much as three-quarters of height, base truly bi-rooted to several-rooted, middle wall layer soluble in 10% KOH, apical bulbs as much as 18 x 13 um, one seen 16 um wide, sometimes haloed by amorphous mass or lightly encrusted; occasional cystidia subcylindric or subconic throughout, lacking bulb and with lumen capillary only in base and lower stem, expanding gradually toward apex, (Weresub)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Jackson(4) (as Peniophora regifica), Hjortstam(6), Weresub(4) (as Peniophora regifica), Ginns(5)
454
FAMILY  Hymenochaetaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tubulicrinis subulatus  (Bourdot & Galzin) Donk^  Fungus 26: 14. 1956;  == Peniophora glebulosa subsp. subulata  Bourdot & Galzin;  Peniophora subulata  (Bourdot & Galzin) Donk
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood and occasionally on hardwood, 2) a whitish to cream or yellowish brown fruitbody that is wax-like, soft, floccose-crustose, discontinuous or continuous, firmly attached, the surface bristly under a lens from projecting cystidia, 3) spores that are allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia with basally thickened, KOH-soluble walls, 5) cystidia that are cylindric, thick-walled, narrowing slightly to the subulate [awl-shaped] and mostly mucronate tip, the capillary lumen widening abruptly near the tip so that it is thin-walled, apically encrusted with crystalline matter except for the outermost, thin-walled part, cystidia in Melzer's reagent grayish to fairly strong blue, tending to dissolve in KOH, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tubulicrinis subulatus has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, IL, MA, MT, NM, NY, OH, and RI, (Ginns). It is very common in the whole of Scandinavia (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached], when fully developed mostly relatively thick, often up to 0.02cm or more, continuous but when dried usually cracking in irregular pieces; "whitish to cream or yellowish brown"; strongly pilose from projecting cystidia; margin thinning out^, (Hjortstam), "resupinate, bound tightly to the substrate, forming thin, floccose-crustose, non-membranous, and rarely continuous patches" a few centimeters across, consistency wax-like, soft; white to cream; surface "finely tuberculate and with an open punctiform texture toward the margin", with fine hairs under a hand lens, (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on all kinds of coniferous wood and occasionally on hardwood^, (Hjortstam), on rotten wood of conifers; spring to fall, (Breitenbach), on wood of Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), and Pinus (pine); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), probably all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES allantoid, smooth, thin-walled, generally 6-8 x 1.5-1.8 um^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-18(20) x 3.5-4.5 um, "in a rather dense palisade", subclavate to more or less stemmed, "thin-walled or, especially after sporulation, basally with thickened walls, inamyloid", with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA cylindric, robust, ordinarily 80-100 um long and 8-10 um wide in the middle part, narrowing slightly to the subulate [awl-shaped] and mostly mucronate tip, capillary lumen widening gradually near tip so that it is thin-walled, "apically encrusted with crystalline matter except for the outermost, thin-walled part", amyloidity variable, usually only grayish "but in some specimens the reaction is a fairly strong blue"; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-2.5(3) um wide, arranged in a fairly dense tissue, inamyloid, with clamp connections, "thin-walled or with slight wall thickening", subhymenial hyphae more or less densely packed, subicular hyphae irregularly interwoven, (Hjortstam), SPORES 7-9 x 1.5-2 um (according to Julich and Stalpers 1980 6-7.5(9) x 1.5-2.5 um), narrowly elliptic, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with 2 droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-25 x 4-4.5 um, narrowly clavate, without basal clamp connection; LYOCYSTIDIA 70-130 x 10 um, subulate, "thick-walled with very thin lumen", "becoming abruptly thin-walled toward the tip and sometimes incrusted", cystidia inamyloid, dissolving in KOH, base rooting; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-4 um wide, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), BASIDIA "with basally thickened, KOH-soluble walls that remain as closely packed husks in the trama", the basidia broadly clavate on generally narrowed stems; CYSTIDIA truly bi-rooted, (Weresub)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'subulate' referring to the shape of the cystidia
SIMILAR  Tubulicrinis gracillimus is similar but in well-developed specimens distinguished by obtuse cystidia, (Hjortstam). Tubulicrinis glebulosus has been collected by O. Ceska from British Columbia and deposited at the University of British Columbia. T. subulata has been considered one of its forms.
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Breitenbach(2)*, Weresub(4) (as Peniophora subulata), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
455
FAMILY  Tulasnellaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tulasnella allantospora  Wakef. & A. Pearson^  Trans. Br. mycol. Soc. 8: 220. 1923
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include very thin, waxy fruitbodies that are pale grayish or lilaceous to obscurely rosy, growth on hardwood, and microscopic characters including crescent-shaped spores.^ RANGE ^Tulasnella allantospora has been found in ON, PQ, AZ, IA, MA, MO, NC, NM, NY, and OH, (Ginns). It also occurs in Europe including the United Kingdom and in the Marshall Islands, (Martin, G.W.). There is a collection from BC by R. Bandoni at the University of British Columbia, and there are collections there also from CA by K. Wells, PA, IA, Norway, and Sweden.
FRUITING BODY  very thin, waxy; "pale grayish or lilaceous to obscure rosy, drying light pinkish, lilaceous gray or invisible"^, (Martin, G.W.), "very thin, adnate, arid-pruinose; hymenial surface grayish", (Gilbertson)
HABITAT  bark and debarked wood of hardwoods, rarely on coniferous wood^, (Martin, G.W.), on Pinus ponderosus (Gilbertson, who is writing about species that grow on that host)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5.5-8 x 2.5-4.5 um, thick-allantoid (crescentic), tapering toward ends, bright pink in mass^; PROBASIDIA 7-10 x 5-6 um, obovate, "epibasidia four, finally with subglobose or broadly ovate bases, tapering abruptly to the slender sterigmata", (Martin, G.W.), SPORES 5.4-8 x 2.5-4.5 um, no germination observed; BASIDIA 7-10 x 5-6 um, obovate, HYPHAE 3.5-5 um wide, thin-walled, septate, with or without clamp connections, (Klett), SPORES 5-7 x 2-2.5 um, allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; HYPOBASIDIA subspherical, collapsing, epibasidia 4, subspherical, 4-4.5 um in diam; HYPHAE 1.5-3 um wide, mostly simple-septate but with occasional clamp connections, (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with allantoid (crescentic) spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gilbertson(9), Martin, G.W.(1), Klett(1), Ginns(5)
456
FAMILY  Tulasnellaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tulasnella bifrons  Bourdot & Galzin^  Bull. Soc. Myc. Fr. 39: 264. 1924
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Microscopically, the stemmed-spherical form of the hypobasidium in the early stages is distinctive, (Martin). Features include 1) resupinate growth on rotten wood or the spore-bearing surface of decaying shelf fungi, 2) a thin, delicate, waxy fruitbody that is grayish white, sometimes faintly lilaceous, 3) spores that are oblong to subcylindric or slightly curved, measuring 4.5-6.5 x 2-2.5 um, 4) tulasnelloid basidia, pyriform probasidia that become stemmed-spherical as the epibasidia form, the epibasidia broadly fusiform to conic, tapering to slender sterigmata, and 5) hyphae that are abundantly branched, irregular, much-septate, with clamp connections lacking or infrequent according to G.W. Martin, present at all septa according to Roberts.^ RANGE ^Tulasnella bifrons has been found in OR, ON, IA, MA, MO, NC, and OH, (Ginns). It also Europe including France, (Martin).
FRUITING BODY  very thin, delicate, waxy; "grayish white, sometimes faintly lilaceous"^, (Martin)
HABITAT  on barkless wood of Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), and Ulmus (elm)^, (Martin), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Pinus, Quercus, Ulmus; underside of moist rotten wood; fertile surface of decaying shelf fungus, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-6(7.8) x 2.8-3.5(5) um, oblong to subcylindric, straight, germinating by repetition^; PROBASIDIA 7-10(14.6) x 5.8-7.8 um, pyriform, becoming stemmed-spherical as epibasidia develop, epibasidia finally broadly fusiform to conic, tapering to the slender sterigmata; hyphae 1.5-3 um in diameter, "abundantly branched, irregular, much-septate", clamp connections lacking or infrequent, (Martin), SPORES 4.5-6.5 x 2-2.5 um, weakly allantoid to cylindric; BASIDIA often stemmed; HYPHAE 2-3(6) um wide; placed in the part of the key with species that have clamp connections at all septa, (Roberts)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  The other Tulasnella species recorded here from the Pacific Northwest lack clamp connections. See also SIMILAR section of Tulasnella eichleriana, Tulasnella fuscoviolacea, Tulasnella pruinosa, and Tulasnella violea.
SOURCES  Martin, G.W.(1), Ginns(5), Roberts(2)
457
FAMILY  Tulasnellaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tulasnella calospora  (Boud.) Juel^  Bih. Kongl. Svenska Vetensk.-Akad. Handl. 23: 23. 1897;  == Protremella calospora  Boud.;  Gloeotulasnella calospora  (Boud.) D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) growth on decayed wood, also mycorrhizal with orchids, and found on old shelf fungi and dead mosses, 2) a thin, waxy or waxy-gelatinous fruitbody that is pale neutral or pinkish gray, 3) very long narrow spores that are cylindric to fusiform, and straight, arcuate, sigmoid, or helicoid, usually with a distinct apical projection, 4) tulasnelloid basidia, spherical, and long-stemmed probasidia, with usually 4 epibasidia, and 5) hyphae without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Tulasnella calospora has been found in OR, AB, ON, IA, ME, NC, NH, and WI, (Ginns). It also occurs in HI, and Europe including France, (Martin). There are R. Bandoni collections from BC deposited at the University of British Columbia (as Gloeotulasnella calospora).
FRUITING BODY  thin, "waxy or waxy-gelatinous"; "pale neutral or pinkish gray, drying whitish or invisible"; "the surface dusted with spores under a lens", (Martin), resupinate, effused [spread out], several centimeters across, about 0.005-0.01cm thick, firm-membranaceous to slightly ceraceous [waxy], adnate [firmly attached], "separable in small pieces, contents homogeneous"; whitish to cream-colored; "even, not cracked when dry"; "margin whitish, indistinct, thinning out"; rhizomorphs or hyphal strands none, (Julich)
HABITAT  on decayed hardwood and conifer wood^, (Martin), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Quercus (oak), Calopogon sp., Goodyera sp., Habenaria sp., Platanthera obtusata, Pogonia sp., Spiranthes sp.; mycorrhizal with species of Orchidaceae; on old shelf fungi; on dead mosses, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 15-52 x 3-4 um, "cylindric, straight, arcuate, sigmoid or helicoid"^; PROBASIDIA 12-20 x 8-14 um, spherical, long-stemmed, "epibasidia usually four, occasionally more, finally ovate to oblong at base, produced into cylindric filament toward apex"; hyphae 3-6 um wide, "mostly repent, sparsely branched", without clamp connections, (Martin), SPORES 19-24 x 4.4-5.3 um, long-sinuous, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, contents homogeneous, thin-walled, with small apiculus; BASIDIA 4-spored, colorless, clavate when mature, sometimes stemmed, broadly ellipsoid when young, 14-27 x 10-13 um, smooth, thin-walled, basal clamp connection absent, contents homogeneous, epibasidia broadly elliptic, about 12-13 x 8-9 um, rather abruptly narrowed to subulate [awl-shaped], sometimes branched sterigmata (up to 11 x 3.5 um); CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE 3-6 um wide, "loosely arranged in subhymenium and trama", cylindric, colorless, "branching from all parts of the hyphae", "thin-walled in the subhymenium, thin-walled to somewhat thick-walled in the trama", with smooth surface, clamp connections lacking, contents homogeneous, (Julich), SPORES 16-30 x 3.5-5(8) um, "broadly to narrowly fusiform, usually with a distinct apical projection", (Roberts)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with beautiful spores'
SIMILAR  Other Tulasnella species recorded from the Pacific Northwest have completely different spores. See also SIMILAR section of Tulasnella eichleriana, Tulasnella fuscoviolacea, and Tulasnella pruinosa.
SOURCES  Julich(6), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Gloeotulasnella calospora), Ginns(5), Roberts(2)
458
FAMILY  Tulasnellaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tulasnella eichleriana  Bres.^  Ann. Mycol. 1: 113. 1903
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Tulasnella eichleriana is recognized among Tulasnella species by its unclamped hyphae, conventionally branched hymenium (see MICROSCOPIC), and small spores. Features include 1) resupinate growth on rotting wood and bark, 2) a waxy to somewhat gelatinous fruitbody that is violet gray, firmly attached, and smooth, the margin colored as the rest of the surface or paler, thinning out, 3) spores that are small, measuring 2.5-4.5(6) x 2.5-3.5 um, nearly round to elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) tulasnelloid basidia, 5) hyphae without clamp connections forming a "conventionally branched" hymenium.^ | Roberts(2) considers that it is almost certainly a complex of small-spored taxa. RANGE ^Tulasnella eichleriana has been found in WA, ID, MB, ON, IA, MA, NH, NY, and PA, (Ginns). Collections were examined from ON, Argentina, Brazil, Denmark, France, Norway, Poland, United Kingdom, and China, (Roberts).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], ceraceous [waxy] to subgelatinous; violaceous gray^, (Roberts), resupinate, effused, several centimeters across, about 0.005-0.01cm thick, "firm-membranaceous to slightly ceraceous", adnate [firmly attached], separable in small pieces; cream to pale grayish; "even, not cracked when dry"; margin colored as the spore-bearing surface or paler, thinning out; rhizomorphs or hyphal strands absent; context homogeneous, (Julich), gray to smoky olivaceous or with a pinkish tinge, with aspect of a pale thin Corticium or Hypochnus, (Overholts)
HABITAT  on rotting wood and bark, Betula sp. (birch), Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Populus sp., Quercus sp. (oak), Salix sp. (willow), (Ginns), also Alnus (alder), Corylus (hazel), Fagus (beech), Nothofagus (southern beech), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), (Roberts)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES nearly round "to pip-shaped (attenuated toward the apiculus, resembling an apple pip)" or elliptic, about 2.5-4.5(6) x 2.5-3.5 um^; BASIDIA mostly clavate, rather small, about 3-5 um wide, sterigmata spherical or ellipsoid at first "becoming clavate, mitriform, or fusiform", 1.5-4 um at widest point, variously elongating up to 18 um or more; HYPHAE about 2.5-3.5 um wide, without clamp connections, forming a conventionally branched, often compact hymenium ["conventionally branched" meaning "composed of highly branched, short-celled, basidia-bearing hyphae arising from straighter, longer-celled, often thick-walled, basal hyphae running parallel to the substrate", as opposed to "cluster-forming", meaning "clusters of basidia are formed on long-celled, little-branched hyphae, basal hyphae being absent or little differentiated", a condition not established for Pacific Northwest species of Tulasnella], subhymenial hyphae "generally short-celled and somewhat swollen", basal hyphae "longer-celled, straighter, with distinct refractive walls", (Roberts), SPORES 3.5-4.5 x 3-4 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, contents homogeneous, with small apiculus, some forming secondary spores; BASIDIA 4-spored, colorless, clavate when mature, 7-10 x 4.5-5.5 um, thin-walled, smooth, basal clamp connection lacking, contents homogeneous, epibasidia about 6-7.5 x 4.5-5 um, broadly elliptic, "rather abruptly narrowed to flexuous-cylindric or subulate sterigmata", about 3.5-4 x 2-2.5 um; CYSTIDIA lacking; HYPHAE colorless, cylindric or somewhat torulose in the subhymenium, 2-5 um wide, loosely arranged, "branching from all parts of the hyphae", with distinct dolipore, clamp connections lacking, thin-walled, smooth, contents homogeneous, (Julich), small basidia and epibasidia, (Overholts)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tulasnella violea (Quel.) Bourdot & Galzin is similar enough that Martin, G.W.(1) gives T. eichleriana as a synonym of that species, but Roberts(2) disagrees emphatically citing the marked difference in microscopic dimensions [spores of T. violea about 5.5-9 x 5.5-7.5 um, for example]. Tulasnella pruinosa has spore width intermediate between T. violea and T. eichleriana, and spores are elliptic to oblong. Tulasnella fuscoviolacea has longer spores than those three species. Tulasnella calospora has very long narrow spores. Tulasnella bifrons has clamp connections according to Roberts(2).
SOURCES  Roberts(2), Julich(6), Overholts(2), Martin, G.W.(1), Burt(15), Ginns(5)
459
FAMILY  Tulasnellaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tulasnella fuscoviolacea  Bres.^  Fungi. Trid. 2: 98. 1900
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Tulasnella fuscoviolacea is microscopically marked by slender nearly cylindric spores and thick basal hyphae. Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, mainly of conifers, 2) waxy, violaceous gray, smooth fruitbodies that are firmly attached, the margin thinning out, 3) nearly cylindric spores that are slightly curved, measuring(7)8.5-12 x 4-4.5 um, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) tulasnelloid basidia, 5) hyphae without clamp connections forming a "conventionally branched" hymenium.^ RANGE ^Tulasnella fuscoviolacea has been found in WA, ID, ON, PE, CA, IA, MN, NH, NY, OH, and PA, (Ginns). It also occurs in Europe (Martin), France (Julich), and Denmark and Italy, (Roberts).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], several centimeters across, about 0.005-0.01cm thick, membranaceous, adnate [firmly attached], separable in small pieces; cream; "even, not cracked when dry"; "margin whitish, thinning out"; rhizomorphs and hyphal strands absent; context homogeneous, (Julich), resupinate, effused, ceraceous [waxy]; violaceous gray^, (Roberts), "waxy to waxy-gelatinous; deep dull violaceous when fresh, drying pale lilaceous", (Martin)
HABITAT  mainly on coniferous wood^, (Martin), Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), hardwood; bark; rotten wood; pine cone, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-12.5 x 3.7-4.5 um, slightly allantoid, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, contents homogeneous, with small apiculus^, germination by means of secondary spores; BASIDIA 4-spored, clavate when mature, 9.5-15 x 7.5-9 um, smooth, colorless, thin-walled, contents homogeneous, basal clamp connection lacking, epibasidia about 10-12 x4.5-5 um, clavate, rather abruptly narrowed to flexuous-cylindric sterigmata, about 6 x 1.5 um; CYSTIDIA lacking; HYPHAE 3-4.5 um wide, loosely arranged, cylindric, colorless, with distinct dolipore, thin-walled, smooth, contents homogeneous, clamp connections absent, (Julich), SPORES about (7)8.5-12 x 4-4.5 um, oblong to subcylindric; BASIDIA mostly clavate, 6.5-8.5 um wide, sterigmata 4-6 um across at widest point; HYPHAE without clamp connections, forming a conventionally branched hymenium identical to T. violea, basal hyphae thick-walled, 5-9 um wide, (Roberts), SPORES 9-18 x 3-4 um, subcylindric, attenuated and laterally depressed at apiculus, rounded at distal end, oblong bilaterally, slightly curved; PROBASIDIA 12-18 x 9-12 um, obovate to pyriform, epibasidia "finally with ovate bases and subulate or thick and abruptly sterigmate apices"; hyphae 3-7 um wide, repent, branching at right angles, without clamp connections, (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fuscous - violaceous'
SIMILAR  Tulasnella fuscoviolacea is one of number of species that appear to be morphologically identical to Tulasnella violea except for their spores (shorter and rounder in T. violea), (Roberts). Tulasnella pruinosa has shorter spores. Tulasnella eichleriana has much smaller spores. Tulasnella calospora has very long narrow spores. Tulasnella bifrons has clamp connections according to Roberts(2).
SOURCES  Julich(6), Roberts(2), Martin, G.W.(1), Burt(15), Ginns(5)
460
FAMILY  Tulasnellaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tulasnella pinicola  Bres.^  Ann. Mycol. 1: 114. 1903;  Gloeotulasnella pinicola  (Bres.) D.P. Rogers
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include thin to rather thick, waxy-gelatinous-mucous fruitbodies that are colorless, pinkish, grayish, or somewhat olive to lead-colored, the surface waxy and bumpy or even, growth on wood, and microscopic characters including basidia arising from erect hyphae of rather large diameter.^ RANGE ^The distribution includes ON, GA, IA, LA, MN, OH, WY, HI, and Europe including Poland, (Martin, G.W.). It also occurs in NC, NY, TN, and VT, (Ginns). There are collections from BC identified by R. Bandoni at the University of British Columbia.
FRUITING BODY  thin to rather thick; colorless, pinkish, grayish or olivescent to plumbeous, drying to a colorless, yellowish, reddish or dark varnish-like film; "mucous or waxy-mucous, undulate or even"^, (Martin, G.W.), soft-gelatinous or mucous-gelatinous, rather thin; gray to brown; surface undulate or bumpy, (Olive(3)), 0.004-0.01cm thick, indefinite in extent, "on the under surface of an old oak limb where it covered the bark and some old leather-fungi over a considerable area"; sordid gray to purplish gray; "gelatinous, and with an undulate or rugose surface", drying to "a thin, black or very dark gray, rough and often carbonaceous layer", (Olive(5))
HABITAT  bark and barkless wood of coniferous and hardwood species, and on old fruitbodies of tough or woody hymenomycetes^, (Martin, G.W.), Betula nigra (River Birch), Carya sp. (hickory), Cytisus sp. (broom), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tulip-poplar), Mimosa sp., Quercus sp., Quercus rubra (Northern Red Oak), (Ginns), barked and debarked hardwood (oak, tulip poplar, river birch, hickory, and Mimosa), fall to spring, (Olive(3) for GA)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-10 x 4-6 um, nearly round to ovate, white in mass^; PROBASIDIA clavate to clavate-capitate, epibasidia 4 or more, finally ovate with a long cylindric or somewhat subulate [awl-shaped] filament tipped with a distinct sterigma; GLOEOCYSTIDIA lacking; HYPHAE erect, branching, with or without clamp connections, (Martin, G.W.), SPORES (5)6-10(12) x 4-6(8) um, nearly round to ovate; BASIDIA becoming 8-18(30) x (4.5)6-9(12) um, each usually producing 4 epibasidia, 9-15 x 2.5-5 um; HYPHAE 2-7 um wide, erect, branching, thin-walled, (Klett), spores 3.9-5.2 x 5.9-9.1 um, nearly round to somewhat cylindric; basidia arising from erect hyphae of rather large diameter, a helpful character in identification, (Olive(3)), SPORES 5.9-8.4 x 4.5-5.9 um, mostly nearly round to obovate, germinating by repetition; BASIDIA mostly in fascicles, forming a rather compact hymenium, 10.4-17.1 x 8.1-9.6 um, clavate or clavate-capitate, epibasidia (2)4, 8.1-12.6 x 6.3-7.2 um, (Olive(5))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living on pine'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Martin, G.W.(1) (as Gloeotulasnella), Klett(1) (as Gloeotulasnella), Olive(3) (as Gloeotulasnella), Olive(5) (as Gloeotulasnella), Ginns(5)
461
FAMILY  Tulasnellaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tulasnella pruinosa  Bourdot & Galzin^  Bull. Soc. Myc. Fr. 39: 264. 1924
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a waxy fruitbody that is violaceous gray, the margin indistinct, 3) spores measuring 6-7.5 x 3-3.5 um in the type, that are elliptic to oblong, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) tulasnelloid basidia, and 5) hyphae without clamp connections forming a "conventionally branched" hymenium.^ | Roberts(2) regards this as a species allied to Tulasnella violea and Tulasnella eichleriana with intermediate-sized elliptic spores but notes a problem in that the differentiation from Tulasnella pinicola is only the conventional branching in the hymenium in Tulasnella pruinosa (see MICROSCOPIC) versus the clustered branching of Tulasnella pinicola, a condition not easy to determine in the partly collapsed hymenium of the lectotype used. "For the moment, T. pruinosa is retained as distinct, but it may well prove to be no more than a deceptive form of T. pinicola.", (Roberts, with Latin names italicized). RANGE ^Tulasnella pruinosa has been found in WA, ON, PQ, IA, MT, NC, NH, NY, OH, and WI, (Ginns), and France and the United Kingdom, (Roberts). Some herbarium specimens under this name are Tulasnella eichleriana (due to the arbitrary reinterpretation by Rogers (1933) of T. pruinosa as a small-spored species), (Roberts(2)).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], several centimeters across, about 0.002-0.005cm thick, visible to the naked eye, ceraceous [waxy], adnate [firmly attached], context homogeneous; pale grayish; "pruinose, even, not cracked when dry"; margin colored as the rest of the surface, "indistinct, thinning out"; rhizomorphs and hyphal strands absent^, (Julich), resupinate, effused, ceraceous; violaceous gray, (Roberts), "gelatinous-waxy, arachnoid or membranous; white or rosy lilaceous, fading", (Martin)
HABITAT  hardwood without bark, (Martin), Acer sp. (maple), Betula nigra (River Birch), Carpinus caroliniana (American Hornbeam), Castanea sp. (chestnut), Fagus sp. (beech), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), Quercus sp. (oak), Salix sp. (willow), Ulmus sp. (elm), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 6-7.5 x 3.3-3.7 um, elliptic, some slightly curved, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, contents slightly guttulate, with distinct apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, colorless, "clavate when mature, ellipsoid when young", 9-12 x 6-7 um, thin-walled, smooth, basal clamp connection absent, contents homogeneous, epibasidia more or less ellipsoid, guttulate, "rather abruptly narrowed to the subulate sterigmata" (about 5-6 x 1-1.5 um); CYSTIDIA none; HYPHAE 2-4 um wide, loosely arranged throughout, flexuous-cylindric, colorless, "branching from all parts of the hyphae", thin-walled, smooth, clamp connections lacking, contents homogeneous, (Julich), SPORES about 6-7.5 x 3-3.5 um (in the lectotype), elliptic to oblong, "often tapered toward the apiculus, occasionally ventrally depressed"; BASIDIA mostly clavate, 5.5-7 um wide, sterigmata about 4 um across at widest point, spherical to ellipsoid becoming clavate, fusiform, or mitriform; HYPHAE about 2.5-3.5 um wide, without clamp connections, forming a conventionally branched hymenium, ["conventionally branched" meaning "composed of highly branched, short-celled, basidia-bearing hyphae arising from straighter, longer-celled, often thick-walled, basal hyphae running parallel to the substrate", as opposed to "cluster-forming", meaning "clusters of basidia are formed on long-celled, little-branched hyphae, basal hyphae being absent or little differentiated", a condition not established for Pacific Northwest species of Tulasnella], basal hyphae with distinct, refractive walls, (Roberts), SPORES 4.5-6.5 x 3-4 um, long-obovate to oblong; BASIDIA 4-spored, "probasidia obovate-oblong, borne at the tips of short dichotomous branches", 8-12 x 5-7 um; epibasidia "finally elongate-obovate, fusiform or cylindric, with long, fine-subulate sterigmata"; hyphae 3-4.5 um wide, "parallel with substrate in thin specimens", perpendicular when thicker, rather thick walled, without clamp connections, (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pruinose'
SIMILAR  Tulasnella violea has round to broadly elliptic spores that are wider (5.5-7.5 um), (Roberts(2)). Tulasnella eichleriana has smaller, nearly round to pip-shaped or elliptic spores, (Roberts(2)). Tulasnella fuscoviolacea has larger spores measuring (7)8.5-12 x 4-5.5 um (Roberts(2)). Tulasnella calospora has very long, narrow spores. Tulasnella bifrons has clamp connections according to Roberts(2).
SOURCES  Roberts(2), Julich(6), Martin, G.W.(1), Ginns(5)
462
FAMILY  Tulasnellaceae, Order Cantharellales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tulasnella violea  (Quel.) Bourdot & Galzin^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 25: 32. 1909;  == Hypochnus violeus  Quel.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood or bark, also on old shelf polypores and on lichens, 2) a waxy to subgelatinous fruitbody that is violaceous gray (occasionally purple or pink), smooth to slightly bumpy, the margin irregular, distinctly bounded to thin and translucent, 3) spores measuring 5.5-9 x 5.5-7.5 um, round to broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) tulasnelloid basidia, and 5) hyphae without clamp connections forming a "conventionally branched" hymenium.^ RANGE ^ Tulasnella violea has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NS, ON, AZ, CO, CT, GA, IA, IL, MA, ME, MO, NC, NH, NM, NY, OH, PA, SC, VT, and WI, (Ginns). It is widespread in Europe, and also occurs in Colombia and Tahiti, (Olive). Collections were examined from France, Germany, Majorca, Norway, and the United Kingdom, (Roberts). It has been found in Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], ceraceous [waxy] to subgelatinous, often substantial and conspicuous; violaceous gray, occasionally purple or pink^, (Roberts), a patch one to several centimeters in extent, attached firmly, filmy wax-like to farinose [mealy]; "lilac-violet when moist, more pink when dry"; "smooth to slightly and irregularly tuberculate"; "margin irregular, distinctly bounded to thin and translucent", (Breitenbach)
HABITAT  on "branches of conifers and hardwoods with and without bark and lying on the ground, as well as on old polypores"; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), dead wood, bark, lichens, old shelf polypores, (Martin)^, Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Holodiscus discolor (Ocean-spray), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Nyssa (tupelo), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow); bark; very rotten wood, limb; fallen branches, old polypores, (Ginns) 
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 5.5-9 x 5.5-7.5 um, mostly round to broadly elliptic^; BASIDIA mostly clavate, 5-9 um wide, sterigmata spherical or ellipsoid "becoming clavate, fusiform, or mitriform", variously extending up to 35 um long; HYPHAE 3-5(7) um wide, without clamp connections, "forming a conventionally branched, compact hymenium", ["conventionally branched" meaning "composed of highly branched, short-celled, basidia-bearing hyphae arising from straighter, longer-celled, often thick-walled, basal hyphae running parallel to the substrate", as opposed to "cluster forming", meaning "clusters of basidia are formed on long-celled, little-branched hyphae, basal hyphae being absent or little differentiated", a condition not established for Pacific Northwest species of Tulasnella], subhymenial hyphae "normally short-celled and rather swollen", basal hyphae "longer, straighter, thick-walled, occasionally dextrinoid", (Roberts), SPORES 6-8 x 5-6.5 um, oval to nearly round, smooth, colorless, some with droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, hypobasidia 10-20 x 5-8 um, oval to clavate, epibasidia oval to pyriform [pear-shaped]; CYSTIDIA not seen; hyphae 3-4 um wide, septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), spores pink in mass (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'violet'
SIMILAR  Tulasnella fuscoviolacea is one of a number of species that appear to be morphologically identical to T. violea except for their spores (longer and narrower in T. fuscoviolacea), (Roberts). Tulasnella eichleriana is similar enough that it is listed as a synonym of Tulasnella violea by Martin, but Roberts(2) disagrees strongly because the microscopic dimensions are so different [size of spores for instance]. Tulasnella pruinosa has narrower spores. Tulasnella bifrons has clamp connections according to Roberts(2).
SOURCES  Roberts(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Olive(1), Martin, G.W.(1), Buczacki(1)*
463
FAMILY  Atheliaceae, Order Atheliales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tylospora asterophora  (Bonord.) Donk^  Taxon 9: 220. 1960;  == Hypochnus asterophora  Bonord.;  Tylosperma asterophorum  (Bonord.) Donk.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Tylospora asterophora is identified easily under the microscope by its triangular spores. Features include 1) resupinate growth on well decayed wood, or on debris on the ground, 2) a whitish fruitbody that is smooth or slightly blistery, with a soft cottony consistency, the margin undifferentiated or slightly filamentous, 3) "triangular" spores that are inamyloid and colorless, and 4) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections and rough with granules and short spines.^ RANGE ^Tylospora asterophora has been found in OR, ON, and PQ, (Ginns), Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and the USSR, (Julich), and Switzerland and Asia, (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, thin to moderately thick; whitish or in the herbarium changing to yellowish cream; smooth or slightly blistery; "margin indifferent" [? undifferentiated]^, (Hjortstam), resupinate, attached loosely to substrate, forming very thin patches several centimeters across, surface arachnoid [cobwebby], "floccose to open-membranous", consistency "cottony, soft, easily wiped off"; white; "margin slightly filamentous", (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  mostly on well decayed wood but found on all kinds of debris on the ground, (Hjortstam), on the underside of very rotten conifer branches lying on the ground and overgrown with moss, according to the literature also on dead leaves, mosses and bare earth; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), on soil, conifer needle litter and other debris in plantations, especially with Picea (spruce) "but probably only on acidic sites", also with Sphagnum in wet woodland, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES about 4.5-5.5 x 4-4.5 um, triangular [illustrated with the apices of the "triangle" rounded and the sides of the triangle curved-indented, with what appears to be the apiculus in the middle of one of the sides, in profile the spore elliptic], walls slightly thickened, slightly cyanophilic^; BASIDIA clavate, 20-25 x 4.5-5.5 um, normally 4-spored; HYPHAE monomitic, "basal hyphae mostly with strong encrustations and with walls thickened, frequently branched, branching at right angles", 3.5-4(5) um wide, "subhymenial hyphae thin-walled, usually smooth and of about the same width", all septa with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 4.5-6 um in diameter, stellate-triangular, with 3 distinct tubercles, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 2-4-spored, 18-25 x 4-6 um, narrowly clavate, with indistinct clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-4 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, rough with fine granules to spinose with short pointed spines, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing stars'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Julich(3) (in German), Buczacki(1)*
464
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Vararia investiens  (Schwein.) P. Karst.^  Kritisk Ofversigt Finlands Basidsvampar 3: 32. 1898;  == Radulum investiens  Schwein.;  Corticium investiens  (Schwein.) Bres.;  Corticium alutarium  Berk. & M.A. Curtis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on fallen wood, 2) a membranaceous fruitbody that is cream to yellow or ochraceous, becoming darker when old, the surface smooth to warted, the margin and subiculum colored as the rest of the surface to bright yellow, the margin abrupt or rhizomorphic, 3) spores (of different sizes by different authors) that are fusiform, smooth, inamyloid with an amyloid plage, and colorless, 4) dichohyphidia (dichophyses) branching with wide angles, the branches straight, branching several times with ultimate branches bearing 2-3 clusters of short dichotomous branches with acute tips, the dichohyphidia golden yellow, slightly to distinctly dextrinoid, 5) gloeocystidia that are subcylindric to fusiform, sulfo-positive or sulfo-negative, and 6) generative hyphae with clamp connections, dextrinoid skeletal hyphae branched and present in the subiculum.^ RANGE ^Vararia investiens has been found in WA, ID, NB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, CO, CT, DC, IA, IN, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MT, NC, NH, NY, PA, RI, VT, WI, and WY, (Ginns), as well as Jamaica, Puerto Rico, and St. Kitts, (Welden).
FRUITING BODY  membranaceous, not separable, up to 0.06cm thick; cream to yellowish or ochraceous, becoming darker when old; even; margin and subiculum bright yellow^, (Stalpers), effused; cream to pale ochraceous or bright yellow; even to warted, (Julich), "effused and spreading over the substrate", "powdery-membranous to membranous", parts easily removed from substrate; between ivory and straw; margin colored as the rest of the surface, "determinate, abrupt or tending to rhizomorphy or frankly rhizomorphic", (Welden), resupinate; light buff to bright yellow, (Martin)
HABITAT  on fallen wood^ (Welden); fallen twigs and branches; logs; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Carya (hickory), Larix (larch), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Paxistima myrsinites (Falsebox), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Rhododendron, Tsuga (hemlock); associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8-11.5 x 3-4 um, fusoid, with amyloid suprahilar plage^; BASIDIA 30-50 x 4-7 um, utriform; DICHOHYPHIDIA branching under wide angle, with straight, stiff branches; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 25-80 x 4-10 um, subcylindric to fusiform, sulfo-positive, rarely with a schizopapilla; HYPHAE generative 1.5-5 um wide, with clamp connections; skeletal hyphae present in subiculum, 0.5-1.5 um wide, branched, dextrinoid, (Stalpers), SPORES 8-11(12) x 2.7-4.5 um, "fusiform, widest in the middle, acute or rarely filiform at the ends", "with amyloid suprahilar plage"; BASIDIA 24-55 x 3.5-6.5 um; GLOEOCYSTIDIA 40-80 x 4-8 um, subcylindric to fusoid; HYPHAE 2-2.5 um, clamp connections present, (Julich who describes European material and notes that American authors give deviating spore dimensions, e.g. Welden(2) below, and Gilbertson gives 7-8.5 x 3-3.5 um), SPORES 13-14(21) x 3.5-4.5 um, tapering to acute apices, the tip often separated from the main spore body by a septum and often collapsed, spore smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with a thin episporium; BASIDIA 4-spored, up to 55 um long, about 5 um wide at base, 3 um wide at neck, sterigmata 4 um long and fragile; DICHOPHYSES golden yellow, main branches about 2-3 um wide, "branching several times with ultimate branches bearing 2-3 clusters of short dichotomous branches with acute tips", "those in or near the surface with shorter internodes but not bushy"; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA long, cylindric, sulfobenzaldehyde negative; context thin; HYPHAE thin-walled, branching with clamp connections, (Welden), SPORES 7-8.5 x 3-3.5 um, fusiform, swollen in the middle and tapered to both ends, inamyloid, often with sterigma remaining attached; DICHOHYPHIDIA loosely branched, slightly to distinctly dextrinoid; GLOEOCYSTIDIA cylindric, thin-walled, negative in sulfuric benzaldehyde; GENERATIVE HYPHAE with clamp connections, (Martin)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Vararia racemosa has similar dichophyses but has smaller spores, (Welden). V. racemosa lacks clamp connections (Julich). Vararia phyllophila has generally narrower spores but not significantly so, and may be distinguished by its delicate dichophyses, its lack of clamp connections, and its pseudocystidia often filled with yellowish resinous material, (Welden).
SOURCES  Welden(2), Stalpers(2), Julich(5), Martin, K.J.(3), Ginns(5)
465
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Vararia phyllophila  (Massee) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.^  Farlowia 1: 323. 1943;  == Peniophora phyllophila  Massee
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on fallen wood, 2) a floccose-membranous, whitish to pale ochraceous fruitbody with a minutely powdery surface, the margin concolorous or whitish, and indistinct, 3) spores (different sizes by different authors) that are narrowly fusoid, smooth, and inamyloid, 4) dextrinoid dichohyphidia that are delicate with finely curved acute tips, 5) gloeocystidia that are abundant, irregularly clavate, and often filled with yellowish resin-like material, and 6) hyphae that are branching, without clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Vararia phyllophila has been found in ID, FL, NM, and SC, (Ginns). It has been reported from WA (Luther(1) who also mentions a record from Panama).
FRUITING BODY  spreading, easily separated from substrate, "floccose to floccose-membranous"; cream; surface minutely powdery; margin thinning, colored as the rest of the surface or whitish, "indeterminate, powdery"; context thin^, (Welden), effused; whitish to pale ochraceous; even, (Julich)
HABITAT  on fallen hardwood and conifer wood^, (Welden), on Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Populus sp., Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Quercus sp. (oak); on dried leaves; on fallen leaves and limbs; on wood on ground, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 11-15(22) x 3-3.5 um, lunate-attenuate, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, with or without droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, up to 28 um long, 5-6 um wide at base and about 4 um wide at apex, sterigmata about 4 um long; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA irregularly clavate, often filled with yellowish resin-like material; DICHOPHYSES arising from thin-walled hyphae, delicate, with finely curving acute tips, main branches about 1-2 um wide, presumably (by genus definition) dextrinoid; HYPHAE about 3 um wide, colorless, thin-walled (some with walls up to 1 um thick), branching, simple-septate; "other hyphae apparently non-septate, filled with yellowish resinous material, giving rise to pseudocystidia", (Welden), SPORES 16-22 x 2.5-3.5 um, narrowly fusoid; BASIDIA 20-30 x 4-5 um; DICHOHYPHIDIA thin, main branch up to 2 um wide, "ultimate branches very thin and slender"; GLOEOCYSTIDIA abundant, 13-25 x 4-5.5 um; HYPHAE 2-2.5 um wide, clamp connections absent, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'liking leaves'
SIMILAR  Vararia investiens has generally wider spores but not significantly so, and may be distinguished by its less delicate dichophyses, its clamp connections, and different pseudocystidia, (Welden). Vararia racemosa has smaller spores.
SOURCES  Welden(2), Julich(5), Ginns(5), Luther(1)
466
FAMILY  Lachnocladiaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Vararia racemosa  (Burt) D.P. Rogers & H.S. Jacks.^  Farlowia 1: 299. 1943;  == Corticium racemosum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on bark and wood of decaying logs, or on slash, 2) a fruitbody that is cream to pale ochraceous, smooth, and firmly attached, the margin indistinct, 3) spores that are cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) abundant dextrinoid dichohyphidia, in small, densely branched clusters (with the ultimate branches short), 5) gloeocystidia that are broadly cylindric (often swollen in the middle), with thickened walls thinning out at the apex, (gloeocystidia not seen by Burt), 6) hyphae without clamp connections (Julich, Martin), or with clamp connections (Welden).^ RANGE ^Vararia racemosa has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, AZ, CO, MT, and UT, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  2-12cm long, 1-4cm wide, broadly effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached], not separable; drying cream buff; even, becoming transversely cracked in the central parts; margin thinning out, indeterminate, colored as the rest of the surface^, (Burt), effused [spread out], cream to pale ochraceous; even, (Julich), resupinate; pale buff; smooth, (Martin)
HABITAT  on bark and wood of decaying logs; July to September^, (Burt), on Abies (fir), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar); decaying wood and bark; slash; logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (5)6-8 x 2-3 um, cylindric^; BASIDIA 25-30 x 3.5-4 um; DICHOHYPHIDIA with ultimate branches short; GLOEOCYSTIDIA up to 10 um wide, broadly cylindric (often swollen in the middle), with thickened walls, mucronate; HYPHAE 2-3 um wide, (Julich), SPORES 5-7 x 2-2.5 um, cylindric; DICHOHYPHIDIA abundant, in small, densely branched clusters, strongly dextrinoid; CYSTIDIA thick-walled, "often mucronate, with the wall thinning out at the narrowed apex"; GENERATIVE HYPHAE simple-septate; (Martin), SPORES 7-8 x 2-3 um, averaging 7.6 x 2.3 um, (also given as 6.5-8 x 2-3 um), cylindric, inamyloid; BASIDIA 4-spored, reaching about 30 x 4 um, sterigmata straight, delicate; DICHOPHYSES not especially distinctive; PSEUDOCYSTIDIA present; HYPHAE of context colorless, "thin-walled, branching, sometimes forming a pseudoparenchyma near the substrate, and bearing clamp-connections", (Welden), SPORES 4-6 x 2-3 um, flattened on one side, smooth, colorless; PARAPHYSES "in hymenial surface with tips branched sometimes racemosely, sometimes in antler-shaped manner, often irregularly", these branches about 0.5 um wide; GLOEOCYSTIDIA none; fruitbody in section 70-140 um thick, colored cream-buff, composed of HYPHAE 2-2.5 um wide, very densely arranged, erect, branching and interwoven, (Burt)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'full of clusters', Burt refers to the paraphyses "with tips branched sometimes racemosely"
SIMILAR  Vararia investiens has clamp connections (Julich). Vararia phyllophila has larger spores.
SOURCES  Burt(1) (as Corticium racemosum), Julich(5), Martin, K.J.(3), Welden(2), Ginns(5)
467
FAMILY  Gloeophyllaceae, Order Gloeophyllales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Veluticeps abietina  (Pers.) Hjortstam & Telleria^  Mycotaxon 37: 54. 1990;  == Thelephora abietina  Pers.;  Stereum abietinum  (Pers.) Fr.;  Columnocystis abietina  (Pers.) Pouzar;  Hymenochaete abnormis  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood (or may bend out to form a cap), 2) a cap that when present is brown-black, zoned, and tomentose, and slopes downward at an acute angle rather than at right angle, 3) a spore-bearing surface that is grayish, yellowish, brownish, brownish orange, or bluish to lilac and smooth to tuberculate or wrinkled, often with a whitish bloom, 4) a black reaction of the spore-bearing surface to KOH, 5) spores that are narrowly elliptic to subcylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless or yellowish, 6) cystidia of 2 types: a) projecting, cylindric to narrowly clavate, thin-walled to thick-walled, smooth or finely encrusted, light-colored apically and yellowish to brownish toward the base (or pale at first but brown when old), b) enclosed, smaller, narrowly clavate to cylindric, brown, thick-walled and septate without clamp connections, smooth or lightly encrusted, and 7) a hyphal system referred to as monomitic or as dimitic, with 5 layers: a) tomentum, b) black cutis, c) subiculum, d) subhymenium, and e) hymenium, the subicular hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Veluticeps abietina has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, MB, NF, NS, NT, ON, PQ, YT, AK, AZ, CA, CO, MI, MT, NH, NY, PA, TN, UT, VT, WI, and WY, (Ginns, who notes that because Veluticeps fimbriata was separated later, some of the western North America records may correspond to that species instead); North Europe including Sweden (Eriksson); and MB, NF, NS, NT, ON, YT, AK, CO, MI, NH, NY, UT, Austria, Czech Republic, Finland, France, Norway, Poland, Sweden, Croatia, USSR, (Nakasone).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate or effuso-reflexed [bent outward to form a cap], forming patches several centimeters to decimeters across, 0.05-0.2cm thick, tightly attached, corky, tough; cap forms on vertical substrate and grows conspicuously obliquely downward (at an acute angle), upper cap surface brown to brown-black, zoned, and tomentose; spore-bearing area "gray-blue to gray-lilac when fresh, gray-brown to ocherish when dry", "tuberculate-undulating, smooth, dull, pruinose"; flesh multilayered; underside of fruiting body with brown felty tomentum^, (Breitenbach), perennial, resupinate or with a cap, 0.1-0.2cm thick, first orbiculate [circular] then coalescing, "margin light brown, fibrillose"; cap surface dark brown, with more or less zonate tomentum, spore bearing area "dark violaceous blue when wet, paler when dry"; in section several layers can be seen under microscope or with a lens: 1) brown tomentum, 2) brown cutis (visible even when resupinate), 3) intermediate layer, 4) spore-bearing surface, (Eriksson), up to 0.2cm thick, orbicular [circular] at first, then confluent, up to 10cm x 5cm, resupinate, or effused-reflexed [bending outward to form a cap], may be imbricate [shingled], spongy-coriaceous [spongy-leathery], annual or perennial; cap when developed narrow, projecting 0.3-2cm, hard, brittle; dark brown to nearly black, grooved; exposed spore-bearing surface is pale yellow, yellowish-white to yellowish gray, brownish orange to grayish brown, or brownish gray, rarely dull violet, turning black in KOH; smooth to tuberculate or rugose [wrinkled], felty, velvety, often cracked, often with a whitish bloom; sterile margin up to 0.25cm wide, entire to crenate [scalloped], loosely attached and often pulling away, grayish orange to brown, without a bloom; flesh brown, sometimes with alternating dark and light layers, (Nakasone)
HABITAT  Abies (fir), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); on bark; wood and logs; debarked log; fence timber; associated with a brown rot^, (Ginns), on wood and bark of coniferous logs and stumps, especially Abies and Picea; associated with a brown rot, (Nakasone), on "logs and branches of conifers, in North Europe usually on Picea abies", (Eriksson, Latin name italicized), on stumps and the ends of fallen trunks of Picea (spruce), more rarely on branches, according to literature also on Abies (fir); throughout the year, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 9-12.5 x (3.5)4-4.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-75 x 6-8 um, cylindric-clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of two types: 1) projecting beyond the hymenium, up to nearly 200 um long and 6-12 um wide, arising from deeper tissues, "thick-walled, finely incrusted, light-colored apically and brownish toward the base", 2) enclosed by the hymenium 40-100 x 3.5-9 um, brown, thick-walled and septate without clamp connections; HYPHAE dimitic: generative hyphae 1.5-3 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 3-5 um wide, very thick-walled, brown, (Breitenbach), |SPORES 9-13 x 4-5 um, narrowly elliptic to subcylindric or even slightly allantoid [curved], smooth, inamyloid, colorless or yellowish, thin-walled, when old slightly thick-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-70 x 5-6 um, narrowly clavate, thin-walled, walls becoming slightly thickened when old; CYSTIDIA of two types: projecting and enclosed, 1) the projecting cystidia 150-200 x 8-12 um, "starting deep in intermediate layer", very thick-walled and generally only slightly pigmented (yellow to light brown), apically almost colorless, "externally with a generally thin and delicate crystalline crust, dissolving in Melzer's reagent and in lactic acid", 2) enclosed cystidia 50-100 x 3-6 um, "thickwalled and strongly pigmented, often with several simple adventitious septa", starting from the skeletal hyphae in the intermediate layer, this type of cystidia may also develop from thin-walled, slightly encrusted basidia-like cystidioles in the hymenium; HYPHAE dimitic: generative hyphae 2-3.5 um wide, thin-walled, colorless, with clamp connections at septa from where branching occurs, skeletal hyphae 2.5-4(5) um, thick-walled, dark brown, with very few simple septa, (Eriksson), |SPORES 10.7-13 x (4)4.3-4.8(5) um, cylindric to narrowly elliptic (adaxial side often straight), smooth, inamyloid, colorless, slightly thick-walled; BASIDIA 4-spored, 60-90(108) x 5-7(8.5) um, tapering to 2.5-3.5 um at base, thin-walled, colorless, (occasionally slightly thick-walled and pale yellow toward base), with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA of two types: hymenial and tramal - 1) hymenial cystidia 90-300 x 7-12 um, tapering to 2.5-4 um at base, protruding up to 100 um, arising from subiculum and hymenium, cylindric to narrowly clavate, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled at apex, thickening at mid-section (up to 3 um), then thinner toward base, smooth or encrusted with a thin crystalline coating, colorless or pale yellow at first but brown when old, with basal clamp connection, 2) tramal cystidia: up to 160 um long, 4-5.5(8) um at widest, narrowing to 2-3 um at base, "typically embedded in subiculum, subhymenium and lower hymenium but occasionally protruding slightly beyond the hymenium", narrowly clavate to cylindric, slight thick-walled to thick-walled throughout, "often with adventitious septa, sometimes constricted slightly, yellowish brown throughout, occasionally smooth but more often lightly encrusted with granular crystalline materials"; HYPHIDIA inconspicuous and scarce in hymenium, up to 70 um long, 3-5 um wide, thin-walled, with basal clamp connection, sometimes with adventitious septa, occasionally branched; HYPHAE monomitic - 5 distinct layers may be present: 1) abhymenial tomentum 70-400 um thick, sometimes absent, of hyphae 3-4.5 um wide, thick-walled, yellowish brown, with rare clamp connections and simple septa, sparsely branched, 2) black cutis 30-150 um thick, of more or less parallel, horizontally arranged hyphae, 3) subiculum 150-450 um thick, of horizontally arranged agglutinated hyphae, of two types a) 2.5-3.5 um wide, thin-walled, colorless, nodose-septate [septa with clamp connections], frequently branched, b) 2.5-4 um wide, thick-walled, yellowish brown, nodose-septate, rarely branched, sometimes differentiating into tramal cystidia that are found scattered but often curve toward hymenium to produce a dense palisade of vertical cystidia at subiculum-subhymenium border, 4) subhymenium up to 1000 um thick, sometimes absent, of hyphae 2-3.5 um wide, vertically arranged, thin-walled, nodose-septate (as well as collapsed hymenial elements and embedded cystidia), 5) hymenial layer up to 130 um thick, (Nakasone)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to Abies [fir]'
SIMILAR  Veluticeps fimbriata has spores 11.9-15.5 x 4.7-5.6(6) um, - measure mature thin-walled spores with homogeneous contents, (Nakasone). Veluticeps ambigua has subicular hyphae without clamp connections, (Nakasone). Amylostereum chailletii is similar but caps are always directed at close to a right angle rather than being directed downward, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Eriksson(2) (as Columnocystis), Breitenbach(2)* (as Columnocystis), Nakasone(2), Ginns(5)
468
FAMILY  Gloeophyllaceae, Order Gloeophyllales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Veluticeps ambigua  (Peck) Hjortstam & Telleria^  Mycotaxon 37: 54. 1990;  == Stereum ambiguum  Peck;  Columnocystis ambigua  (Peck) Pouzar
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, or bending out on vertical surfaces to form a slight cap 2) when present a cap that is narrow, and white to grayish orange or yellowish brown, 3) a spore-bearing surface that is yellowish brown to red-brown or light brown to dark brown, smooth to tuberculate, velvety from cystidia, and spongy-leathery in consistency, the margin entire to fibrillose, often detached and pulling away from the substrate, 4) a black reaction of the spore-bearing surface to KOH, 5) spores that are cylindric-elliptic to narrowly fusoid, smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic, and colorless to yellowish, 6) cystidia of 2 types: a) hymenial cystidia that are embedded or projecting up to 125 um, cylindric to narrowly clavate, and smooth or encrusted with crystals, and b) tramal cystidia that are embedded, cylindric, and smooth, often forming a vertical palisade at the subiculum-subhymenium interface, 7) hyphidia that are cylindric to narrowly clavate, smooth, and colorless to yellow brown, with frequent adventitious septa, and 8) hyphae monomitic without clamp connections, in 3 layers: subiculum, subhymenium and hymenium.^ RANGE ^It has been found in ID, ON, ME, MT, NC, NH, NY, PA, TN, and VT, (Ginns), as well as east-central Europe and eastern USSR (Nakasone).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate or bending outward to form a slight cap when wood is vertically oriented, 8-10cm x 6-8cm, 0.02-0.3cm thick, attached closely to wood "and at most somewhat lifted at margin", "firm and brittle but not tough, annual to perennial"; the exposed spore-bearing surface is dark ocher to umber-brown or red-brown and finely velvety^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, 0.1-0.2(0.3)cm thick, orbicular [circular] becoming confluent up to 15cm x 5cm, loosely attached to wood, spongy-coriaceous [spongy-leathery], perennial; yellowish brown, light brown to brown or dark brown, turning black in KOH; smooth to tuberculate, velvety from projecting cystidia, developing deep cracks; sterile margin 0.1-0.2cm wide, "entire to fibrillose, loosely adherent, often detached and pulling away from substrate, slightly reflexed, white to grayish orange" or yellowish brown; flesh golden brown, (Nakasone)
HABITAT  on conifer wood, especially Picea [spruce] and Abies [fir]^, (Nakasone); Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock); bark; moss-covered wood; cut wood; butt; log; associated with a brown rot, (Ginns), on rotten stumps of Picea (spruce) and according to literature also on rotten spruce beams, (Breitenbach)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 12-14.5 x 3.8-4.2 um, cylindric-elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless to yellowish^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 50-60 x 4-5 um, cylindric-clavate; CYSTIDIA 100-260 x 7-12 um, "with rounded tips, brownish, sometimes incrusted with coarse crystals"; HYPHAE dimitic, generative hyphae 2-4 um wide, septa without clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 3-5 um wide, thick-walled, brown, (Breitenbach), SPORES 12-16(21) x (3)3.5-4(5) um, cylindric to narrowly fusoid, flattened on adaxial side, inamyloid, acyanophilic, thin-walled and colorless at first, becoming slightly thick-walled and dark yellowish brown when old; BASIDIA 4-spored, 70-120 x 5-8 um, narrowing to 2-3 um wide at base; thin-walled and colorless at first, walls slightly thickening and turning yellowish brown toward base, "simple-septate at base, sometimes with adventitious septa", sterigmata 4-8 x 1.5-2 um; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) hymenial cystidia 150-250 x 8-14 um, narrowing to 2.5-3.5 um wide at base, embedded or projecting up to 125 um, arising from subiculum or subhymenium, cylindric to narrowly clavate, at apex thin-walled to slightly thick-walled and with colorless to pale yellow walls, "becoming thick-walled and walls darkening to yellowish brown toward the base", (later turning entirely reddish brown when embedded in subhymenium), "walls up to 6 um wide, simple-septate at base, with scattered constrictions, infrequently developing adventitious septa, smooth or encrusted with tightly adherent hyaline crystals", 2) tramal cystidia up to 200 um long x 3-4 um wide, "embedded in subiculum and subhymenium, arising from subiculum and subhymenium, often forming a vertical palisade of cystidia at subiculum-subhymenium interface", cylindric, smooth, slightly thick-walled to thick-walled throughout, yellowish brown, often with adventitious septa; HYPHIDIA 30-90 x 3-7 um, "arising from hymenium but becoming embedded as subhymenium thickens", cylindric to narrowly clavate, smooth, slightly thick-walled to thick-walled, walls to 2 um thick, colorless to pale yellow at first then yellowish brown when old, "simple-septate at base, with frequent adventitious septa"; HYPHAE monomitic with three layers 1) subiculum 90-250 um thick, of horizontally arranged hyphae 2-4.5 um wide, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, colorless to pale yellow, "simple-septate, freely branching and giving rise to sclerified hyphae", these 2-5 um wide, thick-walled with walls up to 2 um thick, yellowish brown to reddish brown, "with rare simple septa", "sparsely branched, and gradually turning toward the subhymenium" and ending in upper subiculum as a sparse or dense palisade of tramal cystidia, 2) subhymenium up to 600 um thick, thickening, "with one or more layers of vertically arranged, thin-walled hyphae, collapsed basidia, hyphidia, and cystidia", 3) hymenial layer 70-90 um thick, "of basidia, cystidia and hyphidia", (Nakasone)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'changeable, doubtful'
SIMILAR  Veluticeps abietina and Veluticeps fimbriata have generative hyphae that are nodose-septate rather than simple-septate, (Nakasone).
SOURCES  Nakasone(2), Breitenbach(2)* (as Columnocystis), Burt(2) (as Stereum), Ginns(5)
469
FAMILY  Gloeophyllaceae, Order Gloeophyllales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Veluticeps fimbriata  (Ellis & Everh.) Nakasone^  Mycologia 82: 634. 1990;  == Hymenochaete fimbriata  Ellis & Everh.;  Hymenochaete rugispora  Ellis & Everh.;  Stereum rugisporum  (Ellis & Everh.) Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on conifer wood, or bending out from a resupinate surface to form a cap, or predominantly shelf-like, 2) if present a cap that is brown to grayish brown, zoned, and felty, 3) a spore-bearing surface that is grayish, grayish brown, brownish or brownish orange, and velvety, often with a whitish bloom, smooth to warted or wrinkled, 4) a black reaction of the spore-bearing surface to KOH, 5) spores that are elliptic to cylindric, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless to pale yellow, 6) cystidia of 2 types: a) hymenial cystidia (projecting beyond hymenium but eventually embedded) that are cylindric to narrowly clavate, colorless to pale yellow at the apex, darkening to yellowish brown toward the base, becoming entirely dark brown when embedded, smooth or encrusted with colorless granular material, and b) tramal cystidia that are small, embedded in the subhymenium and the lower hymenium, but occasionally projecting beyond hymenium, clavate to cylindric, often with adventitious septa, sometimes constricted slightly and occasionally monilioid in part, yellowish brown throughout, and smooth or encrusted with granular material, 7) hyphidia that are rare and inconspicuous, cylindric to narrowly clavate, colorless to pale yellow, often with adventitious septa, and 8) a monomitic hyphal system - 5 layers may be present: a) tomentum, composed of 2 types of generative hyphae, b) a dense nearly black cutis, c) a subiculum, horizontally arranged and agglutinated hyphae of two types with clamp connections, the first thin-walled and freely branched, and the second thick-walled and rarely branched, this second type giving rise to tramal cystidia that curve toward hymenium to form a dense palisade, d) subhymenium sometimes absent in thin specimens, with one or several layers of vertically arranged hyphae with clamp connections, collapsed hymenial elements and cystidia, some specimens with clusters of agglutinated spores, and e) the hymenial layer^ |Veluticeps fimbriata is common (Nakasone). RANGE ^Veluticeps fimbriata has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AK, AZ, CA, CO, and WY, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  perennial, consistency spongy-coriaceous [spongy-leathery], context brown, sometimes with dark brown and pale brown layers; fruitbody takes three forms: resupinate, effuso-reflexed, and applanate, 1) when resupinate, orbicular [circular] at first, coalescing, to become 0.5-12cm x 5cm or larger, 0.04-0.2cm thick; resupinate spore-bearing surface grayish brown to gray, brownish orange, or light brown, bruised areas turning dark brown, turning black in KOH; "smooth, wrinkled or warted, often cracked", velvety from cystidia, often with a pale white bloom; sterile margin 0.05-0.3cm wide, darker than hymenium, golden brown, light brown or brown, uneven and fimbriate [fringed] to crenate [scalloped] and smooth, lacking a bloom, sometimes closely attached but often loosely attached and pulling away from wood; 2) in effuso-reflexed forms [bent outwards from a resupinate form to make a narrow cap] 0.03-0.3cm thick, often oblong to linear, commonly 1.5-10 x 1-4cm but sometimes larger, becoming imbricate [shingled], spore-bearing surface grayish orange, light brown to brownish gray or brown, sometimes with a whitish bloom, "smooth to warted, slightly to extensively cracked", margins "crenate and smooth, sterile", pale yellow to brown, loosely attached to substrate and pulling away, the cap part projecting 0.3-0.7cm with the upper surface light brown to brown, felty; 3) when applanate [predominantly projecting out from the substrate], 0.1-0.4cm thick, projecting up to 3cm, "imbricate, hard and brittle", spore bearing surface as described for resupinate or effuso-reflexed forms, "margins often lobed and occasionally turning upward, sterile", upper surface of cap grayish brown or brown, (sometimes bleached), zonate, felty, sulcate^, (Nakasone)
HABITAT  on barkless coniferous logs, especially Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce); associated with a brown rot^, (Nakasone); Abies, Larix (larch), Picea, Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 11.9-15.5 x 4.7-5.6(6) um, (averaging 12.6 x 5.0 um in coastal states and provinces, 14.5 x 5.3 um in inland states and provinces), elliptic to cylindric (adaxial side straight to convex), smooth, inamyloid, slightly thick-walled, colorless or occasionally pale yellow, often embedded in the hymenium^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (66)85-100(130) x 5-8(10) um, narrowly clavate, narrower at base (2-3.5 um wide), thin-walled and colorless throughout or thin-walled and colorless at apex then becoming slightly thick-walled and pale yellow toward base, occasionally with adventitious septa, basal clamp connection present; CYSTIDIA of two types: hymenial and tramal, a) hymenial cystidia 145-350 x (3.5)5.5-7.5(10), tapering to 3-3.5 um wide at base, extending 35-80 um beyond hymenium but eventually embedded in specimens with thickening subhymenia, "arising from subhymenium and upper subiculum", cylindric to narrowly clavate, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled at apex, thicker-walled at mid-section and thinning toward base, walls up to 2-3 um thick, colorless to pale yellow at apex, darkening to yellowish brown toward base, becoming entirely dark brown when embedded, smooth or encrusted with colorless granular material, b) tramal cystidia small, arising from subiculum and subhymenium, embedded in subhymenium and lower hymenium, but occasionally projecting up to 30 um beyond hymenium, up to 180 um long and (4)6-10 um wide, tapering to 3-3.5 um at base, clavate to cylindric, "often with adventitious septa, sometimes constricted slightly and occasionally monilioid in part", slightly thick-walled or thick-walled, yellowish brown throughout, smooth or encrusted with granular material; HYPHIDIA rare and inconspicuous, up to 80 um long, 4-5 um wide, cylindric to narrowly clavate, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, colorless to pale yellow, often with adventitious septa, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic: 5 layers may be present - 1) abhymenial tomentum (may be absent in some specimens), 180-200 um thick composed of 2 types of generative hyphae: a) (2)3.5-7 um wide, colorless or yellowish brown "with scattered clamp connections and adventitious septa, rarely branched", b) 1.5-3 um, sclerified, slightly thick-walled to thick-walled, "with rare clamp connections and scattered adventitious septa", 2) a dense nearly black cutis 20-150 um thick, 3) subiculum 150-800 um thick, of horizontally arranged and agglutinated hyphae of two types: a) 2-3 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, nodose-septate, freely branched, b) 3-6.5 um wide, thick-walled, yellowish brown, nodose-septate, rarely branched, this second type giving rise to tramal cystidia that curve toward hymenium to form dense palisade, 4) subhymenium up to 450 um thick, "sometimes absent in thin specimens", with one or several layers of "vertically arranged, thin-walled, nodose-septate hyphae", collapsed hymenial elements and thick-walled, yellowish brown tramal and hymenial cystidia, some specimens with clusters of agglutinated spores, 5) hymenial layer 100-130 um thick, (Nakasone)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fringed'
SIMILAR  Veluticeps abietina has spores 10.7-13 x 4(4.3)-4.8(5) um, (measure mature thin-walled spores with homogeneous contents), (Nakasone); Veluticeps ambigua lacks clamp connections on the generative hyphae, (Nakasone).
SOURCES  Nakasone(2), Ginns(5), Desjardin(6)*
470
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Waitea circinata  Warcup & P.H.B. Talbot^  Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc.  45(4): 503. 1962
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Waitea circinata causes brown patch disease of turfgrasses, sclerotial rot of Zea mays, sheath spot and root rot of Oryza and other grasses and grains, and damping-off of pine seedlings, (Ginns). It is unlikely to be encountered casually outside the context of these plant diseases: the pinkish orange sclerotia up to 0.2cm in diameter usually lie free in the soil but occasionally are found on decomposing roots. Mycelial fruitings also occur on soil. (Warcup).^ RANGE ^Waitea circinata has been found in ID, SK, AR, CA, FL, GA, IN, LA, MS, NC, ND, SD, and TX, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  sclerotia up to 0.2cm in diameter are pinkish or orange but in some strains eventually turn brown^, (Warcup)
