HABITAT  Agrostis palustris (creeping bentgrass), A. stolonifera (redtop), Avena sativa (oats), Beta vulgaris (beet), Bromus tectorum (cheatgrass), Cucumis sativus (cucumber), Daucus carota (carrot), Festuca arundinacea (tall fescue), Glycine max (soybean), Helianthus annuus (common sunflower), Hordeum vulgare (barley), Oryza sativa (rice), Pennisetum glaucum (pearl millet), Phaseolus lunatus (lima bean), Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), Raphanus sativus (radish), Schizachyrium scoparium (little bluestem), Stenotaphrum secundatum (St. Augustine grass), Triticum aestivum (wheat), Zea mays (maize)^, (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 8.5-13 x 4-5.5 um, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, not repetitive, oblong or broadly elliptic with one side flattened, sometimes slightly constricted about the middle, with a rounded distal end and usually widest near the distal end, bearing a prominent truncate apiculus^; BASIDIA 4-spored, (14.5)19-29 x 5-8 um, "urniform or constricted about the middle, but was sometimes without marked constriction and was then more or less cylindrical", sterigmata curved, horn-like, 1/5 to 1/4 the length of the metabasidium, reaching 6 um long; fruiting consists of "wide (11 um) rhizoctonia-like basal hyphae giving rise to narrower, erect, hyaline hyphae which produce irregular cymose clusters of basidial initials that are characteristically involute, circinate, or even coiled" ("characteristically irregular and contorted hymenial branching"); hyphae lack clamp connections, (Warcup)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'coiled, curled away from an apex'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Warcup(1), Ginns(5)
471
FAMILY  Xenasmataceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Xenasma rimicola  (P. Karst.) Donk^  Fungus 27: 26. 1957 (as X. rimicolum);  == Corticium rimicola  P. Karst.;  Peniophora rimicola  (P. Karst.) Hoehn. & Litsch.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth, mainly on hardwoods, 2) a cartilaginous-gelatinous fruitbody that is colorless or bluish gray and under a lens pruinose, sometimes with fertile strands extending over the surface or at the margins, 3) spores that are broadly elliptic to obovate, colorless, and with small blunt warts in Melzer's reagent or cotton blue but nearly smooth in KOH, 4) basidia that are (2)4-spored, pleural (bifurcate at base), and cylindric to subclavate, 5) two types of cystidial elements: a) cystidia that are cylindric to slightly awl-shaped, thin-walled or basally thick-walled, the base often bifurcate, and b) smaller cystidioles that are few in number, cylindric or subclavate, and simple or capitate, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, conglutinate or the walls becoming gelatinized.^ | Although species names in Xenasma take the neuter ending, -cola refers to an inhabitant, and nouns do not agree with the gender of the genus. RANGE ^Xenasma rimicola has been found in BC, WA, OR, ON, PQ, MI, and MO, (Ginns), as well as Finland and Norway, (Hjortstam), and Brazil, France, and New Zealand, (Liberta).
FRUITING BODY  effused, thin, in section 0.002-0.005cm, closely adnate [firmly attached], consistency cartilaginous-gelatinous, drying to a semitransparent varnish-like film; when fresh colorless or bluish gray, sometimes yellowish in older parts, drying to whitish gray; under a lens pruinose; "sometimes with fertile strands extending over the surface or at the margins"^, (Liberta)
HABITAT  on deciduous wood^, (Hjortstam), Acer sp., (maple), Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Alnus sp. (alder), Fraxinus sp. (ash), Picea sp. (spruce), Populus sp., Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Rubus sp., Salix sp. (willow), Ulmus sp. (elm), Phellinus conchatus (polypore), (Ginns)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES (6.5)8.5-10.5 x (3.5)4.5-7 um, broadly elliptic to obovate, slightly depressed on one side with a lateral apiculus, colorless, wall finely asperulate, the asperulations evident in Melzer's reagent, disappearing in KOH^, BASIDIA cylindric to subclavate, "borne directly on the horizontal hyphae, the base bifurcate, very often obscure", 15-24(29.5) x 7-8 um, 2-4-spored, sterigmata 3-4.5 x 1.5 um, arcuate; CYSTIDIAL ELEMENTS of 2 types: 1) cystidia 50-125 x 10-15 um, cylindric to slightly subulate [awl-shaped], the base often bifurcate, wall thin in upper part, thickened in lower part, the thickened parts of the cystidia remaining as tubules in old specimens, 2) cystidioles 24-37 x 2.5-3.5 um, cylindric or subclavate, simple or capitate, the bulb at the apex 3-5 um wide; HYPHAE 1.5-2.5 um wide, parallel to the substrate, nodose-septate [septa with clamp connections], conglutinate or the walls becoming gelatinized, (Liberta), SPORES (8)10-12 x 5-8 um, broadly elliptic, nearly smooth in KOH, in Melzer's reagent and in cotton blue with small blunt warts; BASIDIA 12-15(20) x 6-7 um, subcylindric, pleural, generally with 4 sterigmata and a basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIAL ELEMENTS apparently of 2 types: 1) cystidia 70-130 um long or in some cases even longer, tubular, "thin-walled or basally with slight wall thickening or distinctly thick-walled", 2) cystidioles few, about 20-35 um long, subcapitate; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, (Hjortstam)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living in a fissure'
SIMILAR  Xenasma praeteritum (Jackson) Donk, found in ON, CT, IL, IN, differs mainly in the spores which are smaller and have warts that are easily observed also in KOH, (Hjortstam). Spores of X. praeteritum measure 5.5-9 x 4.5-7.5 um, (Liberta).
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Liberta(2), Ginns(5)
472
FAMILY  Xenasmataceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Xenasma tulasnelloideum  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Donk^  Fungus, Wageningen 27: 26. 1957;  == Phlebiella tulasnelloidea  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre;  == Corticium tulasnelloideum  Hoehn. & Litsch.;  == Xenasmatella tulasnelloidea  (Hoehn. & Litsch.) Oberw.;  Corticium incanum  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a waxy-gelatinous fruitbody that is grayish blue, grayish white, or even pale ochraceous, the surface smooth to uneven, the margin distinct to diffuse, 3) spores that are nearly round to elliptic, with a pronounced suprahilar depression, warted, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia that are short-cylindric and pleural, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Xenasma tulasnelloideum has been found in BC, OR, NS, ON, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, MA, MO, NC, NH, NJ, NY, OH, RI, and VT, (Ginns). Distribution includes Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hjortstam), and Switzerland and Asia (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, tightly attached, "forming thin, membranous-gelatinous patches" several centimeters to decimeters across, consistency "waxlike and gelatinous when fresh, crustose and hard when dry"; gray-white, bluish gray; somewhat uneven, generally weakly veined to reticulate but also +/- tuberculate; margin distinctly bounded to diffuse^, (Breitenbach), thin to moderately thick, about 0.004-0.005cm thick, resupinate, effused [spread out], closely adnate [firmly attached]; usually grayish blue, but also grayish white or even pale ochraceous; "smooth or under a strong lens porulose, thicker specimens often cracking"; margin abrupt, indeterminable [not clearly demarcated], (Hjortstam), "under a lens appearing waxy-pruinose or minutely porous-reticulate to occasionally raduloid", (Liberta), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on dead hardwood, "on the underside of trunks and branches still with bark and lying on the ground"; fall^, (Breitenbach), mostly on barkless hardwood, more rarely on coniferous wood such as Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), (Hjortstam), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Liquidambar, Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak); bark and wood of dead limbs; barkless wood, decayed wood and bark; vegetable debris, (Ginns), probably all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-6 x 3.5-5 um excluding warts, broadly elliptic-dacryoid [elliptic - tear-shaped], verrucose (ornamentation not soluble in KOH), inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 10-18 x 6.5-8 um, cylindric, pleural, without basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, 1-3.5 um wide, gelatinized, septa not observed (but according to the literature, septa are present), (Breitenbach), SPORES nearly round to elliptic, "adaxial side concave with a distinct suprahilar depression", warted, when fully developed usually 6-6.5(7) x 4.5(5) um, inamyloid; BASIDIA short-cylindric, pleural, generally 10-18 x 6-8 um, with 4 sterigmata and a basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, some hyphae parallel to substrate, 2-2.5 um, thin-walled, and rather straight, other hyphae intermingled, conglutinate and strongly gelatinized, often irregularly inflated, all hyphae with clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 3.5-6 x 3-6 um; HYPHAE mostly parallel to the substrate, nodose-septate, (1)1.5-2.5 um wide, "conglutinate or the walls becoming gelatinized", (Liberta)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like Tulasnella'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6) (as Phlebiella tulasnelloidea), Breitenbach(2)* (as Xenasmatella tulasnelloidea), Liberta(2), Ginns(5) (as Phlebiella tulasnelloidea), Buczacki(1)* (as Phlebiella tulasnelloidea)
473
FAMILY  Xenasmataceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Xenasmatella vaga  (Fr.) Stalpers^  Stud. Mycol. 40: 37. 1996;  Phlebia vaga  Fr.;  Phlebiella vaga  (Fr.) D.P. Rogers;  Trechispora vaga  (Fr.) Liberta;  Phlebiella sulphurea  (Pers.) Ginns & M.N.L. Lefebvre;  Corticium sulphureum  Pers.;  Hypochnus filamentosus  Burt;  Odontia tenuis  Peck;  Odontia fusca  Cooke & Ellis;  Grandinia tabacina  Cooke & Ellis;  Tomentella fumosa  (Fr.) Pilat
ENGLISH NAME(S)  yellow cobweb
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a soft, fibrous, cottony, often bumpy fruitbody that is granular and honey-yellow to brownish in the center and toward the margin increasingly filamentous and bright yellow, ending in whitish rhizomorphs, 3) a fruitbody that turns wine-red in KOH, 4) spores that are nearly round to elliptic, with dense short spines, inamyloid, and colorless, 5) pleural basidia, and 6) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, the subhymenial hyphae richly branched and sinuous, the subicular hyphae straight and often encrusted with crystals.^ RANGE ^Xenasmatella vaga has been found in BC, WA, ID, AB, MB, NB, NS, ON, PQ, AK, AL, AZ, CA, CO, IL, IN, MA, MD, MI, MN, MO, MT, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, TN, UT, VT, and WI, (Ginns). It is the most common species of the genus and widespread in Scandinavia (Hjortstam). Distribution also includes Switzerland and Asia (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, appressed tightly to substrate, forming filamentous to membranous patches 0.02-0.05cm thick and several centimeters to decimeters across, "consistency fibrous, cottony, soft"; "in the center granular, dull, honey-yellow to brownish, increasingly filamentous toward the margin, cottony, bright sulphur-yellow, and ending in fine, whitish, fanlike rhizomorphs, older fruitbodies often overgrown with branched, yellow rhizomorphs"; fruitbody turning wine-red in KOH^, (Breitenbach), resupinate, effused [spread out], easily detachable, "often large, smooth, colliculose to grandinioid or comprised of richly branched and anastomosing hyphal threads, often arranged in a fan-like manner", fragile to membranaceous; varying in color "but always with some shade of brown from chamois to deep umber", when fresh "usually with more yellowish colors, especially in sterile parts which can be sulphur-yellow"; margin abrupt or thinning out and then arachnoid [cobwebby] or fibrillose, usually of paler color; rhizomorphs "frequently occurring in the fruitbody and extending beyond the margin", (Hjortstam(6)), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  from conifer wood and hardwood^ (Hjortstam), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Arbutus (madrone), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juglans (walnut), Juniperus (juniper), Liquidambar, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); bark; moss-covered wood; rotten wood; branch; slash; logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on the undersides of dead branches and trunks of Fagus (beech) and other hardwoods and conifers (Larix among others), lying on the ground; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), summer to fall; also on other plant debris, (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5.5 x 3.5 um (excluding spines), elliptic, short-spined, inamyloid, colorless^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 13-22 x 5-6.5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA not seen; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-5 um wide, yellowish, in part encrusted, with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES (4.5)5-5.5(7) x 4-4.5 um, subglobose to elliptic, densely verruculose, inamyloid; BASIDIA subspherical to subclavate, sinuous, pleural, mainly 15-20 x 5-6 um, 4-spored, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, with clamp connections, thin-walled; subicular hyphae and rhizomorph hyphae 2-5 um wide, straight, "often provided with crystals and now and then with slightly ampulliform septa, slightly agglutinated", subhymenial hyphae 2-3 um wide, sinuous, richly branched, hyphae turning vinaceous red in KOH, (Hjortstam)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of sulphur', referring to yellow color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6) (as Phlebiella vaga), Breitenbach(2)* (as Trechispora vaga), Ginns(5) (as Phlebiella sulphurea), Buczacki(1)* (as Phlebiella sulphurea)
474
FAMILY  Xenasmataceae, Order Polyporales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Xenosperma ludibundum  (D.P. Rogers & Liberta) Julich^  as Oberw. ex Julich, Persoonia 10: 335. 1979;  == Xenasma ludibundum  D.P. Rogers & Liberta
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Xenosperma ludibundum is "recognized by its unique spores and basidia which bear only two large sterigmata" (Liberta). Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a fruitbody that is whitish, thin, firmly attached, forming an inconspicuous film that under a dissecting microscope appears pruinose, waxy-crustaceous, and gelatinous, 3) spores that are pyramidal, inamyloid, colorless, and prominently apiculate, 4) 2-spored basidia borne directly on the horizontal hyphae (bifurcate at the base), with long, fairly stout sterigmata, 5) hyphae that are parallel to the substrate, conglutinate or the walls becoming gelatinized, the septa with clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Xenosperma ludibundum has found in OR, MA, and RI, (Ginns). It has been reported from Denmark and Germany, (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  effused, thin, in section 0.002-0.003cm thick, closely adnate [firmly attached], forming an inconspicuous film over substrate; white; under a lens pruinose to thinly ceraceous-crustaceous, (Liberta), "thin and inconspicuous, hardly visible when dried, in the dissecting microscope looking finely pruinose, gelatinous, not separable from the substratum, reminding somewhat of a thin heterobasidiomycete"^, (Hjortstam), effused, closely adnate, up to 0.003cm thick, pruinose to ceraceous-crustaceous, spore-bearing surface even, whitish, (Julich)
HABITAT  on barkless hardwood^, (Hjortstam), on decayed wood of Chamaecyparis thyoides (Atlantic White-cedar), bark of Quercus sp. (oak), (Liberta)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 5-9 x 4.5-8 um, "turbinate with one central and four diagonally arranged tubercles about the periphery of the apex", inamyloid, colorless, prominently apiculate^; BASIDIA 2-spored, 6.5-10.5 x 6.5-7 um, cylindric to subclavate, "borne directly on the horizontal hyphae, the base bifurcate", sterigmata 7-10.5 x 2-2.5(3) um, stout; HYPHAE 1.5-3 um wide, parallel to the substrate, nodose-septate [septa with clamp connections], "conglutinate or the walls becoming gelatinized", (Liberta), SPORES about 8 um across, tetrahedral, thin-walled; BASIDIA 2-spored (rarely 4-spored), 8-10 x 6-7 um, pleural, sterigmata about 6-7 um long, with basal clamp connection; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-3 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections, basal hyphae few, mostly arranged in parallel fashion next to the substrate, slightly conglutinated, (Hjortstam), SPORES 5-9 x 4.5-8 um, pyramidal, colorless; BASIDIA 2-spored, 6.5-10.5 x 5-8 um, cylindric to subclavate, bifurcate at the base, sterigmata up to 10.5 um long; hyphae 1-3 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "ludibundus", which means "playful"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Liberta(2) (as Xenasma ludibundum), Julich(5), Ginns(5)
475
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Xylobolus frustulatus  (Pers.) P. Karst.^  Acta Soc. Fauna Fl. Fenn. 2: 40. 1881 [as X. frustulosus];  == Thelephora frustulata  Pers.;  Stereum frustulatum  Fr. [as S. frustulosum];  Stereum  frustulatum  (Pers.) Fuckel (superfluous combination)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  ceramic parchment
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, especially oak, rarely projecting outward from the substrate to form a shelf, 2) a reflexed to dimidiate part, that when present is dark brown, zoned, and bald, 3) a spore-bearing part of the fruitbody that is distinctly stratified, and soon cracked into small polygons, whitish or pale ochraceous in younger layers and dull to dark brown in older ones, 4) spores that are short-elliptic, smooth, amyloid, and colorless, 5) basidia that are 4-spored, sometimes with a few basal protuberances, 6) cystidial elements of 2 types: a) acanthocystidia or acanthophysoid hyphae, cylindric, obtuse to somewhat pointed, with protuberances along their length, numerous especially during non-fruiting time, colorless to brownish, thin-walled to thick-walled, and b) pseudocystidia that are rare, barely or not projecting, according to Hjortstam(6), but Julich(5) says cystidioles often present and sulfo-negative gloeocystidia rare, and 7) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae without clamp connections, thin-walled to thick-walled, vertically arranged, some with transitions to acanthocystidia and others, when present, with transitions to pseudocystidia.^ RANGE ^Xylobolus frustulatus has been found in OR, NS, ON, AL, AR, CT, DE, FL, GA, IA, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, MD, MN, MO, MS, NC, ND, NE, NJ, NY, OH, OK, PA, RI, SC, SD, TN, TX, VA, VT, WI, and WV, (Ginns), as well as Mexico (Lincoff), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hjortstam).
FRUITING BODY  perennial, mostly 0.1-0.2cm thick, sometimes considerably thicker, distinctly stratified into several layers, soon cracked into small, angular polygons (frustose), rarely reflexed to dimidiate at the margin; the upper surface of the reflexed or dimidiate part, when present, zoned and more or less bald and dark brown; spore-bearing surface pale ochraceous in younger layers (dull to deep brown in older ones), the surface smooth or under a dissecting microscope pilose from protruding acanthocystidia and hyphae^, (Hjortstam), "at first tuberculiform, attached by a narrow base, becoming confluent, strongly cracked", the spore-bearing surface "even to slightly tuberculate, pale buff to avellaneous", (Julich), can be larger than 10cm x 5cm, large irregular patches of small, polygonal, tile-like pieces, the pieces somewhat convex, whitish to pinkish buff, smooth, and finely powdered; cap when present 0.3-2cm wide, "in crowded, polygonal, crustlike plates, with downcurled or free margins", blackish, smooth; flesh 0.05-0.1cm thick, (Lincoff)
HABITAT  on debarked wood of Quercus (oak), "occurring on branches and trunks lying on the ground", more rarely on still attached branches; the sporulation is presumed to take place mostly in the summer as most specimens from fall and early spring are sterile, with the hymenium consisting only of acanthocystidia^, (Hjortstam), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Castanea (chestnut), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Pinus (pine) Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak); "on dead wood; logs and stumps, trunk; associated with a white rot or a white pocket rot", (Ginns), on dry, hard, oak logs; year-round, (Lincoff)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-5(5.5) x 3-3.2(3.5) um, short-elliptic, smooth, distinctly amyloid, "thin-walled or with a slight wall thickening"^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 25-30 x 4-5 um, "elongated clavate, smooth or with a few basal protuberances (acanthobasidia)"; CYSTIDIA of 2 types: 1) acanthocystidia, or acanthophysoid hyphae, numerous especially during the non-fruiting time, about 25-30 um and 4-5 um wide, 2) pseudocystidia, rare, "barely or not projecting above the basidia and acanthocystidia", thin-walled to moderately thick-walled; HYPHAE monomitic, "vertically arranged, short-celled and with transitions to acanthocystidia", about 3.5-5 um wide, sparsely branched, colorless to yellowish brown "or in older layers more strongly pigmented", "other hyphae (tramal hyphae) few or not always found", most easily observed in very thin sections, "vertically arranged, thin to moderately thick-walled, with transitions to pseudocystidia", grayish black in sulfovanillin, 3-5 um wide, all hyphae without clamp connections, (Hjortstam), SPORES 3.5-5.2 x 2.5-3(3.5) um, elliptic; BASIDIA 16-35 x 3.5-5 um, clavate to cylindric; CYSTIDIA absent; ACANTHOHYPHIDIA colorless to brownish, thin-walled to thick-walled; GLOEOCYSTIDIA rare, sulfo-negative; CYSTIDIOLES often present; GENERATIVE HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, colorless to yellowish; thin-walled to thick-walled; SKELETOID HYPHAE 4-6 um wide, yellowish to dark brown, walls up to 2 um thick; BASAL LAYER with hyphae parallel to the substrate, (Julich), SPORES 3.5-5 x 2.5-3 um, oval, smooth, colorless, (spore print white); CYSTIDIA 28-55 x 3.5-6.5 um, bottlebrush-like or prickle-pointed, abundant, (Lincoff)
NAME ORIGIN  from 'frustulum', Latin for 'small piece'
SIMILAR  Xylobolus subpileatus 1) is typically effused-reflexed, not consisting of numerous, small, confluent tubercles, 2) typically has true cystidia, and 3) has a basal layer with hyphae parallel to substrate, whereas X. frustulatus 1) has a fruitbody that is at first tuberculiform, attached by a narrow base, becoming confluent and strongly cracked, 2) has no true cystidia, and 3) has no basal layer with hyphae parallel to the substrate, (Julich). 
SOURCES  Hjortstam(6), Julich(5), Bourdot(1) (as Stereum frustulosum Fr.), Lincoff(2)*, Ginns(5)
476
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Xylobolus subpileatus  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Boidin^  Rev. Mycol. (Paris) 23: 341. 1958;  == Stereum subpileatum  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  Stereum frustulatum var. subpileatum  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) A.L. Welden;  Stereum insigne  Bres.;  Stereum sepium  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate form or more typically bent outwards to form shelf-like cap, generally on hardwood, especially oak, 2) a fruitbody that is relatively thick and consistency corky, drying hard, 3) a shelf-like cap, when present, that projects 1-6cm, the upper surface pale to dark brown, tomentose, and concentrically grooved, 4) a spore-bearing surface that is light buff to ochraceous, even or slightly pleated, sometimes cracked, 5) spores that are elliptic, smooth, amyloid, and colorless, 6) has up to three types of cystidioid elements: a) true cystidia typically present, colorless to yellowish brown, thick-walled, often somewhat encrusted, b) acanthohyphidia cylindric with protuberances, thin-walled to thick-walled, sometimes rare, and c) cystidioles sometimes present, and 7) generative hyphae that are colorless to yellowish, with thin or thickened walls, and skeletoid hyphae that are yellowish to dark brown, with thick walls.^ RANGE ^Xylobolus subpileatus has been found in OR, NS, ON, AL, AR, DE, FL, GA, IA, IL, KY, LA, MD, MO, MS, NC, NJ, NY, OH, PA, SC, TN, TX, and VA, (Ginns).
FRUITING BODY  perennial, resupinate or effuso-reflexed [bent outward to form shelf-like cap], "sometimes laterally confluent and attached by the umbos", consistency "thick, corky, drying rigid, very hard", in section 0.08-0.12cm thick; when shelf-like cap present projecting 1-6cm, upper surface cinnamon brown, concentrically sulcate [grooved], somewhat zonate, tomentose, the margin entire; spore-bearing surface light buff, even, (Burt), "typically effused-reflexed, not consisting of numerous small confluent tubercles", abhymenial surface pale to dark brown, tomentose to felty; spore-bearing surface light buff to ochraceous, even or slightly plicate [pleated], sometimes cracked, (Julich)
HABITAT  Castanea (chestnut), Celtis occidentalis (Hackberry), Fagus (beech), Liquidambar sp., Malus, Platanus (sycamore), Quercus (oak), Taxodium (baldcypress), Ulmus (elm); "on bark; old logs; underside of rotten log; trunks; dead stump"^, (Ginns), on several species of Quercus (oak), (Burt)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5 x 3 um, smooth, colorless^; CYSTIDIA cylindric, incrusted, 30-36 x 7 um, becoming colored where buried in older zones of hymenium, at first sometimes slightly aculeate; IN SECTION 800-1200 um thick, "with the intermediate layer bordered and connected with the tomentum by a denser and darker crust and bearing on the opposite side a hymenial layer which becomes multizonate", hyphae of intermediate layer 3-3.5 um wide, densely and longitudinally arranged, colored, thick-walled, stiff, (Burt), SPORES 4-4.8 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, by generic description amyloid; BASIDIA 18-30 x 3.5-5 um, clavate to cylindric; CYSTIDIA typically present, colorless to yellowish brown, thick-walled, often somewhat encrusted; ACANTHOHYPHIDIA colorless to yellowish, thin-walled to thick-walled, sometimes rare; CYSTIDIOLES sometimes present; GENERATIVE HYPHAE 3-5 um wide, colorless to yellowish, with thin or thickened walls, according to generic description clamp connections would be absent or rare; SKELETOID HYPHAE 4-7 um wide, yellowish to dark brown, walls up to 3 um thick, (Julich)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'somewhat pileate'
SIMILAR  Xylobolus frustulatus 1) has a fruitbody that is at first tuberculiform, attached by a narrow base, becoming confluent, and strongly cracked, 2) lacks true cystidia, and 3) lacks a basal layer with hyphae parallel to the substrate, whereas X. subpileatus 1) is typically effused-reflexed, not consisting of numerous, small, confluent tubercles, 2) typically has true cystidia, and 3) has a basal layer with hyphae parallel to the substrate, (Julich).
SOURCES  Burt(2) (as Stereum subpileatum), Julich(5), Ginns(5)
477
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Xylodon brevisetus  (P. Karst.) Hjortstam & Ryvarden^  Syn. Fung. (Oslo) 26: 35. 2009;  == Hyphodontia breviseta  (P. Karst.) J. Erikss.  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 104. 1958;  == Kneiffia breviseta  P. Karst.;  == Grandinia breviseta  (P. Karst.) Julich;  = Odontia crustula  L.W. Mill.;  = Odontia lactea  P. Karst. sensu Aucts.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on wood, 2) a whitish to yellowish fruitbody with the surface floccose when young, becoming irregularly odontioid (without much bare hymenium showing) with conic spines that are apically bristled under a 20x lens from projecting hyphae, the margin indeterminately thinning out, more bounded when old, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) cystidia of 2 types: a) hypha-like, projecting, with an apical head covered with a cap of resinous matter, and b) gloeocystidia, enclosed, thick-walled, and long cylindric but usually with several constrictions or even torulose, 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae somewhat thick-walled, with clamp connections, in mature fruitbodies the aculeal hyphae with star-like crystals, and 6) often when mature and old, specimens infected with a hyphomycete that has pale brown hyphae and fusiform, pale brown conidia.^ RANGE ^Xylodon breviseta has been found in BC, AB, NB, NF, NS, AR, AZ, CO, IA, MN, NC, NM, TN, and VA, (Ginns), BC, MT, Finland, Germany, Norway, Slovakia, Sweden, Tanzania, Turkey, and China, (Langer), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Denmark (common in Scandinavia), (Eriksson).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], thin, consistency when young "very soft and easily squeezed"; "at first white or whitish, later argillaceous or pale yellowish", when postmature ochraceous or finally pale brownish when infected by a parasitic hyphomycete; surface at first porose-reticulate under a 50x lens, then furfuraceous and when mature irregularly odontioid with conic aculei [spines] that are apically pilose from projecting hyphae; corticioid parts, when visible between the spines, porose; "margin indeterminately thinning out"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, attached tightly, forming thin, crustose patches several centimeters to decimeters across; white when young, later cream to yellowish; "floccose when young, then with dense fine warts to slightly odontioid", "spines ciliate with a fine fringe" under a 20x lens; subiculum between spines "barely visible or, if so, then not smooth but open and porous"; "margin floccose and diffuse when young, distinctly bounded when old", (Breitenbach), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on bark or lignum of decayed conifer wood, less often on hardwood^, in such cases in conifer forests mixed with hardwoods, e.g. Salix (willow) and Betula (birch); "mostly on lying logs but is also often collected on slash, dead branches etc. on the ground", (Eriksson), on dead wood of conifers, according to the literature also on hardwoods; typically on dead but still attached branches, "as well as dead, standing trunks"; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Arbutus (madrone), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Mortonia scabrella (sandpaper bush), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Rhododendron, Thuja; barkless wood and bark; "moss-covered wood and bark; twig; branch; tree base; stump; exposed root; uprooted bottom; log; associated with a white rot", (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4-5 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, smooth, thin-walled, containing one large droplet or sometimes a few smaller droplets^; BASIDIA 4-spored, 14-18 x 3-5 um, at first clavate, then subcylindric, "usually with a median suburniform constriction", containing several oil droplets, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIAL ORGANS of 2 types: 1) numerous sterile hyphal ends in the hymenium, projecting, not well differentiated (hypha-like), the apical head covered with a cap of resinous matter, and 2) gloeocystidia 40-60 x 4-5 um, (in some cases up to 125 um long), enclosed, thin-walled, long-cylindric but usually with several constrictions, in extreme cases totally torulose; HYPHAE monomitic, 2.5-3 um wide, distinct, somewhat thick-walled, "richly branched and intertwined into an open texture", clamp connections at all septa, "in mature fruitbodies aculeal hyphae with numerous, attached, starlike, composed crystals", young hyphae cyanophilic, "older ones slightly or not so"; often when mature and old, specimens "are infected by a Hyphomycete with pale brown hyphae and fusiform, pale brown conidia, developed from small teeth in the apical part of the conidiophores", (Eriksson), SPORES 4-5 x 2.5-3.5 um, elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets; BASIDIA 4-spored, 18-23 x 3.5-4.5 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIAL ORGANS of 2 types: 1) cystidia-like hyphae 25-55 x 2.5-4 um, with capitate ends and sometimes with resinous secretion, smooth, capitate ends up to 5 um across, and 2) moniliform cystidia, 35-55 x 3-5 um, smooth, +/- thick-walled; HYPHAE monomitic, exserted hyphae of the spines 2.5-4 um wide, thin-walled, encrusted with crystals, hyphae of the subhymenium 2.5-3.5 um wide, branched, +/- thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with short bristles'
SIMILAR  Hyphodontia granulosa has somewhat larger spores, 5-6.5 x 4-5 um, and a different arrangement of spines: as a rule these are +/- far apart in H. granulosa and the smooth hymenium remains clearly visible between them, whereas they are close together in X. breviseta so that the hymenium is almost covered up, (Breitenbach). H. granulosa may be difficult to distinguish, but it is normally separable with the naked eye, as in H. granulosa the surface is smooth with distinct, separate spines, whereas X. breviseta is more furfuraceous; microscopically, differences are small, but the spores of H. granulosa are slightly larger and the texture denser with less distinct hyphae, and the hyphomycete has not been observed in H. granulosa, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hyphodontia), Breitenbach(2)* (as Grandinia breviseta), Ginns(5) (as Hyphodontia), Langer(1) (as Hyphodontia), Buczacki(1)* (as Hyphodontia)
478
FAMILY  Schizoporaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Xylodon sambuci  (Pers.) Tura, Zmitr., Wasser & Spirin^  Biodiversity of Cyanoprocaryotes, Algae and Fungi of Israel (Ruggel): 221 (2011);  == Hyphodontia sambuci  (Pers.) J. Erikss.  Symb. Bot. Upsal. 16(1): 104. 1958;  == Grandinia sambuci  (Pers.) Julich;  Lyomyces sambuci  (Pers.) P. Karst.;  == Rogersella sambuci  (Pers.) Liberta & A.J. Navas;  == Hyphoderma sambuci  (Pers.) Julich  Persoonia 8: 80 1974;  == Thelephora sambuci  Pers.;  == Hypochnus sambuci  (Pers.) Sacc.;  == Peniophora sambuci  (Pers.) Burt;  = Corticium serum  (Pers.) Fr.;  = Peniophora thujae  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) resupinate growth on hardwood, especially elderberry and other shrubs, less often on conifer wood, 2) a somewhat waxy fruitbody appearing like white paint, smooth or (when vigorously growing) tuberculate, the margin when young thinning out, in the periphery pruinose, when mature more distinct, 3) spores that are elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, becoming slightly thick-walled, and then somewhat cyanophilic, 4) cystidial elements that are long-cylindric, often with apical resinous encrustation and attached crystals along the length, with 1-2 clamped septa, and 5) a monomitic hyphal system, the hyphae with clamp connections, richly branched, with lots of crystals in the texture especially when old.^ | The Breitenbach(2) description is for Lyomyces sambuci (Pers.) Karst.: they give Hyphodontia sambuci (Pers.) Erikss. and Hyphoderma sambuci (Pers.) Jul. as synonyms. |The online Species Fungorum, accessed February 18, 2022, listed the current names a Xylodon sambuci, but MycoBank, accessed the same day, listed the current name as Lyomyces sambuci. RANGE ^Xylodon sambuci has been found in BC, WA, ID, MB, NS, ON, PQ, AR, AZ, CA, CO, GA, IL, KS, LA, MA, ME, MI, MN, MO, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, TX, VA, and VT, (Ginns). It has been found in MB, ON, WI, Argentina, Austria, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Italy, Spain, Sweden, Yugoslavia, Kenya, Reunion, Tanzania, China, Iran, Japan, Nepal, and Taiwan, (Langer). It is common in south Scandinavia but occurs in northern parts as well, (Eriksson). It also occurs in Switzerland (Breitenbach).
FRUITING BODY  resupinate, effused [spread out], adnate [firmly attached], subceraceous [somewhat waxy] when alive and moist, "when dried of chalky consistency at least in old states", about 0.01-0.03cm thick, at first porous under 50x lens, then continuous, finally more or less cracked in dry weather; "creamish white or more often pure white" (in old herbarium collections yellowish); "smooth or in vigorously growing specimens more or less tuberculate"; "margin in young fruitbodies thinning out, in the periphery pruinose, when mature mostly determinate"^, (Eriksson), resupinate, attached tightly, forming expanses several centimeters to decimeters across, thin and crustose, white to slightly cream-colored, resembling white paint or whitewash; "tuberculate to slightly verrucose", "dull, somewhat fissured when dry"; margin +/- thinning out to distinctly bounded, (Breitenbach), broadly effused, soft, adnate; smooth, pellicular, minutely farinose under 30x lens; subiculum white, byssoid [cottony], (Gilbertson), spore deposit white (Buczacki)
HABITAT  on hardwood of all sorts but most often in hedges, garden bushes, thickets, etc.: even though not restricted to Sambucus (elderberry), occurs with striking regularity on that substrate; rare on conifers^ in Scandinavia, (Eriksson), on dead hardwoods, especially shrubs, but usually on attached branches and trunks, with and without bark, of Sambucus nigra (Black Elderberry); throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Carex (sedge), Chrysanthemum, Cytisus (broom), Fouquieria splendens (Ocotillo), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Juniperus (juniper), Maclura (Osage Orange), Morus (mulberry), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prosopis (mesquite), Quercus (oak), Robinia (locust), Salix (willow), Sambucus callicarpa (Coast Red Elderberry), Sambucus glauca (Blue Elderberry), Sambucus racemosa (Red Elderberry), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), Typha (cat-tail); bark and wood; dead branches; trunks; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), associated with a white rot of dead branches of mesquite, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  SPORES 4.5-6(7) x (3)3.5-4(4.5) um (in var. angustispora Parmasto 5-7 x 2.8-3.5(4) um), elliptic, smooth, thin-walled at first, "when mature with somewhat thickened walls" and then somewhat cyanophilic, with 1-2 droplets, inamyloid^; BASIDIA at first subclavate, then subcylindric with suburniform constriction, 20-30(35) x 4-5 um, normally 4-spored, with basal clamp connection; CYSTIDIA "or rather cystidial elements frequent in the hymenium, but variable, in single cases like sterile, capitate or tapering hyphal ends, in others more developed" and could be regarded as cystidioles or even cystidia, 20-50 x 3.5-5 um, "often with apical resinous encrustation and with attached composed crystals", in some specimens small and few, and in other conspicuous and frequent; HYPHAE monomitic, 3-4(5) um wide, richly branched, with clamp connections, acyanophilic or in young hyphae slightly cyanophilic, "in the subiculum loosely and irregularly interwoven, in the thickening subhymenium thinner and densely united with predominantly vertical hyphal direction"; "lots of crystals in the texture", especially in old fruitbodies - "the snow-white color and the chalky consistency of such fruitbodies depend in the main on the crystal content", (Eriksson), SPORES 5-6 x 3.5-4 um, oval, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with 1-3 droplets, slightly thick-walled and cyanophilic; BASIDIA 4-spored, 20-25 x 3.5-4.5 um, suburniform, with basal clamp connection; LEPTOCYSTIDIA 30-50 x 4-5 um, cylindric, capitate, with 1-2 clamped septa, usually encrusted with rather large crystals; HYPHAE monomitic, 2-5 um wide, usually encrusted with crystals, septa with clamp connections, (Breitenbach), SPORES 6-7 x 3.5-4.5 um, cylindric-elliptic to broadly elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; BASIDIA 4-spored, 15-20 x 6-7 um, clavate, with median constriction; CYSTIDIA frequent, acicular or with swollen tips, projecting slightly, thin-walled, not encrusted; HYPHAE monomitic, subicular hyphae 2-4 um wide, with occasional branching, thin-walled, with abundant clamp connections, with abundant crystalline material, (Gilbertson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Sambucus' (elder, one of its hosts)
SIMILAR  While similar to Hyphodontia species in spore shape, basidia, and cystidioid elements, Xylodon sambuci is different from most Hyphodontia species in 1) the consistency of the fruitbody, which is more ceraceous [waxy], not so fibrous as Hyphodontia, 2) more thin-walled and somewhat wider hyphae, staining only slightly in cotton-blue, and 3) a thickening spore wall that is somewhat cyanophilic, (Eriksson).
SOURCES  Eriksson(4) (as Hyphoderma sambuci), Breitenbach(2)* (as Lyomyces sambuci), Ginns(5) (as Hyphoderma sambuci), Langer(1) (as Hyphodontia sambuci), Gilbertson(2) (as Hyphodontia sambuci), Buczacki(1)* (as Hyphodontia sambuci)
